title: GLOBAL CROSSING STOCK SOARS ON GRACE PERIOD FOR DEBT
description: Shares of Global Crossing Ltd. rose nearly 38 percent yesterday after the company, a fiber optic network operator, said it had received more time from bank lenders to meet borrowing conditions. The stock rose 23 cents, to 84 cents a share. The company's agreement with its lenders covers $2.25 billion of debt with a group of banks led by J. P. Morgan Chase and Citibank. Effective Friday, the agreement waives requirements to maintain certain financial ratios and other terms through Feb. 13, Global Crossing said. Global Crossing had $11 billion in debt and $2 billion in cash as of Sept. 30.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Compulsory Military Service Ends

The change also ends the community service program, an alternative for conscientious objectors, but it does not pardon those who refused to perform any national service. Three men who violated the old law are still serving prison sentences for desertion. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Recession Deepens
description: Singapore's recession deepened in the fourth quarter as the slump in manufacturing extended to services, the prime minister, Goh Chok Tong, said. Gross domestic product shrank 7 percent from a year earlier, after falling 5.6 percent in the third quarter, the prime minister said in a New Year's message to Singaporeans. The nation is in its worst recession in 37 years. ''The outlook for next year depends on developments outside Singapore, especially the U.S. economy, the global electronics industry and the war against terrorism,'' the prime minister said.

title: ECHOSTAR IS ORDERED TO CARRY DISNEY CHANNELS
description: A federal district court judge granted a temporary restraining order against the satellite operator EchoStar Communications, which had threatened to drop the ABC Family channel because of poor ratings, the Walt Disney Company said yesterday. EchoStar planned to drop the Family channel and ESPN Classic at midnight yesterday because it did not have enough capacity. A hearing is expected on Jan. 10 when the order expires. The two companies have been negotiating over the Family channel since October, said Disney's president, Bob Iger. It was then that Disney bought the channel, called Fox Family, from the News Corporation and Saban Entertainment for $5.2 billion. But in recent talks with EchoStar, Mr. Iger said, ''We felt their intention to negotiate was not as real as expressed.'' The tussle comes at an awkward time for EchoStar, which recently said it would merge with Hughes Electronics, which is controlled by General Motors and owns DirecTV, making it the dominant American satellite operator. ''EchoStar stands firm in its belief that it has the right to discontinue broadcasting ABC Family,'' said Judianne Atencio, an EchoStar spokeswoman. Laura M. Holson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Travelers Insurance Sued Over Attack

Silverstein, who paid $3.2 billion for the lease on the World Trade Center in July, has broadened his battle to collect $7.1 billion in insurance claims for the Sept. 11 destruction. Silverstein Properties Inc. sued the Travelers Indemnity Company in federal court in Manhattan on Friday, and sought permission to expand its case against the Swiss Reinsurance Company, the lead insurer, to 19 other insurers. Mr. Silverstein argues that he is entitled to two payments of $3.55 billion for two separate attacks. The insurers argue that the events of Sept. 11 represent one attack. Representatives of Travelers and Swiss Re would not comment on the lawsuit.

title: A City That Knows Snow
description: Lake Erie usually rides peacefully just beyond the low beaches and headlands at the western rim of the state of New York. But now and then -- most memorably in 1977 -- the lake seems to rise in a whirlwind of snow, obliterating Buffalo and the surrounding cities and towns, utterly silencing the countryside, except for the howling among the trees and the rooflines. In the 1977 blizzard, which began on Jan. 28, not all that much snow fell. But high winds seemed to carry the entire snow load of Lake Erie, which was frozen at the time, into the streets of Buffalo, creating a deep, natural impasto that didn't wear away until late spring.

title: Sykora Wants His Game to Get Well, Too

But as he twirled a stick absent-mindedly, what he could not assure anyone was whether it would mark a return to the form that has been missing this season.

title: Here Comes the Euro
description: As of today, the same coins and banknotes can be used to buy a cup of coffee and the morning paper in Amsterdam, Lisbon, Helsinki, Naples, Dublin and Dresden. The franc, mark, lira and other currencies are disappearing, vanquished by the euro. Nothing quite like this changeover has ever taken place. If all goes according to plan, some $600 billion worth of newly minted euros will enter into circulation today at every bank and retail establishment from the southwestern corner of Portugal, where the Atlantic meets the Mediterranean, to Finland's northernmost tundra. Over the next two months, the euro will displace the traditional currencies used by 300 million people in 12 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, FRANK
description: WEXLER-Frank. Of Franklin Square, NY and Pompano Beach, FL. Age 89, December 30, 2001. Much beloved husband of Toby for 65 wonderful years. Devoted father/father-in-law of Stephen and Vicky Wexler and Amy and Robert Heller. Proud grandfather of David and Pamela Heller, Peter, Ronnie, Jennifer, Oren and Sharon Wexler, and Erik Hartog. Dear brother of Estelle Abelson. A gifted educator and leader, he was deeply committed to family, community and the Jewish people. He served for many years as principal of Woodrow Wilson High School in New York City and was the first principal of its successor, August Martin High School. He was founding President of The Jewish Community Center of West Hempstead and its honorary President for over five decades. He was also principal of the religious school of Temple Isaiah in Queens for 25 years. In retirement, he served as President of The Retired School Supervisors and Administrators Association in Florida. Services will be held at The Jewish Community Center of West Hempstead at 10:30 AM on Tuesday, January 1, 2002. In lieu of flowers, the family ask that contributions be made to The Wexler Endowment Fund, Jewish Community Center of West Hempstead, 711 Dogwood Ave., West Hempstead, NY 11552.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLVIN, ELINOR
description: COLVIN-Elinor. On Sunday, December 30, 2001. Born on February 24, 1944. Beloved wife of Stephen B. Colvin, M.D., devoted, loving and caring mother of Laurel Col vin, RN, NP, and Heather Colvin, M.D., cherished grandmother of Julia, beloved sister of Arlene Cheiken and daughter of the late Naomi and Jack Greneman. Ms. Colvin was a graduate of Washington Square College of Arts and Science of New York University and a former elementary school teacher in New York City. Contributions in her memory can be made to either the Elinor Colvin Memorial Scholarship at New York University School of Medicine, C/O Stephen B. Colvin, M.D., NYU Medical Center, 530 First Avenue, Suite 9V, NY, NY 10016, or to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 30 West 26th Street, New York, New York 10010.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXELROD, HARRIET (HONEY)
description: AXELROD-Harriet (Honey). Of Monroe Township, NJ, died December 29, 2001, peacefully at her winter residence at the Cascades in Boynton Beach, Florida, at the age of 83. Cherished wife of Maurice Axelrod, loving mother of Paul Axelrod & Susan P. Aguado, grandmother of David and Peter Aguado, & sister of Sue Spielman, loving aunt to her nieces and nephews and devoted friend to all who knew her. Honey was the president of B'nai B'rith Women of District 3, composed of 3 states on the Northeast coast. While serving as president of BBW, she was on the executive board of the AntiDefamation League. This was a position she held unti the present. Honey and her husband Maurice founded a scholarship fund in New Jersey to promote teaching excellence in the fields of Holocaust studies & helping people of all races and faiths to better live together. Honey is an Endowed Lion of Judah and has been an active participant in the Women's Division of the Jewish Federation of Greater Middlesex County. Honey and Maurice also established the Honey and Maurice Axelrod Philanthropic Fund at the Jewish Federation of Greater Middlesex County. To continue their efforts, donations in her loving memory should be made to: The Honey And Maurice Axelrod Philanthropic Fund, C/O The Jewish Federation of Greater Middlesex County, 230 Old Bridge Turnpike, South River, NJ 08882. Funeral services at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah in Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ at 11:45 on Wednesday.

title: ADVENT, A SOFTWARE MAKER, BUYS KINEXUS FOR $68 MILLION
description: Advent Software Inc., a maker of software to automate securities trade orders, agreed to buy the closely held Kinexus for about $68.5 million. Kinexus provides reports to financial advisers for wealthy investors. The company's customers include J. P. Morgan Chase, Merrill Lynch and Wachovia. Advent, which is based in San Francisco, expects to incur costs of about $2.5 million related to the acquisition, which should add about $20 million in revenue in 2002.

title: They All Took the Oath. One Took a Bus.; Inaugural Styles Reflect Mayoral Personalities
description: On New Year's Day in 1910, William J. Gaynor walked to City Hall from his home in Brooklyn, crossing the Brooklyn Bridge to formally take office as mayor of New York City. More than 1,500 people attended, but the inaugural festivities were so spare that by midafternoon the mayor was out looking for a restaurant for lunch and, finding none open on the holiday, he went home to Brooklyn to eat.

title: 2 Computer Giants Hope to Avoid Pitfalls of Past Mergers
description: In the dry language of business, it does not sound like much -- ''integration risk.'' But it represents the greatest single doubt that surrounds the merger plan of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer, and the biggest obstacle to winning shareholder approval for the deal.

title: POLYMER DEFAULTS ON LOANS AND EXPLORES ITS OPTIONS
description: The Polymer Group, which laid off 600 workers last month, said yesterday that it defaulted on loans and that its lenders planned to block the company from paying $17.8 million to bondholders due tomorrow. Polymer, which makes fabrics used in diapers and surgical products, said it was ''continuing to explore various financial restructuring alternatives with third parties.'' It has hired an investment banking firm, Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, for assistance. The company, based in North Charleston, S.C., said its bank lenders had given it more time to repay the full amount of the loans.

title: Notre Dame Will Name Willingham
description: Tyrone Willingham is leaving Stanford to accept a six-year contract as head coach of Notre Dame's legendary football program, officials at both universities said yesterday. Willingham will not only be the first black to hold one of the most coveted jobs in college sports, he will also be the first black head coach in any sport at Notre Dame.

The dishes are appropriate to the season, even appealing on the surface, but not entirely satisfying.

title: Lighting the New Year
description: New Year's Day has a way of stealing down upon us, coming in the shadow of the Christmas week and its own scintillating eve. If you celebrated at midnight last night, it was easy, if a little illusory, to think of the festivities as a gesture of dismissal, a warding off of the old year and its associated evils. And yet it's hard to feel, this morning, as if this were really the beginning of a new chapter. Some people are so keenly sensitive to beginnings and endings that on New Year's Day they can almost hear the rustle of a colossal page being turned, like the opening of some Selznick version of Dickens. ''I am born,'' says the infant New Year, and off we go, headlong into January. The rest of us are only too conscious of how closely the first Wednesday of the new year is interwoven with the last Monday of the old year, working days both.

title: IONICS SELLS WATER COMPANY TO NESTL FOR $220 MILLION
description: Ionics Inc., a water-purification and treatment company, said yesterday that it sold its Aqua Cool Pure Bottled Water operations to Nestl's Perrier-Vittel unit for $220 million. The final price is subject to adjustment based on the number of customers and the working capital levels, with $10 million of the proceeds to be held in escrow, Ionics said. Aqua Cool water is delivered to offices and homes in the United States, Britain and France, generating more than $70 million a year in sales, Ionics said. Nestl is based in Vevey, Switzerland, and Ionics in Watertown, Mass.

title: Indian Official Calls Arrests By Pakistan 'Step Forward'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWRING, DOUGLAS BONNER, ESQ.
description: BOWRING-Douglas Bonner, Esq. Of Edgartown, Massachusetts and Atlanta, Georgia died December 30, 2001. He was born on Staten Island, New York on August 10, 1919 the son of Charles Warren Bowring & Amy Bonner Bowring. A graduate of St. George's School, Newport, Rhode Island, Princeton University and Harvard Law School, he went on to serve in the Air Force during World War II. He retired as a partner in the New York Admiralty Law firm of Haight Gardner Poore and Haven. He belonged to the Mid Ocean Club Bermuda, Edgartown Yacht Club, Edgartown Reading Room, Edgartown Golf Club, Princeton Club of New York and Harvard Club of Boston. He was an active member of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown having served on the vestry and several search committees. He was an avid supporter of the art and academic world. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth Mitchell Bowring; two daughters, Sally Joy Andersson of Zion, Illinois and Lisa Douglas Bowring of Carnelian Bay, California & 4 grandchildren, Raina Andersson Hodgson, April Andersson, Nathaniel Sargent and Benjamin Sargent. Memorial services will be held at St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Atlanta on January 2, 2002 at 4:00 P.M. and in Edgartown, MA. in May 2002. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Edgartown, Massa chusetts 02539.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTERBERG, SAMUEL JAY
description: WINTERBERG-Samuel Jay, 98. A Larchmont, NY resident for 59 years, died at his home on December 29, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Mary S. Winterberg, he is survived by his daughters Marla W. Frankel and Judie W. Cohen, four grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. A civil engineer, he was a graduate of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art and remained a life member of both the Second Century Society and the Golden Legion. He was also a life member of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers and the American Society of Civil Engineers and the Moles. Notable career projects included the Throgs Neck Bridge and the Empire State Plaza in Albany. An avid sailor, he served The Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, NY as a member of the Board of Governors from 1960 to 1975 and as its president from 1971-1975. A memorial service will be held on Friday, January 4, 2002 at noon at Congregation Emanu-el of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art.

They said future support would go only to groups with local roots that are not part of the Islamic holy war movement that has its most notorious expression in Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda.

title: Diversity and Scholar Are Honored
description: PAUL LAUTER, a professor of literature at Trinity College in Hartford, has won the 2001 Hubbell Award, which is given by the Modern Language Association to a scholar in American literature for lifetime accomplishment. Dr. Lauter, 69, was president of the American Studies Association in 1993 and a founder, editor and treasurer of the Feminist Press. His most recent work is ''From Walden Pond to Jurassic Park'' (Duke University Press). Dr. Lauter has sought to create a greater diversity of authors in the canon of American literature, and he noted that receiving the award ''signifies the widespread acceptance of the change in understanding of what American literature is.'' Peter Valdina

title: Inaugural Shivers
description: Some people do not easily get cold. But few could escape the chilly winds in City Hall Park. Wynton Marsalis performed ''America the Beautiful'' on his trumpet, but first he fluttered his lips and warmed his fingers quite a bit. Mr. Thompson momentarily lost his place in his speech, and blamed his stiffening fingers for being unable to turn the pages in the appropriate order. Ditto for Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum, who sniffled as she spoke. Those seated in the audience huddled under gray blankets, often shuffling their feet to warm them. Those who stood -- reporters, photographers, police officers and random others -- blew on their fingers, rubbed their arms madly and jumped wildly, movements that seemed fitting when Willie Coln began to play salsa. What were Mr. Bloomberg's daughters, Emma and Georgina, thinking, sitting up on the stage with their father wearing no gloves? Certainly their mother, Susan Bloomberg, who donned simple black gloves, would have urged them otherwise.

Each side in the dispute -- the Martha Graham Trust and the Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance -- is planning a performance for April 18 to commemorate the 76th anniversary of Graham's first formal concert, and each program is expected to include her dances as well as work by other choreographers.

title: Meet Eisenstein: Punker, Misfit and Gay Renegade
description: If the seminal Russian filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein had physically matched the style of his monumental films ''Alexander Nevsky'' and ''Ivan the Terrible,'' he would have been a bearded, eagle-eyed titan radiating the thunderous authority of a cultural patriarch. But the image that comes across in the Canadian director Renny Bartlett's impressionistic film biography ''Eisenstein'' (and confirmed by old photographs) is much the opposite. He is a frizzy-haired nose-thumbing avant-gardist. Homosexually inclined (although married), he fit the prototype of the artist as social misfit and compulsive contrarian.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Dept. Sets New Rules On Recovery
description: The Fire Department has banned fire companies from rushing to ground zero when a firefighter's remains are found. Firefighters had developed an informal policy of going to the site in keeping with the tradition in which firefighters carry their fallen brethren from the scene of a disaster. In explaining the new policy, reported yesterday in The Daily News, Deputy Commissioner Francis X. Gribbon said the department was seeking to maintain order. ''We are trying to keep an official notification process, where a body is removed respectfully by those who are at the site,'' he said.

Memorial services will be held at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, Scarsdale, New York on Friday, January 4, at 1 PM. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Killed In Hit-and-Run
description: A Queens man was charged yesterday with leaving the scene of an accident after the police said he struck and killed a 60-year-old woman in Jackson Heights, Queens. Officer Cheryl Cox, a police spokeswoman, said that the man, Loon Gustavo, 21, was arrested after he drove his Ford Taurus away from the scene of the incident, which occurred at 10:30 a.m. on Northern Boulevard at 71st Street. The police did not release the name of the victim, who was walking across Northern Boulevard when she was struck. She was pronounced dead on arrival at Elmhurst Hospital Center. Thomas J. Lueck

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Mounties Under A Cloud
description: Senior members of Canada's parliamentary opposition said the ruling Liberal Party was politicizing the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, known as the R.C.M.P. The National Post reported that members of Parliament representing three opposition groups said recent incidents had created the perception, if not the reality, that the R.C.M.P., Canada's equivalent of the F.B.I., had become too closely tied to the government. A judicial commission recently concluded that officials in Prime Minister Jean Chrtien's office had improperly influenced police actions in a crackdown on demonstrators at an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit held in Vancouver in 1997. The deputy prime minister, Herbert Gray, rejected the allegations, saying that the R.C.M.P. remained free of political interference. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Corrections

After experimenting, he selected an organic beefsteak to be called the Julia Child. The seeds are $4.50 a pack from www.tomatofest.com, with 30 cents going to the American Institute of Wine and Food, which Mrs. Child helped found.

title: A Back Story and a Happy Ending
description: AT the Los Angeles County Fair wine tastings a few years back, we judges would tear through 100 cabernets in the morning, take a break, and come back for 90 zinfandels in the afternoon. That's a good five hours in an ugly room, sniffing, tasting and scribbling notes. When it was over, we were, let me tell you, exhausted.

description: SEARS-Robert L. On December 30, 2001. Loved husband of the late Joan. Devoted father of Andrew and Eric. Loving grandfather of Jeremy, Jill and Maggie. Fatherin-law of Carole and Elizabeth.

title: A Warm Austrian Welcome for Cod
description: STRUDEL is something I take for granted. In Austria, where I grew up, it is used for everything -- desserts and savory dishes. When I worked in a restaurant in Vienna, we always made our own dough for strudel, rolling out layer after paper-thin buttery layer. But in my restaurant here, I do that only for pastries. For savory dishes, I actually prefer the packaged kind, phyllo, because it cooks better when there is no sugar in the recipe.

title: Inaugural Mood Is Patriotic, Subdued and Suffused With Good Feeling
description: David N. Dinkins said that he had not felt so welcome in City Hall in years. Members of the City Council spoke in amazement about actually getting meetings with the mayor. A player on a team called the New York Mets, little recognized at City Hall in recent years, even got to serve as master of ceremonies.

title: Bistro Flavors in an Unbistrolike Setting
description: MATTHEW KENNEY is really two chefs. The first one cares about good food and has an adventurous, roving eye for unusual ingredients and flavors, usually Mediterranean, that he uses to modernize bistro dishes. This is the Matthew Kenney who delighted diners at Matthew's and challenged them at Monz, his somewhat wobbly ramble through the cuisines of Sicily and Sardinia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERLE, ROGER A.
description: WERLE-Roger A., 92. Of Delray Beach, FL and formerly of Brightwaters, NY, died December 27th, 2001. Runner at New York Stock Exchange, 1929. Served in US Fifth Army during W.W. II. Member NYSE, 1959, and a Founder of Lies, Werle & Company. Husband of the late Eileen Haas Werle. Survived by son, Craig of Port Washington, New York, daughter, Cynthia of Satellite Beach, FL., and three grandchildren. Funeral arrangements are private.

title: Victories Are One Part Of Favre's Fun
description: Brett Favre stood in a players' lounge in the bowels of Lambeau Field recently, speaking passionately not about his Green Bay Packers being in the playoffs or his place in N.F.L. history, but about how he was having fun again. The good old Favre from Mississippi is back to having a good old time.

title: Markets and Investing; Individual Investors, While Chastened, Are Not Giving Up

Sunseri, perched behind a counter at the Pennsylvania Macaroni Company, his lavishly provisioned food emporium in a commercial area called the Strip, grumbled that it had forced him to rethink the future.

title: Madam, I'm 2002 -- a Numerically Beautiful Year
description: Now, in the year 2002, we are the last generation for more than the next thousand years to experience two palindromic years in a lifetime. Palindromes in mathematics are numbers that read the same in both directions, like 2002 and 1991. In the English language there are very well-known palindromic words, like ''rotator'' and ''reviver,'' and there are also sentences that are palindromic, like ''Madam, I'm Adam.''

May all who loved her be comforted. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, Senior Rabbi Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

Our condolences to her son Alan and to her grandchildren and great-grandchildren around the world who gave her so much nachas. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The plan, which also calls for a new Yankee Stadium, needs Mr. Bloomberg's approval, and he has been lukewarm about the idea of spending public money on new stadiums given the city's fiscal troubles.

For special occasions -- the transition from 1999 to 2000, for example, or this year, which was to have been Mr. Masur's last New Year's Eve at the orchestra's helm -- he has led Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, a work ideally suited to approaching the New Year thoughtfully and with sober hopes.

title: The Bison Trail Leads to the Greenmarket
description: Ron Kipps has raised bison in West Clifford, Pa., since 1985, but he has sold its meat in the Union Square Greenmarket for only the last few months. Shoppers on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays will find his Elk Trails Bison Ranch truck parked there with cuts of meat and prepared products. Everything is sold frozen. Mr. Kipps said his method of freezing lets the meat remain fresh in the refrigerator for more than a week after it is thawed. It is extremely lean, so steaks are best cooked no more than medium-rare; all the cuts are on the chewy side except for tenderloin ($20 a pound). Garlic sausage ($7 a pound) and meatballs ($6.50 a pound) are superb, and hamburger patties ($5.50 a pound) are convenient to have in the freezer. Smoked slices ($10 a pound), which suggest corned beef, are ready to eat.

It describes the varieties of green tea and how to brew them. Did you know you can tell the temperature of the water according to whether the bubbles look like fish eyes or strings of pearls? Another tip tells how to reduce the caffeine in a cup of tea: toss out the first steeping and rebrew the tea. The author has kinder words than I would have for some commercial tea bags. Recipes are included.

People who call it with complaints or questions that cannot be answered will be referred to the appropriate division of the board. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSKY, LESTER, MD
description: PERSKY-Lester, MD, 82. Passed away December 28, 2001 in Naples, FL. Dr. Persky was born in Cleveland, OH March 4, 1919 and graduated from Cleveland Heights High School. He subsequently attended The University of Michigan on a football scholarship, where his interest in medicine blossomed after a hip injury ended his football career. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Michigan and pursued his medical studies at The Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, MD. Dr. Persky was a Captain in the Army Medical Corps from 1946-48. Subsequent training was in general surgery at the Beth Israel Hospital (Boston). After serving as the Damon Runyon Research Fellow at Harvard University in 1950-51, he returned to Cleveland as a faculty member of Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine, where he was Professor of Surgery as well as Chairman for the Division of Urology for nearly 30 years. Dr. Persky is widely considered one of the most published urologists in the United States, having authored more than 200 scientific articles; he also trained many urologists including six active university department chairpersons. He was a member of every prestigious urologic society in the world, and the Lester Persky Endowed Professorship at Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine was established in his honor. Aside from his busy urology practice, he took great pride in his skill as a general practitioner of medicine and in his tennis game. He was a member fo the Cleveland Racquet Club and the Quail Creek Country Club of Naples. He was a member of the Inaugural Class of Inductees into the Cleveland Heights High School Hall of Fame. Dr. Persky ''retired'' to Florida in 1988 when he jointed the faculty of the University of South Florida College of Medicine as an Emeritus Professor of Surgery. However, his sizable monthly long-distance phone bill reflected his continued dedication and devotion to his former Cleveland patients. He was a member of the medical staff of the VA Clinic in Fort Myers at the time of his death. Dr. Persky is survived by his wife of 52 years, the former Mary Elizabeth Connor, sons David (Mary) Persky of Tampla, FL and Dr. James (Cindy) Persky of Cleveland Heights, OH, daughter Katherine Persky of Manhattan, NY; five grandchildren, Zachary, Paige Abigail, Rachael and Allyson; sister Gladys Yanow of Sarasota, FL and sisterin-law Rosalyn Persky Sugarman of Shaker Heights, OH. Relatives and friends are invited to call at the Fuller Funeral Home, 1625 Pine Ridge Road on Wednesday, January 2, 2002 from 10:30 AM to 11:00 AM. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date in Cleveland, OH. Donations may be made in his memory to the National Kidney Foundation of Florida, 1040 Woodcock Road, Suite 119, Orlando, FL. 32803.

Still, president after president had taken the parks for granted, leaving an overdue repair bill of more than $5 billion as well as an annual operating shortfall in the hundreds of millions. Thus Mr. Bush's promise was no small thing.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Trinidad And Tobago: Selection Criticized
description: The departing prime minister, Basdeo Panday, criticized the recent selection of a political rival as his successor, insisting that new elections should be called instead. Mr. Panday's United National Congress tied with the opposition People's National Movement in the Dec. 10 parliamentary elections. President Arthur Robinson broke the deadlock on Monday by picking the opposition leader Patrick Manning for the prime minister's post. Mr. Robinson said he chose Mr. Manning by taking into account moral and ethical considerations, a reference to the opposition's campaign strategy of emphasizing accusations against the Panday government for sweetheart deals and corruption. Mr. Panday, however, accused Mr. Robinson of bias. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH AND MERCK SAY DRUG FAILED TRIAL
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation and Merck & Company said yesterday that their combination allergy drug had failed to meet its primary goal in late-stage human trials. A tablet containing the main ingredients in Schering-Plough's Claritin and Merck's Singulair did not show significant improvement in patients, compared with the effects of each drug given separately, the drug makers said. The two companies formed a venture in May 2000 to develop and market products for respiratory treatments. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Instant Messenger Found To Be Flawed
description: A newly revealed security hole in the Instant Messenger program of AOL Time Warner could expose the computer of anyone using the software to control by hackers, security experts said yesterday. A loose confederation of security researchers known as w00w00 published a report on the problem, along with ''proof of concept'' software that could be modified to exploit the problem. Matt Conover, founder of the group, suggested that Instant Messenger users restrict incoming messages to those from their buddy lists until the problem is corrected. Andrew Weinstein, an AOL spokesman, said the company would be able to fix the program ''within the next day or two'' without requiring that customers download any software patch. ''To our knowledge,'' Mr. Weinstein said, ''the vulnerability hasn't affected any users yet.'' John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORMANI, EMIL H.
description: SORMANI-Emil H., 80, of Yardley, PA, died Thursday, December 27, 2001 at his home. Born in Luzerne, Switzerland, Mr. Sormani had been a resident of Yardley for over 44 years, moving here from Jamaica, N.Y. Mr. Sormani retired in 1998 as president of E.H. Sormani Inc., textile importers in New York City. Emil was the first importer of French gold lame, representing Diochon Fabrics from Lyon, France. Mills which Emil imported for included mills from France, Italy, Switzerland, Spain, and Brazil. Some of those mills included names such as Taroni, Bianchini-Ferier, Sfate and Combier, and Fabric Frontline. Several American Women's garment manufacturers used fabrics imported by Emil, including Geoffrey Beene, Oscar de la Renta, Bill Blass, Pauline Trigere, Halston and Galanos. Prior to starting his own business in 1963, he worked in New York as a Textile Agent for Foster Willi Lace from St. Gaul, Switzerland. He was also a member of the Arborlea Tennis Club. Husband of the late Patricia U. Sormani, son of the late Joseph and Clara Sormani and brother of the late Hans Sormani, he is survived by two sons, Kenneth U. Sormani, of Tokyo, Japan; Ross J. Sormani, of Boston, Mass.

title: Rumsfeld Says Afghan Prisoners Might Be Brought to U.S. Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that some prisoners being held by American forces in Afghanistan might be transferred to military bases in the United States. He also reiterated the United States' hard-line stance on the surrender of Mullah Mohammad Omar, the Taliban leader.

title: One by One: A Roll Call of Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Medical Education Acquisition
description: The Thomson Corporation, an electronic distributor of legal, financial and educational information, bought a medical education provider, Gardiner-Caldwell Communications Ltd. of Britain, for an undisclosed amount. Gardiner-Caldwell will become part of Thomson's scientific and health care unit, which is based in Montvale, N.J., said Michael Tansey, head of the unit. The business will complement Thomson's Physicians World unit, which provides publication services for drug companies in the United States, Mr. Tansey said.

title: NATIONAL EQUIPMENT BUYS PART OF BRAMBLES INDUSTRIES
description: National Equipment Services, a provider of rental equipment for industrial and construction use, has bought the North American operating unit of Brambles Industries of Australia for $122 million. The purchase will increase the company's presence in the Midwest, National Equipment said. The Brambles unit, which is based in Detroit, is expected to add $160 million to $170 million in revenue this year. National Equipment Services, based in Evanston, Ill., paid $94 million in cash and will pay about $28 million in the unit's receivables, as they are collected. The Brambles unit rents equipment for construction and maintenance projects. In its 2001 fiscal year, which ended June 30, it had $170 million in sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITZ, DOROTHY
description: RITZ-Dorothy. On December 28, 2001. Beloved sister of the late May and Clara. Friends may call after 10 A.M. at the Williams Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx, Friday, January 4. A funeral service will be held at 11 AM. Interment in Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Season May Still Have Bumpy Patches Ahead
description: September is usually a fairly busy month in the reservations department of North American ski areas. Not surprisingly, from Mammoth Mountain in California to Sunday River in Maine, the telephones stopped ringing on the afternoon of Sept. 11. They did not resume ringing for several weeks.

title: One by One: A Roll Call of Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An organization chart on Tuesday showing appointments by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg referred incorrectly to a party affiliation for Martin F. Horn, the commissioner of probation. He had been enrolled as a Democrat in New York until he moved in 1995 to Pennsylvania, where he listed himself as nonpartisan. A spokesman says Mr. Horn has no plans to enroll in a party when he registers to vote in New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Royal Dutch Shares Fall
description: Shares in the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company fell 4.4 percent, their biggest decline in seven weeks, after Fortis, the biggest financial services company in Belgium, said it would sell four million shares it no longer needs. Shares in Royal Dutch, which represent 60 percent of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Europe's largest oil company, slid 2.5 euros, to 54.40 euros, in Amsterdam. That was the biggest decline since Nov. 15 and reduced its market capitalization by about 5 billion euros ($4.5 billion).

title: One by One: A Roll Call of Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Rolls in Orange, With and Without Its Star
description: The pregame talk centered on Florida Coach Steve Spurrier's decision to bench his Heisman Trophy runner-up quarterback, Rex Grossman, in the Orange Bowl tonight for a curfew violation. All that faded, though, as the Gators steamrolled to a record night.

title: A Leg With a Mind of Its Own
description: AMONG the many things that wearing an artificial leg changed in Curtis Grimsley's life was the simple ritual of going to the office.

title: Letting the View Speak For Itself
description: AS you walk up the 300-foot ramp to the viewing platform at ground zero, the wreckage of the towers is blocked from sight. Instead, the view is of the weathered graveyard behind St. Paul's Chapel. It can take an hour or more in a cold line to reach this point, and this first glimpse, of primitive death commemorated in battered limestone, is a sobering prelude to the 16-acre pit to come.

title: Doing It All: One Gadget, Tried Twice
description: EVERY few months another magazine runs an article about computers that will one day be implanted in humans.

title: Marines Complete Sweep Of Al Qaeda Compound
description: About 200 United States marines returned to their base at the Kandahar airport today after sweeping through a deserted terrorist training camp in southern Afghanistan where they recovered only small numbers of weapons and few documents belonging to Osama bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda.

title: Uneasy but Outwardly Calm, Zambia Swears In a President
description: The battered gate at the Supreme Court swung awkwardly on its hinges and shards of glass from smashed streetlights littered Independence Avenue. But with riot police preventing mass protests, this uneasy country inaugurated its president peacefully today.

title: New Executive in Nassau Does the Driving Himself
description: On his first business day as the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi did what most Long Island commuters do. He drove to work today, all by himself.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: More Than We Need to Know

title: Who Are You, Mr. Mayor?
description: We're dealing with a little culture shock here. The new mayor of New York has $4 billion, a Boston accent and a bizarre sense of whom to root for -- he's a Red Sox fan. I have no choice but to worry about him. He can't possibly know what he's in for.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lloyd's Investors Decline
description: Lloyd's of London, the world's biggest insurance market, said the number of individual investors in the insurance market, known as names, fell by 13 percent in 2002, to 2,490, reflecting a continuing downward trend since the 1980's before a series of asbestos-related claims pushed the market to the brink of collapse. At that time names numbered more than 30,000. More recently, the bulk of Lloyd's capital has come from corporate investors. Lloyd's has said claims from the attacks of Sept. 11 will cost it some $1.92 billion, its biggest loss ever from a single catastrophe. At the same time, it said that increased premiums since Sept. 11 could produce Lloyd's first profit in five years in 2002. Lloyd's has said it plans to sell insurance worth almost $18 billion this year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: CALENDER
description: Museum Designers

title: A TV spot, to be broadcast nationwide, will honor the man who had a dream.
description: THE Seattle office of DDB Worldwide is introducing a powerful public service television commercial today to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his civil rights campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, ZACHARY A.J.
description: BERG-Zachary A.J. on January 2, 2002. Adored son of Eric & Barbra. Dear brother of Zoe Madeline. Funeral Service Friday 1 PM at Larchmont Temple in Larchmont, NY. Memorial donations to Dysautonomia Foundation, 633 3rd Avenue, Floor 12, New York, NY 10017, would be appreciated.

title: Malone Advertising Acquiring Haselow
description: Malone Advertising in Akron, Ohio, is acquiring Haselow Marketing Communications in Cleveland, which specializes in business-to-business marketing. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Mourning the Magic Of Markdowns Past
description: FOR years I begged my family to observe Christmas on Dec. 28 so we could take advantage of the post-holiday markdowns. I argued that final-sale eggnog tasted just as sweet and we could even get some things free by then, if we had the gumption to salvage one of the Christmas trees the neighbors had dragged to the curb. Some still have tinsel.

title: Rumsfeld Says Afghan Prisoners Might Be Brought to U.S. Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that some prisoners being held by American forces in Afghanistan might be transferred to military bases in the United States. He also reiterated the United States' hard-line stance on the surrender of Mullah Mohammad Omar, the Taliban leader.

title: Acupuncture Alone Is Inept Against Cocaine
description: Acupuncture is widely used as a treatment for cocaine addiction. But the results of a large clinical trial suggest that when used alone without other treatments the therapy is not effective in reducing cocaine dependency, researchers report yesterday.

title: History's Rough Draft in a Map of Ground Zero
description: LAURA KURGAN emerged from the R train at City Hall on Saturday carrying a shoulder bag crammed with a thousand copies of a map of the area unlike any other.

title: Redmond Journal; Microsoft's Hometown Sees Cause for Optimism
description: Tina Terada-Santos and Jerry Santos have plenty of reasons to be glad to work at the Microsoft Corporation, chief among them that it was on their very first day of orientation -- Sept. 5, 2000 -- that they met, and fell in love. They were married 11 months later.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Rare Lawsuit Advances
description: Children created by artificial insemination are entitled to rights involving inheritance of property from their father even if they are conceived after he dies, the state's highest court ruled. A ruling from that court had been sought by a federal judge hearing a lawsuit brought by a Massachusetts woman who gave birth in 1995 to twin daughters after being inseminated with the sperm of her husband, who had died two years earlier. The woman seeks survivor benefits for the twins from the Social Security Administration, where an administrative law judge ruled that they were not entitled to them and gave as a reason that under state law they were not heirs. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Gains in Chip Industry Fuel Hope in Korea
description: As many industrialized nations wonder how low the global economic slump will take them, there are signs emerging that South Korea may have found the bottom and turned up again.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on Tuesday, about ''Isadora: A Sensational Life,'' on the modern dancer Isadora Duncan, misidentified the father of her daughter, Deirdre. He was the scenic designer Edward Gordon Craig. (The sewing-machine heir Paris Singer was the father of Duncan's son, Patrick.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASIUS, WILLIAM S.
description: MASIUS-William S. Age 89, on December 23, 2001. Survived by his beloved wife Barbara, daughter Carol Zuckerman, son-in-law Stuart Zuckerman, and granddaughter Kate Zuckerman. Also survived by son John and grandchildren Hannah, Max and Sam of Los Angeles. Private services were held. Donations may be made to the New York League for the Hard of Hearing, 71 West 23rd St., NY or to the University of Pennsylvania, 3451 Walnut Street, Philadelphia.

title: Black Is as Good as Gold
description: COLOR fads come and go (remember when orange was the new pink?) but black is forever -- and not just in the world of fashion. In the 1960's and 70's, a sophisticated room had stark white walls and furniture as dense and black as licorice. Decorating in the 80's went over the top with gold, gold and more gold. Now black is back, and it doesn't need a stark white room. Even floral bouquets have a sprinkling of black roses and lilies. Black has the virtue of acting as a neutral. ''Colors stand out against it, and they are uplifted by black,'' said Hilary Jay, the director of the Design Center at Philadelphia University. ''How much color can anyone take?'' Black can be formal, casual or even have a sense of humor.

title: Mets Want to Sign Gonzalez, but at Their Price
description: The Mets are doing a little dance with the free-agent slugger Juan Gonzalez, and it may turn out to be nothing more than a flirtation. But it may also be the negotiating part of a courtship ritual that leads to a multiyear contract.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Friday, 3,161 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: For Couch Potatoes, The Web Delivers
description: CABLE television executives have been promising video-on-demand for years. Somebody should tell them it is already here.

title: 'Lone Cop' Of Edinburgh Has Alter Ego At the Pub
description: Detective Inspector John Rebus, the protagonist of Ian Rankin's best-selling series of crime novels, is, by the author's description, a ''drunken loner cop.'' While on duty in Edinburgh, Rebus walks into pubs and orders Scotch straight or, as he says, ''whisky, no additives.'' Because he is a renegade always challenging authority, he is never promoted, although he is expert at solving the most difficult of cases.

title: Tyco Shares Decline 2.8% On Talk of a U.S. Inquiry
description: Shares of Tyco International fell 2.8 percent yesterday after a research firm questioned whether Tyco is the subject of a government investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPNER, MARGARET LOEB
description: KEMPNER-Margaret Loeb. The Board of Directors, Auxiliary and Administration of The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary mourn the passing of a dear friend and benefactor. For almost half a century Mrs. Kempner was associated with the Infirmary, first as a leader of the hospital Auxiliary, then as a member of the Infirmary's Board of Directors since 1964. She was named an Honorary Director in May 1999 in commemoration of her 100th birthday. She made a special cause of improving the quality of care for children and their families and will long be remembered by those who were touched by her generosity and kindness. Our sincerest condolences to her family. Peter Frelinghuysen, Chairman of the Board Joseph P. Corcoran President and CEO

title: McGreevey Seeks a Resignation Over E-ZPass Woes
description: Warning that the shortfall for New Jersey's financially troubled E-ZPass system may top $300 million, James E. McGreevey, the governor-elect, called today for the resignation of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority's executive director. Mr. McGreevey also asked turnpike officials to cancel all plans to renegotiate the E-ZPass contract before he takes office on Jan. 15.

title: U.S. Raid Killed Intelligence Chief : A Taliban Leader Is Reported Dead
description: WASHINGTON  The Taliban intelligence chief was killed last week in a U.S. bombardment, an Afghan official confirmed Wednesday, as American and Afghan fighters scoured a large fenced compound reportedly used recently by the leader of the former ruling militia, Mullah Mohammed Omar.

title: Flower-Free Painted Porcelain
description: Marie Dage had six children at home when she began painting porcelain six years ago. ''I never thought about it as a business venture, just something I really enjoyed,'' said Ms. Dage, right, whose dishes, below, are flying out of European boutiques. Graphic with a touch of the whimsical, the designs attract young, stylish people who had dismissed painted porcelain as something for grannies. ''In France, we have a strong tradition of 'art de la table,' '' Ms. Dage said. ''Having your breakfast from a beautiful cup is still important.'' Her cups and saucers ($70 to $114) and dinner plates ($75 to $85) are sold at A La Maison, 1078 Madison Avenue (81st Street) and, starting next month, at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose after notes and coins were introduced without the disruptions some analysts and investors had expected. In New York, the euro settled at 90.36 cents, up from 89.13 cents on Monday.

title: After Black Teenager Is Slain, Norway Peers Into a Mirror
description: In the perfect land, could there be self-doubt? The sad story and violent death of Benjamin Hermansen suggest that there could.

title: Jackson Looking to Be a Leader Again
description: He calls the plays, points his teammates in the right direction and is viewed by nearly everyone as a future head coach in the N.B.A. So when the lead begins to shrink and his teammates begin to doubt, the Knicks' Mark Jackson can be expected to remain poised, to chastise or encourage when necessary and to execute properly when the game is in the balance.

title: Not-Guilty Plea Is Set for Man In Terror Case
description: Invoking the name of Allah, Zacarias Moussaoui refused to enter a plea today to a six-count criminal indictment that accused him of a role in the Sept. 11 terrorist plot. His lawyer and the judge in the case then entered a plea of not guilty for him.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about India's movement of military forces because of tensions with Pakistan misidentified the aircraft carrier that moved toward Pakistani waters in the Arabian Sea. It is the Viraat; the Vikrant has been decommissioned.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Retirement For Contractor
description: Gordon Wu quit as managing director of Hopewell Holdings Ltd., a first step to retirement from the construction contractor he founded and shepherded to prominence as one of Asia's largest private investors in roads and power plants in the mid-1990s. Mr. Wu, 66, plans to retire at about age 70, leaving the business to his son, Thomas Jefferson Wu, 29, whom he promoted to chief operating officer. For now, Gordon Wu remains chairman and his deputy, Eddie Ho, advances to managing director.

title: High Hurdles for Deep Mine
description: Construction work on what is thought to be one of the world's richest copper deposits, outside this rusting town near the Congo border, was supposed to commence on New Year's Day, signifying a turn toward better times in Zambia's struggling mining industry.

title: Statuette Is Traced to Midas; Alas, Not Golden, Just Ivory
description: Although it somehow escaped the legendary golden touch, an ivory statuette from the Delphi ruins in Greece has been identified as very likely part of a gift to the God Apollo by the famous King Midas of Phrygia, a University of Pennsylvania archaeologist announced yesterday.

title: Senate Democrats Plan To Subpoena Enron Papers
description: Senate Democrats said today that they planned to subpoena documents from Enron executives and to examine the company's high-level connections to the Bush administration as Congress steps up its inquiry into the company's collapse.

title: New Council Members Dive In, With a Caucus to Change Some Rules
description: Even as the swirl surrounding the selection of the City Council speaker has begun to move through the corridors of City Hall, a large group of Council members has been plotting to change some rules in an effort to wrest authority from that office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMROSEN, SAM
description: BLOOMROSEN - Sam. Temple Beth Torah mourns the loss of our beloved congregant Sam Bloomrosen on December 31. We extend our condolences to his wife Mildred and his sons Lee and Jay. May God comfort all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Michael Katz Leonard B. Austin, President

title: Horrible Year Ends on Up Note At Cantor; Financial Health for the Firm And More Smiles for the Staff
description: As Howard W. Lutnick, the chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, headed to Florida last weekend to see out the worst year of his life, he found himself, beyond all expectations, with good news to share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDERBUSH, ELSA SALKAY
description: FEDERBUSH-Elsa Salkay, 94. On Jan. 1, 2002, at her home in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Max W. Cherished mother of Alexander and his wife Marjorie and Charles and his wife Denyse. Adored grandmother of Maxwell, Benjamin and Zachary. Loving sister of Renee Beck. You will forever be in our hearts.

title: Ruling Eases Restrictions On Tax Shelters For Companies
description: A federal appeals court has issued a ruling in a case involving Compaq Computer that tax experts say will make it much more difficult for the Internal Revenue Service to demolish many corporate tax shelters.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: A Father's Trial
description: Jury selection began in Cambridge for the manslaughter trial of a man who beat another father to death in a confrontation at their sons' hockey practice. Prosecutors say the defendant, Thomas Junta, 42, who was watching from the stands, became enraged when he saw his son being body-checked at the practice, which was supposed to be noncontact. He and Michael Costin, 40, who was overseeing the practice, began quarreling, and in the end Mr. Costin was killed. Mr. Junta's lawyer, claiming self-defense, says the accused will testify that Mr. Costin was the aggressor.

title: Changes at the Top For Two Agencies
description: Two agencies are making changes in top management.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENCHER, SYLVIA
description: MENCHER-Sylvia. Of Riverdale, NY. Loving wife of Irving Mencher and loving mother of Jesse and Eleanor. She was a life member and longtime bridge teacher of Brandeis University National Women's Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSKY, H. PEARL
description: PERSKY-H. Pearl. Congregation Orach Chaim extends its sincerest condolences to our dedicated member Amy Persky on the loss of her beloved mother. May she and the Waldoks and Persky families be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi James A. Lassner, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JOSEPH
description: GREENE-Joseph. 52. After a long illness. Brother of Paul Greenberger, son of Murray Greenberger, OBM, & Ruth Kahan Greenberger, OBM. Graveside service today, at 10 AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABOODI, ESTHER
description: ABOODI-Esther. The faculty of Columbia University's College of Physicians & Surgeons mourn the passing of our dear friend, Esther Aboodi. Esther was a philanthopist and longtime volunteer at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where she was a member of the Health Sciences Advisory Counsel. She supported research promoting new cancer treatments and therapies, and championed the work of young scholars and investigators in medicine. Esther's commitment to the Medical Center earned her numerous awards, notably a volunteer achievement award from the United Hospital Fund. She was a passionate advocate for women's health, including the Center for Women's Health and Women At Risk (WAR), on whose boards she served. Esther and her husband, Oded, recently helped to establish two assistant fellowships at the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center to advance research in lymphoma which will preserve the legacy of our generous and devoted friend. We extend our deepest sympathies to Oded, their children, Henry, David, and Abigail, their spouses and grandchildren. Gerald D. Fishbach, M.D., Executive Vice President For Health and Biomedical Sciences Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Columbia University

title: Israel Eases Armed Blockade as U.S. Peace Envoy Returns
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 3  Israel eased its military blockade on parts of the West Bank today as the Bush administration's peace envoy returned to the region with the seemingly modest goal of trying to bring the two sides together to resume negotiations for a cease-fire. /P>

description: SALZMAN-Ida. With profound sorrow, we mourn the death of Ida Salzman, age 87, who died December 31, 2001. Adored and cherished spouse, for 63 years, of Jacob A. Salzman, mother and mother-inlaw of Richard and Sue Salzman, Anita and Myron Pulier, and Robert Salzman and Lori Brooks. Grandmother of Eric, Greg, Anne, Rachel, Talia and Aramie and great grandmother of Jake, Will, Chloe and Abe. Ida expressed pleasure and gratitude for every aspect of her life. title: Corrections

It is not she but Maria Bibbiena, the painter's longtime fiance, who is buried beside him in the Pantheon.

title: BERMUDA INSURER APPOINTS NEW CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Ace, one of Bermuda's largest insurers, named Philip Bancroft chief financial officer yesterday, effective immediately. Mr. Bancroft, a former partner in charge of the New York regional insurance practice of PricewaterhouseCoopers, replaced Christopher Marshall, who will become executive assistant to Ace's chairman, Brian Duperreault. Mr. Bancroft will report to Mr. Duperreault, who is also the chief executive. In his new position, Mr. Marshall will be responsible for special projects, including mergers and acquisitions.

title: Olbermann to Do Radio Commentaries
description: Keith Olbermann will revive the tradition of the late Howard Cosell's ''Speaking of Sports'' essays, delivering two-and-a-half-minute morning sports commentary for ABC Radio Networks starting on Jan. 21.

title: Movie-Star Modern On a Fan's Allowance
description: LAUREN LEXTON and Kevin MacCarthy moved to Los Angeles from New York City and fell for Silver Lake at first sight. The neighborhood reminded them of the East Village, but with palm trees, houses and hills. Its upscale bohemian ambience -- intermingled sidewalk cafes, dime stores and antique shops -- suited their artistic tastes. Mr. MacCarthy is a storyboard artist for movies, including ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone''; Ms. Lexton, his wife, a documentary filmmaker, made ''Heroes of Iwo Jima,'' which ran on television in June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLES, SUSAN (MORSE)

Hilles of Brooklyn, also survived by four grandsons, one granddaughter and six greatgrandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to the charity of one's choice. Burial will be private. For information, contact J.S. Waterman - Eastman - Waring Funeral Service, Boston, MA (617) 536-4110.

title: Drivers Feeling Their Oats; Despite Fears, Park Carriages Have Plenty of Riders
description: Along Central Park South around the winter holidays there is an economic indicator found not in tourism data but on the streets: full buckets of oats. The fuller the buckets of oats, the more the horses are eating, and the horses eat the most when business is booming for Central Park carriage drivers.

title: Sports of The Times; Title Playoff Remains Far In the Future

title: Fast Track to Nowhere

When the blush of success wears off, they may well realize that this battle, won on a 215-214 vote, has significantly weakened the chances of Republicans -- traditionally the champions of free trade -- to maintain control of the House of Representatives. And only to enact a measure that is of little practical value.

description: A federal district judge today dismissed a lawsuit seeking to halt the Navy's bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Police Shooting Called Justified
description: Officers who shot and killed an armed man after he had shot two other officers, one of whom is in serious condition, acted in accordance with departmental procedures, Daniel Giaquinto, the Mercer County prosecutor, said yesterday. On Monday, two officers, Joseph F. Esposito and Quentin I. Hayes, confronted the gunman, William O. Davis, 23, at the home of Mr. Davis's estranged girlfriend. As they tried to apprehend him, Mr. Davis shot Officer Hayes in the neck and thigh and Officer Esposito in the arm and shoulder, the police have said. Officers arriving at the scene killed Mr. Davis. Officer Esposito was listed in stable condition yesterday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia and Officer Hayes was in critical condition at Robert Wood Johnson Hospital in New Brunswick.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Twin Rebel Leaders Transferred
description: Two chain-smoking teenage twins who led a rebel group called God's Army in Myanmar, the former Burma, have been transferred from a Thai police compound to a refugee camp for ethnic Karen refugees. Johnny and Luther Htoo, who are now about 13 years old, surrendered to Thai authorities a year ago and have been waiting for months for immigrant visas to the United States. But they have also told reporters that they prefer not to go.

title: Best of the Obscure Among 2001's Albums
description: Now that every computer and every apartment is a potential recording studio and every musician could be a do-it-yourself independent label, more than 20,000 albums are released each year, more than any single fan, radio station or critic could possibly assess fully. That means that richly deserving music can go unnoticed, drowned out by better-promoted albums or rendered inaccessible because it eludes the easy categorization that could make it marketable. Top 10 lists and end-of-the-year surveys invariably leave music critics dissatisfied, since so many other worthwhile albums linger largely unnoticed: albums on independent labels and, now and then, albums on major labels that were never treated as high priorities.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Jail For Sept. 11 Falsehood
description: A man was sentenced to an unusually long prison term yesterday for making false statements to the F.B.I. implying that an Arab-American acquaintance knew about the Sept. 11 terror attacks four days before they took place. Judge Nina Gershon of Federal District Court sentenced the man, Jack Barresi, 38, of Brooklyn, to 21 months in prison. Mr. Barresi said an Arab-American had told him that he could ''not wait for you Americans to blow up and die.'' Mr. Barresi later acknowledged to prosecutors that he had a grudge against the man, the manager at the store where Mr. Barresi's fiance worked. Such violations typically carry a sentence of six months, but federal prosecutors urged more time because the statement came at what they said was a time of ''heightened anti-Arab sentiment.'' Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Health Aid for Poor Countries
description: On the list of factors keeping poor countries poor -- bad governance, war, natural disasters -- a prominent place must go to disease. By the most conservative estimates, malaria robs sub-Saharan Africa of 6 percent of its economic strength, and the actual figure could be even higher than 50 percent. As AIDS spreads, the situation will be even more devastating. Disease cuts the lifespan of workers and reduces productivity. High infant mortality compels families to have many children; the families are thus able to spend less on the health and education of each child, and mothers are kept from joining the work force. Disease discourages tourism and investment.

A government spokesman said Representative Todd Tiahrt, Republican of Kansas, had said that he wanted American troops to aid in a rescue but that the proposal was turned down. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: PACIFICARE TO CUT 15 PERCENT OF ITS WORK FORCE

PacifiCare said the moves would save $80 million to $90 million a year. PacifiCare, based in Santa Ana, Calif., said most of the jobs would be cut in the first quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, JOHN ARTHUR, MD
description: EVANS-John Arthur, MD. The faculty and staff of the Department of Radiology at New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Medical Center mourn the passing of Dr. John Arthur Evans, former Professor and Chairman of Radiology and Radiologist-in-Chief from 1952 until his retirement in 1976. After his retirement he remained on staff as an Attending Radiologist and was active in the Department's post-graduate programs. During these two decades, the department expanded and differentiated, and its academic programs were strengthened. He was a pioneer and an influential leader in the field of radiology and taught and mentored a generation of future leaders. He was recognized for his accomplishments by numerous awards, which included the Gold Medal from the Radiological Society of North America in 1967. Dr. Evans served as a Chancellor of the American College of Radiology in 1953. He also served as President of the American Board of Radiology from 1967 to 1969 and was Chairman of the Residency Review Committee that organized the Board's first written exam. He will be remembered as an influential educator and pioneering radiologist who set the highest standards of professional conduct and patient care. We extend our condolences to his entire family. H. Dirk Sostman, MD Professor and Chairman Department of Radiology New York Presbyterian HospitalWeill Cornell Medical College

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, ANIELA (NELA)
description: RUBINSTEIN-Aniela (Nela). Died peacefully at her home in NY on December 31. Age 93. Our beloved mother will be missed by all of us; her children, Eva, Paul, Alina and John Rubinstein, her grandchildren Amy and David (and Kristy) Coffin, Jason (and Amy), Jessica, Michael, Peter and Jacob Rubinstein, and her great grandchildren, Alexander and Julian Coffin-Lennear and Linnea Coffin. She was born in Vilnius, Lithuania, the youngest daughter of Emil Mlynarski, the founder in 1901 and first Conductor of the Warsaw Philharmonic, and later Director of the Warsaw Opera for 20 years. In her youth, she studied dance in Dresden with Mary Wigman. She was briefly married to Mieczyslaw Munz, a pianist who later taught at Juilliard. Her 50 year marriage to Arthur Rubinstein lasted until his death in 1982. They lived in Paris until the outbreak of WW II, when they were forced to leave, later joining the emigre artistic community in Hollywood. They became US citizens in 1946. After 1954 they reclaimed their house in Paris, and also maintained homes in New York and Spain. Our mother was known for her wonderful cooking, her memorable parties, her great charm, her elegance and beauty. She spoke seven languages, was immensely musical, sculpted, painted, and even embroidered with talent. She played a major role in making the annual Polonaise Ball a highly successful event for the benefit of Polish Assistance, Inc. In 1983, Alfred A. Knopf published ''Nela's Cookbook,'' to the delight of her family and friends. It was later translated into Polish. We loved our sweet Ma, and we will deeply miss her spontaneity, her enthusiasm, her generosity, and her quirky humor. A celebration of her life will be planned for a later date.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Homestore Revenue To Be Restated
description: The online home listing company Homestore.com Inc., whose shares have not traded since Dec. 21 as it reviews its accounting, said it had overstated revenue in the first nine months of 2001 by $54 million to $95 million. The overstatement stems from advertising sales that should have been accounted for as barter transactions because they were related to purchases of goods and services, Homestore.com said. Additional ''material restatements'' of results, including those for 2000, are possible, the company said. The company had revenue of $351 million, about $122 million of which was related to advertising sales, through the first nine months.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Packaging Concern
description: Anglo American, the metals and mining giant, said its Mondi International paper subsidiary began an unsolicited cash bid for the French packaging company, Rochette, valuing the French company at about 298 million euros ($270 million). Anglo has been seeking to move away from its South African roots since it moved its headquarters to London in 1999. The offer for Rochette, of 11.6 euros a share, could start a bidding war since Saica of Spain bought 22 percent of Rochette in late December for 10.9 euros a share. Anglo American's bid represented an 18 percent premium on Rochette's closing price last Friday. Anglo American's shares in London rose as much as 4.4 percent, to 1,087 pence. In addition to Rochette's shares, Anglo American also offered about 60 million euros, or $54 million, for Rochette's convertible bonds. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Smoking Restrictions
description: Several places in the country, including the province of Newfoundland and Labrador and the cities of Calgary and Winnipeg, introduced stricter antismoking rules for the new year. A new law in Calgary requires restaurants to mark smoking areas clearly and to prohibit patrons under the age of 18 from sitting there. Winnipeg introduced similar measures after the City Council voted down a proposal for an outright smoking ban in public places. Newfoundland and Labrador has banned smoking in shopping malls, hotel lobbies and inside ferries linking Newfoundland island to the mainland. Smoking will still be permitted in restaurants with liquor licenses, but only if people under 19 are not on the premises. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Jean Nouvel's Works, Built and Not
description: The highly abstract work of the French architect Jean Nouvel (projects that have been built, and those that never will be) is on display in an original and detailed show at the Pompidou Center in Paris. Mr. Nouvel, a charismatic figure best known for the design of the Arab World Institute and the Cartier Foundation, both in Paris, was given free rein to create the innovative exhibition, left. Among the projects on display is the 180-room Broadway Hotel (rendering above), a colorful glass-sheathed building that will go up in New York on Grand Street between Broadway and Mercer. The developer is Andr Balazs, owner of the Mercer Hotel in SoHo and the Chateau Marmont and the Standard in Los Angeles.

description: After years of preparation and some predictions of chaos, Europeans in 12 nations have begun using a common currency with no significant problems, a surprising amount of enthusiasm and even a slight rise in its value today.

title: In Statement, Mandela Shifts On All-Out Support for War
description: Nelson Mandela, who was criticized in some quarters here for coming out strongly in support of the American-led campaign against terrorism, said today that he may have overstated his backing for the war and that his earlier comments may have unintentionally suggested that he was ignoring the conflict's toll on ordinary people.

The government-owned Gas Authority of India Ltd., India's largest gas transmission and marketing company, has declared its intent to bid for the troubled company, which is 65 percent owned by Enron. The other two Indian bidders, Tata Power and BSES, privately owned utilities backed by major Indian industrial conglomerates, are already in the process of due diligence ahead of making their bids. title: Pakistan's Welcome Gestures
description: After three weeks of tensions on the border with India, Pakistan has taken several steps to reduce the threat of war with its neighbor. Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani leader, was reported this week to have cut his government's military and intelligence links with two Islamic extremist groups operating in India, and to have arrested an estimated 100 militant leaders. These actions were in some ways even tougher for Pakistan than its earlier decision to cooperate with the United States' war on terrorism and sever ties with the Taliban in Afghanistan. India has had a mixed response. But it should reciprocate by reducing some forces on its side of the border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTEN, MILDRED BERNEY
description: OTTEN - Mildred Berney, 1911-2001. Widow of Albert Otten, died peacefully in her sleep on Friday, December 28, 2001 at her home in Teaneck, New Jersey at the age of 90. Born March 1, 1911 in Denver, Colorado, she was the 6th of 8 children, of Harry and Esther Michelson Berney. Mildred grew up in Tupper Lake, NY where she graduated with honors from Theodore Roosevelt High School. In the 1930's she moved to the Bronx with her mother and worked for many years as a milliner at Bergdorf Goodman. In 1948 Mildred married Albert Otten and retired from work to become a mother and tireless volunteer for many well-known organizations. Mildred served on the board of Marymount Manhattan College & was extensively involved in and honored by both The Women's Division-American Society for Technion University in Israel, The Teaneck Jewish Center and Temple Emeth in Teaneck, NJ. Mildred was also a member, patron and/or benefactor to many institutions including The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Guggenheim, The Jewish Museum and also The Lotus Club. In her later years Mildred oversaw the exhibition and loan of the family's art collection which is now on display in the Portland Museum of Art in Maine. Mildred Otten was predeceased by her husband Albert in 1985 and her sister and six brothers. Mildred is survived by her son Leslie Bennett Otten and his wife Chris of Bethel, Maine, her three loving grandchildren Meredith, Joshua and Benjamin Jacob, her great-niece, Ellen Mendel as well as her longtime friend and companion Grace Mair. In lieu of flowers, people are asked to make a donation to Beth Joseph Synagogue, P.O. Box 625, Tupper Lake, NY 12986, or a charity of their choice in Mildred's name.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Union City: Serial Arson Is Feared
description: The police are investigating the fourth fire in a month in which arson is suspected. The fire, at a three-story apartment building on Summit Avenue, was reported around 4 a.m. on Tuesday and left 12 families homeless. The four-alarm blaze was brought under control in 90 minutes and no serious injuries were reported. Mayor Brian Stack said he was concerned that a serial arsonist was at work. On Dec. 2, three fires were reported, also around 4 a.m., just blocks from the Tuesday fire. Those fires left more than 100 people homeless.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: November Chip Sales Show Gain
description: Sales of computer chips in November improved slightly for the second consecutive month, as the industry's sharp decline continued to show signs of having hit bottom. The Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group in San Jose, Calif., said global chip sales were $10.6 billion, a 42 percent decline from a year earlier but up 1.6 percent from October, when sales were $10.44 billion. Month-to-month growth of 5.3 percent in Europe offset flat sales in the Americas and a 1 percent decline in Japan. George Scalise, president of the association, said the industry was on track to grow 4.7 percent in the fourth quarter, as predicted. But analysts said chip makers might struggle through more dreary times in the beginning of 2002, as a weak economy continues to hamper demand. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index gained 4.5 percent, to 545.44. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: WEYERHAEUSER SAYS IT WON'T RAISE BID FOR WILLAMETTE
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that it would not raise its $7.76 billion bid for Willamette Industries because the merger would not provide enough savings to justify a higher price. Directors of Willamette will meet today or tomorrow and assess Weyerhaeuser's offer of $55 a share. Weyerhaeuser said it did not think it could save much more than the $300 million a year it had identified after talks with Willamette last month. Weyerhaeuser, based in Federal Way, Wash., has been pursuing Willamette for more than a year. Willamette, based in Portland, Ore., agreed last month to talk with Weyerhaeuser for the first time, after the company increased its bid to $55 a share from $50.

The bar is ''something a bit unexpected,'' said Patrick Jouin, 34, its designer and a protg of Philippe Starck. Modern touches jolt the classic wood paneled room, including an illuminated sandblasted glass bar that looks like a huge ice cube and an oval hanging lamp, left, that is bigger than Mr. Starck's hanging pool table lamp at the Hudson Hotel in New York. ''The bars of grand hotels like the Plaza Athne are magical places where visitors meet locals, day meets night,'' Mr. Jouin said. Meet the Rose Royale cocktail -- Champagne and fresh raspberry pure, $18. Plaza Athne, 25, avenue Montaigne.

title: Argentina's Quest for Salvation
description: Sworn in on Wednesday, Argentina's fifth president in two weeks called his a ''government of national salvation.'' The label might seem to emanate from the same overwrought, tragic streak that bequeathed the tango and the saga of Evita to the world. But President Eduardo Duhalde was not exaggerating. Argentina's crisis is dire, and threatens the viability of its democracy. Mr. Duhalde must govern accordingly, presiding over an administration that works with all the major parties to create a consensus on how to proceed.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Montville: Lawmaker Released From Prison
description: State Representative Kevin Ryan has been released from the minimum-security Bergin Correctional Institution in Mansfield after completing a 120-day sentence for driving while intoxicated. Mr. Ryan, a Montville Democrat, was arrested on July 12 and charged with driving while intoxicated while returning home from a political fund-raiser. It was his third such arrest. Mr. Ryan's driver's license has been suspended for three years. Released on Tuesday, he is serving three months' probation, performing 100 hours of community service and undergoing mandatory alcohol abuse counseling. He has returned to his job as an optician. He said he planned to be in attendance when the General Assembly convened in February and was working out a plan to get rides to and from the Capitol.

title: A Monster's Eyes Reflected In the Glare of the Footlights
