For ogres of all stripes, darkness is the ultimate cosmetic concealer, giving evil a murky glamour and hiding those telltale signs of ordinariness. Drag a monster into the light, and it may start to look like, well, you and me. Which is sometimes the scariest shock of all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC ADAMS, WALTER J., JR.
description: MC ADAMS-Walter J., Jr. died of heart failure on January 3, 2002 at the age of 83. Born on April 15, 1918, he attended Xavier High School and Fordham University. An active member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1947, he was the president of The Garvin Bantel Corporation, member of the New York Stock Exchange Buttonwood Club, and Luncheon Club. He resided at his home, The Glen Farm, on Quaker Hill, in Pawling, New York after his retirement in 1979, and was active in the family farm. Along with his wife, he was a devoted member of the community, and his ability to enlighten people with his words and actions will never be forgotten. He is survived by his loving wife Alice K. McAdams, his two sons Mark and Walter McAdams, and one daughter Alice McAdams Roper. Along with his wife and three loving children, he leaves behind three adoring grandchildren. Respects can be paid at his home The Glen Farm on Friday, January 4, 7-9 o'clock PM. Funeral services will be at 12 noon at St. John's Church in Pawling, New York on Saturday, January 5th.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Concern At Ground Zero
description: Four Port Authority police officers have been reassigned from ground zero after tests showed they had elevated levels of mercury in their blood, said Allen Morrison, a Port Authority spokesman. The officers are in good health, and were reassigned as a precautionary measure. The normal range of mercury is 0 to 13 micrograms per liter of blood, and two of the four officers tested at 14, one at 18, and one at 24, Mr. Morrison said. The Port Authority's medical department has voluntarily tested 58 officers working at the World Trade Center site since mid-November, and is continuing to monitor their health. ''Even though we can't be certain it came from working at ground zero, we thought it would be prudent to reassign these officers,'' Mr. Morrison said. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Emerson: Internet Free Speech
description: A state judge has dismissed a libel suit against a Web site operator who posted anonymous messages that were critical of Emerson township officials. The judge, Mark M. Russello of State Superior Court in Hackensack, ruled on Wednesday that the operator, Stephen Moldow, and his site, eyeonemerson.com, were covered under free-speech statutes. But the judge did not dismiss the case against 60 anonymous co-defendants, said Jack Darakjy, the lawyer for the local officials who filed the suit. Mr. Darakjy said he would now ask the judge for the identities of the defendants whose postings he said damaged his clients' reputations. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Haulers Plead Guilty

The men, Charles and Donald Manzo, owners of B. Manzo & Son Inc., also agreed to leave the trash industry for good. They kept two sets of books and failed to report a large part of the income that came when customers who rented large containers paid in cash from 1995 to 1998, federal prosecutors said. description: More hearing dates are expected to be added today in the union's challenge to baseball's attempt to eliminate two teams. The additional dates will almost certainly push the arbitrator's decision into next month and further complicate Commissioner Bud Selig's ability to execute his plan for the coming season.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Forecast Hurts Software Maker
description: Shares of Peregrine Systems, a 20-year-old enterprise software company, fell $5.24, or 36.1 percent, to $9.27 yesterday on news that it would post a loss for its latest quarter rather than the profit analysts had expected. Peregrine, based in San Diego, said it anticipated a loss of 7 cents to 8 cents a share on revenue of $175 million for the third quarter of fiscal 2002, which ended Dec. 31. Analysts had projected a profit of a dime a share. The pro forma loss excludes approximately $75 million in acquisition costs. Executives attributed the loss to poor economic conditions in Europe and delays in purchasing decisions by customers. It said business activity was up in North America. Final results are due Jan. 24. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSNELL, THOMAS C.
description: GOSNELL-Thomas C. ''Tucker'' Gosnell. Beloved husband of Silvia M. (Ortiz) Gosnell, devoted father of Philip Hale Gosnell, also survived by his parents Thomas Hale and Georgia (Potter) Gosnell of Rochester, NY, brother Arthur Gosnell of Bedford Hills, NY and sisters, Elizabeth Gosnell of NYC and Robin Travers of Princeton, NJ. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend Funeral Services on Saturday, January 5 at Trinity Church, Copley Sq., Boston at 10:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Tucker Gosnell Fund For Cancer Research, Development Office at Mass. General Hospital, Boston, MA 02114. Burial will be at the Newton Cemetery, Newton, MA. For information, call J.S. Waterman-Eastman-Waring Funeral Service 617-536-4110.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: No Review Of Columbine Shootings
description: No federal or state grand juries are expected to look into accusations that a police officer might have killed a student at Columbine High School, one of the 13 people who died in an attack by two students in 1999. John Suthers, the United States attorney for Colorado, said he did not believe that any federal crimes were involved, and Gov. Bill Owens said he would not ask Ken Salazar, the state's attorney general, to convene a grand jury. The parents of a dead student, Daniel Rohrbough, have said they believe a Denver police officer was responsible for their son's death. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: AOL Fixes Instant Messenger Flaw
description: AOL Time Warner announced yesterday that a security flaw in its popular Instant Messenger software had been fixed. The problem, which was revealed earlier this week, was exposed by a group of young security researchers led by Matt Conover, a 19-year-old Utah State University student. Hackers exploiting the security hole could have taken control of a user's home computer running America Online's Instant Messenger software. Andrew Weinstein, an AOL spokesman, said the repair was done in such a way that ''users do not have to download anything or take any other action.'' Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Farewell, Old Bus. Hi, Your Majesty.
description: AN era is ending at Volkswagen, and, in the rarefied precincts of royalty, another is about to begin.

description: When Congress returns to Washington, the battles will resume -- and each party will accuse the other of partisanship. Why can't they just get along?

Contributions in his memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Ave of the Americas, NY, NY 10013.

title: In New York Region, 2003 Starts Off Wet and White
description: The first storm of the new year and the second in 10 days rolled into the region yesterday, giving Connecticut and upstate New York a second big helping of holiday snow and coating roadways farther south with ice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Snow And Cold Prove Deadly
description: Blizzards and bitter cold have hit Eastern Europe and Russia, killing at least 25 people in the last few days and closing roads, train lines, airports and schools. A dozen people have died in Poland, left, from weather-related causes as temperatures dropped to minus-4 yesterday after snowstorms reported to be the worst in 15 years. In Moscow, officials reported that 10 people died on Wednesday night in temperatures as low as minus-11. In Bulgaria, blizzards cut off dozens of towns, and some 60 tourists were reported stranded in a mountain resort. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Agencies say British regulators are too quick to ban ads.
description: SMIRNOFF vodka did it. French Connection has done it many times. Yves Saint Laurent's campaign for Opium perfume featuring the model Sophie Dahl posing naked really did it.

title: GREENPOINT TO CLOSE MOBILE-HOME LENDING UNIT
description: GreenPoint Financial said yesterday that it would close its mobile-home lending business, the second largest in the nation, because loan defaults had surged. The bank plans to lay off 400 people and post a loss for 2001 as it shuts the unit, bought three years ago for $703 million. ''We came to a conclusion that the manufactured-housing business is not a good business for us,'' said the chief executive, Thomas S. Johnson. Conseco, which bought Green Tree Financial, the biggest lender to mobile-home buyers, about the same time, has suffered, as well. The business hurt the company partly because fewer borrowers are paying on time in the slowing economy. GreenPoint shares rose $5.19, or 15 percent, to $40.65, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEARY, WILLIAM J.
description: NEARY-William J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of William J. Neary, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. John H. FitzSimons, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERMAN, JACK
description: LEDERMAN-Jack. On January 2, 2002. Beloved husband of Anne. Loving father of Sara and Norman. Dear brother of Pearl and Millicent. Devoted grandfather of Elizabeth and Andrew. Service Friday, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Federal Appeals Court Upholds Ruling on City's Public Housing
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the city could not favor working families in doling out apartments at 14 low-income housing projects, a ruling that upholds a lower court's finding that such a policy would perpetuate a history of racial segregation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, HELEN K.
description: CARR-Helen K. Died peacefully on January 1, 2002. Beloved wife of Leonard, loving mother of Eugene and Anita. She wil be deeply missed by all of her friends and family. Her generosity, courage, sophistication and beautiful smile will be an inspiration for us all. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St, on Thursday 1:15 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions should be made to The Alumni and Friends of LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts (Helen Carr Scholarship Fund), or High Five Tickets to the Arts, or The Aspen Music Festival and School.

title: Snow Hits an Unpracticed South and Shuts It Down
description: The largest snowstorm in a decade iced the South today, causing hundreds of traffic accidents and 10 deaths. Business essentially closed for the day, and hundreds of airline flights were canceled, stranding 4,000 people overnight in Atlanta alone. Nearly 70,000 people lost electrical power.

title: A Builder Sees Tokyo Rising Ever Upward; Big Bets on End of Sardine Commuting
description: This may be the largest city in the world's second-largest economy, but it still has a decidedly low-rise horizon. Or, as Minoru Mori, 67, the president of the Mori Building Company, put it, Tokyo is ''horizontally congested and vertically vacant.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Eugene Nickerson
description: Eugene Nickerson never achieved his early dream of becoming governor of New York, and as a judge he was denied elevation to the Federal Court of Appeals when President Jimmy Carter's loss of his re-election campaign in 1980 scuttled the Nickerson nomination. But Judge Nickerson, who died on Tuesday at the age of 83, transcended these disappointments, and a serious teenage bout with polio, to make a significant mark on both government and the law.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Britain: Cable Plan Advances
description: Connecticut regulators approved plans yesterday for a 330-megawatt electricity cable stretching across Long Island Sound from New Haven to Shoreham. The decision came nine months after the regulators, the Connecticut Siting Council, rejected an earlier plan for the cable. The new plan rerouted the cable to reduce its impact on shellfish beds. Critics, including Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, have promised to continue fighting the proposal, which still requires a permit from the United States Army Corps of Engineers. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Vision For Ground Zero: Memorial and More
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the head of the commission charged with rebuilding Lower Manhattan said yesterday that the World Trade Center site was unlikely to be transformed mainly into a memorial to the victims of the terrorist attack -- an idea former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani promoted just last week.

title: Buddy, Socks's Nemesis, Is Dead
description: Buddy, former President Bill Clinton's chocolate Labrador, who pulled at the leash, fought with the first cat and stuck by the side of a commander in chief weathering scandal, was struck and killed by a car here on Wednesday.

description: An Earthling With a Mission

title: Benjamin Welles, Biographer And Journalist, Is Dead at 85
description: Benjamin Welles, a foreign correspondent for The New York Times on three continents and the author of a painfully revealing biography of his father, Sumner Welles, a major foreign policy adviser to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 85.

description: MASIUS-William S. Age 89, on December 23, 2001. Survived by his beloved wife Barbara, daughter Carol Zuckerman, son-in-law Stuart Zuckerman, and granddaughter Kate Zuckerman. Also survived by son John and grandchildren Hannah, Max and Sam of Los Angeles. Private services were held. Donations may be made to the New York League for the Hard of Hearing, 71 West 23rd St., NY or to the University of Pennsylvania, 3451 Walnut Street, Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPNER, MARGARET LOEB
description: KEMPNER-Margaret Loeb. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Margaret Kempner, a cherished friend and beloved leader, who was a lifetime trustee of UJA-Federation. Mrs. Kempner expressed her unwavering commitment to Jewish and humanitarian causes through her dedicated efforts on behalf of our Women's Campaign, and our beneficiary agencies. She leaves a legacy of helping improve the quality of healthcare for children and the elderly in the Greater New York area. Mrs. Kempner's philanthropic spirit and generosity will continue to touch the lives of many for years to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Kempner's children and their families, and to the entire Kempner and Loeb families. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Joan Ginsburg, Women's Campaign Chair

title: Rangers Beaten in Overtime
description: Without Eric Lindros, who is recovering from a concussion, and Mark Messier, who has an injured left shoulder, the Rangers were less than six minutes away from being shut out and failing to earn a point for the third straight game.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip Makers Slow Upgrades
description: Amid rising optimism about the Korean economy, South Korea's semiconductor manufacturers are still slashing funds for upgrading factories. The Korea Semiconductor Industry Association said Samsung Electronics, Hynix Semiconductor and a number of smaller companies would spend $3.5 billion on factories this year, down 9.3 percent from 2001. Nonetheless, South Korean manufacturers are increasingly gaining the upper hand in negotiating sales terms, said Yonhap, South Korea's semiofficial news agency. Shares in Hynix rose another 2.5 percent on the Korea Stock Exchange on expectations that Micron Technology would present an offer for all or some of its operations, while shares in Samsung Electronics, the world leader in memory chips, fell 2 percent. The Federation of Korean Industries said a survey showed business confidence at its highest level in seven months. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Long Reach of War in Afghanistan
description: Zameer Pasha, a 42-year-old Muslim, owns a small store in the heart of a Muslim neighborhood here. The store, Pan Plaza, sells American brands of soft drinks, ice cream and cigarettes, along with some locally made products, like cookies and chewing tobacco.

title: Pilot Says Officer's Actions Led to Refusal of Passage
description: The pilot of an American Airlines flight who refused passage to an Arab-American Secret Service officer on Christmas Day did so only after the officer became loud and abusive when his identity was questioned, said the pilot's report on the incident released today by the airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIG, HERBERT
description: WILLIG-Herbert. The National Officers of EMUNAH of America expresses its heartfelt grief at the untimely passing of our long time benefactor Herbert Willig, beloved husband of our esteemed Honorary President Toby Willig. Herbert was a friend to EMUNAH both here and in Israel. He will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. We extend our deepest condolences to Toby and the children Ruth, David and Joseph, and our lifelong members brother Jerry and sister Nettie Wertheim. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marcia Genuth, National President Melanie Oelbaum Honorary National President Shirley Singer, Exec Vice Pres

title: The Rose Bowl Loses Some of Its Luster, but Mystique Lingers
description: As a boy in Oklahoma in the 1950's, Larry Coker liked to watch the Rose Bowl on television. At halftime, he recalled, he would go outside and play with a football, alone, among his mother's bare and thorny rose bushes. More than most sports events, the game on New Year's Day had a mystique that appealed to boyhood dreams.

title: Sandler O'Neill to Start Nasdaq Trading
description: Sandler O'Neill & Partners L.P., an investment bank that had its headquarters in the World Trade Center, said yesterday that it would resume trading Nasdaq stocks on Jan. 22.

description: The California Lottery said yesterday that the Los Angeles office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, had been selected to handle the creative and media duties for its account, with spending estimated at $100 million over four years. The decision is pending final approval, which is expected, from the lottery commission.

description: An envelope containing a threatening letter and a suspicious powder was found today in the Capitol office of Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader. The substance was determined to be harmless, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said it suspected a hoax.

description: Dr. Helen Rodriguez-Trias, a pediatrician, educator and leader in the public health field, died on Dec. 27 at her home in Santa Cruz, Calif. She was 72.

title: Daschle, in Election-Year Drive, Assails Bush Economic Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 — Senator Tom Daschle, the capital's most prominent Democrat, accused the Bush administration today of causing the "most dramatic fiscal deterioration in our nation's history" by pushing through a major tax cut that eroded investor confidence and was "exactly the wrong solution" for fighting recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLNITZ, GEORGE J.
description: STOLNITZ-George J. Age 81 on December 18, 2001 in Bloomington, Indiana. He was an international expert on demographic trends, consultant to the United Nations, and a past president of the Population Association of America. Stolnitz graduated from the City College of NY and earned his PhD from Princeton. He joined the Indiana University Department of Economics in 1956. He is survived by wife Monique Stolnitz, daughters Cindy Heaton, Dr. Wendy Silverstein and Dia Stolnitz and brother Daniel Stolnitz.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: In A Switch, F.B.I. Endorses XP Patch
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation reversed course and said a free software patch offered by Microsoft does protect against serious flaws in the latest version of its Windows software. Microsoft acknowledged last month that a vulnerability in Windows XP could allow hackers to tamper with or destroy users' data files via the Internet, implant rogue software on PC's and even seize control of a user's operating system. Microsoft offered the fix on its Web site in December, when the vulnerability was discovered. A day later, the F.B.I. urged consumers to go beyond installing the fix and to disable some Windows features that could be affected. But officials at the F.B.I.'s National Infrastructure Protection Center, working with researchers at the CERT Coordination Center of Carnegie Mellon University, concluded that Microsoft's patch corrects the problem ''and affords substantial and adequate protection.''

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Senator Declines Run For Governor
description: Senator John B. Breaux, who had considered running for governor next year, said he would remain in the Senate. Mr. Breaux, a Democrat with ties to the Bush administration, would have been the front-runner in the race to succeed Gov. Mike Foster, a Republican stepping down because of term limits. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Unemployment Climbs to 5.8% in December, but Rate of Layoffs Slows
description: In a sign that the nation's job market may be beginning to stabilize, the government reported a moderate increase in unemployment today, as the economy shed 124,000 jobs in December.

title: Safeties Dismiss Rumors Concerning Their Future
description: Sam Garnes and Shaun Williams have heard all that speculation about what the Giants will do with them next year. As the sequence goes, Williams, whose four-year contract expires after Sunday's regular-season finale here against the Green Bay Packers, would stay and move from free safety to strong safety. Garnes would be dumped.

description: Now that the Justice Department has closed its criminal investigation of Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the matter shifts to a Congressional ethics panel that has long been accused of refusing to take action against one of its own.

As the crowd dispersed, relief officials said they had run low on food because shipments had been stolen by local warlords.

title: Freedom and Constraint In the Craftsman's Trade
description: Like fairy-tale siblings evicted from their parental home, the craftsman and the designer set out on divergent paths through the forest of modernity. The designer quickly found fortune and fame. Freed from the necessity of making things with his own hands, he had only to imagine; the magic of industrial technology would realize his ideas in wondrous quantities, and the genie of capitalism would sell his inventions all over the world.

title: Martin's Defense In Spotlight
description: Kenyon Martin was hardly the first defender to chase Michael Jordan fruitlessly around the court. As the numbers rang up like a video game until Jordan finished with 45 points on Monday night, Martin never asked for help, leaving the National Basketball Association's new defensive rules for someone else.

title: Israel Says It Seized Ship Carrying Arms to Palestinians, Who Deny It
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 4  The Israeli Army announced today that it had seized a ship in the Red Sea carrying 50 tons of arms intended for the Palestinian Authority, but the Palestinians said that assertion was false and intended to sabotage renewed efforts by Washington's Middle East envoy to get peace talks under way.

title: Jan Kott, 87, Critic and Shakespeare Scholar
description: Jan Kott, a Polish-American theater critic and expert on Shakespeare whose theories influenced some of the most innovative of modern theater directors, died on Dec. 22 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87 and formerly lived in Stony Brook, N.Y.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Civil Unions Withstand Challenges
description: The State Supreme Court rejected two efforts to reverse recent legislation that granted gay couples many of the rights and benefits of marriage. One claim, brought by town clerks who said that issuing marriagelike civil union licenses to gay couples violated their religious beliefs, was rejected in part because clerks could delegate the function to assistants. The other claim held that $1 bets made by some legislators about the outcome of a vote on the measure should have disqualified them. The court said that was a matter best left to the House.

title: Planning Your Own Straussfest: Where to Hear His Music Live
description: ichard Strauss: A Hero's Life?," a three- week festival featuring the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra and others, will run through Jan. 26 at the following locations: Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street; State Theater, 19 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick; War Memorial, West Lafayette Street, at Barracks Street, Trenton; the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, One Center Street, Newark; and Rutgers University, Martin Luther King Boulevard, Newark. Tickets range from $5 to $65. Information: (800) 255-3476.

title: Kelly Is Said to Be Planning Shift of Officers From Security to Crime-Fighting
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has decided to reduce the number of police officers at security checkpoints around the city as part of an effort to raise the number assigned to fighting crime, officials said yesterday.

description: Fashion Institute of Technology

title: Stocks Rally, With Nasdaq Climbing 3%
description: Technology stocks made strong gains yesterday, with the Nasdaq composite index rising more than 3 percent, as hopes for a quick recovery in profits grew despite mixed reports on the economy.

title: Clearing the Mines, One Precarious Step at a Time
description: PAUL HESLOP, a burly Yorkshire lad who vacated a boring bank job in London eight years ago for a global seek-and-destroy mission against unexploded landmines and the like, pops up in the doorway of HALO USA's new outpost near Lincoln Center, a flagon of anti-jet-lag coffee in one fist, a dummy landmine in the other.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Settlement Awaits Legislature
description: A federal judge said he would approve a $500 million settlement of the state's 27-year-old college desegregation lawsuit only after the full Legislature requested it. The judge, Neal B. Biggers Jr. of Federal District Court, said he wanted a joint resolution before committing the state to the deal to give more money to the state's three historically black universities. Lawmakers convene in regular session on Tuesday.

title: California Lottery to DDB Worldwide
description: The California Lottery said yesterday that the Los Angeles office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ), had been selected to handle the creative and media duties for its account, with spending estimated at $100 million over four years. The decision is pending final approval, which is expected, from the lottery commission.

title: Starwood Hotels Adds Deutsch to Roster
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide is expanding its agency roster by naming the New York office of Deutsch, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle advertising and media planning for the Sheraton and Westin hotel chains. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $30 million.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Local Review Urged For Casinos
description: Attorney General Richard Blumenthal has asked a federal commission to give state and local officials more influence on Indian tribes' public health, safety and other decisions affecting their casinos, as well as on plans to build casinos. Mr. Blumenthal sent a letter on Dec. 28 to the National Indian Gaming Commission on behalf of state governments in Nebraska, Nevada and South Dakota, but his remarks had significance for current and future Indian casinos in Connecticut. Charles F. Bunnell, deputy chief of staff for the Mohegan tribe, which operates the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, said the tribe was a sovereign nation not answerable to state and local officials. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICKERSON, EUGENE H.
description: NICKERSON-Eugene H. The Partners, Associates and Staff of the firm of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel express their profound sorrow at the death of Judge Eugene H. Nickerson. Judge Nickerson was a named Partner of the firm from 1970 until he was appointed to the federal bench in 1977. In his integrity, his grace and his dedication to public service and justice, Eugene Nickerson personified everything a lawyer should aspire to be. Our fond memories of his generous and gentle spirit will long survive him. We extend our condolences to his wife Marie-Louise, his daughters Mal, Lawrie, Stephanie and Susan, and to all other members of his family.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Cuts In State Service
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber said the state would be forced to cut spending on services including education and public safety to cover budget shortfalls. Governor Kitzhaber, a Democrat, is to release his plan for dealing with an $850 million gap in the current two-year budget of $12.3 billion on Monday. The Republican-led Legislature will take up the proposals in February. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: City Faces Challenge to Close Widest Budget Gap Since 70's
description: Suddenly, it's over. New York City's days of simultaneously cutting taxes, spending more and still managing to have billions of dollars left over at the end of each year have come to an abrupt halt, a victim of the recession, the fizzling of the Wall Street boom and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.

title: Harvesting The Riches Of Strauss
description: RICHARD STRAUSS is in the air. True, his works, attractive to performers and audiences alike, have always thrived. But they are ubiquitous these days in and around New York.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Knicks Rewrite the Disaster Script
description: It kept lining up as another Knicks' disaster, following the script almost to the letter. There was the double-digit lead the Knicks built in the first quarter and then lost in the second. There was the Knicks' sloppy ball-handling in the fourth quarter and the wrenching, edge-of-your-seat scenario near the end of regulation. And there was the hot start in overtime that gave the Knicks a 7-point lead with three minutes remaining.

title: Massachusetts Governor Enlists Aide For Election
description: After a long, frustrating search, Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift announced today that she had selected Patrick C. Guerriero, a 33-year-old former mayor and legislator who is openly gay, to be her candidate for lieutenant governor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, FLORENCE KENDALL
description: FISHER-Florence Kendall. Of New York City, Great Barrington, Fayston and formerly Palm Beach, on December 23, 2001. Service Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison and 73rd St, Jan 11, at 11 A.M. Contributions to Planned Parenthood of NYC, 26 Bleeker St, NY, NY 10012.

title: No Split Decision Needed: Miami Wins Title by Knockout
description: When the first Rose Bowl was played here a century ago, Michigan beat Stanford by 49-0. From the way the first half unfolded tonight, Miami looked as if it might defeat Nebraska by the same score in honor of the anniversary.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Nestl Expands Water Business
description: Nestl, the Swiss food company, said it had bought a 51 percent stake in Aqua Spring of Greece to expand its mineral-water distribution business for homes and offices. Aqua Spring has annual sales of about 2 million euros ($1.8 million), said Marcel Rubin, a Nestl spokesman. The company has about 30 percent of the Greek market for home and office water delivery. Nestle is expanding in what it calls high-growth areas: mineral water, pet food, ice cream and nutrition.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Kelly Apostolidis, manager for national media outreach at the Advertising Council, New York, was promoted to director.

title: Film Portrayals To Stir the Soul
description: An epic battle of good versus evil set in a prehistoric landscape; a brutal murder that prompts the victim's grief-stricken parents to consider vigilante justice for a killer who may get off with a light sentence; a struggle for dominance between two soldiers stranded in a trench between battle lines as media vultures descend: those are the themes of three of the most powerful films released for holiday consumption. Although it might appear otherwise, those films -- ''The Lord of the Rings,'' ''In the Bedroom'' and ''No Man's Land'' -- were all completed before the events of Sept. 11. Yet all three reverberate with a prescience that their creators could not have anticipated and convey what might be called a post-traumatic resonance.

title: DOW CHEMICAL SAYS IT WON'T MEET EARNINGS ESTIMATES
description: Dow Chemical said yesterday that it failed to meet its fourth-quarter earnings estimate of 10 to 20 cents a share as a slowing economy pinched sales and cut margins. The company, which will report full results on Jan. 31, did not provide other details. Despite the statement, shares of Dow rose $1.25, or 3.7 percent, to $35.44. The shares fell 7.8 percent last year. Michael Judd, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, said it was likely that earnings hit bottom in the fourth quarter. Dow, like other chemical companies, has struggled as world economies slowed.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK AGREES TO BUY A UNIT OF WEISS, PECK
description: Bank of New York said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the stock-and-bond clearing unit of the money manager Weiss, Peck & Greer for an undisclosed amount. The Weiss, Peck unit, which serves about 70 clients, will become part of Bank of New York's BNY Clearing Services subsidiary. The unit provides securities clearing, trade execution and settlement to broker-dealers, banks and other financial intermediaries. Weiss, Peck is a unit of the Rabobank Group of the Netherlands.

title: Small, Green and Seen On History's Front Lines
description: IT is called the Gator and it shows up, Zeliglike, in the photographs and videotape that will serve as historical records of our times. Agile and exceptionally stable, the small John Deere utility vehicle climbs piles of rubble at ground zero, hauling welding equipment, delivering meals and -- its grimmest task -- removing bodies. It was used at the airliner crash sites at the Pentagon and near Somerset, Pa., and was enlisted for wartime duty in Afghanistan.

title: JUDGE APPROVES CHAPTER 11 PLAN FOR CARMIKE CINEMAS
description: Carmike Cinemas won a judge's approval yesterday of a Chapter 11 recovery plan that restructures about $650 million in debt and allows the company to come out of bankruptcy independently. Carmike, which has more than 300 theaters in 35 states, sought Chapter 11 protection in United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware in August 2000 after failing to make $9 million in interest payments to bondholders. At the time, the chain, based in Columbus, Ga., operated 448 theaters with 2,860 screens. The recovery plan, filed in October, will pay $263 million of Carmike's bank loans and $200 million in senior subordinated notes using a combination of new debt and cash.

Mr. Klatten's WKB Beteiligungsgesellschaft will buy 36.2 million shares from the company's founder and former chief executive, Thomas Haffa, EM.TV said. ''WKB is going to sign a contract with a renowned venture capital company in the days ahead,'' Mr. Klatten said in a statement. The name of the company will be disclosed later this month, he added, but he did not provide a date.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Inquiry Into Conservatives Dropped
description: Prosecutors in Munich dropped an inquiry into the Bavaria-based Christian Social Union, the sister party to the conservative Christian Democrats, the country's main opposition party. They said there were no grounds to investigate a report in the magazine Stern that said that the party had improperly obtained federal matching funds by counting subscriptions to party newspapers as donations. The senior prosecutor, Horst Lehmpuhl, said the practice had been approved by Parliament. Party officials said the accusations were part of a smear campaign against the party leader, Edmund Stoiber, who is a leading candidate to run for chancellor in September. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Consumer Confidence Falls
description: Consumers in New York City turned gloomier in December, even as their counterparts upstate and across the nation grew cheerier, according to a monthly survey of consumer confidence, an important economic indicator. The index for the New York City metropolitan area fell by almost six points in December, to 79.6; meanwhile, the upstate index rose by almost three points, to 78.8. But both levels are much lower than the national confidence index, which rose almost five points last month, to 88.8. The study was conducted by the Siena College Research Institute, in conjunction with the University of Michigan. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sirius Offering Draws $158 Million
description: Sirius Satellite Radio said yesterday that it expected to gross nearly $158 million in a stock offering scheduled to close Tuesday. The new funds should sustain its operations into the second quarter of next year, the company said. The offering price was $9.85 a share, less than half the $21 a share the company commanded when it sold 10 million shares last February. The Sirius network, which includes 100 channels of digital radio programming, is to begin limited service next month and is expected to be available nationwide by the third quarter. Sirius is highly dependent on the willingness of auto companies to equip cars with digital receivers. Only a few luxury vehicles are currently equipped to receive the signals. The stock sale, managed by Lehman Brothers, removed doubts about Sirius's near-term financial condition but reminded shareholders that much more money will be needed to carry the company into 2005, when analysts expect its revenues to finally catch up with spending. The company's shares fell $1.42, or 13.1 percent, to $9.46. Coincidentally, shares of Sirius's main rival, XM Satellite Holdings, fell 8.5 percent, to $15.59, after a report in The Wall Street Journal questioned the expense and signal reliability of XM's service, which began in November. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

Most of Anacomp's creditors agreed to support a recovery plan under which the company's bonds and shares were canceled. Bondholders, owed more than $310 million, got new Class A shares representing a 99.9 percent stake in the company. Anacomp's shareholders received new Class B shares amounting to a 0.1 percent stake, subject to dilution by management stock options.

Mr. Rubin's quotation, with the omitted passage shown in brackets, was: ''I am just convinced that there is no difference between $22 and $23. Let's face it[, if you want a book in translation from a Czech writer, you are going to buy the book] -- price is not a factor if it is a book that you really want.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: England: Higher Interest Rate Possible

''If the world economy begins to pick up as I suspect it will from the middle of the year, then consumer demand will have to moderate,'' Sir Edward told the BBC. ''We may have to actually act to cause it to moderate if it doesn't happen of its own accord, and that is when we would be putting up interest rates.'' Sir Edward is the first head of a major central bank to say rates might rise this year as the global economy picks up.

For nearly 16 years Gilles had been Secretary-Treasurer of the OPEIU representing 145,000 workers throughout the United States and Canada. Gilles Beauregard's devotion to OPEIU and the labor movement began in 1959 when he became President of OPEIU Local 57 in Montreal, Canada. He became Business Representative of OPEIU Local 57 in 1962, Regional Representative of the Eastern Canada Council in 1965, Regional Director of Ontario in 1976, International Vice President OPEIU 1980, Secretary-Treasurer of the OPEIU 1986. His leadership, dedication and strength of character will be missed. We send our condolences to his family and friends. Musicologist, critic, ambassador for opera and the symphonic repertoire, he was a man of extraordinary learning and culture and lent special distinction to the music program at Queens College. His family has suggested that contributions in his honor be made to the Edward Downes Scholarship Endowment, established at his retirement by the Aaron Copland School of Music (Queens College, Flushing, New York 11367).

title: The Challenge in Afghanistan
description: The new year in Afghanistan has opened in an atmosphere of relative stability that seemed unimaginable a few months ago. An interim government under Hamid Karzai controls Kabul, while its allies are more or less in charge of the rest of the country. Humanitarian assistance is flowing to some, although not all, of the places where it is needed. President Bush has made a welcome commitment not to abandon Afghanistan to its feuding warlords as the United States did a decade ago. But it is also becoming clear that rebuilding Afghanistan will be more challenging than prosecuting the war.

title: Times Plans Art Auction For Neediest Cases Fund
description: Reacting to a decline in charitable donations after Sept. 11, The New York Times Company Foundation announced yesterday that it would have an art auction this month featuring the works of 14 well-known New York City artists and that the proceeds would go to The Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Justices to Address Limits of Bus Searches
description: Although the Supreme Court has decided many cases growing out of encounters between police officers and bus passengers, the constitutional ground rules for these tense interactions remain unclear. Today the justices agreed to try again to define the boundary between a search to which a bus passenger has freely consented -- and that is therefore permissible despite the absence of a warrant or probable cause -- and one that is inherently coercive and therefore an unconstitutional seizure.

title: Bush's Policy on Argentina Signals Shift in Approach
description: Seven years ago this month, President Bill Clinton's economic advisers told him Mexico was hours away from economic default and perhaps chaos on the streets. Mr. Clinton ordered an unpopular multibillion-dollar bailout, over the objections of Congress, but with the support of a prominent Republican governor, George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PURGESS, NORMA
description: PURGESS-Norma. On January 3, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Dear mother of Donald & his wife Linda. Cherished sister of Ida Anderson & the late Lillian Scalero & the late Herman Potter. Loving aunt of Beverly and Linda Potter, Patti Purgess and Ann Anderson. Services on Sunday, January 6, at 2:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Ballerina's Reverent Prayer And a Deadpan Comedian
description: ''Mozartiana'' and ''Symphony in C,'' two elegant ballets by George Balanchine, received their first performances of the New York City Ballet's winter season on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: DiFrancesco's Farewells Muted by G.O.P. Rivals
description: After a most difficult year as New Jersey's acting governor and 10 much better ones as the president of the State Senate, Donald T. DiFrancesco is leaving public life on Tuesday. He had planned a public farewell or two.

title: Lindros Appears Ready
description: The decision will be made Saturday after the pregame warm-ups at Mellon Arena, but it looks as though Eric Lindros will return to the Rangers' lineup Saturday afternoon against the Pittsburgh Penguins after missing a week with his seventh concussion.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Much very dangerous work remains to be done.''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES 6.1%. Crude oil prices climbed on reports that OPEC members and rival producers are beginning to make promised output cuts. The February contract rose $1.25, to $21.62 a barrel, in New York.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Removes Official
description: President Vladimir V. Putin dismissed the railways minister, Nikolai Aksyonenko, who is facing charges of misappropriating $2.3 million in government funds allocated for running the ministry and its vast railway network. Mr. Aksyonenko, 52, who wielded great power as a deputy prime minister in former President Boris N. Yeltsin's government, has said the actions against him are politically motivated. But the government press service said that Mr. Aksyonenko had handed in a resignation letter in which he said that he was morally responsible for problems in the ministry and that it would be better served by his departure. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Radio Host To Run For Governor
description: A popular conservative radio talk show host has taken a leave to run for governor. Larry Ahrens, 51, a Republican whose show on KKOB-AM in Albuquerque has been on mornings for 21 years, told listeners this week that he would seek a statewide office. He will not formally announce his bid before Feb. 1. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLMAN, SIDNEY
description: ELLMAN-Sidney. On January 3, 2002. Forever loved by daughter Joyce, son Michael and his wife Sue Ann, grandchildren Jared, Courtney and Chelsea. Sidney was a devoted husband of the late Jeanette and a loving father and grandfather, who served in the U.S. Navy during World War II. His love, understanding and guidance will be missed by all who knew him. Funeral services Sunday, January 6th at 12 noon, from Garlick-Riverside Chapel, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY.

title: Writer Who Was Jailed In Notes Dispute Is Freed
description: Vanessa Leggett, an aspiring author jailed for more than five months for refusing to hand over her research to a grand jury, was released today from a federal detention center when the grand jury's term expired.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the victims of a car accident in Herald Square misspelled the term for an enlightened person, depicted in a Buddhist statue in the apartment of one victim, Xiu-Ying Chen. It is a bodhisattva, not Buddhashiva.

title: Chaney's Words Spark Actions
description: It would have been difficult to blame Knicks Coach Don Chaney if his belief in his team wavered early in the third quarter against the Dallas Mavericks on Thursday night.

title: Tennessee Women Need Toughness Against UConn
description: Pat Summitt, master psychologist, assembled her unbeaten and virtually unchallenged Tennessee basketball team on Dec. 17 and told the players they were the worst rebounding team in her 27-year career with the Lady Volunteers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLVIN, ELINOR
description: COLVIN-Elinor. On Sunday, December 30, 2001. Born on February 24, 1944. Beloved wife of Stephen B. Colvin, M.D., devoted, loving & caring mother of Laurel Tanier, RN, NP, and Heather Colvin, M.D., cherished grandmother of Julia, beloved sister of Arlene Cheiken and daughter of the late Naomi and Jack Greneman. Mrs. Colvin was a graduate of Washington Square College of Arts and Science of New York University and a former elementary school teacher in New York City. Contributions in her memory can be made to either the Elinor Colvin Memorial Scholarship at New York University School of Medicine, C/O Stephen B. Colvin, M.D., NYU Medical Center, 530 First Avenue, Suite 9V, NY, NY 10016, or to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 30 West 26th Street, New York, New York 10010.

title: Farewell, Buddy
description: As soon as a friend e-mailed me with the news that Buddy, former President Bill Clinton's dog, had been killed by a car in Chappaqua, N.Y., Wednesday, I went straight to the Web for news. Buddy and I were, well, buddies, from my days as a White House speechwriter. Wandering the West Wing, he had always reminded me of my own beloved dog, now many years gone. Buddy may not have been the smartest pooch in the free world, but he was full of love and loyalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHALSON, HOWARD
description: MICHALSON-Howard. The City Athletic Club mourns with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Howard Michalson. Michael Todres, President

title: Toyota Says It Will Build Mexico Plant
description: The Toyota Motor Company announced plans yesterday to build a manufacturing plant in Mexico, a move analysts described as crucial to Toyota's attempt to displace Chrysler as the third-best-selling auto company in the United States market.

description: In percent

description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal Fight at Rink Nearly Severed Head, Doctor Testifies
description: In the trial of a father charged with manslaughter for beating another father to death after a youth hockey practice, a medical examiner testified today that the victim died when an artery at the base of his brain was ruptured in a blow that almost severed the head from the neck.

title: U.S. Says It Did Not Help Israel Seize Ship
description: The United States was involved in tracking the arms-laden ship seized by Israel on Thursday, but did not participate in its seizure, senior administration officials said today.

title: Crash Inquiry Is Focusing On the Pilots
description: Investigators looking into the crash of an American Airlines flight in Queens in November have so far found no pre-existing flaw in the jet's tail section and are now focusing on the performance of the pilots, who they believe triggered the airplane's wild rolling and yawing in the seconds before it went down.

title: HOSTILE FIRE KILLS FIRST U.S. SOLDIER SINCE WAR'S ONSET
description: An Army Special Forces soldier was killed today in a brief firefight in eastern Afghanistan, the first death of an American serviceman by hostile fire since the war started nearly three months ago, American officials said.

title: Focus Turns to the Threat of Terrorists Using Food Carts as Weapons
description: With everything including tennis shoes and plastic cutlery looming as potential safety risks in the skies, travelers, aviation and federal officials are expressing concern that another mundane device -- the cart for food and beverage service -- could be turned into a weapon.

title: Jets Know the Score When It Comes to Playing Oakland
description: There was something peculiar about today's Jets practice as they prepared for the Oakland Raiders and a chance to guarantee a playoff appearance: there was no extra security, no fears of a camera-laden helicopter spying on practice, and no paranoia.

title: A Day for Wise Men And Grateful Hearts; Parade in East Harlem Pays Tribute To Heroism in the Face of Disaster
description: Behold, Wise Men from the east came, bearing gifts for the newborn Christ child and, as it has for the last 25 years, El Museo del Barrio celebrated their arrival yesterday with the Three Kings Day Parade in East Harlem, starting on East 106th Street near Madison Avenue.

title: Spurrier Resigns As N.F.L. Beckons
description: Steve Spurrier, who in his dozen years as head coach at the University of Florida led the Gators to a national championship and six Southeastern Conference titles, resigned yesterday, saying he felt that his college coaching career was complete.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNITED DOMINION REALTY TRUST INC., Highlands Ranch, Colo., said it had bought the 75 percent stake it did not already own in three apartment complexes, two in Texas and one in Arizona, with a total of 794 units, from Credit Suisse First Boston, New York, the investment bank, for $46 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, BLANCHE S.
description: WEISBERG-Blanche S. Died January 3, 2002 at age 73. Deeply loved wife of Honorable Gerard M. and adored mother of Andrea and Roland Murphy and Dr. Bruce Weisberg. Beloved sister of Sarah and Abe Hochner. The lights of Bubbie's life, she is also survived by her 4 grandchildren, Roland II, Kyle, Zachary and Brianna. There are no words to describe the immense void left by her passing. Her devotion to family and friends was never ending and will always be remembered. Her warmth and caring will be with us forever. Contributions can be made to UJA Federation. Services will be held Sunday, 1:00 PM at Weinstein-GarlickKirschenbaum Chapels, Brooklyn.

description: Does genius exist?

description: AT THE END OF THE EARTH

title: Patriotism on the Cheap
description: Rudy and Judi are in Boca. Bulls have been sighted on Wall Street. Churchgoing is back down, and ''Portraits of Grief'' has been retired as a daily hymnal.

title: City Fires 3,500 Former Welfare Recipients
description: On the last day of the Giuliani administration, the city's departing welfare commissioner ordered the dismissal of more than 3,500 former welfare recipients now working at union wages for the city parks department, and withdrew the promise of such jobs from about 1,200 others who were reaching their federal welfare time limits last month.

title: Hearing Set On Bid to Put Terror Trial On Television
description: The judge presiding over the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, who is charged in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, has scheduled a hearing next week to consider a request from Court TV to show the trial, an idea that has won the partial approval of Mr. Moussaoui's lawyers.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Saving Sturgeon, And Caviar
description: Facing a possible ban on caviar exports, Russia and three other countries on the Caspian Sea have surveyed their sturgeon stocks and set fishing quotas, according to an Azerbaijani fisheries official. The United Nations agency in charge of monitoring trade in endangered species could ban caviar exports from Russia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan if they failed to follow a 12-month plan devised last summer to save the plunging sturgeon population in the Caspian, the primary source of black caviar. Poaching, pollution and oil drilling have decimated the sturgeon, scientists say. The countries have been allotted quotas for this year ranging from 423 tons of sturgeon catch and 32 tons of exported caviar for Russia, to 69 tons of sturgeon and 6 tons of caviar exports for Turkmenistan. Iran, the other country on the Caspian, is allowed unlimited exports because it controls the sturgeon catch in its waters. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Moscow Journal; Putting Sholom Aleichem on a Belated Pedestal
description: In a city where big and brash are the preferred order of the day, it is a small bijou of a monument, tucked away in a snowy courtyard just off one of old Moscow's most picturesque streets.

title: PPL PLANS TO CUT SPENDING ON NEW POWER PLANTS
description: The PPL Corporation said yesterday that it planned to cut its spending on new power plants by $1.3 billion and reduce its earnings forecasts because of lower electricity prices. The chances for gains in the power generation business ''are diminished from just a little while ago,'' the company's chief executive, William F. Hecht, said on a conference call. The company reduced its 2001 and 2002 profit forecasts to $3.35 to $3.45 a share. It had forecast earnings of at least $4 a share for both years. PPL canceled five projects in its home state of Pennsylvania and one in Washington State. PPL shares fell $2.56, to $32.34.

title: Chinese Race to Supplant India in Software
description: In the battle between India and China over the software business, India holds the edge. But if the recent invasion of Chinese trade and information technology delegations to Bangalore, India's software capital, is any indication, China is hoping to change that.

title: Mr. Torricelli's Ethics Problem
description: The decision by federal prosecutors to end their criminal investigation into Senator Robert Torricelli's finances without seeking an indictment was a big personal and political victory for the New Jersey Democrat, whose already favorable outlook for re-election has been considerably bolstered.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Increases 5.6% In First Days of New Year

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHERRY, JAMES E.
description: McSHERRY-James E. January 4, 2002. Beloved husband of Barbara. Loving father of Jennifer, James and Jack. Devoted brother of Alice and Anne. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, January 6, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Monday, January 7 at 10 AM, St. Francis of Assisi Church, Lower Chapel, 144 West 32nd Street, New York City.

title: Moe Greengrass, 84, King of a Sturgeon Shrine
description: Moe Greengrass, who became Manhattan's ''Sturgeon King'' when his father, Barney Greengrass, left him the family's Upper West Side shrine to smoked fish, chopped liver and a good joke, died on Jan. 1 in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Enron Agrees to Transfer Prized Pipeline to Dynegy
description: A risky eleventh-hour investment in the Enron Corporation paid off for the Dynegy Corporation late Thursday night when Enron agreed to transfer ownership of a prized gas pipeline to it.

title: With a Game to Play, The Vikings Fire Green
description: Dennis Green of the Minnesota Vikings was forced out yesterday by the team's owner, Red McCombs, three days before the final game of the National Football League's regular season. Green was criticized for losing control of his players during a tumultuous season in which the Vikings (5-10) will miss the playoffs for only the second time in Green's 10 seasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUTNAM, MARILYN
description: PUTNAM-Marilyn. On January 4, 2002. Trustee of Theatrical Wardrobe Local 764 I.A.T.S.E. Beloved aunt of Margaret and Emily Putterman. Her family and friends will miss her dearly. Services Monday, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Bank Transfers Protested
description: India's banking system was paralyzed yesterday as more than 500,000 bank employees struck to protest the transfer of 24 employees of Standard Chartered P.L.C. The country's currency and debt markets were affected. India's largest banking union, All India Bank Employees Association, which called the strike, said the transfer was forced on the Standard Chartered employees after they refused to accept a voluntary retirement plan. Bank unions, fearing large-scale layoffs, have been blocking the government's attempts to reform state-owned banks by selling them. A union leader said the strike was to deter Standard Chartered from further enforcing a policy of layoffs through forced transfers. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPER, WYATT
description: COOPER-Wyatt. January 5, 1978. Daddy and Carter within us always. Gloria and Anderson

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Airlines Report Smaller Decline In Travel
description: British Airways, Europe's No. 1 airline, said December passenger traffic fell 10 percent, less than the previous month, showing that demand is reviving following a decline after the Sept. 11 attacks. British Airway's traffic fell 18 percent in November. The improvement mirrored one reported earlier by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. KLM's December passenger traffic showed a decrease of 10 percent from the year-earlier month, compared with a decline of 18 percent in November. British Airways said December revenue, though down from last year, exceeded initial expectations after Sept. 11.

title: Jarvis Says St. John's Is Close
description: St. John's 77-54 loss to Pittsburgh on Wednesday night cast doubt on how competitive the Red Storm can be in the Big East. But Coach Mike Jarvis said yesterday that he was not frustrated or angry with his players and suggested St. John's was a few missed layups and a ''little better defense'' from defeating Pittsburgh.

title: Colorado Ski Packages
description: Colorado Resort Reservations, (888) 811-6363, which represents ski areas in Summit County (Breckenridge, Keystone, Copper and Arapahoe Basin) and the Vail-Beaver Creek resorts has rates as low as $82 a person a day with lift tickets. That price is for five nights (four day's lift tickets) in a two-bedroom condo in Breckenridge Jan 6 to 18 and Jan. 21 to Feb. 14. Contact www.breckenridge.rezrez.com . In Vail, five nights in the Evergreen Lodge in a one-bedroom unit (with four days' lift tickets) are $143 a person a night Jan. 6 to Feb. 5. Visit www.vail.rezrez.com .

title: Europeans So Eager for Euros, Stores and Banks Run Short
description: Soaring demand for euros is forcing many European commercial banks to order up more, and producing at least modest shortages of cash at stores and banks.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 3,119 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSEY, WANDA
description: RAMSEY-Wanda. On December 31. Survived by her loving husband, Robert, sister, Iza, and brother, Alain. Beloved mother of Gregory and Katia. Grandmother of Georgia and Claire, mother-inlaw of Howard. Aunt of Daphne, Barbara, Patrick and Nicholas. Loved by many friends & family. Service to be held at Church of St. John, Darien, CT. 2 PM, January 7. In lieu of flowers, please make donation to the Norwalk Emergency Shelter, 4 Merritt Street, South Norwalk, CT. 06854.

description: The Nets are on the prowl for a point guard to back up Jason Kidd.

description: PAPPELIS-Ruth. December 31, 2001. Loving cousin of Wendy Wall Shabsis and Nicolas Wolfers MacLean. A graduate of Barnard College and later became director of volunteers in healthcare services for many years. She was devoted to the humane care and rescue of animals. Friends may call Friday, January 4, 7-9 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Service Saturday 11 A.M. at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue at 80th St, NYC. Contributions in her memory may be made to an animal charity of your choice.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Restraining Order On Logging
description: A federal judge in Seattle granted a request by environmentalists on Thursday for a restraining order to halt logging on federal land in Oregon. The logging, in the Chu-aw Clau-she forest near Coos Bay, was supposed to have stopped last year while a court evaluated its effect on coho salmon. Judge Barbara J. Rothstein of District Court, responding to reports that logging was continuing, ordered the Lone Rock Lumber Company to comply with the December order by the Bureau of Indian Affairs, which manages the forest. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. Stronger-than-expected U.S. reports indicating the economy may have seen the worst of its recession sent the dollar higher against the euro. The dollar rose to 89.51 cents per euro from 89.96 on Thursday.

title: Democrat Assails Bush on Economy
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the capital's most prominent Democrat, accused President Bush and the Republicans today of causing the ''most dramatic fiscal deterioration in our nation's history'' when they pushed through a major tax cut last year.

title: Martin Faces Suspension As Nets Fall to Magic
description: For the second time in two weeks, the Nets' fiery forward, Kenyon Martin, hammered a superstar opponent late in the game, and because of the ensuing melee he will be suspended again.

title: AT&T Plans To Lay Off 5,000 Workers
description: In a continued attempt to reduce its costs, AT&T announced yesterday that it planned to lay off 5,000 employees this year. The company said it would take a charge of about $1 billion, before taxes, in the fourth quarter of 2001 to cover the costs of these layoffs and the costs of having already dismissed 5,100 employees.

title: Israel Seizes Ship It Says Was Arming Palestinians
description: The Israeli Army said today that it had seized a ship carrying 50 tons of rockets, mines, antitank missiles and other munitions meant for Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority, even as the Bush administration's envoy met with Mr. Arafat in the hope of strengthening his declared cease-fire with Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUASSI, NATALIE
description: SQUASSI-Natalie. Age 36 on Thursday, January 3, 2002 at her home in Red Bank, New Jersey. She was employed as the National Sales Manager, Lauren Division of Jones New York. Beloved wife of Christopher John. Cherished daughter, sister, friend and colleague. She will be forever loved and missed. Visitation will be from 12PM-4PM and 7PM-9PM on Sunday at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Monday at 9AM at the St. James RC Church, 94 Broad Street, Red Bank, N.J. Interment will be private.

title: Zero-Emission Quota on Cars Is Postponed for Two Years
description: The Pataki administration today postponed for two years, until 2004, a requirement that automakers devote a small percentage of New York sales to electric cars that do not produce air pollution. At the same time, the administration adopted a plan to encourage car companies over the next few years to sell large numbers of low-smog vehicles.

title: STORE CHAIN WILL CLOSE THREE OF ITS LAZARUS STORES
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the parent of Bloomingdale's, Macy's and other chains, will close three Lazarus stores in Indiana and Ohio, affecting 190 jobs. Employees at Washington Square Mall in Indianapolis; Tippecanoe Mall in Lafayette, Ind.; and Colony Square Mall in Zanesville, Ohio, were informed yesterday, the company said. The stores are expected to close in early spring, Federated said. Federated is based in Cincnnati.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZELDIN, BENJAMIN
description: ZELDIN-Benjamin. If tears could build a stairway and memories a lane, I'd walk right up to heaven and bring you home again. Happy Birthday, Darling. Love you. Beverly and Childre

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Bid For Stake In Insurer
description: Fiat said its insurance unit, Toro Assicurazioni, had made a formal offer to buy 24.4 percent of the insurer Fondiaria from Montedison, Italy's second-largest utility, for $566 million. Fiat said late Thursday that it would pay 6.73 euros, or $6.05, a share. Toro's offer comes after the Italian insurance regulator ISVAP said earlier this week that it opposed an existing plan for another insurer, Societa Assicuratrice Industriale, to raise its stake in Fondiaria to 30 percent. The board of Montedison has approved Toro's offer.

title: Rangers or the Mets? It's Up to Gonzalez
description: The Mets believe Juan Gonzalez wants to play for them, and now they have given him the chance to do so.

title: Soldier Killed in Firefight Had a Specialty in High Demand
description: Sgt. First Class Nathan Ross Chapman, the 31-year-old Special Forces soldier who became the first American serviceman killed by enemy fire in Afghanistan, never expressed much interest in the military as a youth, his father recalled tonight.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Charges In Children's Deaths
description: A mother of six is being charged with the murders of her three eldest children on New Year's Day. After the woman, Elvira Charley, 31, called the Navajo tribal police to say she had hurt her children, two girls, 11 and 9, and a boy, 10, were found dead of gunshot wounds. Three children ages 5 and under were unharmed. In an affidavit, Mrs. Charley said she was angry at her husband, who moved to Texas in the summer. The family's home had no running water, electricity or phone. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, LILLIAN J.
description: BERGER-Lillian J. Of Pompano Beach, Florida, formerly of Manhattan, passed away Thursday. Services will be held at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street on Sunday January 6, 2002 at 2PM.

title: Dayne's Performance Hindered Most by Lack of Chances
description: At the University of Wisconsin, Ron Dayne became the most productive running back in Division I-A history and won the Heisman Trophy. The jury is still out on his performance as a pro.

title: Low Rating for Rose Bowl
description: Miami's 37-14 trouncing of Nebraska in the Rose Bowl on ABC Thursday night produced the lowest-rated national title game since the Bowl Championship Series format began with the 1999 contests.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Dec. 28 about James Straine, a World Trade Center victim who was a Cantor Fitzgerald bond salesman with a passion for fishing, misstated his age. He was 36, not 38.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Philosophical Call For More Talks
description: The National League for Democracy, the leading opposition group in the former Burma, encouraged the military government to continue its dialogue with the party's leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. In an atmosphere of slight warming between the government and the opposition, the party Chairman, U Aung Shwe, said, ''There is no such thing as an eternal enemy or an eternal friend.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Buddy's Sad Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: A Slam That Helped Snatch The Player-of-the-Year Title
description: The race to become New York Player of the Year is usually determined by the final tournament, played between Christmas and the New Year in Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | New England: Too Much Fishing
description: The government overseers of New England fisheries have done too little to repair the damage of overfishing, a federal judge ruled in a lawsuit. Fishermen say they are constrained by catch limits, but the judge said current rules had not restored depleted stocks. Oceana, the environmental group that brought the suit, said stricter rules would benefit fishermen in the long run. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; How the Clip 'N Snip's Owner Changed Special Education
description: The people of Florence, S.C., know Shannon Carter as the owner of Shannon's Clip 'N Snip, a barber shop where the locals get haircuts and conversation. The Clip 'N Snip has room for seven barber chairs, but Shannon is limiting the business to two for the moment and renting out space until the economy improves enough for the barbering business to expand.

title: Nation's Unemployment Rate Rises to 5.8%
description: The unemployment rate continued to creep upward last month, though fewer Americans lost their jobs than in any of the previous three months.

title: Toms Has Great Day and Shares Lead
description: Even before his superb round at the Mercedes Championships, David Toms was in a terrific mood. He celebrated his 35th birthday today. He woke up on the beautiful island of Maui. And as a rabid fan of Louisiana State football, Toms was delighted to learn that Steve Spurrier had resigned as Florida's football coach.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Dec. 16 about the rising prices of books omitted necessary words in a comment from Stephen Rubin, publisher of the Doubleday Broadway group at the Random House division of Bertelsmann. The error was repeated in the Economic Scene column on Thursday. Mr. Rubin's quotation, with the omitted passage shown in brackets, was: ''I am just convinced that there is no difference between $22 and $23. Let's face it[, if you want a book in translation from a Czech writer, you are going to buy the book] -- price is not a factor if it is a book that you really want.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPNER, MARGARET LOEB
description: KEMPNER-Margaret Loeb. The Kempner Family in loving memory. Verizon and regional phone companies created in the 1984 breakup of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company are barred from selling long-distance service in some states until they prove that local-phone competitors have access to the lines and switches that they need to provide service.

title: Private Sector; Knights of the Citigroup Round Table
description: Deryck C. Maughan, the Citigroup vice chairman who was knighted last week, said the honor ''came as a great surprise.'' But Sir Deryck, a 54-year-old native of Consett in north England, is not the only Citigroup executive on the British throne's annual honors list. David Challen, vice chairman of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, Citigroup's European investment bank, was made a commander of the British Empire. And Sir Deryck is not Citigroup's first knight. Winfried F. W. Bischoff, chairman of Citigroup Europe, was knighted in 1999. Both men serve on the company's management committee, led by Sanford I. Weill, Citigroup's chief executive. Mr. Weill is not expected to defer to the two titled members of his board. Riva D. Atlas

Whenever I'd stomp onto the deck with a flashlight, they'd look at me blankly, then scamper away -- only to return a few moments after I had gotten back into bed. (Both disappeared shortly after the neighbor got a dog, and we got a cat.)

Animal rights advocates had asked for the restraining order on the grounds that the methods for killing the deer -- using high-powered rifles with silencers or catching deer with nets and firing bolts into their heads -- were dangerous and cruel. I'm expecting my period, and I'm not in the mood." Her sentence ends on a panicked note and I can feel the possibility of a good day collapsing inside her, how by mid-afternoon, even as she stands in the kitchen thermoconverting Just Like Beans, she will be wishing she could be traded in for her own improved substitute, a Just Like Lorraine. If only that were possible: just like her but not her at all.

title: In Search of an Extra-Long Life
description: Just when we had begun to think molecular biologists might be inching their way toward extending the human life span, we are confronted with a bit of bad news. A scientific paper published last week reports that an important protein that defends the body against cancer also promotes aging in mice. That could pose a terrible quandary for anyone in search of the proverbial fountain of youth. Reducing the levels of the protein, known as p53, might help us ward off the symptoms of aging -- but leave us highly vulnerable to cancer. That doesn't sound like a great trade-off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATHAM, EUNICE STUNKARD
description: LATHAM-Eunice Stunkard. Age 78, on Christmas Day at her home in Riverdale, NY. In a varied and accomplished life, she graduated from Wellesley College in 1945 and went on to work with displaced people after World War II with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, and was a volunteer for the Unitarian Service Committee, sending medical missions to war-torn countries. She later took a job in the creative department at J. Walter Thompson and worked there and with three other advertising agencies in key executive positions for the next 21 years. In 1970, she became headmistress of The Barnard School for Girls, her former high school in upper Manhattan. Before and after her retirement, she served on the school's Board of Directors and was active in many community affairs. Eunice was the wife of John R. Latham, an avid sailor who predeceased her in 1980 and with whom she cruised the Mediterranean in their 60-foot steel ketch ''Hebe.'' The daughter of Frances and Horace Stunkard, she is survived by her brother, Dr. Albert J. Stunkard of Bryn Mawr, PA; three stepchildren, Scott Latham of Chester Springs, PA, John Latham of Lancaster, PA, and Katharine Butler of Sarasota, FL, and two grandchildren, Luke Butler of New York City and Victoria Latham of Chester Springs. A service will be held at the Mahar Funeral Home (802-442-2516) in Bennington, VT, on Friday, February 8, with burial scheduled for the next morning in a family plot at Rosewood Cemetery in White Creek, NY. A memorial service will also be held at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church, 4765 Henry Hudson Parkway, on Sunday, February 10, at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the church (718-796-5560).

title: Music; Richard Strauss and Hitler's Reich: Jupiter in Hell

Hans Pfitzner, who had strived unsuccessfully to be the Fhrer's court composer, was lying low in shabby south German quarters. Carl Orff, who had composed an ''Aryan'' version of incidental music to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' to replace Mendelssohn's original, among other follies, lied to American denazification officers about having helped found the anti-Nazi resistance group White Rose. He was speedily rehabilitated. His friend Werner Egk, who had been an official in the cultural bureaucracy but who lacked Orff's opportune connections, took much longer to whitewash himself.
