title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDEN, DR. JEAN.
description: HARDEN-Dr. Jean. Died of cancer January 2, 2002, at Scripps Memorial Hospital, La Jolla. Memorial services for Dr. Harden will be held on Monday, January 7, at Mary Star of the Sea Catholic Church, 7727 Girard Ave., La Jolla, at 3:00P.M. Dr. Harden was a native of Rochester, NY. She began her modeling career at age 13 with Eastman Kodak Co. and B. Forman Dept. Store, later earning a scholarship to Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, NY where she studied fashion design. She was featured on the cover of numerous magazines including Parade, Look and Life. When she married she used her public relations flair to help her husband, Frank E. Harden, build two successful companies, Harden Furniture Co. and The Camden Wire Co. In the 1950s while working for Bausch and Lomb Optical, Ms. Harden was selected by the U.S. Government to participate in a tour of the Soviet Union to educate the USSR on ''what the women of the 50's were really like''. Her next career was on television. Her TV shows took her from Rochester to Miami where she had an early morning TV show, news spots, cooking demonstrations, interviews, exercise shows, and even did the weather. While in Miami Ms. Harden became one of the first woman stockbrokers in the state of Florida, catering to a large and mostly wealthy female client base. Dr. Harden moved to Italy in the 1960s where she lived and concentrated on her artistic talents. After 5 years she returned to the U.S., making her home in La Jolla, CA. She earned her Ph.D in art Therapy in the 1980s. Until 2001, she continued to teach art classes, most recently for the Parks and Recreation Department in Ja Jolla, encouraging new students to paint. Dr. Harden's paintings are in many outstanding private collections throughout the world. Dr. Harden was active in community activities and organizations including the San Diego Opera, The Museum of Modern Art in La Jolla, The Charter 100, ChildHelp USA, American Cancer Society, the American Lung Association, and the Food and Wine Club. Dr. Harden is survived by her two daughters, Sheila Harden of La Jolla, CA, and Michelle Sandler of Miami, FL., and three grandchildren, Andrea Harden, Matthew Sandler, and Nathaniel Sandler. The family requests that instead of flowers contributions be made to one of the following charities: National Jewish Medical & Research Center, 1400 Jackson Street, Denver, CO 80206; American Cancer Society, and ChildHelp USA San Diego Chapter, P.O. Box 2156, La Jolla, CA. 92038.

description: MOSSBERG-David, DDS. Age 96 of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Mamaroneck, NY, died peacefully on Friday, January 4, 2002. Dr. Mossberg was the beloved husband of Rose (nee Greenstein) for 55 years and loving father of Edie Medoff of Larchmont, Lori Curtis and son-in-law Tom Curtis of Philadelphia. He will be greatly missed by his grandchildren Daniel and Scott Medoff, Elizabeth McCullough and Lindsey Curtis. Dr. Mossberg was a retired orthodontist who graduated from the University of Pennsylvania School of Dentistry (Class of 1934) and completed his training in orthodontics at Columbia University. During his long and distinguished career he served as President of The Northeastern Society of Orthodontics and was an Assistant Clinical Professor of Dentistry at Mount Sinai School of Dentistry in New York City. He was a Diplomate of the American Board of Orthodontics and a Life Member of International College of Dentists, The First District Dental Society of NY, The American Dental Association and The American College of Dentists, where he was also a Fellow. He served his country as a Lieutenant in the Army during WWII. Dr. Mossberg had numerous and diverse hobbies ranging from jewelry making to golf. He was very humble about all his accomplishments, which included getting a hole-in-one at the Hampshire Country Club. Services are being held at the Beth Israel Memorial Chapel in Delray Beach on Sunday, January 6, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to The School of Dental Medicine, University of Pennysylvania, 40th and Spruce St., Philadelphia, PA 19104, or to a charity of your choice.

title: Music; A Visual Requiem That Inspired Rachmaninoff
description: MARIE BERNA, a young widow from Germany, wanted a picture to dream by: ''ein Bild zum Trumen.'' Such were her instructions to the Swiss painter Arnold Bcklin in Florence in the spring of 1880. Two months later, Bcklin sent her ''The Isle of the Dead,'' a desolate shell of cliff surrounded by waters still and dark, a stand of cypresses pointing skyward like fingers of a prophetic hand. Entrances are cut into the rock faces, as to a catacomb. In a rowboat in the foreground (the visual and emotional focal point of the composition), a figure swathed in white stands watch over a coffin also draped in white. A seated oarsman (no Charon) plies the oars. Strange to say, the boat with all it carries was an afterthought.

As Malcolm looks out the window and ponders the troubled state of the world, his friend rambles on about the insidious, destructive power of the bugs. There are many ways to interpret this odd, throwaway moment. Most obviously, it suggests an element of guilelessness in the young Ali, as well as the playful wit that was his surest weapon against all forms of pomposity. It may also remind viewers who only have memories of an older Ali of his appearances as a television pitchman for d-CON roach spray. Who could have known that those ads grew out of a long-standing interest in pest control?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, ANIELA (NELA)
description: RUBINSTEIN-Aniela (Nela). Died peacefully at her home in NY on December 31, aged 93. Our beloved mother will be missed by all of us; her children, Eva, Paul, Alina and John Rubinstein (Jane Lanier), her grandchildren Amy and David (Kristy Wiberg) Coffin, Jason (Amy Fransetic), Jessica, Michael, Peter and Jacob Rubinstein, and her great grandchildren, Alexander and Julian Coffin-Lennear and Linnea Coffin. She was born in Vilnius, Lithuania, the youngest child of Emil Mlynarski, composer, violinist, co-founder 1901 and first Conductor of the Warsaw Philharmonic, and later Director of the Warsaw Opera for 20 years. In her youth, she studied dance in Dresden with Mary Wigman. She was briefly married tothe pianist, Mieczyslaw Munz, who later taught at Juilliard. Her 50 year marriage to Arthur Rubinstein lasted until his death in 1982. They lived in Paris until the outbreak of WW II in 1939, when they were forced to leave, later joining the emigre artistic community in Hollywood. They became US citizens in 1946. After 1954 they reclaimed their house in Paris, and also maintained homes in New York and Spain. Our mother was known for her wonderful cooking, her memorable parties, her great charm, her elegance and beauty. She spoke seven languages, was immensely musical, sculpted, painted, and even embroidered with talent. She was a co-founder of the annual Polonaise Ball and played a major role in making it a highly successful event for the benefit of Polish Assistance, Inc. In 1983, Alfred A. Knopf published ''Nela's Cookbook,'' to the delight of her family and friends. It was later translated into Polish. We loved our sweet Ma, and we will deeply miss her spontaneity, her enthusiasm, her generosity, and her quirky humor. A celebration of her life will be planned for a later date.

title: QUICK BITE/Maplewood; O, Maplewood, We Stand On Guard . . .
description: I didn't know what to expect from a place in Maplewood called the Maple Leaf -- perhaps a Canadian theme restaurant? In my experience, Canadian cuisine consists mainly of doughnuts and beer. Canadians have also have developed a certain dry ginger ale. Yet, aside from Canadian bacon, the Maple Leaf has nothing to do with our neighbors to the north. The menu is that of a diner: every conceivable dish for breakfast, lunch and dinner, all at very reasonable prices. But the mood and spirit of the Maple Leaf is that of an old-fashioned Main Street U.S.A. family restaurant. If there wasn't a teriyaki wrap on the menu, you'd have no idea what decade it was. I tried a specialty sandwich -- the open sliced Romanian steak deluxe (with fries, $6.95). The manager explained that ''Romanian'' is just another name for marinated skirt steak. Regardless, this succulent sandwich is the best export from that country since Nadia Comaneci. My friend Joe ordered the grilled Cajun chicken sandwich (with bacon, mozzarella cheese, and fries, $5.55) and proclaimed it ''Tasty.'' (He did precede it with a word not fit for a family restaurant.) He also enjoyed an egg cream ($1.10). We both sampled the French onion soup ($2.95) served in a crock with melted mozzarella crusting over the sides. How else would it be served? Excellent food, generous portions, good prices, friendly servers and a pleasing atmosphere: Make-believe? No. Maple Leaf. Jack Silbert

description: KEMPNER-Margaret Loeb. The Kempner Family in loving memory. A memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El January 17th at 10:30 AM with a reception to follow at The Cosmopolitan Club. title: The Ups, Downs and Fine Print of Sector Rotation
description: THE bear market of the last two years has been painful for many mutual fund investors. But it has been relatively good to those who rotate through sectors.

title: A Life Off the Books, With an Eye for the Ladies
description: THE bar was dark and the piano man played. Tony Love sat propped against the leather banquette, the candlelight dancing across his face like the passing frames of a motion picture. He mouthed the words to an old tune he knew: ''I only have eyes for you.''

title: Gazeteer
description: -story, 3-family brick town house at 275A Wyckoff Street, $440,000.

title: Giants Play for Pride, While Packers Dream Big
description: If the Giants had played the Green Bay Packers on Sept. 16, as originally scheduled, it would have been viewed as an early-season meeting between an established power and an emerging one. In every sense, it would have been looked at as a measuring-stick game.

title: HOPE ON TRANSPLANTS
description: Scientists have long dreamed of transplanting animal organs in people, but have been stumped by the problem of immune rejection. Two biotechnology companies -- Immune BioTherapeutics of Charlestown, Mass., and PPL Therapeutics, the Scottish company behind Dolly, the cloned sheep -- have announced a possible solution: cloned pigs that lack a gene that prompts rejection. Hurdles remain before pig organs can be tested in humans. Sheryl Gay Stolberg

title: The Art of Woodworking
description: Anyone who has ever wondered how to choose the right chisel or tune a handpane might want to join the nearly 10,000 people expected to visit the North Jersey Woodworking Show at the Garden State Exhibit Center, 50 Atrium Drive, Somerset, from Jan. 11 to 13.

description: To the Editor:

title: New S.E.C. Rule Starts a Name Game
description: AS if it weren't hard enough to tell one mutual fund from another, many sponsors have decided that certain names just don't work anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, SAMUEL III,
description: SLOAN-Samuel III, 82. A former member and Governor of the New York Stock Exchange, and former Vice President and Director of Hayden, Stone, Inc. died on December 16, 2001 at Jupiter, FL. During World War II, Mr. Sloan was an aircraft commander of a B-24 lead crew in Italy and served 35 missions. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with Three Oak Leaf Clusters. Born in New York, he attended the Buckley School and later Groton School and Cornell University. Mr. Sloan was the husband of the late Marion Baker Sloan, father of Samuel Sloan, Jr., Ellen V. Sloan and Marion B. Sloan; stepfather of Cynthia T. Powers, the late Jay D. Titus and Dorothy D. McFeeters; grandfather of Samuel Colt Sloan and great grandfather of Samuel Colton Sloan. A Funeral Service will be held, 10AM, January 11, 2002 at St. Georges-by-the-River, Rumson, NJ, followed by interment at Fairview Cemetery, Middletown, NJ.

title: Jobs That Travel
description: William M. Adler, who traced the crack cocaine trade in his first book, ''The Land of Opportunity,'' has taken another look at American society, this time examining how manufacturing jobs move from place to place. ''Mollie's Job: A Story of Life and Work on the Global Assembly Line'' (Scribner, $27.50), starts with Mollie James, who moved to Paterson from the South in the 50's and went to work a manufacturing plant in Paterson making fluorescent light parts and heading the local union, the first woman and one of the first African-Americans to hold the position. Then it traces the job as it reverses Mollie James's journey, leaving Paterson in 1989 and heading to the South, to a factory in Mississippi, and then, under the free trade agreement between the United States and Mexico to Matamoros, Mexico. By looking not only at the job but also at the women who hold it, Mr. Adler puts a human face on global economics. He indicts ''free trade'' for exploiting workers -- and for harming places like Paterson in the process. Karen DeMasters

title: Thrift Amid the Squalor, Ego in the Skyline
description: FIVE POINTS

title: The Color of Consensus
description: AMERICAN travelers have long joked that European banknotes, with their bright colors, varied sizes and Dada designs, have all the gravitas of Monopoly money. But last Tuesday, these fanciful and vibrant expressions of cultural identity were replaced by the euro, a somewhat more vanilla byproduct of the design-by-diplomacy method that characterizes nearly every aspect of a unifying Europe -- and nostalgia began to set in.

title: Art/Architecture; Images That Are Glorious And Gloriously Unreal
description: THE basement of the old Peabody Museum here is crammed with the kind of treasures you would expect from an institution with roots going back to the 18th century and with close ties to the China trade. A cannon here. A large gilt eagle there. Vintage clocks and ships' models. Ships' figureheads, including one photographed by Walker Evans in the 1930's. A cluster of life-size, 19th-century plaster figures of people from India. And so on.

title: Amanda Titton, Ross Charno
description: Amanda Titton, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Barry S. Titton of Margate, N.J., was married last evening to Ross Charno, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Steven H. Charno of Great Neck, N.Y. Cantor Robert P. Abelson officiated at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del.

title: After Sharing Highs and Lows, a Goodbye
description: JAMES D. OBERWEIS, who parlayed his milk money into a money management business, has decided to take a break to run for the Senate from Illinois.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMANO, GENEROSO
description: ROMANO-Generoso. On January 2, 2002. Loving husband of the late Lucille Romano. Cherished father of Audrey Napolitano and Geraldine Scoll. Dear father-in-law of Joseph Napolitano and David Scoll. Adored Pop of Jason and Melissa Napolitano and Brett S. Perryman. Rest in peace, love and light, sweet, good Pop. Visiting hours Sunday, January 6, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Peace Chapel, at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, 10 AM on Monday, January 7. In lieu of flowers and in gratitude for our parents' gift to us of loving, happy childhoods, contributions may be made to the Make A Wish Foundation, 828 South Broadway, Tarrytown, New York 10591. Gerri Scoll Audrey Napolitano

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AKERMAN, SIMONE
description: AKERMAN-Simone. On January 3, 2002. Beloved wife of Adrian. Loving daughter of Annette and Joseph. Her unwaving devotion and affection will be missed by her family, friends, colleagues and students. Services Sunday at 12:30 PM at ''Parkside Chapels,'' 98-60 Queens Boulevard.

title: Great Expectations From Some Investors
description: After two years of stock-market declines, most people investing for retirement expect only single-digit returns for the next year or two but are counting on long-term annual returns of at least 15 percent, a new study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MARION J.
description: BROWN-Marion J. On December 29, 2001. Beloved wife of Bernard. Devoted mother of Diane and Fred Robison, Barry and Ilene and Steven and Deborah. Cherished grandmother of Matthew, Jennifer, Heather and Jake. Services were held Monday, December 31, 2001. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made in her memory to the Oceanside Counseling Center, 71 Homecrest Avenue, Oceanside, New York 11572.

title: 'Alive and Kicking'
description: Lisa Ciardi was apprehensive that first day. Doubt hovered over her carefully executed plan like an overcast sky. Did she really believe that a handful of women who were preoccupied with work and kids, with leaks and lawns, would have time for what was, to them, a child's game? What would these women, most of whom she barely knew, think of her if they all felt foolish, or inept, trying to dribble a soccer ball? On the other hand, Lisa also wondered if they'd even show up.

title: Internecine Warfare Erupts Among Liberals
description: So much for political alliances.

description: Robin says that the discussion of Atta's possible homosexuality ''turns the national spotlight away from other evidence of what drove him.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WETZEL, RAYMOND A.
description: WETZEL-Raymond A. Died November 21, 2001. Survived by his daughters, Barbara, Lois, Janine and Kathy, a sister, Barbara Wetzel. Please call 718-499-4494.

title: Correspondence/Plus ca Change . . .; Russia's Leaders Are Different. It's the People Who Are the Same.
description: FOR someone who has known Russia for 20 years, but who lived in the West in the 1990's, perhaps the most striking thing about Vladimir V. Putin's Moscow is how familiar it feels.

title: Camby's Passion Leading to Success
description: It was the most animated and energetic that Marcus Camby has been this season, but it did not come after one of his spectacular slams of a Mark Jackson lob, or when he was swatting one of his four blocked shots away from the basket.

title: Testaverde and the Jets Face a Defining Moment
description: Vinny Testaverde tried a bit of levity, something to soften all the hard edges that had been bared last week.

description: EVERY day the memorials continue for the dead of Sept. 11.

title: Why Parisians Love the Loire
description: The Loire's cheerful reds, endlessly versatile with food, largely elude America's attention. Philippe Delesvaux's 2000 Anjou, redolent of cherries and herbs, explains Paris bistros' love affair with the region. The importer is Jeroboam, owned by Montrachet's wine director, Daniel Johnnes, a discriminating Francophile. Nancy's Wines for Food, 313 Columbus Avenue (75th Street), Manhattan, asks $12. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: E-ZPASS DEBT
description: Edward Gross, director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, has indicated he may resign at the request of Gov.-elect James McGreevey as a result of escalating debt of the problem-plagued E-ZPass system. The Turnpike Authority is the lead agency for installation of the electronic toll collection system. A report by an independent auditing group released last week showed the debt projected for the system by 2008 had climbed to $162 million, up from a previous calculation of $65 million. When E-ZPass was installed, it was said that the fines from toll cheaters would pay the cost of the system. In a written statement issued on Wednesday, Mr. Gross said: ''It is the prerogative of the incoming governor to request the Turnpike Authority Board of Commissioners to select a chief operating officer of the Governor's choice. [I] entered public service knowing it is not forever.'' He said he would confer with the turnpike board this month. Karen DeMasters

title: Author Admits He Lifted Lines From '95 Book
description: The historian Stephen E. Ambrose acknowledged over the weekend that he had copied sentences and phrases in his best-selling book ''The Wild Blue'' from another historian's earlier work. He apologized and said the repetition had been inadvertent.

title: Tax-Sheltered Funds For the Conscience
description: JOHN DENSMORE made a fortune as a drummer pounding out a beat behind Jim Morrison for the Doors, the legendary 1960's rock group.

title: Trolleys
description: To the Editor: Frank J. Prial's endearing ''New Life for Old Trolleys, (Dec. 9) about trolleys on San Francisco streets should not leave New Yorkers wanting for the thrill. Only 80 miles away, the Shore Line Trolley Museum, at East Haven, Conn., contains about 100 antique streetcars, including a vintage subway car from each of the boroughs of New York.

title: Theater; Sounding Better As Time Goes By
description: WITH sensible work routines, good health and some luck, conductors and instrumentalists often get better as they get older. But singers, like dancers and athletes, have to face the facts of bodily decline. Over the years, the voice inevitably fades.

title: Style in a Hotel Shop
description: Don't even think of calling it a gift shop. W the Store, the first boutique in a W Hotel, is a style shop, says one of its creators, Troy Halterman, the design guru who owns Troy, a trendy modern-furnishings store in SoHo. Mr. Halterman is working with Stephen Werther and Tammy McNamara, who started the Portico chain together and who say they want to offer goods that a hip person would want to have. The new shop, which is Lucite filled and opened the last week of December, has limited-edition Pumas and Kate Spade bags, Givenchy handbags, hand-lacquered toys from France, vellum cigarette box slipcovers, sleek cameras by Leica, retro Wagenfeld glass tea sets, funky skateboards, art books, Fabien Baron playing cards, TechnoMarine diving watches and home and pet accessories. Open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. (to midnight on Friday and Saturday).

description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: It's a Wonderful Night
description: I always enjoy the slice-of-life feature that closes each magazine, but Susan Burton's Lives column (Dec. 23) about Jess Tirado was truly sublime. How fortunate we are to live in a city with public places as grand as Rockefeller Center and neighbors as warm-hearted as Mr. Tirado. I'd just like to know, what are the ''good tunes'' he listens to as he drives the Zamboni?

description: WESTERN ASSET MANAGEMENT may be the most obscure big bond manager in the United States.

description: Medicare began to cover nutrition therapy services for elderly people with diabetes or serious kidney disease, and if the investment pays off, Congress could decide to extend coverage to other Medicare beneficiaries. Dietitians said nutrition therapy could save money for Medicare and improve the quality of life for patients. Robert Pear

description: Senator Trent Lott is quoted as saying ''when you say home, I think of a free-standing building. I never thought of [high-rise apartments] as homes.'' One wonders what else he doesn't ever think about.

title: Show Us The Money
description: If America's love affair with New York City is fading, a large part of the blame can be placed on Senator Clinton (Frank Bruni, Dec. 16). If she had a fraction of the political savvy that Senator Schumer has, the city would be holding a blank check right now.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 4 of Arts & Leisure today about the singer Barbara Cook gives an incorrect spelling from the press office for her show ''Mostly Sondheim'' for the name of the show's bassist. He is Jon Burr, not John.

title: Lima Street Vendors Caught Between Police and Poverty
description: Even at a time of death, the street vendors abound. As hundreds of mourners streamed through El Angel cemetery to bury the victims of last Saturday's fire, eager salesmen stood in the sun hawking food, soda, car washes, Bibles and even photographs of every newly filled tomb.

description: MOVIE LOVE IN

title: The Nation: Foul Ball; Somewhere the Bambino Is Smiling
description: THE recent sale of the Boston Red Sox attracted little notice in New York, and probably wouldn't have even if New Yorkers hadn't had other things on their mind. Who are the Red Sox, after all, except another team that gets beat by the Yankees? But in Boston, where the Sox are no mere ball club but a civic and cultural institution, the story was front-page news and the occasion of public lamentation. ''Sleazy,'' ''sordid,'' ''bag job'' were among the kinder descriptions in the local press of the deal that will eventually hand over the Sox to a group headed by John Henry, a Florida financier and owner of the Florida Marlins, and Tom Werner, a Hollywood television producer and creator of ''Roseanne.''

title: Huge Decline Seen In Budget Surplus Over Next Decade
description: Analysts from both parties say the budget surplus for the next decade has shrunk to less than a third of what was projected a year ago, setting up an especially intense partisan battle over taxes and spending in the midst of an election-year recession.

title: Housecleaning at Ailing Funds Is Light, So Far
description: AFTER two years of shabby performance for America's growth-stock funds, the housecleaning has begun.

title: Bears and Mice: From Grizzly to Curious
description: IT has no monkey and ''Curious George,'' no elephant and ''Babar,'' but the ingenious exhibition, ''The Real and the Imagined: Animals in Children's Book Illustration'' at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich is an absorbing, sometimes marvelous experience.

title: Investing on Autopilot? There's a World of Choices
description: SINCE the Vanguard Group created the first mutual fund tracking the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index more than 25 years ago, the logic behind the idea has been so compelling that investments in index funds have grown to over $300 billion.
nbsp;

title: After Clashes, Minister Quits His Post in Italy
description: Italy's foreign minister, Renato Ruggiero, resigned today over his latest disagreement with the center-right government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, a government he had accused of undermining the launch of the euro and European unity in general.

title: Court Foils Rent-Rise Formula
description: TENS of thousands of tenants in rent-controlled apartments in New York City received good news last month when the state's highest court ruled that landlords may not calculate rent increases in a way that could have amounted, retroactively and going forward, to thousands of dollars per apartment.

title: The View From/Monroe; Pet Pigs Raise a Ruckus With Police and Neighbors
description: A MONROE resident and retired firefighter has been in the Bridgeport Correctional Center since a Dec. 12 altercation with police, who went to his home with a search-and-seizure order and removed two pigs that the man, Stanley Czupkowski, was keeping as pets.

title: Corrections
description: The Dining Out column on Dec. 23, about the Bayport House, misstated the name of one restaurant for which the chef, Joseph Felicetta, formerly worked. It was Fusion Grill in East Setauket; Metropolis opened at the site after Mr. Felicetta left.

title: Harvard President Brings Elbows to the Table
description: It was undoubtedly the most negative publicity Harvard University's new president, Lawrence H. Summers, had received in his six months on the job. A dust-up with the professor Cornel West and complaints that Mr. Summers had snubbed or disappointed other celebrated black scholars raised the possibility that Harvard would lose the stars of its Afro-American studies department.

title: Abolish the Board of Education
description: In New York the river that separates City Hall from 110 Livingston St. might as well be an ocean. The city provides nearly half the money for the city's multibillion-dollar school system, yet the mayor appoints only two members of the seven-member Board of Education, whose headquarters is on Livingston Street in Brooklyn. And if he tries to offer suggestions on education policy or school operations, that's considered political meddling.

title: Swifter, Higher, Stronger, Safer
description: WHETHER organizers admit it or not, the goal of every Olympics is to win recognition as bigger, better and more memorable than the previous effort. That could well become true of the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics on the first two counts. It cannot miss on the third -- for reasons that have little to do with skiing or skating.

title: Lehman Bros. Grapples With Arts Zoning Rules
description: There exists in the theater district a careful mishmash of commerce and culture, and a complex set of zoning rules governs them both. These rules are also meant to protect the needs of residents. Such equilibrium is easily unsettled.

title: Palais Royal
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Catharine Reynolds's article about the Palais Royal ''By the Louvre, Bibelots, Brocade and Foie Gras'' (Dec. 9), but for visitors to Paris on a slightly trimmer budget, the Palais Royal has some less rarefied treats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHALSON, HOWARD ALAN
description: MICHALSON-Howard Alan. On January 3, 2002, at age 72. Respected securities broker with Lehman Brothers for 41 years and most recently with UBS PaineWebber and served as a U.S. Naval officer. Beloved husband of Lynn (Morris), loving father of Douglas Michalson and Beth Fiore. Dear brother of Robert and brother-inlaw of Nancy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Saturday, January 5th, 7-9PM with service Sunday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or the Central Park Conservancy.

title: McGreevey Chooses His Attorney General
description: Governor-elect James E. McGreevey of New Jersey yesterday nominated David Samson, an Essex County lawyer with long experience in state government, as attorney general, and named Peter C. Harvey, a former federal prosecutor, as the state's first assistant attorney general.

title: About 'A Nation Challenged'
description: On the last day of 2001, ''A Nation Challenged'' made its final appearance as a separate section of The Times. The events of Sept. 11 and their aftermath -- terrorism, war, trauma and recovery, the search for causes and solutions -- have become woven into all aspects of national and international life. The New Year provided an occasion to reflect that evolution by incorporating the coverage into the newspaper's main sections.

title: These Days, The Swagger Belongs To Boston
description: In more prosperous times, Allan Houston and Latrell Sprewell would shake off miserable starts, find their strokes and their swagger, and eventually rescue the Knicks from a deflating loss. But as fourth-quarter leads keep evaporating and once-struggling franchises like the Boston Celtics keep competing, that vaunted 1-2 Knicks offensive punch is no more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, FREDA (CHUB)
description: SHAPIRO-Freda (Chub). On Jan. 4, 2002, peacefully at home in San Diego, California. Loving widow of the late Charles Shapiro, beloved mother of Daniel J. Shapiro, mother-in-law of Shayne Raze.

title: The Importance Of Being Ernie
description: It helps, when you have a handful of four-foot tunas that you caught that morning (weighing what you call an honest 45 pounds each), to have a neighbor who is a sushi chef. And it would help, when you're trying to cook up wild boar that you killed a few months ago and a couple of dozen sea urchins and lobsters that you dove for yesterday, to have a kitchen as big as an art gallery instead of an art gallery with a bit of a kitchen. And it would help, if you're a third-generation hunter, sport fisherman, diver and self-described addict of Africa, not to be named Ernest. Especially since there was this other Ernest who made just such passions into very famous literary fodder.

title: ZAMBIA'S UNEASY TRANSITION
description: With opposition parties crying foul and protesters taking to the streets, Zambia inaugurated a new president. Levy Mwanawasa, a former vice president, was the handpicked successor of the former president, Frederick Chiluba. But Mr. Mwanawasa's victory was marred by complaints of ballot stuffing and vote tampering. Rachel L. Swarns

title: Private Sector; A Trial by Snowstorm, And It's Not on Court TV
description: When the weather is so bad that it nearly shuts down the Weather Channel, that could become cause for alarm. But executives at the channel, based in Atlanta, said they were never in any danger of going off the air from the snowstorm that hit the South last Thursday. Ultimately, they got more for less.

title: Rub On the Pomegranate
description: The pomegranate, one of the world's oldest fruits, has become the beauty industry's newest darling. Its slightly astringent properties, hydrating powers and light scent can now be found in a variety of products, among them exfoliating scrubs and fragrances. This month, Origins introduces Pomegranate Polish, above, a red body scrub intended to smooth and refresh winter-weary skin. Murad puts pomegranate in both sunscreen ($23) and self-tanner ($21), and Bottoms Up combines it with Champagne in a hair shine rinse ($16.50), all at Sephora. Santa Maria Novella offers a moisturizing bath soap ($38 for a set of four bars, at www.eluxury.com), while beComing makes a Clean Gesture hydrating foam cleanser ($12 at the Avon Spa). And Comme des Garons uses top notes of pomegranate in its White perfume ($60 at Barneys New York), and so does Fresh in its scented Pomegranate and Anise Index candle ($40 at Fresh). The profusion of this ''apple of many seeds'' might almost be enough to lure Persephone out of the underworld again -- just in time for spring.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Alain van den Broek, Joana Garcia Ruiz, Marie Jeanne Ameels Planchon, Brussels, Dec. 7, 2001

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Peter Boyle; Drop a Cue, He Grabs It
description: HE had looked out the windows of his apartment high above East End Avenue on thousands of nights. But last week, the day after New Year's, Peter Boyle found his view of the river thrilling and new. ''Is there anywhere else to be on a night like this?'' he said.

title: Afghan Officials Say Mullah Omar Has Escaped as Taliban Holdouts Surrender
description: American and Afghan forces searching for Mullah Muhammad Omar, the fugitive leader of the Taliban, have failed to find him in a mountainous region of southern Afghanistan, where soldiers had formed the last pocket of Taliban resistance in the country, Afghan officials said today.

title: 2-Game Suspension and Fine for Martin
description: Nets forward Kenyon Martin was suspended for two games without pay and fined $15,000 by the National Basketball Association today for a flagrant foul against Orlando's Tracy McGrady and for throwing a punch at McGrady in the ensuing confrontation in Friday night's 109-96 loss to the Magic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIMITZ, CHESTER W.
description: NIMITZ-Chester W., Rear Admiral, age 86, and his wife, Joan Labern Nimitz, age 89, of Needham and Wellfleet, MA, and formerly of Boca Grande, FL, by mutual consent on January 2, 2002 at their home in Needham. No memorial service is planned and a private burial will take place in Wellfleet, MA. Contributions to Planned Parenthood League of Massachussetts, 1055 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

title: NO HONEYMOON HERE
description: The new mayor of New York City wasted little time in getting down to the tough business of governing a city where a huge budget gap looms and the public is still largely enamored of his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani. On New Year's Day, Michael R. Bloomberg took his oath as mayor and gave his inaugural address, asking for the city's elected officials to join him in cutting 20 percent of their staff. The rest of the government was also put on notice that further cuts are coming, and Mr. Bloomberg reached out to union leaders on his first day on the job to begin talks with them. Jennifer Steinhauer

title: Students To Sailors: 'Please Write Back'
description: LISA SCHOFIELD'S fourth-grade class and Mary Jane Roth's fifth graders at Dows Lane Elementary School have had an unusual writing project this year: they've been corresponding with sailors stationed aboard the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt as part of the combat mission in Afghanistan.

title: Sarah Peskoe, Oren Adler
description: Sarah Tamar Peskoe, the daughter of Susan B. and Howard E. Peskoe of Glen Rock, N.J., was married on New Year's Day to Oren L. Adler, a son of Ayala and Gideon Adler of Franklin Lakes, N.J. Rabbi Shmuel Posner officiated at the Hilton in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: In Atlantic City, a Matter of Town vs. Gown
description: WHEN Robert M. Renneisen Jr. took over as chief executive of the Miss America Organization a little more than two years ago, he was greeted in Atlantic City as a hero, a savior and, most of all, a one-of-us kind of guy.

title: A Friend to the Scaly and Many-Legged
description: BOB SMITH'S office in a Hauppauge industrial park is a mecca for snakes, amphibians and bugs. There's Dumpy, a silky smooth, lime green Australian tree frog with a dreamy, smiley look on his face, sitting on the tray of Mr. Smith's business-card holder, breathing ever so gently that the nocturnal amphibian looks more like a gargoyle. Lurking under the moss in the terrarium by Mr. Smith's desk is a Brazilian rainbow boa constrictor that had 26 babies earlier this year, though the offspring have been relocated to separate lodgings in his Northport basement. When not between sheds, the boa's skin looks iridescent.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Parents Want New Inquiry Into Columbine Killings
description: Brian E. Rohrbough and Susan A. Petrone never much trusted the official account of what happened that awful day at Columbine High School. The report by Sheriff John P. Stone of Jefferson County concluded that their son, Daniel, and the 12 others killed on April 20, 1999, were all shot by Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, Columbine students who then shot themselves to death.

title: MEADOWLANDS DEVELOPMENT
description: After a letter from the United States Fish and Wildlife Service citing potentially negative environmental effects of a big commercial and retail center proposed for the Hackensack Meadowlands, the developer of the project has withdrawn the application from state consideration. But the developer of the Meadowland Mills project is continuing to press for approval from federal agencies and the New Jersey Meadowlands Commission, an independent agency that oversees development in the Hackensack Meadowlands. The developer's lawyer said the application to the state Department of Environmental Protection was removed to await a decision from the Meadowlands Commission later this month, and that the developers may then reapply with the state. The Fish and Wildlife letter said the project, which will require filling between 134 and 206 acres of wetlands, would cause ''substantial and unacceptable adverse impacts to exceedingly valuable wetland resources.''

title: New Careers for 3 Who'd Been Around the Block
description: ON the morning of Sept. 11, Alan Guinn decided he would change the way he lived his life. Standing in Penn Station amid swarms of anxious commuters trying to get home, Mr. Guinn made a commitment to himself.

title: Dance; Rehearsing For Dance And for Life
description: DAVID GORDON is no ordinary choreographer. He understands how to manipulate text and dance so that the result evokes an invigorating place, where thoughtful theater takes on the appearance of being casual. It never is just that. Mr. Gordon, who is 65, plays with many pieces of seemingly disparate phrases before they are transformed into an eloquent whole. In many ways, he is a gleaner of his own work, which he files away with the possibility of revisiting it in the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKIN, KATHARINE URBAN
description: PETERKIN-Katharine Urban. Of Darien, CT, died at her home on January 3, 2002. She was 82. Mrs. Peterkin had been involved in local activities such as the Yellow Balloon and Tots and Teens consignment shops, the Darien/New Canaan Smith Club, the Junior League, and New York City's Foreign Policy Association. With her husband DeWitt Peterkin, Jr., who predeceased her, she was a member of the Tokeneke Beach Club, the Wee Burn Country Club, the Noroton Yacht Club and Ox Ridge Hunt Club. Before his death, Mr. Peterkin had worked for 60 years with JP Morgan, where his positions included Vice-Chairman of the Board and member of the Director's Advisory Council. Mrs. Peterkin was born in Buffalo, New York on May 17, 1919, to the late Florence Zeller Urban and George P. Urban. Her father was head of Buffalos George Urban Milling Company, as was his father and grandfather before him. The Urban family has figured very prominently in Buffalo industry and civic life for well over 150 years and continue to do so. Mrs. Peterkin's great-grandfather was a pioneer in the use of electric power and in 1899 was the first to operate a milling company with electricity generated by Niagara Falls. Mrs. Peterkin graduated from the Masters School and, in 1941, from Smith College. She then became a copywriter with the Young & Rubicam advertising agency in New York City before her marriage in 1948 to Mr. Peterkin. Besides her husband, Mrs. Peterkin is predeceased by her sisters Florence Wyper and Ada Marie Urban, as well as her son Christopher Cameron Peterkin. She is survived by her brother Henry Zeller Urban and his family, as well as her children Clare, DeWitt III, George, Kate, and Patrick, and three grandchildren, Jennifer, Stephanie and William. A funeral service will be held at Darien's St. Luke's Episcopal Church's Chapel on Tuesday, January 8, at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Smith College Alumnae Fund, the Masters School Alumnae/i Fund at Dobbs Ferry, and Amnesty International.

title: Eaten by Boston
description: William F. Weld's elegiac third novel, STILLWATER (Simon & Schuster, $23), is set in western Massachusetts in the late 1930's and is full of ''simple people, accustomed to hard physical work but without any instinct for confrontation.'' They shuffle from primarily agricultural jobs into Ripton Congregational Church to hear dour sermons instructing them of their ''bounden duty to submit to the order of things,'' or they linger at Conkey's Tavern. They have few radios and ''no idea there was a government, except in the towns.'' These are people whose imaginations rarely extend beyond the place and the moment where they are, and their blind acceptance of the hand they're dealt makes them especially susceptible to a corrupt scheme conceived in Boston, where power brokers intent on building a reservoir decide to bribe prominent individuals in the community, displace the residents and put five farming towns under water. Weld's story tells of one valley's last year through the eyes of 15-year old Jamieson Kooby. During this time Jamieson also falls in love with a girl who remembers having lived several other lives in the area, befriends a vagrant who challenges the local officials' corruption and learns from the intelligent and spirited grandmother who raises him. The plot develops as slowly as a Sunday in the valley, and there is a plaintive, lullaby quality to the prose that grows soporific in places. But Weld, a former governor of Massachusetts whose previous novels were both about contemporary politics, succeeds in creating a haunting kind of ghost story about a place stewing in its own slow history until it vanishes forever. Charles Wilson

title: The Fast-Forward Primary
description: The last presidential election ended in such a mess that people tend to forget that its beginning wasn't all that great either. When the Iowa caucuses kicked off in January, everyone complained that things were starting too early. The nominations were sewn up in early March, and states that didn't hold their primaries in the dead of winter felt their voters had been disenfranchised. Supporters of lesser-known candidates claimed the front-loaded schedule was tailored to suit the party favorites. And once the nominations were settled, no one was really looking forward to an eight-month race between George W. Bush and Al Gore.

My father was a longtime business owner in Milford, but even his local paper wouldn't do a story about him. They told me to place a death notice instead.

title: Spooling Back Memory to Before The Unthinkable
description: THE calendar turns, but the traditional spirit of the moment -- to start fresh, to put the past behind -- doesn't seem altogether fitting this year, not with a populace still stunned by what happened on Sept. 11. Memories remain too stark and unshakable. People will move on because they must, but some part is left behind, going over old ground, sifting through it, still trying to understand. I was not an eyewitness to the devastation. My memories are not so immediate and searing. I was simply one of millions who can remember where they were and what they were doing when they heard the news. But memory has a mind of its own. When I go back to the terrible hour of that day, I tend to overshoot the mark, rewinding the tape to the untroubled minutes before the planes struck, a couple of miles away.

She was a writer, a philanthropist, an OSS member in London during WWII, and a friend and correspondent to many throughout the US and Europe. Daughter of the Imagist poet Hilda Doolittle (H.D.) and adoptive daughter to the novelist Bryher and her husband Kenneth Macpherson. In 1950 she married literary agent John V. Schaffner, with whom she shared homes in Manhattan and East Hampton. A lifelong traveler, theater goer, and letter-writer, who loved books, music, cats, and human eccentricity. title: 'The Reckless Mind'
description: WHAT HAS PHILOSOPHY to do with love? If Plato is to be believed, everything. While all lovers are not philosophers, philosophers are the only true lovers, since they alone understand what love blindly seeks. Love evokes in us all an unconscious memory of the beauty of the Ideas, and this memory maddens us; we feel possessed by a frenzied yearning to couple and to "beget in the beautiful," as the Symposium beautifully puts it (209b). Those who possess self-control mate intellectually and commune with the Ideas, which is philosophy's aim, while those who lack it purge their passions in the flesh and remain bound to the world.

Gilles dedicated over 40 years of his life to the members of OPEIU working to gain the benefits of collective bargaining for working people. For nearly 16 years Gilles had been Secretary-Treasurer of the OPEIU representing 145,000 workers throughout the United States and Canada. Gilles Beauregard's devotion to OPEIU and the labor movement began in 1959 when he became President of OPEIU Local 57 in Montreal, Canada. He became Business Representative of OPEIU Local 57 in 1962, Regional Representative of the Eastern Canada Council in 1965, Regional Director of Ontario in 1976, International Vice President OPEIU 1980, Secretary-Treasurer of the OPEIU 1986. His leadership, dedication and strength of character will be missed. We send our condolences to his family and friends. title: Art/Architecture; A Pragmatic Modernist Prepares for Post-Modern Life
description: IT is a blustery afternoon just before Thanksgiving, and Kirk Varnedoe is on the phone in his office at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, working out the final details of a new acquisition. Complex negotiations are nothing unusual for Mr. Varnedoe -- as chief curator of the Modern's department of painting and sculpture since 1988, he has spent roughly a quarter of his life as the steward of the world's premier collection of modern art, a role in which scholarship and aesthetic decisions are always tempered by the practicalities of loans, bequests and purchases. But this acquisition is different. In October, Mr. Varnedoe announced that he was leaving the Modern. And today the negotiations he's involved in have to do not with the museum but with his life after it.

The professors cited what they called snubs by Mr. Summers, especially a meeting in which they said he insulted Dr. West by raising questions about his scholarship, grade inflation in his classes and his making a rap CD.

title: In a Brand, I See Myself

So I told her I couldn't, as I had to take care of some ''personal business.'' The phrase was so bulletproof it even slammed the door on a follow-up question.

title: Television/Radio; Seeing, at Last, How Britain Counts Down the Hits
description: SOMETIMES the simplest ideas are the most durable. One is the pop countdown show. First it migrated from radio to television; lately, it has been rejuvenated by cable with shows like MTV's ''Total Request Live.'' The latest countdown contender on American cable systems is actually a venerable institution: ''Top of the Pops,'' begun by the BBC on New Year's Day 1964 and, as of Saturday, being imported by BBC America. The half-hour show that is taped every Thursday night in England and shown there on Friday will arrive in the United States on Saturday evenings.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Joseph Bertiers was born Joseph Pius Mbatia, but changed his name when he became an artist. ''There are some people who think that white men are the only ones who can do things the best they can,'' he told Ernie Wolfe in an interview in ''Dateline Kenya: The Media Paintings of Joseph Bertiers.'' ''So I use that name so many people can be confused. They think I am a Frenchman, and when they come to the real man, they see a black man.'' Bertiers began by painting signboards and then moved on to events. Today, his incisive commentary can be on pop culture, like his painting about Tonya Harding's ''Tarnished Victory'' (1994) or politics, whether it's the L.A. riots, the Waco showdown or the O.J. trial. The work can be cryptic or concise, but it is always opinionated. ''Our Boy Is Free,'' a portrait of Johnnie Cochran, O.J. and Robert Shapiro, was painted before the end of the trial. Shapiro is wearing a shirt that says, ''It's Only a Painter and a Lawyer Who Can Change Black 2 White.'' Bertiers says: ''O.J.'s trial was pumped with permanent difficulties, which included racism. So I thought he was not guilty.''

title: Someone Tell the Kids

We will have won round one once we've killed Osama bin Laden and his allies and once the leaders of the Arab-Muslim world have killed his ideas. That's the division of labor: we have to eliminate the killers and they have to delegitimate his ideas. I fear, though, that we'll do our part, but Arab-Muslim leaders won't do theirs. And if that's how round one ends, then on your next flight keep an eye on the tennis shoes of the guy next to you.

title: Call My Grandson Beautiful
description: I HAVE the most beautiful grandson in the world, his skin a smooth pale beige-ivory, his hair, small snail-shell black curls, his eyes a deep dark brown, his lashes long. At 2 1/2 he makes everyone he meets smile. Though lacking a clear, non-infant vocabulary, he has a definite sense of humor. On his first ''report card,'' his day-care teachers call him a ''great kid'' whom everyone loves, ''without a mean bone in his body,'' who is empathetic toward his classmates. Yet, last week, he walked with his mother through the downtown streets of one of our whitest and wealthiest towns in Westchester, and was greeted so rudely, so hostilely, that his mother could only deduce that those reactions had to do with the color of her son's skin and his close curls, the clues that he was a biracial child.

title: What's Left
description: When the new government in Afghanistan begins to rebuild, it will have its choice of places to start. Simon Norfolk, a British photographer, captured some of the rack and ruin around the capital using a Wista, a large-format camera that produces pin-sharp 4-by-5-inch negatives. War photographers routinely return home with more than a hundred rolls of 35-millimeter film, but Norfolk shot just 120 frames during his two-week stay in Afghanistan.

description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, J. WADE, JR.
description: MILLER-J. Wade, Jr. Of New York City and Ogunquit, ME. Died December 13, 2001. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, he graduated from Washington and Jefferson College where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He went on to earn a Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, graduating from the Sloane School of Management. During W.W. II, he served as an officer in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific. He enjoyed a distinguished career in management and human resources including the positions of Corporate Vice President of B.F. Goodrich and Executive Vice President of Organization Resources Counselors. During his career, he served as a member of the Business Roundtable. He was a longtime member of the Vestry of Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston, MA. He is survived by his wife Margaret, daughters Susan Werthan of Bethesda, Maryland and Janice Thorpe of Montclair, N.J., and grandsons David and Benjamin Werthan. Donations in his memory may be made to the J. Wade Miller Scholarship Fund, Washington and Jefferson College, Washington, PA. 15301. A memorial service will be held in Maine at a later date.

title: Two Who Made an Evolution
description: French taste in matters of dress appears to be replacing decades of unbridled English theatrics. Two Frenchwomen, both fashion editors, photographed in Paris in October, have for a decade personified this evolution in women's clothes for the 21st century. Far left, five pictures of Isabel Dupr, a stylist at the American edition of Elle, whose informal but creative mix of designers' separates infallibly expresses her personality. The other pictures show Carine Roitfeld, the editor of French Vogue, formerly an assistant to the designer Tom Ford, and her classic French interest in precise fit. Her only frivolities are her shoes and her signature haircut  la Patti Smith, the rocker poet. Both women embody a modern spirit of comfort and function that flatter the wearer. By contrast, the English style has reached its twilight with costumes designed to grab headlines and titillate museumgoers.

Designated a National Historic Site in 1946, it now qualifies for promotional, financial and technical support as one of the 21 National Trust sites.

title: Music; Not Afraid of Tears In a Tough Guys' World

Now here he was, crooning of a broken heart in a wispy voice that seemed to float between sexes. Young women and gay men, more than jazz fans, cheered him on.

Who would duplicate a monument that had already been attacked twice, and expect tenants to move into the world's largest bull's eye? Thus the World Trade Center may well be reborn, in name and in rental capacity, but without the swagger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, WILLIAM A.
description: MOSES-William A. Of New York City, January 3, 2002. With great sorrow we mourn the sudden passing of William, revered father of Andrew Moses, Cynthia MosesManocherian and Henry Moses, devoted friend of the mother of his children Hannah Kaufmann Moses, esteemed father-in-law and friend of Jeffrey Manocherian and Marcia Moses, beloved grandfather of Olivia, Margo and Amanda, brother to Eugene (deceased) and Robert and admired leader of all who worked for and with him. William championed the redevelopment of disadvantaged communities in New York City devastated by the effects of decades of rent control laws and led the battle, with his close friend Sheldon Katz, in the late 1960s and 70s to win control of the Rent Stabilization Association (RSA), where he remained on the Executive Committee of the Board, passionate about the organization's purpose and devoted to his colleagues. He co-founded the Community Housing Improvement Program (CHIP), dedicated to the issues of small property owners, where he remained Chairman Emeritus, always devoted to its members and leaders. Together these two organizations represent the owners of all rent regulated apartments in New York City. He was a lifelong member of the Real Estate Board of New York, member of the Board of Directors of the Realty Advisory Board and accomplished Chairman of his family real estate investment firm. A graduate of the High School of Music and Art, William played the saxophone, clarinet and bassoon in orchestras, including in Carnegie Hall, before serving in the Navy at the end of WWII, and in 1977 was one of the first Americans to travel to China with his architect and friend William Gleckman. He graduated from Syracuse University and received a M.B.A. from Columbia University Business School in 1952. He was passionate about sailing, skiing, photography, China and the Civil War and was a dedicated congregant of Temple Emanu-El. Bill and his extraordinary spirit will live on in all who knew him. Services Tuesday, January 8, 2002, at 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

In the Clinton years, we criticized Senate Republicans for their obstruction. Now that the Democrats are in control, they have no less of a responsibility to give Mr. Bush's nominees fair treatment.

Bill Kroenthal, who is about to become an octogenarian, outdistanced a strong field to collect the money and his first major title. His partner was Bobby Levin, who won a world championship two decades ago at age 24 and has been a top international star ever since.

Conseco's announcement came days after its biggest rival in the mobile-home lending business, the GreenPoint Financial Corporation, said it would stop lending to buyers of mobile homes. GreenPoint said the business was not profitable enough.
