After attending Bennington College, she worked as a reporter for the Journal American Newspaper in New York City. During this time, she met her husband, the late Daniel Lang, staff writer for The New Yorker magazine, to whom she was married for thirty-nine years. She is survived by her daughters, Frances Lang-Labaree and son-inlaw, Robert Labaree, Helen Lang, Cecily Lang-Kooyman, and son-inlaw Eric Kooyman, as well as by her eight grandchildren: Isaiah Orozco, Daniel and Joaquin Lang; Aaron, Hannah and Sophie Labaree; Nico and Olivia Kooyman. She is also survived by her sister, Edith Graham and her brother, Arthur Altschul. Margaret was loyal and generous to her family and many friends in New York, Martha's Vineyard, Stonington, Key West and England. She was vital and adventurous, creative with a love of beauty. Unconventional, quirky with a wry sense of humor, she will be keenly missed. Services will be held on Sunday, January 13, 10:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Manhattan Country School, 7 East 96th St, NY, NY 10028, or to Human Rights Watch, 350 5th Avenue, 34th Floor, New York, New York 10118-3299.

title: Deficit Politics Returns
description: It did not take long after the New Year for President Bush and the Democrats to resume their squabbling over taxes and the federal budget. Unfortunately, their arguments have been covered with so much political padding that the country can hardly be expected to follow them.

title: Ending an Era in High Fashion, Saint Laurent Takes a Final Bow
description: Yves Saint Laurent announced his retirement in Paris yesterday after more than 40 years in which he helped revolutionize the way modern women dress, outfitting them in pants and broad-shouldered suits after the social upheavals of the 1960's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLYNN, ROBERT B.
description: GLYNN-Robert B. Of Manhattan, died on January 6, 2002, after a short illness. Born in 1929 in Passaic, NJ, he was graduated from Harvard College in 1951, and from Harvard Law School in 1956. He was a founding partner of Becker, Glynn, Melamed & Muffly LLP, and Chairman of the Lampadia Foundation, a private foundation devoted to promoting education, culture and social work in Argentina, Brazil and Chile. Bob was a member of the Harvard Club and The Century Association. Much loved, he will be missed by a worldwide circle of friends and family who will always remember his thoughtful generosity, unshakeable loyalty, and never-failing wit. He is survived by his daughter Katherine, of Boston; his step-daughter Hannah Parker, of Brookline, Massachusetts; his step-son Jonathan Parker, of Heartland, Vermont; and their mother Mary E. Jackson. He also leaves his beloved companion Savannah; his sister Muriel Glynn Newmann, of Philadelphia; and his brother Dr. Eugene Glynn, of Ridgefield, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Commentary Fund or any fund promoting classical music. A small funeral service will be held on Tuesday, January 8, at 5 PM, at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, and a larger memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, YAN, KIT SO
description: MARTIN-Yan-Kit So. Author and expert on Chinese cooking, died December 22, in London. She was credited with introducing the West to Chinese cuisine as haute-cuisine at a time when it was not regarded so. She was married to the late Briton, Martin Jr, of Philadelphia and Waterford, CT. She is survived by her son, Hugo Enders Martin of London, and her two brothers and two sisters. A memorial service will be held at Noon, January 12, at 66 Shore Road, Waterford, CT. Burial will be in West Neck Cemetery, Waterford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHLAGER, WILLIAM
description: GOLDSCHLAGER - William. Teacher, educational administrator, lawyer. On January 5, 2002, in Bryn Mawr, PA. Beloved husband of Edna (nee Cohen). Loving mother of Marcia Epstein (Paul) of Gladwyne, PA, and Seth Goldschlager (Isabelle) of Paris, France. Grandfather of Amy and Leonard Feldman, Robin Epstein, Esther, Ezra and Eva Goldschlager. Great-grandfather of Madeline and Benjamin Feldman. Sister-in-law of Roseline Doorech and Pearl Goldschlager. He was an enthusiastic educator and public-spirited administrative law judge. He was a man of great intelligence and integrity, and will be missed by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, January 8, at 1 PM, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel at 114-03 Queens Blvd (76th Road), Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Seth Dooreck Book Fund, c/o Jennifer Sancton, NYU, 25 West 4th Street, Room 526, NY, NY 10012; or to a charity of your choice.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, JANE KENNEDY
description: MARTIN-Jane Kennedy. On Dec. 30, 2001. Beloved mother of five, grandmother of seventeen. Kind, caring, creative, passionate and more. In her 75 years, she never strayed far from New York. She attended the American Academy of Dramatic Arts and worked for Time-Life, Inc. We love you and miss you, Jenny. The Martin clan.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Cleric Loses Jail Privileges
description: Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, the Muslim cleric formerly named H. Rap Brown, was found in contempt of court for discussing his capital murder trial last week with The New York Times and in an earlier letter to his mosque. Judge Stephanie B. Manis of Fulton County Superior Court ruled that Mr. Amin had violated her order prohibiting him from discussing the case in public. Saying Mr. Amin was trying to taint the jury pool, she revoked his privileges to use the jail telephone, send mail and meet with visitors other than his lawyers during jury selection for his trial on charges of killing a sheriff's deputy. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Bush Has Changed. No, He Hasn't.
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Filipino Rebel Deported
description: Nur Misuari, a prominent Muslim separatist leader in the southern Philippines, was deported to Manila from his refuge in Malaysia. Mr. Misuari became a governor after signing a peace agreement in 1996, then turned against the government in November when it appeared that he would lose an election. His supporters staged an uprising and Mr. Misuari fled. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Cancer Fighter Exacts a Price: Cellular Aging
description: The human body is composed not of perishable materials like wood or metal, but of living cells that can grow and replenish themselves. So if the body's individual units are renewable, why do we not live forever?

title: Big Bangs and Big Freezes
description: To the Editor:

title: With Ceremony Under Somber Skies, QE2 Returns
description: An idyllic cruise-ship-brochure day? Not. Evil winds buffeted the Queen Elizabeth 2 yesterday morning as it docked at Pier 88 on the West Side of Manhattan and hundreds of shivering passengers headed up the gangplank, pelted by a pitiless confetti of snow under a titanium-gray sky.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: More Doubt On Pipeline
description: Prime Minis ter Thaksin Shinawatra cast new doubt over the future of a proposed $500 million natural gas pipeline across Southern Thailand during a visit to the area Saturday when he said he would personally review the project. Last month, environmental authorities approved the pipeline, a joint venture between the state-controlled Thai oil company PTT and Petroliam Nasional of Malaysia, over the objections of neighbors and the government's expert review panel. One panel member later publicly called the approval illegal. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: On the Front Line in the O.R.
description: Certified registered nurse anesthetists are nurses who complete three years of advanced training in anesthesia that legally allows them to give anesthesia without a doctor's supervision in 50 states. But Medicare rules, which tend to set standards for all patients, require physician supervision in hospitals. In November, the Bush administration rejected a Clinton administration proposal to let nurse anesthetists work unsupervised in hospitals. Gale Scott spoke to members of opposing professional groups about the issue. Following are edited excerpts of those interviews.

title: Toronto's Streak Snapped
description: Ottawa defensemen Karel Rachunek and Wade Redden each had 2 points as the Senators stopped visiting Toronto's three-game winning streak with a 4-3 victory over the Maple Leafs last night.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Teaneck: Hotel Accused Of Anti-Muslim Bias
description: A mosque in Bergen County has charged that a hotel discriminated against its members by refusing to rent them a ballroom for their post-Ramadan celebration. Waheed Khalid, president of the Dar-Ul-Islah Mosque in Teaneck, said the Marriott at Glenpointe would not rent the ballroom to the mosque on Dec. 15 or 16. The hotel had previously allowed the mosque to rent the room, on Dec. 27, 2000, but that was for the first time since the mosque began asking in 1988, and only after it complained to government agencies. Mike Condrat, general manager of the Marriot, denied the discrimination charge and said the room had been booked already when the mosque wanted to rent it. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Consumer Prices Flat
description: Consumer prices in So Paulo, Brazil's largest city, rose only 0.25 percent in December, the smallest monthly change since May, as high interest rates and a strong dollar continued to keep a lid on spending through the holidays. So Paulo ended the year with inflation of 7.13 percent, up from 4.28 percent last year, mostly because of increases in public services like utilities and transportation. Business leaders hope the moderate inflation figures will lead the central bank to cut interest rates in the coming months. Jennifer Rich (NYT)

title: Judge's Domestic Violence Ruling Creates an Outcry in Kentucky
description: The violent arena of domestic abuse litigation has grown a bit more volatile here, now that a judge has decided to hold two women in contempt of court for returning to men who had been ordered to stay away from them.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Just a Little . . . Hasty

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: G.M. And Daewoo Talk
description: General Motors and Daewoo Motor say they are on course for G.M. to take over Daewoo despite reports that G.M. is concerned about labor problems and hidden Daewoo debts. The G.M. chairman, Jack Smith, told Korean reporters in Detroit that negotiations were progressing on the memorandum of understanding between G.M. and Daewoo's creditors. Alan Perriton, above, the G.M. executive in charge of the talks, acknowledged that the sides had yet to come to terms with the company's labor union, which opposes any deal that risks layoffs. Daewoo said reports of the discovery of debts of more than $1 billion in overseas operations were exaggerated and would not jeopardize a deal. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An editorial last Wednesday about parks policy misidentified a national park in Texas; it is Big Bend, not Big Ben. An editorial tribute to the late Judge Eugene Nickerson on Friday misstated the year he led an insurgent campaign for Nassau County executive. It was 1961, not 1962.

title: Bush Has Changed. No, He Hasn't.
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Mel Sokotch, executive vice president and worldwide account director at the New York office of Foote, Cone & Belding, working on Nabisco brands like Oreo, was named director for consumer health care. He succeeds Colleen Gowl, who became executive vice president and director for consumer health care at the New York office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, and global business director on Thompson's Pfizer account. Foote, Cone is part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Finally, Snow, but a Rather Wet Blanket
description: The much-anticipated snowstorm, when it finally arrived, was more like a bad houseguest: it crept in at dusk and stayed just long enough to make a mess before departing.

title: Rich School, Poor School
description: The much-hyped but disappointing bipartisan education bill that President Bush will sign into law today reveals the extent to which both political parties are caught in a trap that prevents them from addressing the deepest problems in our elementary and secondary education system. The trap is the legacy of localism in school funding, which creates dramatic disparities in per-pupil funding across the country.

title: U.S. SEES BATTLES IN LAWLESS AREAS AFTER AFGHAN WAR
description: The war on terrorism after Afghanistan could focus on denying terrorist groups sanctuary in places like Somalia, Yemen, Indonesia and the Philippines, countries where they have sometimes operated freely, Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul D. Wolfowitz said today.

title: Unreliability Of Key Figure Foiled Inquiry On Torricelli
description: In conference rooms at her downtown headquarters, the chief federal prosecutor in Manhattan, Mary Jo White, listened intently last summer and fall as the key witness in her investigation of Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat, went over his story again and again.

title: EarthLink in Review Of 2 Assignments
description: EarthLink, an Internet service provider, said yesterday that it had begun a review of the creative and media parts of its account, with billings estimated at $40 million to $50 million. The assignments have been handled for 18 months by the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/ Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: Ozzie Smith Awaits Hall of Fame Entry
description: Ozzie Smith spent several hours yesterday moving from a house in the St. Louis area to another one 20 miles away -- and several minutes biting his cuticles. Thinking about his chances of being elected into the Baseball Hall of Fame today, he was a little jittery as he unpacked dozens of boxes.

title: F.D.A. Letter Sends ImClone Stock Lower
description: Shares of ImClone Systems plunged by more than 17 percent yesterday after a letter from the Food and Drug Administration was disclosed raising doubts about whether the company can gain approval for its cancer drug and whether executives had been totally forthcoming in their disclosures to investors.

title: Liberty and Justice, With an Emphasis on All
description: ANTHONY D. ROMERO, the executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, bounds into the foyer of his organization's Lower Manhattan headquarters, stopping to hug the receptionist in celebration of the new year. He walks briskly back to his spacious corner office, with its magnificent view of New York Harbor and the Statue of Liberty.

title: Making the Best of What Remains of Shrinking Habitats
description: Why did the chicken cross the road?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KINDER MORGAN ENERGY PARTNERS, Houston, an owner of more than 20,000 miles of pipelines, said it would purchase 10 percent of the 1,900-mile Cochin pipeline in Canada from Nova Chemicals Corp., Pittsburgh, for about $29 million, to increase its stake to 45 percent. Two other owners have rights to make counteroffers for the 10 percent stake.

title: Genius: You Know It When You See It
description: To the Editor:

title: Rose-Colored Defeats Seem to Suit The Knicks
description: The Knicks were right tonight when they sat at their lockers and patted themselves on the backs for putting forth a good, hard, albeit losing effort against the San Antonio Spurs. They were right in saying that they played with heart and emotion and in declaring that there was no shame in losing to an excellent team on its home floor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODBELL, SHELDON
description: RODBELL-Sheldon, of Palm Beach, Fl passed away on January 7, after an extended illness. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Gerry and Ellen, fatherin-law of Hank Alpert and Dr. Alain Roizen, cherished grandfather of David, Brooke, Erica, and Remy. Survived by his brother Arthur. Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, on January 10, 2002 at 11:30 am. In lieu of flowers please make donations to The Alzheimers Association of Palm Beach 561-820-8166.

title: Argentina Devalues, and the Spanish Feel the Loss
description: When the Argentine government decided over the weekend to devalue the peso, it also decided on several measures to spare its citizens some of the pain of devaluation. The brunt of the costs of those measures will be borne in Spain.

title: A Paleontologist Retains His Sense of Wonder
description: The desk that dominates Dr. Michael J. Novacek's fifth-floor office at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan broadcasts all the contradictions of his daily life. On the table's surface are computers, budgetary papers, administrative notices and the skeleton of a shrewlike creature that went extinct 15 million years ago.

title: LEAR TO CLOSE 4 PLANTS AND CUT 1,200 JOBS
description: The Lear Corporation, a leading maker of automobile interiors and seats, plans to eliminate about 1,200 jobs and close four plants to consolidate production. The company will shut plants in June or July in Marlette, Mich.; Bowling Green, Ohio; Peru, Ind.; and Wentzville, Mo., a spokeswoman, Andrea Puchalsky, said. An undetermined number of workers will be able to apply for other jobs. The cuts represent 1 percent of Lear's work force of 116,900. Lear said in October that it would eliminate an unspecified number of jobs and close under-used plants and offices at its seating, interior and electrical businesses, moves it expected would result in as much as $150 million in fourth-quarter costs. Lear is based in Southfield, Mich.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about lessons learned from the anthrax outbreak referred incorrectly to Dr. Craig Smith of Phoebe Putney Memorial Hospital in Albany, Ga., who commented on differences between warfare and bioterrorism. He was an infectious-disease specialist for the Army in the Persian Gulf war; he was not the only such specialist to accompany American troops.

title: Bush Says He May Not Seek Balanced Budget This Year
description: President Bush said today for the first time that he might not propose a balanced budget this year. It would be the first time since 1997 that the government would spend more than it took in.

title: Big Bangs and Big Freezes
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Teenager Drew 1,000 Investors And the S.E.C. With His Plan
description: The Internet stock bubble may have burst, but the dream of getting rich quick lives on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRASS, BERNARD L.
description: BRASS-Bernard L., 79. Of Riverdale, NY on January 7, 2002. Devoted father of Karen and Joel Newman. Cherished grandfather of Scott and Jeffrey Newman. Loving brother of Lynne Simon.

title: Circuit City Says Its Earnings Will Be Better Than Expected
description: Circuit City Stores increased its fiscal fourth-quarter profit forecast today because of better-than-expected holiday sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABEL, IRVING
description: GABEL-Irving. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of our esteemed former Executive Secretary and extends to Blanche and the bereaved family our heartfelt condolences.

title: Shanahan Tops List To Replace Spurrier
description: On a day when Steve Spurrier said farewell to his players at Florida, Mike Shanahan emerged as the leading candidate to become his successor. Also today, Bob Stoops, Oklahoma's head coach, removed himself from consideration and said he would stay with the Sooners.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Mark Messing joined Best Buy Advertising, Minneapolis, the in-house agency of the Best Buy Company, the electronics retailer, in the new post of vice president for advertising strategy and business development. He had most recently been at the Bozell Group, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as senior vice president for business development and integrated branding and general manager of the New York office. Also, Julie Owen, director for operations at Best Buy Advertising, was named vice president for business operations and integration.

title: EarthLink in Review of 2 Assignments
description: EarthLink, an Internet service provider, said yesterday that it had begun a review of the creative and media parts of its account, with billings estimated at $40 million to $50 million. The assignments have been handled for 18 months by the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/ Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ).

title: Supreme Court Narrows Reach of Disability Law
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 - The Supreme Court ruled today that to qualify as disabled, and therefore to be protected by the Americans With Disabilities Act, a person must have substantial limitations on abilities that are ``central to daily life,'' and not only to life in the workplace.

title: Mayor Says There's No Money To Build 2 Baseball Stadiums
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made it clear yesterday that he did not share former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's vision for new baseball stadiums for New York City in the near future, saying that Mr. Giuliani's project would not be given priority this year.

title: Terrorism Beyond Islam
description: There's just one thing that most Americans and Osama bin Laden seem able to agree on: that the attacks on the World Trade Center arose somehow from Islam. Whether the purest form of Islam or the most perverted, it so enveloped the hijackers in religious zeal that the centrality of Islam to the attacks is hard to deny.

title: Refreshing A Rhapsodist Taken Over By Hollywood
description: Rachmaninoff's enormous popularity is based on a handful of war horses that probably get performed too often for their own good. The point of ''Rachmaninoff Revisited,'' the five-day offering of panels and concerts presented by Lincoln Center's Great Performers series, which began this weekend, is to examine his lesser known works and to revisit a few of the staples in a fresh context. The goals were excitingly realized in Sunday afternoon's program by the Philharmonia Orchestra of London, the first of three conducted by Vladimir Ashkenazy. The main work of interest was the Piano Concerto No. 4, the least often heard of the four.

title: To Teach Reading: A New Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IOVENKO, MICHAEL
description: IOVENKO-Michael. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, January 23 at 5:30 PM at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

title: Civilians Are Reluctant to Join U.S. Test of Anthrax Vaccine
description: Of 10,000 people who may have been exposed to anthrax during the recent attacks, fewer than 2 percent have taken the anthrax vaccine, a figure that reflects postal employees' deep reluctance to enroll in a medical experiment, federal health officials said today.

title: Broken Hand Sidelines Webb
description: The Islanders' Steve Webb, a pugnacious right wing who was lauded last week by General Manager Mike Milbury because he loves to hit people, will be out six to eight weeks because he hit someone too hard Sunday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Sales Fall
description: Japan's 11 automakers said car sales at home shrank for a fourth consecutive month in December as the country's slowing economy prompted consumers to hold off purchases. For all of 2001, sales fell for a fourth year in five. December sales of cars, trucks and buses, excluding minivehicles, dropped 7.6 percent from the same month a year earlier to 296,881, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said. The Honda Motor Company was the only one of the top five automakers to expand sales in December.

title: Chester Nimitz Jr., Navy Admiral, 86
description: Rear Adm. Chester W. Nimitz Jr., a veteran of World War II and son of the World War II naval commander in the Pacific, died last Wednesday along with his wife, Joan, at their home in Needham, Mass. He was 86, and she 89.

title: It's Two Steps Back for the Punchless Devils
description: The Devils reached the halfway point in the season tonight looking no different from when they started. It is 41 games into the schedule and every game is starting to look the same, a tired repeat in which the offense struggles, bogged down by a noticeable lack of intensity or fire. They say they can turn it around, but it does not happen.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TiVo To Sell Digital Video Recorder
description: Starting next month, TiVo will begin selling an advanced digital video recorder that can be connected to the Internet. The box will cost $399 and store up to 60 hours of video. In addition to recording television programs, the new TiVo box will be able to download digital audio and video files from the Internet using Real Networks' RealOne Player. TiVo will begin RealOne and other high-speed Internet services later in the year. Unlike SonicBlue's ReplayTV 4000, the new TiVo will not permit users to send digital video to one another. ''We don't want to support the infringement on people's content and copyright,'' said Rebecca Baer, a spokeswoman for TiVo. SonicBlue's ReplayTV 4000 is being sued by several Hollywood studios and production companies that say it infringed on their copyrights. Jennifer 8. Lee

title: INSIDE
description: Speaker All but Selected

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Drinking Water For Wichita
description: An aquifer that provides Wichita with almost half of its drinking water will be refilled with about 65 billion gallons of water from the Little Arkansas River. A five-year, $5 million study of the river by the United States Geological Survey determined that the water could be used to refill the Equus Beds aquifer if it was treated by the city. City officials have said that without a new source Wichita could face a water shortfall in 15 years. The river water would meet the city's needs for the next 50 years. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Metromedia Fiber Meets Sales Goal
description: Metromedia Fiber Network, a money-losing builder of communications networks, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter sales and profit before certain items met the company's reduced forecasts. Sales were $100 million to $103 million, while earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization were $3 million to $9 million. Sales this year will be $510 million to $535 million, up from $360 million to $363 million in 2001, the company said in a statement. Shares of Metromedia, which is based in White Plains, climbed 17 cents, or 41.5 percent, to 58 cents. More than 119 million shares traded, making it the most active stock yesterday in the United States.

title: Newark Stadium Bill Dies in Final Session
description: The New Jersey Legislature's last-gasp effort to finance a sports arena in downtown Newark and an entertainment complex at the Meadowlands was quietly abandoned today as lawmakers rushed to vote on a flurry of bills in the final day of their session. But Governor-elect James E. McGreevey promised to revive the sports and entertainment proposal when he takes office.

title: Q & A
description: The Drifting Moon

title: Musharraf Sees Blair and Plans to Announce Steps Against Extremists
description: Urging restraint on India and Pakistan, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain flew here today from New Delhi and met with President Pervez Musharraf, who said Pakistan ''rejects terrorism in all its forms and manifestations.''

title: Self-Disclosure in Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Memory: It Doesn't Come in a Pill
description: When I complained to my son Erik about things I can no longer remember, he replied: ''What do you expect? With all you've stuffed into your head all these years, something is bound to fall out.''

title: Huskies Just Miss Second Upset
description: Unranked Connecticut, which upset previously unbeaten and 21st-ranked Miami on Saturday night, came close to bringing down a much higher-ranked opponent tonight with a late surge that almost overcame No. 5 Oklahoma.

title: Nice-Guy Comedy Writer With a Lively Imagination
description: Changing a show's title at the last minute is always a bad sign, especially when the new name is worse than the old. The coyly titled ''Imagine That'' used to be ''The Hank Azaria Show,'' but it is still a sitcom about a nice-guy comedy writer with a rocky marriage whose fantasies materialize onscreen ''Ally McBeal'' style. To compound the bad omens, the show's creator, Seth Kurland (a former producer of ''Friends'') left, his departure cloaked in that weary showbiz clich ''creative differences,'' the grown-up equivalent of ''the dog ate my homework.'' And NBC has scheduled just five episodes before the series makes way for the Olympics next month.

title: Jets Rest, Then Start Planning for a Raiders Repeat
description: By the time Jets Coach Herman Edwards, deprived of sleep, dropped off his wife at home and got back to his office at 5:30 this morning to begin looking at film, there were close to 30 messages of congratulations on his answering machine.

title: Morton's Closes Restaurant
description: The Morton's Restaurant Group said yesterday that it had closed its Morton's of Chicago restaurant in Sydney because of Australian restrictions on beef imports and said it would take a fourth-quarter charge.

title: Still Making Films, Still Explaining the Hitler Connection
description: Leni Riefenstahl, Hitler's cinematic handmaiden, plans to release her first film since 1954, on her 100th birthday, Aug. 22, and she has used the occasion to defend her life once again, in a rare interview published today in Die Welt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, FRANK W.
description: YOUNG-Frank W. The Stecher and Horowitz Foundation extends deepest sympathy to Robert S. Young, dedicated Chairman of the Board, upon the loss of his beloved father. Heartfelt condolences to the entire Young family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, LAURENCE
description: SMITH-Laurence. We mourn the death of our member, and send heartfelt sympathy to his family. Temple Sinai of Long Island Paula Winnig, Rabbi Dr. Richard Storm, President

title: Simms and Gumbel Save Best for Last
description: A montage of Vinny Testaverde's interceptions had just rolled on CBS's broadcast of the Jets-Raiders game on Sunday. The season's lowlights followed a second-quarter pick that Testaverde, the Jets' quarterback, had thrown to Tory James, which led to a touchdown that put Oakland ahead, 16-14.

title: China, Russia and 4 Neighbors Seek Common Front on Terror
description: After a daylong meeting here, foreign ministers from China, Russia and four Central Asian countries said today that the fall of the Taliban in Afghanistan did not end the terrorist threat and that their governments would continue to work together against ''terrorism, separatism and extremism'' to promote regional stability.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Sept. 11 Aid Center Opens
description: The city yesterday officially moved its office to assist families of victims from the World Trade Center attack to 51 Chambers Street from Pier 94. An hourly shuttle bus will take people who have not learned of the change from the pier to the new site. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that the new, permanent office would help as many as 550 people a day. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: A Chilling Aerial Suicide
description: By flying his flight school's single-engine Cessna into a Tampa, Fla., office tower over the weekend, a 15-year-old named Charles Bishop reminded a jittery nation of its continuing vulnerability. The tragedy underlines the need for the federal government to review and tighten security in the lightly regulated world of privately operated aircraft, known as general aviation.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER LEAPS. Copper gained on expectations that a recovery in the United States will increase demand. In New York, copper for March delivery rose 4.05 cents, or 6 percent, to 71.5 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, GLORIA
description: MILLER-Gloria, 79. Died on Jan. 2, 2002. Born in Riverdale, predeceased by her sister Madelon Wald, parents Madelon & Daniel Sullivan and husband, Richard Miller. Survived by her children, Judith, Richard, Kevin & Randall Rogers and eight grandchildren. Donations to Parker Family Clinic, Box 2189, Red Bank, N.J. 07701. Memorial Mass on Wednesday, January 9, 10:00 AM. St. James Church, Red Bank, NJ.

title: Genes Help Identify Oldest Human Population
description: Peering deep into the archive of population history that is stored in the human genome, a Stanford University biologist believes he has picked up a genetic signature of the ancestral human population.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury to Retire
description: LONDON, Jan. 8  The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. George Carey leader of 73 million Anglicans across 160 nations, announced today that he will step down this fall, three years before he was due to retire.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Hackers Hit Lottery Web Site
description: Computer hackers vandalized the state lottery's Web site with graffiti on Sunday but did not alter any information. Keith Elkins, a spokesman for the Texas Lottery Commission, said the matter had been referred to the commission's security division, which would not comment. ''A lot of hackers will do this as a way of saying, 'You've got a weakness in your firewall, and we've found it,' '' Mr. Elkins said. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: N.F.L. Playoff Schedule

Moody's placed Georgia-Pacific's Baa3 senior unsecured ratings on review for downgrade, affecting about $10 billion of the company's debt. Investors demand higher yields to hold junk-rated securities, resulting in increased borrowing costs. Georgia-Pacific bought Fort James, the maker of Brawny paper towels, late in 2000. Dycom will pay $83.7 million in stock, or 0.3333 share, for each share of Arguss, the company said. Based on Friday's closing stock prices, the deal is worth $5.77 a share for Arguss stockholders, a 30.5 percent premium to Arguss's price. Dycom, which is based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., will also assume $65 million of debt. Arguss Communications, based in Rockville, Md., provides system services to telecommunications and cable companies. It said in November that it had eliminated 500 jobs since last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, WILLIAM A.
description: MOSES-William A. Of New York City, January 3, 2002. With great sorrow we mourn his sudden passing. He leaves behind his son Henry Winston Moses from his first marriage to Joan Tiger Morse (deceased), his son Andrew Ferdinand Moses and daughter Cynthia M. Moses-Manocherian from his second wife and devoted friend Hannah Kaufmann Moses, and his ex wife Bernice Schwartz. He was the esteemed father-in-law and friend of Jeffrey Manocherian and Marcia Moses, beloved grandfather of Olivia, Margo and Amanda, brother to Eugene (deceased) and Robert and admired leader of all who worked for and with him. William championed the redevelopment of disadvantaged communities in New York City devastated by the effects of decades of rent control laws and led the battle, with his close friend Sheldon Katz, in the late 1960s and 70s to win control of the Rent Stabilization Association (RSA) where he remained on the Executive Committee of the Board, passionate about the organization's purpose and devoted to his colleagues. He cofounded the Community Housing Improvement Program (CHIP), dedicated to the issues of small property owners, where he remained Chairman Emeritus, always devoted to its members and leaders. Together these two organizations represent all rent-regulated apartments in New York City. He was a life long member of the Real Estate Board of New York, member of the Board of Directors of the Realty Advisory Board and accomplished Chairman of his family real estate investment firm. A graduate of the High School of Music and Art, William played the saxophone, clarinet and bassoon in orchestras including in Carnegie Hall before serving in the Navy at the end of WWII and in 1977 was one of the first Americans to travel to China with his architect and friend William Gleckman. He graduated from Syracuse University and received an MBA from Columbia University Business School in 1952. He was passionate about sailing, skiing, photography, China and the Civil War and was a dedicated congregant of Temple Emanu-El. Bill and his extraordinary spirit will live on in all who knew him. Services Tuesday, January 8, 2002, at 11:30 A.M., Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

GlobalNet, which is based in Lombard, Ill., will become part of Titan's wireless unit, which provides communications services in developing markets in Africa and central Asia. GlobalNet provides voice, data, and Internet services in the United States and Latin America.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Shootout At Bus Station
description: A man was wounded by the Spokane police after opening fire with a semiautomatic rifle in a crowded bus and train complex. Officials gave this account of the incident: Jason Graham, 20, began shooting at the police after he and a companion, Jeremiah Justin Jones, 20, were pulled over in downtown Spokane. A brief chase ended when the men crashed their car and fled into the Intermodal complex, which houses the Greyhound and Amtrak stations. Mr. Jones surrendered, but Mr. Graham opened fire, striking a train, a bus and patrol cars; a slug was found lodged in a dinner roll in the dining car of the train. Officers returned fire, wounding Mr. Graham, who was hospitalized. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Mapping New York's Political Future
description: Ever since the 2000 census became official almost a year ago, New York's state legislators have known that they must use the new data to redraw state and federal districts for this year's elections. This mapmaking is a critical part of representative democracy, the insurance that every vote carries equal weight. Of course it also brings out the fiercest possible instincts of self-preservation among the officials whose districts are being redrawn. While ferocious lobbying has been going on behind the scenes in Albany, this real debate has been concealed from the general public. Legislative leaders are sitting on the first real drafts of these maps, delaying any public discussion until the last possible moment.

Cherished aunt of Gudrun (Goodie) Frutkin and Zita Gurrier; beloved great aunt of Andrew Frutkin, Tanya Dean, Mark Gurrier and Heidi Bidwell; greatgreat aunt of Nicole and Erin Gurrier, and Holly and Shannon Bidwell, and Baby Dean; ''Aunt-inlaw'' to Orrie Frutkin, Frank Gurrier, Garry Dean, Wendy Gurrier and Dewey Bidwell. Contributions in Ilse's memory to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590.

title: UNIROYAL TECHNOLOGY TO CUT 90 JOBS AND FREEZE PAY
description: The Uniroyal Technology Corporation, a maker of light-emitting diode display products whose shares had fallen 60 percent this month, said it planned to cut 90 jobs, freeze salaries and reduce the pay of top executives. The cuts are expected to save the company $7.5 million a year. Bonuses were eliminated in 2001 and its coated fabrics business is for sale, the company said. Uniroyal, based in Sarasota, Fla., has lost money in each of its last three fiscal years as it sought to make the transition from making chemicals and plastics.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Introduces Global Phone
description: Nokia introduced a mobile phone yesterday that permits users to roam across different wireless communications standards in the United States, Europe and elsewhere. The new phone, the Nokia 6340, will work on the Global System for Mobile Telecommunications networks, the most widely used global standard, as well as the Time Division Multiple Access standard, used primarily in the United States. Global System has about 500 million users worldwide and is used in more than 70 percent of the world's digital wireless market. Nokia said the new phone also comes equipped with a digital wallet that permits quick wireless transactions. Nokia shares fell 85 cents, to $25.30.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLD, BEATRICE
description: GOLD-Beatrice. Jan 8, 1994. Memories of you dear Mother are always in our hearts. Your loving Daughter and Family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, IRVIN
description: GRAHAM-Irvin. Songwriter, died Dec. 1, 2001. Married to the late Lillian Graham for 30 years. Devoted brother of Cecile Abraham. Irvin had his first hit at 15 when he wrote ''You Better Go Now'' which Imogene Coca sang in ''New Faces.'' He wrote for the ''Show of Shows'' starring Coca and Sid Caesar. Also wrote for the Jane Frohman Show and he & his co-writers wrote ''I Believe'' for her which has become a standard all over the world sung by singers from Elvis Presley, Frankie Laine, to Barbra Streisand on her latest album. He had many devoted and loving friends who will miss him always.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Official Suspected In Theft
description: The parliamentary speaker, Akbar Tandjung, was officially cited as a suspect in the theft of $5 million in government funds said to have been used to finance his party's campaign in 1999. If he is found guilty, his party, Golkar -- which ruled under former President Suharto -- could be banned from Parliament and from the next presidential election, in 2004. Seth Mydans (NYT)

description: Every Giant had an important decision to make today in the locker room: one bag or two. Generally, a player's choice revealed a lot about his status with the team.

description: A group of environmental and civic organizations has walked out on talks with the Long Island Power Authority over developing a long-range energy plan, calling the talks an ''exercise in futility.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Interim Federal Prosecutor
description: James B. Comey was sworn in yesterday as interim United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Mr. Comey, who has been nominated by President Bush but must be confirmed by the Senate, succeeds Mary Jo White, who stepped down after serving more than eight years in the post. Mr. Comey, 41, was formerly a federal prosecutor in Richmond, Va., where he was known for his aggressive prosecution of gun violence and his work in the investigation of the 1996 bombing at the Khobar Towers apartments in Saudi Arabia, which killed 19 American servicemen. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Delay Strategy Is Seen In Fight for Cruise Line
description: Gearing up for its latest offensive in the battle for P&O Princess Cruises, the Carnival Corporation plans this week to request the postponement of a shareholder vote as it seeks clarification of the cost of breaking up a rival deal, people close to Carnival said today.

title: Handshakes All Around
description: A NATION CHALLENGED Correction: January 9, 2002, Wednesday A picture caption yesterday about a meeting between United States Senators and Afghanistan's interim leader at an airport near Kabul misidentified the senator shown second from the left. She was Jean Carnahan of Missouri, not Susan Collins of Maine.

title: Stormy Weather And the PLeasures Of Humility
description: Americans have a long history as weather wimps. If it is our manifest destiny to live in a nation of climatic extremes, it is likewise our manifest duty to resist them. To city dwellers, even rain can be perceived as an affront, both personal and civic. More extreme events, like the seven feet of snow that afflicted long-suffering Buffalo over Christmas, and the ice and snow recently glazing unprepared climes like Atlanta and the Carolinas, evoke mingled feelings of dread and farce.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Iraq Fuel Shipments Resume
description: Shipments of Iraqi fuel oil into Turkey resumed through the border gate at Habur in southeastern Turkey. The shipments, which are outside the United Nations oil-for-food program, are tolerated by the United States and its allies because of the damaging effect on the Turkish economy of sanctions against Iraq. About 100 Turkish trucks a day will be permitted to return from northern Iraq carrying diesel oil and other fuel, border officials said. The flow was shut off four months ago when the Iraqi government stopped shipments to the Kurds in northern Iraq and is resuming now that the oil has begun to flow again. Before the shutoff, as many as 1,000 trucks a day made the trip. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: AOL Expecting Rule to Lead To Big Charge And Net Loss
description: AOL Time Warner, the world's biggest media company, said yesterday that it would take a charge of $40 billion to $60 billion in the first quarter to reflect the costs of its merger last year because of a change in accounting rules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMPTION, JAMES D.
description: SUMPTION-James D. Of Bronxville, NY, and Vero Beach, FL, age 62, passed away on January 6, 2002. The beloved husband of Julie, loving father of Scott and brother of R. Stephen Sumption was born in Philadelphia, PA, the elder son of Horace Y. and Emily A. Sumption of West Chester, PA. He received a BA from Colgate University in 1961 and served as an officer in The United States Navy from 1962-1965. He began his business career with U.S. Trust Company and later established and was President of Pin Oak Capital, Ltd., a New York investment firm, a subsidiary of Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated. He was an Elder at The Reformed Church of Bronxville and a past President of Siwanoy Country Club. He was also a member of the Union League Club of New York, Red Stick Golf Club and Orchid Island Golf and Beach Club of Vero Beach, Florida. A memorial service will be held at Tthe Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, January 12, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Deacon's Fund of The Reformed Church of Bronxville or to Colgate University.

title: When Oscar Losers Become Winners
description: Here's some consolation for the Oscar nominees for best screenplay who don't get the prize this March: odds are that they'll live longer than the winner, according to a new study in The British Journal of Medicine.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 26 about John C. Dearie, a New York lawyer who runs a mobile law office in a bus, misstated the average number of points he scored per game while playing basketball for Notre Dame. The university says it was 10.35, not 18.

title: Upper East Side Councilman Has Speaker's Job All but Won
description: The battle for a new City Council speaker all but ended yesterday as final political maneuverings made it seemingly inevitable that A. Gifford Miller, a councilman from the Upper East Side, would win election to the second most powerful post in New York City government.

title: Still Digging for Lost Sons After a Million Tons of Pain
description: The father comes to be near his son. He digs through the smoking steel with a small Army pick and shovel. ''Where are you, boy?'' he asks. It has been the same routine for months.

title: An Earlier Start Time For the Wanamaker Mile
description: Since the 1930's, the most glamorous race in indoor track, the Wanamaker Mile, has been run at 10 p.m., at first to accommodate Ted Husing's live radio broadcast.

title: BORGWARNER TO WRITE OFF $19 MILLION FOR ACQUISITIONS
description: BorgWarner Inc., a leading maker of automatic-transmission parts, expects costs of about $19 million in the fourth quarter to write off the value of assets and other expenses. Excluding the cost of 72 cents a share for the write-offs, the company will earn $3.10 to $3.20 in 2001, a spokeswoman, Mary Brevard, said. Analysts surveyed by by Thomson Financial/First Call had forecast BorgWarner would earn $3.15 a share. The costs are mostly related to businesses BorgWarner bought the last few years to broaden its product range. BorgWarner is writing off environmental costs and expenses to combine headquarters of three units at a site in Auburn Hills, Mich.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Holiday Consumers Spend $13.8 Billion Online
description: Holiday shoppers in the United States spent $13.8 billion online in November and December, including travel purchases, according to a report released yesterday by Goldman, Sachs, Harris Interactive and Nielsen/NetRatings. Online holiday spending was up 15 percent compared with the period in 2000, when shoppers spent $12 billion over the Internet, according to Harris Interactive and Nielsen/NetRatings. The 2001 data is based on a weekly national survey of 500 online shoppers randomly chosen from Harris Interactive's panel of Net users. The survey also reported that consumers said 13 percent of their 2001 holiday shopping budget was done online.

description: ABC, which has suffered a steep falloff in its prime-time ratings this television season, announced a change at the top of its entertainment division yesterday, removing the longtime creative executive Stu Bloomberg as co-chairman.

title: Health Spending Soars
description: National health spending shot up 6.9 percent to $1.3 trillion in 2000, the Department of Health and Human Services said. It was the largest one-year percentage increase since 1993.

title: Maine Salmon Are a Breed Apart, Panel Reports
description: A panel convened by the National Academy of Sciences concluded yesterday that the few wild Atlantic salmon still breeding in Maine's rivers are genetically distinct from other strains, bolstering a year-old federal decision to add the state's native salmon to the endangered species list.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Lawmaking Online
description: C-Span addicts can listen to the Legislature live on the Internet now that the state has become the 38th to offer such coverage. Both houses of the Legislature will be covered gavel to gavel at www.ai.org/legislative/session/audio.html. For now, the sessions can only be heard, not seen, but Representative David L. Crooks said there would soon be video as well. The National Conference of State Legislatures said 14 other state legislatures offered audio on the Web, while 20 have video and 20 are covered live on television. Some, like those in New Jersey and Connecticut, offer all three. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

description: Theo Fleury met with his Rangers coaches and teammates this morning and apologized for his behavior in recent games. Coach Ron Low indicated after practice that he would not tolerate any more of Fleury's misbehavior.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hotel Reopens Near Ground Zero
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday officially reopened the Marriott Financial Center hotel, which had been used as a Red Cross center for workers at ground zero since the Sept. 11 terror attack. The 504-room hotel at 85 West Street, a few blocks south of ground zero, suffered extensive water damage from fire hoses after the attack but has since been repaired. ''I want everyone to understand that New York is safe, it's clean and it's open for business,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Visa Issued To Detained Muslim  Doctor
description: A Muslim doctor in San Antonio who was arrested after the Sept. 11 attacks but later released was prohibited from re-entering the country last month after a trip to Saudi Arabia. A State Department official said the doctor, Al-Badr Al Hazmi, was issued a visa on Saturday and would be allowed to return. Muslim leaders in San Antonio had expressed outrage over the situation. On Sept. 12, Dr. Hazmi was handcuffed and dragged away from his San Antonio home in his pajamas. After 12 days of questioning, he was released. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Deal in Works To Raise Pay Of Workers In Health Care
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is promoting a deal with legislative leaders and the largest union of hospital workers that would avert budget cuts to health care programs and pay for raises for health care workers, people familiar with the talks said.

title: REGULATORS URGE EASING U.S. RULES ON AIR POLLUTION
description: Top federal regulators have recommended informally that the White House relax one of the nation's most contentious air pollution regulations, a provision that requires power plants to upgrade pollution control equipment when they upgrade their operations.

description: A Ford Motor Company plant in Edison, N.J., which makes Ranger pickups, might be shut down as part of the major reorganization the automaker is set to announce on Friday, a top Ford official said today.

title: Surprise Bus Strike in Queens Forces 120,000 to Scramble
description: With sleet and snow predicted, Queens commuters were already bracing for a tough morning rush yesterday, but it turned far nastier than expected when nearly 1,500 drivers and mechanics at three private bus lines conducted a surprise walkout.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Visit Set To Nuclear Lab
description: Three inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency arrive in North Korea next Tuesday for a four-day visit to an isotope production laboratory at the North Korean nuclear complex at Yongbyon. But Melissa Fleming, public affairs officer at the agency headquarters in Vienna, made clear that the visitors would not inspect installations suspected of harboring enough weapons-grade plutonium for two warheads, which was produced before the signing of the Geneva agreement in 1994. The inspectors ''are certainly not going to find anything out,'' she said, adding, ''It's not a breakthrough.'' Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Turkey, Well Along Road to Secularism, Fears Detour to Islamism
description: Nowhere does the war against Islamic extremism have more resonance than in Turkey: for eight decades, the country has used draconian laws and the threat of force to crush pro-Islamic politicians and protect secular ideals.

title: EU Passports:An Easy-to-Steal Tool for Terrorists
description: BRUSSELS  When two Tunisian men blew themselves up last September in front of Ahmed Shah Massoud, the Northern Alliance leader in Afghanistan who later died of his wounds, it set off alarm bells around Europe.

title: Vaccine Program Reduces Measles Cases
description: The number of measles cases in the Western Hemisphere fell by 99 percent over the last decade, thanks to an aggressive vaccination campaign led by the Pan American Health Organization, according to an article in The Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi To Sell Shares
description: Vivendi Universal said it planned to raise 3.3 billion euros ($3 billion) by selling existing shares. The proceeds will be used to reduce debt, which swelled after Jean-Marie Messier, the chief executive, transformed the water utility into a media and entertainment conglomerate through several major acquisitions, including the $34 billion purchase of Universal Studios and other entertainment assets controlled by the Seagram Company, and last month's $10.3 billion acquisition of the entertainment business of the USA Networks run by Barry Diller. In December, Moody's Investors Service revised its outlook on Vivendi's long-term debt to negative from stable. Vivendi's current debt rating of Baa is two notches above junk. Vivendi is offering 55 million shares, at 60 to 61 euros each. Separately, Vivendi and the Vodafone Group said that an Internet portal they jointly own, Vizzavi, would cut 100 jobs and replace its chief executive, Evan Newmark, who will leave at the end of the month and be replaced by Guy Laurence, chief marketing officer.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Listen.com To Announce Licensing Pacts
description: Listen.com, an Internet music company, plans to announce today that it has signed licensing agreements with EMI Recorded Music, part of the EMI Group, and BMG, the music arm of Bertelsmann. The agreements will permit Listen.com, based in San Francisco, to sell the labels' music on a streaming basis, which means that Listen.com customers can listen to the music over the Internet. The company said it is making some music available now, and would add more in the coming weeks. However, the deal does not permit Listen .com's subscribers to download the songs onto their own computers or transfer them to mobile devices. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Propelled by Drug and Hospital Costs, Health Spending Surged in 2000
description: National health spending shot up 6.9 percent to $1.3 trillion in 2000, the government said today. It was the largest one-year percentage increase since rising costs led President Bill Clinton to propose guarantee health insurance for all Americans in 1993.

title: Smuggled Arms in the Mideast
description: The opportunity for constructive American diplomacy in the Mideast these days is limited and precarious. That depressing pattern may now be about to repeat itself.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Suharto Son To Be Charged

description: Heart disease is often viewed as more of a man's disease than a woman's, yet more women die in the hospital after a heart attack than men. Some studies have suggested that the reason for the difference is that women get less aggressive treatment.

title: How Excess Vitamin A Can Hit the Hips

title: Now, a Personal Trainer for Your Brain
description: ''Mozart's Brain and the Fighter Pilot,'' by Dr. Richard Restak, Harmony Books, $21.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Inquiry Into Anti-Leftist Campaign
description: The government has appointed a lawyer to investigate cases of torture and murder committed by the state in a counterinsurgency campaign against leftists during the 1970's. The lawyer, Ignacio Carrillo Prieto, will be a special prosecutor with the power to investigate and try cases against government and army officials. President Vicente Fox pledged last year to investigate accusations that hundreds of leftists and sympathizers were killed by government forces. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: The New York Times's Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: Seeking Polynesia's Beginnings In an Archipelago of Shards
description: The archaeologist David V. Burley looked out on Fanga 'Uta Lagoon and tried to think like ancient seafarers. Here, at the head of the lagoon, is where the first of their outrigger canoes must have pulled in, concluding heroic voyages of hundreds, perhaps more than a thousand miles from the west. So here he decided to dig on the South Pacific island of Tongatapu in the kingdom of Tonga.

title: Fred Taylor, Hall of Fame Basketball Coach, Dies at 77
description: Fred Taylor, the Hall of Fame basketball coach at Ohio State whose teams won the N.C.A.A. championship in 1960 and reached the title game the following two seasons, died Sunday at a nursing home in Hilliard, Ohio. He was 77.

title: Theres No Place Like Home
A Different Perspective For Miami's Mourning
description: Danny Fortson and Marc Jackson, two of the N.B.A's bullish players, were pushing and shoving Alonzo Mourning the other night. The two Golden State Warriors were employing an old strategy: make 'Zo blow.

title: Sept. 11 Terror Suspect Backs Effort to Televise His Trial
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 9  A lawyer for Zacarias Moussaoui, the first person charged with complicity in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, said at a hearing in federal court today that Mr. Moussaoui supported a legal effort by a cable television network to broadcast his trial.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Barksdale Closes Venture Fund
description: The Barksdale Group, a venture-capital firm formed in 1999 by former executives of Netscape Communications, said it had decided to close rather than seek another round of financing. Founded by James L. Barksdale, the former chief executive of Netscape, the firm raised $180 million and invested about two-thirds of it in 17 start-ups, including Moxi Digital, which is working on a digital television set-top box and has an alliance with EchoStar Communications. Mr. Barksdale, above, will become a special adviser to General Atlantic Partners; Peter Currie will become a partner at General Atlantic; and Daniel H. Rimer will open a London office for Index Ventures, a Swiss venture capital firm. Quincy Smith, the fourth partner, has not announced his plans. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, DAVID
description: ROSE-David. Beloved husband of Sue. Devoted father of Sharon Sternbach & Althea Hendrickson. Loving grandfather of Joel, Stuart, Ilene, Daniel and Warren. Services are today, 11 A.M. at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: Knicks Swallow Another Bitter Pill
description: General Manager Scott Layden, his arms crossed and his lips pursed, stood in front of his seat after tonight's Knicks game, appearing stunned and angry. After several seconds, James L. Dolan, the chairman of Madison Square Garden, waved Layden forward, and the Knicks officials departed the Compaq Center, trying to digest another agonizing loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOORSANGER, CATHERINE HOOVER
description: VOORSANGER-Catherine Hoover, 51. Died Dec. 24, 2001. The service will be held at All Souls Church at 80 St & Lexington Ave, NYC, 11:30 AM. Friday, Jan 11.

title: Political Memo; A Wary Rank and File Watch Daschle's Attack
description: Wondering why Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, attacked President Bush's $1.35 trillion tax cut last week, but did not call for it to be changed? Just listen to a few of the 12 Senate Democrats who voted for the cut.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Rebel Merger Angers Government
description: The government condemned two rival groups of rebels that have agreed to merge, saying they were hindering efforts to end the country's long civil war. ''We expected that the merger agreement would talk about reaching peace in Sudan instead of showing an intention for escalating the military operations,'' said Foreign Minister Mustafa Osman Ismail. Over the weekend, John Garang of the Sudan People's Liberation Army agreed to join forces with the Sudan People's Democratic Front, led by Riek Machar. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAIR, WILLIAM R., M.D.
description: FAIR-William R., M.D. The staff and leadership of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, William R. Fair, M.D., a noted urologic surgeon and former Chief of the Urology Service. Bill devoted his professional career to advancing the treatment of prostate cancer and, more recently, used his personal experiences to focus public discussion on the value of complementary medicine. Our thoughts are with his family. Harold Varmus, President David Golde, Physician-in-Chief Murray Brennan, Chairman, Department of Surgery Peter Scardino, Chairman, Department of Urology Victor Reuter, President, Medical Staff Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Big Sale of Shares in Vivendi Fails to Excite Investors
description: A planned $3 billion sale of existing shares in Vivendi Universal turned somewhat messy and potentially costly for the company's underwriters today.

title: French Toast, Fortified
description: WHEN the waiter set down the house dessert at El Cid in Chelsea, everyone at my table eyed it with suspicion. ''It looks like an old shoe,'' one friend said. Not exactly the description the chef was after, I'm sure, but true.

title: No Style Points but an A For Effort for St. John's
description: More than ever, St. John's should embrace the Big East, a conference made for teams that are trying to establish an identity.

title: Postal Service Plans Layoffs And 3-Cent Rise in Postage
description: The United States Postal Service said today that it planned to raise the price of a first-class stamp to 37 cents in June and cut as many as 15,000 jobs this year as a result of the weak economy, the attacks of Sept. 11 and the discovery of anthrax in the mail system.

title: Port of Spain Journal; Failed Rebel's Boast: At Least He Rules the Street
description: Older and seemingly unrepentant, Yasin Abu Bakr, the spiritual leader of the Jamaat al-Muslimeen, has endured, even if its infamous attempt to remake Trinidad did not.

title: Sandwiches Worthy of the Pedigree
description: NOTE from the Department of Heightened Expectations: If you're going to call your cafe Bread, the bread had better be really good.

title: Duck Leg Confidential
description: DUCK legs have been my secret ingredient ever since the day I thought about making confit and had a very Jack Sprat reaction to the recipe. What if I left out the usual quart of duck fat? What would happen to the legs?

title: Jordan's Wife Files for Divorce
description: Juanita Jordan, Michael Jordan's his wife of 12 years, has filed for divorce, citing ''irreconcilable differences.''

title: Court Orders $300 Million Paid to Banks By Motorola
description: A federal judge has ordered Motorola to pay $300 million to Chase Manhattan Bank and several other lenders to repay part of a loan to the company's troubled satellite telephone venture, Iridium.

title: Bird Man of the Arctic
description: Ascientist named George Divoky has been living part of each year for the last 27 years in northernmost Alaska, at an inhospitable spot called Cooper Island. The nearest tree to his camp stands 200 miles away.

title: Major League Soccer Eliminates Two Teams
description: Some might call it a dubious distinction, but Major League Soccer has beaten Major League Baseball to the punch on contraction.

title: Sex and the Kitchen
description: IF you've heard of Nigella Lawson, it is likely you know the following things about her: She is voluptuous. She licks her fingers and likes to flick her hair as she flirts with the camera. And her cooking show, ''Nigella Bites,'' has created a sensation in Britain, where it is one of the country's most popular cooking programs.

title: Education Bill Urges New Emphasis on Phonics as Method for Teaching Reading
description: The education bill President Bush signed into law today includes an ambitious federal commitment to teaching reading, which is expected to emphasize phonics over other methods of early reading instruction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHMAN, RUBIN
description: HOCHMAN-Rubin, 95. Predeceased by beloved wife Sophie. Loving father of Phyllis and Murray Shapiro and Tina Schnall. Adored grandfather and greatgrandfather. He was a gentle man whose spirit and wit will be sorely missed.

title: U.S. Seems Sure to Oppose Amnesty Proposed by Afghan Captors : 3 Taliban Leaders Said to Surrender
description: WASHINGTON  Three top Taliban figures have surrendered to anti-Taliban Afghan fighters, local officials said Tuesday in Kandahar, adding that all would be eligible for amnesty.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Judge To Review Deer Kill
description: Lawyers for Princeton Township yesterday asked Judge Neil H. Shuster of State Superior Court in Trenton to allow the town to trap and shoot deer by lifting another judge's week-old order that blocked the program. Critics say the methods for killing the deer -- using high-powered rifles with silencers or catching deer with nets and firing bolts into their heads -- are dangerous and cruel. Judge Shuster is expected to issue his decision today. Meanwhile, Rutgers University found in a poll released yesterday that half of New Jersey residents said there were too many deer in the state, and that of drivers who had to slow down or swerve to miss a deer, one in four had actually hit a deer. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Jon Chalon was named publisher at Spin magazine, New York, part of Vibe/Spin Ventures, succeeding John Rollins, president, who left. He had been vice president and associate publisher at The Industry Standard, New York, which closed.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Congressman Will Retire
description: Representative James V. Hansen of Utah, a conservative Republican, announced he would not seek re-election after 21 years in Congress. Mr. Hansen, 69, chairman of the Resources Committee, made a reputation as an advocate for mining and ranching interests. Environmentalists said they looked forward to electing a replacement who was a better steward of natural resources. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: ARCHER DANIELS PATENTS HEALTH SUPPLEMENT PROCESS
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company, a grain processor, says it has received a patent on a technique for making health-food supplement ingredients from soybeans and flaxseed. The patent covers a method for isolating chemicals that promote cardiovascular and prostate health, the company said. Archer Daniels is based in Decatur, Ill.

title: Old Rules Gone, Argentines Brace for the Unknown
description: For more than a decade, Juan Carlos Meluso and his wife, Silvia Cataldo, awoke each morning knowing that one Argentine peso was worth one American dollar. Although the system was far from perfect, at least the rules were clear.

description: THE CAPRICES

title: A Bush Event Signals All-Out Politics
description: After four months of steering clear of partisan political events, President Bush will appear on Wednesday at a fund-raising dinner here for his brother Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, the White House announced tonight.

description: With the South African rand continuing to struggle and accusations of market manipulation emerging, President Thabo Mbeki appointed a panel today to examine the currency's recent plunge.

title: 4 Israeli Soldiers Are Killed in Attack by Hamas Militants
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 9  Palestinian gunmen attacked an Israeli Army position in southern Israel on the border with the Gaza Strip today, killing four Israeli soldiers and wounding two others, one seriously. The gunmen also died.

title: Counseling Center at Barnard
description: ROSEMARY FRANKEL FURMAN, a Barnard alumna and trustee, and her husband, RICHARD, have decided to contribute $1.25 million to build the Rosemary F. Furman Counseling Center at the college. The center, to open in the fall, will include eight private counseling offices, an acute care room, a secluded reception area and a library/conference room.

description: Folk art charm is combined with honest ingredients in a gift box of Grade A maple syrup and buttermilk pancake mix from Brown Family Farm in Putney, Vt. The mix calls for just water, but it can be enriched with eggs and melted butter to make tender, fluffy pancakes and waffles.

description: GOMES-Dennis James. On September 11, 2001, at The World Trade Center, New York City. title: High Court Rebukes South Carolina Over Death Penalty Sentencing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The United States Supreme Court today spared the life of a convicted killer, at least temporarily, as it took South Carolina's high court to task for the third time over its sentencing procedures in death-penalty cases.

title: White House Seeking Funds To Dismantle Nuclear Arms
description: The Bush administration, initially dubious about the nuclear nonproliferation programs it inherited, plans to ask Congress for 37 percent more money this year than it sought a year ago for Energy Department programs to safeguard and dispose of weapons-grade nuclear materials.

title: Analyst Rates Tyco 'Hold'
description: Tyco International was rated hold today by Nicholas Heymann, a Prudential Securities analyst, the only recommendation by a large Wall Street firm that does not advise investors to purchase the company's shares.

title: Europe Plan Would Give Bumped Fliers More Money
description: To the expected relief of bedraggled fliers, the European Commission has proposed a law to make airlines pay at least the equivalent of about $670 to every passenger bumped from a European flight.

title: Raiders Are Confident Of Turning It Around
description: The Oakland Raiders have been displaced. They have had to ride buses to nearby high schools to find firmer footing than their rain-pelted practice field offers. They have lost their place atop the National Football League, although after 10 games they looked like genuine Super Bowl contenders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, JOSEPH FRANCIS, JR.
description: GOLDEN-Joseph Francis, Jr., of Teaneck NJ, died in his home on January 7, 2002. Born in 1932 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to Joseph Francis Golden, Sr. and Mary Gara Golden, he graduated from Penn Charter School in 1949 and from Princeton University in 1953, where he won the Ivy League batting title and contributed to Tiger teams that went to the College World Series and won the Ivy League Championship in 1953. After college he played professional baseball for the Philadelphia Athletics farm team in 1953 and 1954. After serving in the U.S. Army, he began his forty-year career at Milberg Factors Inc., in Manhattan, where he was President for many years. He was a nationally-ranked senior tennis player, avid golfer, and was a member of Hackensack and Arcola Golf Clubs in New Jersey and Colliers Reserve Country Club and Old Colliers Golf Club in Naples, Florida. He was a strong supporter of Loyola School in Manhattan, Penn Charter School in Philadelphia and of Princeton University, where he received the ''Robert L. Peters, Jr. '42 Award'' for his lifelong support of Princeton's baseball program. He is the beloved husband of Eileen (nee Walsh) Golden, father of Mary Frances and her husband Daniel Sponseller, Eileen W. Golden, Susan and her husband Victor Del Rio, and William and his wife Diane Golden; and grandfather of Julia and Daniel Sponseller, Joseph, Dylan and William Del Rio and Shannon, Katherine and Elizabeth Golden. The family has asked in lieu of flowers that contributions be made, in Mr. Golden's memory, to Loyola School 980 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10028, or to Saint Anne's School 542 8th Avenue South., Naples, Florida, 34102. Visitation will be held on Thursday, January 10, 2002 from 24pm and 7-9pm at the Volk Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, NJ, 07666, 201-836-0202. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10:30 am on January 11, 2002 at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue (between 83rd and 84th Street) New York, New York, 10028 with interment immediately following at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ.

title: NBC Will Live Without N.B.A. and Without Losses From It
description: To Dick Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports, relinquishing the rights to televise the National Basketball Association after this season is all about financial common sense.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Retailer Reports Charge
description: The Dutch-based retailer Royal Ahold reported a 100 million euro ($89 million) charge in the fourth quarter to cover losses from operations in Argentina, which accounts for 3 percent of the company's sales. The company, whose assets include the Stop and Shop and Giant supermarket chains, stuck to its projection of 15 percent growth in earnings per share for 2001 and 2002 and reported that 2001 sales had grown 27 percent, to 66.6 billion euros ($59.4 billion). The company will report full 2001 results on March 7. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: SEARS TO CUT 1,500 JOBS AND LEAVE CARPET BUSINESS
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company will eliminate 1,500 jobs and stop selling and installing carpets as it frees space for more profitable products like appliances. The company expects to book an undisclosed amount of costs for the moves in the fourth quarter, a spokeswoman, Peggy Palter, said. The company will report results on Jan. 17. Sears, which employs 275,000, may shift some affected workers to other positions, Ms. Palter said. The job cuts add to 4,900 positions the company is eliminating in an attempt to double its profit in the next three years in its retail, product-installation and repair businesses. Sears, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., has about 860 department stores and sells carpet at 560 sites.

title: Hijacker Got a Speeding Ticket
description: A leader of the Sept. 11 hijackings aroused no suspicion when he was stopped for speeding in Maryland two days before the attacks, a state police official said today after releasing a videotape of the encounter with a state trooper.

title: Gonzalez And Mets: No Market For Truths
description: If Steve Phillips believed outfielder Juan Gonzalez when he gushed about playing for the Mets, he might want to go out and buy the Brooklyn Bridge and give it to his boss to add to his real estate empire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, MARY EDDY
description: SCHLESINGER-Mary Eddy. Of Lakeville, CT, and Martha's Vineyard, MA, died on January 4th. She was 85. She was the wife of the late Dr. Edward B. Schlesinger. Born in Newington, CT, she graduated from the Oxford-Kingswood School and Smith College, Class of 1938. She was a former resident of Dobbs Ferry, NY, and Alpine, NJ, and a long-term member of the New York-Presbyterian Hospital Auxiliary, The Cosmopolitan Club and the Garden Club of Dobbs Ferry. She was a former member of the Junior League of Westchester. A supporter of land preservation efforts, she gave property to conservation trusts in Salisbury, CT, and Sheffield, MA. She was an accomplished violinist and pianist, an avid sportswoman who excelled at golf and skiing, and a lifelong gardener. Her generosity of spirit, sparkling intellect and gracious manner will be greatly missed. She is survived by Jane Schlesinger of Santa Fe, NM, Mary DePasquale of NYC, Ralph Schlesinger of Malvern, PA, Prudence Adler of Washington, D.C., and seven grandchildren. A service to celebrate her life will be held on Saturday, January 26, at 1PM, at the Congregational Church in Salisbury, CT. Donations may be made in her memory to the Salisbury Visiting Nurse Association, Salisbury, CT. 06068.
