title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tickets For Ground Zero
description: To enable people to see the site where the World Trade Center stood without having to stand in line for hours in the cold, the city will begin offering free tickets to the public viewing stand today for 15-minute intervals. The stand, on Fulton Street between Broadway and Church Street, has attracted thousands since it opened on Dec. 30. Under the arrangement, first reported in The Daily News, tickets will be stamped with a time for visiting. They will be available at the South Street Seaport Museum. The platform is open daily, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Risks Persist, Panel Says
description: Computer systems in the United States are increasingly vulnerable to attack despite plentiful technology to make them secure, a report published by the National Academy of Sciences says. Citing 10 years of studies, the authors of the report, ''Cybersecurity Today and Tomorrow: Pay Now or Pay Later,'' say that ''our ability and willingness to deal with threats has, on balance, changed for the worse.'' Industry needs to do more to build security directly into new hardware and software, the authors wrote, and policy makers should finance research and consider ''steps that would increase the exposure of software and system vendors and system operators to liability for system breaches.'' The report can be found at http://books.nap .edu/html/cybersecurity. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BICKOFF, GEORGE
description: BICKOFF-George. On January 4, 2002. Loving husband of Norma. Beloved uncle. He will be very much missed. Services were held Sunday, at ''The Riverside''.

description: Two men wanted in a rash of shootings that left three dead and two injured in Virginia were arrested yesterday by the New York City police after being pulled over for what investigators called a routine traffic infraction in the Bronx.

title: Police Return to a Focus on Panhandling and Prostitution
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that sweeps begun Friday as part of a renewed effort to crack down on panhandlers, prostitutes and squeegee men have resulted in more than 70 arrests and nearly 200 summonses.

title: 'The Fantasticks' Is Ending Its 42-Year Run
description: Before there was a Unisphere in Flushing Meadow Park or a bridge dedicated to an explorer named Verrazano, before the Beatles cut their first single or the Soviets spirited missiles into Cuba, a small band of actors filed nightly into a tiny theater in Greenwich Village to perform a romantic little musical about a boy, a girl and the travails of young love.

title: Downtown, Hit Brightens An Emerging Playwright
description: Politely put, the characters in Melissa James Gibson's comedy ''[sic]'' aren't exactly setting the world on fire. One is a frustrated composer of theme park jingles. Another is a chronic borrower and academic. The third is a failed auctioneer.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Agence France-Presse on Sunday about Juweid al-Ghossein, a former official of the Palestine Liberation Organization who was forcibly removed from a Cairo hospital and taken to Gaza, misstated his legal history. The Palestinian Authority had won a suit against Mr. Ghossein in Abu Dhabi, accusing him of failure to repay a 1991 loan of $6.5 million. An appeals court reversed that decision. The suit was not brought by Abu Dhabi officials, and a court in Abu Dhabi did not order his arrest in the case. The Palestinian Authority says he is being detained in Gaza in connection with the financial dispute.

title: Not Settling for the Label 'One of the Best'
description: CHTEAU FIGEAC, a treasure of the Bordeaux wine country, is little more than two miles from the center of this medieval village, but take a cellphone and a compass if you're invited to visit. You will see signs for Rocher-Bellevue-Figeac, La Tour-Figeac, Cros-Figeac, Grand Barrail-Lamarzelle Figeac, Yon-Figeac, Cormey-Figeac, Petit-Figeac and several others including two chateaus named La Tour-du-Pin-Figeac.

title: Terrorism Lesson Revised
description: An educational Web site operated by Scholastic Inc. was one of many that posted lessons on terrorism after Sept. 11. But last week, Scholastic quietly reworded its ''History of Terrorism'' lesson after Assemblyman DOV HIKIND complained that it defamed Jews. Mr. Hikind, a Republican from Brooklyn, complained because the lesson suggested that terrorism originated with the Zealots, a first-century Jewish sect that openly resisted Roman rule in Palestine. After getting an indignant letter from Mr. Hikind, Scholastic removed the reference from the site, www.scholastic.com.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Governor's Disclosure
description: Gov. Judy Martz has revealed that she washed the clothes her top aide was wearing after he killed the state House majority leader in a drunken-driving accident. Governor Martz said it was simply a mother's instinct to clean up Shane Hedges's bloody clothes when he came to stay at the governor's residence after the accident. She said she was unaware that the items were evidence until the authorities came to get them days later. Mr. Hedges, the governor's former policy director, is serving six months in a halfway house for negligent homicide in the Aug. 15, 2001, crash that killed Paul Sliter, 32. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Our Towns; Downwind, A Crusade Resurfaces, Mainstream
description: IT'S just under 19 miles north, as the crow flies or the radioactive cloud drifts -- from the Indian Point nuclear power plant to Connie Hogarth's house here on a hill overlooking the Hudson. Not nearly enough to survive a meltdown, she says sweetly, offering a teaspoon or two of horror as she pours a visitor a cup of coffee.

title: THE CHEF
description: THERE is nothing better than a bowl of soup and a piece of good bread. When I was a boy in Austria, I'd come home and smell meat and spices cooking -- goulash! -- and want some right away. The main difference between the goulash you serve for dinner and goulash soup is that for the soup you cut everything smaller. Most of the ingredients are the same, and once you know how to make the soup, you will know how to make a good goulash, too.

title: It's No Way to Run an Airport, but Kabul Staff Makes It Work
description: Sultan-Muhammad Faizi was relaxing over a meal of bread and spinach in the control tower of Kabul International Airport when his radio crackled to life. A United States government plane was arriving from Tajikistan and needed directions on how to land.

title: Rep. Dingell Is Forced to Strip After Hip Sets Off Airport Alarm
description: The phone kept ringing yesterday at the office of Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, who was asked to strip to his underwear on Saturday before boarding an airplane because his artificial hip kept setting off security alarms.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Women Protest Election
description: Hundreds of women marched through Lusaka to protest the recent election of President Levy Mwanawasa, with some baring their breasts in a traditional demonstration of disgust. The election of Mr. Mwanawasa, left, who appointed his cabinet on Monday, was marred by charges of vote rigging. Several opposition party leaders have vowed a court challenge. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Old Bomb Found In Berlin
description: An unexploded World War II bomb found buried beneath the lower ring of seats of Olympic Stadium in Berlin was defused by explosives experts, the police said. The 550-pound British bomb was found during renovation work. The 76,000-seat stadium, designed by the Nazi architect Albert Speer for the 1936 Olympics, is being overhauled for the 2006 World Cup soccer tournament. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Neediest Cases Fund Gets Millionth Gift
description: Among the 719 donations received yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was the millionth gift it has received since the fund's inception in 1912.

title: Enron and Cheney Aides Met 4 Times
description: Officials of the Enron Corporation met four times last year with the staff of Vice President Dick Cheney's energy task force to discuss energy policy matters, but they never talked about the company's finances, according to David S. Addington, Mr. Cheney's counsel.

title: Surge in Bias Cases Punishes Insurers, And Premiums Rise
description: Many companies, alarmed by the increasing size of payouts to resolve harassment or discrimination claims by employees, have bought insurance policies over the last decade to protect themselves.

title: Gustav Rau, 79, Art Collector And Benefactor of Children
description: The art collector and philanthropist Gustav Rau, who amassed one of the world's major private art collections, died in Stuttgart last Thursday. He was 79.

title: Sports of The Times; Martin Should Use Head as Well as Body
description: BYRON SCOTT was talking about smart basketball players, and about how Magic Johnson, once a teammate of his with the champion Los Angeles Lakers, was the greatest, for example, at dealing with referees. The smartest players always look for an edge, Scott was saying, and having the referees not antagonistic toward you -- maybe even liking you -- was a plus. Oh, and wise players also comprehend that they must refrain from ejections. They don't help their team when banished to the locker room.

title: Focusing on Home Front, Bush Signs Education Bill
description: President Bush continued to emphasize domestic politics over war today as he signed into a law a major education bill that he reminded his listeners had been a central promise of his presidential campaign.

title: Closed Trial Begins in Tehran For Dissidents Accused of Plot
description: Iran's hard-line Revolutionary Court began the trials of 15 dissidents today. Most of them are writers and intellectuals and are charged with plotting to overthrow the Islamic system.

title: Club Med Has First Loss in 4 Years and Closes 6 More Resorts
description: Reflecting the plunge in international travel since Sept. 11, the resort operator Club Mditerrane said today that it would close six more of its locations and eliminate its dividend.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Guilty Plea To Murder
description: A man pleaded guilty to murder yesterday for a 1987 killing in which two other men were wrongly convicted and spent 14 years in jail. The man, Arlet Cheston, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to second-degree murder for shooting a livery-cab driver, Jean Ulysses, prosecutors said. Mr. Cheston, 42, of Crown Heights, negotiated a deal under which he will receive the minimum sentence of 15 years to life in prison, said Orlando Rivera, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney's office. The two innocent men were freed last May. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, HANA HERMANN HELLER
description: HALL-Hana Hermann Heller. May 16, 1920-January 6, 2002. wife of the late Dr. Herbert H. Hall, mother of Danita and Suzanne, mother-in-law of Jim, grandmother of Alexandra. With great sadness we mourn her death.

title: Article 2002010991862865005 -- No Title
description: The New York Times

title: The Magic of Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSINI, IGOR (GHIGHI)
description: CASSINI-Igor (Ghighi), 86. On Saturday, January 5, 2002. Son of Count Alexander and Countess Marguerite Loiewski Cassini, and grandson of Count Arthur Cassini, last Czarist Russian Ambassador to The U.S. under The Theodore Roosevelt and McKinley Administrations. Renowned journalist and writer, former reporter for The Hearst Newspapers, and known by many as Cholly Knickerbocker. Possessed with great wit and charm, Igor set many legendary lifestyle trends. The stroke of his pen was often sharp but always dazzling and launched many to fame and fortune. Beloved father of Marina Cassini, Alexander Cassini, Nicholas Cassini and Dimitri Cassini, and stepfather Dana Dantine. Beloved grandfather of Darrah Ferrari, Alessandro Minoli, Michele Minoli, and Isabella Cassini, and great grandfather of Giovanni and Isabella. Beloved brother of Oleg Cassini. The family will be receiving friends Wednesday January 9th, 2-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral services will be held on Thursday 10 A.M. at Our Lady of The Sign, Park Avenue at 93rd Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICOL, ROBERT JOHN
description: NICOL-Robert John. Of Bonner Peak Ranch, La Porte and Fort Collins died at home suddenly on Sunday, January 6th. He was a resident of Colorado since January 1996. The family will receive friends who wish to pay respects at the Reager Funeral Home, 1530 Riverside Ave., Ft. Collins on Wednesday January 9th between 4 and 6 PM. Robert J. Nicol was born in Genoa, Italy on February 22, 1930 to British parents. A graduate of Riverdale Country Day School, Harvard College, and Harvard Law School, he practiced Admiralty Law and business in New York City. Business ownership included Metropolitan News Services, McGrath Industries, and International Terminal Operators. He married Margaret Gammage on October 29, 1955 in Atlanta, Georgia. He is survived by his wife; two daughters, Elisabeth A. Nicol and Margaret W. Nicol, both of Fort Collins; two sons, Robert D. Nicol of Boulder and Ian A. Nicol of Fort Collins; nephews Joseph Holme and Simon Holme of Florida; nieces Roberta Wolyner of NYC and Jennifer Holme of Connecticut; and first cousins Anne Smallwood of Oxford, England and David Smallwood of France. Memorial contributions may be given to the Children's Prosthetic/Orthotic Fund in care of the Poudre Valley Hospital Foundation, 1024 South Lemay Avenue, Fort Collins, CO. 80524-3998.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: 46th Death In Hunger Strike
description: A 27-year-old Turkish woman has died, bringing the death toll to 46 in hunger strikes by leftists to protest prison conditions. The woman, Lale Colak, died at an Istanbul hospital; she was the third hunger striker to die this year. The strikers, who began their campaign more than a year ago, are protesting the shifting of prisoners from large wards to small cells for one to three inmates. The government has refused to negotiate with them, saying they are terrorists. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Fire Destroys Interior of New Jersey Church
description: An intense, smoky fire today ravaged the interior of a newly renovated church that served as both a house of worship and a busy communal center.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Sentencing In Deliveryman's Death
description: A second teenager accused in the killing of a Chinese-food deliveryman in 2000 was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens. The teenager, Darryl Tyson, 19, received a 16-year prison term after pleading guilty to first-degree robbery, the authorities said. Mr. Tyson was one of five teenagers who, prosecutors say, bludgeoned to death the deliveryman, Jin-Sheng Liu, 44, in Springfield Gardens in a bungled attempt to rob the man of food. Mr. Tyson is one of three teenagers who pleaded guilty to first-degree robbery; one was sentenced to 17 years in prison, while another is awaiting sentencing. Two others are awaiting trial. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: U.S. Ends Car Plan On Gas Efficiency; Looks to Fuel Cells
description: The Bush administration is walking away from a $1.5 billion eight-year government-subsidized project to develop high-mileage gasoline-fueled vehicles. Instead it is throwing its support behind a plan that the Energy Department and the auto industry have devised to develop hydrogen-based fuel cells to power the cars of the future, administration and industry officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLASS, FRANCES BEHAN
description: DOUGLASS-Frances Behan. On behalf of the entire downtown community, we extend our deepest sympathies to our esteemed leader and Chairman, Robert Douglass, on the death of his mother. We extend our condolences to the entire Douglass family. Carl Weisbrod, President Alliance for Downtown New York Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association

title: Jets' Special Teams Contributing
description: Chris Hayes, the captain of the Jets' special teams unit, was standing on the sideline, as he has done for most of the games in his career, and imploring Mike Westhoff, the special teams coach, to use it. ''Let's use it now, Coach,'' he said. ''Now's the time.''

title: Hall of Fame Welcomes Smith, but Carter Is Left on Doorstep
description: Ozzie Smith was so extraordinary that extraordinary, for him, became routine. Whether he was dashing into the hole, leaping to make a throw, diving for a grounder or charging a slow roller, Smith deftly did what other shortstops fantasized about doing: he made defense fashionable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEETSTEIN, LEONARD
description: BLEETSTEIN-Leonard. On January 7, 2002 after a long, valiant battle. Beloved husband of Rita. Loving father of Barbara Barrocas and Gary Bleetstein. Devoted father-in-law of Neil Barrocas and Marilee Bleetstein. Adoring and proud grandfather of Danielle, Rachel, Alix, Stacia and Michelle and great grandfather of Zoe, Carmine and Nicholas. Brother of Morton and the late Joel, and brother-in-law of Patricia and Jacqueline. This gentleman will be missed by all who knew him. Service Wednesday 12:30 PM at Temple Beth El, Great Neck, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Rebuilding, For the Price Of a Latte
description: A DESIGNER coffee shop near the Port Authority Bus Terminal charges $3 for caffe latte, and that's for the least expensive cup (the size designated ''tall,'' since the word ''small'' has been banished by American marketers). Some would say it is a fairly steep price for coffee with a spritz of steamed milk. But many commuters happily pay it each day, heading straight from the bus terminal to this shop on Eighth Avenue before charging off to work.

title: Young Women, Back in School, Race to Catch Up
description: Shafiqa Abdulwaquil stared at the division problem and thought, hard. She stared some more, her brow furrowed. Math once came easily to her, and this solution should have too.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: City Layoffs Expected
description: The mayor has announced that 50 to 100 city jobs will be eliminated to reduce an expected $15 million deficit by $5.5 million. The mayor, Dannel P. Malloy, said he would offer an early-retirement package to reduce the number of layoffs. To qualify, an employee must be at least 50, he said. The rest of the deficit will be closed by increasing fees and reducing budgets for city departments, he said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Intramural Discord on Display at a Museum in Dublin
description: The 10-year-old Irish Museum of Modern Art here has occasionally struggled in its short history. But these days, even seasoned members of Ireland's small art world blanch at the boardroom turmoil and infighting at the museum.

title: Bombing Necessary Despite Toll on Civilians, U.S. Envoy Says
description: Two days after he arrived in Afghanistan, the new United States special envoy today defended the continued bombing of this country, even though it was causing civilian casualties.

title: Political Memo; Bloomberg, Indebted to No One, Is Friendly With Few
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was sworn into office last week, the campaign contributors, union leaders, party bosses and lobbyists who typically have the best seats in the house were mostly absent. The scene outside City Hall was instead a demonstration of the extent to which Mr. Bloomberg, as the new mayor's aides like to point out, won office with fewer obligations than any mayor in memory.

title: The Boy Who Crashed in Tampa
description: To the Editor:

title: Team Owners Defend Selig
description: Major League Baseball owners marched strongly to the defense of Commissioner Bud Selig yesterday amid suggestions that he played a role in an improper 1995 loan that could create a conflict of interest in baseball's current plan to eliminate two teams.

title: Beer in Bottles and From Scratch
description: Bierkraft, a new shop at 191 Fifth Avenue (Union Street) in Park Slope, Brooklyn, is not just a place to choose from among more than 350 kinds of beer. It's a place to learn about them as well. The owners, Daphne and Richard Scholz, have a tasting room where experts give free classes. Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster of the Brooklyn Brewery in Williamsburg, gave one recently about holiday beers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Top Terror Prosecutor Named
description: David N. Kelley, who has been leading the Justice Department's task force in Washington investigating the Sept. 11 terror attacks, has been named deputy United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Kelley, who has been a federal prosecutor since 1988, succeeds Shirah Neiman, who becomes chief counsel to the United States attorney. The announcement was made yesterday by James B. Comey, sworn in as United States attorney on Monday. Mr. Kelley, 42, was co-chief of the Organized Crime and Terrorism Unit and was the lead prosecutor in the 1997 trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, convicted in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: New NASA Administrator Says Money Troubles Are Solvable
description: NASA's new leader, Sean O'Keefe, said today that the agency's financial and management problems could be solved and that he was open to any new ideas for getting the most out of the space program.

title: Market Place; New rules help AOL Time Warner, but put it to a test.
description: IT sounded like good news for AOL Time Warner, as well as its investors. On Monday the company announced a big charge against its first-quarter earnings to cover the declining values of some assets since the merger of AOL and Time Warner was completed. And the company noted that new accounting rules would free it from having to take similar charges in the future.

title: Met's 'Tosca' Puts a Few More Miles on the Odometer
description: The Metropolitan Opera revived ''Tosca'' on Friday night; but this production could have used a little more reviving. On one hand, it got the story told, and its three principal singers could all more or less get the job done. On the other hand, the whole thing felt routine. No one involved was quite able to lift the performance out of the well-worn groove established in the course of the many journeys of this 1985 Franco Zeffirelli production.

title: Sojo Ends Retirement For Chance With Yankees
description: Luis Sojo talked plaintively during the World Series about reaching the end of his career and about how much he enjoyed his time in the major leagues. Sojo mused about the possibility of returning as a coach or manager, after spending a couple of years in Venezuela.

title: Twins Should Outlast Bud Selig
description: ALL along, it smelled like a conflict of interest. And for a very good reason. It is a conflict of interest.

title: Hughes's Public Profile Rises With Her Performances
description: On the same cybershelves as the unauthorized biographies about the secret lives of celebrities, there is a tell-all page-turner about Sarah Hughes available in hardback online.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Taubman To Seek New Trial
description: The former chairman of Sotheby's, A. Alfred Taubman, who was convicted last month of price fixing, is seeking a new trial. Mr. Taubman's lawyers say that the judge erred in his instructions to the jury. In court papers filed yesterday, the lawyers contend that Judge George B. Daniels of Federal District Court in Manhattan should have advised the jury that there was nothing inherently illegal in 12 private meetings between Mr. Taubman and his Christie's counterpart, Sir Anthony Tennant. Mr. Taubman, who was convicted of conspiring with Christie's to fix prices charged to auction house sellers, faces up to three years in prison and a fine at his sentencing, set for April 2. Ralph Blumenthal (NYT)

title: The Egg Master of Sydney
description: THEY'VE been described as the best scrambled eggs in the world -- by The Times of London, no less -- but I make no such grandiose claim for the soft, luscious yellow clouds Bill Granger slides in front of you.

title: A Marvel Of Science, Hawking Turns 60
description: There is no crying in physics, where even the best of friends can call each other's work rubbish, and the most beloved theories are coolly thrown out when experiments contradict them.

title: A Lab in South Dakota
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELL, HANNAH B.
description: PELL-Hannah B. On January 7, 2002, loving mother of Merri and Debbie, devoted grandmother of Alexander, Caroline, Kate, Samantha, & Jonathan. Funeral service Wednesday, 1 P.M. at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Towers' Insurers Argue Payment to Leaseholder
description: The insurance companies that stand to lose the most from the disaster at the World Trade Center are forming a united front in their legal battle over whether the World Trade Center's leaseholder is entitled to payment for one attack or two, one of the biggest insurers said yesterday.

title: The Boy Who Crashed in Tampa
description: To the Editor:

title: In Crown Hts., a Case That Won't Go Away
description: It is axiomatic in criminal law that it is tougher to prosecute a case the second time around. Memories fade, witnesses die and the defense will be better prepared, having seen and heard all the evidence.

title: Carrying Heft With Grace
description: MORE good zinfandels are being made than ever, and the choices are many. Huge, concentrated wines are the order of the day, with most hovering around 15 percent alcohol and some even approaching 17 percent, previously the territory of fortified wines like port. The challenge for these monsters is to balance their power with grace.

title: Cooking in Tuscany
description: Pay in full by Jan. 31 and Tuscan Way will take 25 percent off the price of one of its four- and seven-day cooking tours of Tuscany. The Villa Gaia trip, with lessons and lodging in a villa outside the town of Seggiano, is $893 a person for four days and $1,643 a person for a week if three or more people book and pay by Jan. 31; for less than three people, it is $952 a person for four days and $1,752 for a week if paid by Jan. 31. Rates include airport transfers, all meals and lessons and excursions. Book one of Tuscan Way's 98 villas and pay in full by Jan. 31, and the price will be discounted 10 percent. Information: (800) 766-2390 or .

title: Somalia Is No Hideout for bin Laden
description: As a child in the Somali Peninsula, I was brought up to believe that during Ramadan Satan is locked away in a place from where he can do no harm. I'm revisiting this myth, with a view to revising it, given the recent horrors with which the world has become familiar. In the word Satan, derived from the pre-Islamic Arabic root Shatana, I now find a secular meaning: ''the one who spreads destruction'' or ''the one who opposes the will of the community.'' You can work out for yourself the Satan who will fit the world's present context, but he has been very much on the loose, visiting havoc on the world's innocent and choosing to reveal his wicked intentions in different guises, all of them unpalatable. No wonder everyone wants to know where Satan is headed next.

title: Internet Access for Schools
description: New York City has issued $31.4 million in federally subsidized bonds to provide Internet access in 190 public schools. The money will also help buy computer equipment for those schools and integrate technology into their curriculums. The schools that will get the funds have large numbers of poor students, but are not poor enough to qualify for aid from other government programs that help wire schools for the Internet. IBM Global Services has agreed to contribute $3.45 million to the effort, which was made possible by legislation written by Representative CHARLES B. RANGEL. Abby Goodnough

title: Gonzalez Says No to Mets, Yes to Texas
description: The Mets thought it would be easy. After Juan Gonzalez said he wanted to join them, the Mets figured they would make the best offer, Gonzalez would take it, and their supersized lineup would have even more meat. Last night, the Mets learned, the story was too good to be true.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: More Money From Abroad
description: Overseas Vietnamese sent $1.7 billion to their relatives in Vietnam through banks last year, according to official figures. The figures do not include transfers through unofficial channels, including money brought by some 200,000 Vietnamese who visit each year. Remittances through banks totaled $1.4 billion in 2000 and $1.1 billion in 1999. More than half the money comes from the United States, which is home to about a million overseas Vietnamese, of the total of 2.5 million. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Dave Thomas, 69, Wendy's Founder, Dies
description: Dave Thomas, an orphan who went to work in restaurants at 12 and by dint of hard work, quality control and shrewd marketing made Wendy's the third-largest hamburger chain in the world, died yesterday. He was 69 and was known to millions as the folksy character who made a low-key personal pitch for his own fast foods in more than 800 television commercials.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Public Records Law
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco signed a bill creating the Open Public Records Act as the last legislation of his tenure yesterday, ending two years of dispute. The new law requires the state government to keep a greater number and variety of official records and allow public access to them, unless specifically banned. The law also provides for penalties against local officials who fail to open records to the public. Critics said previous versions of the law infringed on privacy.

title: Judge Overrules Decision Allowing Logging of Burned Trees
description: A federal judge in Montana has blocked a Bush administration decision, issued last month, that would have allowed logging on more than 40,000 acres of the Bitterroot National Forest.

title: Baseball's Owners Come to Defense Of Selig on Loan
description: Major League Baseball owners marched strongly to the defense of Commissioner Bud Selig yesterday amid suggestions that he played a role in an improper 1995 loan that could create a conflict of interest in baseball's current plan to eliminate two teams.

title: This Time, Scarlet Knights Fall Short
description: In defeat, Rutgers might have learned a valuable lesson. It cannot keep digging huge holes for itself and then hope for the best.

title: Boy Describes Fatal Beating By His Father At an Ice Rink
description: As his father watched from the defendant's table, a 12-year-old boy described to a jury today how his father fought with another parent at a skating rink, punching him in the head as he held him on the ground.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Impath Buys Software Maker
description: Impath Inc. of New York agreed to buy the closely held Tamtron Corporation to expand its business helping pharmaceutical and genomics companies develop drugs. Impath, which provides doctors cancer testing and treatment information, said the purchase would add about 5 percent to its quarterly earnings. Tamtron's software helps with cancer diagnosis and treatment decisions.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Brewer To Miss Target
description: Japan's largest beer maker, the Kirin Brewery Company, is likely to miss its full-year profit target for 2001 because of sliding beer sales and higher marketing costs. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported that Kirin earned 21 billion yen ($159 million) in group net income last year, 36 percent less than it did the year before, and will miss its pretax profit target by 23 percent, numbers a company spokesman said ''sound right.'' Sales of Kirin's top brand, Lager, have declined for more than four years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Soviet Hotel In Moscow To Be Razed
description: A hulking glass, stone and concrete 1970 eyesore in the heart of Moscow, the Intourist Hotel, shut its doors for good today and awaits demolition, as the city prepares to remove a major Soviet-era wart from its skyline for the first time since the fall of Communism.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Moving West in SoHo

title: Rising Star in Newark Starts Mayoral Run Against Sharpe James
description: Cory Booker, an Ivy League-educated councilman who has become a favorite of the national news media during his four years in local politics, kicked off his campaign for mayor today, challenging the incumbent, Sharpe James, who has led the state's largest city for nearly 16 years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cruise Vote Still On
description: P&O Princess Cruises rejected a request by the Carnival Corporation that it postpone a shareholder vote scheduled for Feb. 14 on whether to accept a takeover bid from Royal Caribbean Cruises. Carnival has made a competing offer for P&O Princess Cruises and is requesting that the shareholder vote be delayed until November, after antitrust regulators in the United States can rule on the deals. Micky Arison, Carnival's chief executive, above, first made the request privately to Lord Sterling of Plaistow, P & O's chairman, and its chief executive, Peter Ratcliffe, in a letter Sunday. When Mr. Arison received no response, Carnival made the contents of the letter public. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Gatti and Millett Are Talking Tough
description: Arturo Gatti and Terronn Millett know how to brawl. They have a reputation for doing it in the ring, although so far not with each other. They do not flinch from punches and are not afraid to draw blood. (Or lose a little of their own.)

title: Getting Acquainted With Dad via Snippets of War
description: Tamar Rogoff never quite knew her beloved but distant father, Bernard Rogoff, a doctor who had been a medical officer in the Burma campaign during World War II. Seeking to understand her father better after his death 16 years ago, Ms. Rogoff explored the wartime life he chronicled in a diary and in passionate, funny letters he wrote to his wife. Alive in those letters, Rogoff remains otherwise largely elusive in ''Daughter of a Pacifist Soldier,'' a haunting, poignant theater and dance piece.

title: Thousands of Jobs Expected to Be Cut At G.M. and Ford
description: The two largest American automakers are expected to announce the elimination of at least 15,000 jobs this week.

title: Factory Orders and Consumer Borrowing Both Increase
description: Factory orders excluding military aircraft and other equipment rose in November for the second consecutive month, the first back-to-back increase in a year, the government reported today.

title: Pataki Confidant to Direct Rebuilding Effort
description: Louis R. Tomson, a former top adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki, has been selected to run the day-to-day operations of the state corporation in charge of rebuilding Lower Manhattan, government officials and downtown executives said yesterday.

title: Money for the Pentagon
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fisherman's Stew To Make at Home (Hold the Beach)
description: This month, Estiatorio Milos, the Greek seafood restaurant at 125 West 55th Street, is offering free samples of kakavia, a stew that fishermen traditionally make on the beach, to customers at the start of dinner or while they wait for tables. The chef and owner, Costas Spiliadis, is at the ladle at left. As an elaborate two-course main dish, kakavia is $120 for two (more than 10 pounds of whole fish go into it).

title: As the Governors Turn, Praise and Bipartisanship
description: Using his brief stint in the governor's office to praise his party's legacy, John O. Bennett, the State Senate president, was sworn in as acting governor this afternoon, and one hour later delivered a State of the State address proclaiming that a decade of Republican rule had left New Jersey a stronger and more prosperous place.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Search Engine Acquired
description: After months of financial and management turmoil, the Spanish- and Portuguese-language Internet company StarMedia Network sold one of its main Brazilian Internet properties, the search engine Cad, to Yahoo for an undisclosed sum. With the addition of Cad, Yahoo Brasil will become the third-largest Internet site in Brazil, Latin America's largest Internet market. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: A Fish With a Taste For Sherry
description: SHERRY, garlic and chickpeas, a decidedly Andalusian combination of flavors, can be served by itself, as a side dish, or with almost any cut of meat, fish or poultry. But I like it best with cod. The subtlety and tenderness of the fish are wonderfully offset by the almost meaty flavors of the scented chickpeas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, DR. MALCOLM A.
description: HYMAN-Dr. Malcolm A. On January 7, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia S. Hyman, dear father of Bruce and Frederic, father-in-law of Tina and Rosalie. Services Thursday, January 10, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Contract Dispute Keeps NBC Viewers Waiting for Naught
description: Entertainment deals are often made on the basis of a handshake, but NBC and its latest late-night star, Carson Daly, were mostly shaking fists at each other Monday night over an unsigned contract that resulted in a last-minute pre-emption of the premiere of Mr. Daly's show.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Anonymity Is Fleeting

title: ACCORD IS REACHED IN SCHOOL BIAS SUIT INVOLVING YONKERS
description: A tentative settlement was announced today in a federal desegregation lawsuit against the Yonkers public schools, a deal that could end more than two decades of bitter litigation and federal intervention in the state's fourth-largest school district.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Charity Scandal
description: The head of the state branch of Easter Seals, a charity for the disabled, was fired after being accused of stealing about $230,000 from the organization, a spokeswoman for the charity said. The president and chief executive, Martha Wittkowski, 44, was suspended without pay in November after charity officials learned of the missing money. She was fired after an audit by a private accounting firm determined that the missing money was taken from a $2.9 million fund intended to rehabilitate a camp. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: The Boy Who Crashed in Tampa
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Cope Quite Well In Martin's Absence
description: Never mind that one important player was sitting at home tonight. The Nets have strength in numbers this season, eliminating their reliance on any one name and his game.

title: Plane With 7 Marines Aboard Crashes on Way to Pakistan Base
description: AMarine Corps refueling plane with at least seven marines aboard crashed into a mountainside today on a landing approach to Shamsi, in southwest Pakistan.

title: Sam Mendes Plans to Leave His Theater Post
description: After nearly a decade leading the Donmar Warehouse, the small London playhouse that helped make him a major cultural figure in Britain and abroad, Sam Mendes is preparing his goodbyes.

title: A Tart and Sweet Twist At the Start of the Day
description: Blood-orange juice, deliciously tart and sweet with a berrylike aftertaste, can add a little Sicilian sunshine to the gloomiest of winter mornings. It is also excellent splashed on a fruit salad or used as a cocktail mixer. The imported juice, made from concentrate, is now available in liter containers for $5.99 at Citarella stores. And if the price seems a bit high, just try squeezing enough fresh blood oranges to get that much juice.

title: In the White House, a Sense Of What History Can Teach
description: From his second-floor suite in the White House, Karl Rove, one of President Bush's most powerful advisers, not only plots the weeks ahead for the president but also ponders the past.

title: U.S. Says It Accepts Statement From Captain on Seized Arms
description: The Bush administration edged closer today to embracing Israel's contention that a shipload of weapons it seized was bound for Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority, saying that it accepted a statement by the ship's captain that he was operating under orders from a weapons agent connected to Mr. Arafat.

title: Treasury to Shorten Time It Takes to Make Securities Deals
description: The Treasury said yesterday that it wanted to shorten the time it takes to process the auctions of its securities to two minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASER, DAVID
description: GLASER-David. The Board of Trustees, Administration, Associate Board and League of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care & Rehabilitation deeply mourn the passing of our beloved former President and CEO, David Glaser. We will remain forever grateful for his visionary leadership from 1980 to 1999 and his pioneering efforts on behalf of the elderly. His name will be a part of our history just as his deeds will inspire us to perpetuate the Institute's mission that he held so dear. He left an extraordinary legacy for which he will always be remembered. Our heartfelt sympathies to his dear wife, Davie, his children, Lewis, Marci and Seth, and his grandchildren. Barbara N. Kurshan, Chair of the Board Barry T. Zeman, President Jonathan H. Freiberger, Steven Olken, Co-Chairs, Associate Board Florence Spencer, Suzanne Sussman, Lillian Wilner, Co-Presidents, Parker League

title: Sept. 11 Terror Suspect Backs Effort to Televise His Trial
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 9  A lawyer for Zacarias Moussaoui, the first person charged with complicity in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, said at a hearing in federal court today that Mr. Moussaoui supported a legal effort by a cable television network to broadcast his trial.

title: Terms Are Up, But They Land On Their Feet
description: The city's term limit laws managed to push four borough presidents and dozens of City Council members out of office. But in the week since their terms expired, many of the former borough presidents and council members have managed to avoid unemployment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ARTHUR
description: LEVINE-Arthur. The United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism mourns the passing of Arthur Levine, International President of the United Synagogue from 1973-77. A respected leader of the Conservative Movement, he worked tirelessly to build solid relationships and guide the organization through a period of growth and transition. An ardent Zionist, he devoted many years to the well being of the State of Israel. A kind and compassionate man, he will long be remembered as a respected teacher and community activist. We extend our condolences to his wife Rosalind and his children Nancy, Susan, and Katzel, and to his sister Marilyn Goshchberg. Stephen S. Wolnek, Int'l Pres Rabbi Jerome M. Epstein, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALETZ, SR. JUDGE HERBERT N.
description: MALETZ-Sr. Judge Herbert N. The Chief Judge, the Colleagues and the Staff of the U.S. Court of International Trade express their deepest sorrow at the passing of a distinguished member of the Court, the esteemed and beloved Herbert N. Maletz, and extend their heartfelt condolences to the bereaved members of his family.

title: In Some Important Ways, The Day Only Starts at 3
description: THE art of Jacob Lawrence, the magnificent African-American painter who wove color, shape, history and sociology into emotionally powerful images, is on display at the Whitney Museum.

title: The Neediest Cases; Bereft by Fire and Grandmother's Death
description: Tristan Christy was awakened one morning last March by neighbors banging on his door to warn of a fire in the apartment above him. They were telling everyone in the building to get out.

title: Zinfandel Muscles In on the Big Boys
description: AT the top of the wine world, where spitting is an art form, zinfandel has been alternately tolerated and scorned. While people reserved their veneration and flowery expressions of respect for Bordeaux, Burgundy and their California counterparts, zinfandel has been the runt of the litter, thought to be capable of a few nice tricks but ultimately unworthy of respect.

title: Gators Turn to Familiar Face
description: Florida has a new coach, and he's a familiar face.

title: I.N.S. to Focus On Muslims Who Evade Deportation
description: Justice Department officials said today that a new effort to find and deport people who have fled to avoid previous deportation orders would begin with tracking several thousand men from Muslim and Middle Eastern countries that have Al Qaeda presences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIGWARD, ANGELA M.
description: SIGWARD-Angela M. Jan. 7, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Roderick Sigward. Devoted mother of Eric and the late Ellen. Loving sister of Geraldine Casey and the late Joseph Cosumano. Graduate of Hunter College and Columbia University School of Social Work. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Monday, January 14, 2-5 and 7-9 PM with service at 8PM on Monday. Interment Wednesday, January 16, Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: Rates Remain High. Blame Bush Budget Or Big Expectations?
description: Do budget deficits matter to the economy?

title: Joint Bachelor's-Law Degree
description: Seton Hall University School of Law and the New Jersey Institute of Technology have created a joint program that allows students to complete a bachelor's degree and law degree in six years. The program is aimed at students who want to work in areas where law and science intersect, including intellectual property, health, drug and telecommunications law, said PATRICK HOBBS, dean of the law school at Seton Hall.

title: Recipe: Braised Duck Legs With Pinot Noir Sauce
description: Adapted from "BayWolf Restaurant Cookbook" by Michael Wild and Lauren Lyle (Ten Speed Press, 2001)

title: Total of City's Public Schools On Failing List Drops by 7
description: A record number of New York City schools were removed this week from the state's dreaded list of failing schools, even though the requirements for getting off the list have become more stringent.

title: FLOWER SHARES FALL AFTER BIG HOLDING ENTERS MARKET
description: 1-800-Flowers.com said yesterday that a venture-capital firm had distributed about five million shares to its partners, setting off a 16 percent decline in its stock price. Shares of 1-800-Flowers.com fell $2.76, to $14.62, on the Nasdaq. The venture-capital firm, Benchmark Capital, distributed all the 1-800-Flowers.com shares it owned, 1-800-Flowers said. Benchmark, based in California, acquired the stock in May 1999 in a private purchase. 1-800-Flowers.com, of Westbury, N.Y., first sold shares to the public in August 1999 at $21 each. When Benchmark distributes shares to its partners, ''it puts more shares into the market,'' a 1-800-Flowers.com spokesman, Ken Young, said. ''It's great for liquidity. We'll have about 19 million shares in the market.''

title: PAPER AND BOX MAKER DROPS TENDER OFFER FOR RIVAL
description: Temple-Inland, a paper and box maker, dropped its $841 million tender offer for a rival, the Gaylord Container Corporation, after the bid failed to attract the minimum amount of shares and notes. The takeover bid drew criticism from some of Gaylord's bondholders, who said the offer was inadequate. Temple-Inland, based in Austin, Tex., offered 87.5 cents on the dollar for the bonds and $1.25 a share. As of yesterday's deadline, only 84 percent of Gaylord's 47.2 million shares were tendered. Temple-Inland will return all Gaylord shares and notes to their holders. Gaylord is based in Deerfield, Ill.

title: Sports of The Times; Twins Should Outlast Bud Selig
description: ALL along, it smelled like a conflict of interest. And for a very good reason. It is a conflict of interest.

title: FIRST BOSTON HIRES ANOTHER MORGAN STANLEY EXECUTIVE
description: Credit Suisse First Boston has named Eileen Murray of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company to be head of global technology and operations, in the second major hiring from his old firm made by John Mack, the chief executive. Ms. Murray spent 18 years at Morgan Stanley, most recently as chief administrative officer for the institutional securities group. At Credit Suisse First Boston, she will be a managing director.

title: Mavericks' Owner Is Fined $500,000
description: Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks, who has achieved a dubious sort of fame for his tirades against referees, was fined $500,000 yesterday by the National Basketball Association for criticizing game officials. The fine is the largest levied against an individual in the league's history.

title: Eminently Presentable Paper Place Mats
description: Not all tables have to be set with linen to be stylish. And not all paper tableware is for the elementary-school set. These sophisticated Japanese paper place mats, by Giorgio Armani, are made from mulberry bark. They are 19 by 13 inches and come in six patterns, including a black-and-white grid and white-on-white stripes, left. The patterns, made with natural pigments, are either batik or embossed. A package of four mats costs $10 to $20, depending on the pattern. And although the mats are paper and basically disposable, they are quite thick, so if your guests are neat, they can be reused a few times. If you prefer to keep them longer, take them to Kinko's and have them laminated in plastic. The place mats are available at Armani Casa, 97 Greene Street (Spring Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Stars Burst on Scene Ensemble, Astronomer Suggests
description: In the most distant observations yet by the Hubble Space Telescope, some astronomers think they are seeing evidence that the universe emerged from its initial darkness in a Kiplingesque dawn of light.

title: Pakistan Says It Has Not Cut Troops on the Afghan Border
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 9  Despite a tense confrontation with India, Pakistan has not reduced the number of troops searching for Taliban and Al Qaeda leaders along the border with Afghanistan, Pakistani military officers said today.

title: Conservative Choices but With Bold Accents
description: Both Lorin Maazel, the New York Philharmonic's new music director, and Zarin Mehta, its executive director, knew from the start that they had to make a strong case for themselves in the first season they programmed together, so it should not be surprising that the 2002-3 season, which they announced yesterday, so deftly balances the traditional and the novel.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Prison Term For Racketeering
description: Steve Kaplan, who ran an Atlanta strip club that the federal government tried to link to organized crime, was sentenced to 16 months in prison after pleading guilty last year to a single charge of racketeering. The Gold Club trial ended in plea agreements last August after embarrassing several professional athletes who admitted that they had sex inside. Judge Willis Hunt of Federal District Court said prosecutors had been ''relatively unsuccessful'' in tying Mr. Kaplan to organized crime. The government had recommended that he serve three years in prison. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Dec. 15 about Detective Claude Richards, a World Trade Center victim who was intelligence coordinator of the New York Police Department's bomb squad, misidentified the neighborhood where he lived. It was Greenwich Village, not Chelsea.

title: Igor Cassini, Hearst Columnist, Dies at 86
description: Igor Cassini, who as Cholly Knickerbocker was king of society gossip for the Hearst newspaper chain in the 1940's and 50's, then lost his job after he pleaded no contest to a charge that he represented the Dominican dictator Rafael Trujillo but without telling the government about it, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: What Makes a Jury Fair?
description: Jury selection in the United States has grown curiouser and curiouser, as a sensible federal appeals court decision this week makes painfully clear. The court overturned the 1997 convictions of two African-American men on civil rights violations in the killing of a Hasidic Jew during the violence that shook Crown Heights in 1991. Whatever one thinks of the defendants' guilt, they were convicted by a jury whose membership was apparently manipulated by the trial judge to achieve what he considered a proper racial and religious balance.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Struggling Islanders Can't Stop Calgary
description: The Calgary Flames charged at the Islanders tonight like a high school football team crashing through one painted butcher-paper banner after another. A man was repeatedly heard hollering, ''Get back!'' at the stunned Islanders. It was their coach, Peter Laviolette.

title: A Dispute and an Agreement That Were About Money
description: It seemed such an easy way to settle things after all these years -- simply agreeing to disagree on whether the Yonkers school system was still suffering from the effect of segregation. The two sides had been disagreeing so heartily for two decades, why the sudden spirit of compromise? In short, it was money that made the difference.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages on Dec. 20 about Lee Greenwood and his song ''God Bless the U.S.A.,'' which has become an anthem since Sept. 11, misstated a title held by his wife, Kim Greenwood. She is a former Miss Tennessee USA, not a former Miss Tennessee.

title: Internet Access for Schools
description: New York City has issued $31.4 million in federally subsidized bonds to provide Internet access in 190 public schools. The money will also help buy computer equipment for those schools and integrate technology into their curriculums. The schools that will get the funds have large numbers of poor students, but are not poor enough to qualify for aid from other government programs that help wire schools for the Internet. IBM Global Services has agreed to contribute $3.45 million to the effort, which was made possible by legislation written by Representative CHARLES B. RANGEL.

title: Philharmonic Moves Into a New Era
description: With its chairman describing it as ''an institution in transition,'' the New York Philharmonic yesterday announced a host of user-friendly changes for next season including a 7:30 p.m. curtain time, music lectures before performances three times a week and twice-weekly preconcert chamber music programs. The Philharmonic season, scheduled to start on Sept. 18, will be the first under its new director, Lorin Maazel. Mr. Maazel will conduct 11 of the orchestra's 34 subscription weeks.

title: Drug Maker Issues Earnings Warning
description: The Andrx Corporation said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit was ''significantly lower'' than the 35 cents a share it earned in the third quarter as sales of some products fell while its generic versions of blockbuster drugs were delayed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODBELL, SHELDON
description: RODBELL-Sheldon, of Palm Beach, Fl passed away on January 7, after an extended illness. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Gerry and Ellen, fatherin-law of Hank Alpert and Dr. Alain Roizen, cherished grandfather of David, Brooke, Erica, and Remy. Survived by his brother Arthur. Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, on January 10, 2002 at 11:30 am. In lieu of flowers please make donations to The Alzheimers Association of Palm Beach 561-820-8166.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 1 about the history of the Peronist movement in Argentina referred incorrectly to the marriage of Isabel Pern to Gen. Juan Pern, whom she succeeded as president after his death in 1974. She was his third wife, not his second.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUMAN, WILLIAM H.
description: YOUMAN-William H. On January 7th, 2002. Beloved husband of Mercedes A. Father of Kimberly Jaquay Wilson. Stepfather of Tunisha Mitchell and Monique A. Ryan. Brother of Donald Sparks and Linda Hemphill. Grandfather of Quintae Youman and Aaron Terrell Wilson. Memorial service Saturday, January 12, 5PM, Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St.

title: Senators Plan Hearings on Bid to Ease a Pollution Control Rule
description: Two Senate committees announced today that they would hold joint hearings next month on the Bush administration's plans to rewrite regulations that require all industries, including utilities, to upgrade their pollution control equipment when they upgrade their operations.

title: Long After the Shark Died, the Rumor Lived
description: Click.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury to Step Down This Fall
description: The archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. George Carey, leader of 73 million Anglicans in 160 nations, announced today that he would step down this fall, three years before he was due to retire.

title: Text: Pataki's State of the State Speech
description: Following is the full text of the State of the State speech by Gov. George E. Pataki in Albany, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEJANI, AMIR H., M.D.
description: TEJANI-Amir H., M.D. Of Ossining, NY, on Jan. 7, 2002. Beloved companion & husband of Nergesh Tejani, M.D., loving and adored father of Rushna Heneghan, Cena Tejani, and Sharyn Tejani, and devoted playmate & Bapa of Ellis, Cody, and Sierra Heneghan, Tehmina Pechefsky, and Kiran Devine. Big, big brother of Ba, Fee, Moe, Gulshen, Mary, Laila, Sultan, and Shamim. As an accomplished pediatric nephrologist, he was a caregiver to countless children and initiator & organizer of the largest research base to benefit children with renal disease. Our hearts are breaking, but you have taught us the river will still flow after you are gone. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, PA 19102. Memorial service to be held at The Purchase Friends Meeting House, Purchase Street (Route 120), Purchase, New York at 11 A.M. on Thursday, January 10th.

title: Campus Evangelists Seek Out Foreign Students
description: Haifeng Tang, a doctoral student in chemistry from China, was not religious when he came to Yale more than three years ago. But within a year, he was baptized in a Protestant church and has not missed a Sunday service since.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMMER, SOL G.
description: SUMMER-Sol G. A man who made this world a much nicer place to live in. He enriched our lives with his friendship. His smile was warm sunshine; his heart, pure gold. Our sympathies go out to his beloved Anita and his family. He leaves such a void in all our lives. May he rest in peace. Barbara and Bentley

title: Big Banks Seeking Enron's Energy-Trading Business
description: Several financial institutions and companies, including Citibank, UBS and BP, have indicated a serious interest in buying the energy-trading business of the bankrupt Enron Corporation, according to people involved in setting up an auction of the business. Each company was required to put up a $25 million deposit to bid for all or part of the operation, according to court documents.

title: The Ravaged Minds From a Generation of War
description: Check-in today for Patient No. 17 went like this: The patient, Khosal Khan, a 25-year-old vegetable vendor whose right leg had been severed at the knee in an American airstrike, was separated from his crutches and chained to a mulberry tree. His mother and two brothers, one of whom was bleeding from the marks where Mr. Khan had just bitten him, were allowed a quick goodbye.

title: Pentagon Study Urges Arms Shift, From Nuclear to High-Tech
description: A classified Pentagon review of nuclear policy calls for sharply reducing United States dependence on nuclear weapons by expanding the use of conventional, precision arms and building a missile defense system, according to officials familiar with the document.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Suit Over Contamination
description: Residents of the Coeur d'Alene Basin are seeking compensation from mining companies for the health costs of living in the Silver Valley, where a century of mining has contaminated the air and water. The class-action complaint, filed in State District Court on Monday, calls for the companies to pay for medical monitoring of up to 100,000 past and present residents. Late last year, the Environmental Protection Agency announced a $359 million cleanup of the toxic metals in the basin. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Justices Narrow Breadth of Law On Disabilities
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that to qualify as disabled, and therefore to be protected by the Americans With Disabilities Act, a person must have substantial limitations on abilities that are ''central to daily life,'' and not only to life in the workplace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, DONALD W.
description: JOHNSTON-Donald W. On Monday, January 7, 2002 of Maplewood, NJ. Beloved husband of Diane DeCillis Johnston. Devoted father of Adam and Evan Johnston. Son of Donald and the late Betty Mauck Gorman. Brother of Suzanne Clark. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral service at Marble Collegiate Church, One W. 29th Street, NY, NY on Thursday, January 10th at 11:00 AM. Interment at the convenience of the family. Visitation will be held at The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey on Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I thought it could run for like five years.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLYNN, ROBERT B.
description: GLYNN-Robert B. The members of Becker, Glynn, Melamed & Muffly LLP mourn the passing of Robert B. Glynn, one of the firm's founding partners. His wit, friendship, counsel, generosity of spirit and personal loyalty will always be remembered. Words cannot express how much we will all miss him.

title: For Little Musical That Could, a 42-Year Run
description: Before there was a Unisphere in Flushing Meadow Park or a bridge dedicated to an explorer named Verrazano, before the Beatles cut their first single or the Soviets spirited missiles into Cuba, a small band of actors filed nightly into a tiny theater in Greenwich Village to perform a romantic little musical about a boy, a girl and the travails of young love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COZINE, DR. KATHRYN
description: COZINE-Dr. Kathryn. The Faculty Practice Organization of the College of Physicians and Surgeons extends its sympathies to the family of Dr. Cozine. Dr. Cozine was a senior anesthesiologist at Columbia Presbyterian. We mourn the loss of this dedicated and caring clinician. Joseph Tenenbaum, M.D., Chair, Faculty Practice Organization, Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, SANDRA J.
description: RAYMOND-Sandra J. On December 15, 2001 at her home in Mill Valley, CA. Wife of Nicholas; mother of Sydney A. and Allen B.; grandmother of Andrew, Trevor and Samuel. A memorial service will be at 2:00 P.M., on Sunday, January 20, 2002 at the Church of Our Saviour, 10 Old Mill Valley. Donations in her memory may be made to the John T. Underwood Foundation, C/O The U.S. Trust Co., 114 West 47th Street, New York, New York 10036-1510, or a charity of choice.

title: Hall of Fame Admits Smith; Carter Left Out
description: Ozzie Smith was so extraordinary that extraordinary, for him, became routine. Whether he was dashing into the hole, leaping to make a throw, diving for a grounder or charging a slow roller, Smith deftly did what other shortstops fantasized about doing: he made defense fashionable.

title: Insurer to Pay More to Victim Families Fund
description: Marsh & McLennan Companies, the insurance brokerage firm that lost 295 employees on Sept. 11, has agreed to contribute millions of dollars more to its own charity to provide extended health benefits to the families of its dead employees.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Teacher Pay Plan
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee unveiled a plan that would link teacher pay to student test scores and raise curriculum requirements for both high school graduation and college admissions. Mr. Huckabee neither estimated the cost of the improvements nor suggested a method for financing them. Last year, a state judge declared Arkansas's public education system inadequate and its system of distributing state aid to local school districts unfair and ordered unspecified improvements. The state is appealing the ruling.

title: Recipe: Slow-Cooked Duck Legs
description: Time: 3 hours plus 24 hours' curing 1 teaspoon ground allspice

title: Keep the Fireworks Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted last Wednesday for a recipe with an article about crepes. The recipe, for lemon-ginger crepes, was adapted from Susan Spicer at Bayona restaurant in New Orleans.

title: Plane With 7 Marines Aboard Crashes on Way to Pakistan Base
description: AMarine Corps refueling plane with at least seven marines aboard crashed into a mountainside today on a landing approach to Shamsi, in southwest Pakistan.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Imax Repurchases Debt
description: The Imax Corporation, the struggling maker of big-screen film-projection systems, repurchased $42 million of debt, signaling a turnaround and setting off a 49 percent increase in its share price. Shares of Imax, based in Mississauga, Ontario, rose 1.98 Canadian dollars ($1.24), or 49 percent, to 5.99 Canadian dollars on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Decode Genetics To Buy Medichem
description: Decode Genetics, a gene information company in Reykjavik, Iceland, said it had agreed to acquire Medi Chem Life Sciences for nearly $84 million in stock. The deal values MediChem at $3.04 a share. Shares of MediChem, based in Woodridge, Ill., rose 45 cents, to $2.80. Decode shares fell 56 cents, to $9.24. Decode said combining its target discovery program with MediChem's small-molecule development abilities would aid in discovery of novel drugs.

title: Administration Considers Ways to Cut Terror Risk From Small Planes
description: In response to last weekend's suicide crash by a teenage pilot into a Florida skyscraper, the Office of Homeland Security has been discussing more urgently ways to reduce the terrorism risk from small planes. But officials are still groping for a way to control the sprawling general aviation system.

title: Echoes of Sept. 11: How We Changed
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Forums
description: From "Survivor" to the French fries at Balthazar, here are the week's highlights.

title: After Founder Dies, Wendy's Ponders New Ways to Pitch
description: The death yesterday of R. David Thomas, the founder of the fast-food chain Wendy's International, ends a second career he reluctantly began 13 years ago as the public face of his company, in what became the longest-running and perhaps most successful campaign of its kind. Now, Wendy's and its longtime agency, Bates USA in New York, face considerable challenges in determining what to do.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RAYBURN, WILLIAM BISHOP
description: RAYBURN-William Bishop. 1/9/87. A literary light in heaven, so missed and loved on earth. JFR Mc

title: Terrorism's Other Battlefields
description: From the first days of America's new war against international terrorism, President Bush has made clear that the use of United States military force would not necessarily end with the defeat of the Taliban regime in Afghanistan or the killing or capture of Osama bin Laden. He rightly warned governments around the world that offering sanctuary to international terrorists could expose their countries to American military attack. With Osama bin Laden and other top leaders of Al Qaeda now on the run from Afghanistan, Mr. Bush needs to initiate a discussion with Congress and the American people about whether the war should be extended to other lands.

title: U.S. Forces Pursue Al Qaeda Leaders in Treacherous Terrain
description: American forces continued their sweep through a perilous swath of eastern Afghanistan today after two ranking Al Qaeda fighters were captured on Monday and laptop computers and cellphones discovered in recent weeks yielded information that could help thwart future terrorist attacks, military officials said.

title: Ravaged Psyches in a Generation of Fighting
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan, Jan. 8  Check-in today for Patient No. 17 went like this: The patient, Khosal Khan, a 25-year-old vegetable vendor whose right leg had been severed at the knee in an American airstrike, was separated from his crutches and chained to a mulberry tree. His mother and two brothers, one of whom was bleeding from the marks where Mr. Khan had just bitten him, were allowed a quick goodbye.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELS, RUTH
description: MICHAELS-Ruth. Beloved wife of David. Devoted mother of Diane Michaels and Heidi Lamar. Dear sister of James Eisenberg. Loving grandmother of Sara, Casey and Jordan. Services Bernheim-ApterKreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ, Thursday 10:30 AM. Donations to the Parkinson Disease Foundation, c/o Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, NY, New York, would be appreciated.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: A Fisherman's Stew to Make at Home (Hold the Beach)
description: This month, Estiatorio Milos, the Greek seafood restaurant at 125 West 55th Street, is offering free samples of kakavia, a stew that fishermen traditionally make on the beach, to customers at the start of dinner or while they wait for tables. As an elaborate two-course main dish, kakavia is $120 for two (more than 10 pounds of whole fish go into it).

title: Ticket Setup for Ground Zero Viewing Stand
description: To enable people to see the site where the World Trade Center once stood without having to stand in line for hours in the cold, the city will begin offering free tickets to the public viewing stand for 15-minute periods today.

title: He Knows Every Crack In the Parish Sidewalks; A Priest Recalls 60 Years in Parkchester
description: The Rev. Joseph J. O'Shea is a priest at St. Helena's Roman Catholic Church in the Parkchester neighborhood of the Bronx. He is 87 years old and has been a priest at the parish since 1942, a feat that has earned him the record for continuous service to a single Catholic church in the city and makes him the honorary Cal Ripken of the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Vatican to Hold Secret Trials of Priests in Pedophilia Cases
description: VATICAN CITY, Jan. 8 — The Vatican has issued new rules saying it will use secret ecclesiastical courts to try priests accused of sexually abusing children and will oversee the cases directly from Rome.

title: Rice Deal Is No-Win Situation
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 8  Each side praised the deal as if it would push it near the top of its conference. The Knicks were delighted to send Glen Rice, an aging star who was unhappy as a reserve, to the Houston Rockets for Shandon Anderson, a defensive stopper and capable slasher, and Howard Eisley, a point guard with a nice shot.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Carlyle Buys Security Unit
description: The debt-laden Daiei, Japan's largest retailer, will sell its security transport subsidiary to the Carlyle Group for 3.5 billion yen ($26.5 million). Carlyle will hold 90 percent of the company, which employs 1,850 workers and operates a fleet of trucks that move money among banks, stores and other companies. With 2.3 trillion yen ($1.7 billion) in debt, Daiei is scrambling to sell assets to raise cash before the end of its fiscal year, which closes in February. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Tuesday, 3,117 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBIN, MYRON
description: WERBIN-Myron. We are very saddened by the news that the father of our dear partner, Barry Werbin, has passed away. Our spirits are brightened, however, in the knowledge that he lived a long and fruitful life, enjoyed Barry's eternal love and devotion and that he leaves a loving daughter-in-law, Lisa, and two cherished and adoring grandhildren, Gregory and Kyra. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences. Herrick, Feinstein LLP

title: New Jersey Democrats Get Control, and Deficit
description: There is no extra money to spend and no appetite here for raising more, but today the Democrats of Trenton could at least savor their first day in power in 10 years.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Medical School To Get Millions
description: Two Wall Street financiers and their wives are giving $150 million to the Weill Medical College of Cornell University, the school announced yesterday. Sanford I. Weill, above right, chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, and his wife, Joan, are donating $100 million. Maurice R. Greenberg, above left, chairman and chief executive of American International Group Inc., and his wife, Corinne, are giving $50 million. The gifts to the school, which is affiliated with New York-Presbyterian Hospital, are major contributions to its five-year, $750 million fund-raising campaign. The campaign has already raised $332 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, the financial holding company, increased its quarterly dividend to 19 cents from 18 cents, payable on Jan. 31 to holders of record as of Jan. 18.

title: Tread the Boards, Watch the Rubble
Learning From Enron
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Ban Around the United Nations Is Lifted
description: New York City scaled back its extensive security around the United Nations on Monday, lifting a ban on car and truck traffic that had been in place since Sept. 11 along part of First Avenue.

description: WOLZ-Carl. Carl Wolz, A Founder of The Martha Hill Dance Fund will be sorely missed and fondly remembered. Irwin Denis

description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan May Be Unable to Calm Kashmir
description: Pakistan's president says he is taking steps to crack down on Islamic militants who use his country as a base to drive India from Kashmir. But it seems that word has yet to trickle down to this Himalayan border region, where the countries have fought on and off for 50 years.

title: White House Shifts on Welfare Law; Food Stamps for Legal Immigrants
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Bush administration proposed today to restore food stamps to legal immigrants, whose eligibility for benefits was severely restricted by the 1996 welfare law.

title: AD MARKETER SAYS PROFIT WILL MEET REDUCED FORECAST
description: The R. H. Donnelley Corporation, an advertising marketer, plans to cut 100 jobs and says 2001 profit was at the lower end of its reduced forecast. Profit for the year was $2.35 to $2.37 a share, excluding $30 million in pretax fourth-quarter costs, partly related to eliminating the 100 jobs, at its Raleigh, N.C., publishing plant, Donnelley said. In October, the company lowered its forecast for the year to $2.35 to $2.40 a share from $2.40. The company said it would report final results in mid-February. Donnelley's advertising sales have been hurt as companies have curtailed spending in a slowing economy. The company, based in Purchase, N.Y., named David Swanson its chief executive on Monday, He will start in May, succeeding Frank Noonan.

title: Recipe: Pasta With Anchovy Sauce
description: Adapted from "How to Eat" by Nigella Lawson (John Wiley & Sons, 2000)

title: Stocks End Lower as Technology Shares Lose Early Gains
description: Despite posting solid gains in early trading, stocks lost ground today, as investors cashed in on the market's recent run-up and pondered whether the market had advanced too far too fast.

title: On Radio Show, Torricelli Takes The Times to Task
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli said yesterday that The New York Times had deliberately misrepresented his relationship with a wealthy political contributor who was at the center of a federal investigation into his activities.

title: Instead of a Fancy Restaurant, Raw Wood
description: THE architect about town David Rockwell, designer of Nobu, the Monkey Bar and other culinary haunts favored by the slinky set, is just back from a private luncheon aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 honoring his celebrity-chef buddies who convened at ground zero to turn out comfort food for rescue workers in the grim days after Sept. 11.

title: Who's Home, Who's Not
description: Two world-renowned figures have been on the run, living in ''undisclosed locations'' since Sept. 11. There are occasional sightings of both, but then they vanish. One figure is named Osama bin Laden. The other is named Dick Cheney.

title: All Hard Edges, but With a Soft Center
description: THE first surprise at Moda comes at the start of the meal. A waiter drops by and puts a small plate on the table. It has a lot going on in a small area. There is an assortment of very good olives, a few pickled lupini beans and heaped chunks of Parmesan, one of the few cheeses that's equally good grated or whole. Among the tidbits is a small dish filled with good olive oil and another with an irresistible blend of butter and olive oil sprinkled with crunchy grains of salt. There's a lot to be said for keeping diners busy as they study the menu.

title: Topics of The Times; A Man of Fashion Departs
description: Gone are the days when the very look of Yves Saint Laurent the man -- the hair, the glasses -- seemed to embody the fortune-telling spirit of high fashion, when his designs both evoked the future and distilled the present. Great designers should merely attenuate as they grow older, dissolving at last into wisps of silk, but Mr. Saint Laurent has decided to retire in the flesh instead. After 44 years in haute couture, and 44 years in the Rousseau-like jungle of his own fame, he was probably wise to step down.

description: Commissioner Bud Selig will attend a negotiating session today and explain to the players' representatives why he feels the clubs need a hefty increase in revenue sharing and the luxury-tax rate on payrolls.

title: In Upheaval Within Bayer, Chief Resigns At Drug Unit
description: The head of Bayer's worldwide drug operations resigned today during a strategic upheaval intended to allow the company to reshape itself through joint ventures.
