title: Business Travel; Pants and profiling: Life on the front lines of checkpoint security at the nation's airports.
description: JOHN D. CORNELIUS, a flight attendant for Alaska Airlines, already has a nomination in mind for 2002 Person of the Year. The nominee is a male airline passenger, identity unknown, who recently made the ultimate gesture of futility while being rudely prodded and frisked at a security checkpoint at the Seattle airport.

title: Showing in Canada: The Mystery of the Falling Dollar
description: It's hard to say what they are, but Americans generally love them and Canadians hate them: the mysterious forces that have pushed the value of Canada's dollar relentlessly downward to new lows in recent weeks.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank To Sell Goldman Shares
description: Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, Japan's second-largest lender, will sell all its shares in the Goldman Sachs Group by tomorrow. The bank, which will complete the sale through a subsidiary in the United States, holds 8,670,527 common shares in Goldman Sachs. Goldman's shares closed yesterday at $92.50. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Vatican to Hold Secret Trials Of Priests in Pedophilia Cases
description: The Vatican has issued new rules saying it will use secret ecclesiastical courts to try priests accused of sexually abusing children and will oversee the cases directly from Rome.

title: Jets Discover There Is a There in Oakland
description: Coach Herman Edwards was so certain that his team would be facing Oakland this Saturday in the first round of the playoffs that he went to sleep in the middle of Monday night's game, which determined the Jets' opponent. He did not find out for sure that the Jets would play the Raiders for the second week in a row until the team's trainer told him when Edwards got to work at 5:45 a.m.

title: Alcoa Has Loss, Its First Since '94
description: Alcoa posted its first quarterly loss today since 1994 as revenue plunged 21 percent and expenses increased for closing plants and laying off workers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about allegations of borrowed passages in Stephen E. Ambrose's book ''The Wild Blue'' misstated a description of John Adams that figured in another recent embarrassment to a historian -- in this case, David McCullough. The phrase used in error by Mr. McCullough was ''colossus of independence,'' not ''colossus of liberty.'' (What Thomas Jefferson actually called Adams, at the Continental Congress, was a ''colossus on the floor.'')

title: Rollback on Clean Air
description: A proposal to weaken an important provision in the Clean Air Act is making its way to the White House for a final decision by President Bush. The recommendation, from the Energy Department and The Environmental Protection Agency, is variously described as ''tentative'' and ''informal'' -- in any case, not final. One can only hope so. It is a bad idea, one of several to emerge from Vice President Dick Cheney's task force on energy last spring. By rejecting it, the administration can spare itself the kind of embarrassment it suffered when it tried to roll back the Clinton administration's arsenic standard last year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Estonia: Prime Minister Quits
description: Prime Minister Mart Laar resigned, forcing Estonia's longest serving post-Soviet government to step down in a dispute within the three-party governing coalition over the pace of reforms. Mr. Laar predicted that he would be replaced by a new government led by Finance Minister Siim Kallas. The political confrontation could slow Estonia's preparations to enter NATO later this year and the European Union in 2004. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Prosecutor Willing to Deal In Child Drownings Case
description: Five months after the district attorney here made the controversial decision to pursue the death penalty against Andrea Yates, the mother charged with murder for drowning her five young children in a bathtub, a prosecutor suggested today that he would agree to a life sentence if Mrs. Yates pleaded guilty to the murders.

title: Aleksandr M. Prokhorov, 85; Russian Won Nobel for Lasers
description: Dr. Aleksandr M. Prokhorov, who shared a Nobel Prize in Physics for research that led to the development of lasers, died yesterday at his apartment in Moscow, Russian news agencies reported. He was 85.

title: U.S. IS BUILDING UP ITS MILITARY BASES IN AFGHAN REGION
description: Even as the air war in Afghanistan wanes and American-backed forces hunt down pockets of Al Qaeda and Taliban resistance there, the United States is preparing a military presence in Central Asia that could last for years, military officials say.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Six Face Terror Charges
description: Under heavily armed guard, six men who were arrested by the Irish police on Saturday night for suspected membership in a paramilitary group, the Real I.R.A., were charged with membership in an illegal organization at a special antiterrorist court in Dublin. The Real I.R.A., which claimed responsibility for a 1998 bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, that killed 29 people, is thought to be involved in criminal activities, including cigarette smuggling and drug dealing. A seventh man, also arrested Saturday in the border town of Dundalk, was released without charge. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Scythian Gold From Siberia Said to Predate the Greeks
description: Russian scholars from the State Hermitage Museum have concluded that a discovery of Scythian gold in a Siberian grave last summer is the earliest of its kind ever found and that it predates Greek influence. The find is leading to a change in how scholars view the supposed barbaric, nomadic tribes that once roamed the Eurasian steppes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chip Maker Sells Bonds
description: Four months after denying that it needed to raise cash, Infineon, the world's fourth-largest memory chip maker, successfully sold a billion euros ($890 million) of convertible bonds. It was the company's first debt sale and came after a 1.5 billion euro ($1.3 billion) equity offering in July. Infineon, based in Munich, posted a 591 million euro ($526 million) loss in fiscal 2001 after prices for DRAM chips fell sharply to less than a third of production costs. Siemens, the company's largest shareholder, also announced that it had sold 40 million Infineon shares worth 974 million euros ($867 million). Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: When Rachmaninoff Was Fascinated With the Funereal
description: It would undoubtedly be going too far to say that Rachmaninoff was obsessed with death. Certainly in that regard he couldn't hold a candle to Mahler. But Rachmaninoff was apparently fascinated by the Dies Irae, the ancient funereal plainchant that many composers have quoted, though none as frequently as he.

title: Selig Talks, Then Dismisses a Call to Resign
description: Bud Selig came to town as baseball commissioner yesterday, made a sales pitch to members of the players' negotiating committee and left as commissioner after rejecting a congressman's call for his resignation.

title: Court Rules Detention Law Unconstitutional
description: In the second such ruling in three weeks, a federal appeals court said yesterday that the 1996 law requiring mandatory detention without bail of certain immigrants who have committed crimes was unconstitutional.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Unicef Seeks Euro Windfall
description: Unicef hopes to cash in on the euro changeover by collecting soon-to-be-defunct foreign currency. Since 1987, when the children's fund began its ''Change for Good'' program, it has collected $31 million in unused coins and bills from travelers who have returned home with foreign currency. The agency is planning to expand its program and collaborate with supermarkets, schools and airlines to gather currencies that will soon be outmoded. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Software Maker Meets Target
description: SAP, a leading maker of business-management software, said it exceeded its latest sales forecast for 2001 and met a target for profit, setting off a 13 percent gain in its stock price. Sales rose more than 16 percent, beating SAP's 15 percent forecast, as revenue from software licenses surpassed analysts' estimates, a spokesman, Markus Berner, said. SAP lowered its forecast in October. SAP's operating profit as a percentage of sales was probably 20 percent, Mr. Berner said.

title: Optimistic Visions For Trade Center Site
description: ''A New World Trade Center: Design Proposals'' at the Max Protetch gallery features 50 ideas from architects and artists including Zaha Hadid, Daniel Libeskind, Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, and Steven Holl. Mr. Holl's ''Floating Memorial/Folded Street,'' inset top, offers a zigzagging ramp sheathed in glass that rises 1,200 feet but occupies relatively little space at street level, freeing up the area for observation decks. The ''footprints'' of the twin towers would become illuminated ponds. ''We left the exact spaces where the buildings were, for reflection,'' said Mr. Holl, who created the proposal with Makram El-Kadi and Ziad Jameleddine of his office. Another New York architect, Eytan Kaufman, did ''The World Forum and the World Bridge,'' a system of bridges, above, that flow to New Jersey. The young Dutch firm of Oosterhuis Associates came up with ''Ground Zero 2011,'' inset above, which proposes a programmable building that would change over a one-year cycle. Giuseppe Lignano, partner in the downtown architectural firm LOT-EK, suggested keeping the ''tub'' that the World Trade Center was built in empty, ''to add value to this depression in the middle of a very dense, urban spot.'' Max Protetch, the gallery's owner, said he wanted something optimistic. ''Museums can't move so quickly,'' he said. From next Thursday through Feb. 16 at 511 West 22nd Street; (212) 633-6999. AMY GOLDWASSER

The Nets need him on the court, not off it serving another suspension, and he needs to do some damage control, lest he be labeled another N.B.A. miscreant.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Testing Pay Service
description: Napster, hoping to evolve from record industry nemesis to a for-profit music exchange, plans to begin a test version of its new subscription service today. The service will be available to 20,000 Internet users, who will be able to download music from Napster and to exchange music with each other from their home computers. During the test, participants will not be charged. However, Napster ultimately plans to charge fees of $5 to $10 a month to allow users to acquire 50 songs, said Konrad Hilbers, Napster's chief executive. A crucial catch is that the major labels have yet to license their music to Napster for use on the service (the test version uses music from independent labels). But Mr. Hilbers, above, has said such licensing deals are imminent. Mr. Hilbers said that as part of the deals, the company would also settle a lawsuit brought by the labels, which have contended that Napster abetted in rampant copyright infringement. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Roosevelt Educators Point to Improving Test Scores
description: Even as state officials debate the survival of the beleaguered school system here, the district's administrators today asserted that rising test scores indicated that the district could succeed if given adequate resources.

title: A Late Show Starts Late, By One Day
description: If NBC and Carson Daly had planned some publicity stunt for his new later-than-late-night talk show, they couldn't have done a better job than the dispute that caused the network to pull the premiere and replace it with a repeat of ''SCTV'' because Mr. Daly had not signed his contract. (NBC wants to sell repeats to the E! channel, and Mr. Daly's camp does not.) The decision was made three minutes before the show, ''Last Call With Carson Daly,'' was scheduled to begin on Monday night (actually 1:35 Tuesday morning), right after ''Late Night With Conan O'Brien,'' which had plugged it.

description: The Israeli government decided today to halt construction of a mosque next to the main Christian shrine in Nazareth, a project that has drawn protests from the Vatican and Christian leaders here and abroad.

title: Turkish Court Ruling Hobbles a Popular Pro-Islamic Politician
description: In a blow that may prevent Turkey's leading pro-Islamic politician from becoming prime minister in the foreseeable future, the country's highest court placed tight restrictions today on the political activities of Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the former mayor of Istanbul.

title: Video, Music, Now Photos: For Mac Users, the i's Have It
description: First came iMovie, free Apple software that made video editing simple on Macintosh computers, and iDVD, which allowed Mac fans to burn those movies onto blank DVD's. Then came iTunes, a free Apple program for managing music collections and burning them onto CD's.

title: Abraham Is the Diamond in the Jets' Pass Rush
description: The turning point for John Abraham came after a game in which he had no sacks. The day after that game, in mid-December against Cincinnati, the defensive coordinator, Ted Cottrell, was struck by a question Abraham asked when he stopped by Cottrell's office.

title: Revisiting the Disabilities Act
description: It is often said that bad cases make bad law. Tuesday's Supreme Court ruling narrowing the scope of the Americans With Disabilities Act shows that a well-intentioned but imprecise law can generate valid court decisions that nevertheless frustrate the spirit of the statute. There is little to fault in the unanimous decision. The problem lies in the law's language. Congress can and should find a way to eliminate the confusion it inadvertently sowed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Stake In Drug Tester Sold
description: The Stephens Group, a family-owned investment company, said it would sell its stake in Huntingdon Life Sciences, a British drug-testing company that has been a target of animal-rights protesters. A year ago, Stephens lent Huntingdon $16 million and became its largest shareholder. At the time, animal rights protesters, who had attacked Huntingdon executives with car bombs and made death threats, vowed to take their campaign to Stephens. About 150 protesters gathered outside the firm's headquarters in Little Rock, Ark., in October. Last week, a town house in New York owned by Warren A. Stephens, the president and chief executive, was vandalized and a group called Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty claimed responsibility. The Stephens Group said it was selling its stake to an unidentified buyer, because Huntingdon had returned to profitability. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCUTCHEON, BILL W.
description: McCUTCHEON-Bill W., 77. A resident of Mahwah for 42 years, on January 9, 2002. Beloved husband of Anne (Routsong) McCutcheon. Loving father of Carol Crevani of Mahwah, NJ, Jay McCutcheon of Baltimore, MD., and Kenna McCutcheon Colley of Blacksburg, VA. Adored grandfather of 5 grandchildren. description: Seven high-ranking officials of the vanquished Taliban government, including the justice minister who played a leading role in the Taliban's repressive laws and the destruction of the Buddha statues at Bamian, surrendered to a provincial leader and were allowed to go free on Monday, a spokesman for Afghanistan's new government said today.

title: Transcript of Chris Conrad's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Wednesday, Dec. 19, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Chris Conrad. Mr. Conrad leads several drug reform organizations. This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: Executive Gets Post in Film Marketing
description: Alan Cohen, a longtime executive in network television advertising and promotion, has been named to the vacant post of president for domestic theatrical marketing at 20th Century Fox in Los Angeles, part of the News Corporation ( news/quote ).

title: The Governor as Confectioner
description: New York's governor, George Pataki, managed yesterday to seem upbeat about a state financial predicament that even he had to admit is a ''fiscal crisis.'' What would have most state leaders preaching gloom and preparing the public for sacrifice had Mr. Pataki remembering the heroes of Sept. 11, recalling the Battle of Saratoga and offering up suggestions for additional, albeit modest, spending programs.

title: End of the Road For HomeStyle, Despite Remake
description: Four issues after a redesign and editorial overhaul, Home Style magazine closed yesterday, the latest in a string of consumer magazines to shut.

title: FedEx Shipped a High Radiation Package Without Knowledge
description: FedEx unwittingly carried a package from Paris to New Orleans last week that was emitting so much radiation that the recipient, a company that packages radiation sources for industrial testing, has been unable to get near enough to measure it directly.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Pacific Shifts To El Nio Phase
description: For the first time since 1998, the Pacific is shifting into a warm phase, El Nio, that can alter weather patterns from Asia to the Americas, federal climatologists said. At its most intense, the change can spawn extreme weather in widespread areas. Powerful winter storms in California and droughts in Indonesia have been just two of its effects. El Nio also disrupts fisheries along the western coast of South America and tends to suppress hurricanes in the Atlantic, as well as increasing the average temperature of Earth. The climatologists said it was too early to know how severe or prolonged the cycle would be. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: MARTHA STEWART SELLS $45 MILLION OF HER STAKE
description: Martha Stewart sold a $45 million stake in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia to ValueAct Capital Partners, her biggest share sale since the company sold stock to the public in 1999. Ms. Stewart sold 9 percent of her stock at $15 a share ''for diversification and estate planning purposes,'' she said in a statement. The sale represents a 6 percent stake in the company, which is based on Ms. Stewart's advice to homemakers. Ms. Stewart sold three million shares of Class A common stock to ValueAct, the statement said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 3 about the Japanese success of the movie ''Sen to Chihiro,'' by the celebrated animator Hayao Miyazaki, misstated its relationship to the country's literacy rate. Japan has nearly complete literacy, not a low rate.

title: Sure Sign of a Warming Trend: An Immersion in Bulb Culture
description: Brent and Becky Heath, who grow bulbs in Virginia, have revised ''Tulips for North American Gardens'' and ''Daffodils for North American Gardens'' (Bright Sky Press, $22 each). The books are now in stores. Mr. Heath grew up on a daffodil farm, so talking about bulb culture may be in his genes. Gorgeous close-ups of hundreds of varieties, with suggestions for companion planting for pots and borders, as well as sources, may trigger a bad case of the ''if only's.'' So make note of where things do or don't bloom this spring and make your bulb order for next fall. You can visit the Heaths' trial gardens in Gloucester, Va., from mid-March to mid-April. (By reservation, www.brentandbeckysbulbs.com).

title: Dominant Offense and Tough Defense Spell Victory
description: This was a game the Devils were supposed to win. After all, despite a mediocre record in what has been a befuddling season, the Devils have not lost back-to-back games since November.

description: INTERNET

title: New Look for the Olympics: Warplanes and Troop Patrols
description: When the Olympic torch reaches Rice-Eccles Stadium at the University of Utah in a month, commercial air traffic at Salt Lake City International Airport will be at a standstill. Surveillance planes will be flying miles overhead as F-16 fighter jets remain on constant alert nearby. Thousands of military troops will patrol the streets.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Suit On Water Management
description: An environmental group from New Mexico has sued to challenge Arizona water laws, contending that the state has mismanaged water resources. In the suit, the group, the Center for Biological Diversity, says that although it is illegal in Arizona to pump water directly from a stream, it remains legal to pump ground water that may feed the stream and that this reduction in stream flow affected riparian habitats. If the suit succeeds, it could affect the use of water by rural areas, as well as by developers and miners.

title: Black Scholar Looks Beyond Mended Fence And Harvard
description: Although he is satisfied that fences have been mended with the president of Harvard, Cornel West, a prominent African-American professor, said today that he was still considering leaving Harvard and going to Princeton University, in part because the episode was so unsettling.

title: Settlement Near for Insurer Accused of Overcharging Blacks
description: The Life Insurance Company of Georgia is close to settling a lawsuit that accused it of routinely charging black customers higher premiums for life insurance than white customers, regulators and insurance company representatives involved in the discussions confirmed yesterday.

title: Ex-Labor Secretary Outlines Race to Lead Massachusetts
description: Bursting late into a crowded field, Robert B. Reich, the former secretary of labor, announced today that he would be a Democratic candidate for governor of Massachusetts.

title: SCHWAB PLANS TO EXPAND RETIREMENT PLAN BUSINESS
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said yesterday that it was creating a division to sell services like retirement plans to companies, as the company seeks to expand its presence in a market with $3.5 trillion in client assets. John Philip Coghlan, a Schwab vice chairman who oversees Schwab's business with companies and independent investment advisers, said the corporate services division would be led by Walt Bettinger. Mr. Bettinger, an executive vice president, was previously head of Schwab's retirement plans services division.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  THOMAS, GEORGE M.
description: THOMAS-George M. Always in our hearts. Your integrity, strength and love is dearly missed. Bernice Joan Philip Edward and Family

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the jazz pianist Ralph Sutton on Jan. 1 misstated the current name of Northeast Missouri State Teacher's College, which he was attending in 1941. It is Truman State University; it changed from Northeast Missouri State University in 1996.

title: Argentina's Woes May Strengthen Its Ties to Brazil
description: Argentina's decision to devalue the peso is suddenly bringing it closer to its giant neighbor, Brazil, repairing a tattered alliance that strengthens Brazil's bargaining power in trade negotiations with the United States.

title: Finnish Designer Is Saluted By a London Shop
description: Timo Sarpaneva, the Finnish designer, far right, whose work spans 50 years and many disciplines (textiles, ceramics, glass, graphic design, porcelain and stainless steel, among them) is 75, and he is being honored at Vessel, a hot design shop in Notting Hill in London. Vessel is selling his Suomi vases for Rosenthal and rare glass pieces he designed for Venini. His Sun in the Forest cup and saucer for Rosenthal, above, were done last year in a limited edition and are not being sold in the United States. The misty blue and golden yellow colors were inspired by nature. ''When I go very deep into the forest, all of my senses are alerted,'' he said. ''That is when I can hear with my eyes.'' The cup and saucer are $60 plus shipping. The show, ''Timo Sarpaneva: 50 Years of Avant-Garde Design,'' runs until the end of this month. Vessel is at 114 Kensington Park Road; Vesselstore@aol.com; (011) 44-207-727-8001. DONNA PAUL

title: Sparkle in a Bleak Season; When the Going Gets Tough, Some Go Shopping at Museums

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: German Likely To Head U.N. Mission
description: Michael Steiner, the German Balkan expert, is expected to be named the new head of the United Nations mission in Kosovo after the sudden resignation of Hans Haekkerup in late December. Mr. Steiner, talented and impatient, had to leave his post as foreign policy adviser to Chancellor Gerhard Schrder after losing his temper at some German airmen during an unexpectedly long refueling stop for Mr. Schrder's plane in Moscow last November. Mr. Schrder is pressing the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, to give the difficult Kosovo post to Mr. Steiner, who would be the first German to run a European protectorate since World War II.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Smuggling Term Lengthened
description: A man's sentence for smuggling 10 tons of caviar was more than doubled, to 48 months, on Monday after prosecutors appealed his original sentence. The trial judge had sentenced the man, Eugeniusz Kozcuk of Stamford, to 20 months, saying that the value of the caviar, $2 million a ton, made the crime appear more serious than it was. But on Monday the three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit imposed the longer term. In 2000, Mr. Kozcuk was convicted of filing documents declaring imports of 88 pounds of caviar, while smuggling 10 tons by bribing airline employees to carry suitcases containing caviar tins. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: For Clutter, a Command Performance
description: DEB MARGOLIN, 47, has spent much of her life thinking about mess. As a child, she went on strike against cleaning, on the grounds that no matter how much you did, mess always came back. As an adult raising two children in a ranch house in this neat northern New Jersey suburb, she lives in constant reminder of clutter's furtive creep. For Ms. Margolin, a playwright and actor, the ineluctability of mess remains one of life's great dramatic subjects.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: U.N. Campaign Begins
description: The government has begun its campaign to persuade citizens to join the United Nations. A nationwide vote, set for March, is the first on the issue since 1986, when voters rejected membership by a 3-to-1 margin. Polls show a close contest, with foes arguing that joining would undermine the country's traditional neutrality and cost the country a lot of money in dues. But Foreign Minister Joseph Deiss said membership would not force Switzerlandto take part in military actions and ''is a guarantee against isolation in foreign policy.'' Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: COACH INC. SAYS QUARTERLY PROFIT BEAT THE FORECAST
description: Quarterly profit at Coach Inc. rose more than forecast after the company cut costs, controlled inventory and sold more leather handbags and accessories during the holiday season. Profit in the second quarter, which ended Dec. 29, was at least 96 cents a share, compared with 88 cents a year earlier, the company said, a result that was better than Coach's Oct. 23 forecast of 92 cents. Analysts' average forecast was 93 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Coach will report final results on Jan. 23. Second-quarter sales rose 12 percent, to $235.8 million from $211 million, Coach said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Drugs Came From North Korean Ship

The deal increases Bradesco's assets under management by $882 million, to $21 billion. Late last year, the Lloyds TSB Group sold its asset management business to Banco Itau, another large bank. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, MARGARET ALTSCHUL
description: LANG-Margaret Altschul. Of New York City. Died peacefully, January 4th, in Key West, at age 86. She was born on November 4, 1915 to Helen Goodhart & Frank Altschul. After attending Bennington College, she worked as a reporter for the Journal American Newspaper in New York City. During this time, she met her husband, the late Daniel Lang, staff writer for The New Yorker magazine, to whom she was married for thirty-nine years. She is survived by her daughters, Frances Lang-Labaree and son-inlaw, Robert Labaree, Helen Lang, Cecily Lang-Kooyman, and son-inlaw Eric Kooyman, as well as by her eight grandchildren: Isaiah Orozco, Daniel and Joaquin Lang; Aaron, Hannah and Sophie Labaree; Nico and Olivia Kooyman. She is also survived by her sister, Edith Graham and her brother, Arthur Altschul. Margaret was loyal and generous to her family and many friends in New York, Martha's Vineyard, Stonington, Key West and England. She was vital and adventurous, creative with a love of beauty. Unconventional, quirky with a wry sense of humor, she will be keenly missed. Services will be held on Sunday, January 13, 10:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Manhattan Country School, 7 East 96th St, NY, NY 10028, or to Human Rights Watch, 350 5th Avenue, 34th Floor, New York, New York 10118-3299.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rating Cut Is New Blow For Gateway

The decline added to a 25 percent drop on Tuesday after the company, based in Poway, Calif., said that fourth-quarter sales were $1.16 billion, falling substantially short of analysts' forecasts of $1.39 billion. Moody's cut Gateway's senior unsecured debt one notch to Ba1 -- below investment grade -- from Baa3 on concern about the personal computer maker's ability to maintain or increase sales and market share.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Survey: E-Government Trumps E-Commerce
description: Internet users in the United States were more likely to visit government Web sites than they were to handle banking or stock transactions online, according to a survey by the University of Maryland. About 55 percent of adults with access to the Internet visited a government Web site last year, the study found, and 21 percent said they conducted business with a government agency from their personal computer, including renewing vehicle registrations and paying taxes. By contrast, the survey, which was based on telephone interviews with 500 people, showed that 20 percent of Internet users made bank transactions online, 15 percent reported paying credit card bills and 10 percent said they traded stocks via the Web. ''This research suggests that e-government is in many ways even more prevalent than e-commerce,'' Roland Rust, director of the university's Center for e-Service, said in a statement. ''E-service appears to be an increasingly attractive alternative to standing in line at a government office.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, JOSEPH FRANCIS, JR.
description: GOLDEN-Joseph Francis, Jr., of Teaneck NJ, died in his home on January 7, 2002. Born in 1932 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to Joseph Francis Golden, Sr. and Mary Gara Golden, he graduated from Penn Charter School in 1949 and from Princeton University in 1953, where he won the Ivy League batting title and contributed to Tiger teams that went to the College World Series and won the Ivy League Championship in 1953. After college he played professional baseball for the Philadelphia Athletics farm team in 1953 and 1954. After serving in the U.S. Army, he began his forty-year career at Milberg Factors Inc., in Manhattan, where he was President for many years. He was a nationally-ranked senior tennis player, avid golfer, and was a member of Hackensack and Arcola Golf Clubs in New Jersey and Colliers Reserve Country Club and Old Colliers Golf Club in Naples, Florida. He was a strong supporter of Loyola School in Manhattan, Penn Charter School in Philadelphia and of Princeton University, where he received the ''Robert L. Peters, Jr. '42 Award'' for his lifelong support of Princeton's baseball program. He is the beloved husband of Eileen (nee Walsh) Golden, father of Mary Frances and her husband Daniel Sponseller, Eileen W. Golden, Susan and her husband Victor Del Rio, and William and his wife Diane Golden; and grandfather of Julia and Daniel Sponseller, Joseph, Dylan and William Del Rio and Shannon, Katherine and Elizabeth Golden. The family has asked in lieu of flowers that contributions be made, in Mr. Golden's memory, to Loyola School 980 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10028, or to Saint Anne's School 542 8th Avenue South., Naples, Florida, 34102. Visitation will be held on Thursday, January 10, 2002 from 24pm and 7-9pm at the Volk Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, NJ, 07666, 201-836-0202. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10:30 am on January 11, 2002 at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue (between 83rd and 84th Street) New York, New York, 10028 with interment immediately following at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ.

title: ALCOA BIDS FOR REST OF A NORWEGIAN ALUMINUM PRODUCER
description: Alcoa said yesterday that it had offered 4.6 billion kroner ($516 million) for the 60 percent of Elkem, the Norwegian producer of aluminum and other metals, that it does not already own. The bid was rejected as too low by Elkem's No. 2 shareholder. Elkem shares rose 8.4 percent, to 168 kroner ($18.85), its biggest one-day increase in almost three years, surpassing the bid of 155 kroner ($17.39) a share by Alcoa. Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, said it was forced by Norwegian law to make the offer after its stake exceeded 40 percent. ''This is not a good price,'' said Finn M. Jebsen, chief executive of Orkla, a Norwegian consumer-goods company that owns 32 percent of Elkem; he is also chairman of Elkem, which is based in Oslo.

title: Pataki Vows to Limit Spending And to Avoid Delaying Tax Cuts
description: Basking in the patriotic spirit in New York since Sept. 11, Gov. George E. Pataki promised in his annual address today to hold the line on spending without postponing tax cuts and urged lawmakers to rise above partisanship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, JOHN PATRICK
description: LANE-John Patrick. Of Ardsley, NY, Jan. 9 following a long illness. Raised in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, Jack was the loving husband of Ellen, devoted father and fatherin-law Sean & Elizabeth, Mariellen and Peter, Neil and Kathleen, adoring grandfather of Brendan, Caroline, Kevin, Isabel, Daniel, Clare and Thomas. He was the loving brother of Catherine McMahon & was predeceased by his cherished brother Daniel. He is also survived by many beloved nieces and nephews. The devoted son of Cornelius and Margaret Lane of County Cork, Ireland, Jack was a proud United States Army Veteran in the China-Burma-India Theatre of Operations in World War II. He retired from Texaco, Inc. in New York following a nearly half-century career in financial operations. He was a loyal member of the St. Patrick's Society. Visiting Thursday 7-9 & Friday 2-4 & 7-9PM, Edwards -Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry. Mass of Resurrection 10 AM Saturday Church of the Sacred Heart, Dobbs Ferry. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Jack's memory to benefit retired sisters at Marion Woods Residence, 152 Ridge Rd, Hartsdale, NY 10530, would be warmly apprecated by his family.

title: IRAN EXERTS SWAY IN AFGHAN REGION, WORRYING THE U.S.
description: Iran is seeking to exert political and military influence in border regions in western Afghanistan in ways that challenge the authority of the interim government in Kabul and threaten Washington's long-term goals in the country, Pentagon and intelligence officials said today.

title: Who Lost the Surplus?
description: On Feb. 4, the White House will send to Congress its proposed budget for 2003. There is no doubt that it will project a severe decline in surpluses from the estimates made last summer. The question of what caused this deterioration is likely to be a major topic of discussion from now until Election Day.

title: Catch a Rising Star And Put It in Your Pocket
description: At the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week, Sony introduced two digital video cameras billed as the smallest and lightest ever made. The two Handycam models, the DCR-IP5 and the DCR-IP7BT, weigh 12 ounces and measure about 3 inches long by 4 inches high by less than 2 inches thick -- small enough to fit in a pocket. They use a new tape format, called MICROMV, to record up to 60 minutes of video at DVD resolution, on a cassette that is 70 percent smaller than a MiniDV cassette. Suggested prices are $1,300 for the IP5 and $1,700 for the IP7BT. The cameras display a thumbnail image of the first frame of each scene; touch the image and the tape fast-forwards to it. Users can also electronically enter a title for each cassette, which appears once the cassette is reinserted. The more expensive Handycam model stores still digital images on Sony's removable Memory Sticks. It can also be used as a wireless Bluetooth connection to the Internet, to e-mail short video clips and stills or to view Web pages on the camera's swivel screen. Eric A. Taub

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Prisoner Escapes
description: A convicted robber charged with assaulting a woman freed himself from restraints and escaped from police custody yesterday as officers opened a van carrying him and other prisoners, the police said. The man, Omari Scott, 21, was still at large last night. Mr. Scott was released from prison Dec. 24 after serving a sentence for a 1998 robbery conviction, but was being transported to Central Booking in Brooklyn on charges that he had assaulted a woman on Tuesday who had testified against him in the robbery case, the police said. Mr. Scott escaped around noon when correction officers opened the door of the van, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, HAROLD N.
description: WEBER-Harold N., 98. Of Northlake Drive, Orange City, FL, died Wednesday in the John Knox Medical Center, Orange City, FL. Born in Albany, New York, he was the son of the late Adna F. and the late Mabel Norris Weber. He was a graduate of Amherst College, Amherst, MA., and a member of AARP. He was an Administrator, employed by State of New York Transportation Dept. before he retired and moved to Florida in 1970. No known survivors exist. Lankford Funeral Home in Deland, FL.

description: Scott Bassen and David Rosen, associate creative directors at Deutsch, New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, were named vice presidents. They work as a team on the Snapple account, as well as on new-business efforts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Teenage Hoaxer Sentenced
description: An Oregon teenager who made a false online threat against a Westchester County high school was ordered yesterday to pay police overtime costs of $3,160 and sentenced to home confinement for three months. Judge Charles L. Brieant of Federal District Court also ordered the defendant, Benjamin Ballard, 19, of Portland, to three years' probation and ordered him to stay off the Internet during that time. Mr. Ballard pleaded guilty in October to making an interstate threat on the Internet, for sending an Edgemont High School student a chat-room message on March 23 warning her not to go to school because ''there's going to be a lot of people dead tomorrow.'' As a result, all the schools in the Edgemont school district were closed for a day. Hope Reeves (NYT)

On a mild-mannered street of sweet little 40's and 50's bungalows is a private quarter-acre landscape of rare Javanese stone deities, gold rush-era hand-hewn stone Corinthian columns, a koi pond and a fountain framed with centuries-old Chinese carved stone temple fragments, and a 10-ton Sierra white granite cube crowned with a plume of Japanese jungle bamboo.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Charges In Shootings
description: Two men wanted for three killings in Virginia were charged yesterday in connection with two shootings in Queens on Monday night. The police said the charges had not been determined yet. The two men, Jamel Crawford, 22, and Joshua Andrews, 19, both of Prince William County, Va., were charged with shooting Ayodej Atanda, 20, an employee of a Springfield Gardens store, and James Celestine, 61, an off-duty traffic enforcement officer who confronted the men after they drove a car on the lawn of his Queens home. Mr. Atanda was treated at Mary Immaculate Hospital and released, and Mr. Celestine was in stable condition yesterday at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. The charges pending in Virginia include first-degree murder and armed robbery. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; An Online Financial Pioneer Acquires Bricks and Mortar
description: E*Trade was an amiable host to the late-90's Nasdaq trading bash. With its cheap commissions and consumer-friendly stock-trading Web site, the company was one of the online pioneers that empowered millions of Americans to take on Wall Street pros. Like few others, E*Trade's advertising campaigns captured tech investors' irrational exuberance. It was only two years ago that E*Trade aired Super Bowl spots starring a dancing chimpanzee (''Well, we just wasted two million bucks'' was its punchline) and an emergency-room patient who had ''money coming out the wazoo.''

title: Economic Scene; Take me out to the ballgame, but don't make taxpayers build the ballpark. The high cost and low benefit of sports subsidies.
description: IN his last week as mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a deal to issue tax-exempt municipal bonds to subsidize half the $1.6 billion cost of building new stadiums for the Yankees and Mets on the sites of the existing stadiums. The state would also throw in $150 million to improve parking and transportation. In return, the teams would sign 35-year leases, with no escape clauses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESE, RAYMOND
description: TESE-Raymond. Age 89. Beloved husband of Lucille Madonia Tese, Tuesday, January 8 after a six month battle with cancer. He faced death, as he faced life, with great courage. The fourth of six children, Raymond was born in New York on September 10, 1912. His father, Salvatore, emigrated to the United States from Sicily in 1910. Working as a shoemaker, he not only supported his family but sent his sons to college. Raymond attended New York University and St John's University School of Law, and was admitted to practice in the NY State Appellate Division, First Department, in June, 1942. He worked for the law firm of Reed, Abbott and Morgan, and then joined his brother Vincent in the firm of Tese & Tese. He continued to work even after his official retirement, completing his last case just six weeks ago. Among his many honors, Raymond was proudest of his position as past Exalted Ruler of the B.P.O. Elks, New York Lodge No. 1. Raymond is survived by his wife, Lucille, his brother, Charles, his sister Angela, and an extended and loving family of nieces, nephews, great nieces, and great nephews. Viewing will be at the Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road in Westwood, NJ on Friday, followed by a Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, 9:30AM at St Gabriel's Church, East Saddle River Road, Saddle River, NJ. Interment will be at St John's Cemetery, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Bush White House Starts Own High-Mileage Car Program
description: As the Bush administration replaced one government-backed program to build high-mileage cars with another today, hardly anyone rushed to eulogize the old project. Environmentalists said too much had been spent and too little accomplished, while automakers said the effort's goals had been unrealistic in the first place.

description: The Mets' decision makers woke up yesterday and realized there was still a reason to go to work. They were set back late Tuesday night when Juan Gonzalez, the prize free-agent outfielder, decided to sign with the Texas Rangers. But several intriguing options remain for the Mets' outfield and starting rotation, and the task is to fortify those spots.

description: A University of Wisconsin foundation and the Geron Corporation announced today that they had reached a patent licensing agreement that is expected to make it easier for other companies and academic scientists to develop medical treatments using human embryonic stem cells.

title: Be Kind to Your Hard Drive: Clean Out the Cobwebs
description: ALTHOUGH the prefabricated holiday cheer is often swept away by the cold January winds, helping a friend is a good thing year-round. One friend you can help without even going outside is your humble computer, and a little PC T.L.C. can make you both feel better. Perhaps you have noticed that your hard-working pal is slowing down or that your hard drive is so packed with files that you have a hard time loading up a new video game.

description: The leader of the former Communist Party will be in charge of economics for the new government of the city state of Berlin, he announced today.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: More Trains For Commuters
description: New Jersey Transit will add trains, revise service and extend lines to reduce overcrowding following the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, the agency announced on Tuesday. Starting Sunday, there will be four new direct trains between Summit and Midtown Manhattan, three in the morning and one in the afternoon. There will also be two new trains for the morning peak hours on the Northeast Corridor express service and extended lines on two North Jersey Coast Line trains. The changes are expected to help accommodate an increase of more than 10,000 riders a day. Fewer commuters are driving into Manhattan because of security restrictions and the destruction of the World Trade Center PATH station, transit officials said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: For Mom and Pop, Closing Time; A Hell's Kitchen Drugstore Ends a Half-Century Run
description: Unlike many other independent pharmacists, Albert and Maria Gardini, the owners of a small drugstore in Manhattan's theater district, foresaw the cataclysmic changes that were about to sweep through their industry and adapted to them.

title: Buccaneers Don't Have Monopoly on Motivation
description: For a number of reasons, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers are motivated to win their wild-card playoff game here Saturday. The players fear their popular coach, Tony Dungy, will be fired if they lose. They want revenge for being routed in Philadelphia in last season's playoffs. The Buccaneers have never won a playoff game on the road in five tries. Finally, some Buccaneers were offended by what they perceived as gloating by Eagles quarterback Donovan McNabb at the end of their playoff game last season.

title: Conner's New Yacht to Navigate City Streets for Starters
description: The veteran America's Cup campaigner Dennis Conner is planning to dock his latest Cup challenger in New York City this morning after a most unusual voyage. For it's not every day that a 79-foot International America's Cup Class yacht finds itself in the middle of Manhattan after a cruise on Interstate 95.

title: In a Modern-Design Outpost, Selective Classics
description: Twenty miles north of Manhattan, modern design has set up shop in Nyack. A store called re:Fresh Home offers a well-edited range of current design classics (Jonathan Adler's ceramics, Angela Adams's pillows and glassware, John Pomp's hand-blown glass vases, and pillows and wall hangings from Hable Construction) alongside collages by a local artist, Liv Hanson, and hand-thrown sake sets by Steinwelder Pottery. The shop is organized by color groups (green being the most popular, for the moment). Bath salts from Chemistry Set in real Pyrex, far left, are $16 each; red ceramic bowls from Wingard are $48; the plastic Air chair by Jasper Morrison is $85 and the tulip-shaped Bombo table by Magis is $450. The 24-inch round convex mirror from Room Interior Products is $88. ''People can't start designing their homes with a clean slate, so we pick items that can be integrated into varied existing dcors,'' said Jessica Rattner, who is an owner of the store with her husband, Billy Rattner. Re:Fresh Home is at 95 1/2 Main Street, Nyack, N.Y.; (845) 353-3165; open Tuesday through Saturday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., Sunday from 12 p.m. to 6 p.m. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Running in Place During a Lost Season
description: These are strange times indeed for the Giants. This season, for the first time in 27 years, the offense ranked higher (9th) than the defense, which was 14th in the National Football League.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Man Arrested In Bomb Case
description: A man arrested on a minor drug charge was later found to be carrying instructions for making bombs, the police said yesterday. The police have notified federal authorities about the arrest and the bomb instructions. The man, Frank Bourricaudy, 22, was arrested on Friday and is being held on $100,000 bail. He was also charged with weapons possession and unauthorized interception of emergency communications during a crime. The police said he was carrying a .45-caliber automatic pistol with an illegally altered serial number and a police scanner when arrested.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Governor Wants More Budget Cuts
description: Addressing a joint session of the Republican-controlled Legislature, Gov. Dirk Kempthorne asked for further cuts to balance his budget for the 2003 fiscal year. The governor, also a Republican, said that the withholding of $55 million from state agencies that was ordered last year should be made permanent and that more sacrifices would be needed to balance his $1.9 billion plan. Rising Medicaid cases and inmate populations will swallow the 4.3 percent revenue growth projected for next year, he said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Winter Perennial Resurfaces With Cherished Finds
description: It won't be at the Armory on Park Avenue, but the Winter Antiques Show will be at the Hilton New York (Sixth Avenue and 53rd Street) from Jan. 20 to 27. A Herter Brothers side chair (right, circa 1881) was made for the William H. Vanderbilt residence on Fifth Avenue. With mother-of-pearl intarsia, it is on offer for $1.2 million. Also available, a near-perfect Navajo chief's blanket (circa 1840), discovered at the Antiques Road Show, for $500,000; www.winterantiques show.com or (718) 292-7392. The American Antiques Show at the Metropolitan Pavilion (125 West 18th Street) from Jan. 17 to 20 will include owl-shaped andirons ($2,400 a pair) and colorful 1800's game boards ($2,500 to $14,500); www.folkart museum.org or (212) 977-7170. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Justices Chide South Carolina in a Death Sentence, Again
description: The Supreme Court overturned a South Carolina death sentence today because the judge refused the defendant's request to inform the jurors that there was no chance the man they had convicted of murder would ever be released if they sentenced him to life in prison.

title: New Tree Disease May Afflict California's Giant Redwoods
description: California's awe-inspiring redwoods may be susceptible to a fast-spreading new disease that has already killed tens of thousands of oaks and other trees and infected many plant species in the state, according to preliminary findings by University of California scientists.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Dec. 15 about Jim Cleere, a World Trade Center victim and vice president of the Seabury & Smith division of Marsh & McLennan, misstated the date of his marriage to Jean Rieger Cleere. It was March 1978, not October. The sketch also misstated the timing of a phone conversation between Mr. Cleere, who was in New York for a meeting at 1 World Trade Center, and his wife, as well as her location at the time. The couple spoke after the second plane hit the World Trade Center, not as it hit. She was at her office in Newtown, Iowa, not at home. The article referred incompletely to Mr. Cleere's 1977 phone call to his future wife. The couple had met on a blind double date, each with someone else, a year earlier.

Shares in Avaya, which is based in Basking Ridge, N.J., plunged after the announcement was made yesterday, closing down $2.12, or 17 percent, at $10.35. Simon Romero (NYT)

description: GELOBTER-Martin. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude. Loving father of Steven and Lewis. Adored father-in-law of Lidia. Fond father-in-law of Ellen. Cherished grandfather of Evan, Dylan and Giselle. Devoted brother of Jane Boss. Dear brother-in-law of Joyce and Dick Greenwald. Caring uncle. Captain in the U.S. Army Quartermaster Corps. Director of Camps Equinunk and Blue Ridge. Chemistry teacher at East Meadow High School. He touched the hearts of children. Services today, 1:30PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Marty Gelobter Fund for Pediatric Critical Care Research, C/O Dr. Bruce Greenwald, Division of Pediatric Critical Care Medicine, New York Presbyterian Hospital, 525 East 68 St, M-508, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Executive Gets Post In Film Marketing
description: Alan Cohen, a longtime executive in network television advertising and promotion, has been named to the vacant post of president for domestic theatrical marketing at 20th Century Fox in Los Angeles, part of the News Corporation.

title: Romania's Road to Victory Lies Through the Internet
description: Some countries have little opportunity to win major international titles, because economic circumstances make it difficult for their players to travel. One of these is Romania, which has, however, taken full advantage of the opportunity to play on the Internet. Two weeks ago four of its players, Dorin Petra Musat, Serban Criscota, Alexandre Feber and Catalin Popescu, calling themselves Romanian Beauty, won the third OKbridge Internet World Championship without leaving their homes. A year earlier they captured the same title but had to go to Birmingham, Ala., to contest the final.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Laidlaw To Settle Suit
description: Laidlaw, the bankrupt operator of the Greyhound Lines bus business, agreed to pay $55.4 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the company's bondholders. The settlement requires that Laidlaw pay $42.9 million to bondholders and $12.5 million to its bankruptcy estate, the company said. Bondholders, who bought the debt from Sept. 24, 1997, to March 13, 2000, accused the company of disseminating false and misleading information about the relative priority of some of the debt and Laidlaw's financial status. Laidlaw failed to pay interest on $1.8 billion of bonds in May 2000, leading to the biggest corporate default of the year in the United States. The settlement is contingent on a final agreement and the approval of several courts.

title: Footlights
description: Brazilian Ways

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Sheriff Fires Deputy Over Tape
description: A sheriff's deputy who denied to his superiors that he saw a boy shot to death at Columbine High School after telling the boy's parents that he had seen the shooting was fired. The sheriff said Deputy James D. Taylor, a 14-year veteran, violated policies by providing false information to the parents of Daniel Rohrbough, one of 13 people killed on April 20, 1999, at the school. The parents, Brian Rohrbough and Susan Petrone, secretly tape recorded Mr. Taylor and used the tape in an effort to persuade prosecutors to have a grand jury learn whether a Denver police officer had shot their son. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Hockey Father Takes Stand To Explain Deadly Beating
description: Thomas Junta, the truck driver charged with manslaughter in the beating death of another father during a practice hockey game, took the stand in his own defense today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, AIDA ROVETTI
description: WHITE-Aida Rovetti, 104. Of Waterford, CT, died on January 8th, in New London, CT. She was a founding trustee of the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theatre Center in Waterford. Mother of George C. and Nelson H. White. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Saturday at 10 AM in St. Joseph Church, New London, CT. Calling hours will be held on Friday from 5-7 PM at the Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home, New London. Memorial contributions may be made to the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theatre Center, 305 Great Neck Road, Waterford, CT. 06385, or to the Florence Griswold Museum, Old Lyme, CT. 06371.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about progress in treating the sleep disorder narcolepsy misstated the age of Bill Baird, a man from Monterey, Calif., whose case went undiagnosed for years. He is 63, not 66.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, TOM
description: SHEA-Tom. Died yesterday morning after a valiant struggle with cancer. Throughout his illness he maintained the same zest and zeal that characterized his life-he lived abundantly. A member of the New York and New Jersey Bar Associations, Tom worked in transportation law and taught courses in law. More recently, he worked in residential real estate in New Jersey. His wife Mary, and children Joe, Todd, Kristin, and Elizabeth will be hosting a celebration of Tom's life this Saturday at 11 AM at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scotch Plains, NJ. He is also survived by 3 sisters: Patricia Draddy, Betsy McDermott, and Marijean Sommer. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Atlantic Home Care and Hospice, 33 Bleeker Street, Milburn, New Jersey 07041.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ARTHUR J.
description: LEVINE-Arthur J. Loved and mourned by his wife Rosalind, his daughters Nancy, Susan & Ketzel, his grandchildren, his sister Marilyn and family. A principled man of constancy & commitment to the causes he believed in and the people he loved. We are particularly proud of his advocacy on behalf of Soviet Jewry and women in the Conservative rabbinate. His love of Verdi, gardening, the ocean and the Yankees lives through us all. Funeral is today, at 10 A.M., Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck.

title: Battle for Australia Miner Winds Down
description: Robert M. Godsell, the chief executive of AngloGold, flew home to South Africa late today after spending three days here pleading with major investors to accept his company's offer for their shares in Normandy Mining, Australia's largest gold producer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUPNICK, HARRY
description: KRUPNICK-Harry. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation extends deepest sympathy upon the passing of Harry Krupnick beloved husband of Ethel and father of Jerry, Founder and Trustee. Our sincere condolences to the entire Krupnick family. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation

title: Season Is No Laughing Matter, and the Future Is Bleak
description: Shandon Anderson was in a playful mood Tuesday night. Fifteen minutes after Moochie Norris of the Houston Rockets sent the Knicks to another crushing defeat with a buzzer-beating 3-pointer, Anderson held a microphone in Kurt Thomas's face while a group of reporters questioned Thomas about his ejection from the game. When the questioning was done, Anderson, feigning seriousness, threw in his own question, leading him and Thomas to burst out in laughter.

title: Maternity Shopping Without the Nausea
description: THE main reason I decided not to have a fourth child was that I could not bear to face my old maternity clothes again.

title: Joined at the Hip
description: You'll have to look long and extremely hard to come up with an example of corporate treachery in the United States that's as horrible as the Enron debacle. This is a scandal with a very broad reach and it has some of the wise guys in the Bush administration and other top Republicans trembling in their penny loafers.

title: Justice Dept. to Form Task Force To Investigate Collapse of Enron
description: Widening the potential scope of the criminal investigation into the Enron Corporation, the Justice Department plans to form a special task force of prosecutors from across the country to conduct the inquiry into the company and its eventual collapse, government officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODBELL, SHELDON
description: RODBELL-Sheldon, of Palm Beach, Fl passed away on January 7, after an extended illness. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Gerry and Ellen, fatherin-law of Hank Alpert and Dr. Alain Roizen, cherished grandfather of David, Brooke, Erica, and Remy. Survived by his brother Arthur. Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, on January 10, 2002 at 11:30 am. In lieu of flowers please make donations to The Alzheimers Association of Palm Beach 561-820-8166.

title: Amargosa Valley Journal; Barren, Desolate and at Least Arguably Heaven
description: On clear days, and that means almost all of them, Doris M. Jackson can see for 100 miles in all directions from the Stateline Saloon and Gambling Hall. ''There aren't too many places you can do that,'' she said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SERVICEMASTER CO., Downer's Grove, Ill., a commercial landscaping provider, said it would acquire the minority interest in ServiceMaster Home Service Center held by Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

title: Storage That Grows As a Child Does
description: OFTEN, the youngest member of a household needs the most storage space, not just for toys and games but also for books and globes -- even television sets. Organizing the paraphernalia means containing what could become a big mess and teaching the family's younger children that everything has its place. Many options are modular and can be added on as a child's needs change.

title: 2nd Man Gets 25-Year Term For Beating Mexican Laborers
description: A Queens man was sentenced today to 25 years in prison for joining a friend in the attempted murder of two Mexican day laborers in September 2000, closing a case that drew national attention to the long-brewing tensions over Long Island's immigrant workers.

title: Arafat's Implausible Denials
description: The radical Islamic ayatollahs of Iran were responsible for dispatching the shipload of 62 rockets and antitank missiles, along with 1,400 mortar shells, to their proxy warriors in the Middle East. Included were 3,000 pounds of powerful new C-4 explosives to be used by suicide bombers against civilians.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Housing Starts Are Up
description: Canadian housing starts rose in December to the highest level since February 1992, as work on condominiums and apartment buildings increased, the government's housing agency said. Total starts rose 4 percent, to 175,500, in December from a revised 168,800 in November, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMY, SIDNEY J.
description: ZIMMY-Sidney J. Of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Patty and Jeffrey Schneider, Jane Zimmy and Ron Neumann. Adored Poppy to Nikki and Jamie Schneider. Graveside service at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, N.J. Friday, 11AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Boca Raton Community Hospital, 800 Meadows Rd., Boca Raton, FL. 33486. For information, please call ''BernheimApter-Kreitzman'' 1-973-422-0600.

title: Guiding a Balky Image Onto Your Web Page
description: Q. I am making a Web page, and my images won't show up even though I have uploaded them to the Web server. Why might this be?

title: OXFORD EXPECTS ENROLLMENT IN HEALTH PLANS TO RISE
description: Oxford Health Plans said it would add customers in 2002 instead of losing members as it had previously forecast, and its stock price rose 12 percent. The shares rose $3.51, to $32.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Oxford expects enrollment to rise 2 percent this year for employer health plans, it said. The insurer had 1.36 million customers in employer plans as of Sept. 30. Oxford had forecast a membership decline of 1 percent to 2 percent.

title: A Salvation Army Soldier, Drafted in the Terror War
description: CAN it be? Has a director of the Salvation Army used the words ''phone sex''? Of course he's a local guy, but even so, who knew that they knew?

title: Apple, in Search of Perfection, Enlarges iBook's Screen
description: A pleasant surprise awaited Apple executives when they tallied feedback forms from customers of the popular, all-white iBook laptop. Apple said the most frequent response to ''What would you like to see changed?'' was ''Not a thing.''

title: MTV and Showtime Plan Cable Channel for Gay Viewers
description: Looking to take advantage of what they say is a large and lucrative niche audience untapped by television programmers, two cable divisions of Viacom, MTV Networks and Showtime, are developing a plan to create the first cable channel aimed directly at gay viewers.

title: White House Moves to Contain Political Damage From Enron Turmoil
description: The White House disclosed today that Kenneth L. Lay, chief executive of the Enron Corporation and a leading financial supporter of the Bush presidential campaign, had contacted two Cabinet members a few weeks before the giant energy company's collapse to warn of its growing difficulties.

title: Bloomberg's School Plan Gets Support in Albany
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared today to get a warm reception to his ideas for revamping the management of New York's public schools.

title: Corrections
description: The Lessons column yesterday, about after-school programs, misstated the ratio of adult mentors to children in such programs. The ratios are high, not low -- a high number of adults to a given number of children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEDERLANDER, HARRY JAY
description: NEDERLANDER-Harry Jay. The oldest of five brothers who run a theater empire that stretches from London to Los Angeles, died of cancer January 6, 2002 at his home in Rancho Mirage, California. He was 84. A Detroit native he also has a residence in Bloomfield Hills, MI. He was a Veteran of the US Army Ordinance Corps-WW II. Spearheaded by his father David T. Nederlander a showman and theater operator, Harry and his brothers owned or managed theaters in New York, Chicago, Cincinnati, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Detroit & London. A partner in the New York Yankees he is also on the Board at Beaumont Hospital in Michigan and Federated Investors in Pennsylvania. Lifetime honorary Chairman of the Board and past president of the Bloomfield Open Hunt Club, Bloomfield Hills, MI where he helped organize horse shows for many years. Also a member of the Bloomfield Hills Country Club and Morningside Country Club in Rancho Mirage where he was an avid golfer. He is survived by his wife, Marjorie; their children, Robert Wayne Nederlander, Harry Jay ''Skip'' Nederlander, Jr., Scott E. Nederlander (Dawn), Kathryn Breech Raft (Dr. Arnold) and W. Kimball Breech (Kristin); grandchildren; Taylor, Sarah, Chandra, Erin, Chad, Lauren, & Kristin; brothers, James Nederlander (Charlene), Frederick Nederlander (Betty), Joseph Nederlander (Carole) & Robert Nederlander (Gladys) and one sister Frances Nederlander Kohn. Memorial service Friday in suburban Detroit. No flowers please, family suggests memorials to Wayne State University Apple Award, 5104 Gullen Mass, Detroit, MI 48202 or Michigan Association For Children With Emotional Disorders (MACED), 15920 W. Twelve Mile Rd., Ste 201, Southfield, MI 48076. For information A.J. Desmond & Sons 800-294-5668

title: X-Rays Define Clear Images Of Milky Way
description: Peering deep into the heart of the Milky Way with X-ray vision, an American spacecraft has produced what astronomers say is the sharpest-ever image of the most dynamic region of Earth's home galaxy.

title: Gyorgy Kepes Is Dead at 95; Artist and Aesthetic Theorist
description: Gyorgy Kepes, an influential designer, photographer, painter, educator, writer and aesthetic theorist, died on Dec. 29 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 95.

title: U.S. Freezes Assets of 2 Groups, Saying They Diverted Gifts to Al Qaeda
description: Continuing its assault on Osama bin Laden's financial network, the Bush administration announced yesterday that it was freezing assets of two groups professing humanitarian aims that officials said had funneled charitable donations to Al Qaeda instead.

title: Corrections
description: The Pop Life column on Dec. 26, about Eminem's 2000 album ''The Marshall Mathers LP,'' quoted erroneously from a line from a song on it, ''The Way I Am.'' The line is ''I'm not gonna be able to top a 'My Name Is' '' -- a reference to a hit on his ''Slim Shady LP'' -- not ''I'm not going to be able to top what my name is.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Console Sales Cheer Sony
description: Riding the recent surge in demand for video games, Sony said it had sold more than five million of its flagship PlayStation2 consoles worldwide during the holiday shopping season. Sony, the Japanese electronics maker, rang up twice as many PlayStation2 consoles between the last weeks of November and December than it did during the comparable period in 2000, shortly after the PlayStation2 was introduced. Boasting that it sold more consoles than its rivals Microsoft and Nintendo combined, Sony said it had sold 1.1 million PlayStation2's in Japan and about 2.5 million in North America, including 640,000 during Christmas week alone. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Takeover Of City Union Will End Soon
description: After a three-year trusteeship aimed at rooting out widespread corruption, District Council 37, New York City's giant municipal union, will again be allowed to run its own affairs beginning this spring, union leaders said yesterday.

title: Red Storm's Women Shoot for Higher Level
description: The longtime success of men's basketball has overshadowed another reality at St. John's: the women's program has struggled to establish a foothold in the Big East, a conference dominated by Connecticut, Notre Dame, Rutgers and Boston College.

description: To the Editor:

title: Milosevic Is in Court as Trial Plan Is Set
description: As Slobodan Milosevic assailed the court's legitimacy, judges at the United Nations war crimes tribunal made provisions today to protect his rights for the trial that is to begin next month.

title: In Making Crowded Homeless Shelters Safer, Some View the Issue With a Sense of Security
description: With use of homeless shelters in New York City at record levels, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has embarked on an intensive program to make city-run shelters safer. At the same time, anecdotal evidence suggests that there has been no substantial increase in crime at these shelters in recent years, city officials and other experts said this week.

title: The Sun, the Moon . . . 'The Fantasticks'
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple Delivers Hyperbole and Beauty
description: Apple did something weird and risky last week. In the days leading up to this week's Macworld Expo in San Francisco, the company put ever more tantalizing headlines on its Web page. "This one is big. Even by our standards," said one. "Count the days. Count the minutes. Count on being blown away," said another. "Beyond the rumor sites. Way beyond," said one, a comment on the gossip Web sites that frantically tried to guess what Steve Jobs would unveil at his annual keynote speech.

title: 5 Teenagers Charged in Sexual Assault of 13-Year-Old
description: Five high school boys in this upscale suburb have been charged with beating and sexually assaulting a 13-year-old girl last week inside her middle school and in a secluded area nearby, the Union County prosecutor said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Kodak Plans Wireless Venture
description: Eastman Kodak said yesterday that it was forming a new venture to focus on the transmission of video and still images over wireless devices. The company, called Appairent Technologies, will be financed by Kodak and the Monroe Fund, a venture capital unit of the Trillium Group, based in Rochester. The plans call for Kodak to spin out some internal operations into Appairent and to contribute several patents and patent applications. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Missile Protesters Plead Guilty
description: Fifteen Greenpeace members and two journalists who trespassed at Vandenberg Air Force Base near Lompoc in July and disrupted a test of missile defenses pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges on Tuesday in federal court in Los Angeles under a deal that let them avoid felony charges, the environmental group said. The 17 face six-month jail terms at sentencing. In reaching the accord, Greenpeace promised to refrain from unlawful protests at specified military bases that support missile defense and agreed to pay a $150,000 fine, the group said.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; History Shows First 5 Days Can Put Bulls On Right Path
description: One of Wall Street's most noted indicators -- the first five trading days of January -- has sent its signal. And it says that this will be a good year for the stock market.

title: The View From HollyBeCa
description: IF there is one New Yorker who doesn't compare the collapse of the World Trade Center to a disaster movie, it is James Sanders. ''It had a kind of hideousness, a specificity, that a filmic scene never has,'' said Mr. Sanders, an architect, urban historian and the author of ''Celluloid Skyline: New York and the Movies'' (Knopf, $45), published last month.

title: Kelly Plans to Cut Money For Overtime Police Patrols
description: Facing a budget crisis, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he planned to significantly reduce the additional patrols that for two years have been financed by a $172 million overtime program in which officers worked on their days off.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KEMPNER, MARGARET LOEB
