title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Amnesty Would Free Thousands
description: As many as 10,000 prisoners would be freed under a general amnesty approved by the lower house of Parliament to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Central Asian nation's independence and to relieve prison overcrowding. The amnesty, which requires the approval of the upper house and of President Nursultan Nazarbayev, would apply to juvenile criminals, invalids, women over 63, men over 65 and veterans of World War II, according to Deputy Justice Minister Nikolai Belorukov.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Cott Hires Executive From Coke to Run U.S. Soft Drink Business
description: Hoping to sustain the steady turnaround that has made it the unofficial king of private-label sodas, the Cott Corporation appointed a 20-year employee of the Coca-Cola Company today to take charge of its most important market -- the United States.

title: Limbs for Afghans
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 City Showcases For Swedish Design
description: SWEDISH design takes center stage at three exhibitions and sales beginning this month.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Welfare Caseloads Grow Sharply
description: Welfare caseloads rose sharply last month in the state with the nation's highest unemployment rate, 7.4 percent. The Human Services Department said the number of cases rose to 17,724 last month, an increase of more than 2,000 from the previous December. A spokeswoman for the department, Marianne Hoffman, said the number of families with both parents receiving assistance had risen 17 percent from November to December and 79 percent from last year. In November, the number of Oregonians receiving food stamps set a record, 339,770.

title: Pakistan Says It's Keeping Afghan Patrols at Full Strength
description: Despite India'a military buildup, Pakistan has not reduced the number of troops hunting for Taliban and Al Qaeda leaders along the border with Afghanistan, Pakistani military officers said today.

title: Van Gundy's Unique Voice Adds Noteworthy Analysis
description: The enduring memory of Jeff Van Gundy as the Knicks' head coach is of a man so intense that he looked miserable whether he was winning or losing. At postgame news conferences, he frequently looked as if he had just endured a night out with a band of angry vandals.

title: A New York Moment In a Bazaar Setting
description: Call it a bagel souk. Interesting lighting fixtures, mirrors and decorative accessories like ceramic vases and wall sconces from Morocco adorn the Bagel Zone, an East Village cafe that is more a North African bazaar than a typical New York coffeehouse. You can enjoy a comfortable place to sit and a homemade bagel (fresh from a steamer), a sandwich and tea or coffee while choosing a chandelier or a vase. The merchandise is reminiscent of what can be found at ABC Carpet & Home or in the Anthropologie catalog. Colored glass lanterns hang from metal chains, and large saffron, blue or orange urns sit on high shelves. The walls hold iron sconces and mirrors in colorful frames. Table lamps of parchment and patterned with henna are $40 to $65. Lanterns are $45 to $225, vases, $20 to $40. Iron sconces are $7 to $25, and mirrors range from $20 to $425. The Bagel Zone, at 50 Avenue A (Third Street), isopen from breakfast until 7 p.m. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Stevenson Upsets Capriati
description: Alexandra Stevenson had to get back to tennis. She simply did not know what to do with all the grief that resulted from the terrorist attacks Sept. 11.

title: U.S. Asks Curb On Student Pilots
description: The Federal Aviation Administration urged flight schools today not to allow student pilots unescorted access to airplanes before they are ready to fly solo.

title: Princeton Wins Permission To Proceed With Deer Hunt
description: Princeton officials won permission today to proceed with their second annual hunt to thin the deer population, as a state judge lifted a restraining order obtained two weeks ago by animal rights advocates.

title: Judge in Wisconsin Voids A Religion-Based Initiative
description: In a case widely seen as the first legal challenge to the constitutionality of President Bush's religion-based initiative, a federal court in Wisconsin has ordered the state to stop giving money to a drug and alcohol addiction program that relied heavily on Christian spirituality in its approach to treatment.

title: N.B.A. TV Deal May Kill CNN/SI
description: Employees of the sports network CNN/Sports Illustrated were told yesterday that it will most likely cease to exist by the fall in anticipation of its becoming a network owned by the N.B.A. and AOL Time Warner.

title: Publicity Council Names New Chief
description: Kathy H. Cripps has been named president at the Council of Public Relations Firms in New York.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Military Satellite Planned
description: The government announced its intention to put the country's first military satellite into orbit in three years. Besides observing events on earth, the satellite would help guide weapons and also serve commercial purposes, the government said. The satellite, expected to cost more than $500 million to develop, build and launch, is part of a program to modernize South Korea's military.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. to Form a Task Force For Investigation Into Enron

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONDLIFFE, JANE R.
description: CONDLIFFE-Jane R., 84, of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Martha's Vineyard, died at home on January 9, 2002. The daughter of the late Arthur J. and Grace Ellinger Rosenthal, she attended the Lincoln School, Rosemarie Hall, Smith College (Class of 1940) and the Columbia University School of Social Work. She spent many years as a senior staff member of Westchester Family Services and was one of the founders of Consultants in Care, a home health care service in Riverdale. She was active in many civic associations in Riverdale including the Riverdale Neighborhood House and Riverdale Senior Services. Her first husband, John C. Condliffe, from whom she was divorced, died in 1978. Her second husband Joe Alex Morris, died in 1988. She is survived by her brother, Arthur J. Rosenthal of New York, three children, Arthur J. (Toby) Condliffe of Toronto, Ellen Condliffe Lagemann of New York, and David C. Condliffe of Riverdale, a third son, Douglas B. Condliffe, predeceased her in 1977, and seven grandchildren, Keith, Elizabeth, and Judith Condliffe of Toronto, Nicholas Kord Lagemann of New York, and Kate, Barbara and Kalle Condliffe of Riverdale. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to the Douglas B. Condliffe Fund for the Arts at Riverdale Country School, 5250 Fieldston Road, Bronx NY 10471-2999 or to Riverdale Senior Services for the Jane R. Condliffe Fund, 2600 Netherland Avenue, Bronx NY 10463.

title: Srinagar Journal; Left Orphaned by War: The City and Its Children
description: Pressed hard against a cliff at the dead end of a twisting road in the old city here, a cluster of squat red buildings houses the lingering misery of Kashmir. It is an orphanage for boys, a great many of whom were left fatherless and destitute by the bloody 12-year guerrilla war in this Himalayan valley.

title: Slide Show: The Victims
Destruction of the World Trade Center
Pitcher Perfect
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Aisles Grow Less Cluttered As End Nears For Bookstore
description: Many of the shelves in the basement are empty, a ''Lost Our Lease -- Store Closing'' sign is in the window, and all the merchandise is marked down at least 20 percent. Coliseum Books, a Columbus Circle fixture for nearly three decades, and one of the few independent bookstores in Midtown Manhattan, is going out of business at the end of the month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONER, MOE
description: FONER-Moe, 86. Died in his sleep on January 10, 2002. He was a loving husband to Anne, father to Nancy and Peggy, and grandfather to Alexis. He spent his long life devoted to social justice. He developed creative projects promoting peace, workers' welfare, and racial harmony. Moe was loved by everyone, and we will miss his humor, warmth, energy, enthusiasm, and deep caring for people. Memorial service to be announced. Funeral service for friends and family Sunday, January 13, 2:00 PM, at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76 St.

title: DANAHER AGREES TO BUY MARCONI'S DATA SYSTEMS UNIT
description: The Danaher Corporation, the maker of Craftsman tools, agreed to buy the data systems business of Marconi P.L.C. for $400 million to add product-identification equipment to its line of manufacturing products. Marconi Data Systems, formerly known as Videojet, has annual sales of about $300 million. Danaher agreed last month to buy Marconi's environmental-testing equipment unit for $325 million. Danaher plans to expand into 18 new markets, including product identification, primarily through acquisitions. It bought at least four businesses in 2001 in an effort to increase sales and profit.

description: In percent

title: Chaney Boils Over After Knicks Are Drubbed
description: For the first time in his five-week tenure as coach of the Knicks, Don Chaney showed anger tonight. After the Knicks were pounded from tip-off to buzzer in a 111-89 loss to the Dallas Mavericks, Chaney was not the composed, laid-back man who hours earlier spoke optimistically about his crumbling team.

title: Enron's President Said to Have Asked Treasury Official for Help
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 - The Treasury Department disclosed today that the president of Enron Corporation asked a top department official last year for help in obtaining a credit extension to stave off bankruptcy.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREY, ESTHER
description: KOREY-Esther. B'nai B'rith International mourns the loss of Esther Korey after a long illness. She was the beloved wife of William Korey, mother of two daughters, and grandmother of two. Involved with and devoted to B'nai B'rith and her husband's efforts combatting Soviet Anti-Semitism and promoting human rights. May her memory serve as a blessing.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Meeting On Peace Effort
description: A delegation from Norway met with the newly elected government in a first step to formalize a cease-fire with separatist Tamil rebels. Peace talks broke off almost seven years ago and Norway has been trying to revive them to resolve an 18-year conflict that has claimed more than 62,000 lives. The rebels have suggested that their chief negotiator be allowed to live in Madras, the capital of Tamil Nadu, in India, a tricky proposal because India has listed the Tigers as a terrorist group, as have Sri Lanka, the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia. The state rejected the suggestion yesterday, Agence France-Presse reported. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: City Girds for Protests at Economic Summit Meeting
description: In the fall, the organizers of an annual summit meeting for the world's economic, political and academic leaders decided to move the conference from its usual site in Switzerland to New York City as a show of solidarity in the aftermath of the terror attacks. Security, the organizers were told by city and police officials of the Giuliani administration, would be little problem for a force accustomed to dealing with large-scale demonstrations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBLE, MARSHALL HAYS
description: NOBLE-Marshall Hays, 78 years old. Of Pawcatuck, CT, died of cancer January 8, 2002, at Lawrence & Memorial Hospital in New London, CT. He was the beloved husband of Carolie Woods Noble and devoted stepfather of five Hollingsworth chldren. He was a graduate of Culver Military Academy and Princeton University. After serving in the US Army special forces in World War II, he was a career Foreign Service officer in the United States Department of State, with extensive postings in Southeast Asia. He was Deputy Chief of Mission in Luxembourg. Services will be held Saturday, 1 PM Jan. 12, at the Calvary Church, 27 Church St., Stonington, CT. Contributions will be appreciated by the Community Cancer Center, Lawrence & Memorial Hospital, 365 Montauk Ave., New London, CT 06320, or Visiting Nurses Assoc. of Southeastern Conn., 403 North Frontage Rd, Waterford, CT 06385.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Doctors Implant A Pacemaker In A Congresswoman
description: Representative Darlene Hooley, a Democrat, left a hospital in good condition after having a pacemaker installed on Wednesday. Ms. Hooley, 62, who represents the Fifth District, was suffering from the flu and became dizzy at a town hall meeting in Portland on Tuesday. She was taken to a hospital, where doctors detected an irregular heartbeat and suggested installing a pacemaker. She underwent surgery on Wednesday, and was resting in her home south of Portland, a spokeswoman said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Vodafone Shares Cooling With Slower Growth in America
description: The Vodafone Group, a wireless favorite among investors, has lost a bit of its luster of late.

title: Enron's President Said to Have Asked Treasury Official for Help
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The Treasury Department disclosed today that the president of the Enron Corporation ( news/quote ) asked a top department official last year for help in obtaining a credit extension to stave off bankruptcy.

description: COZINE-Dr. Kathryn. Died on December 21, 2001 at the age of 65. Associate Clinical Professor of Anesthesiology at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. title: U.S. Is Taking War Captives To Cuba Base
description: A C-17 Globemaster cargo plane carrying 20 heavily guarded Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners left a Marine Corps base in southern Afghanistan today on its way to the United States naval base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, the first wave of hundreds of detainees who will be held there.

title: Ridge Voices Confidence in Olympics Security Plans
description: After touring Olympic sites for three and a half hours, Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, said today that security plans had convinced him that Salt Lake City and the surrounding region would be ''one of the safest places on the globe'' during the Winter Games next month.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Norway Indicts Teenage Programmer
description: Jon Johansen, a Norwegian teen ager who helped create a program that can break the technological safeguards on DVD's, has been indicted on charges originally intended to protect telephone and bank records. If convicted, he could receive up to two years in prison. The indictment comes two years after the Motion Picture Association of America asked the authorities in Norway to investigate Mr. Johansen, whose DeCSS program unlocks the contents of DVD's, making it possible to copy them. Mr. Johansen has said the program is intended to enable people to play DVD's on computers running the Linux operating system. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Turkey, on Road to Secularism, Fears Detour
description: ISTANBUL, Jan. 7  Nowhere does the war against Islamic extremism have more resonance than in Turkey: for eight decades, the country has used draconian laws and the threat of force to crush pro-Islamic politicians and protect secular ideals.

title: Court Rules Chinese From Mainland Cannot Stay With Parents : Abode-Seekers Lose in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kong's highest court cleared the way Thursday to deport thousands of immigrants from mainland China by rejecting pleas from children to join their parents who reside here permantly.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: DMX Pleads Guilty
description: The rap performer DMX, accused of disorderly conduct and animal cruelty, has agreed to plead guilty to lesser charges and star in public service announcements to encourage children to avoid guns and be kind to animals, prosecutors said yesterday. The performer, whose real name is Earl Simmons, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to creating a nuisance when the police went to his Teaneck home in June 1999 to investigate a shooting. He was later charged with neglecting his 13 pit bulls and possessing crack cocaine pipes.

title: Ties to Enron Leave Banker in an Awkward Spot
description: Enron's collapse leaves Marc Shapiro of J. P. Morgan Chase in a difficult position.

description: NEW YORK

title: Divining the Future of Law and Technology
description: When I was commissioned to write Cyber Law Journal in 1997, I thought that the best way to cover my beat would be to plop myself down at the intersection of law and cyberspace and watch the litigants, lawyers, cases, professors and judges pass by. That turned out to be as good a method as any, with the added benefit that parades are fun to watch. But now after four and a half years and well over 200 columns I'm leaving my seat. Today's column is the final Cyber Law Journal.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Back to an Era of Slurs, Paranoia and Persecution
description: History has a way of cleaning itself up so that, in retrospect, shameful events of the past lose their terror and seem merely unfortunate lapses in judgment. In looking back to the savagery of the Hollywood blacklist in the late 1940's and 50's, when anti-Communist hysteria swept the country and many talented filmmakers were driven out of the industry, it's easy to forget the intensity of the paranoia and the viciousness of the persecution.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Chemical Maker Restructuring
description: The Dutch chemical group Akzo Nobel will expand a previously announced restructuring program. No new figures were given, but a company spokesman said that the company hoped to save more than the 100 million euros ($89 million) originally announced by raising the number of job cuts and accelerating the schedule. The company had announced cuts of 2,000 workers in July after reporting a sharp fall in second-quarter earnings.

title: Judge Rules Fingerprints Cannot Be Called a Match
description: A judge has ruled for the first time that fingerprint evidence, a virtually unassailable prosecutorial tool for 90 years, does not meet the standards set for scientific testimony and that experts in the field cannot testify that a suspect's prints definitely match those found at a crime scene.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: No Higher Bid For Broadcaster
description: The German media giant Bertelsmann refused to raise its buyout offer of 44 euros a share to minority shareholders who own 11 percent of the broadcaster RTL Group. Bertelsmann raised its own interest in RTL to 89 percent in December when it bought a 22 percent stake from Pearson P.L.C., also at 44 euros a share. The deal included a provision that would require Bertelsmann to increase its payment to Pearson if it subsequently bought shares from minority shareholders at a higher price. Bertelsmann is not obligated to buy the remaining stakes, but has expressed interest in doing so before an initial stock offering expected in the next few years. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Iran must be a contributor in the war against terror. Our nation, in our fight against terrorism, will uphold the doctrine of either you're with us or against us.''

title: Juan Garca Esquivel Dies; Pop Composer Was 83
description: Juan Garca Esquivel, a composer and arranger whose meticulously outlandish pop instrumentals from the 1950's and 60's sparked a lounge-music revival in the 90's, died on Jan. 3 at his home in Jiutepec, Morelos, Mexico. He was 83.

title: A Familiar Capital Script
description: The rapidly exploding Enron inquiry presents elements reminiscent of earlier Washington scandals, including carefully phrased denials and accusations of easy access. And in a matter of hours today, it sent the White House into a full-scale effort to contain the potential damage to President Bush at a time when he wants to focus on the war on terrorism and the flagging economy.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: City Won't Fight Redistricting
description: Waterbury will not challenge a new redistricting plan that splits the city between two Congressional districts for the first time. The redrawn political map means two incumbents, James H. Maloney, a Democrat, and Nancy L. Johnson, a Republican, will face off in November. Mayor Michael J. Jarjura, a Democrat, announced yesterday that a contemplated legal challenge had been abandoned as too costly and complex. On Dec. 21, a bipartisan commission merged two districts and moved a quarter of the city's 107,000 residents into a third district.

title: A Fragmented Family Struggling to Reconnect
description: ''What Time Is It There?'' was shown as part of the 39th New York Film Festival in 2001. Here are excerpts from Elvis Mitchell's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 29; the full text is available at nytimes.com. The film -- in Mandarin, Taiwanese and French, with English subtitles -- opens today in Manhattan.

title: Chronicling a Bubble Called Kozmo.com
description: Though shot in digital video and accompanied by a sprightly techno score, ''E-Dreams,'' Wonsuk Chin's documentary about the rise and fall of Kozmo.com has the artifactual feel of an old newsreel. The movie is a window into an era that feels curiously remote. Listening to the buoyant young C.E.O.'s and market analysts talk about their I.P.O.'s and market caps, you may feel a vague stirring of nostalgia, accompanied by mild disbelief. Did people really talk that way back then? Did they really believe that a business devoted to delivering videocassettes and pints of Ben and Jerry's to lazy urbanites could merit hundreds of millions of dollars in venture capital?

title: Reported Deal Would Keep Two Troopers Out of Prison
description: After months of negotiation, the New Jersey attorney general's office and defense lawyers have outlined a plea bargain that provides no prison sentences for two state troopers charged in the 1998 shootings of three black and Hispanic men on the New Jersey Turnpike, officials with knowledge of the discussions said yesterday.

title: Matsushita Plans an Overhaul to Reduce Costs
description: Facing huge losses this year, the sprawling Matsushita Electric Industrial Company announced a plan today to overhaul itself in the next three years, reabsorb five partly spun-off subsidiaries and shift some production to China to cut costs.

title: San Diego Symphony Gets a Record Gift
description: The financially troubled San Diego Symphony is scheduled to receive a $100 million endowment, the largest ever awarded to a symphony orchestra in the United States and a sum guaranteed to place it firmly on the nation's musical landscape.

title: Sampling Glasgow
description: This might be called Scotch over ice. Icelandair Holidays offers quick trips to Glasgow through March 31 starting at $399 a person, based on double occupancy. They include two nights in a three-star hotel and round-trip air fare on Icelandair from New York, the Baltmore-Washington area and Boston, by way of Keflavik, Iceland. For departures from Minneapolis-St. Paul or Orlando, add $50 a person. For information, call (800) 779-2899 or visit www.icelandair.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, JOHN PATRICK
description: LANE-John Patrick. Of Ardsley, NY, Jan. 9 following a long illness. Raised in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, Jack was the loving husband of Ellen, devoted father and fatherin-law to Sean & Elizabeth, Mariellen and Peter, Neil and Kathleen, adoring grandfather of Brendan, Caroline, Kevin, Isabel, Daniel, Clare and Thomas. He was the loving brother of Catherine McMahon & was predeceased by his cherished brother Daniel. He is also survived by many beloved nieces and nephews. The devoted son of Cornelius and Margaret Lane of County Cork, Ireland, Jack was a proud United States Army Veteran in the China-Burma-India Theatre of Operations in World War II, where he served with rank of Acting Major. He retired from Texaco, Inc. in New York following a nearly half-century career in financial operations. He was a loyal member of the St. Patrick's Society. Visiting Thursday 7-9 & Friday 2-4 & 7-9PM, Edwards Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry. Mass of Resurrection 10 AM Saturday Church of the Sacred Heart, Dobbs Ferry. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Jack's memory to benefit retired sisters at Marion Woods Residence, 152 Ridge Rd, Hartsdale, NY 10530, would be warmly apprecated by his family.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: ScreamingMedia Names New Chief
description: ScreamingMedia in New York, which offers online content and technology services, said yesterday that it had named Kirk M. Loevner as its president and chief executive. He succeeds Kevin Clark, who continues as chairman. Mr. Loevner, 44, had been executive vice president at InterTrust Technologies in San Francisco. Mr. Loevner, above, joined InterTrust in January 2001, when it bought PublishOne, a digital rights management company that he had founded. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Reprieve For Prairie Dogs
description: School officials in Boulder County have postponed plans to kill hundreds of prairie dogs on school grounds. Parents and teachers had become concerned that the increasing number of rodents could spread disease to children and that their burrows could be hazardous. School authorities said that after they made their initial decision other options besides extermination had come to their attention and that they would allow 30 days to review them. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Asbury Park: Stone Pony Rally
description: Supporters of the Stone Pony nightclub, popularized by Bruce Springsteen and other rock icons, rallied yesterday against a developer's proposal that could lead to the club's demolition. ''Over my dead body,'' Domenic Santana, the Stone Pony's owner, told more than 100 people at a rally inside the club. The city has hired an appraiser to determine the value of the property before condemning it and turning it over to the developer, Ocean Front Acquisitions. However, Councilwoman Kate Mellina told the crowd that a professional planner hired by the city would prepare an alternative plan that could spare the club. The developer did not return calls for comment.

title: Sotomayor Tests Positive Again
description: Javier Sotomayor of Cuba, the high-jump world-record holder, who retired in October, tested positive for a muscle-building steroid in a retest, the International Association of Athletics Federations said. Sotomayor, the 1992 Olympic champion and a two-time world champion, initially tested positive for the steroid nandrolone after a meet July 14 in Tenerife, Spain, said Nick Davies, an I.A.A.F. spokesman.

title: Old New York Visited Anew

I may even be forced to acknowledge that my paraphernalia-filled apartment in Manhattan is just a slightly neater, less unkempt version of the overstuffed home in Baltimore where I grew up.

title: Political Memo; Party Battles Looming Over Costly Old Issue: Health Care Coverage
description: As Congress and the Bush administration return to the domestic agenda, almost no issue will be harder, more expensive or more divisive to deal with than health care. But in an election year marked by a recession and rising health care costs, the issue will be very hard to ignore, political strategists and policy analysts say.

title: U.S. Supports Colombian On Ultimatum to Rebels
description: The Bush administration today voiced support for President Andrs Pastrana's ultimatum to leftist rebels in Colombia, even as officials and experts expressed misgivings that it could lead to further violence and disrupt counternarcotics efforts.

title: Sports of The Times; Similar Acts Looked Upon Differently
description: NEARLY a week after Brett Favre sacked himself in the vicinity of Michael Strahan, the Giants' popular defensive end appears to be in the clear, free of the tepid and mostly local debate on competitive ethics that followed the favor from Favre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, LEWIS GEARY
description: FLEMING-Lewis Geary. Of Point Lookout, L.I., on January 9, 2002. Pearl Harbor survivor. Retired President of the Waverly Division of F. Schumacher Co. Lifetime member of the K. of C. Ave Maria Council. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Sullivan). Proud father of John A., Thomas, and Christopher. Loving father-in-law of Jo-Ann, Margaret, and Andrea. Doting grandfather of Lucy, Virginia, Jack, and Nora. Funeral Mass is today, 10 A.M., Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal R.C. Church, Point Lookout. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. For information, call Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, Wantagh, NY.

title: Israel, in Reprisal for Killings, Razes Gaza Refugee Homes
description: The Israeli Army retaliated today for the killing of four Israeli soldiers Wednesday by Palestinian militants by bulldozing dozens of houses in a refugee camp in the Gaza Strip, leaving hundreds of homeless people searching for their belongings in a five-acre sea of rubble.

title: Studies Will Take Sept. 11's Measure In Health Effects
description: Public health researchers in New York, struggling to determine the real dimensions of the health threat at the World Trade Center site, are beginning an ambitious series of long-term studies to identify and then track a wide range of people who lived through the nightmare of dust, smoke and stress when the towers fell.

title: David Moreno; Nancy Shaver
description: Feature

title: Rite Aid's Loss Grew in Quarter
description: The Rite Aid Corporation, the No. 3 drugstore chain in the nation, said yesterday that its loss widened in its most recent quarter as profit from prescriptions shrank and sales of nonpharmacy items slowed.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Wyoming: Low-Staffed Sheriff's Department
description: The Albany County Sheriff's Department says it no longer has enough people to respond to every call. Sheriff Jim Pond said low wages had left the agency short staffed. He said that officers would respond to felonies in progress and crimes against people but that some reports might merit just return calls. Sheriff Pond said that he should have 19 deputies and 19 detention officers but that he had 6 deputies and 11 detention officers. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Fen-Phen Settlement Approved
description: The American Home Products Corporation won final approval of a $3.75 billion settlement of fen-phen lawsuits after the deadline for filing legal appeals expired, company officials said today.

title: As Historian's Fame Grows, So Do Questions on Methods
description: For most of his career, the historian Stephen E. Ambrose was best known for his exhaustive multivolume biographies of Dwight D. Eisenhower and Richard M. Nixon. He was respected in his field but seldom read by the general public until 1994, when he published ''D-Day,'' a sentimental tale about rank-and-file soldiers.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Al LoBalbo, 82, a Basketball Coach 50 Years
description: Al LoBalbo, who in 11 seasons as a head coach made Fairleigh Dickinson University's basketball team a national leader on defense and as an assistant coach helped teach defense for Bobby Knight at Army and Lou Carnesecca at St. John's, died of pneumonia Saturday at a convalescent home in Mountainside, N.J. He was 82.

title: A Familiar Capital Script
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The rapidly exploding Enron ( news/quote ) inquiry presents elements reminiscent of earlier Washington scandals, including carefully phrased denials and accusations of easy access. And in a matter of hours today, it sent the White House into a full- scale effort to contain the potential damage to President Bush at a time when he wants to focus on the war on terrorism and the flagging economy.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The lure at Lure is fish. The restaurant, situated in what used to be Match Uptown, is the spinoff of Lure at the Independent in Bridgehampton, N.Y., and the pedigree shows. The appetizers include New York foie gras with rhubarb and walnut oil, and a grilled vegetable terrine, but the nonfish entries are, so to speak, swimming upstream.

title: Turkey, on Road to Secularism, Fears Detour
description: ISTANBUL, Jan. 7  Nowhere does the war against Islamic extremism have more resonance than in Turkey: for eight decades, the country has used draconian laws and the threat of force to crush pro-Islamic politicians and protect secular ideals.

title: Initial Jobless Claims Fall, Spurring Optimism
description: The Labor Department reported today that the number of workers filing new claims for jobless benefits dropped last week to a level that led economists to suggest that the worst of the recession might be over.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Motient Files For Bankruptcy
description: The Motient Corporation, which operates a wireless communications network for users of BlackBerry hand-held computers, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday. Motient is restructuring its debt in a prearranged deal with creditors. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 8 Accused In Drug Scheme
description: The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, left, yesterday announced the indictment of eight people accused of operating a million-dollar-a-year drug ring that offered home delivery to middle-class New Yorkers, including a fire battalion chief. The drugs included Ecstasy, cocaine, marijuana and prescription medications. A Manhattan hospital chemist, a Brooklyn doctor and the other defendants are charged with various counts of criminal sale and possession of controlled substances and conspiracy. The battalion chief, Robert Gleason, 43, who has since retired, had become addicted to painkillers after an on-the-job injury, his lawyer, Stephen G. Murphy, said. ''If he had not taken them, he could not have gone to work,'' Mr. Murphy said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, STANFORD
description: EISENBERG-Stanford. American Friends of The Hebrew University mourns the passing of Stanford Eisenberg, member of the National Council of Trustees. With his wife, Helen, who served as President of the South Palm Beach County Chapter, the Eisenbergs generously provided support for programs of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, including the Amy Eisenberg Graduate Student Scholarship in Education for the Gifted in memory of their beloved late daughter, and the Miriam and Julius Vinik Chair in Mathematics in memory of Mrs. Eisenberg's parents. Honored as Benefactors of The Hebrew University, the Eisenbergs have also supported the Rothberg International School, the Lautenberg Research Center for General and Tumor Immunology, and many other important projects of The Hebrew University. We extend out deepest condolences to Helen and her daughter, Ann Friedlander. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of The Board

title: The Enron Investigations
description: Washington is suddenly awash with investigations into the demise of Enron, as well it should be. The failure of the politically powerful energy trading company is the biggest corporate bankruptcy in the nation's history. Given the company's close ties to the Bush administration, and its generous campaign contributions to members of Congress, only an exacting and unflinching set of investigations can assure the country that Enron executives are not receiving special treatment from the government. So far, the White House is taking the right steps. We trust its determination will not flag in the months ahead, even if embarrassing questions come up about Enron's ties to the administration.

title: Jets' Secondary Faces A Familiar Challenge
description: One is tall, the other small. One is known for using his body; the other, usually the smallest player on the field, his head. But on Saturday, the Jets' starting cornerbacks -- the big Marcus Coleman and the smallish Aaron Glenn -- will have the same role: halt the Oakland Raiders' two future Hall of Fame receivers, Jerry Rice and Tim Brown.

title: The Future of bin Ladenism
description: Alive or dead, Osama bin Laden poses problems. If buried at the bottom of a bombed cave, we may not know his fate for some time. And while the world waits, Mr. bin Laden may become, among many Muslim militants, a modern-day version of a vanished imam, a lost spiritual guide whose hoped-for return will empower the oppressed and vanquish the strong.

title: EQUIFAX CUTS 700 JOBS AND TAKES $37 MILLION CHARGE
description: Equifax Inc., a consumer-credit reporting company, said yesterday that it had eliminated 700 jobs, or about 12 percent of its work force, and closed offices after the July spinoff of a payment-processing business, Certegy Inc. Equifax had fourth-quarter expenses of about $37 million related to the job cuts, and $23 million for writing down the value of technology investments. The expenses reduced profit by 25 cents a share. Equifax, based in Atlanta, said it needed to pare the work force because the spinoff reduced sales by $800 million. A spokesman said the cuts were mostly in Europe and Latin America.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: European Economy Grew
description: Gross domestic product in the 12 euro-zone countries grew 1.4 percent in the third quarter of last year, down from 1.6 percent growth in the second quarter, the statistics office of the European Union said. The statistics office, Eurostat, said the figures were a revision from previously reported growth of 1.3 percent. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: Ford Is Said To Be Cutting Up to 15,000 More Workers
description: The Ford Motor Company's board agreed on a plan tonight to cut its work force by up to 15,000 hourly workers, in addition to the 5,000 salaried workers it said it would cut last year, and also close several of its plants, including a truck plant in Edison, N.J., according to a person close to the deliberations.

title: The Greater Danger
description: If you think Iraq is scary, come here to the bleak and snowy border between the two Koreas and look north.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEK, KENNETH CHEE KEUNG
description: SHEK-Kenneth Chee Keung. On January 8, 2002. Beloved husband of Eleanor, devoted father of Susan, Beau and Kim Shek-Chan, loving son of Franklin and Muriel Shek. Loving brother of Anthony Shek & Anna Shek Chang. Family will receive friends on Saturday, January 12 and Sunday, January 13 from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral service Monday, January 14, 9:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Dysfunctioning Comically in the Burbs
description: Although ''Orange County'' lasts less than an hour and a half, it often feels like six different movies fighting each other for attention. It is much less, in the end, than the sum of its parts. Some of the parts, happily, are inventive and funny, but the picture, unruly as it is, is ultimately as indecisive and tentative as its hero, a suburban teenager named Shaun Brumder, played with wide-eyed agitation by Colin Hanks.

title: Visions for Hallowed Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, VIVIAN B.
description: SINGER-Vivian B. Of Rego Park, NY died in her home on January 9, 2002 after battling a long illness with leukemia. Born in 1924, Vivian was a devoted wife to her husband Eugene, a caring mother to her family and a giving and sharing woman to her friends and community. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, at 11:30AM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Rego Park, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Cancer Research and Treatment Fund, 1440 York Avenue, NY, NY, 10021.

title: Ex-Diplomat Is Sentenced In Illegal Use Of Influence
description: A retired State Department expert on North Korea was sentenced yesterday to three years' probation for acting illegally to help a businessman who was a central figure in the federal investigation of Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey.

title: Ad Pages Decline At Steepest Rate
description: Advertising pages in magazines last year fell by the largest percentage since 1977, the year comparable records were first kept, according to an annual count by the Publishers Information Bureau in New York.

title: State Sues 2 Power Plants Over Pollution Controls
description: New York State filed a lawsuit today charging that two power plants near Buffalo violate federal clean-air laws.

title: The Leisurely February-April Romance of Two Guys
description: ''What if there's nothing wrong with me?'' Eban (Brent Fellows) says about an hour or so into the extremely underdramatized ''Eban and Charley.'' With this film, the writer and director James Bolton takes a sensational subject, the love affair between 29-year-old Eban and just-turned-15 Charley (Giovanni Andrade), and leeches it of vitality or even something as base as lust.

title: AnnTaylor Plans to Take Write-Downs
description: The AnnTaylor Stores Corporation, a retailer of women's career clothing, will have quarterly pretax costs of $17 million as it writes down assets, discontinues its cosmetics business and cancels some merchandise orders to control inventory.

title: Scientists Plumb Life's Mysteries With Minds and Hearts
description: SERVANTS OF THE MAP

title: After Signs of Progress, Devils Retreat Once More
description: Each victory seems to spark hope that the long-awaited turning point has come at last. A game or two later, the optimism turns out to be little more than wishful thinking. On a new night, it was an old story.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip Makers Still Discussing Merger
description: A top-level negotiating team from Micron Technology has reportedly offered to take over all of Hynix Semiconductor's memory chip facilities. The team, led by the Micron chairman, Steven Appleton, was expected, however, to encounter difficulties in reaching agreement on a price. Micron was said to have offered as little as $2 billion for a joint venture while Hynix suggested as much as three times that amount. Although the two sides might work out a memorandum of understanding, they were not believed likely to come to final terms any time soon. Hynix, burdened with $8 billion in liabilities, still counts on slowly rising prices of semiconductors to add to the value of its assets. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Panel Is to Propose Breaking Up Amtrak
description: Amtrak, the money-losing national railroad, should be broken up, with the government taking ownership of the tracks and competing companies taking over some or all of the most popular train routes, a plan to be unveiled today says.

title: Enron's Auditor Says It Destroyed Documents
description: As the fortunes of the Enron Corporation unraveled in late 2001, officials of its accounting firm, Arthur Andersen & Company, destroyed ''a significant but undetermined number'' of documents relating to the company and its finances, Andersen disclosed yesterday.

title: A Hard Hit by Peca Can't Lift the Isles
description: The television camera caught the normally fearless Michael Peca on the Islanders' bench tonight. Peca was dabbing tears from the dark hollows beneath his eyes.

title: IMATION, MAKER OF DATA STORAGE DISKS, TO CUT 500 JOBS
description: The Imation Corporation, a maker of data storage disks, will cut 500 jobs, or 14 percent of its work force, as part of a restructuring that will reduce pretax fourth-quarter profit by $60 million to $65 million. The job reductions are in addition to 500 transferred to Kodak Polychrome Graphics, which bought Imation's color proofing and software business last quarter for $50 million. The cuts will be completed through the course of the year, a spokesman said. The sale and some asset write-offs are expected to save about $37 million a year.

title: Suit Accuses Big Utility In California Of Fraud
description: The state attorney general weighed into a bitter legal battle left over from last year's energy crisis today by filing a civil suit against the PG&E Corporation, charging that the company improperly siphoned off billions of dollars in cash from its utility subsidiary.

title: Mets Are Looking At Two Pitchers
description: The Mets are still trying to tinker with their revamped team, especially their starting pitching. General Manager Steve Phillips has expressed the most interest in Pedro Astacio and James Baldwin, right-handers with recent injury problems. Astacio hurt his right shoulder last season and Baldwin had arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder after the 2000 season. Rick Helling and Terry Adams are other possibilities.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Motorbike Sales
description: The Yamaha Motor Corporation expects sales of its motorcycles and other bikes to rise 14.2 percent this year on strong demand from other countries in Asia, including China. Yamaha, Japan's No. 2 motorbike maker -- after Honda -- expects to sell 2.3 million motorbikes this year after a 5.7 percent slide last year. The company sells 90 percent of its motorbikes overseas. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Leaders Call For Action On Terrorism
description: East African leaders opened a summit meeting in Khartoum by urging united action against terrorists. The United States has in the past accused Sudan of helping to foster terrorism, and as it hunts Osama bin Laden, Washington has accused an Islamic group in Somalia of having links with Al Qaeda. The host of the meeting, President Omar al-Bashir, urged his colleagues to help ''shed the image'' that Africa is a breeding ground for terrorists. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Colombian Troops Move on Rebel Zone as Talks Fail
description: A day after President Andrs Pastrana declared an end to peace talks with leftist rebels, convoys of government troops and tanks moved toward a vast demilitarized zone that the guerrillas were allowed to occupy during three years of negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTAG, JUDITH
description: MONTAG-Judith. Of Norwood, NJ (formerly of Tenafly). Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Devoted mother of Sanford, Rodney and Dawn, mother-in-law of Nancy & Sally, dear sister of Arline Price, loving grandmother of Andrew, Jenna, Alex and Julia. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ, Friday, 12:30 (1-800522-0588). Should friends desire, contributions to Judith Montag Memorial Fund for Amyloidosis.

title: Visions for Hallowed Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: So Much More Than Just a Desk: A Home's Center
description: ''In the 18th century, a secretary-bookcase was the nerve center of the home,'' said Leigh Keno, the dealer in American antiques. ''Everything valuable was kept there: cash, account books, receipts, treasured volumes. It was like a computer is to us today, but instead of a password, you opened it with a key.''

title: Kung-fu Brave Vs. Gallic Beast
description: Born in Hawaii and raised in Germany, the martial-arts champion Mark Dacascos plays an American Indian in the French film ''Brotherhood of the Wolf.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a plan to end broadcasts of the Grand Ole Opry on WSM-AM in Nashville after 76 years misstated the name of a Chicago radio station that is among famous Top 40 stations that changed their formats. It is WLS, not WSL.

title: The Neediest Cases; Leap in Annual Donations And Fund's Millionth Gift
description: On Christmas Day, officials of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reported that donations were down 24 percent from the previous year, a far larger decline than was ever recorded from one campaign to the next in the fund's 90-year history.

title: Cohen a Surprise Second After Kwan Takes Lead
description: As the sprite-sized Sasha Cohen arched her fragile back into a comma during a captivating spin, as she soared into her triple jumps with helium in her bones, her defiance was disguised beneath her grace.

title: Faintly Connected Dots Portray a Qaeda Man
description: As investigators retrace the movements of Richard C. Reid, the drifter who is accused of trying to blow up an American Airlines plane last month with an explosive in his sneakers, they are becoming increasingly convinced that he carried cash and messages for Al Qaeda across Europe and the Middle East.

title: Radio Free Torricelli
description: Senator Robert Torricelli used to assure his constituents that he would love to explain what went on between himself and a wealthy political contributor if only his hands weren't tied by a continuing federal investigation.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Trafficking In An Antihistamine
description: Federal drug agents arrested more than 50 people and issued about 50 other warrants in a dozen cities as part of a nationwide investigation into the trafficking of pseudoephedrine, a prescription antihistamine used in over-the-counter cold and flu medicines that is also the main ingredient in methamphetamine, the Drug Enforcement Agency said. Over the last year, officials said, the agency has tracked a network that smuggled Canadian-manufactured pseudoephedrine into the country, largely through Detroit and Chicago. The pills were sold to methamphetamine laboratories on the West Coast, many of them in California, officials said.

title: Kmart Shows Fresh Signs Of Trouble
description: Squeezed by a poor holiday performance, Kmart said yesterday that it was seeking additional financing and reviewing its business plans for the next two fiscal years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, DR. RICHARD W.
description: BRENNER-Dr. Richard W. On Wednesday, January 9, 2002, of New Vernon, NJ. Beloved husband of Judith (nee Resnick), devoted father of Andrew Brenner and Jill Brenner, cherished brother of Judith Church and the late Martin Brenner, dear grandfather of Alex and Kevin. Funeral services will be conducted from Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ on Friday, January 11, at 11:30 AM. Interment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ.

title: Dolan's Bid Raises Stakes, Complicating Red Sox Sale
description: Three weeks after the Boston Red Sox were awarded to a group led by John Henry, the owner of the Florida Marlins, one of the losing bidders, Charles F. Dolan, submitted a new bid yesterday that was $40 million higher than the winning bid.

title: Tom McDonald Leaves
description: After 30 years of intelligent and versatile reporting at Channel 5, Tom McDonald, the weekend sports anchor, has left the station. His replacement, Reischea Canidate, comes from KSWB-TV in San Diego. Curt Menefee, who left the station on Dec. 31, will be replaced by John Discepolo. Richard Sandomir

title: World Briefing | Europe: Latvia: Big Jump In H.I.V. Cases
description: The number of Latvians known to carry H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, grew last year by 84 percent and the number of new infections soared by 73 percent over the previous year, the deputy director of the National AIDS Prevention Center said. Four in five new infections were caused by needle-sharing among drug users, the deputy director, Inga Upmerce, said. Although the number of new infections in the nation of 2.4 million people remains tiny, at 807, and the total number of infections is only 1,765, the rate of increase is worrisome and demands new prevention tactics, she said. Latvia, like some other former Soviet republics, is experiencing one of the world's most rapid increases in infection. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Singapore Details Terrorist Plot to Bomb U.S. Ships and Soldiers
description: MANILA, Jan. 11  Terrorists linked to Al Qaeda planned a series of bomb attacks against Western embassies, American naval vessels, American companies and a shuttle bus carrying American soldiers, the Singapore government said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: South Brunswick: Football Pool Arrests
description: An office worker operating a Super Bowl pool was turned in by a co-worker and arrested on charges of promoting gambling, prosecutors said. The worker, Wayne Davis, 34, a mid-level manager for AT&T in South Brunswick, could face a maximum of five years in prison. He is accused of taking nearly $3,000 of an estimated $30,000 from the pool money for personal profit, the Middlesex County prosecutor's office said after a three-month investigation. But John Murphy, Mr. Davis's lawyer, said the Super Bowl pool was much smaller than $30,000 and was about to be disbanded for lack of interest.

title: Pilot Safe After Fighter Jet Crashes in Woods
description: A New Jersey Air National Guard fighter jet crashed into a wooded area near the Garden State Parkway during training this morning, scattering debris across the highway but causing no injuries.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Investment In A School System
description: Eddie C. Brown, manager of an investment fund, is donating $5 million to the troubled school system in Baltimore. The money will be used for a five-year initiative, the Turning the Corner Achievement Program, which will focus on poor middle-school children who need academic help, as well as children who are gifted. The program will begin with two groups of 35 students in depressed neighborhoods and a group of gifted students from throughout the city.

title: Kittles Reels Off 12 Straight, Helping Nets Stay Atop East
description: First there was a blur. Then came the breeze.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBIN, MYRON
description: WERBIN-Myron. My loving father died January 8, 2002 at age 92. Adored by his grandchildren, Gregory and Kyra, loved by his daughter-in-law Lisa. World War II vet, 307 Bomb Wing. Your lightness of spirit, selflessness and laughter will be in our hearts forever. Your son, Barry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, MARIANNE
description: LANDAU-Marianne. December 31, 2001. Escaping Nazi Germany, she found profession and family in New York. Wife of Herbie, mother of Pamela, mourner for both, she leaves vivid memories to grandson Julian; cousins Herbert, Robert, and their families; niece Deborah; cousin and friend Gaby; and many other relatives and friends. Services Sunday, January 13, 10 AM, Schwartz Bros. Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIESS, FRED
description: ZIESS-Fred. The offices and staff of Maunter-Glick mourns the loss of our dear friend, our deepest heartfelt condolences to his brother Alan and sister-in-law Wendy and their family.

title: 'Loop'
description: P.S.1 Contemporary Art Center

title: Buyout Firm Is Acquiring Manufacturer Of Packaging
description: First Atlantic Capital Ltd., a New York private investment firm, is planning to announce today that it has agreed to buy the Ranpak

title: 'Of the Newest Fashion' -- 'Masterpieces of American Neo-Classical Decorative Arts'
description: Hirschl & Adler Galleries

title: Dear Mr. Blair: Stay Home and Help
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair has returned from another whistlestop diplomatic trip to find Britons unimpressed with his international stardom and angry that he is devoting energies abroad when public services at home that he pledged to restore are crumbling.

title: Editorial Observer; Channeling Ghosts of Presidents Past, Rutherford B. Hayes Included
description: President Bush passed a milestone of sorts recently when he disclosed that over the holidays he had been reading ''Theodore Rex,'' the new best-selling biography of Theodore Roosevelt by Edmund Morris. Mr. Bush was evidently given the book by his political adviser, Karl Rove, who is something of a history buff, especially of the emergence of the modern Republican Party at the turn of the last century.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Wants Interviews Closed
description: Lawyers representing Microsoft in its antitrust case have asked a federal judge to bar public access to interviews with witnesses that are being conducted in preparation for the remedy phase of the lawsuit. During the antitrust trial, a federal court opened the depositions to the public after a request was made by a group of news organizations, including The New York Times. The request was based on a 1913 law that requires depositions in antitrust cases to be made public. Microsoft maintained that the law did not apply to the proceedings between the company and the nine states that refused to join a proposed settlement with the Justice Department. Several news organizations, including The Times and The Washington Post, said they were considering whether to challenge Microsoft's latest request. Stephen Labaton (NYT)

title: 'From Goddess to Pinup' -- 'Icons of Femininity in Indian Calendar Art'
description: IndoCenter of Art and Culture

title: We Solemnly, Merrily Swear; Newly Elected Officials Celebrate With Pageantry
description: All of the more than 700 seats were filled and 200 people stood along the sides of the auditorium at Public School 218 in Washington Heights on Sunday to see Miguel Martinez sworn in as the neighborhood's new city councilman.

title: Carol Rhodes
description: Brent Sikkema

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Poor Outlook For Auto Supplier
description: Magna International, one of North America's biggest automotive equipment suppliers, said its earnings remained under pressure from production cutbacks, price discounting on new models and general economic uncertainty in the automotive industry. The company, which is based in Toronto, expects 2002 earnings from operations of $5.25 to $5.90 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call previously forecast earnings of $5.52 for 2001 and $5.61 this year. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Art in Review
description: icrography: The Hebrew Word as Art"

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Offers Layoff Details
description: Motorola said yesterday that the planned elimination of 9,400 jobs announced last month would include 20 percent of its nearly 600 executives and that four plants would be closed this year. The closings include a wafer manufacturing plant and an assembly and packaging plant in Sendai, Japan, and assembly and packaging plants in Hong Kong and Austin, Tex. The closings will account for 4,000 of the 9,400 jobs. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Raiders Need Gruden's Pride and Poise
description: If Jon Gruden accepted all of the bad vibes and criticism that have followed his team during its free fall -- a sparkling 8-2 season that has turned into losses in four of its last six games, including three straight defeats -- then his Raiders might as well disappear even before their playoff game against the Jets tomorrow.

title: To freshen an I.B.M. campaign, Ogilvy uses ex-stars of the N.B.A.
description: THE term ''b-to-b'' usually means business-to-business, but an aggressive campaign for I.B.M. hopes to make buyers of information technology equipment think it means basket-to-basket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, ELEANOR D., (NEE LETTIERI)
description: LYNCH-Eleanor D., (nee Lettieri). Died January 9, in Venice, FL at age 78. She was born in Jersey City, New Jersey and moved to the Venice area from Oradell, NJ in 1981. Eleanor was the fourth of 12 Lettieri children. Her husband, James F. Lynch, who was a copy editor for the New York Times for 32 years, predeceased her in 1985. Survivors include her sons: Christopher of Boston, MA, and Dean of Tappan, NY; a daughter, Barbara Lynch of Union City, NJ; and granddaughter Madeline Lynch of Tappan, NY.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Dance; 2 Festivals Are Offering Films, Photos and Shows
description: Dancegoers will face an embarrassment of riches this weekend, when two ambitious festivals open at theaters and exhibition spaces around Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAM, CAPT. YAACOV KUBEK
description: ADAM-Capt. Yaacov Kubek (1922 -2002). On Monday, January 7, peacefully at Roosevelt Hospital following a brief illness. Capt. Adam was a Master Mariner, intrepid sailor and decorated war veteran. He was born in Busk, Poland, and was a young immigrant to Palestine where he joined the Haganah in 1938. Following his graduation from Israel's Officers Academy in Haifa, he saw active service with the allied navies during World War II, earning a testimonial message from Pres. Harry Truman and serving in the Atlantic, Pacific and Mediterranean war zones. A unique naval distinction belonged to Capt. Adam -he was Commanding Officer of the first warship in Israel's navy during the 1948 War of Independence. Capt. Adam was an active member of The Explorers Club, in support of education in scientific exploration for young people and laypersons, and was North American Director of Operation Drake, under the patronage of H.R.H. Prince Charles. He was predeceased by his late sister, Ernestina, and is survived by his brothers Lonek and Y'Israel; his daughter, Judith Adam, & grandsons Brendan and Arden; his niece, Zmira Adam Shuruk; his nephew, David Ronen; his dear former wife, Nina Reitzman Adam; and many sincere and genuine friends. A memorial service is expected to be held in early spring. For information, email: YAACOVADAM@aamanheim.net

description: Tony Shafrazi Gallery

title: Are They Alive or Mannequins? Who Can Tell?
description: You are no doubt familiar with the look. You know, the look: that glassy, hungry gaze of the undead that beams from the eyes of models in upscale fashion magazines and advertisements.

title: A Blunt-Speaking General Says India Is Ready for War
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 11  In remarks that seemed to surprise India's own political leadership for their baldness, the army chief declared today that the military was fully prepared for a large-scale conventional war with Pakistan and was also ready to deliver a devastating nuclear strike should Pakistan use its nuclear arsenal first.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEPES, GYORGY
description: KEPES-Gyorgy. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be deeply mourned by the world of art.

description: For all New York Times film reviews since 1996, go to the Film Archive .

title: Court Orders 'Tiger Lady' to Plan Animals' Removal
description: New Jersey wildlife officials have spent the last year and a half trying to shut down the Bengal tiger preserve run by the woman known as the Tiger Lady. But as one legal proceeding follows another, a conclusion has proven to be as elusive as the animals are in the wild.

title: France Bans Damages for 'Wrongful Births'
description: French lawmakers adopted a bill today that would effectively strike down a court ruling that ordered financial compensation for a severely disabled boy because medical errors had allowed him to be born.

title: Moe Foner, Labor Official and Movement's Unofficial Cultural Impresario, Dies at 86
description: Moe Foner, who played a major role in building New York City's largest union of health care workers and later was the labor movement's unofficial cultural impresario, staging art shows, plays and concerts, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Wells Is All Smiles in His Return to Yankee Pinstripes
description: Two old acquaintances relaxed on Christmas Eve in Pete & Shorty's Tavern in Clearwater, Fla., the conversation pleasant and benign for the first hour. George Steinbrenner told David Wells that Wells would enjoy pitching for the Arizona Diamondbacks, and Steinbrenner -- knowing Wells had shaken hands on an agreement with the Diamondbacks four days before -- wished him well.

title: Visions for Hallowed Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTIN, HAROLD
description: ANTIN-Harold, 81. Of New York City and Petersburgh, NY, died peacefully at home on January 8, 2002. Born in 1920, he graduated from Townes & Harris and City College of New York. Possessing a quick wit and the ability to speak and write extemporaneously, he found his way by becoming a wellknown public relations counselor; pioneering in assisting various major corporations achieve their investment and financial objectives. For Hal, each day was a celebration of life; he had no yesterdays, only today. Hal was loved by everyone and will be sorely missed. He was the beloved husband of the late Jacqueline and devoted father of the late Todd Antin. He is survived by his son, Mark; and daughter, Dana; two brothers, Ira Antin, DMV and Sanford Antin, MD. Funeral services 9:45 AM Friday, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Perception and Memory In a Fourth Dimension
description: Over her 20-year career Roni Horn has produced many kinds of art: Minimalist sculpture, intricate collages on paper, geometric sculptures embodying poems by Emily Dickinson, landscape photography, limited edition books about travel to Iceland, videos and autobiographical prose. Other than elegant economy and formidable intelligence, no singular, visually conspicuous style links these endeavors. Though highly esteemed in certain circles, she remains, even for those who know her name, an elusive quantity.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Strong Holiday For Electronics
description: Holiday sales at Electronics Boutique, a chain of video game specialty stores, surged 57 percent, to $416.4 million from $264.6 million a year earlier. The company, based in West Chester, Pa., attributed the jump, which included a 40 percent increase at stores open at least a year, to strong demand for two consoles, Nintendo's GameCube and Microsoft's Xbox, as well as the continued dominance of Sony's PlayStation2. Electronics Boutique sold nearly 4 games with each Xbox, nearly 5 games with each GameCube and 13 games with each PlayStation2, which has sold eight million units in North America in 14 months. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: When Jews Found a Place Among European Artists
description: Except for Camille Pissarro and maybe Max Liebermann, you may not have heard of most of the artists in ''The Emergence of Jewish Artists in 19th-Century Europe'' at the Jewish Museum.

title: Hevesi and Other Candidates Are Fined by Finance Board
description: The city's Campaign Finance Board yesterday fined Alan G. Hevesi, the former city comptroller, along with several other candidates in last year's elections for accepting improper campaign contributions.

title: Our Wretched States
description: Many Americans are surprised at the speed with which assurances that immense federal surpluses were here to stay gave way to the reality of deficits. Some of us, however, aren't surprised; we're simply following a trail blazed in places like Richmond and Austin. In the 1990's most states had Republican governors; and they applied the same strategy -- using what-me-worry forecasts and bogus accounting to justify tax cuts for the affluent -- that the Bush administration applied at a national level in 2001. In both cases the consequences were predictable.

title: How Iroquois Artists Turned Trespassers Into Tourists
description: Faced with continuing loss of their lands and the decline of hunting and fishing in the 19th century, the Iroquois nations of New York State and Canada came up with a successful survival strategy: they would sell tourists the fancy beadwork they had long done for themselves.

title: NEVADA SITE URGED FOR NUCLEAR DUMP
description: After spending 14 years and $4.5 billion on studies, the Energy Department said today that it would recommend that Yucca Mountain, a barren volcanic structure about 90 miles from Las Vegas, be used to bury thousands of tons of highly radioactive nuclear waste from power plants and nuclear weapons factories.

title: Canadian Group Seeks To Acquire Agency
description: Mad Dogs and Englishmen in New York is in discussions to be acquired by the Wolf Group in Toronto, which also has United States offices in Buffalo, Cleveland, New York City and Rochester.

title: The Siblings Mann, Gloomy In the Shadow of a Legend
description: It could not have been easy to be a child of a cultural monument as towering as the German writer Thomas Mann. The filmmakers Andrea Weiss and Wieland Speck say as much in their documentary ''Escape to Life: The Erika and Klaus Mann Story,'' which chronicles the peripatetic lives of Mann's two oldest (of six) children. Forced to flee Germany in 1933 and live the rest of their lives as exiles, Erika and Klaus toiled under an immense godlike shadow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARR, ALFRED ANDREW
description: PARR-Alfred Andrew, 99. Died peacefully at his home in Cairo, NY on Wednesday, January 9th, 2002. Born in Richmond Hill, Queens, he left school at 15 to work in the New York offices of US Steel. He then became a steelworker in the mill at Pittsburgh. Returning to New York, he began working as a bookkeeper, eventually becoming resident manager at The Dakota in the 1950s. Everyone who met him was charmed by his good nature and personal kindness.

description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the efforts of MTV Networks and Showtime to create a cable television channel aimed at gay viewers misstated the affiliation of Gene Falk, an executive who said it could be on the air within a year. He is the senior vice president for the digital media group at Showtime, not MTV Networks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUSIN, MICHELLE
description: COUSIN-Michelle. Gifted writer and inspirational NYU Professor. Rest in peace. For graveside service information call: 212-239-1662.

title: The Irradiation of Mail Can Also Zap the Contents
description: Attempts by the United States Postal Service to make mail safer by zapping it with radiation have hit a snag: the process tends to destroy computer chips and to damage other delicate items including food, pharmaceuticals, clothing, contact lenses -- and even the paper mail itself.

title: Scientists Paint Universe As a Vast Sea of Green
description: The universe, by definition, holds everything imaginable and then some. It has stars and planets and moons, life here and possibly there, red giants and white dwarfs and -- the ogres to top all ogres -- big, bad black holes.

description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 3,117 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Despite Signs of Recovery, Greenspan Says Economy Remains at Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the economy is not yet out of danger, injecting a note of caution into a growing consensus among economists and investors that recovery from the recession is imminent.

title: Is the Camera a Reliable Witness?
description: PHOTOGRAPHY walks many fine lines. Democratic and prolific by nature, it undermines old genius-at-work, precious-object ideas of art. At the same time, it keeps laying claim to art's special powers and perks. One of its traditional selling points is objectivity. Yet it's a medium of calculation: of measured light and chosen angles, of zooming in and editing out. These opposites define its tensions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFFERTS, ALAN
description: LEFFERTS-Alan. Beloved husband of Ann. Devoted father of Kenneth and Sondra Lefferts, Gary and Susan Lefferts, Kathy and Ray Cappiello and Rosina Mandato. Cherished grandfather of Evan, Rose, Scott, Russell, Joy, Marshall, Beth, Brad, Christopher, Michelle, Jim and Jessica. Loving great-grandfather of Samantha. Services today 10:30 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: A Morgan Stanley Victory In Dispute on Bond Funds
description: Securities regulators have lost the latest round in a legal battle with Morgan Stanley over tactics that its brokers and managers used to sell three bond funds in the early 1990's. But the regulators are not giving up the fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, WILLIAM N.
description: SMITH-William N. On Thursday, December 27, 2001 of Exeter, NH, formerly of Manhattan. Beloved father of Abigail V. Smith of Newton, MA. Regional Director of Major Gifts for Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, NH. Funeral held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan, Monday, January 21, 2002 at 11AM. Private burial was held in Mt. Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, MA. Donations to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, C/O Dr. Posner, 44 Binney Street, Boston, MA. 02115.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Judge Voids Weapons Ban
description: A Hamilton County judge ruled that the state's ban on concealed weapons violated the state constitution, and he ordered police officers to stop enforcing the ban. A private investigator and three other plaintiffs, who said they needed guns to protect themselves, filed suit in 2000, asserting that the state constitution allowed citizens to bear arms whether or not they are concealed. Cincinnati, the county and the state said they would appeal. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the effect of the recession on Americans' lives gave an outdated name for a polling firm whose chairman, Humphrey Taylor, said 17 percent of the population felt directly affected. It is the Harris Poll, owned and produced by Harris Interactive, not Louis Harris & Associates.

title: Bold New Look, Tired Old Metaphor
description: Yes, I love it, it's just too wonderful; now let's get down to business. Apple's new iMac is indeed unique. It is the first desktop computer of the new millennium to trigger a gale-force hype storm.

title: 7 Marines From Across U.S.: Profiles From a Fatal Mission
description: Their hometowns are spread across the nation, from the suburbs of New York City to Montgomery, Ala., to the wheat farming country of Washington. Some had joined the Marine Corps because it was a family tradition, while some merely wanted a way to go to college and see the world.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Money For Governor's Race
description: Though he canceled fund-raisers after the Sept. 11 attacks, Gov. Jeb Bush raised more than $751,000 for his re-election campaign in the last three months of 2001. Campaign reports show that Mr. Bush, a Republican, has raised more than $2 million in cash since last summer. Former Attorney General Janet Reno, a Democrat, raised more than $455,000 in the last quarter to bring her total to $557,285. Another Democrat, the Tampa lawyer Bill McBride, has raised $744,906 in cash since entering the race. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Lawyer Seeks to Contest Rule Allowing Eavesdropping on Inmates
description: The lawyer for a terrorist convicted in the embassy bombings trial in Manhattan is seeking to challenge the constitutionality of the Bush administration's new rules allowing prison officials to eavesdrop on inmates' conversations with their lawyers, court papers show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sears Bias Suit Settled
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer yesterday announced a $250,000 settlement with Sears Roebuck & Company, which was accused of religious discrimination against employees. He said part of the money was used to finance a nationwide study of states' workplace discrimination laws. Sears was charged with not hiring an Orthodox Jew who refused to work on Saturdays and dismissing a Seventh-day Adventist who also refused to work on Saturdays. The study was jointly published by the American Law Institute and the American Bar Association. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Terror Aid Offices To Open
description: Two offices to help families hurt by the terrorist attack apply for federal aid will open in New Jersey next Friday, officials in Washington announced yesterday. The offices for the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund will be at 101 Hudson Street in Jersey City, near the Exchange Place PATH station, and 399 Thornall Street, near the Metropark New Jersey Transit station, in Edison.

title: High Court to Rule on Challenge to Death Penalties in 9 States
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide a potentially far-reaching challenge to the constitutionality of the death penalty laws in nine states where judges rather than juries make the crucial finding of whether a murder was committed with sufficiently "aggravating circumstances" to warrant a sentence of death.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Tobacco Case Fees Dispute
description: The lawyer who represented Maryland in its lawsuit against tobacco companies offered to cut the legal fees he was seeking to about $250 million from $1 billion. The lawyer, Peter G. Angelos, who owns the Baltimore Orioles, argued the case that led to a settlement by the tobacco companies, which was expected to total some $4 billion. Mr. Angelos's original contract with the state stipulated fees totaling 25 percent of the settlement. The state legislature halved that amount, but Mr. Angelos sued. His latest offer came as a national arbitration board prepared to award him $132 million in total fees. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOYAN, ANNA M.
description: SLOYAN-Anna M. Died aged 100 at her home in Hamilton Square, NJ, January 7. She was predeceased by her husbands David Scheideler and Jerome Sloyan, whose children Virginia Sloyan, Sister Stephanie Sloyan, R.S.M. and the Reverend Gerard Sloyan who found in her a loving mother. She was also predeceased by her brother Charles Cullen and her sister Laura O'Rourke and Sister Thomas Aquinas Sloyan, O.P. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Gregory the Great Church, Hamilton Square, January 11 at 11 AM.

He is Caetano Veloso, not Velosa.

title: Sports of The Times; Skating Is Classy, But Tributes Are Not
description: THE fans voted with their arms, heaving identical soft yellow objects toward the ice. Michelle Kwan received the highest count, easily more than 100, and right afterward she also received the best marks for the short program.
