title: New Le Monde for a New France
description: If newspapers are a measure of the people who read them, the changes in format and content announced today by the daily Le Monde may signal how the nation where it holds an established place is evolving.

title: Bush Meets India's Envoy; Fears of Pakistan War Deepen
description: President Bush met with a senior Indian official at the White House today as members of the national security staff reviewed a stream of intelligence reports suggesting that tensions along the Pakistan border are rising, and that the chances of a military conflict have grown considerably.

title: Teachers' Union to Move Downtown, a Shift Mayor Says 'Can't Hurt' Contract
description: The president of the union representing New York City teachers said yesterday that the union would spend up to $75 million to move into two buildings near ground zero because it was desperate for more space and wanted to bolster the suffering downtown economy.

title: Walter Waggoner, 84, Times Reporter and Editor
description: Walter H. Waggoner, a reporter, correspondent and editor at The New York Times for 41 years, died Wednesday in Chapel Hill, N.C. A former resident of Montclair, N.J., he was 84 and lived in Pittsboro, N.C.

title: Bracing for Soft Sales, Carmakers Stake Out High Ground
description: WITH economic gloom casting shadows like winter snow clouds over the North American International Auto Show, the luxury market appears to be giving off a glimmer of light.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: State Plans Overhaul Of Welfare Program
description: Welfare recipients face changes in the state's welfare-to-work program in coming months, after recommendations from an advisory panel. State audits from last year found the program helped a minimal number of people escape poverty and placed relatively few in programs that led to employment. The changes will clarify policies for applying for loans and extending cash assistance. They will also allow recipients to appeal before losing benefits and ensure that people who miss mandatory training sessions because of a disability are not penalized. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Opposition Supporters Sentenced
description: A judge sentenced 14 supporters of the opposition party, Renamo, to prison terms ranging from three months to eight years for their roles in riots that killed at least 41 people, the state news agency reported. The riots erupted in November 2000 after Renamo demonstrators clashed with the police in several cities in the worst political violence since the civil war ended in 1992. In addition to the riot deaths, at least 80 people, mainly opposition supporters arrested during and after those confrontations, suffocated in desperately overcrowded jail cells. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHNER, HANNAH
description: FLEISCHNER-Hannah, 87, of Boca Raton, passed away January 7, 2002. She is survived by her stepchildren, Lenny (Jayne) and Alice (Harvey) Kerner, five step-grandchildren and eight step-greatgrandchildren. Graveside service Sunday, 11:00 AM, Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, NY. Call Eternal Light, 1-800-226-9905.

title: Mrs. Dole Crisscrossing N. Carolina In Senate Bid
description: It is a long way from the grandeur of presidential politics to the grand opening of the Microtel Inn and Suites in Robbinsville, N.C., population 747. But that is where Elizabeth Dole, now a candidate for the United States Senate in North Carolina, found herself this week.

Two cases in point, both on DVD, are ''Alberto Giacometti,'' with two documentaries about this existentialist sculptor, and ''Mlis the Magician,'' about the famed illusionist, director and entrepreneur who took fiction to the screen at the turn of the 20th century. description: Lynette Harrison was named publisher at InStyle magazine, New York, part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. She succeeds Louis Cona, who became publisher at Vanity Fair, New York, part of the Condé Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications. Also at InStyle, Kevin M. Belden was named associate publisher marketing, succeeding Hope Hening, who also left for Vanity Fair, as associate publisher.

description: Todd Eldredge did not follow the wild jumps and extreme leaps of the video-game generation surrounding him by pulling off a quadruple jump tonight.

title: Wallace Gray, 74, Literature Teacher at Columbia
description: Wallace Gray, a professor emeritus of English and comparative literature and a favorite teacher for generations of Columbia College students, died on Dec. 21 in Manhattan. He was 74 and lived in Morningside Heights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, TOM
description: SHEA-Tom. Died yesterday morning after a valiant struggle with cancer. Throughout his illness he maintained the same zest and zeal that characterized his life-he lived abundantly. A member of the New York and New Jersey Bar Associations, Tom worked in transportation law and taught courses in law. More recently, he worked in residential real estate in New Jersey. His wife Mary, and children Joe, Todd, Kristin, and Elizabeth will be hosting a celebration of Tom's life this Saturday at 11 AM at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scotch Plains, NJ. He is also survived by 3 sisters: Patricia Draddy, Betsy McDermott, and Marijean Sommer. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Atlantic Home Care and Hospice, 33 Bleeker Street, Milburn, New Jersey 07041.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Nuclear Test Compensation
description: Checks for $150,000 have begun arriving for people who became sick after working on Amchitka Island during testing of nuclear weapons during the cold war. Many of the 3,000 Energy Department workers at the facility from 1963 to 1974 could be eligible for the compensation for cancers from radiation, beryllium disease and silicosis, a lung disease. Officials have contacted 1,400 former Amchitka workers or their families. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rates Unchanged
description: The Bank of England left interest rates unchanged at 4 percent. The decision to hold the benchmark rate steady was widely expected by economists, who say Britain may narrowly avoid recession because consumers are still spending. Housing prices and retail sales have remained robust, despite a continuing slump in manufacturing. Bonds gained because investors have not ruled out another rate cut by Britain's central bank, which cut interest rates seven times last year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAKE, JOHN. NATHANIEL ELDRIDGE
description: WAKE-John. Nathaniel Eldridge, Glynnis Eldridge, Jean McGavin and Daniel Eldridge are greatly saddened by the untimely death of our teacher and friend. Science class will never be the same again. Observance today 2-5 and 7-9 at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., 212-674-8055.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANCE, WILLIAM B.

description: On his first day on the job, Michael R. Bloomberg ambled away from his security detail into a protest to shake hands with those who came to yell at him.

description: Lehman Brothers Holdings said yesterday that it had raised $1.6 billion for a fund to buy real estate in the United States and Europe, tapping investor appetite for assets that have outperformed the stock market.

description: While it is still too soon to know what type of tone Michael R. Bloomberg will ultimately set at City Hall, early indications are that it will be quite different from his predecessor's. The mayor has shaken hands with protesters, and his administration is weighing whether to reopen City Hall Park to the public.

title: WATCHING MOVIES WITH: Wes Anderson; From Centimes, A Wealth Of Ideas
description: ''WHY did I pick this movie?'' Wes Anderson asked himself, slouching against the wall in the glass-lined lobby of an office building on the Paramount Pictures lot, a sultry black-and-white portrait of Dorothy Lamour peering over his shoulder. ''I don't actually have an answer for that.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLYNN, ROBERT B.
description: GLYNN-Robert B., The editors and staff of Commentary mourn the death of their stalwart and much loved friend, and will ever miss his erudite, magnanimous, mirthful spirit. Our hearts go out to Savannah and his family. Neal Kozodoy, Editor Norman Podhoretz, Editor-at-Large

description: Russia today strongly criticized Bush administration plans to store rather than destroy decommissioned nuclear warheads, suggesting that such plans would undermine the credibility of any new arms control accord aimed at eliminating thousands of nuclear weapons.

title: Ambitions, Auditions And Egos Laid Bare
description: When Daisy Eagan was 11, she won a Tony Award for her performance in ''The Secret Garden.'' There she is in a clip from 1991, weeping as Audrey Hepburn hands her the award. And here she is today, one of a dozen unknown actors in Bravo's new reality series, ''The It Factor,'' waiting to audition for a cookie commercial. The would-be cookie eaters have been told to prepare a series of emotional reactions, to act tentative, shy, cynical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUEL, CINDY ANN
description: DEUEL-Cindy Ann, 28. Of Brooklyn, died September 11 in WTC. Survived by her loving husband Victorio Tomas Pons, brothers Richard and Joseph, father Joseph & mother Patricia Kocian. Burial will take place 10 A.M. on Saturday at Cedar Lawn Cemetery in Paterson, NJ.

title: U.S. Officials Ending Monitoring of Teamsters' Finances
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced yesterday that federal officials were ending an unusual arrangement in which the government monitored the union's finances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERS, ELIZABETH UDELLA DUDLEY
description: WATERS-Elizabeth Udella Dudley. Age 89 and a longtime resident of Southbury, CT, died on Jan. 5, 2002, at Danbury Hospital. A ninth-generation descendant of William Dudley and Jane Lutman, who settled in 1639 in Guilford, CT, Mrs. Waters is survived by her brother, George Allen Dudley of Rensselaerville and NY, NY; her three children: Jane Allen Waters and Martha Merrill Waters, both of Dutchess County, New York, and Dudley Franklin Waters of Summerville, South Carolina; plus numerous grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

title: Argentina Is Still Shaky Despite Currency Measures
description: The Argentine government's devaluation of the peso by nearly 30 percent on Sunday night was supposed to bring an end to an emergency bank holiday here, which began before Christmas. But after four business days, banks and foreign exchange houses still have not resumed normal operations, and it is not clear when they will. Irritation, uncertainty and nervousness continued unchecked.

title: CALPINE RECEIVES $1 BILLION LINE OF CREDIT
description: Calpine, a power plant developer, said yesterday that it had been granted $1 billion in unsecured credit, increasing its finances for the third time since its credit rating was cut a month ago. The one-year credit line will let Calpine borrow $350 million and provide $1 billion in guaranteed backing from banks, the company said. Calpine, which has a $400 million credit facility, now has access to $750 million for borrowing and $1.4 billion in letters of credit. Moody's Investors Service cut Calpine's credit grade to junk level last month, citing its debt burden. Calpine, which owns or is building power plants in 29 states, Canada and Britain, then sold $1 billion in convertible notes to pay back debt. It sold $200 million more in notes this month.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS AND BONUSES
description: Burlington Industries, the textile maker, said yesterday that it would lay off 4,000 workers as part of a reorganization and asked a judge hearing its bankruptcy proceedings to approve up to $13 million in executive bonuses to retain top employees. The company, which filed for Chapter 11 protection on Nov. 20, said in court papers that it wanted to pay the bonuses to 71 executives it ''simply cannot afford to lose'' to rivals. Burlington also asked for approval of a $1 million bonus payment to Douglas J. McGregor, the chief operating officer. A judge will consider the bonus plan at a hearing next week. The company said yesterday that it would close five factories and lay off 2,800 workers in North Carolina, Mississippi and Virginia, reduce operations at another North Carolina plant and lay off 1,200 workers in Mexico.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Talks With U.S. On Immigration
description: Foreign Minister Jorge G. Castaeda began a two-day visit to Washington aimed at reviving negotiations with the Bush administration on immigration reforms. Before the Sept. 11 attacks, Mexico and the United States had committed themselves to forging agreements that would, among other things, expand the number of Mexican workers allowed into the United States. Mexican officials are also urging the United States to give legal status to some three million undocumented Mexicans. With formal talks resuming, Mexican officials said they hoped to reach agreements by the end of this year. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

Saritha Rai (NYT)

Cummings bestowed on the editor and poet Louis Untermeyer. Untermeyer's influential 1919 anthology, ''Modern American Poetry,'' omitted some of the great poetic innovators of the time, but included three poems by Untermeyer himself and one by his wife. Cummings gutted him in four lines.

It was the original judge in the case, Frederic Block of United States District Court, not a panel of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals.

title: China's Weaponry Detailed
description: China's nuclear ballistic missile force will include between 75 and 100 warheads by 2015, but the nuclear arsenal will remain far smaller than those fielded by the United States and Russia, according to a new government intelligence report.

title: Two Debuts, Planned and Unplanned
description: It's often said of ''The Barber of Seville'' that the first act is better than the second. It was striking, then, that the reverse was true at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night. The first act seemed soggy, like a half-fallen souffl; in the second, some of the principals improved, and the performance had a rousing, satisfying finish.

title: Pataki Seeks Fast Approval Of Health Plan
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is calling for a wide array of new health care spending, program cuts and taxes, from money for doctors' malpractice bills, to lower payments to pharmacists, to a higher cigarette tax. He is asking the Assembly and State Senate to approve it Monday, though they have yet to see a complete proposal.

title: Parties Weigh Political Price Of Enron's Fall
description: Concern that the escalating Enron inquiry could ensnare the White House has rattled some Republicans in Congress, who said they were not yet willing to defend the administration while so many facts were still unknown but who warned Democrats against trying to use the case for partisan advantage.

title: PRESIDENT TO RETIRE FROM UNITED TECHNOLOGIES
description: The president and chief operating officer of the United Technologies Corporation, Karl J. Krapek, will retire at the end of this month after 20 years with the company. Mr. Krapek, 53, ran the Otis elevator and Carrier air-conditioner businesses, along with the Pratt & Whitney jet engine unit, before being named to the top posts in 1999. He has been mentioned by analysts as a possible successor to the chief executive at Honeywell International, Lawrence A. Bossidy, who is expected to retire this year.

title: FORD PLANS TO CUT 35,000 EMPLOYEES AND SHUT 5 PLANTS
description: The Ford Motor Company announced its most sweeping cutbacks in two decades today, terminating 35,000 workers, closing five plants and dropping four models.

title: DaimlerChrysler Speeds Sale Of Stake in Software Venture
description: DaimlerChrysler has forced Deutsche Telekom to buy out its interest in Debis Systemhaus, a software joint venture, for 4.6 billion euros ($4.1 billion) in cash, two years earlier than planned.

description: MERSON-Robert. 4/19/45-1/12/97 Its been 5 years since you left us. We miss you and love you more than ever. Your smile & laughter will always be with us. Love, Miriam & Larry Ann & Ardie All your nieces, nephews & ''greats'

title: Americans on the Watch
National Briefing | West: California: Land-Use Rules For Malibu
description: The California Coastal Commission has adopted a draft land-use plan for Malibu in a move for better control over development along that city's 27 miles of coastline. The plan declares more than half the city an environmentally sensitive habitat and provides details on where development should occur. It also calls for opening several access ways from roadways and beaches that homeowners have blocked. City officials criticized the plan as too restrictive in some areas and too broad in others. The commission and city have until Sept. 15 to work out a final plan. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

description: St. John's expects a boost today when it plays at Providence. Kyle Cuffe, the 6-foot-8 forward who is the Red Storm's top offensive player taller than 6-6, has been cleared to play after missing the past four games with an eye injury.

title: Acknowledging That God Is Not Limited to Christians
description: Dr. Joseph C. Hough Jr., the president of Union Theological Seminary in New York, has been calling in recent speeches for Christians to adopt a new theological approach to other faiths, one that goes considerably beyond simple tolerance, as a response to Americans' growing awareness of religious diversity in the United States and the world. In e-mail and telephone interviews with Gustav Niebuhr, he said he was speaking for himself and not the seminary.

description: A Florida jail inmate told the authorities that there was a plot to bomb Gov. Jeb Bush today, but law enforcement officials said none of the inmate's information had been substantiated.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said that cuts to the city's budget would begin with his office, but apparently he was not referring to salaries for his top aides. Although the mayor will only be earning a dollar a year for his public service, his top advisers will receive the same salary that Rudolph W. Giuliani's advisers did at the end of their term.

description: Seton Hall's 5-foot-8 point guard played like a giant. Its busy 2-3 zone defense, a switch from its usual man-to-man, worked wonders. The Rutgers reserves scored just 8 points in 51 minutes of playing time, and their coach said, ''You can't win many games like that.''

description: The Bridgestone Corporation has settled a lawsuit related to its recalled tires, avoiding what would have been the company's first trial in the United States involving the tires.

description: There are no hard and fast rules governing how soon an accounting firm can destroy documents related to an audit, but the papers are generally maintained for years, accountants said yesterday after the disclosure that Arthur Andersen had destroyed Enron documents.

description: It seems like only yesterday that John O. Bennett, New Jersey's departing acting governor, placed one hand on a Bible, the other in the air, and was sworn in as the state's chief executive.

description: Terrorist suspects arrested last month in Singapore were linked with Al Qaeda and planned bomb attacks against Western embassies, American naval vessels, American companies and a shuttle bus carrying American troops, the Singapore government said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Steel Maker Raises Prices
description: Europe's biggest steel maker, Usinor, said it would raise prices by as much as 10 percent, and Thyssen Krupp, a German rival, said it might follow. The increase is the first sign of a recovery in the steel industry after prices fell to their lowest in 20 years. Usinor said it was able to raise prices because it was experiencing increasing demand. Some analysts viewed that as a sign that world economies might be recovering, although they cautioned that the surge in demand might be a result of a concerted effort by steel producers to reduce output as a way to drive up prices. Last month, the governments of about 40 countries agreed to reduce steel output over 10 years by almost 100 million tons. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

This often helps the defenders uncover a crucial ruff. Unfortunately for Lightner, the first time he used it a disaster ensued and his partner, Ely Culbertson, indignantly refused to have anything more to do with this sensible suggestion.

description: The general prosecutor's office released Vyacheslav Sheremet, an executive of Sibur, a gas-processing company that is partly owned by the Russian gas monopoly Gazprom, Russian news agencies reported. Mr. Sheremet was one of three executives taken into custody this week amid an investigation into the disappearance of Sibur assets valued at $85 million. title: With Suicide, an Admiral Keeps Command Until the End
description: Throughout the fall and winter, Chester Nimitz's daughters kept asking him if he was certain that he was ready to carry out his plan and end his life.

title: The Crown Heights Saga, Cont'd.
description: When a federal jury convicted Lemrick Nelson Jr. and another defendant, Charles Price, of civil rights violations for their roles in the 1991 slaying of a Hasidic Jew, Yankel Rosenbaum, during a night of mob violence in Brooklyn's Crown Heights neighborhood, it seemed as if a long ordeal for New York City and those involved in the wrenching case was finally over. But alas, it turns out that sense of closure was premature. A three-judge appellate panel has now ruled that the verdict was rendered by a jury whose composition was improperly manipulated by the trial judge, David Trager of the United States District Court in Brooklyn. Judge Trager, the panel said, conducted a prejudicial ''race-and-religion-based reshuffling'' with the aim of achieving a jury mix that would ease public acceptance of the trial's result. By a 2-to-1 vote, the appellate panel found the denial of fair trial rights sufficiently egregious to order a new trial.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Corsica: Ex-Governor Sentenced For Arson
description: A former governor of Corsica, the French-ruled Mediterranean island, has been sentenced to a year in jail for ordering arson attacks on illegally constructed beach-side restaurants near the capital, Ajaccio. The governor, Bernard Bonnet, said Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France ordered the undercover police to set fire to the restaurants in 1999. But no clear link to Mr. Jospin emerged during the trial. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Moves by Zimbabwe's President Are Criticized in South Africa
description: South African officials today denounced Zimbabwe's efforts to restrict and intimidate supporters of its leading opposition party as Zimbabwe braced for its most fiercely contested presidential election.

title: Australia Gold Miner Is Still Up for Grabs
description: One of the most drawn-out takeover battles in the global mining industry was extended further today after the board of AngloGold gave shareholders of Normandy Mining, Australia's largest gold producer, another week to consider its plan.

title: Kmart's Credit Rating Cut For Second Time in a Month
description: Adding to Kmart's woes, Moody's Investors Service downgraded the company's credit rating yesterday for the second time in less than a month, citing concerns about the operating performance of the company and uncertainty about the success of its business strategy.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Carrier Halves Investment
description: The J-Phone Company, the operator of Japan's third-largest cellular phone system, will invest slightly more than 300 billion yen ($2.3 billion) in its network in the year ending in March, about half its original target. A subsidiary of the Vodafone Group, J-Phone has been hit by slowing demand for cellular phones as consumers hang onto their older models longer. J-Phone, which added 2.15 million new users in 2001, took almost one-quarter of the Japanese market. It will roll out its third-generation phone network in June. NTT DoCoMo, a rival, unveiled its version last October, but sales of the new phones, which cost up to $500, have been slow. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: MetroStars Acquire Serna and Balboa
description: Moving swiftly after Major League's Soccer decision to fold its two Florida franchises, the MetroStars acquired the Colombian striker Diego Serna and the American defender Marcelo Balboa yesterday.

title: Mari Kajiwara, 50, Dancer Known for Pure Modern Style
description: Mari Kajiwara, an American modern dancer of stunning quality who mesmerized audiences as a leading member of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the Ohad Naharin Dance Company and the Batsheva Dance Company of Israel, died on Dec. 25 in Tel Aviv. She was 50 and had lived in Tel Aviv since Mr. Naharin, her husband and an internationally known choreographer, became artistic director of Batsheva 12 years ago.

title: Utah's Democrats Spot Opportunity in House Republican's Retirement
description: This week's unexpected announcement that Representative James V. Hansen, Utah's senior House member, is retiring after 11 terms in Congress has scrambled the political landscape of the state, giving Democrats, an endangered species here, a glimmer of hope for revival.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Calling With Style
description: Nokia said it would introduce a line of handcrafted mobile phones, some encased in precious stones, as it seeks to enter the luxury goods market. The move would be the latest by Nokia to find new avenues of growth as demand for traditional handsets slows. Nokia in recent years has introduced so-called lifestyle phones, designed for different activities, on the premise that people would want to use one phone while exercising, for example, and another for a night out on the town. It has also introduced a line of interchangeable casings that make it easy to match the color of a phone to an outfit. Vertu, a Nokia unit, will begin making the new phones this month. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Equality For Women
description: President Fernando Henrique Cardoso signed a new civil code that makes women equal to men in the eyes of the law. Among the things the new code eliminates is the concept of paternal power, which gives fathers unlimited legal rights to make decisions on behalf of their families. It also abolishes a law that allows a husband to annul his marriage if he learns that his wife was not a virgin when they married. Aiming at full equality, the legislation also gives divorced men the right to seek alimony from their former wives. The new code, which has 2,046 articles and replaces legislation dating to 1916, will take effect early next year. Mery Galanternick (NYT)

title: What's Fishy About the Hart Building?
description: The Hart Senate Office Building is about to reopen after many weeks of fumigation because of the anthrax spores in a letter to Senator Tom Daschle. As the senatorial occupants who have suffered in temporary quarters prepare to move back in, I find myself reflecting on the conflict 23 years ago that almost prevented their palatial domain from being built at all. The Hart project was saved by a tiny fish called the snail darter.

title: Corrections

Lay, to the 2000 Senate campaign of John Ashcroft, now the attorney general. It was $54,999, not $54,499 or $57,499.

title: Carl Wolz, 69; Dance Scholar Who Bridged East and West
description: Carl Wolz, a teacher, scholar and dance festival organizer who sought to promote cooperation between Asian and Western dance communities, died on Jan. 2. He was 69 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Museum Does Its Part
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Says Iran Gave Terrorists U.S. Arms
description: Iran purchased American-built Stinger antiaircraft missiles in Afghanistan in 1994 and turned them over to a Lebanese-based terrorist organization, but the missiles proved to be defective, according to United States intelligence reports.

title: PRESIDENT OF UPN NETWORK IS LEAVING VIACOM
description: The UPN television network president, Dean Valentine, is leaving Viacom Inc. a month after UPN was folded into the larger CBS Television unit run by Leslie Moonves. The departure takes effect immediately, Viacom said. In early September, Mr. Valentine sued UPN, contending that the network owed him as much as $22 million under an employment contract he signed four years ago. Viacom said in December that it would merge the money-losing UPN with its bigger CBS unit this month to reduce costs and increase advertising sales. Mr. Moonves said that he met with UPN executives a week ago and it was too early to know what changes would be made.

title: For Big History, The Past Begins At the Beginning
description: Female tavern owners in early 20th-century Bolivia. A Polish periodical for Jewish children. A medieval Catalan women's monastery. These were the typical fare at the American Historical Association's annual convention Jan. 4 to 6. That's no surprise. Over the last few decades, historical research has become more and more specialized. As Gale Stokes, a Rice University historian who was at the convention, put it, ''There's a sense of grinding the nuts into an ever finer powder.''

title: What Is America's Place In the World Now?
description: Here's a test:

title: Weather Makes the Man
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Deflation And Less Lending
description: Wholesale prices fell and banks cut lending in December as deflation picked up steam. Wholesale prices, which strip out volatility caused by exchange-rate fluctuations, slipped 1.4 percent from a year ago, the 14th consecutive decline, the Bank of Japan said. Prices of steel, machinery and other industrial goods fell the fastest. The central bank also said that bank lending contracted 4.3 percent in December, completing the fifth consecutive annual decline. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONKIN, DR. LAWRENCE S.
description: SONKIN-Dr. Lawrence S. On January 9, 2002 at New York Hospital. Beloved husband of Patricia. Cherished uncle of Mitchell, Leslie, Ellen and great-uncle of Rachel, Matthew, Julie and Cliff. Services private.

title: UBS Wins The Bidding For Enron's Trading Unit
description: The Enron Corporation announced yesterday that UBS Warburg had won the bidding for its energy-trading business, which was the crown jewel of Enron and was responsible for about 90 percent of its revenue.

title: German Right Backs Bavarian to Run Against Schrder
description: The populist and experienced governor of Bavaria, Edmund Stoiber, will lead the conservative opposition parties in their effort to defeat Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's Social Democrats in elections in September.

title: Japan's Premier Tours Asia to Promote Trade Bloc
description: His economy in distress, his banks teetering and his currency sinking, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan has embarked on a whirlwind tour of Southeast Asia to promote a vision of regional economic cooperation and trade liberalization -- only to find that his country is now seen as more hindrance than help.

title: Gem Courier Robbed In 7th Queens Theft
description: A jewelry courier carrying about $1.5 million in gems was robbed at gunpoint in Queens on Thursday. The police said yesterday that they believe the crime and six similar thefts in the last two months were the work of one South American gang.

title: DVD Counterfeiting Arrests Called Largest Case of Its Kind
description: A man and his uncle, accused of running a pirating operation out of a store in Brooklyn, were indicted yesterday in the biggest DVD-counterfeiting case in the five-year history of the format in the United States, federal officials said.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Wrigley Plans Meet Landmark Standards
description: The Landmarks Preservation Council of Illinois said that most of the Tribune Company's plans to renovate Wrigley Field, home of the Chicago Cubs, meet historic-preservation standards. Renovations, which would increase bleacher seating, alter entrances and add box seats behind home plate, were proposed last year by the company, which owns the Cubs. Negotiations with the City of Chicago began when officials questioned the plan and asked that the ballpark, which was built in 1914, be given landmark status, which would give the city a say in remodeling. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: When A Gift Isn't Right
description: The new year brought some happy news for Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey. On Jan. 3, the United States attorney in Manhattan, Mary Jo White, announced that she was closing her investigation into allegations that the senator had illegally accepted tens of thousands of dollars in cash and gifts from David Chang, a businessman. Without offering any explanation for her decision not to seek a criminal indictment, Ms. White referred the matter to the Senate Ethics Committee.

title: Nuclear Weapons Subtraction
description: The Bush administration has finally come to appreciate the national security dividends paid by a relatively inexpensive set of programs designed to help Russia dismantle its cold-war nuclear weapons and secure its bomb-grade plutonium and uranium from theft or sale to rogue nations or terrorists. With the threat of nuclear terrorism growing and Moscow now proposing to remove thousands more warheads from its nuclear arsenal, these programs -- known collectively as Nunn-Lugar for the two legislators who helped originate them a decade ago, Senators Sam Nunn and Richard Lugar -- are more urgently needed than ever.

title: Video Captures Sept. 11 Horror In Raw Replay
description: The videotape is raw.

title: Beware The Price Of a Slice
description: It was too early to pop open the Champagne, but ordering a celebratory slice at the local pizza parlor did not seem out of line. Giddiness over imminent good times faded, however, when a colleague pointed out that the price of pizza suggested that the subway and bus fare would be raised before too long.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS 3.4%. New doubts over Russia's commitment to OPEC's planned supply cutbacks pushed the price of crude oil down. The February contract fell 70 cents, to $19.68 a barrel.

title: Who Should Run the Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Moss Is Still The X Factor For the Jets
description: THE Jets will either play the final game of a topsy-turvy season tonight in Oakland or continue a magic playoff ride next week in Pittsburgh.

title: Argentine Peso Drops Sharply After Link to the Dollar Ends
description: Freed from its link to the American dollar for the first time in nearly 11 years, the Argentine peso dropped sharply on foreign exchange markets here today as the government ended an emergency bank holiday that had halted normal economic activity since before Christmas.

title: Gaza Picks Up Pieces Left by Israeli Bulldozers
description: The runway of Gaza International Airport was blocked with piles of broken concrete today after Israeli tanks and bulldozers rumbled into the area overnight, digging trenches in the tarmac and ensuring that the airport, long a symbol of Palestinian aspirations for statehood, would be out of commission for some time to come.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Problem At Nuclear Plant
description: The nuclear power station in Temelin, just 35 miles from the Austrian border, had to be shut down yesterday because of a generator problem just hours after it was powered up for tests. The plant was first switched on in October 2000 but its commercial use has been delayed by negotiations with Austria and by technical problems. Austria has repeatedly threatened to block talks on the Czechs' entry into the European Union unless Prague guarantees the plant is safe. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Anthrax Drug Sold Online Leads to Suit
description: The attorneys general of Florida and Washington State filed suit this week against an online pharmacy and a Florida physician who prescribed Cipro, a powerful prescription antibiotic that can be used to treat anthrax, without examining patients or speaking with them.

title: Bucking the Court, Again, to Marry the Jackal
description: The phone rings all the time in Isabelle Coutant Peyre's elegant Left Bank law office these days. Sometimes complete strangers call to talk about her wedding plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAM, CAPT. YAACOV KUBEK
description: ADAM-Capt. Yaacov Kubek (1922 -2002). On Monday, January 7, peacefully at Roosevelt Hospital following a brief illness. Capt. Adam was a Master Mariner, intrepid sailor and decorated war veteran. He was born in Busk, Poland, and was a young immigrant to Palestine where he joined the Haganah in 1938. Following his graduation from Israel's Officers Academy in Haifa, he saw active service with the allied navies during World War II, earning a testimonial message from Pres. Harry Truman and serving in the Atlantic, Pacific and Mediterranean war zones. A unique naval distinction belonged to Capt. Adam -he was Commanding Officer of the first warship in Israel's navy during the 1948 War of Independence. Capt. Adam was an active member of The Explorers Club, in support of education in scientific exploration for young people and laypersons, and was North American Director of Operation Drake, under the patronage of H.R.H. Prince Charles. He was predeceased by his late sister, Ernestina, and is survived by his brothers Lonek and Y'Israel; his daughter, Judith Adam, & grandsons Brendan and Arden; his niece, Zmira Adam Shuruk; his nephew, David Ronen; his dear former wife, Nina Reitzman Adam; and many sincere and genuine friends. A memorial service is expected to be held in early spring. For information, email: YAACOVADAM@aamanheim.net

title: Giants Dismiss an Assistant
description: After a season in which their special teams were among the worst in the N.F.L., the Giants yesterday fired their special teams coach, Fred von Appen, after one season. Von Appen had been hired to replace Larry Mac Duff, whose four-year tenure with the Giants was also marked by poor special teams play. But von Appen could not turn around the units either.

title: PROGRESS ENERGY, A UTILITY, TO BUY NATURAL GAS ASSETS
description: Progress Energy Inc., owner of utilities in Florida and North Carolina, agreed to pay $153 million for natural gas assets in Texas and Louisiana to gain a supply of fuel for its power plants and gas customers. Progress, which is based in Raleigh, N.C., will pay the closely held Westchester Gas Company $135 million in stock and $18 million in cash for the assets, a Progress spokesman, Aaron Perlut, said. The purchase, expected to be completed this quarter, will increase 2002 earnings, Progress said. The acquisition includes 215 producing gas wells, 52 miles of pipeline and 170 miles of gas-gathering systems, all within a 25-mile radius, Mr. Perlut said.

title: The Neediest Cases; Searching for a Home And a Long-Lost Father
description: Staring at a computer screen, Chabliss Bennett, 22, scanned name after name in the New Jersey phone listings, trying to find the one that could lead her to unlock a family mystery. She called a few numbers, but none of the people who answered said they knew anything about her father, Chartlon Bennett.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ESTHER
description: ROSENBERG-Esther. On Thursday, Jan. 10, 2002 in Flushing, New York at age 91. Wife of the late Robert Rosenberg, mother of Joann (Irving) Lederman of Roslyn, NY; grandmother of Diane (Arthur) Levin of Manhattan and Lisa (Jonathan) Bruml of San Mateo, CA; great-grandmother of Sarah and Jacob Bruml at home; sister of Benjamin Sann of Tucson, AZ., and Rose Santo of Mohegan Lake, NY. Graveside services will be held Sunday, January 13th at 9:00 AM in the Temple B'nai Israel Cemetery, McKeesport, PA.

title: A Fiddler in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Official Urges Combining Several Agencies to Create One That Protects Borders
description: The White House Office of Homeland Security has set off a storm inside the Bush administration with a broad proposal to create an agency that would consolidate border security efforts now spread across the federal government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIERCE, GERALD
description: KIERCE-Gerald, 75 of Naples passed away Tuesday, January 8, 2002. Born July 28, 1926 in Lowell, MA. He was the son of the late Walter F. Kierce and Mae Winifred Flannery. He attended Keith Academy with Xaverian Brothers and graduated with the class of 1943 with honors of Salutatorian. Gerald served with the 4th Marine Division in WWII and was honorably discharged in 1945. He attended college of the Holy Cross Worcester, MA. And graduated with the class of 1949 with a Bachelor's Degree in Mathematics. As an undergraduate, he revitalized the tennis team as a varsity recognized team which had been discontinued during WWII. Gerald relocated to New York City in January of 1950 working in various investment firms which included Chemical Bank as Vice President of the Bond Department, Deputy Fiscal agent of Federal Farm Credit Banks which was a major factor in the funding of American agriculture. He retired in 1987 as Vice President of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Government and Corporate Bond Departments. Gerald relocated March 1, 1988 to Naples Bath and Tennis Club with his beloved wife Stella Facelli Kierce who survives him. Also surviving are two sons, a daughter, seven grandchildren, a sister and a brother. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to St. William Catholic Church, 601 Seagate Drive, Naples, Florida 34103.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shares In Hynix Fall
description: Hynix Semiconductor denied a news report that it was near an agreement with Micron Technology, and its shares fell 3 percent. The stock price initially rose after the Yonhap news agency reported that the companies were close to a memorandum of understanding for Micron to take over all Hynix memory-chip operations. The stock reversed course after a Hynix spokesman said the report was untrue. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: JUDGE DENIES NEGOTIATIONS PLEA BY UAL MECHANICS
description: A federal judge said he would not intervene with a presidential panel's review of United Airlines mechanics negotiations, thus barring the union from striking the carrier until at least Feb. 20. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers argued that the National Mediation Board's recommendation that a presidential board be established might have been improper. The contention by the union at the UAL Corporation has a slim chance of winning, said Judge James Robertson of United States District Court. President Bush appointed the panel Dec. 20. The union asked Judge Robertson for a preliminary injunction to stop the panel's proceedings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, VIVIAN B.
description: SINGER-Vivian B. Of Rego Park, NY died in her home on January 9, 2002 after battling a long illness with leukemia. Born in 1924, Vivian was a devoted wife to her husband Eugene, a caring mother to her family and a giving and sharing woman to her friends and community. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, at 11:30AM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Rego Park, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Cancer Research and Treatment Fund, 1440 York Avenue, NY, NY, 10021.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: In South Korea, A Murder Most Politically Foul
description: SEOUL  She was strangled 15 years ago this month in Hong Kong in what her husband said was a bizarre plot by North Korean agents to punish her for failing to have him abducted to North Korea.

title: 2nd Bond-Rating Firm Issues a Warning About State's Credit
description: Standard & Poor's today became the second major bond-rating firm to raise warning flags on New Jersey's credit, saying that the state's current bond rating, which is very high, may be lowered unless the state manages to fill a yawning budget deficit.

title: INSIDE
description: Death Penalty Dispute

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Unemployment Rises
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose to 8 percent in December from 7.5 percent in November, Statistics Canada said. The increase, which brings the jobless rate to its highest level since April 1999, partly reflects a loss of jobs, but also a jump in the number of people looking for work. According to Statistics Canada, employment in manufacturing shrank by 4.8 percent, or 111,000 jobs, last year, the biggest fall in a decade. The drop was most pronounced in the computer and electronic products industries. Total employment crept up 0.2 percent in 2001, with the entire increase coming from part-time jobs. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: DELTA GIVES ITS MECHANICS AND CLEANERS A RAISE
description: Delta Air Lines said its mechanics and cleaners would receive a previously postponed 16 percent pay increase, effective March 16, to give them the second-best pay in the industry. The mechanics' compensation will now be second only to wages at American Airlines, part of the AMR Corporation, up from a fourth-place ranking, a Delta spokesman, Tom Donahue, said. The pay increase, affecting about 10,000 workers, will cost the company $77 million this year. The pay increase is part of a program established last year to make workers' pay at Delta, which is based in Atlanta, comparable to other carriers'. Pay rates for flight attendants, reservation agents and other workers are under review, Mr. Donahue said.

title: A Voice of the Yankees Goes From Radio to TV
description: When he started calling Yankee games on WABC-AM in 1992, Michael Kay had no experience as a baseball broadcaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONDLIFFE, JANE R.
description: CONDLIFFE-Jane R. Riverdale Country School extends its deepest sympathies to the family of Jane R. Condliffe. A longtime friend of the School, Jane was the mother of former Riverdale Trustee Ellen Condliffe Lagemann '63, David C. Condliffe '66, Arthur J. Condliffe, and the late Douglas B. Condliffe '77, and grandmother of Nicholas K. Lagemann '91. Jane's love for and support of Riverdale Country School will long be remembered. Richard S. Zinman, Chairman John R. Johnson, Headmaster

title: When a Dignified Family Is Shouting and Screaming
description: ''The Magnificent Ambersons,'' Booth Tarkington's Pulitzer Prize-winning 1918 novel, must be a victim of a curse.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KEMPNER, MARGARET LOEB
description: KEMPNER-Margaret Loeb. A memorial service at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave and 65th St, January 17th at 10:30 AM, with a reception to follow at The Cosmopolitan Club.

title: INTERNATIONAL SPECIALTY TO SELL ITS FINETECH UNIT
description: International Specialty Products, a maker of chemicals used in hair care, drugs and adhesives, agreed to sell its ISP FineTech business to Pharmaceutical Resources Inc. for about $109 million. The transaction is expected to close within a month, International Specialty Products said. ISP FineTech, which has operations in Columbus, Ohio, and Haifa, Israel, had sales of about $25 million in 2001, the company said. International Specialty Products is based in Wayne, N.J., and Pharmaceutical Resources is based in Spring Valley, N.Y.

title: Seized Arms Would Have Vastly Extended Arafat Arsenal
description: More than a year ago, senior officials of Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority drew up a shopping list of advanced weapons to strengthen radically the limited Palestinian arsenal, according to American officials briefed on Israeli and American intelligence.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: New Face On U.N. Security Council
description: President Vicente Fox named the head of the National Security Council, Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, as ambassador to the United Nations. The job gained new prominence this week when Mexico took a two-year seat on the United Nations Security Council. During his year as security chief Mr. Zinser, a former legislator and academic with no law enforcement experience, reportedly faced resistance from the military and the federal intelligence agency. Analysts said a lack of support from President Fox made his job harder. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the seizure of a ship carrying weapons that Israel said were being smuggled to the Palestinian Authority misstated the origin of the mandate under which Britain governed Palestine, when Jews smuggled weapons to arm their underground. The authority derived from the League of Nations, not the United Nations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Jan. 3 about delays at a mine in Zambia being developed by Konkola Copper Mines, a unit of Anglo American, misidentified the jurisdiction in which a complaint drafted by environmentalists about the company's operations would potentially be filed. It would be with the government of Britain, where Anglo American is chartered, not with the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Minimizing the Enron Taint
description: As he tries to figure out how to handle the backwash from the collapse of Enron, George W. Bush has a great advantage. Having watched what happened to his predecessor, he should understand the importance of simply making everyone tell the truth right away.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Unemployment Continues To Climb
description: Oregon's unemployment rate rose for the sixth consecutive month in December, climbing to 7.5 percent from 7.4 percent in November. Its rate is half a percentage point higher than Washington's, the next highest. Unemployment has been rising in Oregon since it bottomed out at 4.2 percent in December 2000. Last month 129,500 Oregonians were without work. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Reaping The Wind
description: An Irish company received approval to build the world's largest offshore ''wind farm,'' with 200 turbines on sand banks four miles out at sea along the east coast, south of Dublin. The company, Eirtricity, said the five-year project would generate 520 megawatts of electricity -- 10 percent of Ireland's needs. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Kwan Takes Time to Share Her Happiness
description: There must have been an impostor wearing Michelle Kwan's translucent skin, lacing up her skate boots and trying on her sequins.

title: Flyers Cannot Stop Talking About the Rangers' Lindros
description: The Rangers look at Saturday's game in Philadelphia as an important one they hope to use to break their five-game losing streak.

title: Federal Judge Deals Setback To Microsoft In Private Suits
description: Microsoft suffered a setback in its recent campaign to resolve its legal problems yesterday, when a federal judge in Baltimore rejected a proposed settlement of more than 100 private class-action suits against the company.

title: Red Sox Partners Reviewing Sale After Dolan's Late Bid
description: A belated, surprise bid by Charles F. Dolan forced the limited partners of the Boston Red Sox to go into extra innings yesterday.

title: Bucs Brace for Eagles, Not the Chill
description: Not very often does a thermometer get to take center stage at an N.F.L. playoff game. But this afternoon the focus will be on the temperature at Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium at kickoff for the game between the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Eagles, and like everything else about the buildup to this game, there is uncertainty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, STANFORD E.
description: EISENBERG-Stanford E. Of Boca Raton, FL. and Hackensack, N.J., on January 9, 2002, after a 2-1/2 year illness. Beloved husband of Helen. Father of Ann Friedlander and Amy (deceased). Father-inlaw of Stephen R. Friedlander. Mr. Eisenberg graduated from Rutgers University. He served in the U.S. Navy during WWII as Executive Officer on the USS Hudson. Mr. Eisenberg was a generous man who was active in many charities including the United Jewish Appeal, American Friends of Hebrew University and ADL. His friends and relatives will all miss Stan. We will miss his wit, his song, his poetry, his integrity, the Times Sunday crossword undone, in all we will miss you, Stan. Funeral service at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J. Friday, January 11th, at 1:30PM, 201-489-3800. The family will be receiving visitors at their home, The Excelsior II, 170 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack, N.J. through Monday evening, January 14th.

title: The Modern Relocates Its Film Stills Amid Protests
description: Next month, over protests from members of New York's film community, the Museum of Modern Art will move its collection of four million still photographs from films -- a rare record of cinema history -- to its film storage and preservation center in Hamlin, Pa., for an indefinite period.

title: FEDERAL SIGNAL'S EARNINGS ARE BELOW EXPECTATIONS
description: The Federal Signal Corporation, a maker of emergency vehicles and public-safety equipment, cut almost 300 jobs, or 5 percent of the staff, and said fourth-quarter profit was less than analysts had expected. Earnings, excluding charges and costs, were about 26 cents a share, compared with the 28-cent estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Federal Signal, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., said it would take a pretax charge of $3.6 million, or 5 cents a share, mostly for the job cuts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If we have to go to war, jolly good.''

title: Greenspan Sounds Note Of Caution On Economy
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said yesterday that the economy was not yet out of danger, injecting a powerful voice of caution into a growing consensus on Wall Street that a recovery is imminent or already under way.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Acquisition
description: SK Telecom is about to increase its dominant position in the South Korean mobile phone market by acquiring Shinsegi Telecom, a smaller competitor. The government approved the takeover despite objections from SK Telecom's leading rivals, Korea Telecom Freetel and LG Telecom. SK Telecom and Shinsegi together control 52.3 percent of the booming South Korean mobile phone market. The government, wary of SK Telecom's rise over its rivals, has demanded that it restrict its market share to 50 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Dec. 22 with an article about a New York State bill to require outdoor light fixtures to focus their beams downward for the sake of sky watchers referred incorrectly to the words ''visual pollution,'' spray-painted on a sign in Bridgehampton, N.Y. There was no indication that the reference was to light illuminating the sky.

title: Sampras Defeats Agassi In Australian Open Tuneup
description: Pete Sampras underlined that he means business at next week's Australian Open by beating his rival Andre Agassi, 7-6, 6-7, 6-3, in the Kooyong Classic final today in Melbourne, Australia.

title: Bush Bypasses Senate on 2 More Nominees
description: Seeking to end a months-long stalemate, President Bush used a backdoor procedure to appoint two nominees to high-ranking positions in the State and Labor Departments today after they had failed to win Senate approval.

title: Everyone Weighs In With Rebuilding Ideas
description: Almost immediately after Sept. 11, a rising chorus of voices began to offer suggestions about how to rebuild Lower Manhattan and what should be done to address the issues of transportation, office space, businesses, residents and a memorial to the victims of the attacks.

title: Losses Rise as Sprewell Plays More, Scores Less
description: It is his team and it is falling apart. The question is: is he falling apart as well?

title: Man Charged With Lying About Radio Device in Room
description: An Egyptian student who was staying in a hotel room with a view of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 was charged yesterday with lying to federal investigators about an aviation radio that was found in the room's safe.

title: Rachmaninoff Challenging a Pianist to Battle
description: Beloved by many, dismissed by others, Rachmaninoff's music invites both responses. Here to tell us why was the Third Piano Concerto, offered on Wednesday in the last of three Rachmaninoff programs by the Philharmonia Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall. No better evidence exists of a composer who knew too little about writing for orchestras and perhaps too much about writing for the piano. The soaring melodies, supported by sheets of high strings in unison and made interesting by an original ear for harmony, sweep listeners off their feet, helpless and unwilling to resist.

title: Behind India's Brinkmanship: Ominous Preparations to Follow Through
description: Late last month, when India's implied threats of war against Pakistan were largely seen as a forceful bluff, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee summoned senior leaders of his party to an emergency, closed-door session here in the capital.

title: Corrections
description: A round-table discussion of the stock market in the special Outlook issue of Business Day on Jan. 2 misstated the business of the Principal Financial Group, whose stock was recommended by a participant, Charles I. Clough Jr. The company manages retirement savings and sells life and health insurance. It does not sell property and casualty insurance.

description: To the Editor:

description: In percent

title: Major Death Penalty Appeal Accepted
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide a potentially far-reaching challenge to the constitutionality of the death penalty laws in nine states where judges rather than juries determine whether to sentence a killer to death.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Retailer Gains Sales
description: Shares in Europe's largest retailer, Carrefour S.A., closed up more than 6 percent after the company announced a 5 percent increase in fourth-quarter revenue, to 21.3 billion euros ($19 billion) from 20.3 billion euros for the period a year earlier. The increase was almost 9 percent when adjusted for currency exchange-rate fluctuations. Carrefour, which operates 9,000 stores in Europe, Latin America and Asia, but whose biggest markets are in France and Spain, reaped the harvest of an aggressive promotion program that included an offer in December to pay consumers 10 times the price difference if they discovered a product selling for less at a competing store. The results were also the latest indication that European consumers did not stop spending in the wake of the September terrorist attacks. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Rate Gains
description: The inflation rate in Brazil rose to 7.67 percent in 2001 as a consequence of the wayward currency, the real, which depreciated by 16 percent last year. The government, which bases its monetary policy on inflation targets, set a maximum inflation ceiling of 6 percent last year, but an energy crisis and concern over the fitness of the economy in neighboring Argentina put pressure on the real. This year, the government has an inflation target of 3.5 percent, give or take two percentage points. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: UConn Officials Consider Dismissing a Professor Accused of Threats and Bad Behavior
description: Moshe Gai arrived at the University of Connecticut in 1994 as the man whose reputation and talent as a nuclear physicist would bring some much-needed renown to a physics department in need of a star. Now, seven years and several internecine battles later, he may become the university's first tenured professor in 18 years to be fired.

title: A Farewell to Fords With Stories: Luxe Continental to Buff Cougar
description: The four vehicles being dropped by the Ford Motor Company include some storied names, but none of them have sold well lately.

title: Survey Finds A Community In Anguish
description: In late October, about six weeks after the World Trade Center attacks, a team of government interviewers fanned out through Lower Manhattan, knocking on apartment doors, to gauge the mental and physical health of residents who lived near ground zero. What emerged, through conversations with 414 anonymous New Yorkers, was a snapshot of a suffering community.

title: U.S. and Canadian Unions Look at Plans Differently
description: On the surface, the Ford Motor Company's plans to close five plants and eliminate about 15,000 hourly jobs in the United States and Canada seem like simply the latest in decades of auto industry cutbacks.
