title: A Vietnam-Era Vision of Love and Hope
description: Newcomers and old acquaintances got together at the New York State Theater on Wednesday night when the New York City Ballet presented Jerome Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering.''

title: Russian Court Orders Dissolution of Independent TV Network
description: For much of last year, Russia's popular independent NTV television network wasted away in an endless legal battle, victim of what was variously called a Kremlin crusade to snuff out a free press, a corporate blood feud and an utterly impenetrable intrigue.

title: Chasing a Few Big Plays, the Jets Play It Again
description: As Laveranues Coles went streaking to a startling 40-yard touchdown on the second play of the Jets' 24-22 victory over the Raiders last Sunday, Coach Herman Edwards was already reading the emotion meter. Edwards calls it an explosion play, and the Jets have craved it throughout a season full of offensive misadventures.

title: Bush and Democrats Disputing Ties to Enron
description: With the Justice Department and Congress ratcheting up investigations into the Enron Corporation, President Bush is seeking to play down his relationship with Enron's embattled chairman, Kenneth L. Lay. But their ties are broad and deep and go back many years, and the relationship has been beneficial to both.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the seizure of a ship carrying weapons that Israel said were being smuggled to the Palestinian Authority misstated the origin of the mandate under which Britain governed Palestine, when Jews smuggled weapons to arm their underground. The authority derived from the League of Nations, not the United Nations.

title: Lincoln Rallies To Defeat Grady
description: Lincoln of Brooklyn rallied from a 14-point halftime deficit to top its Coney Island rival Grady, 62-59, in overtime yesterday despite the 4-for-27 shooting by guard Sebastian Telfair.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, NATHAN
description: BLASER-Nathan. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. We all miss you. Blaser family

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Friday, 3,117 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: ENRON SOUGHT AID OF TREASURY DEPT. TO GET BANK LOANS
description: The president of the Enron Corporation repeatedly called a senior Treasury Department official last fall and sought help arranging bank loans for the energy company as it scrambled to avoid collapse, the Bush administration said today.

title: First 'Unlawful Combatants' Seized in Afghanistan Arrive at U.S. Base in Cuba
description: Twenty prisoners from the war in Afghanistan arrived in Cuba today, emerging from their Air Force cargo plane in orange prison jumpsuits and face masks, some of them shackled at the legs and all of them manacled. One had been sedated, Pentagon officials said.

title: Indian General Talks Bluntly Of War and a Nuclear Threat
description: India's army chief declared today that the military was fully prepared for a large-scale conventional war with Pakistan and was also ready to deliver a devastating nuclear strike should Pakistan use its nuclear arsenal first.

title: Eisenhower in Kabul
description: There is speculation now about whether President Bush will visit Afghanistan once the American bombing campaign ceases and the new government is established in Kabul. If he does go, he will not be the first American president to make the journey. On Dec. 9, 1959, Dwight D. Eisenhower, while on a goodwill mission to Central Asia and the Middle East, made a pilgrimage to Kabul. There, he met with the eager, 45-year-old Afghan king, Mohammad Zahir Shah -- the same king many now would like to see return from exile to reclaim the throne in Kabul.

title: Secretary Powell to Visit Afghanistan Next Week
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will visit Kabul, Afghanistan, next week to meet with the country's new interim leaders, review the nation's reconstruction needs and pledge American assistance for the rebuilding.

title: Kennedy Will Call For a Delay In Tax Cut
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy is expected to call next week for a delay in the next round of personal income tax cuts enacted in 2001 as part of President Bush's $1.35 trillion, 10-year tax reduction, Congressional aides said.

title: DENDREON SAYS ITS CANCER VACCINE IS IN DOUBT
description: The Dendreon Corporation said its Provenge vaccine for prostate cancer might not make the goals set for a late-stage study, according to an interim analysis of results, setting off a 38 percent fall in its share price. Shares of Dendreon, a developer of cancer-vaccine candidates, fell $3.05, to $5, on Nasdaq, where it led the list of percentage losers. Provenge, Dendreon's leading experimental product, may not be as effective as researchers had hoped in slowing the progression of prostate cancer, said the company, which is based in Seattle. The drug is in the last of three stages of testing generally required for Food and Drug Administration approval. The study findings indicate ''that it is possible, but not probable, that the primary endpoint of the study will be achieved,'' Dendreon's chief executive, Christopher S. Henney, said in a statement.

title: Yashin's Vanishing Act Has Isles Fading, Too
description: Michael Peca, who usually plays center for the Islanders, was asked Thursday to skate as a right wing on Aleksei Yashin's line. This was not exactly a rare honor.

title: Slide Show: Analyze This
description: Surrealism is back -- and we've got it.

title: A Soundtrack to the Heyday of the 18-Wheeler
description: BY definition, the perfect country song must mention mama, trains, prison and whiskey. Trucks, too, are part of the equation, and for years, country music's trucking songs commanded much the same respect as the drivers who kept the big rigs rolling. Trucker tunes once carried enough cultural cachet, in fact, that a 1963 anthem like Dave Dudley's ''Six Days on the Road'' crossed over into the pop Top 40.

title: What Are You Looking At?
description: SELECTED ESSAYS

title: Sometimes, Being Green Is a Red Herring
description: THERE are moldy spots on walls and sewage smells in the basement. Some rooms on the second floor have no heat, and plumbing in the bathroom there isn't connected. The wiring is balky, the porches have rot, and an unexplained flow of water runs across the yard, ending near the front door.

title: Golden Vineyard Country
description: THE scruffy Maverick Saloon, a cowboy bar behind an Old West facade in the tiny town of Santa Ynez, is about as apt an introduction as I can imagine to the golden, rolling wine country of the Santa Ynez Valley in northern Santa Barbara County.

title: Here Comes Terrell Owens
description: Eighty-eight players in the 1996 draft were plucked before Terrell Owens, including receivers Keyshawn Johnson, Terry Glenn, Eric Moulds, Marvin Harrison and Amani Toomer. Relatively speaking, Owens was ignored.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Christopher E. Clouser, executive vice president and chief global marketing officer at the Burger King Corporation, Miami, was named to the added post of president at Burger King Brands, a division that owns and manages all trademarks, copyrights and domain names in connection with Burger King restaurants in the United States and offers Burger King marketing services like advertising. In addition, all marketing executives at Burger King, which is owned by Diageo, will now report to Burger King Brands.

title: No More Raging at a Yellow Bus; In Yonkers, Cooler Heads Look Back at Years of Desegregation
description: The Web site of the Yonkers Public Schools neatly sums up a two-decade battle over desegregation here with a drawing of light- and dark-skinned students standing beside a tree of knowledge. Bright turquoise letters proclaim this ''a unique, culturally diverse community.''

title: For a Maestro, A Long Goodbye
description: WITH a seemingly endless wave of appointments of prospective music directors at major American orchestras finally completed, can a wave of long goodbyes be far away? Several incumbent maestros are in fact already taking lingering leave of their orchestras. The New York Philharmonic is deep into a season largely devoted to honoring Kurt Masur. Seiji Ozawa, in transition from the Boston Symphony to the Vienna State Opera, was glimpsed on international television conducting the New Year concerts of the Vienna Philharmonic.

title: Remembering the Nuns And Two Beautiful Apples
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Dec. 30 for a ''Lives They Lived'' article about Nguyen Van Thieu, the former president of South Vietnam who spent the last years of his life living near Boston in quiet, wealthy exile and often wandered the city by himself, misspelled the name of a street there known for its fashionable shops. It is Newbury, not Newberry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEWELL, DAVID R.
description: JEWELL-David R. 54, of Holmdel, NJ, on Thursday in San Francisco, CA. Partner with Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe Law Firm, NYC. Dear husband for 32 years of Judith (nee Kernan), caring father of John Jewell M.D. and Jessica, brother-in-law to John and wife Ann Kernan, brother of Sandra, Katherine, Jackie and MaryClaire. Visitation Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Holmdel Funeral Home, Holmdel, NJ. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Catharine's R.C. Church, Holmdel. Internet at Holmdel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Vincent de Paul Society, c/o St. Catharine's Church, P.O. Box 655 Holmdel, NJ 07733. Donation envelopes available at funeral home.

title: Like a Tsunami
description: THE highest court in Hawaii had just dealt a setback to the islands' beleaguered native population, and Evan S. Dobelle, the new president of the state university, decided that he had to respond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, JOSEPH L., JR.
description: SELIGMAN-Joseph L., Jr. Died January 8, 2002 in Stinson Beach, CA, age 88, from complications of pneumonia. He was born in NYC November 26, 1913. He went to grammar school at St. Bernard's and high school at Taft School in Watertown, CT; graduated from MIT in 1934 majoring in General Science, member of Theta Chi fraternity, Yale Law School and Harvard Business School, graduated 1938. Active military service, 1941-45, U.S. Army Lt. Colonel, wounded December, 1941. He was an associate of Pillsbury, Madison & Sutro in San Francisco until 1959 when he joined Kelso, Cotton and Ray, which became Jordan, Keeler & Seligman, until he retired in 1980 as a senior partner. Longterm Board member of San Francisco Home Health Service. which is now VNA and Hospice of San Francisco. After retirement he and his wife moved to Stinson Beach where he was an active member of the Community Association. He is survived by his wife, Peggy van Horne Seligman and three sons, Thomas, Edward and Garrett, and three grandsons, Christopher, Timothy and Dylan. Donations in his memory should be made to Hospice at CaliforniaPacific Hospital, San Francisco, CA, the SF Zoological Society, MIT or Yale Law School. There will be no funeral. A memorial service is being planned.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Kew Gardens Hills; Tranquil Enclave, Especially on Saturday
description: ON a Saturday morning, the sidewalks of Kew Gardens Hills are crowded with families in their Sabbath best on their way to services at nearby synagogues. Most of the stores that line Main Street are shuttered, meter parking is plentiful and the tranquil quiet of local side streets is seldom invaded by passing cars.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about notable Connecticut residents who died last year, misstated the given name of a retired minister of the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford. As the article said, he was the Rev. Bernard Drew, not Thomas.

title: HOCKEY CONVICTION
description: Thomas Junta, a 44-year-old truck driver, was convicted of involuntary manslaughter for beating another man to death at their sons' ice hockey practice in July 2000. He claimed self-defense, but witnesses said he pinned the victim to the floor and punched his head repeatedly. He faces 20 years.

title: A Haven For Women Is No Longer Quite Home
description: FOR decades, the halls of Linda Brady's co-op on East 18th Street were redolent with a comforting mix of old-fashioned smells: L'Air du Temps perfume, takeout Chinese food, fabric softener.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Sara Ann Leopold and Dr. Mitchell Kyle Spinnell misstated the location of the medical group where he practices. It is in Fort Lee, N.J., not Englewood.

title: Not So Soothing
description: To the Editor: ''A Soothing Jaunt in Rugged Arizona'' (Dec. 16), by Judith Anderson, which mentioned the Coronado National Forest trail, sent shivers along my spine.

title: Two Tall Women
description: ''Double Teamed'' is the story of Heather and Heidi Burge, twins who made it to the W.N.B.A. (the Sacramento Monarchs and the Los Angeles Sparks, respectively). The movie (Disney Channel, Friday at 8 p.m.) covers their high school days and their professional success. Perhaps the filmmakers' biggest challenge was finding two tall actresses who had basketball skills and looked enough alike to play twins. Poppi Monroe (near right) and Annie McElwain had it all. Nick Searcy and Mackenzie Phillips (center) play their parents.

title: Ivanchuk Keeps His Cool Against the Speedy Anand
description: The matchup was the speedboy against the nervous neurotic.

title: A Hushed Tory Scandal Is Back for All Britain to View
description: It was the most sensational scandal of Margaret Thatcher's prime ministership, and it has resurfaced in damning new detail with the end of a gag order that stilled all mention of the behavior of the disgraced cabinet officer, his mistress and their child born 18 years ago.

title: Making the Mouse More Lovable
description: Mr. Gorman, 32, helped develop Microsoft's newest mouse, the Wireless IntelliMouse Explorer, a cordless, updated version of the IntelliMouse Explorer that uses an optical sensor instead of a trackball.

title: Gay Muslims Face a Growing Challenge Reconciling Their Two Identities
description: In late September, two F.B.I. agents visited the home of Ramzi Zakharia, a Palestinian Muslim who lives in Jersey City. He said they told him they had heard that he had posted subversive comments on a Web site, including some that were critical of United States foreign policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARTER, RUTH
description: TARTER-Ruth. Wife of the late Samuel. Devoted and loved mother of Lois Grossman. Cherished Mema to Stacy and Lisa. Loving aunt and dear friend. We will miss you.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We will take strict action against any Pakistani who is involved in terrorism inside the country or abroad.''

title: Fund Manager Moving To New Role at Janus
description: The Janus Capital Corporation, whose stock mutual funds plummeted after the Internet bubble burst, has appointed James Goff, a fund manager, to the vacant position of director of research.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: I was struck by the picture of Etan Patz. The day Etan disappeared, I was working just a few doors down from the family. I often saw Etan on the fire escape with his mother, where she used to relax, watching passers-by on the quiet street below. Each day I looked among the faces of the millions for him. In the days and months that passed, Etan's face, printed on police posters on every block for miles, faded from the poles and from the public consciousness. Two or three times over these many years I have called the family to tell them that I remember their son, that I am still hoping for his miraculous safe return, that I worked there then and remember it all. I wonder if I should have called them, but somehow I wanted them to know that they were in my thoughts and prayers.

title: Building Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lives They Lived
description: Nearly half a century ago, Robert Ludlum was an aspiring theatrical producer operating a small but successful theater in the Garden State Mall in Paramus, N.J. (''Short. Punchy.,'' by Colin Harrison). I was a reporter at The Passaic-Clifton Herald-News then, where the managing editor would hold aloft Playhouse on the Mall tickets and shout, ''Anyone want to see a play?'' The catch was, you had to write a review. I always jumped at the chance and regularly reviewed Ludlum's fare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, JOSEPH F., JR.
description: GOLDEN-Joseph F., Jr. To a man who has helped us throughout our business careers, he will be greatly missed. Our condolences to his family. Norman Fass Michael Fass

title: A Different Battleground, A Lobby's Bulletin Board
description: Until recently, the marble lobby of 420 Riverside Drive, near West 114th Street, was a tranquil place of stained-glass windows and how-do-you-do civility. But the recent removal of two American flags that hung briefly over the lobby entrance and the doorman's desk has sparked shouting matches between some neighbors and led others to post letters of debate on the lobby bulletin board. On Jan. 23, a buildingwide vote is to determine whether Old Glory merits hanging there at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZURKOW, JEROME S., ESQ.
description: ZURKOW-Jerome S., Esq. Died December 24, 2001 in NJ at the age of 85. Brilliant lawyer, loving and devoted husband and father, and spirited adventurer. He is survived by his devoted and loving wife, Bibi, and daughter, Marina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, STANFORD E.
description: EISENBERG-Stanford E. Of Boca Raton, FL. and Hackensack, N.J., on January 9, 2002, after a 2-1/2 year illness. Beloved husband of Helen. Father of Ann Friedlander and Amy (deceased). Father-inlaw of Stephen R. Friedlander. Mr. Eisenberg graduated from Rutgers University. He served in the U.S. Navy during WWII as Executive Officer on the USS Hudson. Mr. Eisenberg was a generous man who was active in many charities including the United Jewish Appeal, American Friends of Hebrew University and ADL. His friends and relatives will all miss Stan. We will miss his wit, his song, his poetry, his integrity, the Times Sunday crossword undone, in all we will miss you, Stan. Funeral service at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J. Friday, January 11th, at 1:30PM, 201-489-3800. The family will be receiving visitors at their home, The Excelsior II, 170 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack, N.J. through Monday evening, January 14th.

title: The Therapy Generation
description: YOU see him walking north on Broadway, arms swinging, legs moving at such a brisk clip that you almost miss him, and suddenly you're sucked into the force field of a very busy, self-confident Co-lumbia University sophomore.

title: Filmmaker Buys the Rights To Book About Jersey City
description: Helene Stapinski may have to leave the country soon.

title: For Women, to Soar Is Rare, to Fall Is Human
description: IT is not enough for women to succeed in business. They also must fail.

title: Hatfield vs. McCoy in TV Land
description: WHEN Jamie Kellner took over as chairman of Turner Broadcasting System last spring, he declared that he would immediately restore the pride of its largest cable network, CNN, and help it to beat back its nimble and ornery challenger, the Fox News Channel.

title: Kwan, Cohen and Hughes Secure Spots on the Olympic Team
description: For the first three minutes of her long program tonight, Michelle Kwan skated with the deliberate steps of a gunslinger pacing off a distance in a duel.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Robert Frost contemplated only two ways to end the world: fire and ice. These are hardly sufficient for Peter Watts, whose MAELSTROM (Tor/Tom Doherty, $25.95) posits the imminent collapse of human civilization under simultaneous attack by a daunting array of biological, nuclear and electronic horrors.

title: 'Roscoe'
description: Roscoe Owen Conway presided at Albany Democratic Party headquarters, on the eleventh floor of the State Bank building, the main stop for Democrats on the way to heaven. Headquarters occupied three large offices: one where Roscoe, secretary and second in command of the Party, received supplicants and debtors, one where Bart Merrigan and Joey Manucci controlled the flow of visitors and phone calls, and one for the safe which, when put here, was the largest in the city outside of a bank vault. Of late, no money was kept in it, only deceptive Democratic financial data to feed to the Governor's investigators, who had been swooping down on the Party's files since 1942, the year the Governor-elect vowed to destroy Albany Democrats.

title: Put Away the Slide Projector
description: ON the border of my computer monitor sits a Post-It note with the name of Marcelo Falero, an Epcot employee who befriended my family two years ago during a Disney pilgrimage. My wife, our three children and I took a family photo with Mr. Falero shortly after he had given our children express passes for a ride we had been turned away from because the park was closing.

title: UNRAVELING ENRON
description: The executives at Enron always wanted their business well-known, with its practices studied by others. Now, following the collapse of the energy giant, it looks like they'll get their wish. The Justice Department is forming a special task force to investigate possible crimes in the collapse, joining ongoing inquiries by Congress and regulators. There will plenty of work for everyone: the White House has acknowledged that Enron's chairman contacted two cabinet officers before the collapse, and Enron's auditor, Arthur Andersen, admitted to destroying relevant documents. Kurt Eichenwald

description: IT was a cold night, two weeks before Christmas in 1945, when a very nervous Nancy Fisher took center stage at the Sterling Opera House in Derby for the Naugatuck Valley Glee Club's annual winter concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMAIRE, EMMY
description: LEMAIRE-Emmy, 92. On December 27, 2001, in Hightstown, New Jersey. Born September 11, 1909, in Richmond, VA. Graduated from Sweet Briar College in 1930. Served in the Navy as a WAVE during World War II. Married Captain Remy Lemaire of the French Navy in 1946. Lived in New York City and retired to Portugal. Returned to New York City in 1981. Member of Colony Club, Cosmopolitan Club and National Society of Colonial Dames. Survived by the following nieces and nephews: Celia R. Lewis of Payzac, France, Caroline A. Riely of Memphis, TN, John C. Riely of Chestnut Hill, MA, and Henry C. Riely of Richmond.

title: In Defense of 'Outsider': A Question Of Labels
description: IF the artwork presented under the outsider banner is often strange and perplexing, so are the attitudes of many people who passionately champion this material. The larger outsider art's audience grows, the more vehemently people within the field object to the term outsider, and the more complaints we hear about the very idea of such a category.

title: Top Credentials Sought For Airport Security Jobs
description: The Department of Transportation, which last month agreed with Congress in deciding not to require high school diplomas for airport screeners, has taken a different approach in hiring the security directors at the largest airports.

description: Bill Richardson, whose term as energy secretary in the Clinton administration was clouded in controversy over problems with the Los Alamos national laboratory and the scientist Wen Ho Lee, announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for governor of New Mexico.

description: It is such an emotional topic that Antoinette Rubino cannot talk about it without sobbing. Mrs. Rubino's daughter, Joanne, was killed at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. There was zero-down, zero-interest, zero-payments-for-six-months financing, and a bell that went ''clang clang clang clang'' every time the Sea Ray booth sold a boat, which was about every half-hour. Most devoted to cousins and friends, here and abroad. Passed away peacefully. Remembrance Tuesday, January 15, at 3 PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: The Long-Range Forecast
description: SITTING on Bill Solecki's desk at Montclair State University was a study outlining the probable effects of global warming toward the end of the century: more frequent severe winter storms, sending floodwaters surging into such places as Jersey City and entrances to the Hudson River tunnels.

description: NEWS flash: Osama bin Laden is still missing. Congress considers education package. Santa's reindeer are probably female.

title: They Refused to Fight, Even in the 'Good War'
description: EARLY in a new documentary about World War II, American soldiers push through the Normandy surf under German fire. This scene stands even a half-century later as the signal image of the generation that defeated Hitler and Hirohito. From the commemoration of D-Day's 50th anniversary in 1994 to its cinematic rendering in ''Saving Private Ryan'' to its prominence in books by Studs Terkel, Stephen Ambrose and Tom Brokaw, the storming of Omaha and Utah beaches has come to typify valor in pursuit of justice.

description: The local crowd tends to skewer politicians with an easy cynicism over morning coffee here at the Newport Cafe.

As Hindus and Muslims slaughtered each other during the partition of the subcontinent into India and Pakistan, Kashmiris spared each other the same fate. Gandhi described the Kashmir valley as a ray of hope in the darkness.

description: JANICE SWEET FAIRLEY spent virtually all of her working career at the telephone company, starting as an operator for Michigan Bell, and rising to a manager of data services after the company was reorganized as Ameritech.

description: DOCKRY-John James. Practicing attorney criminal defense field. Survived by a cherished sister, Margaret Culotta of Washington, D.C, her husband and children. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

description: The United States has notified Britain that a British subject is one of the 20 detainees from Afghanistan being held at the United States Naval Base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, a Foreign Office spokesman in London said today.

Someone came to us to do this partnership with a banking software firm. This third party was a compelling person, got us all whipped up about the deal.

title: A Show of the Gritty And the Spiritual
description: EVERY few years the 28 members of the cooperative gallery Art/Place take a break from exhibitions of their own art to put on a show of new work by artists outside the gallery, with each member choosing a guest. The result is a cozy and pleasant group show containing recent work in painting, sculpture, printmaking and photography. Sometimes a piece is straightforward, but often it is oblique, fanciful or teasing.

He was an only child, and from infant to late teenage years he lived with his parents, ‘Peggy’ (Rosa Anne, née Lucas) and William Amis at 16 Buckingham Gardens, Norbury, London SW16.

title: College Prep; Tricks of the Trade
description: Back in 1981, when I began my career as an administrator, admissions staff members spent most of their time deciding which high school seniors to admit. Twenty years later, admissions has a new name, enrollment management, and a much broader mandate: to recruit and select the best undergraduates in an increasingly competitive marketplace, to raise the institution a notch or more in the influential rankings of U.S. News & World Report and to maintain steady enrollment in the freshmen, sophomore, junior and senior classes.

title: MICROSOFT UNSETTLED
description: A federal judge threw out a settlement that would have given free software and computers to the nation's poorest schools to end dozens of suits accusing Microsoft of overcharging for its software. The judge, J. Frederick Motz, said the settlement was ''critically underfunded'' and would have anticompetitive effects on the market -- Apple Computer also supplies schools.

title: Pop Quiz; How Wel Koude Yow Answere?
description: Subject tests are only occasionally required but are often recommended to provide an edge in graduate school admission. Among the eight subject tests that are part of the Graduate Record Examinations, English literature is the only one in the humanities -- the sole subject with an undergraduate curriculum that was consistent enough for a national test. Here is a sampling of G.R.E. subject-test questions reflecting what undergraduates are being taught in literature.

title: Threads of Chappaqua's Past

title: QUICK BITE/Trenton; The Food Can Go, but Not the Staff
description: The grounds of the New Jersey Department of Corrections resembles a small college campus, and in its midst is an ivy-covered brick building reminiscent of a student union. But the 14 young employees there are not undergrads. They are are inmates of the Garden State Correction Center, a minimum security facility, and the building houses a restaurant called the Mates Inn. The program began as way to train inmates to cook for juvenile inmates, but in 1978, Agnes Naughton took over and opened the restaurant to the public. Now Department of Correction employees, neighborhood residents and students and faculty from Mercer County College stop in for breakfast or lunch. Menu items might include prime rib, seafood, chicken or pork chops ($5.95 to $6.95). Lighter lunch items include a Cajun wrap with shrimp, lettuce and rice on a honey-wheat flat bread ($4.75) and a mixed fruit salad ($1.75). Ms. Naughton selects each of the workers, who, she says, must be free of any major institutional infractions and demonstrate a desire to work. It shows. On a recent visit, everyone from the waiter to the kitchen staff showed a ready smile and an obvious enthusiasm. The pay is just a few dollars a day, plus tips. ''We're not here to make a profit,'' Ms. Naughton said. ''The most important thing about this program is to foster confidence in our employees and teach skills they can use when they are released so they can do something productive with their lives.'' Jo Piazza

title: Where's Nina?
description: In the course of immortalizing countless stage performers with his animated drawings, Al Hirschfeld has become synonymous with the American theater. Even his most ardent admirers might be surprised, however, to discover just how extensively Hirschfeld has also rendered Hollywood figures during the past eight decades. Two new volumes celebrate the artist's bicoastal career. Hirschfeld's New York (Abrams, $15.95) includes an affectionate tribute by Frank Rich and a biographical sketch by Clare Bell, an art historian, who tells us that Hirschfeld ''drew constantly'' as a boy. Though his first job was sculpturing architectural reliefs, he was hired as the advertising art director at Selznick Pictures in 1921, when he was only 18. Hirschfeld's breakthrough caricature for The New York Times was a woolly depiction of the Scottish vaudevillian Harry Lauder, in 1928. In his essay for Hirschfeld's Hollywood (Abrams, $15.95), David Leopold, a curator and the artist's archivist, says that Hirschfeld was as closely associated with MGM in the 1930's and 40's ''as he is with The New York Times today.'' Many of the posters and film ads have been handsomely reproduced in the graphic equivalent of Technicolor; they conjure familiar images of the Marx Brothers in ''A Day at the Races'' or Judy and Mickey in ''Strike Up the Band.'' In his humorous, loving foreword, Larry Gelbart refers to Hirschfeld as both a ''sit-down comic'' and ''the undisputed Chairman of the Drawing Board'' -- apt designations for a supremely witty artist who wields a wry pen. David Kaufman

description: Wild steelhead are a big, seagoing rainbow trout, regarded by many anglers as the most elusive of fishes. They are highly migratory, meaning they are born in freshwater rivers and streams, then head to the ocean for two or three years before returning to spawn. Upon that return, anglers assemble at the river to greet them. Some years, the conditions are ripe and experienced anglers find numerous steelhead. Other years, for reasons that aren't fully understood, few fish return. During those down years even the experts can do nothing more than case their rods, call it quits and hope that the following year will bring more fish.

title: Which Way Did He Run?
description: Firemen have a culture of death. There are rituals, carefully constructed for the living, to process the dead. And so on Sept. 11, when members of Engine Company 40, Ladder Company 35 discovered that every man from their house who responded to the World Trade Center attack -- 12, including a captain and a lieutenant -- had disappeared, they descended on the site in droves, prepared, at the very least, to perform the rite of carrying out their own. Several who had been on vacation in Maryland barreled into their cars and raced up the Interstate, arriving within hours. Others, who got to the firehouse only to find there were no more vehicles, commandeered anything with wheels -- taxis, Red Cross vans, buses.

A denim cheerleader-style mini with pleats and side buckles by Chlo ($425, left), is available at Kirna Zabte. Tracey Ross in Los Angeles has halter tops made from vintage Jets T-shirts ($125). And Saks Fifth Avenue offers a Joomi Joolz sweat suit with rhinestone football helmets ($96 for the top, $80 for the bottoms) as well as that ultimate in athlete chic, Oscar de la Renta's football bag, right, a chubby oval pocketbook ($350 to $4,500). title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICOL, ROBERT JOHN
description: NICOL-Robert John. Of Bonner Peak Ranch, La Porte and Fort Collins died at home suddenly on Sunday, January 6th. He was a resident of Colorado since January 1996. The family will receive friends who wish to pay respects at the Reager Funeral Home, 1530 Riverside Ave., Ft. Collins on Wednesday January 9th between 4 and 6 PM. Robert J. Nicol was born in Genoa, Italy on February 22, 1930 to British parents. A graduate of Riverdale Country Day School, Harvard College, and Harvard Law School, he practiced Admiralty Law and business in New York City. Business ownership included Metropolitan News Services, McGrath Industries, and International Terminal Operators. He married Margaret Gammage on October 29, 1955 in Atlanta, Georgia. He is survived by his wife; two daughters, Elisabeth A. Nicol and Margaret W. Nicol, both of Fort Collins; two sons, Robert D. Nicol of Boulder and Ian A. Nicol of Fort Collins; nephews Joseph Holme and Simon Holme of Florida; nieces Roberta Wolyner of NYC and Jennifer Holme of Connecticut; and first cousins Anne Smallwood of Oxford, England and David Smallwood of France. Memorial contributions may be given to the Children's Prosthetic/Orthotic Fund in care of the Poudre Valley Hospital Foundation, 1024 South Lemay Avenue, Fort Collins, CO. 80524-3998.

title: Home-Grown
description: I have to admit that when I heard that the anthrax making the rounds was the ''Ames'' strain, my ears pricked up. I used to live in Ames -- Ames, Iowa -- where the anthrax strain was first developed, and I was reminded of the paradoxes of that cow college town. No place could have been quieter than Ames. (I wouldn't be surprised to hear the same said of the neighborhood around Fort Detrick, Md., where the Army started working with anthrax in the late 50's.) We used to say to people who had lived in Ames and left that things were just the same, and, more or less, they were. The high school got a big new building, the junior high school got a big new building -- that was the news. Ames was a good place to raise kids, with great day care and wonderful neighborhoods of inexpensive, solid houses and sidewalks.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: I commend you on your choice of Milan Hlavsa as an important figure who died in 2001 (''Prague Rock,'' by Paul Berman). Frankly, I was surprised when I found him included. Not many know who the Plastic People of the Universe are or have heard their music. My boyfriend helped organize underground concerts of bands that were considered ''dissident.'' He printed handouts and posters for such events illegally at the print shop where he worked. It was a risk to listen to this music, but it was a voice, the only one they had, and so it flourished, even under oppression.

title: DISABILITY RULING
description: In a decision that limits the reach of the 11-year-old Americans With Disabilities Act, the Supreme Court said an assembly line worker whose carpal tunnel syndrome left her unable to grip tools could not be considered disabled on that basis alone. The justices ordered a lower court to re-examine the case in light of the worker's remaining ability to attend to her personal hygiene and do household chores. To qualify as a disability, an impairment must prevent an individual ''from doing activities that are of central importance in most people's daily lives,'' the court said. Employers' groups praised the decision. Linda Greenhouse

title: The Nation; The Stripes Are on Their Sleeves, Not Their Pants
description: EACH evening, as Army Special Forces troops rise with the moon to stand sentry in this former Taliban stronghold, a lieutenant colonel named Dave sits on the carpeted floor of the Governor's Palace to advise local leaders on the complexities of turning tribal warriors into a civilian-controlled security force respecting the rule of law.

title: Winter Scenes
Scared Straight In Business School
description: DON'T be led astray into the path of virtue, Oscar Wilde said. But most people think that's the path to follow. Who better to educate students on the matter than those who have wandered off and are now paying for it?

title: Palestinians Revise Number of Arrests in Weapons Shipment
description: Palestinian officials said today that they had detained one man, not three as they had previously announced, for questioning in connection with a weapons shipment intercepted at sea this month by Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGE, GERALD
description: PAGE-Gerald. The Ninth District Dental Society expresses its deepest sympathy to the family of Gerald Page of Larchmont, NY, who served as our beloved Executive Director from 1978 to 1996.

title: 'Palladio'
description: Atown called Ulster in central New York—west of the Hudson, but still closer to Albany than to Syracuse or Buffalo—prospered briefly in the 1960s and '70s when IBM opened a regional sales division on the site of an old dairy two towns away. Ten minutes off the thruway, the abruptly thriving area wasn't long removed from its earlier life as farm country; most of the old sagging barns were bought up and knocked down to make way for new construction, but a few of the better-preserved ones were left on the vistas to go about the picturesque business of their own slow decline. They stand there today, swaybacked, holes punched in their steep roofs by years of snowfall; and the regional sales division has shut down. Roger Howe was offered a job there, a job that effectively represented the promotion which had not been forthcoming in his four years at the office in Westchester. He and his wife, Kay, with a small relocation allowance from the company and what remained of her inheritance from her father, moved upstate in the fall of 1970, when their son Richard was three years old, and Kay, though she didn't know it at the time, was pregnant with Molly.

title: January 6-12; FRONT LINES
description: THE FIRST PRISONER TRANSFER -- Twenty of the nearly 400 American detainees in Afghanistan, described as particularly dangerous and guarded by 40 military police officers, left the Kandahar airport and arrived at the U.S. naval base at Guantnamo Bay 27 hours later. They will be held in 6-by-8 foot concrete and chainlink cells, awaiting interrogation and possible trial before military tribunals. The United States considers them ''unlawful combatants,'' not prisoners of war, but says it will accord them Geneva Convention protections.

title: Bonjour, Teacher. Guten Tag, Too.
description: WHEN the International School at Dundee opened in Greenwich more than a year ago, the founders of the magnet school insisted that foreign language be treated equally with other, more traditional elementary subjects, such as math and English.

title: Rebuilding New York; How to Fill the Hole at Ground Zero
description: Laboring in overdrive since soon after the Sept. 11 attacks, construction and subway workers at Manhattan's ground zero are now well ahead of schedule. The World Trade Center site should be cleared by summer; a key subway stop in the area should be working again by fall. The heroic speed of the recovery will soon leave an empty lot and a deep hole where the towers and, later, their tragic shells once stood. At this point, the city needs to be assured that plans for redeveloping the site are moving forward with the same sense of urgency. A large crater and haphazard planning about what to put there would send the worst possible signal to the people and businesses who are trying to decide whether their future lies in Lower Manhattan.

title: Favre Was Not First To Grant Special Favor
description: If Brett Favre remains puzzled by the public resentment over his gift of a record-setting sack to the Giants' Michael Strahan, Favre need only view the film from one particular N.F.L. game almost two decades ago. It was when the former Jet Mark Gastineau broke the sack record by nearly breaking Tampa Bay quarterback Steve DeBerg in half.

title: Kristin Cuscela, Matthew Siano
description: Kristin Nicole Cuscela, a daughter of Mary Lee and Frank P. Cuscela of Dallas, Pa., was married yesterday to Matthew Brady Siano, a son of Sylvia and Anthony J. Siano of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Randolph L. C. Weber performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Charles Wrightington, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Rebuilding New York; The Possibilities of Lincoln Center
description: The combined effects of the terrorist attacks and the recession have left many Manhattan institutions reeling -- including Lincoln Center, the city's premier performing arts complex. Sept. 11 caught its resident companies in the midst of protracted wrangling over an ambitious 10-year, $1.2 billion redevelopment plan that will depend, in part, on an infusion of city money. Not long after his inauguration, Mayor Michael Bloomberg made it clear that a harsh new fiscal reality might mean, at the very least, postponing that plan. Now Lincoln Center must adjust to this new reality while finding a way to perform seriously needed repairs. It must also find leadership with the ability and vision to continue planning for the future.

title: The Health Card
description: The great challenge for Gov. George E. Pataki this year will be to weather a financial crisis without seriously damaging either public services or his chances of re-election in November.

title: New Pewter Museum In Shakespeare's Village
description: Harvard House, a 16th-century timber-framed house in Stratford upon Avon, England, has been restored and reopened as the Museum of British Pewter. Built in 1596, it was the home of a rich butcher, Thomas Rogers, whose grandson, John Harvard, emigrated to the Colonies and was instrumental in founding the university in Cambridge, Mass., that bears his name.

title: After a Blight, Elms Rebound
description: MORE than 70 years after Dutch elm disease began to wipe out 90 percent of the magnificent American elms that lined the streets of so many cities and towns, a handful of resistant varieties are beginning to cast their regal shade over the country's lawns and boulevards.

title: Streetscapes/West 144th Street Between Amsterdam and Convent Avenues; A Block With an Eyeful of Styles, Colors and Forms
description: THE block of West 144th Street between Convent and Amsterdam Avenues, the centerpiece of the Hamilton Heights Historic District, offers an architectural blizzard of styles, colors and forms -- Tudor, Gothic, Flemish and Romanesque, in red, brown, white, yellow and tan masonry.

title: Scents to Chase the Blues
description: For the midwinter doldrums, mood candles -- scented candles designed to have aromatherapeutic effects on temperament -- are apparently just the tonic. A runaway post-Sept. 11 item, the candles have a popularity that continues to hold strong. Now, manufacturers are bringing out a new batch of wax burners, intended to manipulate moods with just the flick of a Bic. Aromapharmacy's Lozac candle is encased in pill-bottle packaging and uses sage and geranium to help stem the blues ($14 at Sephora). Susan Ciminelli's Srnit candle ($45 at the Susan Ciminelli Spa at Bergdorf Goodman) contains the essential oils of white flowers; once lighted, it purportedly induces feelings of tranquillity. Bliss's Bougies aim at stress ($32 at www.blissworld.com), while L'Artisan Parfumeur's le Bourbon candle has a sweet, familiar vanilla fragrance meant to counteract homesickness ($70 at Barneys New York). Molton Brown's Relaxing Air candle ($38 at www.sephora.com) uses tangerine and cedarwood to, well, relax the air, whatever that might mean. And to not merely enhance your mood but to actually put you in it, this week Aveda will reintroduce Love Pure-Fume candle ($22), an oversize sandalwood and jasmine votive that the company says works as a natural aphrodisiac.

description: To the Editor:

title: For Want of a Piece of Cable, a Tram Was Lost
description: The Roosevelt Island tram has been out of commission since the day after Thanksgiving, when it was shut down for routine maintenance. The small cause of the large problem was a cable that was a bit too short.

description: Fantasy Auction for Fire Safety

description: THE New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's winter music festival, ''Richard Strauss: A Hero's Life?,'' spotlights the phantom of Nazi sympathies that still dogs the composer 52 years after his death.

title: Gotcha!
description: 'Uofallpeople'' is the name of the file I must grimly address today. It contains the pointing of fingers by the Gotcha! Gang at the language maven for errors in my columns last year.

title: Executive Life; The New M.B.A. Vogue: A Job at a Blue Chip
description: HIS father worked as a manager at Bristol-Myers Squibb for 22 years, but Brandon Thomas, a student at the McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas at Austin, had no intention of following in his footsteps. The staid culture of a Fortune 500 company just wasn't for him.

title: A Train to a Plane to a Bus to a Subway
description: PHOTOS, drawings and computer-generated images of some of the world's most exciting urban design projects are on display along a twisting corridor at the Art Institute here. For one project in the Belgian city of Lige, the architect Santiago Calatrava has designed a huge glass building with soaring canopies and a roof supported by monumental arched ribs. Scheduled to be completed in 2006, it has a great central hall, as well as offices, a shopping center, an 800-space parking garage and subway connections. One of the towering glass walls will offer visitors a panoramic view of a nearby mountainside.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about dangerous intersections in the city referred incorrectly to the intersection of Essex and Delancey Streets. It is near the Williamsburg Bridge, not the Manhattan Bridge.

title: Gulotta Legacy Remains One of Failure
description: Thomas Gulotta's Disneyland farewell essay [''The Gulotta Legacy: His Version,'' Dec. 30] shows that he is still clueless. He neglected to mention the scandals that plagued his tenure, including the health insurance scandal. Or that he reduced the county's work force but kept bloating the payroll with patronage jobs. Or his cutting back on services.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRACHMAN, ROY P.
description: DRACHMAN-Roy P. The International Council of Shopping Centers, its trustees, staff, and 40,000 members worldwide mourn the passing of our beloved founding member, past Chairman 1960-1963, Member of the Board of the ICSC Educational Foundation, and industry pioneer. Innovator in a wide range of areas including parking, Roy P. Drachman was a man of great intellectual curiousity able to take the big risk when the opportunity arose. His generosity is legendary and virtually every aspect of his home town, Tucson, Arizona has been touched by his philanthropy. He was also a Stalwart Champion and benefactor of the University of Arizona. His greatest gift was that of his friendship, open full and enthusiastic. ICSC members who knew him or of him will always remember his quick wit and helping hand. Michael Kercheval, President John Riordan, Vice Chaiman International Council of Shopping Centers

title: No More Pencils, No More ...
description: AS more school districts consider summer sessions to cope with overcrowding or failing students, a new book serves as a reminder of how and why the beloved two-month respite came to be.

title: Cross-Sound Cable Takes Step Forward
description: TEN months after rejecting an underwater cable to carry electricity from Connecticut to power-hungry Long Island, Connecticut regulators have approved a new plan to reroute the line slightly away from commercial shellfish beds.

title: Jets Audio
description: Postgame audio from the Jets vs. the Oakland Raiders provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Tucson
description: Tucson isn't normally a Type-A kind of city, but for just a few weeks each year the adrenaline really surges. These are the weeks, from now into March.

title: Ideas & Trends: In the Dark; The Rogue to Fear Most Is the One Following Orders
description: IN 1999, Pakistan's civilian prime minister sent the head of its intelligence agency on a secret trip to the United States. He listened as Clinton administration officials urged Pakistan to withdraw its support for the Taliban. Equally important, he had instructions to tell the Americans that Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif suspected that the Pakistani army chief of staff was plotting a coup against him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANSON, ROBERT SINCLAIR JR.
description: SWANSON-Robert Sinclair Jr. Of Naples, FL, and South Burlington, VT, died in Naples on January 10, 2002. He was born in New York City to Robert and Louise Swanson on April 27, 1925. He was graduated from the Stony Brook School and Babson College. He served in the 10th Mountain Division of the United States Army in Italy in World War II. He retired as President of S. B. Thomas, Inc., makers of Thomas's English Muffins. He served as President of the Board of Trustees of the Stony Brook School for 25 years. He served on the Board of the Long Island Savings Bank. As a Little League coach he led five championship teams. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Virginia, his daughter Barbara Sherman of New York City, his sons Alan of Charlottesville, VA, and Robert III of South Hero, VT, and two brothers, John P. Swanson of Flat Rock, NC, and George Daniel Swanson of Cary, NC. He is predeceased by his son Lawrence, his grandson Matthew, his sister Janet, and his brother David. He had eight grandchildren. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Stony Brook School, Stony Brook, NY 11790. A memorial service will be held Friday, January 18, at 1 PM, in the chapel of the Stony Brook School, Stony Brook, NY, with reception to follow.

title: Standing Up for Indian Point
description: EVER since terrorists flew a fully fueled jet right by the Indian Point nuclear plant as it followed the Hudson River to the World Trade Center, neighbors to the north, south, east and across the river to the west have packed board meetings and petitioned politicians, demanding the plant's shutdown.

title: Consuming Rituals of the Suburban Tribe
description: Angela Macri crouches beneath the shower nozzle and blinks into the blazing lights of a one-person film crew. The shower curtain has been drawn back so that her movements are exposed to the camera; Macri seems a little nervous as she adjusts the faucets.

title: The Year Begins, Not With a Bang, but a Whisper
description: IT was fitting that the first snow of 2002 came as a whisper of whiteness rather than a shout, as the city held its breath. A tough place, yes, but not ready yet for any kind of wallop.

title: House That Lives On in Literature Has New Visitors: Archaeologists
description: James Fenimore Cooper used Rose Hill Manor as the setting for his 1821 novel, ''The Spy.'' The carillon of the nearby University Church inspired Edgar Allan Poe's 1849 poem ''The Bells.'' In 1841, the Rev. John Hughes, New York's first Roman Catholic archbishop, used the manor to establish a college. Initially named St. John's College, it evolved into Fordham University.

But some of those same parents have been less attuned to finances in another area, sending their children off to college with wallets bulging with high-interest-rate credit cards.

description: ANY of the vehicles now on the streets first appeared as concept cars at the North American International Auto Show, then reappeared a year or two later as products that you could buy, with real window stickers bearing real suggested prices.

title: MILOSEVIC'S WITNESS LIST
description: After mocking the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague for months, Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslavian president, has drawn up a list of 35 present and past world leaders he plans to call as witnesses in his two upcoming trials, according to two of his Belgrade lawyers. Among them: former President Bill Clinton, former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, and the former secretary general of NATO, Javier Solana. Few lawyers in The Hague expect the witnesses to appear. Marlise Simons

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: MARTIAL arts adventure does not come more gracefully or romantically packaged than in Ang Lee's CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON, which flew away with the Oscar for the best foreign film of 2000 as well as the awards for cinematography, art direction and original score (by Tan Dun). This Taiwanese film is, simply, a treat for the eye and ear. Starring Chow Yun Fat and Michelle Yeoh as 19th-century masters of martial arts, ''Crouching Tiger,'' riding of the balletic combat choreography of Yuen WoPing, revolves around the theft fo the Green Destiny, a legendary sword, by a headstrong young woman - Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:40 a.m. on Starz.

title: An Invitation to Join 'Team Nassau'
description: JUDGE EUGENE NICKERSON'S death on the day of my inauguration has prompted me to reflect on his legacy and to seek instruction from it. Eugene H. Nickerson assumed the office of county executive shortly before I was born in 1962. He was the first Democratic county executive in Nassau's history and took office near the peak of the incredible growth of the county, which went from 550,000 residents in 1950 to 1.1 million residents in 1960.

title: Suit Over Estate Claims a Widow Is Not a Woman
description: J'Noel Gardiner is hardly the first widow to be accused of marrying a man twice her age for money instead of love, with a stepson she first met at her husband's funeral trying to block her inheritance.

description: IS time running out for Arthur Andersen & Company?

title: GLOBAL CLOSE CALL
description: A 1,000-foot-wide asteroid hurled past Earth at 68,000 miles per hour, missing by about half a million miles, a pretty close call by solar system standards. Such near-misses are, disconcertingly, not uncommon, and a rock of that size and speed could destroy an area the size of Texas. Astronomers say chances of a direct hit are small -- perhaps one every 20,000 years -- but if such an asteroid were on a bull's-eye course, there would be no time or way to stop it. The asteroid was spotted less than two weeks before it zipped by. Kenneth Chang

title: In the Region/Long Island; 10 Years After Fire, Sayville Building Is to Reopen
description: TEN years ago, on Jan. 19, 1992, Dave Smith's print shop in Sayville was demolished in a fire that destroyed the two-story 19th-century building in which he was renting space on South Main Street. The 9,000-square-foot building contained six stores on the ground floor and four apartments on the second floor, three of which were unoccupied. There were no serious injuries, but the damage totaled more than $700,000. The fire was one of three separate blazes in the hamlet's downtown area to occur in the bitter 9-degree temperature early that Sunday morning.

title: Ann Simmons, Erik Seligman
description: Ann Elizabeth Simmons and Erik Mark Seligman, both engineers, were married last evening at Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Cincinnati. The Rev. Robert Agnew performed the ceremony, in which Cantor Lawrence Ellis participated.

title: WATERSHED QUALITY
description: Two watersheds in southern New Jersey ranked among the worst in the nation for water quality, according to a federal Environmental Protection Agency survey released last week. The Cohansey-Maurice watershed in Gloucester and Camden Counties and the Mullica-Toms watershed in Camden and Burlington counties were rated a 6, the worst rating on a water pollution scale based on data collected in 1999 about untreated water. A spokesman for the Philadelphia region of the E.P.A. said the water quality had become better lately with improvements in sewage treatment plants along the rivers.

title: Where He Was Calling From
description: Back then, my phone would ring at 1 or 2 o'clock in the morning, and Ben's voice would be in my ear. No greeting or preamble, just the crackle of his notebook's pages and the words unspooling. That was what he liked to do, ambush me with a story, jump out of the darkness and mug me with it. ''It's Ben,'' I'd whisper to my boyfriend, who'd groan himself back to sleep. I'd listen for however long he read, sometimes drifting off, or trying gamely to follow along and make appreciative noises.

title: Jordan Lifts Wizards And His M.V.P. Bid
description: Unthinkable and even provincial a few months ago, the subject must now be broached without laughing: Michael Jordan for most valuable player.

title: DataBank; Amid Conflicting Reports, Investors Cash In
description: Optimism about an economic recovery collided last week with concerns that stocks had become overvalued. With no major economic news to consider, investors cashed in on the market's recent rally.

description: TAPLINGER-Jean R., 89. Beloved husband of the late Marjorie. A renaissance man: linguist, artist, thespian, singer, inventor, mechanical engineer, son of a newspaper man. Assistant Commissioner, Boy Scouts of America. Survived by his beloved daughter Sandra Sobel, son Lee R. Taplinger, grandsons Geoffrey & Alan Sobel, sister Harriet Leland, brother Arthur Taplinger. title: A G.R.E. Primer
description: Applicants to graduate school know well the G.R.E. reasoning test, which is required for most programs. Far less familiar are the subject tests, which are given three times a year (next date, April 6) in eight disciplines: chemistry, computer science, literature in English, mathematics, physics, psychology, biology, and biochemistry/cell and molecular biology.

title: The Abyss Yawns
description: OVER nearly three decades, Lewis Fortner has tried to steer generations of students through the slalom course that is four years of college. In private counseling sessions, he has heard a lot of venting and obsessing, and he has learned that the famously anxious freshman year is only ''one of the major, articulating points in one's life.'' The other is senior year.

title: The Talk Of Kabul
description: I've got good news and bad news from Afghanistan. The good news is that America doesn't need a lot to satisfy its basic security interest here, which is that this distant land never again be so uncontrolled that a tumor like Osama bin Laden can grow in its midst and then metastasize into the world and threaten us. We really don't need much to get that -- just a loose Afghan federal government, some basic police and army units, a functioning economy and a few institutions.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: I was deeply touched by Amanda Stern's Lives column on Etan Patz (''Seeing Etan'') -- not only because I so clearly remember the tragedy of this small boy's disappearance, but also because of the beautifully rendered youthful colorblindness of the writer as a little girl.

title: The Nation; The Art of Turning a Sow's Ear Into a Silk Purse
description: THIS week the Bush administration moved closer to relaxing the rules for air-pollution controls on dirty power plants, and it moved in a California court to promote offshore oil drilling. It took an aggressive step forward for the nuclear power industry, declaring a Nevada mountain scientifically safe for the storage of nuclear waste. And it replaced a research program for auto fuel efficiency that was showing modest success for cars on the road with a more ambitious program that won't affect the car fleet for years, if ever, and in the meantime does nothing to cut gas consumption or promote efficiency.

title: A Chekhov Kind of Day Down by the Melancholy Sea
description: Weekdays between noon and 3 p.m., a happy little world unfolds at the edge of winter's greatest tribute to melancholy, the boardwalk at Coney Island. In fact, the players don't much notice the boardwalk.

description: IN retrospect, I probably should have tried harder to persuade my husband to go along. Las Vegas is the kind of place, I discovered, where you desperately want someone to elbow when the outrageous happens -- and it happens often.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: Rebecca Johnson's memoir of the superfibbing talk-show host Morton Downey Jr. (''Pants on Fire'') missed one of his biggest lies: his pose as a ''blue-collar bully'' was just as much of a fabrication as anything else he did. For all the chain-smoking, loudmouth, roughneck bravado, Downey was a child of privilege, American-style. Thanks to the good fortune of his Irish-tenor father, a recording star and sometime actor, Downey grew up in Park Avenue apartments, Hollywood villas and Palm Beach mansions, attended posh schools and spent his life swaddled in Kennedys. (Morton Downey Sr. was one of Joseph P. Kennedy's best friends.) His mother's sisters were the movie stars Constance Bennett and Joan Bennett, and an uncle was a French marquis. Downey the Demon? Try Downey the Dude.

description: Some of the dust has cleared in the closely watched governor's race in Pennsylvania. But there is still plenty of murk about the outcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTAG, JUDITH
description: MONTAG-Judith. Of Norwood, NJ (formerly of Tenafly). Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Devoted mother of Sanford, Rodney and Dawn, mother-in-law of Nancy & Sally, dear sister of Arline Price, loving grandmother of Andrew, Jenna, Alex and Julia. Services were held at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ (1-800522-0588). Should friends desire, contributions to Judith Montag Memorial Fund for Amyloidosis.

title: Transportation Hubs Need Regional Planning
description: Re ''Transportation Hub at Gabreski Debated'' [Jan. 6]: The idea of transportation hubs on the East End has come up not only in Southampton but in the towns of East Hampton and Riverhead. The traffic problems cannot be viewed in isolation, however, nor can they be adequately addressed by the traditional fixes of widening roads. What needs to occur is a thorough examination of current and future development, based on zoning regulations, demographic patterns and other key indicators.

title: WETLANDS CONSERVATION
description: Ducks Unlimited, a conservation group based in Tennessee, will work with the fish and wildlife agencies in New Jersey and Delaware to restore 15,000 acres of wetlands along the Delaware Bay, including about 10,000 acres along the Maurice, Salem and Cohansey Rivers and Alloways Creek in southern New Jersey. Using money from Ducks Unlimited and state and federal financing sources, $15 million will be spent to build dikes and other devices to return water levels to normal heights and better support birds and animals. All the wetlands are in state wildlife refuges. Karen DeMasters

title: 'Public Intellectuals'
description: This book reflects a long-standing interest of mine in the phenomenon of academics' writing outside their field or, what often turns out to be the same thing, writing for a general audience. But it has more immediate stimuli as well. One is the discussion, in my book on the Clinton impeachment fiasco, of the contemporaneous public commentary on that remarkable episode by philosophers, historians, and law professors. The commentary was of surprisingly low quality on the whole, but I made no effort in my book to account systematically for this surprising fact. Second, a review I did for the New York Times of public intellectual Gertrude Himmelfarb's book on the crisis (as she sees it) of contemporary American society provoked a surprising number of comments, many positive. It had struck a chord and led my longtime editor at Harvard University Press, Michael Aronson, to suggest that I attempt a fuller analysis of the deficiencies, as they seemed to me, in the treatment of political and social questions by "public intellectuals"—intellectuals who opine to an educated public on questions of or inflected by a political or ideological concern.

A new panel appointed by the president will get a crack at the question, in particular assessing accusations of market manipulation. Henri E. Cauvin

title: PESO PROBLEMS
description: After a 10-year experiment in which the peso and the dollar were used interchangeably, a bankrupt Argentina admitted that it could no longer afford the economic or social cost and devalued its currency by nearly 30 percent. The one-to-one policy, introduced by a Pernist government, initially brought economic stability by wiping out inflation. But it became a straitjacket, sapping the economy's strength and toppling presidents until a new Pernist government decided to unlink the currencies and default on Argentina's $141 billion public debt. title: 'Affairs of Honor'
description: Few national politicians were as anxious as Pennsylvania's Senator William Maclay—or at least, few were as diligent about documenting it. For throughout the entirety of his two-year term of office, Maclay memorialized his anxieties on the pages of his diary in lavish detail. Judging from his entries, Maclay's fears were legion. He worried about his oratorical performances on the Senate floor. He worried about the counterthrusts and jabs of his peers. He worried about his comportment at social events, particularly in the presence of the great George Washington. He worried about Washington himself, fearful that the new president would allow corrupt friends and advisers to surround him with monarchical pomp and splendor. He worried about the political implications of almost everything; French lace, fancy carriages, and formal ceremonies all reeked of monarchical corruption, threatening the foundations of the new republic. Keenly observant, and anxious about almost everything he saw, Maclay suffered his way through his brief senatorial career (fig. 2).

title: Refugees and Reparations in the Mideast
description: Before he died, my father gave me a piece of paper. He was the sole surviving member of his family, which had been wiped out in the Holocaust. After World War II, he settled in Israel, established a home and a family, and contributed in his modest way to the miracle of Jewish renaissance. That piece of paper was the only evidence that my father was the legal owner of a large house in the town of Hrubieshow in eastern Poland.

title: First Comes the Church
description: The typical New England church is white clapboard with a tall steeple, probably Congregational and built on the village square. Is there a typical New Jersey church? There is, according to Frank L. Greenagel, who wrote ''The New Jersey Churchscape: Encountering 18th- and 19th-Century Churches'' (Rutgers, $35). It is set in a remote plot (or was when it was built). The oldest churches were made of wood only when a congregation could not afford brick or stone. The building is not always recognizable as a church; it could be a schoolhouse or town hall. It may be one of several denominations -- the state was always more religiously diverse than New England. Mr. Greenagel spent five years researching and photographing many of the state's 1,100 churches from the 18th and 19th centuries, and his book includes 225 of them with commentary.

title: DUNBAR LEAVING

Colonel Dunbar was hired from the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1999 by Governor Christie Whitman to revamp a department criticized for racial profiling. Colonel Dunbar was criticized by some as acting too slowly to make changes, and morale in the department flagged as some of his changes were put into place. Mr. McGreevey said during his campaign that he wanted to bring in someone new.

description: Van der Kemp-Gerald. The Board of Directors and the Advisory Committee of The Versailles Foundation, Inc., Claude MonetGiverny, mourn the passing of Gerald Van der Kemp, after a long illness on December 28, 2001, in Paris, at the age of 89. Mr. Van der Kemp was curator of Versailles for many years and responsible for its restoration. Subsequently, he became curator and director of Claude Monet's home and garden at Giverny, which he restored, and it became a national monument. Through his efforts, The Versailles Foundation attracted to its honorary advisory committee, such individuals as the Hon. and Mrs. William McC. Blair, Jr., Baroness Edmond de Rothschild, the Hon. and Mrs. Douglas C. Dillon, The Hon. and Mrs. Evan G. Galbraith, Mrs. James M. Gavin, Mrs. Amory Houghton, The Hon. and Mrs. Arthur A. Houghton, Jr., Mrs. John N. Irwin, David Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, the Hon. and Mrs. Sargent Shriver, Mrs. Stuart Symington and Mrs. Edward Wheeler. Mr. Van der Kemp was an extraordinarily charming, gifted, brave and noble person, ably supported by his loving wife, Florence Van der Kemp, who was highly effective in raising funds from American patrons for The Versailles Foundation and Giverny. A requiem mass will be held for invitees on January 28, at the Chapelle Royale at The Chateau de Versailles. The Versailles Foundation, Inc. Florence Van der Kemp, President Barbara de Portago, Vice President Carl S. Forsythe, III, Secretary-Treasurer

title: A Film Noir Voice in Dreamy Standards and a Samba

The lower end is an aggressive blues bark that delivers scat improvisations in abruptly phrased volleys. At the top is an exotic, swerving falsetto. But it is Mr. Bey's middle register that defines his sound. A mellow, crooning baritone with a voluptuously rounded vibrato, it is a film noir voice: languid, mysterious and surpassingly beautiful. When Mr. Bey lingers over the lyrics of ''Little Girl Blue,'' you are reminded of the very young Nina Simone, who brought a similarly pure sound and intense moodiness to the Rodgers and Hart standard.

title: A Failure to Account
description: Harvey Pitt was recently quoted in Barron's as saying that ''there is nothing rotten with the accounting profession.'' What makes the assessment alarming, instead of just laughable, is that Mr. Pitt is the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Pitt was a prominent Washington litigator who represented Arthur Andersen and other major accounting firms before being appointed to the S.E.C. by President Bush. We can only hope that the latest revelations in the Enron saga will prompt him to change his view and to take on a forceful role in regulating his former clients and protecting the integrity of financial markets.

Courageous, fiercely independent, eternally youthful, passionate music lover and pianist, artist, voracious reader in English, her fourth language. title: Packers Put Owens And 49ers on Sabbatical

His 6-foot-3 size, sturdy build and sprinter speed make him a dangerous wide receiver. So how did the Green Bay Packers, en route to a 25-15 victory today over the 49ers in a wild-card playoff game, limit Owens to 4 catches for 40 yards and no touchdowns, his lowest yardage total since the Jets limited him to 38 yards in Week 3?

Enron contributed to the ballet, including a donation for a recent charity performance of ''The Nutcracker'' for poor children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLUCHAN, SEYMOUR
description: SLUCHAN - Seymour. Known professionally as Sy Slater, passed away on January 12, after a valiant struggle with cancer. Born in the Bronx, Sy was a lifelong New Yorker. He attended Stuyvesant H.S. and City College, and was a transportation specialist for over forty-five years, most recently as managing consultant to Premier Coach. Sy's wit, humor and intelligence enriched the lives of all of those he touched, who will deeply miss his quiet, steadfast selflessness. He is survived by his beloved wife Robin, their children Andrea and Michael, and his son Keith. Services Monday, January 14, 11:30 AM, at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In his memory, contributions may be made to Boys & Girls Harbor, 1 E. 104 St, NYC 10029, Attn: Development Office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEALS, JULIA
description: BEALS-Julia. Born in Boston, MA, and currently a resident of New York City and Ipswich, MA, died unexpectedly on Monday evening, January 7, 2002. She graduated from the Winsor School in 1952 and attended the New England Conservatory of Music Dance Program and completed the two-year acting course at the Stella Adler School of Theatre in New York City. She was an actress in the late 50's and 60's appearing Off-Broadway in Schnitzler's La Ronde among other productions. Equity Library Theatre presented her in her one woman play, Past Midnight; Past the Morning Star, based on the life and poetry of Emily Dickinson. In her later life, she continued her interest in the Arts. She is survived by three sisters: Jane B. Butler of Lenox, MA, Margaret H. Beals of New York City and Rockport, MA, and Isabella T. Frost of Brookline, MA, and Warren, VT; three nieces, Carolyn Butler, Amanda Frost and Annabel Frost; two nephews, Thomas Butler and Joshua Frost. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend memorial services on Friday, January 18, 2002, at 11 o'clock at the Church of Our Savior, 25 Monmouth Street, Brookline, MA. Burial will be private. Contact J.S. Waterman & SonsEastman-Waring 617-536-4110.

title: When Ken Burns Pilots the Twain Riverboat
description: Before Sam Clemens became Mark Twain, he tried out other pen names, including the irreverent Thomas Jefferson Snodgrass. No writer was ever more sardonic about American culture than Twain, and no filmmaker is more earnest than Ken Burns. In ''Mark Twain'' that makes for a maddening collision between Twain's ironic sensibility and Mr. Burns's familiar, sentimental style. Twain is forced into the Burns cookie cutter here, complete with the unironic sound of ''Sweet Betsy From Pike,'' fiddled relentlessly in the background. As Huck Finn once said: ''I can't stand it. I been there before.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lyndhurst: New Jersey Fire Clouds West Side
description: Unusually strong winds pushed heavy, acrid smoke from a New Jersey brush fire across the Hudson River and into the streets of the West Side of Manhattan yesterday. The fire spread from a compost pile at the Lyndhurst offices of the Nature's Choice Corporation, a recycling company, into the surrounding high grasses, where it smoldered for much of yesterday, officials said. The fire, first reported around 12:30 p.m., was contained by late afternoon, said Sgt. Scott Hild, of the Lyndhurst Police Department. The cause of the fire was not immediately clear, he said. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Man Shot in Antigay Incident, the Police Say
description: A man was shot in the chest on a Harlem street Friday night by one of two men who attacked him and his roommate and shouted antigay remarks at them, the police said. The incident was being investigated by the Hate Crime Task Force, and detectives were still searching yesterday for the two attackers.

title: Billion-Dollar Gimmick
description: Not even a week ago, Gov. George Pataki stood before a full house of state leaders and promised that when he put together this year's budget ''we will not use fiscal gimmicks to conceal reality.'' But all the while he was apparently planning the largest fiscal gimmick in New York State history. And Mr. Pataki wants to pull off this sleight of hand before the rest of his budget has seen the light of day. Even in an election year, this is no way to run a state government.

title: Rest Is for Winners, So Knicks Get Back to Work

That tells you two things about the state of the Knicks right now: first, Don Chaney is not quite the easy touch he has been made out to be; second, the Knicks are in worse shape than they ever were under Van Gundy's command.

title: The Fiscal State of the States
description: Legislatures in 39 states will begin their regular sessions this month facing fiscal challenges unseen in at least a decade. Some of the problem is of their own making; during the cash-flush 1990's, America's state legislators passed tax cuts totaling $35 billion. Yet they were also responding to public demand for increased spending and are the victims of a slowing economy. Now, forced to find solutions, they may provide Congress with some ideas for reducing the federal deficit.
