description: BULL-John S., 91. Of West Palm Beach, FL. Passed away at Hospice of Palm Beach County. A memorial service will be held at the Norwegian Seaman Church, Manhattan, NY, May 28, 2002 at 11 AM.

title: Ex-Sunbeam Executives to Pay $15 Million to Settle a Lawsuit
description: Albert J. Dunlap and other former executives of the Sunbeam Corporation have agreed to pay $15 million to settle a stockholder lawsuit accusing them of inflating stock prices.

title: MindShare Selected By Novartis
description: Novartis in Basel, Switzerland, which sells products under names like Ex-Lax, Gerber, Maalox and Triaminic, said yesterday that it had consolidated its worldwide media planning and buying assignments at offices of MindShare, part of the WPP Group.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: $1 Million In Ecstasy Seized
description: A man who was standing outside a Hoboken PATH station with a shopping bag containing $1 million worth of the drug Ecstasy has been arrested, the police said. They said the man, Moestafa Ali Baldew, 36, was visiting from the Netherlands, a major center for the production of Ecstasy, a powerful hallucinogen. He was carrying 25,000 Ecstasy pills, weighing 15 pounds, meant for a potential buyer, officials said. Mr. Baldew, who was arrested Thursday after a monthlong investigation, is being held on $2 million bail, the Hudson County prosecutor's office said.

title: Rangers to Play Without Messier and Johansson
description: After placing their captain, Mark Messier, and one of their top scorers, Andreas Johansson, on the injured list, the Rangers arrived in Columbus, Ohio, yesterday afternoon for tonight's back end of a home-and-home series with the Columbus Blue Jackets.

title: Diabetes Candidates Can Reduce the Risk
description: Most serious childhood diseases can now be prevented by vaccines, and most bacterial infections can be cured with antibiotics. But one condition now running rampant has no medical preventive or cure.

title: Urlacher Plays Key Role in the Bears' Turnaround
description: The blue-and-orange football jersey, with No. 54 below the name, has been one of the top-selling jerseys in the N.F.L., and it contrasts the black and blue administered by its namesake owner, one Brian Urlacher, the singular middle linebacker for the Chicago Bears.

title: Sports of The Times; Architect Gets 'Credit' For Knicks
description: EVERY few weeks there is another explanation for the rockslide of a basketball season that is currently under way at Madison Square Garden, another scapegoat passed off as revelation.

title: For Jets and Testaverde, It's a Matter of Money
description: Quarterback Vinny Testaverde hopes to finish his career with the Jets, and he said today that if they decided to release him it would be more for financial reasons than for his performance this season.

title: Wrongly Held in a Killing, a Man Is Freed
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., Jan. 14  A Long Island man was cleared of manslaughter charges today, more than five months after he was mistakenly arrested and jailed in the killing of a friend.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, HARRIET (NEE GOTTHELF)
description: PAUL-Harriet (nee Gotthelf). 1936-2002. Passed away suddenly on Jan. 12, 2002. Born and raised in New Rochelle, NY. Graduate of Boston University. Beloved wife of Marvin Paul, mother of Nina Paul, Caryn and Sam Kasmanoff, David and Joshua Paul. Grandmother to Nathan, Noah, & Anna Kasmanoff, beloved sister of Henry and Roanne Gotthelf and Bunny and Everett Kunin. Tributes may be made in her honor to Young Israel of North Woodmere. Harriet is deeply loved and shall be missed by all.

title: Television at a Terrorism Trial
description: In a letter to his mother from prison last November, Zacarias Moussaoui, thought to be the intended 20th hijacker in September's terror attacks, said he would prove his innocence at trial even though he expected American prosecutors to fabricate evidence against him. His case is scheduled for October in a federal court in Virginia. It should be televised so that the world can assess his claims as they are made and challenged.

title: Critic's Notebook: Making (and Breaking) an Opera Record; Domingo Celebrates Verdi With a Four-CD Set of All of His Tenor Arias
description: Sometimes it seems that the inexhaustible tenor Plcido Domingo is trying to fortify his place in the operatic pantheon simply by doing more than anyone else ever has. As of last week (and he keeps track), he had given 3,045 performances, not even including those as a conductor. He will turn 61 on Monday and already has commitments through 2005. He has sung 118 complete opera roles. He holds the record for opening nights at the Metropolitan Opera: 19 as of this season. (Enrico Caruso is in second place with 17.)

title: AMERICA WEST IS CLOSER TO RECEIVING GOVERNMENT LOAN
description: America West Holdings said yesterday that it had met government conditions to receive a $429 million loan for its airline as soon as this week, the first secured under a program to help airlines hurt by the Sept. 11 attacks. America West said it might have had to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection without the federal aid. The guarantee sets off more than $600 million in concessions negotiated by America West Airlines from aircraft makers and lessors, suppliers and local governments. The program provides the airline industry with $5 billion in cash aid and $10 billion in loan guarantees to help it recover from a decline in air travel and meet increased security costs.

title: African Leaders Press Mugabe on Abuses as Vote Nears
description: For hours at a meeting in Malawi, African leaders huddled behind closed doors today, pressing and prodding President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to abandon violence and intimidation as his deeply troubled country lurches toward election day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, PAULINE
description: GREENBAUM-Pauline, 102. January 12, 2002. We mourn the loss of our beloved Aunt Paulie, whose life was spent in service to God and her fellow human beings. Her vibrant optimism and joyous personality will be an inspiration to us all. Gloria, Mindy, Jean, and her many adoring nieces and nephews

title: Court Affirms Motorist Stops Based on Officers' Experience
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  Ruling in an Arizona case today, the Supreme Court unanimously reaffirmed the right of law enforcement people to stop vehicles when a number of circumstances and the officers' own experience raise suspicions of wrongdoing.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Giuliani, Pardners

title: Technology Briefing | Europe: Britain: Strong Year-End Spending
description: British consumers spent robustly in the year-end holiday season, according to figures from Sainsbury, the second-largest supermarket chain, and GUS, Europe's biggest catalog-shopping company and the owner of the Argos chain of stores. Sainsbury said sales increased 6.4 percent in the 12 weeks ended Jan. 5. GUS said sales at Argos's 480 British stores, which sell goods from toys to refrigerators, rose 17 percent in the 14 weeks ended Jan. 5. But at GUS's Burberry fashion business, sales were up only 1 percent. Shares in both Sainsbury and GUS fell after the figures were announced. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANCE, CYRUS R.
description: VANCE-Cyrus R. Devoted husband of Grace Sloane Vance. Beloved father of Elsie, Amy, Grace, Camilla and Cyrus. Proud grandfather of Simon and Clare Vance and Kemal Askar. Honored father-in-law of Peggy Vance, Brigadier General (ret.) William Holmes and Atilla Askar. Died on Saturday, January 12, 2002. Funeral arrangements will be private. Contributions may be made in his memory to the UN Trust Fund in Support of Special Missions (Fund Code SZ), Yale University, the Cardiovascular Institute at Mount Sinai Hospital, New York.

title: Corrections
description: Acredit in some copies on Sunday with the obituary of Cyrus R. Vance misspelled the name of a picture agency. It is Corbis-Bettmann, not Corbis-Bettman.

title: Tokyo Journal; The New Adults: Don't Be Fooled by the Kimonos
description: Filing into the ornate lobby of a luxury hotel here, a spanking new generation of adults almost appeared today to be outdoing themselves to live up to age-old images of young Japanese men and women.

title: Giuliani Loosened Ball Clubs' Leases Days Before Exiting
description: As part of his last-minute agreement with New York City's Major League Baseball teams to build each a new stadium, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani quietly amended each team's current lease, giving the Yankees the right to leave the city on 60 days' notice if the team does not get a new stadium, and releasing the Mets from paying the city large sums of advertising dollars.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Netro Expected To Buy AT&T Unit
description: The Netro Corporation, a wireless Internet start-up, is expected to announce today that it acquired broadband assets from AT&T Wireless, ending AT&T's $1 billion-plus foray into fixed wireless Internet access. Netro of San Jose, Calif., agreed to pay $16 million in cash and more than $20 million in stock for the operation's intellectual property licenses, equipment assets and more than 100 employees. AT&T Wireless decided last year to get out of the fixed wireless business after accumulating about $1.3 billion in charges from Project Angel, a flawed effort to provide fast wireless Internet connections. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Woodbridge: Woman Killed By School Bus
description: A school bus struck and killed a woman yesterday afternoon, the police said. The woman, Anna Adams, 79, was hit at the intersection of Inman and Cleveland Avenues around 4 p.m. No children were in the bus -- which is owned by the Rahway Bus Company -- at the time. The driver, Alfred Byington Jr., 69, was not injured. The accident is under investigation. ''I doubt very much that criminal charges would be applicable in this matter,'' said Sgt. Dennis Gorman of the Woodbury police. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: New Yorker Dies After Surgery To Give Liver Part to Brother
description: A healthy 57-year-old man died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan from surgical complications after an operation in which he donated part of his liver to provide a transplant for his brother. The brother, 54, is recovering.

title: Blair Enjoys Being an Olympic Spectator
description: Bonnie Blair hasn't changed much.

title: Pakistan Leader Reaffirms Support for the Kashmir Cause and People
description: Islamabad, Jan. 15  General Pervez Musharraf restated Pakistan's unbending support for "the Kashmir cause and the people of Kashmir" today as officials here and in New Delhi awaited the peace-making mission of the American Secretary of State, Colin Powell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWERLEIN, DURAND D. ''RANDY''
description: ZWERLEIN-Durand D. ''Randy'' of Babylon Village, L.I. On January 13, 2002. Beloved husband of Rayna Adler Zwerlein. Devoted father of Cory Zwerlein and Amanda Zwerlein. description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. Studies Ways To Help Minorities
description: Faced with mounting public cynicism over a billion-dollar industry, the National Collegiate Athletic Association introduced ideas today intended to maximize graduation rates while minimizing any adverse impact on minority athletes.

title: Tunnel Vision; Same Sway And Strum, More Blues
description: As stages for musical performance go, it could not be much worse. The acoustics stink. The lighting lacks all subtlety. The stage itself lists from side to side. Occasionally, the patrons smell. And every few minutes, someone interrupts to say something semi-intelligible about the Port Authority.

title: New Luxury Project in Works
description: PARIS  Just as French high fashion had seemed burnt out, with the retirement of Yves Saint Laurent, a phoenix may be rising from the ashes.

title: Bush Calls for Bipartisanship on Trade and Taxes
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15  President Bush ended a two-day tour of what he called "the spine of America" today with a call for members of both parties to end their arguments over trade policy and taxes, and agree on ways to spur the economy by increasing exports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANKOWITZ, KARIN (NEE BRUNS)

Donations may be made to the Gilda Club, Hackensack, NJ. Information: Blackley Funeral Home, 809 Broad Ave, Ridgefield, NJ.

title: Poets in Motion
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Phone Service Bids
description: India will open international long-distance calling licenses to bidders from Jan. 26, Pramod Mahajan, the communications minister, said. The government-owned Videsh Sanchar Nigam holds a monopoly on international long-distance calling until the end of March. The government has already announced that it plans to sell its 53 percent stake in Videsh Sanchar to a private partner. But given the slow pace of privatization, that is not expected to happen before Videsh Sanchar loses its monopoly on international long-distance calling. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: A Post-September 11 Mandate for Education
description: In the aftermath of September 11, images of two crashing towers seemed permanently etched in my memory, and all the tears of helplessness, despair, anger and confusion have proven to be inadequate relief. Too many innocent lives were lost, and even more lives permanently impacted as families, friends and others in this country and abroad have struggled to comprehend the tragedies. The site where the World Trade Center once stood is today a manifestation of both the worst and best in humankind. Paradoxically, ground zero is the scene of utter devastation at the hands of the meanest and ugliest of human intentions; yet at the same time, it is a testament to the sheer resilience of the human spirit and the capacity of the heart of Americans to respond with a groundswell of unity, volunteerism, patriotism and unconditional respect for others. Our task is to honor that spirit and be guided by it.

Great-grandmother of Rachel, Abigail and Louis. Services today, 1:15 PM at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York. Contributions can be made to The Care Center of Martin's Run, 11 Martin's Run, Media, PA 19063.

title: E*Trade Net Up From a Year Ago
description: The E*Trade Group, a leading online broker, said its fourth-quarter net income rose from a year ago, helped by new bank and brokerage accounts and lower costs.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Monday, 3,114 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

description: KAHN-Geraldine. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our dedicated benefactor, Jacalyn Weinstein. To Jackie, Marty, and to the entire family, our heartfelt sympathy. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: A Small Package Containing Partygoers Both Happy and Sad
description: Six young dancers made attractive debuts in Richard Tanner's ''Soire'' when the New York City Ballet presented this little work on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: INSIDE
description: Chaotic Time for Coaches

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Searchers Find Avalanche Victims
description: Rescuers found the bodies of a father and daughter who were killed in an avalanche over the weekend while snowmobiling near Paxson, but they were unable to recover them. The father, Donny Rice, 35, and his daughter, Jessica, 13, both of Fairbanks, died on Saturday; their bodies were found the next day. Susan Rice, 38, a relative of Donny Rice, was injured in the avalanche, but was rescued by her husband, Wesley Rice. The deaths bring the number of avalanche deaths in Alaska this winter to five, one more than last season. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Joy in Rwanda: Signing On With the Gorillas
description: It was a soaring, magical, improbable moment, like a fairy godmother turning your pumpkin into a chariot, or Sir Ian McKellen inviting you to his Oscar party. Only better.

title: Miscellany
description: Unilever signed a multimedia marketing alliance with AOL Time Warner, New York, to advertise its brands, including Dove and Good Humor. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Age Burnishes a Balanchine Work With Soft Lightness
description: George Balanchine's ''Kammermusik No. 2'' has grown lighter and prettier-looking over the years. The once intense, erotically charged ballet looked positively frisky in a performance by the New York City Ballet on Saturday night at the New York State Theater.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Lynn Ponton; An Expert's Eye on Teenage Sex, Risk and Abuse
description: Even the best parent-teenager relationships have their shares of disconnects, and it is hardly surprising that they often occur on the subject of sex. Beyond a certain point, parents can only guess what their children are thinking, feeling and doing -- and hope that they are doing it safely. But Dr. Lynn Ponton knows.

title: Personal Assessments Shift After Sept. 11
description: Have Americans become a more sensitive lot since Sept. 11, as some predicted would be case? That may be, at least based on what Americans themselves are saying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERCES, PAUL N.
description: PERCES-Paul N. Of Manhattan and Monterey, MA, on January 10, 2002, at home. Husband of Marjorie. Father of Peter P. Berke and of Becky, 1963-1983. Memorial service at 4PM, Saturday, January 26, Ethical Culture Society, NYC.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 2 Sentenced In Pyramid Scheme
description: A federal judge sentenced two executives yesterday in a $160 million pyramid scheme that defrauded more than 7,000 people over 10 years. Anthony Gianninoto, 54, was sentenced to 46 months and Eileen Lane, 49, was sentenced to 30 months. Mr. Gianninoto was the comptroller and Ms. Lane was a data processing supervisor with the First Interregional Equity Corporation., which is defunct. Federal prosecutors said the company sold phony leases for office equipment. Both defendants received leniency, their lawyers said, because of their cooperation, which led to the convictions last year of three members of the Goettlich family, who controlled the company. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The trade publications Advertising Age and Adweek named their agencies of the year for 2001. Advertising Age, part of Crain Communications, made these selections: Global agency of the year, BBBO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group; global media agency of the year, Carat, part of the Aegis Group; and United States agency of the year, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group. Adweek, part of VNU, made these selections: Global agency of the year, also BBDO; United States agency of the year, Deutsch, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: The Shape of Snores to Come?
description: Don't like snoring? Then, a new study suggests, you may want to look closely at the shape of a potential mate's head.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Plan To Fix Railroads
description: Battered by public dismay over the collapsing railway system, the government announced a 10-year, $48 billion rebuilding plan to restore safety and efficiency to the network, which was broken up and sold off in an ill-conceived privatization during the 1990's. The system has been plagued by crashes, delays, emergency track replacements, shortage of drivers and aging of rolling stock and equipment, and the collapse in service has become the principal complaint of Britain's voters. The spending figure is 15 percent higher than a provisional figure given last year, and the government hopes for matching private investment to meet the estimated $100 billion that the modernization program is expected to cost. The Rail Passengers Council said the plan offered only a ''glimmer of hope'' and said the industry remains dangerously underfinanced. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: A Defender of Children, but Never Defensive
description: THE mea culpa does not come naturally to this chubby-faced city official, a Brooklyn minister in his weekend life and a ''barefoot boy from Mississippi'' in his early life, now on invisible tenterhooks amid unpacked boxes in the prime corner office at 150 Williams Street.

title: On Road Trip, Bush Offers Jokes on Pretzels and Serious Talk on Trade Issues
description: President Bush traveled along the Mississippi River today to argue that increasing international trade is one way out of the American recession, while nursing and joking about the wounds he suffered Sunday night when he fainted after choking on a pretzel.

title: Pakistan Has Rounded Up 1,430 As Part of Plan to Curb Militants
description: The Pakistani government has rounded up 1,430 people across the country in recent days and sealed 390 offices of militant groups as part of a widening crackdown on extremists ordered by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, a senior police official said today.

title: AT&T and Others Brace for Trouble From Argentina
description: Argentina's currency devaluation and debt default could create problems for some of the biggest United States and European telecommunications companies.

title: Fox Is a Leading Candidate to Become the Panthers' Coach
description: John Fox, the Giants' defensive coordinator, spent yesterday meeting with owners and executives of the Carolina Panthers and is among the leading candidates to become the team's head coach, according to N.F.L. officials. The Panthers, however, are continuing their search and will also contact Tony Dungy, who was dismissed last night as the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' coach. Published reports have also linked Louisiana State Coach Nick Saban to the job search.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about measures being considered by the government to reduce the risk of terrorism from small planes misstated the maximum number of identification codes available for craft to be assigned for tracking by air traffic controllers. It is 4,096, not 2,401.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Corning Reports Bigger Loss
description: Corning, the maker of optical fiber and cable used in communications networks, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss would be wider than expected because of higher-than-expected costs and write-downs. Excluding expenses from layoffs and write-downs, Corning said, it expected to lose 28 cents to 29 cents a share. The company had expected a loss of 20 cents to 25 cents a share. Corning said it had pretax expenses of $90 million after it permitted employees to sell stock they had received as compensation. It recorded $60 million in pretax costs from writing off inventory and $28 million from writing off an investment in research. Shares fell 27 cents, to $9.81, then slid as low as $9.56 in after-hours trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, SOL
description: BROWNSTEIN-Sol. Elliot and Marguerite and Howard and Roz would like to say that we will always think of you and love you. And Dad, you were the greatest and we will never forget your love and kindness to all of us. Much love and devotion.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Globix Plans To Seek Protection
description: The Globix Corporation, an Internet service provider whose market value has fallen to $5.87 million from almost $1 billion in 1999, said yesterday that it would seek bankruptcy protection. Globix said it expected to reorganize quickly because holders of more than 51 percent of $600 million in debt and the company's preferred shareholders had agreed to a restructuring plan. The company, based in New York, will reduce debt by $480 million as bondholders will exchange $600 million for $120 million in secured notes and a ''substantial'' equity position.

description: Taking a new approach in their investigation into the anthrax attacks, federal agents examined photocopying machines on Friday at Rutgers University for possible links to the anthrax mailer, a scientist at Rutgers said.

description: The Israeli authorities demolished nine Palestinian homes in East Jerusalem today on the ground that they had been built without permits, days after the army razed dozens of refugee dwellings in the Gaza Strip, drawing criticism at home and abroad.

title: Sunken Fires Menace Land and Climate
description: Fires are burning in thousands of underground coal seams from Pennsylvania to Mongolia, releasing toxic gases, adding millions of tons of heat-trapping carbon dioxide to the atmosphere and baking the earth until vegetation shrivels and the land sinks.

title: Putting an End to Warlord Government
description: In defeating the Taliban, American policymakers have had to make hard choices in the struggle to reconcile sometimes conflicting military and political goals. Next week, when they meet in Tokyo, the United States and other donor nations will face equally hard choices in deciding how to help rebuild Afghanistan.

title: Aspirin's Heart Benefits Are Endorsed
description: An influential government task force today granted its highest endorsement to the practice of taking aspirin to help people at increased risk of heart attacks.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man To Shut Personal Charity
description: An Irvington man, conforming to an order by a federal judge, agreed to stop soliciting charitable contributions for thousands of body bags needed after the attack on the World Trade Center. The man, Bobby Ellis, 52, did not plead guilty to any crime, but prosecutors said he had no connection to any official relief effort. Judge John W. Bissell of Federal District Court in Newark signed an order yesterday barring Mr. Ellis from soliciting contributions through the mail for the Brotherhood Emergency Collection, the charity he had created. Mr. Ellis, who represented himself in court, could not be reached for comment because he does not have a published telephone number. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Court Upholds Agency's Separate Right to Sue Over Workplace Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The Supreme Court ruled today, in a case with consequences for workers and employers across the country, that a federal agency can file lawsuits on behalf of employees who have signed away their own rights to sue their companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, IRVING
description: GOLDSTEIN-Irving. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre, mourns the loss of its esteemed member Irving Goldstein and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Joy and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Ferne Skiba, President

title: Justices Divided, Searching For Drama
description: Poor Supreme Court. The White House got ''The West Wing,'' the Supremes are stuck with ''First Monday,'' a cheesy new dramatic series on CBS whose precedents can be found in almost every television clich. But who knows? Audiences may tune in because it's so familiar it already feels like a bad habit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBART, IRVING
description: WEISBART-Irving. In Woodbridge, Connecticut on January 13, 2002, Irving Weisbart, formerly of New York and West Palm Beach, died at age 95. He was predeceased by Ethel, his beloved wife of 56 years and is survived by his loving children Bertrand and Martha, of Orange, Connecticut & Martin and Karen of Manhasset, New York. He leaves cherished grandchildren Laura and Ken, Paul, Steven and Shami, David and Megan, Michael, Lauren and Elyssa, and is also survived by great grandchildren Zachary, Evan, Noah and Rachel. A kind, caring, loving, giving man, may his memory be a blessing. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, January 16 at 11:00 AM, the Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, 543 George Street, New Haven. Contributions may be made to Connecticut Hospice, Congregation Mishkan Israel or the charity of one's choice.

title: Health Bill Is Rejected In Assembly
description: The Democratic majority in the State Assembly rejected Gov. George E. Pataki's request to pass a complex health care bill today that would give raises to hospital workers, financing them in part with a $1 billion windfall from an insurance company.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Friday about a New Jersey judge's decision to give the owner of a tiger preserve more time to come up with an alternative to the state's plan to move her animals to a Texas sanctuary misspelled her surname in some copies. She is Joan Byron-Marasek, not Bryon-Marasek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLDERMAN, EDITH (NEE GOLDSMITH)
description: OLDERMAN-Edith (nee Goldsmith), died on January 10th, 2002. She will be missed by daughters, Ruth Deutsch & Natalie Kartman, grandchildren, Lauren Deutsch, Robin Herman, Naomi Berkowitz, Lynn Penland, 6 great-grandchildren, brother, Arthur Goldsmith, sister, Florence Kahn, and many nieces and nephews. Carol and Peter Kornfeld

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, MURRAY
description: LIPTON-Murray. Age 97, on January 13, 2002. Manufacturer of men's outercoats. Executive Vice President and Partner with Robert Hall Clothes. Beloved husband of the late Lillie. Loving father of David and Harry and father-in-law of Helen & Arlene. Dear grandfather of Eric and Douglas. Graveside service Tuesday, 1 PM, Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Trip To Jerusalem Barred
description: A court rejected an attempt by a Coptic Christian to overturn a ban issued by the Interior Ministry against his traveling to East Jerusalem to pray at Christian sites. The court cited dangers created by the Israeli occupation of Palestinian land and noted that the Coptic patriarch, Pope Shenouda III, had banned the faithful from praying in East Jersualem while it remained under Israeli control. Although Egypt has a peace treaty with Israel, it has discouraged normalization of ties and requires permits for anyone wishing to go there. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Miller Doles Out Power To a Clamoring Council
description: When Gifford Miller finished his acceptance speech and stepped from behind the lectern into his new life as speaker of the City Council last week, more than a security detail and chauffeured municipal car suddenly awaited him. He also faced the daunting task of completing the jigsaw puzzle of the Council's hierarchy, fitting together the competing desires of 50 other members and those of the behind-the-scenes power brokers who helped nudge him into office.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ask Jeeves Buys Software Company
description: Ask Jeeves, the online question-and-answer service in Emeryville, Calif., has acquired Octopus Software, which is closely held, to improve its customer-service software. Terms were not disclosed. Octopus's software will be combined with Jeeves's. The combined product will permit companies to answer questions and complete transactions, the company said. Ask Jeeves shares fell 14 cents, to $3.56.

title: Weary in Victory, MacCulloch Relishes Game-Winning Role
description: The last time Todd MacCulloch could recall playing the hero in the closing seconds of a game came during his college days. He still could retrace the details -- how he hit a go-ahead shot, then blocked a layup by an Oregon point guard, securing a victory for his Washington Huskies.

title: Q & A
description: The Cold, Clear Air

title: New Side to Face-Recognition Technology: Identifying Victims
description: Since Sept. 11, discussion of the disputed technology of face recognition has focused on its potential for identifying criminals and terrorists -- and for invading citizens' privacy. But in England, the police are pursuing a different path: they want to use facial recognition software to identify crime victims.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Foot-and-Mouth Disease Gone
description: The government announced that the country was officially free of foot-and-mouth disease, almost a year after the first cases were diagnosed at a slaughterhouse and adjoining farm in Essex. The highly contagious disease, which rampaged through Britain and resulted in the slaughter of 5.9 million sheep, cows and pigs, has cost the country billions of dollars in eradication expenses, in compensation payments to farmers, and in lost tourism and export revenues. But the announcement is ''not the end of the story or the end of the risk for the disease,'' said Lord Whitty, the agriculture minister, adding that it will be months before the British meat and livestock export markets return to normal. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Chief Used Stock to Repay Enron Loan, Lawyer Says
description: Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman and chief executive of Enron, used his company stock to repay a loan sometime last year, a lawyer for Enron disclosed last night. That indicated that Mr. Lay had shed more of his holdings than had previously been disclosed.

title: Private Sector, Public Doubts
description: The emerging story of Enron's collapse is about an abuse of corporate power. Top Enron executives were allowed to sell off hundreds of millions of dollars of the doomed company's stock before it turned worthless -- at which point employees and most shareholders took devastating losses. Federal and state investigators are now focusing on possible criminal misconduct, yet the more interesting question is whether Enron's collapse will undermine public trust in business.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Really Cool Parrot

title: McCall Seeks Strict Limits On Pataki's Role in State Ads
description: Attacking Gov. George E. Pataki for spending millions of dollars in state money on advertisements featuring himself, Comptroller H. Carl McCall today called for strict limits on the practice.

title: At Schering, Optimism And Problems
description: To hear Schering-Plough executives tell it, the future is bright.

description: LAWRENCE-Scott Andrew. January 15, 1949 to August 2, 1985. We miss you every day. Love and adore you forever. Mother, Sara, Joshua

title: Changes in Top Management At Automotive Parts Maker
description: Magna International, an auto parts maker, named Belinda C. Stronach, its chief executive and daughter of the chairman, Frank Stronach, to the additional post of president today after James Nicol quit.

title: Britain Turns Aside Criticism About U.S. Treatment of Detainees
description: LONDON, Jan. 15  Britain, Washington's main ally in the war in Afghanistan, today turned aside charges from human rights groups, lawyers and members of Parliament that the treatment of terror suspects being transported to a prison on the United States naval base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba violated international standards.

title: U.S. Loses Trade Case to Europeans on Offshore Tax Havens
description: The United States lost its final appeal today in a dispute with Europe over tax policies. The ruling is considered all but certain to renew trans-Atlantic trade tensions and could cost American companies billions of dollars in higher taxes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Consultant Criticizes Yale and Its Unions
description: A consultant that Yale University and its two major labor unions chose to study Yale's rancorous labor relations issued a report yesterday that severely criticized both the university and the unions.

title: Peace Talks Are Revived By an Accord In Colombia
description: Colombian rebels and the government of President Andrs Pastrana came to a final-hour agreement today to restart stalled peace talks and avoid a wider war, diplomats who brokered the deal announced.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Hall Park To Reopen
description: City Hall Park, closed since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, will reopen to the public today, officials said. The park has always attracted sandwich eaters, pigeon watchers and tourists, but the protracted removal of Consolidated Edison electrical lines made the area dangerous for a time. The decision to reopen was made by the city's Parks and Police Departments in consultation with the Office of Emergency Management and Con Edison, a spokeswoman for the Parks Department said. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Husband Sought in Killings Is Seized on Mexican Coast
description: Two days after he was placed on the F.B.I.'s list of the 10 most-wanted fugitives, a Michigan man accused of killing his wife and three children on the Oregon coast was captured Sunday night in Tulum, the Mexican coastal town of Maya ruins, the federal authorities said today.

title: Dolan Again Raises Bid for Red Sox
description: In the ongoing saga of the sale of the Boston Red Sox, two losing bidders played a game of ''Can You Top This?'' yesterday. While the Massachusetts attorney general tried to induce the winning bidder to increase the money it would pay the majority owner, Charles F. Dolan and Miles Prentice made new bids, which would pay significantly more money to the majority owner.

title: Doctors' New Practices Offer Deluxe Service for Deluxe Fee
description: In a city full of medical innovations, this one raised some eyebrows. Two respected physicians announced plans to open a medical practice that charges patients $4,000 a year on top of the medical costs covered by their health insurance.

title: New China-Taiwan Battle: 3 Words on Passports
description: At one level, it was a minor change: on Sunday, the government of Taiwan, formally known as the Republic of China, said it was planning to add the words ''Issued in Taiwan'' to its green passport cover. Currently it reads simply ''Republic of China.''

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Legislature Considers Transportation Issues
description: The Legislature convened in Olympia, with transportation, the issue that required three special sessions last year, still topping the agenda. Gov. Gary Locke, a Democrat, has proposed an $8.5 billion package to improve the state's transportation infrastructure. It would increase the gasoline tax by 9 cents over three years. Democrats control both chambers of the Legislature by slim margins, but Republicans have said any increase in taxes should be put to a public vote. Lawmakers must also deal with a $1.25 billion gap in the state's budget. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telefnica Executive Named
description: Telefnica has reshuffled management at the company's Admira media arm after its losses more than doubled in the first nine months of the year. Telefnica, Spain's leading telephone company, named Luis Abril, left, general secretary of Telefnica, as the top executive of the media unit, after Juan Jos Nieto. Telefnica has spent more than eight billion euros to create one of Spain's largest media groups to sell programming to its Internet and phone clients. Analysts and investors have questioned the media acquisitions as losses mount.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOSNOW, MORRIS
description: SOSNOW-Morris. Pa, two years have passed. Take care of Nana. We miss you both. Love, Mindy, Ron, Dari, Eric and Perri

description: One of the things that we Americans are finally waking up to since Sept. 11 is the degree to which we are disliked and resented around the world.

title: Berlusconi Says Italy Won't Take Europe's Orders
description: Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, said in a blunt speech in Parliament today that his country takes orders from no one, including its European partners.

"Primal Scream" was on the soundtrack, overlaid with Marlon Brando's "The Wild Ones" talking up a good time. And out strode models in biker jackets with "Versace," "La Medusa"or even "Donatella" written on the back in blood-red Dracula script.

description: In his inaugural address as the 51st governor of New Jersey, Gov. James E. McGreevey challenged New Jersey's citizens and lawmakers today to help trim the state's budget, to focus on improving education and to remain vigilant about maintaining safety following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRUCE, WILLIAM JAMES
description: BRUCE-William James. A memorial service will be held 1:00 PM January 17, 2002, at the CCUN Chapel, 777 UN Plaza (44th Street & First Avenue), New York City.

title: Cyrus Vance, New Yorker
description: Cyrus Vance, who died on Saturday, was best known for long and distinguished service in various important posts in Washington. These included nearly four years as Jimmy Carter's secretary of state -- a job from which he resigned to protest what he regarded as a foolhardy and diplomatically counterproductive attempt to rescue American hostages in Iran. Such acts of conscience are rare in the upper echelons of government, but in Mr. Vance's case it seemed a fitting response given his principled approach to everything he did.

description: FISHBONE-Harold, M.D. On January 13, 2002. Beloved husband of Anita, devoted father of Alan and Douglas, loving brother of Gerald and Ivor. Pette Scholarship Fund'' at St. Joan of Arc Elementary School, 370 SW 3rd Street, Boca Raton, FL 33432. For more information, contact Babione Funeral Home, 561-395-8787.

description: Here in the bleakest winter of the Winter Garden, life is conceivable once more.

description: TANAKA-Ikko. The Art Directors Club mourns the loss of its esteemed member and Hall of Fame Laureate, dean of Japanese graphic designers and one of the world's greats. His design genius was matched by an enormous generosity of spirit.

title: Astacio Has Become Mets' Main Target
description: The Mets were always interested in Pedro Astacio when he pitched for the Colorado Rockies, and now Astacio is an important figure in the completion of the Mets' winter makeover.

title: The Wounds Linger, on Both Sides
description: As they do their best to slip out of the public gaze, James Kenna and John Hogan will be among the last in New Jersey's racial-profiling drama to try to leave it behind.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about strong holiday sales at Barnes & Noble and Borders books misstated the period for sales beyond the holiday season reported by Barnes & Noble. They were for the 48 weeks ended Jan. 5 -- not the four months ended on that date. For the 48 weeks, sales at superstores rose 8.4 percent, to $3.10 billion, over the previous year. Sales at B. Dalton fell 15.2 percent, to $291.2 million, and sales at its GameStop video game stores rose 50.8 percent, to $1.03 billion.

title: Fighting Urinary Tract Infections With a Phone Call
description: Painful bladder infections, which send millions of women to doctors each year, can often be treated safely with just a phone call and a prescription.

title: MIRAVANT SHARES SKID ON DRUG'S DISAPPOINTING TESTS
description: Miravant Medical Technologies said its leading product, a drug to treat a major cause of blindness, did not work in a late-stage study, setting off a 75 percent decline in its stock price yesterday. Shares of Miravant, an unprofitable company that specializes in light-activated drugs and has no other products ready for the market, dropped $7.31, to $2.44 a share. ''It's a major setback for them -- this was their most advanced product,'' Fariba F. Ghodsian, a health care analyst at Roth Capital Partners, said. The company will work with its partner, the Pharmacia Corporation, to determine whether to continue developing the drug, known as SnET2, a Miravant spokeswoman, Laurens Lichty, said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: XL CAPITAL LTD., Hamilton, Bermuda, an insurer, acquired a minority interest in closely held Stanfield Capital Partners, New York, an investment company specializing in debt obligations. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: New Domain Suffix Begins
description: A new suffix for Internet addresses, .name, will begin today. The operator of the new domain, Global Name Registry, said about 60,000 World Wide Web and e-mail addresses ending in .name that were registered through Dec. 18 will begin working today, while a second batch, registered from Dec. 19 through Jan. 14, will be activated by the end of the month. The .name extension is one of seven domains being added to the Internet's address system. For $30 to 35 a year, individuals can register Web sites with addresses like www.john.smith.name and receive e-mail messages at an address like john@smith.name. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: 92 SHOPPING CENTERS ARE BEING SOLD FOR $354 MILLION
description: The New Plan Excel Realty Trust said yesterday that it agreed to buy 92 strip mall shopping centers from the CenterAmerica Property Trust for about $354 million. New Plan, based in New York, also said it would assume $300 million in debt. The company last year sold its apartment business to focus on strip malls anchored by grocery and drugstores. In the purchase from CenterAmerica, which is also based in New York, New Plan will increase its holdings by 33 percent, adding properties with 10.4 million square feet of space, mostly in the Houston and Dallas areas. CenterAmerica is majority owned by a real estate fund of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

title: Hounds Foiled as Supreme Court Takes Up Case of Intruder
description: All anyone at the Supreme Court knows is that a fox ran past a startled police officer and into the underground garage just before dawn on Sunday, a flagrant act of trespass that was captured by a security camera. Perhaps more to the point, no one saw it run out.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Internet Magazine Closes
description: Internet Week, a weekly print magazine that reported on Internet business and strategy, stopped publishing on Jan. 7, a spokeswoman for CMP Media, the magazine's publisher, said. The spokeswoman, Alexandra Raine, said layoffs were inevitable but some workers would probably find jobs at the company's 30 or so other technology publications. Internet Week was founded in 1984 as Communications Week and changed its name to Internet Week in 1998. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKINS, NORMAN
description: ATKINS-Norman. Prominent baritone of the New York City Opera, and Cantor Emeritus Metropolitan Synagogue of NY, former president Emerson, NJ Board of Education. Beloved husband of the late Mildred, devoted father of Jay Atkins, Bruce Atkins, and Andrea Atkins Hessekiel, cherished fatherin-law of Sherri Atkins, Debra Atkins, and David Hessekiel. Loving grandfather of Jessica, Rachel, Alexis, and Scott Atkins, and Kira and Sophie Hessekiel. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Wednesday 10 A.M. Should friends desire, contributions to The American Heart Association or a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Selig Invites Fehr To Address Owners
description: Major League Baseball owners and players may yet erupt in one of their typical labor wars, but for now they are maintaining a tone so civil that for the first time ever, a commissioner has invited a union leader to address the club owners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DER KEMP, GERALD
description: Van der Kemp-Gerald. The Board of Directors and the Advisory Committee of The Versailles Foundation, Inc., Claude MonetGiverny, mourn the passing of Gerald Van der Kemp, after a long illness on December 28, 2001, in Paris, at the age of 89. Mr. Van der Kemp was curator of Versailles for many years and responsible for its restoration. Subsequently, he became curator and director of Claude Monet's home and garden at Giverny, which he restored, and it became a national monument. Through his efforts, The Versailles Foundation attracted to its honorary advisory committee, such individuals as the Hon. and Mrs. William McC. Blair, Jr., Baroness Edmond de Rothschild, the Hon. and Mrs. Douglas C. Dillon, The Hon. and Mrs. Evan G. Galbraith, Mrs. James M. Gavin, Mrs. Amory Houghton, The Hon. and Mrs. Arthur A. Houghton, Jr., Mrs. John N. Irwin, David Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, the Hon. and Mrs. Sargent Shriver, Mrs. Stuart Symington and Mrs. Edward Wheeler. Mr. Van der Kemp was an extraordinarily charming, gifted, brave and noble person, ably supported by his loving wife, Florence Van der Kemp, who was highly effective in raising funds from American patrons for The Versailles Foundation and Giverny. A requiem mass will be held for invitees on January 28, at the Chapelle Royale at The Chateau de Versailles. The Versailles Foundation, Inc. Florence Van der Kemp, President Barbara de Portago, Vice President Carl S. Forsythe, III, Secretary-Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTAUER, RUDOLF M.
description: LITTAUER-Rudolf M. Of Poughquag, N.Y. and Sarasota, FL. Born Oct 29, 1905, died January 8, 2002 at his winter home in Sarasota. Beloved husband of 63 years of Hilde (nee Apt) and father of Andrew and of Sibyl Weil (deceased). His family and many friends will miss him and cherish his memory.

title: Bloomberg Frees the Press
description: For New York journalists, the administration of Michael R. Bloomberg shows promise of being a liberating experience. We have never had a tougher time than under the authoritarian rule of Rudolph W. Giuliani. When I say that the Giuliani administration was the most repressive regime for the press in the city in half a century, I am speaking from experience. I have covered City Hall since 1949. Fortunately, we see signs that Mayor Bloomberg will lift restrictions and restore the freedoms we have lost over the last eight years.

title: Union Labor Pays Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Pleads for Afghan Aid While U.S. Jets Raid Compound
description: With Afghanistan's interim government unable to pay its workers and foreign aid only trickling in, the United Nations made an impassioned plea today to foreign governments, asking them to increase their financial donations.

title: Technology Briefing | Australia: Australia: Mine Bid Advances
description: Newmont Mining has cleared another regulatory hurdle as it closes in on its takeover target, Normandy Mining of Australia. The Foreign Investment Review Board, which must clear plans by international bidders for Australian companies, approved Newmont's proposal. Next month, shareholders in Newmont will consider the takeover of Normandy, which is also being pursued by AngloGold of Britain. Newmont, based in Denver, has challenged AngloGold's proposal for Normandy before the Australian Takeovers Panel. Newmont wants the panel to rule that a seven-day extension of AngloGold's offer made late last week is misleading. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: In the N.F.L., Winning Just Isn't Enough
description: This is the chaotic and perilous climate that exists for pro football coaches: for many owners, regular-season success is no longer sufficient. With parity running rampant across the National Football League and surprise teams surfacing in the last two Super Bowls, owners and fans yearn not only for success at the highest level, but a more entertaining brand of football as well.

title: Court Affirms Motorist Stops Based on Officers' Experience
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  Ruling in an Arizona case today, the Supreme Court unanimously reaffirmed the right of law enforcement people to stop vehicles when a number of circumstances and the officers' own experience raise suspicions of wrongdoing.

title: Wines of the Week
description: The next time youre seeking Italian comfort, do it American-style by uncorking a bottle of sangiovese. Sangiovese grapes thrive outside Italy in places like Californias Napa Valley where they grow on hillsides and bask in the sun, just like they do in Tuscany. Californian versions tend to be more fruity and softer than their Italian brethren, but the best ones maintain the grapes zesty, food-friendly acidity, dusty floral aromas, and long, black pepper finish.

title: Among Newest of the New
description: New music, once thought to challenge the establishment, has become part of the establishment: its champions are critics and conservatories. An example: Ensemble X, a group of faculty performers from Cornell University and Ithaca College, founded in 1997 and devoted to contemporary music, which played at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night.

title: Henry Reuss, Liberal in Congress, Dies at 89
description: Henry S. Reuss, for 28 years a leading liberal in Congress on issues from interest rates to pollution to Watergate to aid for New York City, died on Saturday in San Rafael, Calif. He was 89.

title: French Judge Investigating Chirac Quits Bench
description: The French judge who led the main investigations into allegations of corruption against President Jacques Chirac, but was then removed from the case last fall, has resigned from the bench, saying his work has been sabotaged at every turn.

title: The Neediest Cases; Help Points Troubled Man Toward Bachelor's Degree
description: Peter Beltre lives by his favorite expression.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 5 about Donald T. DiFrancesco's final days as acting governor of New Jersey misspelled the given name of the state senator who briefly succeeded him. He is John O. Bennett, not Jon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBERHARD, LESLIE
description: EBERHARD-Leslie, 50. Died of complications from cancer, in Los Angeles, California on Saturday. He was a noted TV and theatrical writer. He wrote for many Saturday morning TV series, including Saved By The Bell, USA High and Malibu, CA. With collaborator David Levy, he wrote many theatrical musicals such as ''Jolson'', ''All Dressed Up'', ''Hey Ma'' and ''Jeckyl and Hyde'', (not the Broadway version), which is currently touring. He is survived by his mother, Theresa Eberhard of St. Louis, his sister, Joanne Kalemis and his longtime partner, actor Loren Freeman. A service will be held in St. Louis this week, and an additional memorial will be held in Los Angeles.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Enron Employee Warned Chairman About Accounting

title: MindShare Selected by Novartis
description: Novartis in Basel, Switzerland, which sells products under names like Ex-Lax, Gerber, Maalox and Triaminic, said yesterday that it had consolidated its worldwide media planning and buying assignments at offices of MindShare, part of the WPP Group ( news/quote ).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, LEONARD N.
description: ZIMMERMAN-Leonard N. On January 13, 2002. Knowledgeable of world affairs, concerned for people everywhere, a teacher, a scientist, & a wonderful storyteller, he found immense joy in family, the garden, music, & conversation. He would want us to ''celebrate life,'' and to ''do the right thing.'' He will be remembered always by his wife Rima, sons Erik and Raul, daughter Leda, and his seven grandchildren.

title: Surprising Defeat May Help Jaspers
description: Manhattan's great run is over, and perhaps it is for the best. With their winning streak ended at 12, the Jaspers can now focus on winning the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, where they are suddenly the team to beat after being picked to finish fourth in the preseason.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUREWITZ, MICHAEL
description: HUREWITZ - Michael. Beloved husband of Vickie. Devoted brother of Adam and Maritza. Adored uncle of Venessa and Stephanie. Good friend to many and will be sorely missed. Services will be held Wednesday, 1 PM at Gutterman Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre. Donations made to Mike Hurewitz Scholarship Fund for Journalism Students, C/O Tom Maginn, Resident Controller, Times Union, Box 15000, Albany, New York 12210.

title: Net Surges 69% at Fannie Mae On Record Mortgage Activity
description: Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of United States mortgages, said today that its fourth-quarter net income rose 69 percent as homeowners refinanced loans at a record pace and lower interest rates cut its cost of capital.

title: A Cloud Over Sundance, But the Parties Go On
description: In the opening of the documentary ''Derrida,'' a blissful examination of the life of the philosopher Jacques Derrida by the directors Kirby Dick and Amy Ziering Kofman, a blur of movement whooshes across the screen while a voice says, ''There's a future which is predictable.''

title: Fountains and Bubbles: New Cosmic Mysteries
description: With the whole cosmos as its agenda, the meeting of the American Astronomical Society last week in Washington was a sounding board for scientists with new findings and ideas about nearly everything from mysterious gamma ray bursts in deep space to revealing images penetrating the turbulent heart of the Milky Way, Earth's home galaxy.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Panamsat Profits Increase
description: The PanAmSat Corporation, a commercial satellite operator, said fourth-quarter profit rose and it increased its 2002 earnings forecast. Net income rose to $3.2 million, from $559,000 in the year-earlier period. Sales increased to $203.7 million, from $202.9 million. PanAmSat, based in Wilton, Conn., expects a profit of 35 cents to 45 cents a share, compared with an earlier forecast of 25 cents to 35 cents.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Cutback In Music Expectations
description: Jupiter Media Metrix, which studies Internet traffic and buying patterns, has cut its projections about growth of online sales of music. In a report to be released today, Jupiter estimates that Internet music sales -- compact discs, revenue from subscription services and downloads of individual songs -- will grow to $5.5 billion in 2006. Last July, the company projected sales would hit $6.2 billion by 2006. Jupiter analysts attributed the reduced expectations to the economic slowdown and the slow starts of online subscription services. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Ending Their Lives, in Control
description: To the Editor:

title: At Landfill, Buckets Full Of Memories
description: It is one of the grimmest evidence rooms in the city's history, on top of the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island. The New York Police Department and the F.B.I. opened it to reporters yesterday, displaying items recovered from the debris that used to be the World Trade Center.

title: Bank of New York Suit Revived
description: A federal appeals court revived a lawsuit accusing executives of the Bank of New York Company of looting assets from Inkombank, a Russian bank that is now defunct.

title: Expert Says He Discerns 'Hard-Wired' Grammar Rules
description: In 1981 the linguist Noam Chomsky, who had already proposed that language was not learned but innate, made an even bolder claim.

title: Barbara Cook Takes Sondheim in Fond Stride
description: The first thing to acknowledge is simple incredulity. Barbara Cook -- whose sublime evening of song, ''Mostly Sondheim,'' is being presented on Sundays and Mondays through Feb. 11 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center -- is 74. But if you closed your eyes and just listened, you'd never know it. Her soprano pipes sound prime of life like: mellifluous, rangy, bell clear and either full or delicate, as necessary. And her voice fills the vertical silo space of the Beaumont as easily as if it were a broom closet.

title: DOLLAR GENERAL REVISES DOWNWARD 3 YEARS OF EARNINGS
description: Dollar General said yesterday that it has lowered its reported earnings for fiscal years 1998 through 2000 by 60 cents a share after a review of accounting practices. The company, a discount retailer based in Goodlettsville, Tenn., earned a combined $1.21 a share for the three years including the expense of settling lawsuits, Dollar General said. That was lower than the combined $1.81 it previously disclosed for the period and less than the $1.74 a share it expected to report when it began the re-examination. Dollar General in April said it would restate its earnings for 1998 and 1999 and delay filing an audited statement for 2000 as the retailer investigated ''allegations of fraudulent behavior.'' The announcement came two months after the chief financial officer, Brian Burr, quit.

title: High Rating For Packers-49ers
description: The Green Bay Packers' 25-15 victory over the San Francisco 49ers Sunday afternoon on Fox was the highest-rated wild-card playoff game of the weekend, generating an overnight 18.3 Nielsen rating, up from a 15.5 in the same time period on CBS last year.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell on expectations that United States inventories will stay abundant. In New York, crude oil for February delivery fell 79 cents, or 4 percent, to $18.89 a barrel.

title: Crony Capitalism, U.S.A.
description: Four years ago, as Asia struggled with an economic crisis, many observers blamed ''crony capitalism.'' Wealthy businessmen in Asia didn't bother to tell investors the truth about their assets, their liabilities or their profits; the aura of invincibility that came from their political connections was enough. Only when a financial crisis came along did people take a hard look at their businesses, which promptly collapsed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKE, RUTH GRATENSTEIN
description: LOCKE-Ruth Gratenstein. Born January 23, 1921, passed away January 13, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Jerome. Dear sister of Dorothy Gratenstein, Connie Frankel, and Sylvia Monforte. Devoted mother of Peter & Patricia Infantino, adored grandmother of Taylor & Dexter Locke, Damian, Dorian and Julian Infantino. Cherished aunt and loyal friend. Service on Tuesday, January 15, 12:45 PM, Parkside Chapel, 66th Avenue and Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York. Shiva Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

description: To the Editor:

description: In percent

title: New, Improved Nassau Starts With the Rakes
description: He may have grand ideas, but the new Nassau County executive is also proving to be a stickler for details, from the way groundskeepers wield their rakes to how switchboard operators answer the phones.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Troops Guard Schools
description: Nearly 750 police officers and British Army troops guarded the entrances to dozens of schools in northern Belfast yesterday because of a death threat to teachers and other workers at Roman Catholic schools issued by a Protestant paramilitary group, the Red Hand Defenders. The threat, issued on Friday, included other public sector workers and was followed on Saturday by the slaying of a Catholic mailman, Daniel McColgan, 20, by the Ulster Defense Association, another Protestant group. To protest the killing, Northern Ireland postal workers suspended deliveries until after Mr. McColgan's funeral today, and other unions plan to stage a half-day walkout on Friday. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Who's Keeping the Accountants Accountable?
description: After decades in which accountants managed to convince the public of their ability to bless the books of corporate America with virtually no regulatory oversight, there is growing skepticism about whether accountants can continue to police themselves.

title: Monday Night, The Sequel
description: In 20 years, it would be hard to imagine the release of ''Monday Night Mayhem II,'' a film about the wacky misadventures of Al Michaels, Dan Fouts and Dennis Miller and how they revolutionized sportscasting but loathed each other. The premiere of ''Monday Night Mayhem'' last night on TNT demonstrated that the juicy, rousing, bitter tale of the Howard Cosell-Don Meredith-Frank Gifford team was unique, and no attempt to imitate its appeal or chemistry has ever generated as much interest.

title: U.S. Could Free Up $200 Million in Afghan Funds, Powell Says
description: SHANNON, Ireland, Jan. 15  Responding to urgent pleas for financial help from Afghanistan's interim government, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States should be able to help free up more than $200 million in frozen funds that could be used to pay government expenses "in the course of this week."

title: A Fuel Cell Initiative Too Costly for Use in Cars
description: The goal of the research partnership between Washington and the auto industry -- a midsize car that would go 80 miles to a gallon with no loss of performance or carrying capacity -- was a stretch, critics said, when it was established by President Bill Clinton in 1993. As it turned out, they were right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARROW, HENNY HENRIETTE
description: BARROW - Henny Henriette. Daughter of Leon Ringer of Antwerp, Belgium passed away on January 1, 2002. She fled the Nazi Holocaust escaping through the south of France in 1942, spending the remainder of the war in Cuba, finally entering the United States in 1947. Always interested in teaching English to the foreign born, she headed a program at The New School University to tutor international students in English conversation for the past 20 years. She will be dearly missed by husband Edward & her daughter, Frances Barrow-Hirsch of Tel Aviv. There will be a memorial service at The United Nations Chapel, 1st Avenue at 44th Street on Sunday, January 20th at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to Hadassah.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHARKEY, JAMES
description: SHARKEY-James. 9/13/34 to 1/15/01. Loving, remembering and missing you everyday. Jackie, Children, Grandchildren, and ''The Boys''

description: To the Editor:

title: KEY MILITIA LEADER DIES IN BOMB BLAST IN THE WEST BANK
description: Israel calls Raed al-Karmi a terrorist, but here Palestinian children wear pictures of him on cords around their necks. Grown men sing a song praising him as ''the Promise.''

title: Bush to Be Monitored in Wake of Fainting Episode
description: The White House physician said yesterday that he would monitor President Bush for a few days to make sure that the fainting episode he experienced on Sunday was due to a nervous system reaction to choking and not to an underlying medical problem.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday about a visit between President Bush and his father with Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman of Enron, at a baseball game in April 2000, when the younger Mr. Bush was governor of Texas, referred imprecisely to the man talking to Mr. Lay. He was the former president. The current president was in the foreground.

title: Corrections
description: A credit in some copies on Sunday with the obituary of Cyrus R. Vance misspelled the name of a picture agency. It is Corbis-Bettmann, not Corbis-Bettman.

title: Redefining Pakistan
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf's new crackdown on violent Islamic groups in Pakistan, which has already led to dozens of arrests, is a momentous development that should help defuse the confrontation with India. It was reassuring, as well, for India to react by welcoming the decision by General Musharraf, the Pakistani leader, which he announced over the weekend. Understandably, India now insists that General Musharraf's words be matched by deeds in the disputed Muslim-dominated state of Kashmir. But on his visit to the region this week, Secretary of State Colin Powell should try to coax India into making some form of reciprocal gesture to Pakistan, perhaps by pulling back some of its forces on the border.

title: Democrats Ponder How Wide a Net to Cast
description: Seven months ago, when he took over as chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said he would examine the ''serious allegations'' raised by a colleague from California about the relationship between the Enron Corporation and one of its chief Washington regulators.

title: Court Upholds Agency's Separate Right to Sue Over Workplace Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The Supreme Court ruled today, in a case with consequences for workers and employers across the country, that a federal agency can file lawsuits on behalf of employees who have signed away their own rights to sue their companies.

title: Sampras Wins With Spirited Play
description: It was function over fashion on the second day of the Australian Open.
