description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, HUGO
description: KAHN-Hugo. It is with deep sorrow that we report the death of Hugo Kahn, beloved husband of Margie; devoted father of Alan and Danny (Shira), and proud grandfather of Yael and Aliza. Hugo was a founder and benefactor of Youth Centers of Israel Inc., which was very important in streamlining the youngsters in the waves of immigrants that came to Israel. He will be sorely missed. Arno Kahn, President Paul Kaufmann, Treasurer Rebecca Skydell, Secretary

title: Palm Acts to Help Advance Technology on Wireless Links
description: Bluetooth, an emerging technology for wirelessly connecting digital devices, gained support from the leading hand-held computer maker yesterday, when Palm Inc. introduced kits that help software developers create Bluetooth programs.

title: Underground Fires Menace Land and Climate
description: Fires are burning in thousands of underground coal seams from Pennsylvania to Mongolia, releasing toxic gases, adding millions of tons of heat-trapping carbon dioxide to the atmosphere and baking the earth until vegetation shrivels and the land sinks.

title: Gerald Van der Kemp, 89, Versailles' Restorer
description: Gerald Van der Kemp, the French art expert who masterminded the restoration of Louis XIV's palace at Versailles and saved the ''Mona Lisa'' from destruction by the Nazis, died Dec. 28 in Paris. He was 89.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teacher Faces Charges
description: A home instruction teacher with the New York City public schools was arrested yesterday and accused of working at a bagel shop during hours in which he claimed he was teaching. The teacher, Frank Accardi, 54, falsified records to say that he was working with students when he was not, and collected more than $1,000 for instruction he never provided, according to a report released by the school system's special investigations office. Mr. Accardi is charged with fourth-degree grand larceny and falsifying business records. His lawyer was at a trial yesterday and could not be reached for comment, his office said. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a satirical new morning television show in Mexico misstated the origin of a cartoon character whom the host imitates to parody the country's first lady. The character, Sweet Polly, is from the United States, not Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBROW, STEPHEN
description: DOBROW-Stephen. The Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority mourns the untimely passing of our esteemed charter member and friend, Stephen Dobrow. His wit, intelligence and encyclopaedic knowledge of our transit system will be sorely missed. James F. Blair, Chairman Beverly Dolinsky, Exec Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARONS, THELMA (TOBY)
description: AARONS-Thelma (Toby). Undiscovered artist. Beloved wife of Bernard, devoted mother of Spencer, Gwen, Mark, Brian, dear sister of Seymour and Alvin and sisterin-law of Annette, Sheila, Jonas and Pam, cherished grandmother of Grant, Brady and Manoj, and loved mother-in-law of Karen and Mimi. Services January 16, 11 AM, Sherman's, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, 718-377-7300.

title: How to Persuade the Young to Watch the News? Program It, News Executives Say
description: Niche advertising has been around for years. Now, television news executives are exploring niche news programming.

title: Help in Navigating Health Care Web Sites
description: ''Healthcare Online for Dummies,'' by Howard and Judi Wolinsky, Hungry Minds, $21.99.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATTISTONI, RICHARD P. ''CHIC''
description: BATTISTONI-Richard P. ''Chic''. On Jan. 14, 2002. Loving husband of Meryl and adoring father of Julianna. Beloved son of Vincent and Alma. Cherished brother of Ann & brother-in-law, Dave Becker. Dear son-in-law of Eugene and Rosanne Schaffer. Longtime friend and business partner of Kathleen and Grant Peacock. To all his friends, a better one could not be found. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations in his memory can be made to Gilda's Club, 195 W. Houston Street, New York, NY 10014.

title: Airlines Say They Are Set To Meet Screening Deadline
description: As the airlines struggle to meet a Friday deadline that requires them to screen all checked baggage, the new head of the Transportation Security Administration said today that aviation officials had hurt security since the Sept. 11 attacks by talking too much about their methods.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Russian Troops Now Welcome
description: President Eduard A. Shevardnadze reversed course and told Parliament that he wants Russian peacekeeping troops to remain in the nation's rebel-controlled separatist region, Abkhazia, lest their removal lead to a blood bath against ethnic Georgians there. The 1,600 troops have been monitoring a cease-fire in Abkhazia since 1994, but Mr. Shevardnadze called for their departure last fall after a series of rebel actions that he accused Russia of supporting. He said yesterday that Russia had since moderated what he called its support for Abkhazian independence and that the troops should remain as long as United Nations forces are not committed to replace them.

title: Troubled Kmart Considers Its Options
description: The board of the Kmart Corporation, one of the nation's largest discount chains, is meeting to evaluate its financial options, one of which may be to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, several people close to the discussions say.

title: The Anesthesia Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: Tom Allon, publisher at Manhattan Media, New York, was promoted to the new posts of president and chief executive; he will continue as editor in chief. Mr. Allon is being succeeded as publisher by Diane Straus Tucker, who was most recently the publisher at The Westchester County Times and The Fairfield County Times, based in New Milford, Conn., which are now owned by the Journal Register Company.

title: Chief Judge Urges Amending Constitution to Realign Courts
description: The state's chief judge, Judith S. Kaye, called today for a constitutional amendment to streamline the state's tangled court system, a plea she has made in the past without success.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Video-Poker Ban Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A new state law prohibiting video poker machines was ruled unconstitutional by a Fulton County judge who said it posed a threat to personal liberty. The law was enacted last summer after more than 15,000 of the machines began to appear in bars and truck stops around the state, having been moved from South Carolina after that state banned video poker in 2000. Judge John Goger of Superior Court ruled in favor of several amusement companies that sued to block the law, saying its wording was too vague. State officials said they would appeal. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Format Aims for Added Excitement
description: High jump competitions often leave the jumpers and the spectators unsatisfied. Fields are sometimes too large, the jumpers may have to wait too long between attempts and the elite athletes may have long waits while lesser jumpers eliminate themselves.

title: STARWOOD SEEKS OFFERS FOR ITS EUROPEAN HOTEL GROUP
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide said yesterday that it was soliciting offers for its Ciga Group of European hotels more than a year after first saying it would sell the unit. Starwood said it would begin reviewing ''preliminary indications of interest'' next month for the 25 hotels, which include the Hotel Danieli and the Gritti Palace in Venice. The company, which is based in White Plains, will consider selling the properties individually or in groups, a Starwood spokesman, David Matheson, said.

title: Two Rappers Find Rhyme and Rage in Greenwich
description: Life as a rap artist in this wealthy enclave of diamond rings and dog salons is not as easy as it seems. Just ask Andy Kaufman.

title: Schools Chief Offers Possible Cuts in Budget
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy submitted about $600 million in possible cuts in the education budget yesterday for the fiscal year starting July 1, opening what will most likely be an intense round of negotiations with the Bloomberg administration.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Squabble Over Conventions
description: State Democratic leaders are fuming over a plan by Connecticut Republicans to hold their state convention this summer on the same weekend as the Democrats' convention. In a letter sent yesterday, the chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, John W. Olsen, demanded an explanation from his Republican counterpart, Chris DePino. Mr. Olsen accused Mr. DePino of changing dates to accommodate the travel plans of Gov. John G. Rowland, the presumptive Republican nominee. Mr. DePino called the letter ridiculous, but said he was forced to advance his biennial convention a week, to July 12, for logistical reasons, including conflicts in Mr. Rowland's schedule. The city has not yet been chosen. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Technology Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fashion House For Sale
description: Holding di Partecipazioni Industriali is talking with several groups to sell its fashion house, Valentino, the unit's chief executive, Fabio Giombini, said. Speaking to reporters during a fashion show in Milan, Mr. Giombini said the unit's revenue grew about 10 percent last year, but he did not say whether the concern earned a profit. Valentino lost money in 2000. Holding di Partecipazioni is selling the unit to focus on publishing.

title: 2 Premieres, With Tumult and Genocide
description: Gerard Schwarz led the New York Chamber Symphony in three works on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall, with premieres by Soong Fu-Yuan and Aaron Jay Kernis sharing the first half of the program and the Mendelssohn Symphony No. 5 after the intermission.

title: Greens Without Fees in Georgia
description: Through Feb. 28, guests at the lodgings on Sea Island, Ga., will receive one round of golf each day on the islands' three courses, designed by Davis Love 3rd, Rees Jones and Tom Fazio. The accommodations are the Cloister and the Lodge at Sea Island Golf Club. Rates start at $425 a room without meals at the Lodge, or $314 with all meals for two at the Cloister. Visit www.seaisland.com . To reserve, call (800) 732-4752. Restrictions apply.

title: Justice Department Will Seek Life in Prison for Walker
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 - The American-born Taliban fighter John Walker Lindh will be tried in a civilian court, not a military tribunal, on charges of conspiring to kill American citizens in Afghanistan, Attorney General John D. Ashcroft said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DAVID
description: COHEN-David. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY, mourns the passing of our member, David Cohen. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Clara and family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Rose Schecter, President

title: Detective Held Hostage At Precinct
description: An armed man was holding a police detective hostage at the 19th Precinct station house on the Upper East Side early this morning, the police said.

title: ENRON'S CHAIRMAN RECEIVED WARNING ABOUT ACCOUNTING
description: A senior Enron employee explicitly warned the company's chairman in August that several years of improper accounting practices threatened to bring down the company, Congressional investigators said today.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Premier Revamps Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Ali Abu al-Ragheb selected a new government and appointed as foreign minister Marwan Muasher, who as ambassador to Washington shepherded a free trade agreement through Congress last fall. The new cabinet is expected to focus on improving the economy in advance of delayed parliamentary elections that are likely to take place in September. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: U.S. Forces Find Weapons Cache Near Kandahar Airport
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Jan. 15  American soldiers uncovered a cache of weapons hidden near the airport here where United States troops are based, while the local militia continued to hunt down Taliban officials and Al Qaeda fighters who fled as the city fell to anti-Taliban forces last month.

title: Brazilian Vignettes, Nuanced And Melodic
description: Monica Salmaso has a gorgeous, quintessentially Brazilian voice: quietly lustrous and sustained, suffusing each liquid note with languid secrets. In her concert on Friday night at Kaye Playhouse, the first of two nights presented by the World Music Institute, Ms. Salmaso also had a thoroughly Brazilian approach to music. She sang about Brazil's history, folklore and multifarious cultures with absolutely no deference to purism.

title: Extra Policing After Sept. 11 Often Amounted to New Name for Old Job
description: Even with all the attention in Washington to domestic security, many police departments across the country say they have changed their priorities and assignments little if at all since Sept. 11. Several say they are ready to scale back changes made immediately after the terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINOWITZ, HILDA (MALIN)
description: MALINOWITZ-Hilda (Malin). Age 93, on January 13, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Cherished aunt of Eleanor Sussman, Marvin & Miguelle Sussman, and Norman and Alyce Sussman, Lewis and Barbara Malin, Steve Malin, Jill Jacobson, Sandy and Ernie Reichard, Michael and Evelyn Malin, George and Bea Ostroff, Freya Nanfra, Barbara Linn, Michael and Lisa Linn. Beloved great aunt. Adored ''Mother'' of Shireen Ali. Services Tuesday 1:30 PM at ''Weinstein - Garlick - Kirchenbaum'' Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Three Companies Guided by Spirits of Joy
description: Three companies took part in ''Creative Expressions,'' the festive program that James LeMark Yarborough presented on Friday night at the Joyce SoHo: Mr. Yarborough's own New York-based Nommo Contemporary Dance Theater, Dance and Body Works Dance Ensemble from Washington, and Sankofa Dance Theater from Savannah, Ga.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLIDES. The dollar fell against the yen and the euro. In New York, the dollar settled at 131.96 yen, down from 132.24 yen on Friday. The euro traded at 89.41 cents, up from 89.25 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, PAMELA
description: KANTOR-Pamela. Loving sister of Stuart, wife of Morgan, mother of Jessica. Dear friend of many. You will be missed my darling by all of the Kantor family. Martin and Carrie Kantor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POOR, ANNE
description: POOR-Anne. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be deeply mourned by the world of art.

title: ANADARKO PETROLEUM WARNS OF SLIDE IN EARNINGS
description: The independent oil and natural gas producer Anadarko Petroleum said yesterday that profit fell more than expected in the fourth quarter as energy prices plunged. Profit fell to about 25 cents a share in the final quarter of 2001 from $1.88 a year earlier, Anadarko said in releasing preliminary results. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had said they expected earnings of 36 cents a share. Petroleum producers have reduced drilling as energy prices fell, eroding profit. Anadarko slowed its drilling in July and is cutting its budget for 2002 in half, the chief executive, John N. Seitz, said.

title: Softhearted Pirates and One Sappy Guy
description: It doesn't matter what you think, you must admit they've got it right. In songs that patter, jokes that wink with gleeful wit, the tone is light. With generous simplicity, brute charm and neat self-mockery, this is the very model of a modern Savoy company.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Beth Collins was named vice president and group director at the Parenting Group, New York, which includes BabyTalk, Healthy Pregnancy and Parenting magazines. She had been vice president and general manager at Family.com and FamilyFun.com, New York, part of the Walt Disney Internet Group unit of the Walt Disney Company. The Parenting Group is part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNING, MARY MARGARET BOURNE
description: DUNNING - Mary Margaret Bourne. Died January 12, 2002, at home in Manhattan after a long illness. Born July 26, 1911, and formerly of Decatur, IL, she was the beloved wife of the late James Dorr Dunning Sr., mother of James Jr. Cherished grandmother of James III and David, all of New York City, and dear friend to many. title: GE CAPITAL BUYING 2 COMDISCO UNITS FOR $665 MILLION
description: A unit of General Electric said yesterday that it had reached agreement to buy two leasing businesses of Comdisco Inc. for about $665 million in cash and assumed debt as Comdisco tries to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings. GE Capital, the finance arm of General Electric, said it would acquire Comdisco's electronics and laboratory and scientific leasing businesses. Comdisco will also receive payments if the transferred leases exceed certain performance goals. Comdisco, based in Rosemont, Ill., said it expected to complete evaluating bids for its remaining leasing businesses -- information technology, telecommunications and health care -- by the end of the month.

title: FOSTER WHEELER FALLS AFTER DELAYING INTEREST PAYMENT
description: Foster Wheeler, a builder of refineries and chemical and power plants, said yesterday that it would defer interest payment on junior subordinated notes, setting off a 48 percent decline in its stock price. Foster Wheeler said it would extend the interest period for the debentures for one quarter, or until April 15. The action defers the dividend on FW Preferred Capital I 9 percent preferred securities for the same period, the company said. The company's shares fell $2.09, to $2.25 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Foster Wheeler is based in Hamilton, Bermuda, but has its operational headquarters in Clinton, N.J.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Irishman To Lead Parliament
description: Pat Cox, a Liberal Democrat from Ireland, was elected president of the European Parliament. Mr. Cox, 49, a former television journalist, replaces a French conservative, Nicole Fontaine. His election breaks a long period of control by conservatives and Socialists, and he pledged to make the body more relevant to alienated voters. He came to prominence in 1999 when he helped lead the Parliament's move to throw out members of the European Union's executive branch, the European Commission, over a corruption scandal. title: WALKER WILL FACE TERRORISM COUNTS IN A CIVILIAN COURT
description: John Walker, the American wanderer turned Taliban warrior, was charged today in a criminal complaint with conspiring to kill United States citizens and supporting terrorist groups. He will be tried in federal court in Alexandria, Va., and could face life in prison if convicted.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit Up At Software Maker
description: The Oracle Corporation Japan, the nation's largest provider of database software, said first-half profit rose 22 percent, helped by sales of services that help clients make marketing and accounting operations more efficient. Parent net income at the Japanese unit of the Oracle Corporation totaled 9.5 billion yen ($73 million), or 74.08 yen a share, in the six months ended Nov. 30, up from 7.8 billion yen, or 60.78 yen a share, in the period a year ago.

title: Navigating New Jersey's Future
description: New Jersey's new governor, James McGreevey, was sworn into office yesterday and delivered an inaugural address about austerity and recovery. It was a speech notably spare of new programs and promises, urging New Jerseyans to ''tighten our belts -- not harden our hearts, but tighten our belts and live within our means.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, EDWIN MCCAMMON
description: MARTIN-Edwin McCammon. On January 12, 2002, at home in Washington, DC of pneumonia. Beloved husband of Margaret (Peggy) Martin. Father of Patricia Sanjuan and Edwin M. Martin, Jr., father-in-law of Pedro Sanjuan and Nancy Spangler. Grandfather of Victoria Sanjuan, Jonathan Martin, Pilar M. Sanjuan, Jennifer Martin, India Sanjuan, Timothy Martin, Amy Martin, Theodore Martin and Katherine Martin. Great-grandfather of Robert Sternberg, Jessica Sternberg and Spencer Martin. Contributions may be made to the Wintergreen Nature Foundation, PO Box 468, Nellysford, VA. 22958.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Balancing The Budget
description: Gov. Dirk Kempthorne said he would halt construction projects and capitol renovation and dip into the state's $18.8 million share of a tobacco lawsuit settlement to balance a $2 billion budget. The governor, a Republican, said December revenue reports were down by $20 million. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Doctor Indicted As Conspirator In Drug Billing
description: A federal grand jury indicted a New Jersey urologist yesterday on charges of conspiring to receive kickbacks, with the help of a pharmaceutical company, to prescribe a drug for prostate cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBROW, STEPHEN B.
description: DOBROW-Stephen B. Our loving son and brother, although sorely missed, will be forever in our hearts and minds. Shiva will be observed at 190-06C 69th Avenue, Apt 2B, Fresh Meadows, NY on Wednesday and Thursday 3 P.M. to 9 P.M., and Friday 10 A.M. to 12 P.M., and Sunday noon till 6 P.M.

title: Account Decisions By 2 Big Advertisers
description: Gateway, the struggling computer seller in Poway, Calif., named Siltanen/Keehn in El Segundo, Calif., as creative agency of record. Though billings were not disclosed, Gateway spent $156 million in advertising in the first nine months of 2001, according to CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending by marketers.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: More Domestic Security
description: Dearborn, home to the country's largest concentration of Arab-American Muslims, is creating a new police position to oversee terrorism-related security. Mayor Michael A. Guido said the city would earmark $250,000 in next year's budget for counterterrorism, including heightened building security, hazardous-materials response and handling anthrax threats. The lieutenant, who has not yet been named, will be a liaison to state and federal agencies. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKELL, SYLVIA
description: BERKELL-Sylvia, 88 years old. Died on January 14, 2002, after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Devoted mother of Arthur. Cherished grandmother of Kelly and Jacqueline. She was Chairman of the Board of Curtains & Home. Services, Friday, 1 PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' Great Neck, NY.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Andersen Fires the Partner In Charge of Auditing Enron

title: Murder, He Wrote (and Witnessed, Too)
description: If junky pleasure were so easy, there would be more of it on television, instead of just junk. Kevin Williamson, creator of the hit television series ''Dawson's Creek'' and the popular ''Scream'' horror movies, knows the difference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHBONE, HAROLD, M.D.
description: FISHBONE-Harold, M.D. All of us mourn the loss of our esteemed firend Dr. Fishbone. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Anita, Alan and Douglas. Miracle House

title: Crash Inquiry Finds Damage To Jet's Tail
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it had found damage to the tail of the American Airlines jet that crashed in Queens on Nov. 12 but could not say whether it was a cause of the crash or an effect.

title: Ornstein Added to Roster
description: The Jets are signing eight players to their 2002 roster, including quarterback Gus Ornstein.

title: From College to Sundance Festival
description: Next month, KING WAI CHEUNG graduates from Brooklyn College. This month he is at the Sundance Institute in Park City, Utah, showing his film, ''Farewell Hong Kong,'' which was partly financed by the college. In the 10-minute film, one of 79 chosen from more than 2,000 entries, a young man from Hong Kong living in New York ponders issues of identity as Hong Kong passes from British custody to Chinese. Mr. Cheung, 33, left Hong Kong for the United States in 1992 and enrolled at Brooklyn College to study film, music and philosophy. ''Farewell Hong Kong'' was his first short film. Karen W. Arenson

title: DELTA PETROLEUM BUYS PROPERTY TO DOUBLE OIL OUTPUT
description: The Delta Petroleum Corporation, an oil and natural gas exploration company, has agreed to buy all of the Castle Energy Corporation's oil and gas properties in the United States for about $57.3 million in stock and cash to double its daily production of oil. Delta said it would pay $20 million in cash and about 9.57 million shares for the assets of Castle. The value was based on Delta's closing price on Monday of $3.90 a share. Shares of Castle, which is based in Radnor, Pa., rose $1.33, or 25 percent, to $6.53. Delta will get 525 oil and gas wells in 14 states, the chief executive, Roger Parker, said. Delta is based in Denver.

title: Vance's Tireless Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Created: Bigger U.S. Role; Evolving: What the Role Is
description: LIBERAL Democrats have long wanted more federal involvement in education, hoping this would bring extra funds to urban schools. Conservative Republicans argued against a federal role, warning that it would lead to national curriculums that reflect liberal values.

title: Bibi Osterwald, 83, Stage and TV Actress
description: Bibi Osterwald, an actress in theater, television and films, died on Jan. 2 in Burbank, Calif. She was 83 and lived in Burbank.

title: Argentines Line Up to Escape to the Old World
description: Liliana Cardamone's father came to Argentina from Italy as a child because his parents dreamed of a better life here. But on Friday morning, Ms. Cardamone was standing in a long line outside the Italian Embassy, preparing to claim Italian nationality so that she and her husband and two small children can move to her father's homeland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNING, MARY MARGARET BOURNE
description: DUNNING - Mary Margaret Bourne. Died January 12, 2002, at home in Manhattan after a long illness. Born July 26, 1911, and formerly of Decatur, IL, she was the beloved wife of the late James Dorr Dunning Sr., mother of James Jr. Cherished grandmother of James III and David, all of New York City, and dear friend to many. Funeral service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st St, Thursday, January 17, at 4:30 PM. Friends are requested to make memorial donations to St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Now, a Craft Bar

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Seeking Trade And Support
description: President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has begun a state visit to Russia and Ukraine, hoping to interest both in launching satellites from a Brazilian rocket-launching base on the edge of the Amazon. Russia would like Brazil to choose Russian jet fighters for a modernization of its air force now under way. And the Brazilians are seeking support for their effort to win a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by television networks to tailor news programs to young people misspelled the surname of the president of ABC News, who said he had learned from experience about overcatering to them. He is David Westin, not Weston. The article also misidentified the CBS News program on which Rebecca Rankin, a reporter for the music network VH1, has appeared. It is ''48 Hours,'' not ''60 Minutes.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 21 about wealthy politicians who have used their fortunes to advance a public agenda misstated the period in which Ronald Maiorana worked as press secretary to one such figure, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York. It was 1970 to 1973, not the governor's entire term.

title: U.S. and Philippines Setting Up Joint Operations to Fight Terror
description: In the first major expansion of the war on terrorism, American and Philippine military officers in Manila began preparing joint operations today against a Muslim extremist group linked to Al Qaeda in the southern Philippines.

title: The Bold Shirazes of Oz
description: SHIRAZ is Australia's ambassador to the wine world, sounding its own friendly ''G'day'' with every sip.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Woman Is Stabbed To Death
description: A woman was stabbed to death in the Bronx early yesterday morning, and a man seen dragging her body out of his apartment ran at police officers with a knife when they approached him, the police said. The man, identified as Jorge Sanchez, 22, who lives in a basement apartment on Bronx River Avenue in the Bronx River section, was arrested and charged with second-degree murder. Mr. Sanchez lunged at four police officers at the crime scene, but he was arrested without causing any injuries, the police said. The police did not identify the woman who was killed. They said she knew Mr. Sanchez, but that they did not know the nature of their relationship. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: ZIFF DAVIS TO HAVE LARGER RESTRUCTURING COSTS
description: Ziff Davis Media, the publisher of PC Magazine, said yesterday that it expected to have restructuring costs of as much as $275 million in the fourth quarter. The company also renegotiated its bank agreements to avoid default. The costs are related to discontinuing some businesses, consolidating plants and cutting jobs, Ziff Davis said. The company said it had forecast costs of about $150 million. Ziff Davis said it hired a financial adviser, Greenhill & Company, to help it weigh options for reducing its debt. The company has suffered from declines in the advertising and technology markets.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Pfizer Plans to Offer Prescriptions To the Elderly for a Monthly Fee
description: Pfizer, the world's largest drug company, said today that it would offer its drugs to low-income elderly people for a flat fee of $15 a month for each prescription, a fraction of the average retail price of $65.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LALLI, CELE GOLDSMITH
description: LALLI-Cele Goldsmith. Former Editor-in-Chief of ''Modern Bride Magazine''. On Monday, at the Danbury Hospital after an automobile accident. Wife of Michael A. Lalli. Mother of Francesca L. Morrissey, and Erica L. Sullivan. Sister of Joan G. Rosen. Also survived by five grandchildren. Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Saturday at 11:00 AM, at St. Leo's Church, 24 Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT. Calling hours Friday 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 at The Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford. Memorial contributions to CACLD, 25 Van Zant Street, Unit 15-5, E. Norwalk, CT 06855.

title: CNN Expected To Re-Sign Larry King
description: Larry King, the anchor of the most popular program on CNN, is close to completing a deal to remain with the network for four more years after flirtations with MSNBC and the Fox News Channel, people close to the negotiations said today.

title: Shoe Bomber Suspect Linked to Al Qaeda
description: Afederal grand jury in Boston issued a nine-count indictment today against Richard C. Reid, the man who is accused of trying to blow up a commercial jetliner with explosives that were hidden in his shoes.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Presidential Recount Sought
description: A leading opposition party filed a petition in the Supreme Court demanding a recount of the ballots cast in the presidential election last month. The United Party for National Development is led by Anderson Mazoka, who narrowly lost the election to Levy Mwanawasa. Mr. Mazoka says the election was rigged and has asked the court to investigate anomalies cited by international observers. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: When Puppets Outshine Real-Life Actors
description: The newest collaboration of Sigfrido Aguilar and Jim Calder, ''The Alamo Piece,'' looks a bit like unapologetic self-indulgence and, as one would expect of these two, it has nothing to do with the Alamo. Actually, one would guess it is a work in progress, since it takes on Mexican and American history at the border, and the two currently share a grant from the U.S.-Mexico Fund for Culture, a Rockefeller Foundation entity, to develop a theatrical work about the border.

title: When You Finish This, You Need a Siesta
description: MEXICO has its own version of the hero, a fusion of sandwich and burrito called the torta. South of the Rio Grande, tortas are made with a stuffable, pitalike bread called teleras. A tiny restaurant in Hamilton Heights, El Toro Partido, uses a conventional white roll instead, but the tortas are exceptional. They are also painstakingly made to order; expect a 10-minute wait, or phone ahead.

title: Kelly Picks Marine for Counterterrorism Unit
description: All 40,000 officers in the New York Police Department will receive specialized training to help them respond to terrorist acts as part of Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly's broad counterterrorism initiative.

title: Recipe: Braised Lemon Sole With Watercress
description: Method adapted from Tom Colicchio

title: Death of Donor Halts Some Transplants
description: Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan said yesterday that after the death of a man who donated part of his liver to his brother, it had temporarily halted operations in which healthy adults donate part of their livers for use as transplants to other adults.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the growing use of paid obituaries in newspapers misstated the practice of The Washington Post. The Post, which publishes unpaid obituaries, says its policy is to write one about any resident of the area whose relatives request it, provided the family agrees to include all information the paper deems newsworthy. The Post does not base its obituary decisions solely on the prominence of the subject.

title: Ashcroft's Message: Case Against Walker Is Solid
description: When Attorney General John Ashcroft announced the charges that 20-year-old John Walker will face in an American civilian court, it was the start of the public dance that comes in many public cases.

title: Powell Embarks on Mission To South Asian Powder Keg
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell headed today for perhaps his most delicate diplomatic mission: pressing India and Pakistan to defuse their confrontation over Kashmir, as the two nuclear-armed nations have hundreds of thousands of troops massed on their border.

title: Russia's Nuclear Arsenal
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Finance Minister 'Marries' Gay Partner
description: Two of the country's most powerful men, the finance minister and a media executive, have formalized their long relationship by entering a domestic partnership similar to marriage. A spokeswoman for Finance Minister Per-Kristian Foss, 52, said he and Jan Erik Knarbakk, 50, the executive vice president for TV, film and publishing in the national Schibsted media group, registered their partnership on Jan. 4, gaining all the benefits and obligations of marriage apart from the right to adopt children. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Trade Center Tenants To Meet
description: The World Trade Center Tenants Association will hold a meeting, open to anyone who leased space in the complex. It is scheduled for noon in the office of the Manhattan borough president, Municipal Building, 19th Floor, Manhattan. Information: Meyer Feig at mfeig@theinteracorp.com.

title: ARTHUR ANDERSEN FIRES AN EXECUTIVE FOR ENRON ORDERS
description: Arthur Andersen fired its partner in charge of auditing the Enron Corporation today, saying he had ordered the destruction of thousands of documents and e-mail messages after learning that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an investigation of Enron's accounting.

title: Donor's Death at Hospital Halts Some Liver Surgeries
description: Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan said yesterday that after the death of a man who donated part of his liver to his brother, it had temporarily halted operations in which healthy adults donate part of their livers for use as transplants to other adults.

title: Tyco Shares Fall as Investors Show Concern on Accounting
description: Shares of Tyco International Ltd. skidded 8.5 percent yesterday after the company said its earnings for the current quarter would fall short of analysts' forecasts.

title: Cuomo Far Ahead of McCall In Raising Campaign Funds
description: In the last six months, Andrew M. Cuomo raised twice as much money to run for governor as his fellow Democrat, H. Carl McCall, did, and nearly matched Gov. George E. Pataki's pace, the campaigns reported today.

title: Success at 14, Despite Autism; His Drawings Go for Up to $1,200 and Win High Praise
description: In the strange world of outsider art, Jonathan Lerman, at 14, is already an insider.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Start-Up Takes On Patent Job
description: A start-up intellectual property consulting firm, ipValue, announced yesterday that it had signed a six-year exclusive deal with the research and development arm of British Telecommunications to generate licensing revenue from its 14,000 patents. The agreement, and the company itself, reflect the increasing efforts technology companies are making to try to commercialize their patents instead of merely using a patent portfolio as a defensive fortress against competitors. They are following the lead of I.B.M., whose royalty revenues have increased seventeenfold over the last decade to more than $1.7 billion. The president of ipValue is Joseph Zier, former head of KPMG's intellectual property practice, and it is backed by $30 million from the Boston Consulting Group, General Atlantic Partners and Goldman, Sachs. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Fuel-Rod Study Discounts Theft
description: Federal energy regulators said today that their investigation into two radioactive fuel rods discovered missing two years ago from the Dominion Millstone Nuclear Power Plant here had concluded that the rods had probably been mistakenly shipped to two national underground disposal sites.

title: York Journal; Racial Adversaries Converge on City Trying to Heal
description: Just as this blue-collar city tries to face up to some long-buried racial violence, it is finding itself the chosen venue of white supremacist hate groups and rival anarchist protesters whom civil rights specialists have been tracking across the nation as a kind of traveling circus of publicity hunters.

title: Institutions Brace For Cuts By the City
description: Late last week the city's new budget director, Mark Page, sent a memo to the Department of Cultural Affairs, along with all the other city agencies, asking them for cuts of 25 percent in their building plans over the next four years.

title: World Business Briefing | South Africa: South Africa: No Higher Gold Mine Bid
description: Setting the stage for an end to its protracted bidding contest with the Newmont Mining Corporation, AngloGold Ltd., the world's largest gold producer, said it would not increase its offer for Normandy Mining Ltd., Australia's biggest gold miner. AngloGold of South Africa and Newmont of Denver have been battling for control of Normandy for months and last week AngloGold extended the deadline for its offer until Jan. 18. Anglo's cash-stock offer of 1.95 Australian dollars a share is only 3 cents lower than Newmont's. While AngloGold now looks unlikely to win, the company appears to be positioning itself to try to capture as much as 10 percent of Normandy, which would give AngloGold leverage in forging cooperative agreements with Newmont. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

title: A Barometer of Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Intel Reports That Earnings For Quarter Beat Estimates
description: Ending its worst year on an upbeat note, the Intel Corporation reported fourth-quarter earnings today that exceeded most expectations.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Decline In Steel Demand Seen
description: A leading European steel maker, Thyssen Krupp, said that demand would decline this year and that a sales target announced last November of 38 billion euros ($34 billion) now appears to be ambitious. The chief executive, Ekkehard Schulz, said at a news conference that the 2002 fiscal year, which ends in September, was likely to be another difficult one, particularly in the first half. Mr. Schulz said he expected the company to raise prices in April as a result of low inventories.

title: Justices Limit Reach of Arbitration Law
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that arbitration agreements that bar employees from suing their employers for discrimination cannot prevent a federal agency from going to court on the workers' behalf and seeking back pay, damages and reinstatement for victims of discrimination.

title: Suffolk Plans to Supply 40% of Energy Its Residents Use, Undercutting LIPA's Rates
description: In a bid to cut local electricity rates, Suffolk County is developing a plan to provide about 40 percent of the energy its residents use, by expanding a little-known county agency.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about fears of violence in and near a rebel-held zone in Colombia after the collapse of peace talks misidentified a town where anti-rebel groups accused doctors and a store owner of having helped the rebels and where a nurse spoke of her fears. It was San Vicente del Cagun, the largest town in the zone, not Puerto Rico, a town just outside the zone.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUSSELL, EDWIN F.
description: RUSSELL-Edwin F. A memorial service will be held at 4:30PM, January 23, 2002 at All Saints Episcopal Church, 230 E 60th Street, NYC.

title: Parents Vote Not to Reopen Public School Shut Sept. 11
description: An overwhelming majority of parents from Public School 89, which was shuttered after the World Trade Center attack, voted last night against a Board of Education plan to reopen the school building on Feb. 4.

title: Recipe: Provenal Braised Beef
description: Adapted from "Lulu's Provencal Table," by Richard Olney (HarperCollins)

title: For Andersen and Enron, the Questions Just Keep Coming
description: Arthur Andersen tried yesterday to salvage its reputation by firing a partner who it said had directed the destruction of Enron documents. But the actions it said the partner took have left Andersen facing the likelihood of criminal investigations even as it tries to reassure the public, and its clients, that its audits can be trusted.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Crackdown On Political Violence
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen ordered the police to crack down on political violence before local elections set for Feb. 3. A new report by the United Nations said 15 people active in politics have been killed or died in suspicious circumstances in the last year. Most were members of parties opposed to Mr. Hun Sen's party. The police deny that any political killings have taken place. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: The Real Lessons of Enron's Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Spice and Froth For Those Cold Winter Days
description: Hot drinks with Latin accents are warming up the New York winter at Mosaico, a Latin-themed cafe at 175 Madison Avenue (34th Street). Assorted hot chocolates head the list: Mexican frothed with spices and chilies, Cuban with coffee and whipped cream, Argentine with dulce de leche. The chef, Orlando Len, left, gives a nod to his native Colombia in Agua de Panela, made with a dark, molasseslike brown sugar paste called panela dissolved in hot water with cinnamon, cloves and ginger, and topped with whipped cream. Latin Apple, a mixture of warm apple cider and dulce de leche, is crowned with whipped cream drizzled with more dulce de leche. For an easy home version, just heat cider in a saucepan and add dulce de leche to taste. Mosaico Moo is simply milk combined with a little honey and almond syrup and steamed, also easy to make if you have a milk frother. The drinks are $2.25 for 10 ounces, $2.50 for 12 ounces and $3 for 16 ounces, and each comes with a warm Colombian cheese biscuit. But they're served in paper cups, not glass mugs, unless you insist.

title: After 11 Years, Democrats Take Control and Savor the Moment
description: To be a Democrat in Trenton today was to be expansive, as Joey Novick was while people all around him elbowed their way up to the stage after the inauguration of Gov. James E. McGreevey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTER, SYDNEY
description: ALTER-Sydney. Beloved husband of Helen for 66 years. Devoted father of Phyllis Malino and the late Nedra. Adored grandfather of Dana Gordon, Debbie and Rob Ackerman and loving great grandfather of Jason and Andy. Graveside services at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Brooklyn, on Wednesday at 11 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANCE, CYRUS R.
description: VANCE-Cyrus R. Devoted husband of Grace Sloane Vance. Beloved father of Elsie, Amy, Grace, Camilla and Cyrus. Proud grandfather of Simon and Clare Vance and Kemal Askar, and honored father-in-law of Peggy Vance, Brig. Gen. (Ret.) William Holmes, and Atilla Askar. Died Saturday, January 12, 2002. Visitation on Thursday, January 10, 5-8PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, 11AM, at the Church of Heavenly Rest, 2 E. 90 St., NY, NY. Burial will be held at Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, VA. on January 24 at 2PM. Contributions may be made in his memory to United Nations Trust Fund in Support of Special Missions (Fund Code SZ), First Ave. at 42nd St., NY, NY 10017; Yale University Memorial Program, Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521-2038; Cardiovascular Institute, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Gustave Levy Pl., New York, NY 10128.

title: Selig Is Facing Heat With Owners' Support
description: Bud Selig enters the quarterly meetings of Major League Baseball owners today under the weight of a greater barrage of public criticism than perhaps any commissioner has ever faced. But inside the meeting room at the Biltmore Hotel in Phoenix, he will sit among friends and supporters, more or less immune from the charges that have battered him in recent weeks.

title: Persistent Losses Intensify Pressure on Opel's Chief
description: It has been only eight months since Carl-Peter Forster took over as chief executive of General Motors' Opel subsidiary, but he is already under time pressure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, SELMA
description: GOODMAN-Selma. On January 14, 2002. Beloved wife of Irving. Loving mother of Hillary & Stacey and her husband Eric. Devoted grandmother of Brette & Joshua. Dear sister of Bea. Services Thursday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. We will miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHACHNOW, RUTH
description: SHACHNOW-Ruth. On January 15, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Dennis. Loving mother of Lisa & Walter, Marjorie, Nancy & Peter. Dear sister of Bernice Polivy. Adoring grandmother of Michael, John, Anna, Kelly, Drew and Matt. Service on Wednesday 1 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Let's Keep the House Where Ruth Built It
description: To the Editor:

title: An Imaginary Tour of the Mediterranean
description: THE Marseille hovering behind Marseille the restaurant is not a real city. It is a poetic notion, a constellation of tastes, a vision of fierce white sunlight, bright blue water and chilled pink wine. It is, in short, a license to invent, and Alex Urea, Marseille's executive chef, has taken full advantage in this spacious, confident-feeling brasserie on the western edge of the theater district. He has not committed the sacrilege of leaving bouillabaisse off the menu, but, like his wine list, he wanders at will all over the Mediterranean, gathering ingredients from North Africa, Spain, Italy and France.

title: 2 Women Accuse Law Firm of Discrimination
description: Two women who worked for the law firm headed by David Boies filed a lawsuit yesterday charging that the firm had illegally discriminated against them and other female lawyers by paying them less than their male counterparts and by putting them in a dead-end career track.

title: Countertop Muscle Machine
description: The Tix sandwich toaster makes a snappy impression. Designed by Luca Trazzi, it is all curves and chrome, with a big ticking dial and red and blue lights that come on when the machine is plugged in or in use. But its beauty is more than chrome deep. It grills sandwiches to perfection, with two hinged baskets that slightly squeeze everything together for a result that's somewhere between the usual grilled cheese and a panini. A pull-out tray catches drippings and crumbs. Of course, the machine also makes perfect toast. The Tix is made by ViceVersa in Italy and costs $130 at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: E.P.A. Power Plant Cases To Proceed, Ashcroft Says
description: The Justice Department concluded today that the Clinton administration had acted reasonably in filing lawsuits against power plants under the Clean Air Act.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Property Tax Increase Urged
description: Citing falling revenue and rising costs, William Schuber, the Bergen County executive, proposed a 9.2 percent increase in county property taxes, the largest since he took office in 1990. Under the proposed rate of 23.5 cents per $100 of assessed valuation, taxes on a house assessed at the county average of $210,000 will increase $32. Mr. Schuber said the increase was needed to balance the county's $329.8 million budget. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Aging Cypriot Rivals to Begin Talks to End Ethnic Dispute
description: Two aging political leaders will sit down across a table from each other Wednesday to begin negotiations that will most likely decide their places in history and the future of the divided island they uneasily share.

title: A New Breed of Japanese Slacker
description: A"freetah" is the slang term for a young Japanese person who slacks from one noncareer low-paying job to the next.

title: Imus in the Mainstream
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheffield Gets Wish; Braves Get a Slugger
description: It turns out the Mets are not the only team in their division capable of making a splashy move. The Atlanta Braves, who had spent the winter fine-tuning while the Mets overhauled their roster, landed the All-Star outfielder Gary Sheffield yesterday in a four-player trade with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Jumps In Front Of Train
description: A man died after jumping into the path of a subway train at 42nd Street and Eight Avenue last night, the police said. The authorities did not release the name of the man, who was pronounced dead on the scene after being struck by a southbound A train at 8:03 p.m., said Officer Louis Camacho, a police spokesman. Service was halted in both directions on the A, C and E lines, but restored by shortly after 9 p.m. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Bleak Phone-Equipment Outlook Leads Marconi to Cut More Jobs
description: Marconi of Britain said today that it would lay off an additional 4,000 workers, about one-quarter of them in the United States, to cut costs because it believed that the telecommunications market was unlikely to recover before 2003.

title: THE CHEF
description: PERFECT golden Wiener schnitzel can be a work of art. Or it can be the worst dish of your life, more like a piece of lead.

title: South of the Border in Northern Manhattan
description: IF the street food is any clue, the stretch of the Upper West Side from 96th Street to 110th Street must be one of New York's fastest-growing Mexican neighborhoods. From early afternoon to late at night, lines of people wait by the taco trucks parked just off Broadway at 96th and 104th Streets. Early in the morning a vendor sells tamales stuffed with pork or chicken, light yet rich and very spicy, to subway riders at 103rd. Competing vendors stake out corners on Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Recovering Weatherspoon Decides That He's Not Ready
description: Don Chaney has had few reasons to smile during his brief, but dismal, tenure as the Knicks' head coach. But Monday afternoon something good happened.

title: Delta Farmers Want Copyright on Catfish
description: With blue herons circling overhead as fishermen pull in the day's catch, Joey Lowery explains why he is doing battle with the Vietnamese to save his own and other Mississippi Delta catfish farms.

title: Blair Enjoys Being Olympic Spectator
description: Bonnie Blair has not changed much. Even now, at 37, Blair still has that all-American, girl-next-door look. Blair, who won five gold medals over a speedskating career that spanned four Olympics, still looks fit enough to compete in the Salt Lake City Games next month.

title: Troopers' Case Ends, But the Talk Goes On
description: In a Trenton courtroom, the case that got the nation talking about racial profiling ended Monday as two state troopers pleaded guilty to reduced charges in the shooting of three unarmed men on the New Jersey Turnpike four years ago. But here in the streets and stores of North Jersey, the talk rolled on today -- a mix of anger, resignation and cynicism about the plea deal, and only meager signs of hope that profiling will cease.

title: Devils Fall in Overtime as Brodeur's Slump Continues
description: Zdeno Ciger crossed the blue line with the puck and slowly pulled his stick back, looking like Tiger Woods at the 18th tee. Martin Brodeur shifted toward Ciger and had plenty of time to cut down all the angles.

title: Recipe: Braised Lamb Shoulder With Olives
description: Time: 1 hour, plus 2 to 3 hours' cooking time and overnight chilling 4 to 4 1/2 pounds lamb shoulder, boned, rolled and tied (ask your butcher to do this, leaving a good layer of fat on the meat and reserving the bones)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Deer Hunt Cleared
description: A state judge yesterday rejected a motion to stop Princeton Township's annual deer hunt, leaving the town free to begin thinning the local herd. Animal-rights advocates, who sued to stop the hunt, had sought a halt prior to a hearing by a special two-judge panel. The township maintains that deer are dangerous to drivers and damage property and the environment. The rights group says the town's use of private hunters to shoot or trap the deer is cruel and dangerous, and that more humane alternatives exist. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: Justices to Rule on H.M.O. Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  With patients' rights legislation stalled in Congress, the spotlight moved to the Supreme Court today for an argument on whether states have the authority to require an independent medical review of a health maintenance organization's refusal to pay for a covered service.

title: First Ennis Cosby Scholars Graduate
description: After an 18-month course, 20 New York City elementary-school teachers have become the first Ennis William Cosby scholars of Fordham University's Graduate School of Education. Named for the son of Bill Cosby, the Hello Friend/ Ennis William Cosby Foundation provided the university with a grant to train 20 teachers each year for three years to teach reading to students with learning disabilities. Ennis Cosby, who was dyslexic, was studying for an advanced degree in special education when he was killed in 1997. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: The Farthest Thing From Pressure Cooking
description: FOR hours, I heard nothing but the occasional tinny pangs and shoosh! as the gas in my oven relighted. And when I checked it, I took the lid off the pot, only to peer in at a tied shoulder of lamb, seemingly unchanged, with bubbles slowly emerging around its edges as it braised.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Veteran Politician Seeks Top Job
description: Kim Jong Pil, an enduring political figure, said he would run for president in December. Mr. Kim, 76, supported Park Chung Hee in his takeover of the government in 1961, served as his intelligence chief and prime minister, was implicated in a corruption scandal after Mr. Park's assassination in 1979, ran for president in 1987 and then supported the reformist Kim Dae Jung in his successful 1997 campaign. President Kim, barred by the constitution from seeking a second term, picked Kim Jong Pil as his first prime minister but pulled his party from the governing coalition last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Quintessential American Shows in Europe for First Time : Moving Into Armani Territory, Ralph Lauren Takes On a Rival
description: MILAN  It is billed as the clash of two silver-haired titans with solid gold companies. On Wednesday, Ralph Lauren is staging a fashion show in Europe for the first time in a career that hits 35 this year. And by moving from Marlboro country to Giorgio Armani territory, he is taking on Italy's fashion king  the only designer in the world who can rival him for bucks and clout.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Ruling Favors Republicans
description: In a victory for Republicans, a three-judge federal panel said it would begin the process of redrawing the state's Congressional districts. A plan favored by Democrats and drawn by a state judge is awaiting approval from the United States Department of Justice, but the three judges said it might not be ready by the state's March 1 deadline for candidates to file.

title: Larger Minority Role Sought In Managing Retirement Funds
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that minority-owned firms should receive 10 percent of asset-management fees for managing corporate pension and 401(k) money -- setting a goal far higher than what such firms now receive.

title: Court Rules on Police Searches of Motorists
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that in evaluating whether ''reasonable suspicion'' existed for a police officer to detain a suspect briefly for questioning, courts should pay more attention to the officer's experience and the event's overall context than to possibly innocent explanations for individual parts of the incident.

title: Legal Counsel In Many Ways Mirrors Client
description: The law firm of Vinson & Elkins, which became publicly enmeshed this week in the Enron scandal, is often described much like its client: hugely powerful, international in scope and rich with connections from the statehouse to the White House.

title: Professorship for a Surviving Chef
description: MICHAEL LOMONACO, right, who was executive chef of the doomed Windows on the World at the World Trade Center, has been invited to be a distinguished visiting professor at New York City Technical College, a campus of the City University of New York, beginning next month. Mr. Lomonaco will hold classes in the culinary arts and help the college explore the possibility of developing a food and cooking program for CUNY-TV (Channel 75 on cable in New York City).

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMPAQ COMPUTER CORP., Houston, the second-largest personal computer maker, won a $17 million contract to supply 4,000 Evo workstations annually to Avid Technology, Tewksbury, Mass.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Tuesday, 3,114 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: The Real Lessons of Enron's Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Lessons of Enron's Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: For $8 a Bottle, The World's Richest Region
description: I DON'T think it's an overstatement to say that there are more good, reasonably priced and exciting wines emanating from southern Italy these days than from any other wine region. Prices are coming down everywhere in the wine world but the Italians have had a head start. So long as they don't drop the ball through greed and overproduction, theirs will be the wines to beat over the next five years, and perhaps even longer.

title: Enron's Ties to a Leader of House Republicans Went Beyond Contributions to His Campaign
description: It is well known that the Enron Corporation lavished money and attention on political figures all over the nation's capital. But for an insight into how carefully the company cultivated members of Congress, look no further than its efforts to please its home state powerhouse, Representative Tom DeLay.

title: Osama bin Laden
A Moment to Seize in Kashmir
description: The national address by President Pervez Musharraf on Saturday has been praised both in Pakistan and internationally, but it has also generated debate on the real intent behind it. While setting a new agenda of arresting Islamic militants in de-escalating the immediate tension with India, the speech fell short of announcing any major changes in Pakistan's support for Kashmir's struggle to become part of Pakistan. The Indian government appeared less impressed than the international press precisely because the speech did not indicate any fundamental policy change. In fact General Musharraf reiterated that the Kashmir issue ''runs in our [Pakistani] blood.''

title: McGREEVEY PLEADS FOR TRENTON UNITY
description: Declaring that the ''days of irresponsible borrowing and runaway spending are over,'' James E. McGreevey was sworn in as New Jersey's 51st governor today and challenged state residents to help him improve their educational system and deter terrorism even while facing a spiraling fiscal crisis.

title: World Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Add Grosjean to List Of Surprising Losers
description: When the Grand Slam tournament presidents agreed last year to expand the number of seeded players to 32 from 16, there was widespread concern that the decision might make the opening rounds less compelling and more predictable.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Lenders Differ in Disclosing Their Exposure to Troubles
description: The two biggest lenders to Enron have given distinctly different responses to questions about their ties to the failed company. While J. P. Morgan Chase rushed to detail its potential losses, Citigroup has repeatedly rebuffed inquiries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSLYN, GERDA (NEE STEINHAGEN)
description: ROSLYN-Gerda (nee Steinhagen). Wife of deceased husband Sidney, died January 14th, 2002, at age 92. Special sister to Ruth Nurnberger and Helga Hoffbauer, daughter Ellen Plancher, grandson Kevin, granddaughter Daryn and great-grandchildren Brian, Jamie and Megan. We will forever miss our loving Mom/Nani.

title: Professorship for a Surviving Chef
description: MICHAEL LOMONACO, right, who was executive chef of the doomed Windows on the World at the World Trade Center, has been invited to be a distinguished visiting professor at New York City Technical College, a campus of the City University of New York, beginning next month. Mr. Lomonaco will hold classes in the culinary arts and help the college explore the possibility of developing a food and cooking program for CUNY-TV (Channel 75 on cable in New York City).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Newspaper To Make Debut In Spring
description: The New York Sun, a daily newspaper being started by investors and former members of The Forward, announced yesterday that it would begin publication in the spring. Its editor will be Seth Lipsky, left, former editor of The Forward, the English-language descendant of the Yiddish daily, and vice president of the new paper's parent publishing company. Representatives of the company said yesterday that the broadsheet would be published on weekdays, from offices at 105 Chambers Street. They also disclosed a new list of investors, including Charles Brunie, the former chairman of the Manhattan Institute; Russell L. Carson, general partner of Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe and chairman of Rockefeller University; and the philanthropist Michael Steinhardt, founder of Steinhardt Partners and chairman of Tel Aviv University. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFENDORF, CHARLES E.
description: DEFENDORF-Charles E. On January 13, 2002, of North Salem, NY at the age of 89. Former president and CEO of Seelye, Stevenson, Value & Knecht and former chief engineer of the Penn Central Railroad. Survived by his wife of 53 years, Beatrice, and sons, Charlie, Richard and Robert and one grandson, Charles, Jr. Reposing Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, 1300 Pleasantville Rd, Briarcliff Manor, New York on Wednesday, 2-4 & 7-9PM. Services Scarborough Presbyterian Church, Route 9 at Scarborough Road, Scarborough, on Thursday, January 17, at 10AM. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery Mausoleum.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Lower Interest Rates
description: Canadian banks said they would lower their prime lending rate to 3.75 percent from 4 percent after a quarter-point cut in the Bank of Canada's target for the bellwether overnight rate. The overnight rate now stands at 2 percent, down from 5.75 percent a year ago and the lowest level since September 1960.

title: U.N. Officials Press White House To Free Family-Planning Money
description: United Nations officials pressed the White House today to release $34 million for international family planning in suspension because of objections from conservatives about China's abortion policies.

title: A New Breed of Japanese Slacker
description: A"freetah" is the slang term for a young Japanese person who slacks from one noncareer low-paying job to the next.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Moulinex Deal Set
description: Four months after the Moulinex Brandt Group of France, best known to Americans for its Moulinex and Krups appliances, sought protection from creditors, a French commercial court awarded control of the Brandt white-goods division, which manufactures stoves and other large kitchen appliances, to Elco Holdings Ltd. of Israel. The court rejected rival bids from the Whirlpool Corporation, Candy of Italy, and Arcelik of Turkey, after Elco pledged to maintain seven of eight existing factories and about 80 percent of the work force in France, or 4,195 employees. Elco pledged to invest 318 million euros, or $284 million, in Brandt over the next year. In October, SEB, a rival French appliance maker, acquired Moulinex Brandt's small-appliance activities, including the Moulinex, Krups and Rowenta brands.

title: San Diego Offshore
description: The 206-room Shelter Pointe Hotel and Marina, on 12 acres on Shelter Island in San Diego Bay, has deluxe rooms with water views and daily breakfast for two for $119 a night plus tax. The rate applies through March 14 and there is limited availability; reservations are recommended. The hotel features two heated pools and whirlpools and a fitness center. Formerly the Kona Kai Resort, it was bought and renovated by Pacifica Hotel Company in 1998. Information: (800) 566-2524 or www.shelterpointe.com .

title: Footlights
description: Writers' Words

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bridge Set For Ground Zero
description: A New Jersey company has been hired to install a 500-foot-long temporary bridge at the World Trade Center site. The two-lane bridge, which is to cost about $2 million, will let trucks climb in and out of the site's seven-story pit. Trucks now drive precariously on muddy roads that are supported by packed debris. The bridge will be installed over the next six to eight weeks to aid the final stages of the cleanup. It will be built by Acrow Corporation of Carlstadt, N.J., and run parallel to West Street. It will also be used to help with any rebuilding at the site. Eric Lipton (NYT)

title: Dismay With Saudi Arabia Fuels Pullout Talk
description: A number of senior officials in Congress and the Pentagon are saying the United States should consider withdrawing military forces from Saudi Arabia because of frustration over what they consider the kingdom's tepid support for the war on terrorism and the restrictions it places on American military operations.

title: Major Railroads Win Ruling to Block Strike
description: The Union Pacific Corporation and other major railroads won a court order this week to block a strike by train engineers who protested a plan to assign freight-car switching work to a rival union.

title: The Real Lessons of Enron's Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: Stiffling the Urge to Claw Out an Eye
description: ''Collected Stories'' by Donald Margulies is a fascinating but difficult play because you need to know the ending to appreciate the rest. There goes the thrill of the unexpected.

title: Kabul Needs $15 Billion, Official Says
description: The interim government of Afghanistan needs an immediate infusion of money to keep operating, the head of the United Nations Development Program said today, adding that over the next 10 years, about $15 billion will be required to reconstruct the country.

title: New Questions About Kava's Safety
description: IN Europe, the reaction was swift. On Nov. 8, German scientists reported that kava, an herbal supplement promoted for stress reduction, may be responsible for 30 cases of liver toxicity in Germany and Switzerland. Switzerland pulled kava off the market. Britain asked for its voluntary withdrawal. And Germany warned manufacturers that it may soon ban kava. Last week, France banned its sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, HERMAN J.
description: FINE-Herman J. Of Bronx, New York, beloved husband of Esther (Goldstein) Fine, died on January 14, 2002. He was born in New York, June 14, 1913. He was a longtime member of Beth Shraga Synagogue. He attended Yeshiva D'Harlem and Yeshiva Yitzhak Elchanan High School. He then went to City College where he received a B.A. and an M.S. in Education. He subsequently earned an M.A. degree in Semitic Studies from Columbia University. He also completed a course of study at the Jewish Theological Seminary. Besides his beloved wife, he is survived by his loving daughters and sons-in-law, Serena and Michael English of New York, Rhoda and Todd Gladstone of Connecticut and sister Diane Kassner of the Bronx. He is also survived by his loving grandchildren, Rebecca & Daniel English, Debbie & Beth Gladstone and many nieces and nephews. Funeral services were held at the Louis Hirsch & Sons Funeral Home, 1225 Jerome Avenue in the Bronx with burial at Beth El Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. A memorial period will be observed at his home at 185 E. 206 Street in the Bronx until Monday January 21, 2002. Donations in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Muslim Animal Slaughter Approved
description: The country's highest court overturned a ban on the traditional Muslim slaughter of animals by slitting their throats and letting them bleed to death, ruling that Muslim butchers do not have to lessen the animals' pain. The Constitutional Court said the ban, imposed by a lower court in 1995, impermissibly interfered with professional freedom as it effectively barred Muslims from working as butchers. Animal protection laws prohibit the killing of animals without anesthetic but allow exceptions for religious reasons. Overturning the ban will make it easier for German Muslims to observe the Id al-Adha holiday next month, when families sacrifice animals, Muslim officials said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Beefy Soup Without The Beef
description: SOUP made without meat or meat broth can be insipid. That's why most people think pea soup needs ham and mushroom-barley soup needs beef. But it's possible to make a satisfying, even hearty, vegetarian soup if you choose your ingredients carefully, and extract every bit of flavor from them.

title: Georgia Finds Itself in Jobless Benefits Bind
description: Like many other states, Georgia once thought it could have it all. Three years ago, when its economy was humming and jobs were plentiful, the Legislature suspended the unemployment insurance tax for thousands of businesses with few effects on the needy.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We may never know why he turned his back on our country and our values, but we cannot ignore that he did.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISENBERG, GILDA
description: WEISENBERG - Gilda. Beloved wife of Stuart, devoted mother of Jill and Les Jacobs and Karen and Mitchell Rose. Cherished grandmother of Elizabeth and Andrew. Loving sister of Joan Miguez. Services Wednesday 11:30AM at Temple Judea, 333 Searingtown Rd, Manhasset, NY & a memorial service on Thurs, January 24 in Boca West in Boca Raton, FL. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, LI-Lymphoma Research.

title: Some Guidance From the Pros for the Kosher Julia Child
description: Kosher cooking has a bright new venue at the Jewish Community Center, which has just opened at 334 Amsterdam Avenue (76th Street). Starting Feb. 4, chefs from restaurants on the Upper West Side, including Neil Annis of Marika, Sarabeth Levine of Sarabeth's and Gennaro Piccone of Gennaro, will present a series of demonstrations there on adapting their recipes in accordance with kosher law ($275 for the series, $50 per class for members, or $335 and $60 for nonmembers). There's a kosher teaching kitchen with gas range tops, ovens, refrigerators and dishwashers  two of each, for meat and dairy preparations  and a full program of classes, including some for children and families. The director of the center's cooking school, Einav Gefen (far left, with Ms. Levine), was a chef in Israel, studied cooking at Peter Kump's (now the Institute for Culinary Education), and was an intern at Daniel. Some instructors, like Anita Jacobson, also teach at the Institute for Culinary Education. For information: (646) 505-4379.

title: The Fugue State
description: Los Angeles has plenty of experience with natural disasters and staged disasters -- not to mention box-office disasters.

title: Council Speaker Plans to Cut Stipends for Himself and Others
description: Gifford Miller, the speaker of the City Council, is planning to cut the stipend given for his post by about 25 percent, officials said yesterday, and wants to trim both the range and the dollar amount of other stipends paid for positions like committee chairman or majority whip.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BellSouth Fined Over Payments
description: The BellSouth Corporation yesterday reached a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in which it agreed to pay a $150,000 penalty to end an investigation into allegations that the company made improper payments in two Latin American countries. The S.E.C.'s complaint accused BellSouth of paying $60,000 to the wife of a congressman who was chairman of a legislative committee with oversight of Nicaragua's telecommunications industry. That committee proposed repeal of foreign ownership restrictions, later approved, that allowed BellSouth to take control of its Nicaraguan subsidiary in June 2000. The S.E.C. also contended that employees of BellSouth's unit in Venezuela made about $10.8 million in payments to offshore companies from 1997 to 2000 and improperly recorded the disbursements based on fictitious invoices. The S.E.C. said BellSouth was unable to identify the circumstances of the payments and the identity of their ultimate recipients. A BellSouth spokesman said the company neither admitted nor denied the S.E.C.'s findings under the terms of the settlement. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Captives Remain Holed Up in Kandahar Hospital Drama
description: Standing with his soldiers on the second floor of Mirvais Hospital here, Nazer Jan said at least some of the six men believed to be Al Qaeda fighters trapped on the other side of a sealed doorway at the end of the corridor were still alive, despite attempts to starve them out.

title: When Are Captives Prisoners of War?
