title: Hostage Taker Had Own Gun, Police Say
description: A man who held a police detective at gunpoint for more than three hours inside an Upper East Side station house early yesterday morning had carried the weapon with him when he was brought in for questioning on a harassment complaint lodged by his child's mother, the police said.

title: Profit at EBay Increased 8% Last Quarter
description: EBay Inc., the Internet auctioneer, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose more than 8 percent as buyers and sellers used its Web site for holiday gifts.

title: Univision bets on a new Spanish-language network, TeleFutura.
description: WITH the advertising business slumping so badly, it hardly seems the moment to start selling commercial time on a new television network.

title: N.C.A.A. President to Retire Within a Year
description: Cedric W. Dempsey ended speculation about his status today, saying he will step down as president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association when his term expires next Jan. 1.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vodafone Sells Stake
description: The British telecommunications company Vodafone Group sold its remaining stake in Atecs Mannesmann, a German engineering and automotive firm, to Siemens for 3.7 billion euros ($3.3 billion). Vodafone sold slightly more than 50 percent of Atecs to Siemens shortly after it acquired the unit when it bought Mannesmann in February 2000. The sale is part of Atecs's attempts to shed its nontelecommunications units and reduce its long-term debt.

title: Raiders Reach New England On Garner's Swollen Foot
description: His performance was not quite like Willis Reed's limping into Madison Square Garden to lead the Knicks in Game 7 of the 1970 N.B.A. finals, but Charlie Garner, the diminutive Oakland running back, provided plenty of playoff heroics last Saturday night in a 38-24 victory over the Jets.

title: Kennedy Urges Delay of Some Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for postponing much of the tax-cut package embraced by President Bush and Republicans in Congress, declaring that there are too many urgent national needs to give breaks to those who need them the least.

title: Students Seek Refuge, And Some, Answers
description: Nina B. de Fels was teaching a ninth-grade English class at Martin Luther King Jr. High School yesterday afternoon when she heard shots. Soon afterward, an assistant principal came on the public address system and announced that everyone should stay in their classrooms.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about questions from Democratic lawmakers about the effectiveness of regulators in light of the collapse of Enron misspelled the surname of the chief of staff for Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California. The aide, who said calls from Enron executives to members of President Bush's cabinet last fall should have prompted at least a preliminary investigation, is Philip M. Schiliro, not Schilaro.

title: S.E.C. and Auditors Consider New Rules
description: Harvey Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has met with the Big 5 accounting firms to discuss changes in how auditors are regulated, a spokeswoman for the commission said last night.

title: Still Licentious, but Freshly Vulnerable Too
description: ''And did you like my number?''

title: Rangers Without Two Key Players
description: After placing their captain, Mark Messier, and one of their top scorers, Andreas Johansson, on the injured list, the Rangers arrived in Columbus, Ohio, yesterday afternoon for tonight's back end of a home-and-home series with the Columbus Blue Jackets.

title: Social Security Agency Settles Workers' Bias Case
description: The Social Security Administration has agreed to pay nearly $8 million to settle a class-action discrimination complaint by 2,200 black male employees, officials said today.

title: Same Old Spurrier To Coach Redskins
description: Steve Spurrier was not here to apologize for his bank-busting $25 million contract, and he saw no reason to change now that he is the new coach of the Washington Redskins.

title: Bloomberg Says Details On Stadiums Were Omitted
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he was unaware of some details of the new stadium deals with the Yankees and the Mets that the Giuliani administration negotiated in its final days, including a clause that allows the teams to abandon the city on 60 days' notice.

title: Fear and Flight in Deadly Kashmir
description: One night two weeks ago, Gulshan Kumar Sharma heard a knock at the door and a voice calling out, ''Didi'' -- older sister, in Hindi. When he answered, the 28-year-old Hindu farmer was gunned down on the threshold of his mud house.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Senator Seeks Full Term
description: Senator Jean Carnahan, a freshman whom Republicans view as vulnerable, said she would run for election in November. Ms. Carnahan was appointed to serve two years of the term that her husband, Gov. Mel Carnahan, was elected to after he was killed in a plane crash just weeks before the election in 2000. In a letter to her supporters, Ms. Carnahan said she would formally announce her candidacy in a few weeks. She will probably face former Representative James M. Talent, a Republican who narrowly lost the race for governor last year.

title: The Show 'Cats' Nears Final Meow in London
description: After more than two decades as a fixture on the London stage, ''Cats,'' the Andrew Lloyd Webber show that ushered in the era of the megamusical and sired productions around the world, will close out its West End run on May 11. At the time of its closing, the show will have played for 21 years to the day and nearly 9,000 performances at the New London Theater, easily making it the longest-running musical in British history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANSON, ROBERT SINCLAIR JR.
description: SWANSON-Robert Sinclair Jr. Of Naples, FL, and South Burlington, VT, died in Naples on January 10, 2002. He was born in New York City to Robert and Louise Swanson on April 27, 1925. He was graduated from the Stony Brook School and Babson College. He served in the 10th Mountain Division of the United States Army in Italy in World War II. He retired as President of S. B. Thomas, Inc., makers of Thomas's English Muffins. He served as President of the Board of Trustees of the Stony Brook School for 25 years. He served on the Board of the Long Island Savings Bank. As a Little League coach he led five championship teams. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Virginia, his daughter Barbara Sherman of New York City, his sons Alan of Charlottesville, VA, and Robert III of South Hero, VT, and two brothers, John P. Swanson of Flat Rock, NC, and George Daniel Swanson of Cary, NC. He is predeceased by his son Lawrence, his grandson Matthew, his sister Janet, and his brother David. He had eight grandchildren. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Stony Brook School, Stony Brook, NY 11790. A memorial service will be held Friday, January 18, at 1 PM, in the chapel of the Stony Brook School, Stony Brook, NY, with reception to follow.

title: Group Finds Common Ground and Hurdles on Religion-Based Plan
description: Many had never met before. Some were acquainted only from shouting at one another on television talk shows about the proper place to draw the line between church and state.

title: For a Change, the Mess Precedes Parcells
description: One of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' assistants was on the telephone recently and vented like a steaming volcano. He was bitter, infuriated really, at what he felt was the unfair treatment of the head coach, Tony Dungy, by the owner, Malcolm Glazer. But the assistant's ire was raised even higher when the name Bill Parcells came up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMZUE, FRIEDA (NEE ALTMAN)
description: GAMZUE-Frieda (nee Altman). Died peacefully Monday, January 14 at the age of 97. Beloved wife of the late Boris, dearest sister of the late Ruth, Sid, and Nathaniel. Adored aunt of Steven, Nelson, Roger, Kip, Stephen, and Davis. Member of Actors Equity. Memorial service to be held Thursday, 2PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about constituents' reaction to the coming racketeering trial of Representative James A. Traficant Jr., Democrat of Ohio, misstated the name of the high school he attended in his district. It is Cardinal Mooney, not Bishop Mooney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, ROBERT
description: APPEL-Robert. Died on January 10. Of Fairlawn, NJ. Predeceased by his wife Helen, he is survived by his son James (Diane).

title: Buccaneers Make Move In Parcells's Direction
description: Two executives of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, and sons of the team's owner, said today in a contentious news conference that they had not contacted potential candidates to replace Tony Dungy and had not even assembled a list of candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YARVIN, HAROLD A.
description: YARVIN-Harold A. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted father of Mitchell, Eric (Nancy), and Julie (Steve) Brodsky. Dear brother of Laura (Yarvin) Goldfluss. Loving grandfather of Jessica Yarvin and Jack Brodsky. Services today 11:30 A.M. at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: The Bickering Brechts Taking One Final Fractious Holiday
description: ''The Farewell,'' Jan Schtte's portrait of the ailing playwright Bertolt Brecht three days before his death, in the late summer of 1956, is the psychological equivalent of the kind of close-up photo that scours the face to uncover every dermatological blemish and portray the countenance as a map of personal ruin. As memorably embodied by Josef Bierbichler, Brecht, who is 58 at the time of the story, comes across as a sacred monster slavishly attended by a regiment of jealous, bickering women. A bearish autocrat one minute, a sniveling baby the next, he is alternately thunderous and pitiful, the embodiment of the great artist as a spoiled demigod in the twilight of his reign.

title: COOPER BUYS EYE-CARE UNIT FROM BRITISH COMPANY
description: The Cooper Companies, a maker of contact lenses, has agreed to buy the eye-care unit of Biocompatibles International for $23 million to expand its range of coated lenses. In addition to the cash payment, Cooper will pay off about $11.6 million in Biocompatibles' debt and will lend the company $63.8 million, Biocompatibles said. Cooper, based in Irvine, Calif., will gain 950 employees and Biocompatibles' ProClear coated lenses, which are designed for dry eyes. The unit had about $70 million in 2001 sales. Cooper will also gain a coating that may be used to develop extended-wear lenses, its chief executive, Thomas Bender, said. Biocompatibles, based in Britain, plans to concentrate on stents, tiny metal tubes used to prop open arteries.

title: A Clinton Loyalist Puts Faith in a Fortified Harlem
description: CLYDE WILLIAMS, the domestic policy adviser to Bill Clinton, is heading to a bakery down Lenox Avenue in Harlem, a few blocks from Mr. Clinton's new penthouse office. But it's not just any bakery. He opens the door of an elegant new establishment, Settepani, owned by an Eritrean woman who greets him warmly.

title: Mini-Manhattan Campus for Stony Brook
description: As campuses go, the State University of New York at Stony Brook's new Manhattan campus is limited: 18,000 square feet at 401 Park Avenue South at 28th Street -- a tiny speck relative to its sprawling 1,200 acres in Suffolk County. But the university, which has 21,000 students, hopes that the 11 classrooms, 2 conference rooms, and offices, which are being unveiled this month, will start a greater focus on the city. The university already conducts social work and education programs in New York, and plans to add regular classes for students and short courses and other events for alumni, and to use the space as a base for student internships and fund-raising.

title: Korea Looks to Sell as Banks Turn Profit
description: Long-stalled government plans to get out of the banking business have been given a lift by reports that as a group, South Korea's banks returned to profits last year.

title: The Prosecution of John Walker
description: The Bush administration is doing the right thing by prosecuting John Walker in a civilian court rather than a military tribunal or a court-martial for his association with the Taliban and Osama bin Laden. The charges the government has brought against the young American, including conspiring to kill United States soldiers in Afghanistan and aiding a terrorist group, seem more appropriate than treason, which can bring a death sentence. Mr. Walker will face extremely serious charges that could be punished by life imprisonment. As the case proceeds, the Justice Department must ensure that he receives a fair trial.

description: She's looking for someone with a keen appreciation of history, a lot of imagination and a welder's torch. Forty-foot ceilings wouldn't hurt, either.

title: Panel Cuts $2.8 Million for Roosevelt Schools
description: As state overseers tonight imposed $2.8 million in cuts in the Roosevelt school district to prevent it from running out of money, legislative leaders were seeking a full state takeover and more money for the long-troubled district.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Premier Names Deputy
description: In a broad cabinet shuffle, Prime Minister Jean Chrtien appointed John Manley, the foreign minister, left, who had also been the coordinator of antiterrorism efforts, to be his deputy. The promotion appeared to make Mr. Manley, 52, a strong contender in a struggle within the ruling Liberal Party to replace Mr. Chrtien. But the prime minister, 68, said he had no plans to step down. Mr. Chrtien also dropped Alfonso Gagliano, the public works minister, who had been embroiled in corruption controversies. The changes came after the surprise resignation of Brian Tobin, the industry minister. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Iranian Pardoned After Reformists Walk Out
description: The speaker of the reformist Parliament and most of its members walked out today to protest the jailing of a lawmaker who had spoken out against hard-liners. The action prompted the country's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, to grant a pardon.

title: Misdirected Defense Dollars
description: It's axiomatic that military budgets grow in wartime, and this year will be no exception. The Bush administration's planned $350 billion Pentagon budget for the next fiscal year is some $20 billion higher than current spending and a 6 percent increase over the rate of inflation. Events since Sept. 11 have clearly demonstrated the need for a highly flexible military force, adequately paid and housed, maintained in a high state of readiness and equipped with the appropriate high-tech tools of 21st-century warfare.

description: Invoking security concerns, President Bush has issued an executive order barring union representation at United States attorneys' offices and at four other agencies in the Justice Department.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 16  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell emerged tonight from a meeting with President Pervez Musharraf and other top Pakistani officials praising their efforts to crack down on violent extremists and vowing to do all he could to help defuse tensions with India over the disputed Kashmir region.

title: Sniffing Out Meaning: A Portrait of the Artist as a Pig, or Perhaps a Dog
description: All of what is best and worst about the art of the theatrical auteur Lee Breuer is present in ''Ecco Porco.'' This is an assessment that the self-aware Mr. Breuer might well take as a compliment. Performed by Mabou Mines, the experimental troupe that Mr. Breuer helped found in 1970, the show (at P.S. 122 through Jan. 27), is a meandering essay on the artistic sensibility, an undisciplined four-hour skate across a deep intellectual pond.

description: You can sit for hours in Ivo Lorenc's comfy cafe here and not notice exactly what is going on: a painting on the wall, for instance, shows a winter scene so cheery it is possible to miss that the snowmen have gathered in a subtle pack and are stabbing someone in the snow. With carrots.

description: Here's the thing about following current events. When an item first appears in the news, you must make a quick decision: Will it turn into a daily front-page story or will it end up being filler, buried next to an article about Connecticut opening its motor vehicle tax records to the public? All too often, I make the wrong call.

title: Rumsfeld Believes bin Laden and Omar Are Still in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he believes the elusive Osama bin Laden and Mullah Muhammad Omar are still in Afghanistan.

title: EXXON MOBIL VENTURE STARTS EXPANSION IN QATAR
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation's liquefied natural gas venture in Qatar has begun building a third production line that will nearly double production by 2004, Qatar's energy minister said yesterday. The Ras Laffan Liquefied Natural Gas Company, a partnership between the Exxon Mobil and Qatar's government, will spend $700 million to increase output to 11.3 million tons of liquefied natural gas a year from 6.6 million now, said Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah, according to the official QNA news agency. Qatar, whose North Dome site is the world's largest natural gas field, aims to become the largest exporter of liquefied natural gas. The new line's production will be shipped to India.

title: Waiter, Please Put a Lid on It
description: LONG ago, before anyone had heard of fish tartare, potato foam or the foie gras martini, waiters performed a very basic function. They stood and took your order. If there were specials, they recited them. When the food came out of the kitchen, they delivered it to the table. Everyone seemed happy with the setup.

title: Sports of The Times; N.B.A. Needs To Hit Shaq Much Harder
description: FORGET about not wanting to be punched by Shaquille O'Neal. You don't want to be bumped by him. ''If I was trying to squeeze through a subway door, and Shaquille O'Neal was next to me,'' Henry Feldman, a basketball fan and Manhattan accountant, observed, ''I'd take the next train.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Concern For Zimbabweans
description: The government announced that it would suspend deportations of Zimbabweans whose requests for asylum were rejected until after their country's election in March. The decision was made out of concern for the harsh treatment opposition figures are receiving from the security forces of President Robert Mugabe. Home Secretary David Blunkett said that 106 Zimbabweans were currently awaiting deportation and that he was concerned some might be persecuted, imprisoned or tortured if they went back. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Tuition Rises for Many Immigrants
description: With the City University's higher tuition for illegal immigrants taking effect this month, some public officials and public interest groups have lined up to fight it. Assemblyman PETER M. RIVERA of the Bronx has introduced a bill that would allow all immigrants who graduate from a New York high school, or earn an equivalent degree in the state, to pay in-state tuition, now $1,600 a semester at a four-year CUNY college. (Students without legal immigration status -- there were more than 2,000 last year -- will now have to pay the out-of-state tuition of $3,400.) The Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund and other opponents have sued to stop the increase. And a group of students and faculty members started a three-day hunger strike yesterday in protest. MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN, CUNY's chancellor, said that he supported Mr. Rivera's legislation, noting that CUNY adopted the higher tuition to conform to federal law. Karen W. Arenson

title: A Periodic Table of Flavors
description: ''THE ELEMENTS OF TASTE,'' the long-awaited effort from Gray Kunz and Peter Kaminsky, is really two books under one cover.

title: Layoffs at Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the big securities firm, yesterday laid off 120 employees who worked in its information technology department, a spokeswoman confirmed. About two-thirds of those laid off worked in the company's headquarters in Manhattan or at other offices in North America, the spokeswoman, Judith Hitchen, said. The cuts were made to reduce costs and came after a review of technology projects, some of which were postponed or canceled, she said.

title: Neat and Sweet, But an Odd Nut
description: HAZELNUTS are often the ugly ducklings of the nut bowl, left waiting and lonely while the popular walnuts, pecans and almonds are whisked away. Their rich, musky flavor tends to be overshadowed by the double handicap of their small size and a bitter skin, which is best removed before eating.

title: William Moses, 74, Real Estate Executive
description: William A. Moses, a New York City real estate executive who was active in organizations representing small landlords, died on Jan. 3 in his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, DAVID MAYER
description: EPSTEIN-David Mayer. Of Lexington, MA January 15, 2002. Husband of Anne M. Epstein (Merrick), father of Eve M. Epstein-Burian and her husband, Ronald, of Portland, OR and Beth S. Epstein-Hounza and her husband, Max, of Paris, France. Brother of Carolyn Koistinen of Northridge, CA. Grandfather of Leah Burian of Portland, OR and Samuel Hounza of Paris, France. title: A Bouquet That Delights the Eye and the Palate
description: Clusters of hon shimeji mushrooms are pretty enough for a centerpiece. They have an almost honeyed flavor and a texture that stays crispy when they are gently cooked. They are delicious with bay scallops, steamed fish, and to float in a broth. The mushrooms are cultivated and are sold in clusters for $11.50 a pound. Each cluster is about a half pound. They keep well in the refrigerator. Manhattan Fruit Exchange, in the Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), carries them year-round.

title: Stephen B. Dobrow, Straphangers' Droll Voice, Dies at 58
description: Dr. Stephen B. Dobrow, who served for 40 years as the surrogate voice of the straphanger, demanding better mass transit, hectoring transit officials and using his encyclopedic knowledge of the subways to suggest better ways to fix them, died on Sunday at his home in Woodside, Queens. He was 58.

title: Some Guidance From the Pros For the Kosher Julia Child
description: Kosher cooking has a bright new venue at the Jewish Community Center, which has just opened at 334 Amsterdam Avenue (76th Street). Starting Feb. 4, chefs from restaurants on the Upper West Side, including Neil Annis of Marika, Sarabeth Levine of Sarabeth's and Gennaro Piccone of Gennaro, will present a series of demonstrations there on adapting their recipes in accordance with kosher law ($275 for the series, $50 per class for members, or $335 and $60 for nonmembers). There's a kosher teaching kitchen with gas range tops, ovens, refrigerators and dishwashers -- two of each, for meat and dairy preparations -- and a full program of classes, including some for children and families. The director of the center's cooking school, Einav Gefen (far left, with Ms. Levine), was a chef in Israel, studied cooking at Peter Kump's (now the Institute for Culinary Education), and was an intern at Daniel. Some instructors, like Anita Jacobson, also teach at the Institute for Culinary Education. For information: (646) 505-4379.

World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Samsung's Profit Falls
description: The world's largest producer of memory chips, Samsung Electronics, said its fourth-quarter profit fell 64 percent, to $307 million, largely as a result of a drop in memory chip prices. The outlook is better for this year, however, with 128-megabit DRAM (dynamic random access memory) chips now selling for $3.50 on the spot market. They fell to less than a dollar last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Euro Is a Hit in Montenegro (Yes, Montenegro)
description: The scene at the local bank appeared ominous: locked doors, a throng of anxious customers outside and a security guard who would admit only one person when another left.

title: White House Says Economics Adviser Saw Little Risk on Enron
description: The White House said today that President Bush's top economic adviser, who had served as a paid consultant to the Enron Corporation before joining the administration, had directed a review of the broad economic effects of a potential collapse of the company but concluded it posed little risk to the American economy.

title: Bonus Season for Baseball
description: Perhaps politicians serving out their last days in office should be urged to do as little as possible. Certainly former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani did not do the city any favors when he fell into the trap of trying to wrap up deals for new Mets and Yankees baseball stadiums a few days before stepping down.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Unemployment Rises
description: Unemployment in Britain nudged upward for a third successive month, but the overall unemployment rate remained close to a 26-year low at 3.2 percent, far below the levels in the European Union and the United States. Government figures said 3,200 more unemployed people claimed benefits in December; the total was 963,500, lower than economists had forecast. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIFF, SAUL
description: SEIFF-Saul. Died in his sleep on January 15 after a prolonged illness. Builder and philanthropist, he is mourned by his wife, Elaine, his sister, Estelle Fincke, his daughters, Marilyn, Francine and Andrea, his grandchildren Joshua, Hilary, Lisa, Alex and Erika and his great-grandchildren Alex, Nicholas and Zackary. Funeral services Thursday, January 17th at 1 PM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

title: Eight Architectural Eyes Take A Fresh Look at Everyday Objects
description: Rare is the architectural firm that sets up a retail shop, but Rios Associates has done so with notNeutral. It is the brainchild of Mark Rios of Rios Associates and his colleagues, Frank Clementi, Julie Smith and Matt Richmond. Rios Associates (which does architectural, landscape and environmental design) was responsible for the ''Terminator 2'' three-dimensional attraction at Universal Studios Hollywood and Rock, a restaurant in Marina Del Rey, Calif. NotNeutral sells housewares and bed, bath and furniture accessories designed by the four. The Circuit tableware, above, was inspired by a circuit board (four five-piece table settings cost $254). The inventive deck of cards, below, sells for $12. NotNeutral is a 500-square-foot store in front of the Rios Associates design office, 8008 West Third Street in Los Angeles; (800) 270 5612; www.notNeutral.com.

title: Keith Clark, Bugler for Kennedy, Dies at 74
description: Keith Clark, the Army bugler whose imperfect rendition of taps at the funeral of President John F. Kennedy came to be seen as a perfect embodiment of national sorrow, died last Friday at a hospital in Fort Pierce, Fla. Mr. Clark, who lived in Port Charlotte, Fla., was 74.

title: Auditor Struck Many As Smart and Upright
description: David B. Duncan was a man on the move at Arthur Andersen's offices here. In his 20-year rise at the accounting firm, the leading one in the city, he had become the lead partner serving Enron, one of the firm's biggest and most prestigious clients.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Orders From Chip Makers Fall
description: Orders for the equipment used to make computer chips fell a record 85.6 percent in November, the Semiconductor Equipment Association of Japan said. It was the 11th consecutive decline for the equipment makers, which include Tokyo Electron and the Nikon Corporation. Chip makers order such equipment about six months before they need to crank up production. The yearlong slide in demand suggests that chip makers, whose products go in things like computers and cellphones, do not plan to increase output any time soon. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Parcells May Be Bending The Rules
description: In mid-December, Bill Parcells went to a Giants home game and sat in a luxury box with a New York radio personality and another friend. A few days after the game a Giants player joked that Coach Jim Fassel had better watch his back.

title: Tribes Balking At Cave Hunt, Pentagon Says
description: Many Pashtun tribal leaders in eastern Afghanistan have balked at cooperating with American Special Operations Forces in the hunt for Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters, weapons caches and intelligence that could prevent future terrorist attacks, military officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Head Of Business Group
description: The Times Square Business Improvement District yesterday named as its new president Tim Tompkins, the director of Partnerships for Parks. He succeeds Brendan Sexton, who resigned in September. Mr. Tompkins was one of the leaders of Parks 2001, which campaigned for more public money for parks. He said the issues affecting Times Square were similar to those affecting parks.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Despite big losses at American and Continental, executives say airlines may recover in 2002.
description: AMERICAN AIRLINES and Continental Airlines reported large fourth-quarter losses yesterday, reflecting the plunge in air travel after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But executives at the airlines expressed some optimism that the industry might recover later this year.

title: Nets Can't Miss as Jordan Just Falls Away
description: The night was delirious and dizzying, showcasing the kind of rare performance reserved for special talents.

title: Bloomberg Sees No Wrong In Last-Day Bonuses to Staff
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that there was ''nothing wrong with me spending my own money'' to reward several campaign aides with bonuses ranging from $25,000 to $300,000 on his last day as a private citizen, the day before some of them joined his administration and went on the city payroll.

title: Hospital Says Two Died in Nitrous Oxide Mistake
description: Two women at a hospital in New Haven died over the last week after they were accidentally given nitrous oxide instead of oxygen during medical procedures, hospital officials said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Bid To Save Independent Station
description: In a battle to stay on the air, journalists from TV-6, the independent television station declared bankrupt and ordered dissolved by a court in a case the station calls rigged, said they would set up their own company and sever ties with the station's owner, the Interfax news agency reported. The owner, Boris Berezovsky is an outspoken opponent of President Vladimir V. Putin and was thought to be a reason behind moves to close the station. The government's press minister, Mikhail Lesin, said he would review the new company's application to continue broadcasting.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Rubber Plants or Shrubs?

title: In West Bank Town, Palestinians Weep for Jewish Friend
description: Sleepless at 2 o'clock this morning, Jamal Arja, a Palestinian from this hillside town, called the daughter of a close Jewish friend who had been kidnapped here on Tuesday and killed by Palestinian gunmen.

title: Rutgers Gets Solid Showing From Kent
description: For a change, Rashod Kent was able to smile with satisfaction. On a night everything that could go right went right, Kent burst out of a six-game offensive slump to lead Rutgers to a 79-66 victory over West Virginia, the team he likes to dislike. He even managed to hit a handful of shots from the free-throw line, where every shot he launches seems to be a misadventure.

title: Enron Letter Suggests $1.3 Billion More Down the Drain
description: The letter that the Enron executive Sherron S. Watkins sent to the chairman of the company provides a few new details about Enron's web of partnerships and raises the possibility that the company might have to reduce its past earnings by $1.3 billion more than it already has.

title: Enron And the Gramms
description: When Senator Phil Gramm and his wife Wendy danced, it was most often to Enron's tune.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Seeking Delay In Tax Cut
description: Gov. Parris N. Glendening proposed delaying a 2 percent tax cut and spending more than $700 million from state reserves to balance the budget. Mr. Glendening, a Democrat, asked the Legislature to increase spending 2.7 percent, to $22.2 billion, in the fiscal year beginning July 1. His plan to delay the income tax cut for 18 months, which would provide $175 million, encountered immediate opposition. The reduction would be the final installment of a five-year, 10 percent tax cut the Legislature approved in 1997. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about senior Pentagon officials and members of Congress who say the United States should consider withdrawing its forces from Saudi Arabia misstated the rank of an Air Force officer who has filed a lawsuit challenging a Pentagon rule that American servicewomen must wear long robes when venturing outside Saudi bases. She is a lieutenant colonel, not a major.

title: Owners Give Approval To Sale of the Red Sox
description: With the threat of another legal headache behind them, Major League Baseball owners approved the $660 million sale of the Boston Red Sox today to a group led by John Henry. But they passed up the opportunity to execute an unprecedented triple play involving teams in three cities and two countries.

title: Islanders Get 2 Scorers
description: The Islanders continued to fortify their roster for a playoff run yesterday by acquiring the high-scoring forwards Kip Miller and Ted Donato. Miller, Donato and Jim Cummins are expected to be with the team for tonight's game in San Jose against the Sharks.

title: Getting Around the Crowded City With a Push-Off and a Battery
description: Hydrogen fuel-cell motors are the rage at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. The new technology will power the two-wheel Scoot, right, a scooter you can also carry on your back. The prototype, designed by Yves Behar and Johan Liden of fuseproject, a San Francisco-based industrial design company, is aimed at urbanites in congested cities. The scooter is made of cast aluminum and carbon fiber and will be powered by a fuel-cell battery. (Scoot is awaiting patent.) Fuseproject expects the scooter to cost about $500. Mr. Behar founded the firm in 1997, after stints at frogdesign and lunar design in San Francisco, where he did projects for Apple and Hewlett-Packard. The prototype of Scoot will be seen at the Chicago Athenaeum Good Design Award 2001 exhibition from March 8 to April 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, MATILDA
description: BARNETT-Matilda. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) deeply mourn the loss of Matilda Barnett of Los Angeles, CA, a generous and devoted ATS supporter. In the memory of her late husband, Gabriel, and her late son, Brian Morris, Mrs. Barnett established the Brian Morris Building-Matilda and Gabriel Barnett Student Dormitory at the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. In doing so, Mrs. Barnett attained the rank of Technion Guardian, representing the highest level of commitment to the Technion. Mrs. Barnett's support of the ATS was a family tradition. Her brother, the late Sir Arthur Gilbert, also was a Technion Guardian. Mrs. Barnett is survived by her nephew, Colin Gilbert, and her niece, Jacqueline Brumer. Her kindness and generosity will be missed by those who knew her. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Evelyn Berger, President Lawrence S. Jackier, Chair, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President William Litvak, President, Southern California Chapter David Polak, President, Western Region Diane Siegel, Director, Western Region

title: Rains Help Australia Turn Corner on Worst Wildfires in Years

Not a bad idea, nor an astonishing thing for an industry in which self-help books are such a cash-producing genre.

Gov. George E. Pataki has joined other governors in seeking more federal aid for welfare.

description: A distressed student facing suspension stormed through the campus of the Appalachian School of Law today with a handgun, killing the dean, a professor and a student and wounding three others before he was tackled by fellow students, the state police reported.

title: Walk and They Walk With You
description: ON Monday, a row of 32 giant flowers sprang up along eight display windows on the Lexington Avenue side of Bloomingdale's, between 59th and 60th Streets. The five-foot-tall flowers, which resemble daisies as a child might draw them, are made of glass tubing. When pedestrians pass by the windows, the flowers burst into sky-blue neon light, one by one, and then fade in seconds. As each flower glows against a backdrop of white spandex, it emits a short electronic tone, like the clink of a toy piano.

description: Mats Wilander and Pam Shriver were elected to the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I., yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Symantec Has 99% Drop In Profit
description: The Symantec Corporation, maker of the Norton antivirus software, said its fiscal third-quarter profit fell 99 percent on acquisition-related costs. Net income fell to $100,000, or break-even on a per-share basis, in the quarter ended Dec. 31, from $13.9 million, or 21 cents, in the year-earlier quarter, Symantec said. Sales rose 32 percent, to $290.2 million from $219.3 million. Excluding acquisition-related costs, office closings and other items, Symantec said it would have earned 78 cents a share. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, analysts had expected Symantec to earn 64 cents. Its shares fell $3.45, or 4.9 percent, to $66.95.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Vote On Media Law Put Off
description: A proposed law that would require journalists to be citizens of the country and licensed by the government has been put aside by Parliament until next week so amendments offered this week can be reviewed by the minister of information. The law, which would make it all but impossible for foreign journalists to work in Zimbabwe, is one of a series of bills the governing party has been pushing through Parliament in what critics say is an effort to weaken the opposition before elections in March. In recent days President Robert Mugabe, who is running for re-election, has come under renewed pressure from fellow African leaders who have urged him to ensure that the vote is open and fair. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REBOUSSIN, MARCEL AUGUSTE
description: REBOUSSIN - Marcel Auguste (April 26, 1906-January 15, 2002). Died in Williamsburg on January 15th after a brief illness. He was 95. A Professor of French with the Department of Modern Languages at the College of William and Mary (1946-1968), he is survived by his son Roland, two grandsons and a great-granddaughter. Sylvia, his wife of 60 years and a longtime elementary teacher in Williamsburg, died in 1992. He was born in Chateau-Renault, France and maintained his French citizenship after seventy years residence here. He attended Ecole Normale Superieure (training as a teacher's college instructor) in St. Cloud, a suburb of Paris. There he met Sylvia Lesser, an American college student from Kansas City traveling with fellow students from Columbia University Teacher's College. Around 1930, Marcel arrived in New York City having won a scholarship to study English at Columbia University on the basis of a thesis on ''Moby Dick''. Following a renewed courtship, the couple married on August 27, 1932. Marcel's first job was as Civilian Instructor of French with the US Military Academy at West Point. Roland was born in 1935, while they resided at the West Point Bachelors' Quarters. In June the family moved to France. They lived in Evreux, Normandy for three years while Marcel taught Ecole Normale. There he met lifelong friends, painter Paul Perraudin and poet Pierre Menanteau, and passed his exams for the Aggregation at the Sorbonne. After the death of his mother in 1939, Marcel returned to his former job at West Point again, leaving his wife and son in Washington, DC. He sailed across a much more dangerous Atlantic Ocean with the goal of liberating his country from Nazi occupation. On his 36th birthday in 1942 he left Halifax with a convoy of 24 ships. After a brief detainment by the British authorities, he finally met DeGaulle in London and was promoted to Captain in the Free French Army. Marcel was assigned to a military liaison position at Pointe-Noire, French Equatorial Africa. He arrived in Brazzaville in September 1942. He was ordered to Morocco and then Paris towards the end of the war, spending a short time at the front as Free French forces re-occupied their country. He remained in Paris briefly after the war, before returning to his family in the US. Marcel. Marcel took a job teaching French at William and Mary in 1946. He was a dedicated professor who loved teaching and publishing his research. He kept a fine garden at his residence in Skipwith Farms.

description: Only a few old-timers, men with long beards and women hunched over low from a lifetime of toiling, remember the day that the Fascists trucked a giant granite obelisk away from Aksum.

title: SMARTFORCE BUYS CENTRA SOFTWARE FOR $260 MILLION
description: SmartForce, an educational software maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Centra Software for $260 million in stock to add customers and products that support live Internet interaction. Centra's shareholders will receive 0.425 share of SmartForce for each Centra share. That values Centra at $10.29 a share, based on Tuesday's closing price of SmartForce's American depository receipts. Centra closed on Tuesday at $8.85 a share. SmartForce will also assume stock options valued at $24 million. Centra is based in Lexington, Mass. SmartForce is based in Redwood City, Calif. Its stock trades as American depository receipts because it is incorporated in Ireland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANCE, CYRUS R.
description: VANCE-Cyrus R. The Fellows of the America-China Forum join with the Directors and staff of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations in recording our deep sorrow in the loss of the vision, leadership, counsel and friendship of Cyrus Vance. A world-respected statesman and outstanding national leader, he brought to the U.S.-China relationship, as he did to an extraordinarily broad agenda of domestic and global issues in which he interested himself, exceptionally wise judgement coupled with uncommon courage and profound humanitarianism. His loss will be deeply felt. Henry A. Kissinger, Chair, America-China Forum Herbert J. Hansell, President, America-China Forum Carla A. Hills, Chair, National Committee on U.S.-China Relations John L. Holden, President, National Committee on U.S.-China Relations

Ted loved his work and everyone loved working with him. Besides vision, energy and wit Ted had a big heart. Our sincerest condolences to his wife Amanda and his children Jackson and Dexter. Ted set a standard. His enormous professional talent and endearing personal qualities will be sorely missed. But his example will continue to inspire us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNING, MARY MARGARET BOURNE

Born July 26, 1911, and formerly of Decatur, IL, she was the beloved wife of the late James Dorr Dunning Sr., mother of James Jr. Cherished grandmother of James III and David, all of New York City, and dear friend to many. Funeral service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st St, Thursday, January 17, at 4:30 PM. Friends are requested to make memorial donations to St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: Where Old Meets New, The Word Becomes Art
description: The architect Josh Schweitzer is neither Jewish nor religious, but he has designed a modern synagogue (left and above) that seems deeply spiritual. It is the 7,000-square-foot new home of Congregation Kol Ami (Voice of My People), a gay and lesbian Reform Jewish congregation in West Hollywood. Rabbi Denise L. Eger said the congregation of 300, many of whose members are in entertainment, wanted a place that would ''not look like the synagogue we had grown up in.''

title: Clocks That Won't Miss a Second in 20 Million Years
description: FOR most people, time just flies. But for scientists who build atomic clocks, which are the most accurate timepieces in the world and crucial to the proper functioning of telecommunications networks, Global Positioning System satellites and other systems, time flies in increments of one nine-billionth of a second.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Reward In 1965 Shootings
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is offering a $40,000 reward for information leading to the indictment and arrest of anyone responsible for the shootings of the first black sheriff's deputies in Washington Parish in 1965. One deputy, O'Neal Moore, was killed, and the other, Creed Rogers, was wounded. An initial investigation closed without charges; the case was reopened in 1989. The deputies were shot in Varnado, about 60 miles north of New Orleans, by three men in a pickup truck.

He was warming up with his San Diego Padres teammates, and they agreed: there was nothing better than this weather, this stage, this setting.

description: On Christmas morning of 2000, Susan and Derek Q. Johnson's children found no gifts under the tree in their West End Avenue apartment. Instead, the Johnsons bundled Dillon, 5, and Kira, 1, into the family S.U.V. and whisked them 45 blocks uptown to Hamilton Terrace in Harlem, one of the city's most gracious and secluded streets.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Death Penalty Moratorium
description: In its continuing effort to be perceived as a progressive nation, Kyrgyzstan extended a moratorium on death sentences and announced a plan for gradual abolition of the death penalty. The extension was signed into law by President Askar Akayev in what officials said was a confirmation of the Central Asian nation's ''commitment to basic human rights and freedoms.'' Earlier this month Kyrgyzstan adopted a human rights program under which the death penalty could be abolished by 2010. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: AL QAEDA TRAINED BOMBING SUSPECT, INDICTMENT SAYS
description: Richard Reid, who was overpowered on a Paris-to-Miami flight last month as he tried to light explosives in his shoes, was a Qaeda-trained terrorist who tried to bring down an airliner carrying nearly 200 people, according to a federal grand jury indictment filed in Boston today.

title: As Mediators Seek Peace, India's Navy Is Ready for War
description: As Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived in Islamabad today on a mission to get India and Pakistan to talk about peace, India was still trumpeting its preparedness for war. Its new navy chief said at a news conference today that his forces were ''fully mobilized.''

title: Enron Board Fires Andersen as Auditor
description: HOUSTON (Reuters) - Bankrupt energy giant Enron Corp. said Thursday its board of directors voted to fire accountancy firm Andersen as the company's auditors, effective immediately.

title: Cypriot Leaders Agree to First Talks in 4 Years on Reunification
description: The rival leaders of ethnically divided Cyprus agreed today to an intensive schedule for peace talks in what was viewed as a major step forward in efforts to reunite the Mediterranean island after a split of more than 27 years.

description: K.C. Boutiette, Jondon Trevena and Catherine Raney were added to the United States Olympic long-track speedskating team yesterday.

description: A mysterious American-financed advertising campaign promoting fundamentalist Protestant values and ''power for living'' has caused an uproar here, prompting a ban on its television spots and some self-searching on the part of Germany's established churches.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HARVARD INDUSTRIES, Lebanon, N.J., a maker of vehicle parts, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for the second time in five years.

title: Metro Matters; Thanks, CNN, Mr. Pretzel And Jennifer
description: NEVER doubt the resilience of the American public. In some ways we will never be the same. But in other ways, it seems, we will never be different. The evidence is mounting that we have indeed returned to what passed for normal before the events of September, and have done so with the gusto of a lapsed dieter.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic: Visit By Haitian Leader
description: President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti arrived in the Dominican capital to discuss a range of issues including the extradition of a former Haitian police official accused of plotting a failed coup attempt last month. Dominican officials have said they will deport Guy Philippe, the police official, to a third country rather than hand him over to Haiti. Mr. Aristide is expected to ask President Hipolito Mejia to increase border security; Haitian officials believe the commandos who stormed the presidential palace last month crossed over from the Dominican Republic. The visit came one day after the Organization of American States said it would set up a mission in Haiti to try to resolve the political stalemate between Mr. Aristide and the opposition. David Gonzalez (NYT)

description: Melancholy stirs in Harrison Birtwistle's ''Shadow of Night.'' Its seeds are old: a Drer etching, a Tudor song. Its means are modern: more like clinical depression than the ruminative sadness of ancient poets and philosophers.

title: DEVILS ACQUIRE KAMENSKY
description: The Devils traded the minor-league defenseman Andre Lakos to the Dallas Stars yesterday for Valery Kamensky, the veteran left wing whose two-year stint with the Rangers was expensive and disappointing. The Devils hope Kamensky can provide some offense to a team struggling to make the playoffs a season after reaching the Stanley Cup finals.

description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 3,113 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

description: An initial theory that debris on the runway led to the fiery crash of the Air France Concorde in July 2000 has been confirmed by the French aviation safety agency.

description: A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve Board's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.

description: Performing arts organizations often like to trumpet what's new. But Robert Harth, the new executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall, had every reason to send out a message of continuity when he introduced Carnegie's 2002-3 season at a news conference yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMANN, DERICK OTIS
description: STEINMANN-Derick Otis. 58. Died on January 5, 2002 in St. Croix, United States Virgin Islands. Chairman of the Board and CEO of American Banker and the Bond Buyer from 1975 to the mid 1980s, he worked to transition them into the computer era and facilitated their sale to International Thomson Corp. He was graduated from Bowdoin College in 1964, receiving a Master's in experimental psychology from Purdue University in 1967 and a Doctorate in industrial psychology from Bowling Green State University in 1972. While serving as Chairman of the Board of Directors of Juan F. Luis Hospital in St. Croix, he helped the hospital gain national accreditation. His love of music involved him with the Laura Boulton Foundation, which archived Native African music. He also produced recordings of West Indian Crucian Scratch Band music to preserve St. Croix's cultural heritage. He is survived by his sons: David and Victor; wife Suzanne P. Steinmann; sisters: Sherry Revel, Starr Steinmann, Serena Kreegal, Chanel Wheeler, Vivi Wagner and Sabrina Hodge; brothers: Sumner and Otis; Marcia Steinmann, the mother of his sons; numerous nieces and nephews, and many other relatives and friends. He was a resident of St. Croix and also had a home in Edison, NJ. He was born in Colon, Panama on December 3, 1943. Derick was a generous and kind man, placing the needs of others above his own. He will be missed. In accordance with his wishes, his body was cremated and his ashes spread at sea off St. Croix.

title: Union to Respond to Owners
description: Major League Baseball will let the players' union provide the House Judiciary Committee with analysis of documents that claim baseball's 30 teams lost $519 million last season, Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan said yesterday. The tentative agreement was reached by Rob Manfred, baseball's labor negotiator, and Conyers, the committee's ranking Democrat.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bailout Talks For Daiei
description: The country's second-largest retailer, Daiei, is in talks with its three largest lenders, UFJ Holdings, the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation and Mizuho Holdings, to assemble a 420 billion yen ($3.2 billion) bailout, according to The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading financial newspaper. Daiei is saddled with $17.5 billion in debts and has already burned through most of a 500 billion yen credit line offered by the banks last year. The company, which plans to announce a three-year restructuring plan as early as this month, has been selling share stakes and assets. It is reported to be ready to sell stores in China and Hawaii as part of that plan. Ken Belson (NYT)

The affected sentence, about a memorandum by an Enron executive discussing the company's law firm, should have read, ''Ms. Watkins also urged that Vinson & Elkins not be used to investigate the transactions, contending that the firm had a conflict of interest because of its involvement in advising Enron on some of the deals.''

title: A Satellite Speedometer For Those on the Fast Track
description: Skiers who have long wondered how fast they are telemarking down the piste can now figure it out with a new Global Positioning System tool. Timex's Ironman Triathlon Speed & Distance System combines a G.P.S. sensor and a full-featured digital watch to enable skiers, joggers, bicyclists and even swimmers to track their speed, distance and pace accurately.

title: Recorders For Those Blessed With A Silver Tongue
description: It's not particularly surprising that the two latest digital voice recorders from Olympus are smaller and cheaper and record longer than previous models. But they offer another innovation: the VN-900 and VN-1800 include a third, higher fidelity recording mode that an Olympus spokeswoman, Karen Thomas, called ''broadcast quality.''

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: 2 Classes Suspected Of Cheating
description: Georgia Tech officials are investigating whether 186 students in two computer programming classes may have cheated on homework. A software program detected duplications in the students' work, much as a program found signs of cheating last year in term papers for a physics class at the University of Virginia. The Georgia Tech inquiry is expected to take months; students found to have cheated could be expelled or given failing grades. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Arraigned In Killing Of Family
description: Christian Longo, accused of killing his wife and three children, was arraigned on seven counts of aggravated murder. Mr. Longo, 27, who was captured in Tulum, Mexico, is being held on $2.5 million bail. The bodies of his wife, Mary Jane, 35, and their children -- Zachary, 5; Sadie Ann, 3; and Madison, 2 -- were found in December.

title: U.S. Traces Iran's Ties to Terror Through a Lebanese
description: One of the world's most wanted men, charged with the terrorist hijacking of a T.W.A. jetliner in 1985 and implicated in a recent shipment of arms from Iran to the Palestinians, has been operating for years with the protection and backing of the Iranian intelligence services, according to Central Intelligence Agency documents.

title: U.S. and Mexico Battle Over Sweetening Drinks
description: American high-fructose corn syrup has met its death in the Mexican soft drink industry, at least for now. It is survived by its main competitor, Mexican cane sugar.

title: Bush Declares Free Markets Are Essential For Americas
description: President Bush invited Central American nations tonight to strike a separate trade accord with the United States and cautioned Argentina against using the country's economic crisis as an excuse to backtrack on free-market reforms or return to an era of protectionism.

description: An Algerian man was sentenced to 24 years in prison yesterday for his role in a plot to bomb Los Angeles International Airport during millennium celebrations in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONS, SARAH
description: ARONS-Sarah. At age 85. Beloved wife of the late Saul (Charles). Devoted mother of Rosette, Madeleine and Elliot. Cherished grandmother of Alison, Jonathan, Lauren, Rachel & Emily. Services Thursday 12 noon at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Mastering a New Instrument: The Web
description: SIMON O'NEILL, a tenor with the Juilliard Opera Center, is busy building his career -- and his Web site. At 29, Mr. O'Neill has decided that talent and a glossy publicity photo are not enough to make it in classical music today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMANN, GERARD A.
description: NEUMANN-Gerard A. on January 15, 2002 of Naples, Florida, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Past President and Chairman of the Board of Spearin, Preston & Burrows, Inc. Beloved husband of the late Alice Gertrude Neumann. Devoted father of Mary Alice Cunningham, Gerard, Rosanne Sheridan, George, Kathleen Gaffney, Jeanne O'Neill, Ann Neumann, and Helen Westerman. Adored grandfather to twenty-one and great-grandfather to eleven. Dear brother of Irene O'Halleran Drucker. Reposing Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre, NY Saturday 10 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the Little Flower Children's Services, PO Box 9000, Wading River, NY 11792, in his name would be appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Inflation Falls In Region
description: A steep drop in energy prices helped reduce the regional inflation rate to 1.7 percent last year, from 3.1 percent in 2000, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday. The rate measures inflation in New York City and its northern suburbs, Long Island, and parts of New Jersey and Connecticut. Gasoline prices have dropped by about a third since peaking in June, the bureau reported. But owner-occupied housing costs rose by 6.6 percent, far more than the 2.4 percent increase in 2000. Rental costs rose only slightly, to 4.1 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Paul J. Fannin, 94, Who Served In Top Elected Offices in Arizona
description: Paul Jones Fannin, a two-term Republican senator, three-term governor and longtime pillar of Arizona conservatism, died on Sunday at his home in Phoenix. He was 94.

title: Exploring a Deal to Offer Sex Videos
description: For Gerard Van der Leun, it was an unusual meeting. Mr. Van der Leun, vice president for Internet ventures at the General Media Corporation, was approached last year by Enron, at the time an energy-trading company little known outside the financial pages.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Jesse Jackson Jr. Sues Challenger
description: Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., left, son of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, sued a political challenger with the same name, saying that he entered the race to confuse voters. The congressman, a Democrat, has accused State Senator William Shaw and his brother, Robert Shaw, the Cook County commissioner, of orchestrating the candidacy to draw votes away from him. The Shaws were not named in the suit and have denied involvement. A hearing officer overseeing the case will make a recommendation to the full Board of Elections on whether the challenger should be removed from the ballot.

title: AUDITOR RECEIVED WARNING ON ENRON FIVE MONTHS AGO
description: Enron's auditors knew in mid-August of a senior Enron employee's concerns about improprieties in the energy company's accounting practices, Congressional investigators studying Enron's collapse said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Sinn Fein Pressed
description: President Bush's envoy for Northern Ireland, Richard N. Haass, urged Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, to name members to serve on the province's new police board and to stop discouraging Catholics from joining the new cross-community Police Service of Northern Ireland, which replaces the 92 percent Protestant Royal Ulster Constabulary. Northern Ireland's other Catholic party, the Social Democratic and Labor Party, and two main Protestant parties have joined the board but Sinn Fein has refused to, saying reforms do not go far enough.

title: Jersey City Apartments Evacuated When Crane Malfunctions
description: The arm of a construction crane on this city's booming waterfront malfunctioned this morning, leaving the crane damaged and threatening to topple onto a nearby apartment complex. The police evacuated a hotel and the apartment complex, and 800 residents were kept out of their apartments overnight.

title: Menacing Man Is Fatally Shot, Police Say
description: A police officer and a sergeant shot and killed a man who lunged at them with a kitchen knife and a metal hook yesterday in the courtyard of a Brooklyn housing development, the authorities said.

title: PROVIDIAN SELLS $8.2 MILLION IN CREDIT CARD LOANS
description: The Providian Financial Corporation, a leading issuer of Visa and MasterCard credit cards, has agreed to sell its proceeds from $8.2 billion in credit card loans to J. P. Morgan Chase & Company to raise cash and satisfy regulators. The loans, about one-quarter of its business, are with Providian's most creditworthy customers. Providian, based in San Francisco, is trying to find a buyer for $3 billion in loans to customers with poor or short credit histories. In November, federal regulators told Providian to improve its capital ratios, measures of the company's cushion against unexpected loan losses, after profit plunged because of an increase in the number of customers with blemished credit who could not pay their credit card bills.

title: Words That Move the Soul At Up to About 75 M.P.H.
description: While it is illegal in many parts of the country to drive with a cellphone under your chin, it is perfectly fine to speed down the highway while listening, say, to the stirring downsizing passages from Jack Welch's autobiography (although it is not recommended if you were one of the downsized).

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Judges Named For Rights Trials
description: After many delays, the government appointed 18 judges to oversee various human rights trials including the trial of 19 people -- some of them generals -- accused of atrocities when East Timor voted for independence in 1999. It was not clear when the trials would begin.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Neo-Nazis? No, Nerds

title: 4 Former Radicals Are Charged In 1975 Killing in Bank Robbery
description: Two days before she was to be sentenced in a decades-old bomb plot, the longtime fugitive Sara Jane Olson was charged with murder today along with three other former radicals who were long suspected in the killing of a woman in a 1975 bank robbery in Carmichael, Calif.

title: Post-Punk Post-Mortem Keeps a Reputation Intact
description: Mission of Burma, which played its first concerts since 1983 on Saturday and Sunday at Irving Plaza, had a typical post-punk career. Formed in Boston in 1979, it released one album (''Vs.'' in 1982) along with scattered singles and an EP during its four-year existence. But Mission of Burma was never forgotten.

title: In Ravens vs. Steelers, Defense Comes First
description: The usually boisterous bunch was subdued yesterday. Sort of. None of them really wanted to pontificate at length about the Trent thing, the swagger thing or the Super Bowl thing -- locker room shorthand for the three factors that make the Baltimore Ravens the most intriguing, and dangerous, team remaining in the N.F.L. playoffs.

title: Muslims and Modernity
description: To the Editor:

title: Farewell to a Source of Exotic Furnishings
description: A HOME furnishings store on the Upper East Side is closing Jan. 31 and offering deep discounts until then.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Mayor Faces Investigation
description: The state's Campaign Spending Commission has requested a criminal investigation of the 2000 campaign of Mayor Jeremy Harris of Honolulu. The five-member commission accused the mayor and three campaign aides of flouting a $4,000 contribution limit by attributing donations to people who did not make them, including children of some donors. The mayor's supporters have challenged the accusations and say they may hurt his campaign for governor this year. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: Predictable Password Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Politicians Assail Evacuation Plans for Nuclear Plant Disaster
description: The political wrangling and divisions over evacuation plans for residents near the Indian Point nuclear power plant have deepened in recent days, putting some Hudson Valley officials into conflict.

title: U.S. Agency To Take Over Investigation Into Collapse
description: A federal agency with vast experience in investigating building collapses and other major catastrophes is moving to take over, and significantly expand, the inquiry into the fall of the World Trade Center's twin towers on Sept. 11.

title: Betting Against the Dollar: A Key to Big Gains in Bonds
description: Stephen S. Smith, executive vice president and portfolio manager at Brandywine Asset Management, is making a big bet that the dollar will weaken this year against the euro and several other currencies, including the Australian dollar, the New Zealand dollar, the Norwegian krone and the Swedish krona.

title: Once Burned (in 80's and 90's), Twice Shy
description: It is a fair bet that when Enron collapsed, very few people's thoughts turned immediately to Burnett & Hallamshire, a British coal-mining company that went to the wall in the mid-1980's.

title: Crisis Experts Say Andersen Has Big Job in Trying to Repair Its Reputation
description: Trying to control the considerable damage to its public reputation from the scandal surrounding its wayward client Enron, Arthur Andersen has begun explaining its side of the story as to what went wrong and why. But executives who specialize in crisis communications and the restoration of corporate reputations warn that Andersen, a Big Five accounting firm, has much work to do.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Governor Supports Term Limits
description: Gov. Dirk Kempthorne restated his intention to veto a repeal of the state's term-limit law, even as a bill sponsored by fellow Republicans made its way through the Legislature. The Republican leaders of the House proposed a bill last week that would roll back the term limits approved by voter initiative in 1994. Term limits were upheld last month by the State Supreme Court and will not affect state legislators until 2004.

title: Powell, in a Visit to Kabul, Says U.S. Embassy Back to Full Status
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 17  In a whirlwind visit to this war-ravaged capital, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell announced today that the United States had restored its crumbling, long-shuttered embassy to full diplomatic status, and he assured Afghanistan's interim leader, "We will be with you in this current crisis and for the future."

title: Black Hawk Download; Moving Beyond Music, Pirates Use New Tools to Turn the Net Into an Illicit Video Club
description: DEREK MARTIN's selection of cable channels does not include MTV, but that has posed no obstacle to his enjoying the network's comedy show ''Jackass.'' After a friend recommended it recently, Mr. Martin, 24, of Toronto, used a free software program called Morpheus to download an episode from another Morpheus user who had made it available to be copied over the Internet. It was so funny, Mr. Martin said, that he proceeded to copy all 24 episodes from the last three years, downloading nonstop with his cable modem while he was sleeping or at work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERMAN, GERTRUDE
description: OBERMAN-Gertrude. On January 16. Beloved wife of the late Hyman for 62 years. Devoted mother of Susan and Michael Koral, Michael and Sharon Oberman. Loving grandmother of Howard and Pam Greenstein, Todd and Shari Greenstein and Abby Oberman. Doting great-grandmother of Brooke Greenstein, Harris Greenstein and Allyson Greenstein. Graveside services January 17 at 11 AM, Mt. Ararat, Farmingdale.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about senior Pentagon officials and members of Congress who say the United States should consider withdrawing its forces from Saudi Arabia misstated the rank of an Air Force officer who has filed a lawsuit challenging a Pentagon rule that American servicewomen must wear long robes when venturing outside Saudi bases. She is a lieutenant colonel, not a major.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITTER, CHASKELE, CANTOR
description: RITTER-Chaskele, Cantor. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of a most cherished member of its extended family. Chaskele was not only admired as one of the greatest cantors of his century, but was equally respected for his commitment to Am Yisrael and Eretz Yisrael, giving selflessly of his talents and means to benefit countless noble causes. Heartfelt condolences to his loving and devoted son, Dr. Samuel (Dr. Rebecca) Ritter, who brought him so much nachas in life. Michael Scharf, President Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Josh Weston, Honorary Chairman Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: Political Memo; A Major Health Measure, Passed Without a Second Thought
description: When the Senate filed in, Jay and Dave were on the air. When the Assembly did, even Conan was done for the night. The bill on their desks was still hot from the copier, and when 200 bleary-eyed legislators voted on it early this morning, almost none of them had read it.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Gov. George E. Pataki's announcement of a deal on health-care legislation at a rally of hospital workers who stand to receive salary increases referred incorrectly to a video photographer who taped him in the cheering crowd. While several cameramen did, none were employed by his re-election campaign, according to his chief spokesman, Michael McKeon. A still photographer employed by the governor's office did take pictures.

title: Intel Names Heir Apparent For Chief Executive Position
description: The Intel Corporation named a 28-year employee as president and chief operating officer today, grooming him to take over the company as chief executive when Craig R. Barrett retires within three years.

title: U.S. Releases Photos and Videos of Suspected Members of Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Warning that "these men could be anywhere in the world," Attorney General John D. Ashcroft released videotapes and photographs today of five suspected Al Qaeda members who he said were apparently talking of future terrorist attacks.

title: The Neediest Cases; Love and a Special Stroller Are All This Girl Needs
description: Desiree Torres reclined in her wheelchair, on top of one rag doll and next to another, all of them under a pink blanket with bunnies on it. A cast covered Desiree's right leg, a result of an operation in November to correct the structure of her hip.

title: Terrorists Among Us (1942); Detecting the Enemy Wasn't Easy Then, Either
description: Report any suspicious activity. Remain extremely vigilant. Keep your eyes peeled.

description: A Chase in the Ointment

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Andersen Knew in August About Enron Concerns

title: Edwin Martin, 93, a Voice In 60's Latin America Policy
description: Edwin McCammon Martin, who was assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs during the Cuban missile crisis in late 1962, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAAP, DICK
description: SCHAAP-Dick. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Dick Schaap, an early and ardent supporter of an Olympic Games in New York City. The great chronicler of New York sports, its glorious history, colorful personalities and extraordinary events, he was a friend and mentor and the source of unequaled inspiration. We miss him and will always cherish his wisdom, enthusiasm and gentle humor. Our condolences to Trish and the family. NYC2012 Jay L. Kriegel Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDRON, LINDA
description: ANDRON-Linda. Loving mother, daughter, sister, wife. Will be sorely missed and remain forever in our hearts. Funeral to be held at Congregation Ahavat Torah at 9:30 AM on Thursday, January 17. Shiva will be observed at 133 Huguenot Avenue, Englewood, NJ on Thursday, January 17 through Wednesday morning, January 23.

title: Mets Gamble On Astacio For $5 Million
description: The bulk of the Mets' work this winter has involved revamping baseball's worst offense, and they have added Roberto Alomar, Roger Cedeo and Mo Vaughn. If anything, their pitching suffered for it.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Renewed Plea For Income Tax
description: Gov. Tony Knowles is asking state residents for a third time to consider reinstating an income tax. The state abolished the tax in 1980, but with a budget shortfall of more than $1 billion expected over the next three years the governor, a Democrat, thinks the tax is necessary, an administration official said. The income tax, combined with increases in taxes on alcohol and the cruise ship industry, would generate about $400 million annually.

title: 'Depression Princess' Tells About Life of Addiction
description: GOING to chat with the writer Newsweek once called ''the famously depressed'' Elizabeth Wurtzel, one expects there will be tales of despair, but it's surprising to hear them even before you even set foot in her place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONAR, JAMES A.
description: BONAR-James A., 67. Of Larchmont, NY and Lake Cossayuna, NY, on December 15. Loving and devoted father of five children, all from his first marriage: James B., Monica, Christopher, Marguerite Keller, and Julia. Doting grandfather of five. Beloved husband of the late Eulalie Hilts Bonar. Dear brother to Lawrence and Janet. Longtime Professor of History and American Studies at Manhattanville College, where he was instrumental in founding the American Studies Department and fought tirelessly to unionize the faculty. At home, he was a generous and ever-present caregiver. A memorial will be held at the home of his daughters in New Rochelle, February 2 at 4 PM.

title: Mexican Cruise
description: Fares for 10-day cruises of Mexico's Pacific Coast on the Sea Princess start at $899 a person, double occupancy, in April. The round trip from Los Angeles includes Cabo San Lucas, Acapulco, Zihuatanejo, Puerto Vallarta and Mazatlan. For some March sailings, fares start at $999. Air fare to Los Angeles is extra. There are 975 cabins, 410 with balconies; (800) 774-6237 or www.princesscruises.com .
