title: 'Cheese!' To 'Print,' In One Step
description: THE digital age has done wonders for photography. Once you had to take your film to the mall for developing. But today you can eliminate all that expensive hassle with little more than a $600 digital camera, a $300 printer and a $1,000 computer. Just connect the camera to the computer with a U.S.B. cable; copy your multimegabyte JPEG files to the hard drive; open the photos in an image-processing program; rotate and crop each one, adjusting the color; calculate the pixel density and desired output dimensions -- and then click on Print. What could be simpler?

title: Apple's Retail Stores Show Positive Data on Customers
description: Apple Computer said yesterday that 40 percent of the people who bought computers at the 27 retail stores it has opened in recent months were first-time users of Macintosh machines. The figure, analysts say, is an encouraging sign for the company's strategy of trying to lure newcomers to Macintosh, whose users are loyal but less than 5 percent of all personal computer buyers.

title: U.S. Plans to Delay Requirement That Utilities Cut Emissions
description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to delay for one year a requirement that coal-fueled power plants reduce emissions affecting states in the Northeast.

title: Queens Democrats Pick Some Council Plums
description: As City Council Speaker Gifford Miller officially doled out leadership and committee assignments yesterday, Queens reaped the most benefits, snaring chairmanships for all 13 of its Democratic members, including for the two most powerful committees, Land Use and Finance.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Historic House Style Multiplied
description: The hotelier Bill Evans said his first sight of Greene & Greene's 1908 Gamble House in Pasadena, Calif., was a ''borderline religious experience.'' He emulated its classic style in the Lodge at Torrey Pines, a new hotel in La Jolla. He tried to avoid what he called the Disney-type effect in translating the style of historic houses into a four-story hotel and has used authentic materials and details throughout. The A. R. Valentien restaurant, above, will have chandeliers like those in Greene & Greene's Blacker House, made of mahogany, ebony and stained glass. The hotel, at the famous Torrey Pines Golf Course, opens April 4; a room is $350 to $525; (858) 453-4420.

title: Donations Returned
description: Enron was a prolific contributor to candidates and causes, with almost $6 million given since 1989. Now some of those same dollars are headed back to the company or to charity.

title: Michael Bilandic, Daley Successor in Chicago, Dies at 78
description: Michael A. Bilandic, who became mayor of Chicago after the death of Richard J. Daley, his mentor, only to see the Daley political machine sputter to a stop under his leadership, died on Tuesday in Chicago. He was 78.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Argentine Peso Sinks to New Lows as Crisis Continues
description: The Argentine peso plunged to new lows today as the Argentine central bank tried for a second time to stabilize its value by selling dollars.

title: Late Turnover Is Costly As Knicks' Slide Hits 6
description: The Knicks' hottest player had the ball in one of his favorite spots on the floor, the top of the key. With the way he had been shooting, the Knicks expected something magical. But Allan Houston's streak of great offense ended at the most inopportune time tonight.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Small Silver Key Unlocks the Treasures Within
description: With its enigmatic silver plastic case, the new Sony Micro Vault looks as though it could be anything from a felt-tipped pen to a prop for the next James Bond movie.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: From Cuba, With Rhythm, Taking Jazz By Storm; Dafnis Prieto Makes His Mark in New York
description: Most young jazz rhythm-section players come to New York to study, keeping their eye on the main chance. A few lucky ones hit the jackpot with one of the few regularly touring bands. But the overwhelming majority struggle to keep afloat, and their names might not be singled out for 5 or 10 years or, in some cases, ever.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer's Sales Rise
description: Pursuing a longpromised turnaround, the retailer Marks & Spencer said a new line of women's designer clothing and other factors helped fuel an 8.3 percent increase in same-store sales over the holidays. But Luc Vandevelde, the chief executive, cautioned that the growth rate would fall. It was the second quarterly gain after four consecutive declines. The company's shares closed down 0.5 pence, at 359.5 pence. Last month Marks & Spencer sold its Brooks Brothers chain in the United States. It has been withdrawing from overseas ventures to focus on its British stores. Its Kings Super Markets, based in New Jersey, is for sale, and Mr. Vandevelde said an announcement was possible next week. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Finding Frank, From Stockholm to TriBeCa
description: MANY of Josef Frank's textile and furniture designs are available through Svenkst Tenn, the Swedish furniture company for which they were originally designed (Strandvagen 5, Stockholm; www.svenskttenn.se or 011-46-8-670-16-00). Prices are reasonable ($97 for a lamp, excluding shipping). An added incentive is that the store is owned by the Kjell and Marta Beijer Foundation, which donates its proceeds to the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for medical research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, EDYTHE B.
description: GOODMAN-Edythe B. Age 89, passed away on January 11, 2002. Wife of the late Theodore R. Goodman. Mother of Ted Goodman and Gwen Mazer. Grandmother of T.R., David, and Gordon Goodman. An educator & director of the Victory Day Care Center. Active on many boards and committees in the community. A life long member of the Trinity Baptist Church, and given many honors. Viewing will be at the Trinity Baptist Church, 808 East 224th Street, Bronx, NY, 5-8 PM on Thursday, January 17, 2002. Funeral service will be 11:00 AM, Friday, January 18, 2002. Burial following at the Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: New Mayor, New Focus
description: Just two weeks into his mayoralty, with most of his administration in place, Michael R. Bloomberg is now offering significant clues about where his policy priorities may differ from Rudolph W. Giuliani's, on such issues as services to the poor, human rights abuses and public health.

title: Yahoo Posts Lower-Than-Expected Loss; President Says He Will Quit
description: Jeff Mallet, the No. 2 executive of Yahoo, the struggling Internet portal, said yesterday that he would resign, even as the company announced higher revenue and lower losses than it had forecast.

title: Top Five Men Vanish in Australian Summer
description: For the first time in the 34-year history of open tennis, all five top-seeded men have failed to reach the third round at a Grand Slam event.

title: Liberty Media Backs Away From Kirch Deal
description: Liberty Media, the cable television holding company controlled by John C. Malone, announced today that it no longer wanted to buy a stake in a television venture controlled by the Munich-based billionaire Leo Kirch.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Set Condition For Talks
description: Ethnic Tamil rebels have demanded that a ban on their group, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, be lifted before they will enter peace talks with the government to end an 18-year civil war that has killed more than 62,000 people. The government has not made clear its position on lifting the ban; the group has been designated a terrorist outfit by Sri Lanka, India, the United States and Canada. G. L. Peiris, a government official, said the issue would be discussed.

title: Patriots' Brown Fills the Glenn Vacuum
description: It is not enough to catch 83 passes in a National Football League season, not if you are the Patriots' Troy Brown and after eight seasons you are still considered a No. 2 receiver. So at the end of the 2000 season, Brown went back to his alma mater, Marshall University, as usual, and told the college players to wave their hands in his face as they always do, the better for him to fine-tune his focus and work on his route running.

title: The Twain You'll Meet
description: In Mark Twain's first best seller, ''Innocents Abroad,'' a rhapsodic Italian guide exposes him and his traveling companions to a bust of ''Christopher Columbo.'' The Americans drive the guide to distraction by refusing to be impressed -- by professing, in fact, never to have heard of the gentleman. ''Which is the bust and which is the pedestal?'' they ask (a distinction that needs clarifying with regard to so many works of art), and ''Is -- is he dead?''

title: Economic Scene; If there was a new economy, why wasn't there a new economics?
description: THERE was never a new economics to go along with the new economy. Sure, there was a lot of talk about increasing returns, network effects, switching costs and so on. But these are hardly new concepts; they've been part of the economics literature for decades.

title: Taunts May Have Sparked a Shooting at a School, Police Say
description: Investigators interviewed dozens of students and teachers yesterday as they tried to determine the motive and identity of a gunman who wounded two students in a hallway of Martin Luther King Jr. High School on Tuesday, police officials said.

title: Samuel A. Tower, 87; Wrote Stamp Column
description: Samuel A. Tower, a writer and an editor for The New York Times and a stamp columnist there for 11 years, died Friday in New Haven. He was 87.

title: Latest Shootings Add to King High School's Reputation for Turbulence
description: When Martin Luther King Jr. High School opened in the shadow of Lincoln Center in 1975, it was seen as a promising effort to integrate white, black and Hispanic students in a thriving neighborhood that held one of the city's cultural gems.

title: Buyers Are at The Door Again
description: THE winter apartment-hunting season in Manhattan, which began around Thanksgiving -- normally the deadest of times for co-op and condo sales -- is bursting with activity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELDRIDGE, HARRY S.
description: ELDRIDGE-Harry S. Age 90, of Riverdale, NY. Devoted father of Stephen and Hindee. Loving grandfather of Jolie, Nicole, and Michael. Services Friday 11:00 AM at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-On-Hudson, New York.

title: Doesn't a Chair Need a Pocket, Too?
description: The Pocket Chair solves a problem you didn't know you had: it provides a slot to stash today's paper or a large place card. The chair is stackable, set on powder-coated steel legs and made of polycarbonate, the work of the Los Angeles-based designers Mark Zuckerman and Monty Lawton, who have their own store, Inhouse. Taking their design from concept to completion was, Mr. Lawton said, an ''education in how the furniture manufacturing process works in the United States.'' In transparent, white, rose, light blue and yellow, it sells for around $180. At Inhouse, 7370 Beverly Boulevard, Los Angeles; (323) 931-4420; www.inhousefurniture.com.

title: McGreevey Gets to Work, Asking for 5 Percent Cuts
description: At 8 a.m., New Jersey's new governor, James E. McGreevey, today held his first cabinet meeting and ordered department heads to identify ways to cut 5 percent from their operating budgets and freeze all discretionary spending.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Job Fair Scheduled
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said another job fair would be held this month to try to match the growing ranks of jobless New Yorkers with employers. The three job fairs that the city has held since the attack on the World Trade Center attracted thousands of job seekers. The fair, called the Workforce Development Job Expo, will be held Jan. 29, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. City officials said yesterday that they hoped to draw 400 employers. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: 91 Years After Dying, Mahler Hits His Stride
description: Classical musicians sometimes apply what they call the hundred-year rule to composers. Only a century after music is composed, they say, can its quality and value truly be appraised.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the relationship between President Bush and Senator Edward M. Kennedy misstated the history of the Oval Office desk now used by Mr. Bush and once used by the senator's brother, President John F. Kennedy. Bill Clinton, among other presidents, used the desk; it was not taken out of storage by Mr. Bush.

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan Makes More Money For the Nets
description: IN all the years when Michael Jordan used to pack the Meadowlands, the usual sellout crowd of 20,049 never saw a tired, heavy-legged Jordan trail by 39 points at halftime.

title: Putting Personal Before Perfect
description: WHAT'S really important? As an interior designer, as well as a New Yorker, I have asked myself that question many times over the last few months. One designer who seemed to have figured it all out was the architect and furniture designer Josef Frank, who was born in Baden, Austria, in 1885 and was battered by two world wars.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Settles Patent Dispute
description: The InterDigital Communications Corporation said that it had settled a patent dispute with the NEC Corporation for $53 million and entered a licensing agreement with the company that includes royalty payments. NEC will make the payments to settle disputes that stem from a 1995 licensing agreement, InterDigital said. InterDigital, which is based in King of Prussia, Pa., makes chips for delivering fast Internet access to cellphones. It will receive a $19.5 million advance royalty payment and an additional royalty for sales of licensed NEC products. Shares of InterDigital rose $2.48, or 26.2 percent, to $11.94.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Debra D'Angelo, director for print production at the Advertising Council, New York, was promoted to senior director.

title: Lender Sues Trade Center Leaseholder Over Insurance Money
description: One of the lenders to Larry A. Silverstein, who holds the lease on the World Trade Center site, has filed a lawsuit accusing Mr. Silverstein's companies of misallocating insurance money paid out after the Sept. 11 attack.

title: Justices Hold Hearing in Case Concerning Patients' Rights
description: With patients' rights legislation stalled in Congress, the spotlight moved to the Supreme Court today for an argument on whether states have the authority to require an independent medical review of a health maintenance organization's refusal to pay for a covered service.

title: A Gay Cable Channel
description: To the Editor:

title: Boutique Medicine
description: It is easy to understand why a handful of doctors around the country are offering highly personalized medical care to patients who can afford to pay thousands of dollars a year for the added service. What doctor wouldn't be eager to work with fewer patients and less hassle for the same or added income? But it seems a bit much for the physicians engaged in these ventures to depict their reach for a better life as motivated by solicitude for their patients or as a principled protest against the high-volume demands of managed care.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN - Felix. 1/17/11 - 7/26/94. Founder, National Society for Graphology. World renowned teacher, beloved by all whose lives he touched. Janic

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATTEL, GERHARD
description: GATTEL-Gerhard. At 89 years of age on January 16, 2002. Survived by his cousins, Eveline Roth and Leopold Gattel. Funeral service Friday, 12:30 PM Schwartz Bros Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76th Rd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, JOHN B.
description: O'DONNELL-John B., on January 15, 2002. Beloved father and close friend. Survived by his daughters, Alison and Melissa, and friend, Steven T. Wozencraft. Loving son of Thelma, fond nephew of Edna Kawash. Family will receive friends on Thursday and Friday, 35 PM and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral, Saturday, 9:30 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola, 84th St. and Park Ave.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Has Component Customer
description: Motorola said yesterday that Benq, a Taiwan-based cellphone manufacturer, would use a packaged platform of Motorola chips, circuitry and software in next-generation phones that Benq will begin manufacturing next fall. The supply agreement is the first signed by Motorola under a strategic policy announced last year that emphasizes selling to other manufacturers technology that Motorola previously developed for its own cellphone unit. Benq was formerly known as Acer Communications and Multimedia. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

description: NEW YORK

description: MAYER-Arlene (nee Simon), 56 years young, died January 16, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Kurt Mayer. Devoted mother of Amanda. Loving stepmother of Steven and Susan. Also survived by her mother Sally Simon, sister Gail Raifman, brother-in-law Jerome Raifman, sister-in-law Naomi Mayer and brother-in-law Michael Mayer, nieces Alyson Raifman, Tamar Mayer, Hilla Mayer and nephews Charles Raifman and Jeffrey Raifman. Senior Vice President of Foa & Sons. A friend to all. Forever in our hearts. Service Thursday, January 17, 11:45am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Peter Levathes, 90, Movie, TV and Ad Executive
description: Peter G. Levathes, 90, a movie and television production executive in New York who led the 20th Century Fox studios in the early 1960's, died on Jan. 9 in Washington.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures were credited erroneously in some copies last Thursday with an article about health-care institutions that reproduce small-town environments for people with memory loss. The pictures of Main Street and a brick archway and piano at the Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Conn., were by Larry Lefever. Pictures of the Corumbene Nursing Home in Tasmania were by David Stephenson/Nest.

title: A Growing Number of Potential Targets for Lawsuits
description: With each new report of possible misdeeds by professionals who worked for or with the Enron Corporation, the list of deep-pocketed potential targets of civil and criminal lawsuits resulting from the company's spectacular collapse grows longer. A variety of major companies might just end up paying damages to help compensate victims of Enron's implosion.

title: Tracking Work Hours By Touch, Not a Punch
description: DYLAN'S CANDY BAR on Manhattan's Upper East Side believes in better living through candy. With 5,000 kinds of confections, stools that look like peppermints and a staircase embedded with jelly beans, the 5,500-square-foot store is every child's fantasy of a candy paradise come to life.

title: Tiniest Babies Show Success As Youths in Spite of Hurdles
description: The first study to track extremely premature infants into adulthood has found that despite frequent physical and learning disabilities that often prevent them from attending college, these ''preemies'' are nearly as likely to complete high school as children of normal birth weight, and less likely to engage in risky behavior.

title: A Wealth of Information Inside a Magnetic Strip
description: Q. What information is on the magnetic strip on the back of credit cards, and what is transmitted back and forth when a card is swiped?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, JULIUS
description: SILVER-Julius. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) deeply mourn the loss of Julius Silver, a distinguished and colorful attorney, devoted philanthropist and seminal figure in the ATS/Technion partnership. By founding the Technion's Julius Silver Institute of Bio-Medical Engineering in 1970which he continued to support along with his late wife RoslynDr. Silver helped establish the Technion as an international leader in this pioneering field. A Technion Guardian who reached the highest level of commitment to the ATS, the Technion and Israel, Dr. Silver was an Honorary Life Member of the Technion International Board of Governors and a Life Trustee of the ATS Board of Regents. He was honored with a Doctorate of Science in Technology from the Technion in 1971 and the ATS' prestigious Albert Einstein Award in 1989. A centenarian, Dr. Silver survived his beloved daughter Enid Winslow. He will be sorely missed by his ATS/Technion family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Evelyn Berger, President Lawrence S. Jackier, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Aaron Etra, Chairman, New York Metropolitan Region Joseph Huber, Director, New York Metropolitan Region

title: Lincoln Center's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Settlement In Police Shooting
description: The family of an unarmed man shot by police officers has accepted a settlement of $62,000, court documents show. The family of the unarmed man, Christopher Malone, 24, sued the Village of Ossining for $20 million in July 1998, but accepted the offer Tuesday, just before jury selection. The family acknowledged as part of the settlement that a grand jury and the Justice Department had found no criminal responsibility on the part of the police officers. A large portion of the settlement will go toward the college education of Mr. Malone's 8-year-old son, the agreement states. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Son of Carwash, the Self-Cleaning House
description: LET history record that here, in a living room with soap and water-dispensing nozzles on the ceiling, a decisive battle in the war on household drudgery was fought.

title: Sharing Grief to Find Understanding
description: Rita Lasar was padding around her East Village apartment after breakfast when the news crackled over the radio. About 7,000 miles away, in Kabul, Amin Said had finished dinner and was listening to the radio when he heard.

title: Israel Philharmonic Tackles Symphony's Many Ironies
description: In two concerts this week at Carnegie Hall, the Israel Philharmonic under its lifetime conductor, Zubin Mehta, got better and better. The musicians' disappointing start on Monday was in an all-Brahms program -- indeed, an all-Brahms, all-D major one consisting of the Violin Concerto and the Second Symphony. Maybe the players were exhausted from travel; maybe they were put off their collective stroke by a very brilliant but self-regarding performance of the concerto by Maxim Vengerov. Whatever the reason, the concert was dull. The wind playing was heavy, with unexceptional solos, and the violins became coarse when moving at speed into the upper register.

title: Do's, Don'ts and Don't-You-Dares
description: Would your children like free hot chocolate? Would you like new skis or a new snowboard? How about $5 off every lift ticket? Or a free, unlimited season pass?

title: For Games on Ice, a Fiery Debut
description: ON Feb. 8, a three-story-high flame will rise from an angular glass-and-metal caldron high above the Rice-Eccles Stadium at the University of Utah, signaling the opening of the Olympic Games here. Of the billions of people watching, few will be more impressed than Tim Hunter's friends from the Rhode Island School of Design, class of 1998.

title: A Community Center West Hollywood Can Love
description: At the end of the Plummer Park Community Center, right, on the less affluent east side of West Hollywood, is a lounge for elderly Russian immigrants. At the other end is a meeting place for local teenagers. In the middle is a multipurpose hall that is used on Tuesday nights by cross-dressing square dancers. Call it an only-in-West Hollywood mixed-use institution that wanted an uninstitutional feeling.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Donations Urged For Nonprofits
description: After raising $425 million, the September 11th Fund called on people yesterday to direct contributions to other charitable causes. The fund is asking for donations to other causes, officials said, because more than enough government and philanthropic aid is available to victims of the terror attacks. Nonprofit groups, from museums to homeless shelters, have reported a sharp drop in donations. Of the $425 million raised by the fund, a project of the New York Community Trust and the United Way of New York City, more than $160 million has been distributed. David Barstow (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: A.C.L.U. Sues Over Airport Search
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois filed suit against a National Guardsman and three security guards at O'Hare International Airport for making Samar Kaukab, an American of Pakistani descent, remove her traditional Muslim head covering in a search last November in which her pants and sweater were also opened. The A.C.L.U. said Ms. Kaukab, 22, had been singled out because of her religious attire for a search that violated her constitutional rights to equal protection and religious freedom. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

title: South Korea Begins an Anti-Corruption Effort as Scandals Swell
description: The government has begun a broad offensive this week against corruption as President Kim Dae Jung battles the effects of a series of scandals that have reduced his already sagging popularity and jeopardized his ability to govern.

title: Witness Tells Of Molesting As Young Boy By Ex-Priest
description: Testimony began today in the trial of a former priest accused of sexually molesting boys for more than 30 years.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Pepsi Unit Recognizes Not All Is Cola
description: PepsiCo has carved out a new unit dedicated solely to selling and promoting noncarbonated drinks, institutionalizing the changes in consumer taste responsible for much of its growth over the last few years.

description: Stonehenge, it is not.

description: Now that music has now taken over the home computer, Hewlett-Packard wants to put it back in the stereo rack, where it belongs.

description: PARISI-William S. On January 15, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Aida (nee Aliprando). Devoted father of Valerie Marie. Former Administrative Law Judge for the City of New York. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa & Sons Funeral Home, 345 Avenue U, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass on Friday 10:30 AM Guardian Angel RC Church. Interment is in Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting Friday 9 AM only.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, LORRAINE
description: SCHNEIDER-Lorraine. The members of the East Midtown Coalition for Sensible Development express sorrow on the death of Lorraine Schneider. We appreciated Lorraine's significant contributions to EMCSD, especially as Corresponding Secretary. Lorraine devoted her life to the well-being of her community, and her passing is a loss to us all.

title: Afghanistan Issues Order Taking Hard Line on Opium Production
description: Afghanistan's interim leader issued a decree yesterday banning the cultivation of opium poppies, reviving a struggle previously waged by the Taliban against Afghanistan's most lucrative crop, United Nations officials reported.

title: Footlights
description: Force of Nature

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Monetary Policy Unchanged
description: With rates already near zero, the Bank of Japan left monetary policy unchanged at its two-day meeting. The bank said it would keep up to 15 trillion yen ($114 billion) available in the money markets for companies to borrow and promised to add liquidity if there was a ''risk of financial market instability.'' But the policy board resisted calls for more unconventional steps to help the economy, either by weakening the yen or by buying a broader set of assets to help bail out lenders. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Appointment at Sony
description: The Sony Corporation of America named Robert Wiesenthal to the new post of chief financial officer and executive vice president yesterday. The company, a New York-based unit of Sony of Japan, said Mr. Wiesenthal would remain executive vice president and chief strategy officer of Sony Broadband Entertainment.

title: Protests Sink Bush Plan to Shift U.S. Oversight of Media Mergers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  A Bush Administration plan to overhaul government antitrust reviews and give the Justice Department responsibility for reviewing all mergers involving communications, entertainment and software companies was scuttled today after protests from Capitol Hill and from members of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Nose-Diving Rangers Cannot Muster a Goal
description: Less than a month ago, the Rangers were sitting atop the National Hockey League's Atlantic Division. Eric Lindros then sustained the seventh concussion of his career Dec. 28. Now, the Rangers, who are not getting production from their No. 1 line, are struggling to remain in playoff contention because they cannot score goals.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fund Manager Revises Results
description: The troubled fund manager Schroders revised its 2000 profit downward because of an accounting error that inflated earnings by about $16 million. The British company, Europe's third-largest manager of pension funds, said the error related to fees paid by clients, but it denied overcharging. The errors were made at the time Schroders sold its investment banking arm two years ago to Citigroup for $2.2 billion. The company also said 2001 pretax profit was as much as 10 percent below analysts' forecasts of about $100 million. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Jollied Along For a Ride
description: Dorfman and Froot. Those could be names for members of a vaudeville team. And in a sense, David Dorfman and Dan Froot are vaudevillians, brainy ones, for their breezy song-and-dance routines are indebted to postmodern dance and performance art, as well as to popular entertainment. But they are never so cerebral that they cease to be lively.

title: INSIDE
description: Three Slain at Law School

title: National Briefing | Washington: Agency Faults Meat Inspection
description: An independent audit by the General Accounting Office criticized a pilot inspection system for slaughterhouses, recommending that Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman impose stricter standards to improve the safety of poultry and hog slaughterhouses. At issue is how to inspect carcasses and avoid spreading organisms that cause 76 million food poisoning cases each year. The report was released one day after the Bush administration announced that it would expand the inspection system to 25 more plants.

title: On Defensive, General Says Prisoners Get Mats, Even Bagels
description: Smarting a bit from criticism by international human rights groups, United States troops here who received 30 new prisoners from the war on terrorism in Afghanistan were determined today to show that their captives would be treated properly.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Rochelle Park: Slander Suit Filed In Club Incident
description: Owners of a nightclub fined after a temporary dance floor collapsed in November, sending dozens into a swimming pool below, have filed a slander suit against Rochelle Park Township officials. The suit, filed in December, charges that Police Chief Richard Zavinsky and a building inspector, Gary L. Montroy, had made defamatory statements to the news media. The suit alleges that the officials accused the club, Metro Lounge, of criminal negligence, overcrowding and tolerating drug use. The township's lawyer, Joseph J. Rotolo, said yesterday that the officials' comments on the incident, in which no one was seriously hurt, were truthful and within their rights to make. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMONACO, JEROME
description: LoMONACO-Jerome. On January 15, 2002, of Forest Hills, NY. Lead tenor New York City Opera and Associate Professor at Illinois State University. Husband of Anne. Father of Marietta, Thomas, Jerome, Jr. and Robert. Reposing: Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Ave, Forest Hills, Thursday 7-9, Friday 2-5, 7-9. Funeral Mass, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, on Saturday, January 19, at 10:15AM. Interment, St. John's Cemetery.

title: A Picture-Perfect Pair Falls Apart in Bobsled
description: Two months ago, Jen Davidson and Jean Racine were inseparable friends who laughed at their quirky differences, completed each other's sentences and shared their inner thoughts in times of grief.

title: Tell-All Book Portrays Split In Leadership Of China
description: A recently published book, supposedly written by someone with remarkable access to the inner workings of China's Communist Party, denounces the leadership of President Jiang Zemin and promotes Prime Minister Zhu Rongji as the under-recognized brains behind the brawn of the country's central government.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker To Cut 1,400 Jobs
description: LSI Logic, a manufacturer of specialized communications chips, said it would trim its work force by 20 percent and sell two businesses in an effort to return to profitability in the second half of the year. The company, based in Milpitas, Calif., said it would reorganize its manufacturing operations in Tsukuba, Japan, and that it had begun discussions to sell two divisions that make products for digital subscriber lines and phones for code division multiple access cellular networks. To pay for the overhaul, which will claim 1,400 jobs, LSI Logic will take a charge of $50 million to $70 million in this quarter. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Stung by Security Flaws, Microsoft Makes Software Safety a Top Goal
description: Seeking to remove the tarnish from Microsoft's reputation for developing secure and reliable software, Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, distributed a companywide memorandum on Tuesday to call on employees to put more emphasis on making the company's products ''trustworthy.''

title: Fighting to Get Around Jargon
description: Rats. It happened again. We were on a train, it was a Thursday, and a close friend was reading my column in a paper someone had left on the seat.

title: Troubles at Enron and in Argentina Hurt J. P. Morgan
description: Hit by Enron's bankruptcy, turmoil in Argentina and continued weakness in private equity markets, J. P. Morgan Chase & Company said yesterday that it lost $332 million, or 18 cents a share, in the last three months of 2001, in contrast to a profit of $708 million, or 34 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 2000.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New York: Heir Caught with Contraband
description: Robert A. Durst, heir to a New York real estate empire, was caught last week with contraband in his jail cell in Easton, Pa., where he is being held on murder charges. Prison guards found a packet of checks that had been smuggled to Mr. Durst in the Northampton County Prison. A millionaire, Mr. Durst had $523 in his pocket and $38,600 in the trunk of his car on Nov. 30, when he was stopped by the police in nearby Hanover Township on a shoplifting charge. But that money was confiscated and Mr. Durst was not supposed to have any money or financial instruments in his cell. Mr. Durst was arrested in Pennsylvania on a fugitive warrant issued by the police in Galveston, Tex., where he is charged with murdering and dismembering a 71-year-old drifter.

title: As a Sculpture Takes Shape in Mexico, Opposition Takes Shape in the U.S.
description: In a tumbledown studio here barely big enough for his work and far too small for the magnitude of his crusade, the sculptor John Houser is putting finishing touches on an American monument that he hopes will break records and uphold tradition.

title: A Warm Front Enters the Home

title: A Smooth Defensive Move Helped This Slam Succeed
description: The world of bridge lost three of its leading citizens last month. Joyce Lilie, long a resident of the New York metropolitan area and a winner of four national titles, died in Las Vegas just three months after losing a son, Steven Furman, in the World Trade Center collapse. Bill August, a leading player, teacher and writer, died in Palm Beach, Fla. And Jean-Marc Roudinesco died in France, the country he represented with distinction on many occasions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILEZIKIAN, SARA
description: BILEZIKIAN-Sara. On behalf of the members of the Department of Medicine of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and the Medical Service of New York Presbyterian Hospital, we extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Drs. John and Sophie Bilezikian on the loss of their daughter Sara. John Tenenbaum, M.D. Interim Chair, Department of Medicine

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the promotion of suburban airports as alternatives to Los Angeles International referred incorrectly to El Toro, where Mayor James K. Hahn of Los Angeles proposes building an international airport. The installation there is a former Marine Corps air station, not a former Air Force base.

title: Kennedy Wants to Delay Tax Cuts to Pay for Programs
description: Saying what many Democrats think but make a point of not saying, Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for postponing $300 billion worth of last year's tax cuts so the nation could afford a prescription drug program and better early childhood education and health care.

title: Afghan Women And Aid Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Powell Lauds Pakistan's Efforts Against Extremists
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell emerged tonight from a meeting with President Pervez Musharraf and other top Pakistani officials praising their efforts to crack down on violent extremists and vowing to do all he could to help defuse tensions with India over the disputed Kashmir region.

title: Enron Avoided Income Taxes In 4 of 5 Years
description: Enron paid no income taxes in four of the last five years, using almost 900 subsidiaries in tax-haven countries and other techniques, an analysis of its financial reports to shareholders shows. It was also eligible for $382 million in tax refunds.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Save My Show

title: The Kashmir Flashpoint
description: Secretary of State Colin Powell is in South Asia trying to ease the dangerous buildup of military forces on the tense border between India and Pakistan. His most urgent task is to persuade the nuclear-armed neighbors to pull back their armies to reduce the risk of war. But sooner or later, India and Pakistan will have to peacefully resolve the explosive disagreement between them over the status of the northern Indian state of Kashmir. More than 50 years have passed since their first war over Kashmir, without any measurable progress in settling the conflict.

title: A Merger of Book Middlemen Could Deeply Influence Sales
description: Two of the most influential behind-the-scenes players in the book industry have agreed to merge, forming a powerful new gatekeeper with a pivotal role in shaping the fortunes of new books.

title: Prices You Just Can't Believe
description: JVC'S Web site is extensive and easy to navigate. Descriptions of the company's merchandise are more than adequate; pictures are large and clear; each product is clearly linked to similar JVC devices for comparison.

title: It May Be a Grudge Match for Forrest, but Not for Mosley
description: Shane Mosley wants it known that he is not a man to hold a grudge, at least not against Vernon Forrest.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Group To Challenge Domain Names
description: The consortium responsible for the new .info domain plans to announce today that it will challenge the legitimacy of an initial batch of 700 .info registrations made during a period intended to allow trademark holders early access to names. Registrants whose names are challenged will be required to provide proof of valid trademarks to keep the names. In December, the consortium of domain registrars, Afilias, which is based in Newtown, Pa., said it would challenge about 10,000 registrations that appeared to have been made using false trademark data. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: IT GROUP SEEKS CHAPTER 11 AND AGREES TO SELL ASSETS
description: The Shaw Group has agreed to pay $105 million in cash and stock and assume some liabilities to buy most of the IT Group, a hazardous- waste manager, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday. Shaw, a construction company based in Baton Rouge, La., said it would pay half the price in cash and half in stock, and provide as much as $75 million in financing to keep the IT Group operating. The IT Group listed $1.34 billion in assets and $1.08 billion in debt in its bankruptcy filing. The sale is subject to competing offers. The IT Group is based in Monroeville, La.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINZELBERG, MORRIS
description: WINZELBERG-Morris. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle mourns the passing of our esteemed Honorary Vice President and a respected leader in our community. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Bertram S. Schwarz, President

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about relatives of Sept. 11 terror victims who arrived in Kabul from the United States misidentified the third person from the left. She was Medea Benjamin of Global Exchange, the San Francisco-based group that organized the visit, not Kelly Campbell, a surviving relative.

title: Who Audits the Auditors?
description: As four government agencies and six committees of Congress begin to investigate the Enron failure, it's important to recognize that this is not just about Enron and its auditor, Arthur Andersen. We need to look at the entire system of gatekeepers -- auditors, corporate boards, analysts, ratings agencies, investment bankers, lawyers and accounting standard-setters -- who operate and regulate our financial markets. The confidence of individual investors depends on honest, independent gatekeepers. Sadly, the collapse of Enron shows this system urgently needs reform.

title: ALLSTATE SAYS LAWSUIT AND REVAMPING WILL CUT PROFIT
description: The Allstate Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit would be cut by $108 million, or 15 cents a share, for costs related to an overhaul and a settlement it had made with plaintiffs in a Georgia lawsuit. Allstate, one of the largest auto insurers in the nation, will record an expense of $70 million, or 10 cents a share, for closing claim offices and redesigning its customer information centers. The company, based in Northbrook, Ill., estimates the changes will save it $140 million a year before taxes. Allstate also said it was reserving $38 million, or 5 cents a share, in the fourth quarter for the settlement with Georgia auto policyholders. Allstate will report its financial results for the fourth quarter on Feb. 6.

title: Welfare Rolls Grew in City Late Last Year
description: For the first time in six years, New York City's welfare rolls began to rise by several thousand people in the late fall, adding to growing concerns among government officials nationwide that the country's revamped welfare system may be caught short in the recession.

title: Compaq's Sales and Profits Exceed Analysts' Predictions
description: Compaq Computer reported fourth-quarter sales and profits yesterday that blew past Wall Street's estimates, giving a boost to supporters of the company's $24 billion deal to be bought by Hewlett-Packard.

title: The Wary Jets Are Still Operating in the Shadow of Parcells
description: The Jets are preparing to lose at least two key staff members to Bill Parcells, if -- really, when -- he signs with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. It is the others who could go who are really scaring the Jets.

title: Botanical Garden to Pay $365,000 for Polluting
description: The New York Botanical Garden agreed yesterday to stop dumping polluted water into the Bronx River and to pay $365,000 for river improvements, the state attorney general's office announced.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Car Struck
description: A police car was hit last night by a car driven by a suspected car thief, the police said. The crash occurred in the Williamsburg section after officers in an unmarked car tried to stop the suspect, who then hit the patrol car while trying to escape, the police said. The two officers in the patrol car were taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, and the police said their injuries were not life threatening. The suspect was taken into custody, said Officer George Jensen. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, DEAN STEDMAN (DINI)
description: REILLY-Dean Stedman (Dini). Of Greenwich, CT & Vero Beach, FL at 75 after a gallant battle with pancreatic cancer. Surviving are her adoring husband of 50 years Gerald D; beloved sons Mark S. of New York, Craig C. of McLean, VA, Kent D. of East Norwalk, CT; beloved daughters Dean V. of Greenwich, Shawn R. Mills of Lyons, CO, six grandchildren, a sister Paula S. Lieber of Neenah, WI & Palm Desert, CA and several nieces and nephews. For information contact Fred D. Knapp & Son Funeral Home. A memorial mass celebrating her life 11 AM Saturday January 19, 2002 at St. Michael the Archangel Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich. Donations appreciated ''Oncology Nursing Education Fund'', Greenwich Hospital Development Office 5 Perryridge Road Greenwich, CT. 06830, (203) 863-3863. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that an act of kindness be done for a friend or for a stranger in her memory.

title: Finding a Spark for a Guy in Need of One
description: ''Italian for Beginners'' was shown as part of the 39th New York Film Festival in 2001. Here are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2; the full text is available at nytimes.com. The film, in Danish with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan.

title: Facing a Door He Can't Open
description: Seth Pehr knows he was lucky that he did not lose his life in the disaster at the World Trade Center, where he worked as a locksmith for 26 years. But he lost a lot of other things.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Teachers Endorse Reno Rival
description: Former Attorney General Janet Reno, one of nine Democrats seeking the nomination to challenge Gov. Jeb Bush in the fall, was passed over for an endorsement by the Florida Education Association. The union, with 120,000 members, instead endorsed a Tampa lawyer, Bill McBride, a political newcomer who has raised more money than Ms. Reno in the primary race. The union, which has mounted legal challenges against a statewide school voucher plan that Governor Bush pushed into law, calls Mr. McBride an energetic candidate who stands the best chance of reversing that program. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Olympian Injured
description: Emily Cook, an American freestyle aerialist and the only women to have already qualified for the U.S. Olympic freestyle team, sustained a serious ankle injury in training Thursday in Lake Placid, N.Y., which jeopardizes her availability for next month's Winter Games. Cook was preparing for this weekend's World Cup event here. Taken to a nearby hospital, there were indications that Cook had at least dislocated an ankle. Bill Pennington

description: Whitney Museum of American Art

title: A New Oil Game, With New Winners
description: In ''The Great Game,'' published just as the Cold War ended, Peter Hopkirk chronicled the struggle, throughout the 19th century and into the 20th, between Britain and Russia for influence, control and profit in Central Asia. The jewel in the crown was the Indian subcontinent; but the pathway to it ran through Afghanistan. Now the prize is oil -- getting it and transporting it -- and Afghanistan is again contested territory. The difference is that, this time around, it is the United States that will be playing the game with Russia.

title: Bald Eagles Resettling Their Old Neighborhood
description: In the bird blind overlooking the Housatonic River in Connecticut, a wildlife biologist announced a sighting.

title: St. John's Sees That It Can Be A Good Team
description: Boston College should be the class of the Big East. It is the defending conference champion and has the conference's best player. St. John's, a band of inconsistent shooters who have played spottily this season, should be a step below.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Lawmaker Faults Sept. 11 Bills
description: An influential state senator is opposing measures that would waive some taxes and fees and provide free college education for families of the 59 Marylanders killed in the Sept. 11 attacks. The lawmaker, Walter M. Baker, an Eastern Shore Democrat who is chairman of the powerful Judicial Proceedings Committee, said it was unfair to give breaks to victims of terrorism but not victims of other violence. One bill would exempt terrorism victims' families from probate fees and inheritance taxes; another would waive tuition at state universities. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: In Famously Tolerant City, Impatience With Homeless
description: After three hours of begging for change in a chilly, wind-swept fog, all Tricia T. could show for it was a pair of stiff hands, purple and gnarled from the cold, and 75 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, WILLIAM GOADBY
description: LAWRENCE-William Goadby, 88. A world renowned artist, died in Edgecomb, Maine on January 5, 2002. He was the youngest son of Robert Cutting Lawrence and Marguerite Lowe Lawrence. Bill's paintings are in the permanent collections of the Library of Congress, the Museum of Natural History, and the U.S. Coast Guard Academy Museum. He served in the United States Coast Guard in World War II and was awarded the Silver Star for Gallantry and Intrepidity in Action. Bill is survived by his wife of 42 years, Nathalie Brown Lawrence, his nephews, H. Lloyd Lawrence, Jr., Robert C. Lawrence, III, and nieces Genevieve L. Condos, Marguerite L. Lawrence, Grace L. Harding, Margo L. LaBau and Camilla Smith. Memorial contributions may be made to the Miles Health Care Center, Bristol Road, Damariscotta, ME 04543.

title: Japan Slows Down, but Not Its Road Builders
description: With massive white concrete pylons rising from a small farming valley, the New Tomei Expressway is emerging as Japan's answer to Germany's autobahn. Engineers are attacking mountains, straightening curves, smoothing inclines, and placing 60 percent of the highway on bridges or in tunnels, all in an effort to allow drivers to speed along at nearly 90 miles an hour.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Old Masters In Their Prime

title: Shoe Bomber Suspect Denies Charges
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18  Richard C. Reid, the man accused of trying to blow up a transatlantic flight last month by igniting explosives hidden in his shoes, pleaded not guilty today in federal court in Boston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACAL, VERA BACAL KOENIG
description: BACAL-Vera Bacal Koenig. Died of natural causes on January 15, 2002, at age 89. Even though Vera had Alzheimer's and was confined to a wheelchair, she said only a year ago, ''There are still three things I want to do. #

title: KIMBALL SAYS IT LAID OFF 300 ADDITIONAL WORKERS
description: Kimball International laid off 300 workers in its fiscal second quarter, the company said yesterday, bringing the job cuts last year to 2,300 as customers reduced purchases of desks, chairs and office cubicles. Profit in the quarter fell 47 percent. Kimball, which now has 9,000 employees, cut 3.2 percent of its staff, mostly in manufacturing, in the quarter ended Dec. 31. Net income dropped to $6.5 million, or 17 cents a share, from $12.4 million, or 32 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 11 percent, to $296.6 million from $332.8 million.

title: Cottrell Meeting With Other Teams
description: As the Jets prepare for a meeting today that will help determine their off-season personnel moves, the future of their staff continues to be in question.

title: Unemployment Shoots Up In December
description: The unemployment rate in New York City shot up last month to 7.4 percent from 6.9 percent as more than 10,000 jobs disappeared from the city's battered economy, government officials said yesterday.

title: American Insurer May Quit Deal to Buy Hyundai Units
description: The American International Group has threatened to scuttle its agreement to take over the three financial units of the Hyundai group, once South Korea's largest conglomerate.

title: Initial Jobless Claims Are Lower
description: The number of new claims for jobless benefits fell unexpectedly last week to the lowest level in more than five months, the Labor Department said today, a sign the economy might be pulling out of recession. A separate report by the Commerce Department showed a drop in the construction of homes and apartments in December.

title: Clay Ketter
description: Sonnabend

title: Bush's Advisers on Ethics Discuss Human Cloning
description: President Bush's newly appointed Council on Bioethics, a collection of 18 doctors, legal and ethical scholars, scientists and a journalist, met for the first time today and plunged into the thorny issue of human cloning, which Mr. Bush has said he opposes for any reason.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, LAURA
description: TURNER-Laura, 92 years old. Died on January 16, 2002. Beloved mother of Sophie and David Zaretsky. Devoted grandmother of Daniel and Jeffrey. Cherished sister of Anne and Kaz Rozycki. Loving aunt of Henry Rozycki and Aliza Beer. Services Friday, 2:30PM at ''Temple Beth-El of Great Neck'', 5 Old Mill Rd. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to North Shore LIJ Research Institute-Dr. Eidelberg, Parkinsons Disease Research.

title: Procter & Gamble In Shift on Clairol
description: Procter & Gamble in Cincinnati said yesterday that it would dismiss one agency that had worked on assignments for Clairol products but keep another. The decisions on the accounts, with combined spending estimated at $147.5 million to $172.5 million, came two months after Procter acquired Clairol from Bristol-Myers Squibb.

title: G.O.P. Weighs Chief's Stance on Enron Tie
description: As questions intensify about Enron's ties to the White House, Republicans who gathered here today for the party's winter meeting said they were not entirely reassured after last week's decision by the newly selected party chairman, Marc Racicot, to stop lobbying for a firm whose biggest clients included Enron.

title: County Executive Vows to Stop Pipeline Through Westchester
description: The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, pledged today to block construction of the Millennium Pipeline, a high-pressure natural gas line that would run near homes and schools in this largely affluent county, and called on Gov. George E. Pataki and other state leaders to join the fight.

title: Powell, in India, Declares That Tension Has Eased
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived here on Thursday night, expressing confidence that tensions have lessened between India and Pakistan, and that the two nations might soon find a way to ease a monthlong standoff that has led to a huge military buildup along their common border.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Road Is Unkind To the Isles
description: The road has been a surprisingly friendly place for the Islanders this season, but not last night. Not against the Pacific Division-leading San Jose Sharks, who outplayed the Islanders most of the way in a 3-2 victory before a sellout crowd of 17,496 at the Compaq Center in San Jose, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPLAN, CELIA
description: CAPLAN-Celia, 90. Of Westfield, New Jersey, on Jan. 16th, 2002. Devoted wife of the late Alex; beloved mother of Howard Caplan, Norman Caplan and Sandra Pack; dear mother-in-law of Anne Caplan, Marisa Caplan and Fred Pack; adoring grandmother of Amy, Debbie, Leslie, Diana, Larry, Seth, Keith, Jason, Mark & David; loving great grandmother of Jamie, Alec and Emily. Funeral services Sunday at 10:15 AM in Flynn & Son Funeral Home, 319 Amboy Ave., Metuchen, NJ. Interment will follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI.

title: The Reluctant Director of Downtown Restoration
description: PERHAPS this is one of those instances where the best man for the job is the man who didn't want the job. Our snowy-headed host, John C. Whitehead, reveals he nearly did something way out of character -- crawl under his fancy desk at 65 East 55th Street when he heard that he was Gov. George E. Pataki's pick to run the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation, the agency that will determine what manner of phoenix rises from the disaster zone that was once capitalism's bastion.

title: The Body Imperfect, 50 Years Ago And Today
description: AS the offices of Vogue emptied during the summer of 1949, Irving Penn, who at 32 was one of the magazine's rising stars, retreated to his studio for a series of pictures, which he made just for himself. These were photographs unlike almost any he had done -- in one sense, the exact opposite of what he and every other fashion photographer was doing.

title: Sports of The Times; B.C.S. Is a Symptom of a Larger Problem the N.C.A.A. Must Face
description: DAVID B. FROHNMAYER was one of a multitude of college presidents attending the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention this week. He may have been the only one with a legitimate complaint.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic, Haiti: Development Plan
description: The Dominican and Haitian presidents, meeting in the Dominican Republic, have agreed to joint economic development projects aimed at providing jobs for Haitians who live on the countries' common border. President Jean-Bertrand Aristide told his Dominican counterpart, Hiplito Meja, that he was prepared to establish 14 free zones on the border where Dominican factories could employ Haitians. David Gonzalez (NYT)

description: A Beautiful Mind

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Airbus Plans $530 Million In Cost Cuts
description: Feeling the pinch of weakening demand for aircraft after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, Airbus Industrie said today that it would cut costs by $530 million this year through early retirement of about 1,200 employees and other measures. Executives said that by eliminating overtime and part-time work, the company would reduce its labor costs the equivalent of 4,800 more full-time jobs without resorting to layoffs.

title: U.S. Hunts 5 Men Seen on Tape, Saying They May Plan Attack
description: The Justice Department announced a global manhunt today for five suspected members of Al Qaeda who were videotaped in Afghanistan offering what Attorney General John Ashcroft described as ''martyrdom messages,'' indicating that they could be preparing for a suicide attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMSEN, BASIL MAX
description: THOMSEN-Basil Max. Died January 15, 2002, after a courageous struggle to recover following open heart surgery. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Kim and Jon, loving brother of Phil and Doug and their wives Claire and Flora. His kindness, humor and generosity of spirit will be remembered by all who knew him. He will be missed in our hearts forever. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, January 20th at 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Devils Don't Break the Rangers' Fall
description: More than two and a half weeks into 2002, the Rangers are still looking for their first victory of the new year. Mike Richter, so brilliant over the first three months of the season, is struggling in goal. Eric Lindros, who carried the team offensively, is searching for his first point since returning from his seventh career concussion, which he sustained on Dec. 28.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: $8 Million For Park Land
description: Essex County has received nearly $8 million in state money to help preserve 240 acres as public park space, the Essex County executive, James W. Treffinger, has announced. In 1995, Essex County bought 600 acres in Verona, North Caldwell, Caldwell and Cedar Grove for $44.5 million. The state money, which comes from an agency that buys land for parks and other natural uses, will help offset the debt. The other 360 acres will be developed with town houses and housing for the elderly. Money from private development will be used to reduce the rest of the debt.

title: 'Traces: Primitive and Modern Expressions'
description: Jan Krugier

title: Golf and Massages
description: The Quail Lodge Resort and Golf Club in Carmel, Calif., has packages for up to 40 percent off through March 31 that offer a choice of daily golf for two or a massage for one. It's priced at $192 a night for two from Sunday through Thursday, and $223 weekends, and also includes Continental breakfast. Blackout dates are Jan. 31 to Feb. 3. The 97-room resort, on 850 acres, has its own 18-hole course, four tennis courts, two outdoor pools, a spa and fitness center. Call (888) 828-8787 and ask for the Winter Golf Getaway.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Man Arrested After Threats
description: A 25-year-old Japanese man was arrested for threatening to blow up the prime minister's official residence unless American troops were removed from the country. Tokyo Metropolitan Police identified the arrested man as Hidenobu Hamada, an unemployed resident of Wakayama prefecture. The police said the suspect had sent 18 threatening e-mail messages to Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, warning that the 48,000 American troops stationed in Japan must be removed within six months.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Deer Hunt Begins
description: A day after a court cleared the hunt, Princeton Township's annual deer hunt got under way on Wednesday with the killing of 17 deer by professional hunters, the State Fish and Game Department said yesterday. A state judge rejected a motion from animal rights activists to block the hunt. The township maintains that an excessively large deer population harms the environment and is dangerous to drivers, who swerve to avoid them. Officials hope that as many as 400 deer will be killed this winter.

title: Merck Is Said To Limit Perks In Marketing To Physicians
description: A sales representative for Merck says she and her associates have been told by their superiors that they should no longer treat doctors to free Broadway plays, weekend trips and other gifts that could be viewed as inappropriate.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: U.S. Military Has No Evidence bin Laden Is Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  The general who is running the military campaign in Afghanistan said today that he has no evidence to support an assertion from Pakistan's leader that Osama bin Laden is probably dead.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Lloyd's of London Weighs a New Path to Profitability
description: Four months after suffering heavy losses in the terrorist attacks in the United States, Lloyd's of London, one of the oldest and best-known names in insurance, proposed sweeping changes yesterday intended to make itself more competitive.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Chechnya: Rebels Kill 6 Russian Soldiers
description: Separatist rebels in Chechnya killed six Russian soldiers, the Russian military said, one of the largest single-day losses to which the Kremlin has admitted in weeks. The Kremlin reported the losses as the head of the United Nations refugee agency, Ruud Lubbers, urged Russia to reduce its military presence in the province and move toward a political settlement. The Kremlin recently declared Chechnya's guerrilla war over, setting the stage for what some predicted would be the forced repatriation of some 150,000 war refugees in Ingushetia, a neighboring province. Most experts say Chechnya remains too dangerous for refugees to return in large numbers. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: 3 Airlines Post Weaker Results
description: Southwest Airlines posted a decrease in fourth-quarter profit today, while Northwest Airlines and the US Airways Group reported wider losses as the recession and Sept. 11 attacks kept travelers off planes.

title: SIX ISRAELIS SLAIN BY ARAB GUNMAN
description: A lone Palestinian gunman walked into a crowded reception hall here late Thursday night and opened fire with a semiautomatic rifle, killing 6 people and wounding at least 25, witnesses and the police said.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. A * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: This Is a Hen. You Know, Eggs?
description: We have raised our children to be indoor children. They like it there, and we do, too. It is not as if we avoid or ignore the outdoors. But we are city people and, as a friend who moved from the city once told us, only in the city would people talk about ''outdoor space,'' as if all unspecified space were indoors.

title: Male Aspiration to the Fore In Lauren's European Debut
description: MILAN  After a decade of dressing down, casual Fridays, sloppy sportswear and designer stubble, men's fashion has returned to an old ideal: aspirational attire.

title: An Emotional Weekend For Wisconsin's Coach
description: The rivalry between Wisconsin and Minnesota, when played by the two Western Collegiate Hockey Association teams, is usually an emotional affair. But last weekend at the Kohl Center in Madison, the two-game series had an added layer of unexpected sentiment.

title: Warner Talks And the Rams Can Hear Him
description: The question that the St. Louis Rams hope will no longer be a question come Sunday in their second-round National Football League playoff game against Green Bay is whether Kurt Warner, their star quarterback, can speak up.

title: Former Client Raises Questions of Conflict
description: Since the Enron Corporation disclosed that its former chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, simultaneously worked for the company and for partnerships with which it did deals, investors and experts have raised questions about the potential conflict of interest.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The Black Duck, on the ground floor of a renovated 18th-century Federal-style town house, makes a dignified presence on a raffish stretch of 28th Street. Surrounded by all-night produce stores, cheap ethnic restaurants and a parking lot across the street, it somehow manages to give the impression that it sits right in the middle of Georgetown. The clubby interior, with dark-wood wainscoting and nautical paintings, and the American seafood menu, put it in the scallop, scrod and pewter school of American restaurants. It's a style encountered all up and down the Atlantic coast, but not all that often in Manhattan. The owners, Atlantic Stars Hospitality Group, are a hotel and cruise-ship company based in Newport, R.I., so the nautical theme is second nature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDRON, LINDA
description: ANDRON-Linda. The Auxiliary Minyan was shocked and dismayed on the sudden death of Linda. We extend our profound condolences to Richard and Eliana and hope that we can be a source of support and strength for you. Your Friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, FLORENCE V. (NEE STANIS)
description: HOWARD-Florence V. (nee Stanis), 93. Of New Hyde Park on January 17, 2002. She had been a member of Notre Dame Church and the Altar Rosary Society for over sixty years. Beloved wife of the late James, Sr. Dearest mother of James F. Howard and Rev. Theodore J. Howard, Pastor of St. Mark's Catholic Church, Shoreham, New York. Dear mother-inlaw of Maureen. Loving sister of Agnes Reilly, Regina Stanis and the late Theodore Stanis and Theresa Yekelek. Dear aunt of nephews and nieces. Reposing at New Hyde Park Funeral Home, 506 Lakeville Road, New Hyde Park, NY, on Sunday and Monday, between 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM (Exit 33 South LIE). Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, January 22 at 11 AM, Notre Dame RC Church, New Hyde Park, NY. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing.

title: Antiques To Benefit A Museum
description: The American Folk Art Museum has organized its first American Antiques Show, which runs through Sunday at the Metropolitan Pavilion in Chelsea. Among the examples of Americana in the show is a compass quilt, left, from about 1845, being shown by Laura Fisher, one of 44 exhibitors in the event.

title: Profits Increase at G.E., But Sales Are Off 2.9%
description: The General Electric Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 9.7 percent as it cut costs and sales fell.

title: Lawyer No Longer Questions State Police Appointee's Conduct
description: A defense lawyer who had questioned the conduct of Joseph J. Santiago, Gov. James E. McGreevey's nominee to head the New Jersey State Police, said yesterday he was now convinced Mr. Santiago had done nothing wrong in a trial of two police officers in December 2000.

title: Firefighters Block a Plan for Statue in Brooklyn
description: Plans to honor firefighters with a bronze statue depicting a black, a white and a Hispanic firefighter raising an American flag at ground zero were abandoned yesterday in response to complaints by firefighters.

title: Televised Plays In Stores Soon
description: It's a natural progression. For about two years, dozens of productions from the golden age of drama on television have been available on VHS from the Broadway Theater Archive at www.broadwayarchive.com. On March 26, five of them are to be released in stores by Kultur, one of video's best-known distributors of performing arts programming. And they will be available on DVD.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

description: BROWN-Ann Ward. Of Sausalito, CA. on January 16, 2002. Born in Brooklyn, NY, July 18, 1927. Dearest mother of Paula Brown Caplice and Michele Brown Steiner. Grandmother (''PAL'') to Mike, Nanette, Alex, Philip, Veronica, Stephan and Friedy. Great grandmother to Aidan Jack. Beloved sister to Catherine Ahern, Helen Cosgrove and the predeceased Frances Handley and John Ward. Friend and confidant to many nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday January 22, at St. Thomas More, Madison Ave, 89 St. Family requests in lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Sausalito Volunteer Salvage Shop, 19 Princess St., Sausalito, CA 94965, Attn Nursing Scholarship Fund or the Hospice of Marin 415-927-2284.

title: Dance History Leaps to Life In the Archives
description: The Jerome Robbins Dance Division of the New York Public Library of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center is one of the city's great cultural treasure troves. It is the largest dance archive in the world, with holdings that date back to 1460. But even dance fanatics tend to forget about this research center once known simply as ''the Dance Collection.''

title: Hidden Files
description: In its war against the West, Al Qaeda's greatest success has been its ability to use the tools and behaviors of ordinary civilian life to interrupt the conduct of ordinary civilian life. Sept. 11 made that point, as did the arrest in late December of Richard Reid, who was allegedly trained by Al Qaeda and who wore explosive sneakers aboard a jetliner bound from Paris to Miami. But there is no better evidence of Al Qaeda's search for everyday targets than the discovery of two computers once used in a Qaeda office, a desktop and a laptop, that were later purchased by a Wall Street Journal reporter from a computer merchant in Kabul for $1,100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORKIN, HELEN (NEE CLARKE)
description: ORKIN-Helen (nee Clarke). Beloved mother Kathleen Jones, James & the late Frank. Devoted grandmother of Laura Staples, Walter Jr, Stephanie Jones; Danielle and Jamie; Danielle and Thomas. Dear great-grandmother of Colton & Tyler Jones. Reposing Pitta Funeral Home, 300 McDonald Ave, Bklyn until Saturday 9:15 AM. Mass of Christian burial at The Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Ft Hamilton Pkwy, E 4 St 9:45 AM. Visiting 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: Gulotta's Campaign Fund Is Bigger Than Both Parties'
description: When Thomas S. Gulotta retired last month after 14 years as Nassau County executive, he left county government in the poorhouse, with chronic budget deficits, soaring debt, tattered credit ratings and state-imposed fiscal monitors.

title: Arne H. W. Larsson, 86; Had First Internal Pacemaker
description: Arne H. W. Larsson, a Swedish engineer who in 1958 received the world's first implanted heart pacemaker, has died in Stockholm. He was 86.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 11 about astronomers' finding about the color that the universe would appear if it could be seen from afar misstated the effect of combining pure red and blue light. The blend produces magenta (purplish red), not pale green. Thus the article referred incompletely to the reasoning by which the universe would look pale green. While the scientists analyzed light from older ''red'' stars and younger ''blue'' stars, both types also emit a wide range of colors, including green, which predominates when all the visible light is analyzed together.

title: Inert Bomb at a Science Fair Raises Interest of Authorities
description: A high school student's science project was meant to demonstrate how heat is involved in transferring energy. But because the project was an inert bomb, the student and his teacher are taking some heat of their own.

title: Bobsled Battle
description: Jen Davidson said yesterday that she was moving ahead with a grievance that she has filed against her former bobsled partner, Jean Racine, because Racine denied her a chance to prove herself against her competitors.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Fraud Investigation
description: Federal agents occupied the National Water Commission and seized files in a fraud investigation of 19 top managers. The managers were fired Wednesday night and accused of taking bribes to approve illegal wells in water-starved Mexico.

title: Enron's Chief Sold Shares After Receiving Warning Letter
description: Documents disclosed yesterday indicate that Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman and chief executive of Enron, disposed of stock within days of receiving a letter warning of accounting problems at the company.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Prisoner Kills Counselor
description: A counselor for the Corrections Corporation of America, the nation's largest private operator of prisons, was stabbed to death by an inmate, becoming the first employee to die in job-related violence in the company's 19-year history. The counselor, Delbert Steed, 57, was stabbed in the back with a homemade weapon while meeting with the prisoner, who was serving two life sentences for murder at the Hardeman County Correctional Facility in Whiteville, some 50 miles northeast of Memphis, company officials said. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZ, LOLA
description: GEWIRTZ-Lola. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a respected member of the Queens, NY, and Connecticut Jewish communities, wife of the late Rabbi Jonas Gewirtz and beloved mother of Dorothy (and Julius) Berman and Dr. William (and Debbie) Gewirtz. Dorothy, vice chairman of the Stern College for Women Board of Directors, together with her husband, Julius, YU Trustee and chairman of YU's affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary Board of Trustees, are YU Guardians. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Gewirtz/Berman family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Marjorie Blenden Diener, Chairman, SCW Board Herbert Smilowitz, Vice Chairman RIETS Board

title: Solid Consumer Spending Bolsters Microsoft
description: Drawing strength from its new video game business and the introduction of its latest version of its industry- dominant Windows operating system, Microsoft reported second-quarter results today that surpassed Wall Street's expectations in both earnings and revenue.

title: Venus Williams Overcomes a Slow Start and Advances
description: After a week full of aches, pains and nasty surprises, Venus Williams proved today that it was indeed possible for a heavily favored player to avoid an upset at this Australian Open.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Case Of Ex-Priest Goes To Jury
description: Jurors began deliberations in the trial of a former Roman Catholic priest, John J. Geoghan, 66, who is charged with sexually molesting a boy in 1991. In closing arguments in Middlesex County Superior Court, Mr. Geoghan's lawyer, Geoffrey Packard, suggested that the accuser, now a college student, and his mother had brought the charges in pursuit of money, sought in a related civil suit. The prosecutor, Lynn Rooney, said Mr. Geoghan, defrocked in 1998, had slipped his hand into the boy's shorts and squeezed his buttocks, an act she called indecent and a crime.
