title: A Dissident Czech Band That Rocked the Boat
description: Taking their name from the lyrics of a Frank Zappa song, the Plastic People of the Universe were the leading band in Czechoslovakia in the 1970's and 80's, two decades of political foment to which they made some significant contributions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIFERMAN, CELIA
description: HEIFERMAN-Celia. The Officers, Trustees and Members of the Forest Hills Jewish Center mourn the loss of Celia Heiferman, beloved wife of our former President Sol Heiferman z''l, former board member and beloved personality in her own right. Her devotion to family and community were exemplary, and we will treasure always the memory of her gentle way. May Ruth and the family find comfort and strength in the memory of her love. Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik Cantor Adam Frei Tina Berger, Executive Director Valerie K. Leibler, President

title: Players Union Chief Talks to Owners
description: Donald Fehr stood in a hotel conference room today facing close to 100 baseball club owners and executives. Not even a handful of them had preceded Fehr, the players union chief, into Major League Baseball.

title: Powell Sees Encouraging Signs on India-Pakistan Tensions
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 18  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell ended 36 hours of cross-border diplomacy in India and Pakistan today without concrete agreements from either side on de-escalating their military standoff but with strong signs from both New Delhi and Islamabad that tensions are easing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLODGETT, MERRIL BECK
description: BLODGETT-Merril Beck. On January 16, 2002. Beloved wife of Herbert. Devoted daughter of Esther and the late Ira Beck. Dear sister of Phyllis Beck Bloom. Cherished aunt of Michael & Sarah. Services Sunday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her name to A Gift of Life, PO Box 49, Madison Square Station, NY, NY 10159.

title: Kmart Fires Its President And Names A Chairman
description: The Kmart Corporation fired its president and named a new chairman yesterday, but the giant retailer failed to reassure investors and manufacturers, who are waiting for concrete signs that the company will not file for bankruptcy.

title: Schaap's 'Collection Of People' Mourns
description: The journalist Dick Schaap, Jimmy Breslin's friend of 52 years, died last month, and yesterday Breslin's memory returned to an obituary Schaap wrote about the taboo-breaking comedian Lenny Bruce.

title: City to Appeal Court Order Over Homeless at Church
description: The city has decided to appeal a recent federal court decision, which allowed homeless people to sleep on the steps of a Manhattan church, after failing to negotiate a settlement, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: Mystery of L.I. Vagrant Remains, but He's Dead Meat
description: He was dark and elusive, and he knew his way around Long Island's East End -- ambling along the beach, stopping by the Fox Hill Country Club golf course, popping over to the Riverhead Raceway.

description: Casey Kaplan

title: Congress Rebuffed on Energy Documents
description: The White House refused again today to turn over documents demanded by Congress as part of an inquiry into workings of the administration's energy task force, including records of a meeting that Vice President Dick Cheney had with Kenneth L. Lay, chairman of the Enron Corporation.

title: Truth Is Out: This Season Will Be Last For 'X-Files'
description: This will be the final season for ''The X-Files,'' one of the most talked about and most profitable television shows of the past decade, the Fox network said yesterday.

title: Argentine Stock Exchange Is Reopened
description: Struggling to get control of the economic crisis, the government of President Eduardo Duhalde reopened the country's stock exchange today, forced the resignation of the central bank president and moved toward easing some restrictions on bank accounts.

title: Travel Videos
description: All videos require Realplayer .

title: Club May Land In Washington
description: Amid all the talk about eliminating two major league teams, Commissioner Bud Selig acknowledged today that relocating a team would be feasible at some point.

title: Sprewell Says if He Goes, Garden Will Be Emptier
description: In recent weeks, Latrell Sprewell has seemingly given up trying to be the Knicks' general manager. The player who openly lobbied for Chris Webber and then all but chastised Knicks management for failing to add significant size to the roster last summer has made mum the word when discussing the Knicks' personnel.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday incorrectly said Mark Twain has been dead for 97 years. He died in 1910.

title: McGreevey Administration Hints at Tax Rebate Cuts
description: Faced with a steep budget deficit, the administration of New Jersey's new governor, James E. McGreevey, is considering whether to repeal or reduce a property tax rebate program that paid the average homeowner $500 last year, state officials said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: OpenTV In Deal With AT&T
description: OpenTV will offer interactive television services through a unit of AT&T that supplies digital cable channels to 275 cable operators across the country. The AT&T unit, Head end in the Sky, reaches six million digital cable customers in 2,000 communities. The cable operators will be able to offer OpenTV games, news, weather and horoscopes to customers who have Motorola DCT-2000 digital set-top boxes. Last year, AT&T announced a similar agreement with Liberate Technologies, an OpenTV rival. AT&T and Microsoft also have a longstanding relationship to develop interactive television services. Headend in the Sky is one of the AT&T cable businesses being acquired by Comcast. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Reopening Delayed For Senate Offices
description: One day after officials declared the Hart Senate Office Building free of anthrax and cleared it for reopening, they closed the building indefinitely today after finding cleanup gear in the space above a ceiling.

title: Both Timeless and Timely: 'Roots' at Quarter-Century
description: AN African father holds his infant son up toward the starry night sky and gives him a name. ''Kunta Kinte, behold the only thing greater than yourself,'' he says near the start of the mini-series ''Roots.'' Who could have guessed that 25 years later, that scene would retain its visual elegance and emotional power, yet also bring to mind a more pedestrian scene? Today when the baby Kunta Kinte is lifted to the heavens, the gesture recalls the start of ''The Lion King,'' when the film's baboon-shaman, Rifiki, lifts the cub Simba to the sky, a cue to begin the song ''The Circle of Life.''

title: Several Administration Officials Held Enron Shares
description: While much has been made of the huge sums the Enron Corporation invested in the political campaigns of President Bush, some senior members of the Bush administration were also heavily invested in the company's stock.

title: The Damaged Spirit of the Sept. 11 Fund
description: When World Trade Center families and others agreed to express their concerns together last night at an armory on Park Avenue, they were motivated by a deadline. Only days remain to submit comments on the proposed rules and regulations of the fund set up by the federal government to compensate those whose lives and livelihoods were devastated on Sept. 11. The rules are flawed, and we urge the White House, the Justice Department and Congress to act now to change them.

title: Museum Aims to Make Money the Old-Fashioned Way, at Antiques Fair
description: No sooner had the bustling American Folk Art Museum settled into its brand-new home on West 53rd Street than it came up with another new venture, an antiques fair. Through Sunday it is presenting the first edition of the American Antiques Show, and it plans to make the show, a middle-size but choice mart for antiques and folk art, an annual event during the third week of January.

title: Screening of All Checked Airline Bags Is to Start Today, but Safety Concerns Remain
description: As the airlines prepared to start baggage procedures to reduce the risk of bombing, experts predicted only modest improvements in security, and hoped for only modest schedule disruptions.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the News Watch column of Circuits yesterday about digital voice recorders from Olympus referred incorrectly at one point to a new model. It is the VN-900; the VN-90 is an earlier one.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES PLANS MORE JOB CUTS AND PLANT CLOSINGS
description: PPG Industries, a maker of paints, specialty chemicals and glass products, said yesterday that it planned to reduce its work force and close plants as fourth-quarter earnings fell 34 percent. The company will have first-quarter costs before taxes of $60 million to $90 million related to the cuts. PPG said it was not prepared to say how many jobs would be eliminated or which plants would be closed. PPG has been cutting jobs and closing plants as orders declined after the makers of automobiles, appliances and electronics sold fewer products amid the recession. Net income in the fourth quarter fell to $83 million, or 49 cents a share, from $126 million, or 75 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 7 percent, to $1.91 billion from $2.05 billion.

title: Tests Have Been Started For Banned Substances
description: With the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City nearing, the World Anti-Doping Agency has performed 2,600 out-of-competition tests with 900 more to be completed before opening ceremonies on Feb. 8.

title: A Bit Fancy For Go Fish
description: This week's sales of Americana have several outstanding lots, but probably none are showier than the pair of Charles-Honor Lannuier American Empire-style card tables that Christie's is selling this afternoon. The tables, which retain their Lannuier labels and were included in the catalog for the Lannuier show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1998, have winged female caryatid supports and paw feet. They have rosewood veneers, matching die-stamped brass borders on their aprons and gilded brass star-and-eagle mounts. They were made around 1815 for a Philadelphia merchant, George Harrison, and his wife, Sofia.

title: Top-Ranked Duke Turns to Williams
description: The second half was almost four minutes old and Maryland was staggering. Jason Williams sensed it. He turned to his Duke teammates after a timeout, pumped his fists near halfcourt and implored the Blue Devils to ''blow these guys out.'' Then Williams matched his fiery words with some impressive actions.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling In Rent Case
description: A court ruling allowing landlords to evict from rent-stabilized apartments tenants who charge their roommates more than a fair share of the rent has been upheld by an appeals court. The appellate ruling also says that even if tenants are unaware of the law, they can still be evicted. The ruling stemmed from a case last year involving a disabled 70-year-old retiree, Jean E. Mazzolo, who took in a roommate at her Park Avenue apartment and charged him $2,200 when her monthly rent was less than $1,850. The woman's lawyer, Darnay Hoffman, is considering a further appeal.

title: A Nation in Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Lost $5.4 Billion in 2001 After Charge for Revamping
description: Ford Motor reported a $5.45 billion net loss for 2001 today, its first annual loss since 1992 and a long way from its $3.47 billion net profit in 2000.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Corsica Plan Blocked By Court
description: A plan to give the troubled island of Corsica more independence from France hit a roadblock when parts of the legislation were declared unconstitutional because they breached the principles of national unity. The ruling is an embarrassment for the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, who hoped the legislation would end separatist violence on the Mediterranean island. Two other Jospin initiatives have also been struck down recently, an effort to raid the country's social security budget to meet the costs of the reduced 35-hour week and a law preventing companies from shedding workers.

title: How the Impact of Modern Life Transformed Ideas of Nature
description: Does an exhibition of British landscapes sound exciting? If not, you may be pleasantly surprised by ''Pastoral to Postindustrial: British Works on Paper From the Whitworth Art Gallery,'' now at the Grey Art Gallery at New York University.

title: India Presses Its Conditions For Pullback From Border
description: India will not withdraw its forces from the border with Pakistan until raids across the border end and Pakistan hands over suspected terrorists, India's defense minister said here today.

title: Voices From the Underground
description: To the Editor:

title: British Charge 2 Algerians With Belonging to Al Qaeda
description: After months of investigation, the British authorities today charged two Algerian men arrested last September with membership in Osama bin Laden's terrorist network -- the first formal link drawn here between Al Qaeda and Islamic extremists alleged to be operating in this country.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Tuesday about the Sundance Film Festival misidentified the director of the documentary ''How to Draw a Bunny.'' He is John Walter; Andrew Moore is the cinematographer and producer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, SILVIA N.
description: WEINBERG-Silvia N. Of Forest Hills, NY, on January 16, 2002, age 90. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving mother and mother-in-law of Emily and Henry Goldberger, and Eric Weinberg. Adored grandmother of Tanya Weinberg, and Ethan and Jesse Goldberger, and cherished sister of Ethel Schaefer. Strong in spirit and with great love for her family, she lived a full and independent life until this past October. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends. Services on Sunday, January 20, 12 noon, Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66th Ave., Forest Hills. For additional information, please call 908-272-3710 or 215-790-0129.

title: Candidates Chosen For Goodman's Seat In the State Senate
description: The Republican and Democratic Parties officially nominated their candidates last night in the State Senate race to succeed Roy M. Goodman, a Republican who has represented the 26th District on the East Side of Manhattan for 33 years.

title: U.S. Agency Not Protecting Public Health, Officials Say
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency failed to protect the public health by not focusing more attention on indoor air quality, which continues to be a nagging issue for thousands of residents and workers near the World Trade Center site, a group of elected officials from New York City said yesterday.

title: N.F.L. Warns the Buccaneers and Parcells
description: The National Football League, concerned that the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Bill Parcells may be skirting league tampering rules, issued a stern warning yesterday to both parties that could subject them to punishment by Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, according to N.F.L. executives.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HARRIS, Melbourne, Fla., a maker of communications equipment, said it had won a $200 million contract with General Dynamics U.K., a unit of General Dynamics, Falls Church, Va., the military contractor, to supply 10,000 high-frequency radio systems for Britain's Bowman Tactical Radio Program, a military project.

title: PLEXUS SAYS IT IS CUTTING 5 PERCENT OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: The Plexus Corporation, a provider of electronics design and testing services, is cutting 300 jobs, or 5 percent, of its work force by the end of its second quarter in March, the company said yesterday. Plexus would not disclose the number of jobs that had been cut already. The cuts are expected to save Plexus $1.5 million to $2 million a quarter. Plexus has about 6,000 employees after it bought the assets of MCMS Inc. this year, a spokeswoman said. Plexus also said it would combine the MCMS plant in San Jose, Calif., with the Plexus plant there, and close the MCMS plant in Raleigh, N.C.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Reassurance is good. Cash is better.''

description: To the Editor:

description: EUROPE

title: Resonance From the Violent, Unsettled World of 80 Years Ago
description: Cataclysm inspires rumination, philosophy, regret, soul-searching -- the kind of thinking, in other words, that divides contemporary history into before and after. That the world will never be the same after Sept. 11 is accepted wisdom and has become the leaping off point for many a discussion of what went wrong and how we must now be different. Indeed, it can arguably be said that confronting a new and discomforting order in the world is currently the primary psychic business of mankind.

title: Art in Review
description: Paul Pfeiffer

title: Man Convicted of Lying to F.B.I. About Intent to Study Aviation
description: An Egyptian man arrested at Kennedy International Airport on Sept. 19 with what officials said were forged pilot's documents and a fake pilot's uniform was convicted by a federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday of lying to F.B.I. investigators about his intent to study aviation.

title: Nets Shooting for Seventh Straight Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 17  It would have come as no surprise had the Nets canceled practice today because the team had come down with a serious case of euphoria. Does it get any better than silencing Michael Jordan and embarrassing his Washington Wizards? Could anything be bigger than a how- do-you-top-that, 111-67 victory in front of the first packed house of the season?

title: Engineers Try to Devise Plan To Remove Teetering Crane
description: A damaged construction crane teetering high above the waterfront here continued to keep hundreds of residents off balance today, as they resigned themselves to at least one more night outside their apartments while engineers worked to solve the problem.

title: Steelers Are Happy The Bus Is Set to Roll
description: On a bowling lane, Jerome Bettis is a different athlete. His footwork is soft as he sets up his cutter ball, so spin and trajectory can converge on the right pocket and send the lumber flying. He has rolled one perfect game of 300, and just missed attaining a kegler's nirvana two other times by a single pin.

title: TREDEGAR TO CLOSE PLANT THAT MAKES LAYER FOR DIAPERS
description: The Tredegar Corporation, a maker of plastic films used in diapers and aluminum pieces used in window framing, said yesterday that it would close a plant in Carbondale, Pa., eliminating 58 jobs by the end of September. Tredegar said the closing cost $1.8 million, or 5 cents a share, in the fourth quarter. Over the next nine months, the move will cost Tredegar an additional $800,000. The plant, part of Tredegar's Film Products unit, produces the outer layer of disposable diapers. Declining demand from diaper makers led to the decision to close the operation, a spokesman said. The company has reduced its number of plants to five from eight in the last two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESHES, NATHAN
description: CHESHES-Nathan. Age 96. Beloved husband of Regina. Loving father of the late Rina Stempel. Devoted grandfather of Andrea. Adored great grandfather of Max and Cameron. Graveside services today 1 PM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. For information call Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 718-377-7300.

description: LEFKOWITZ-Harry. Congregation Beth Sholom mourns the passing of our esteemed member, Harry Lefkowitz. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Steven Wolinsky Chairman of the Board

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 15.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. to Invest $750 Million to Promote Development
description: Eager to help New York City after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. yesterday announced a program in which unions would invest $750 million of their pension funds for housing and commercial development.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Alison Lazar was named manager for advertising sales and corporate communications at the New York office of ESPN, part of the Walt Disney Company. She had been a communications consultant. At another Disney television network, ABC, ABC New Media Sales, New York, part of the ABC National Television Sales unit, was selected by the Yankees Entertainment and Sports Network, New York, to handle the selling of national and regional commercial time for three years. The Yankees network is to be introduced in March for viewers in Connecticut, New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Metro Briefing column on Wednesday about plans for a new paper, The New York Sun, to begin publishing in the spring referred imprecisely to the past affiliation of some founders. They are former staff members of The Forward, not former members. The article also misstated the title of Seth Lipsky. He is to be The Sun's president, not vice president.

title: INSIDE
description: No Insurance at Ground Zero

title: John W. Locke, 87, Agent for Edward Gorey and Other Artists
description: John William Locke, an artist's representative who helped transform the aesthetics of American illustration by introducing satiric European illustrators and cartoonists to magazines, book publishers and advertising agencies, died on Jan. 3 in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 87.

title: F.T.C. ASKS CONOCO AND PHILLIPS FOR MORE INFORMATION
description: Conoco and Phillips Petroleum said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had asked for more information about their $17 billion merger. The request is routine, a Phillips spokesman said. Phillips, based in Bartlesville, Okla., received a second request from the trade commission when buying a refiner, the Tosco Corporation, in September for $8.37 billion. The merger is still expected to close in the second half, Phillips and Conoco said.

title: Album of the Week
description: JAY-Z: ''Jay-Z Unplugged'' (Roc-A-Fella Records). Arguing against electronic instruments in hip-hop, on the theory that live instruments sound better, is a fool's game. I've run aground on that argument; as soon as you put the idea out there, it looks idiotic. It's not counterintuitive to use real instruments; it's just counterproductive. Hip-hop means efficiency, reaching the maximum number of people at once, in one three-minute radio blast. Balanced sound, warm acoustics in an intimate room and all that isn't part of the deal.

description: Southfirst

title: An Enron Legacy: Lower Reported Profits
description: ''FAIRLY'' is the forgotten word of American accounting. But the Enron debacle threatens to make it a very contentious word as scared auditors suddenly decide that they should rein in corporations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, ARLENE
description: MAYER-Arlene. An indomitable spirit whose warmth, sincerity and wisdom touched all who knew her. Truly, ''the wind beneath my wings.'' I loved you and shall miss you forever. Weezie

title: 2 Neo-Nazis In Norway Are Guilty In Race Death
description: Two neo-Nazis were sentenced today to prison terms of 16 years and 15 years for their roles in the first racially motivated killing on record in Norway, shorter sentences than the prosecutor had sought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CADENA, CARLOS ALBERTO
description: CADENA-Carlos Alberto. On January 16, 2002. Beloved husband of Rosalba. Dear father of Martin, Fernando, Alberto and Nancy. Proud grandfather of 4. Survived by his mother Elena. Family to receive friends at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 103-33 Lefferts Blvd., Richmond Hill, NY, Friday 29 P.M. and Saturday 8-10 A.M. Funeral Mass Saturday 11 A.M. at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church followed by private service at Fresh Pond Crematory.

description: ATTENTION, attention, loyalists of Bill Parcells. Be careful what you wish for, and proceed to Tampa at your own risk.

title: A System Corrupted
description: Clearly, Larry Lindsey shouldn't have described the Enron affair as a ''tribute to American capitalism,'' and Paul O'Neill shouldn't have declared: ''Companies come and go. It's part of the genius of capitalism.'' Both the top White House economist and the Treasury secretary have been excoriated for their callousness. But did they have a point?

title: Carnival's New Bid for P&O Escalates Cruise Line Battle
description: Carnival, the largest cruise line, raised its hostile bid for P & O Princess Cruises 12 percent today, seeking to prevent P & O's merger with Royal Caribbean Cruises.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Accord On A Forest
description: An environmental organization and the Weyerhaeuser Company, one of the world's largest timber concerns, have negotiated a deal that will set aside 100,000 acres of land east of Seattle as a working forest, protecting it from development. The environmental group, the Evergreen Forest Trust, is to pay Weyerhaeuser $185 million for the tract and will harvest much of it, as the company did, although 20,000 acres of delicate wildlife habitat and riverbanks will be exempted from logging. The land, the trust's first acquisition, covers Cascade foothills in parts of two counties where population growth has been rapid.

title: Kuni Sugiura -- 'The Artist Papers and Other Works'
description: Leslie Tonkonow Artworks and Projects

title: Fifty Ways to Use Your Cellphone
description: One of the great things about being a commuter is discovering the untapped potential of the cellular phone. I sat by a particularly creative woman recently on a 6:12 p.m. Metro North train out of Grand Central Terminal. Somewhere between the Botanical Garden and Mount Vernon stops, she phoned home to explain exactly where, in the vast expanse of her kitchen freezer, there was a container of frozen spaghetti sauce. For more than two minutes she guided someone past the Birdseye sweet corn, behind the chocolate chip Eggo waffles, to the left of a four-pack of Perdue boneless chicken breasts until -- voil! There in a light green Tupperware container sat the sauce, ready to be thawed out for her family's dinner. What an improvement over wasting precious seconds earlier in the day by leaving a note on her kitchen countertop! I could not but be in awe.

title: Messier Battles Age and Injury
description: Happy birthday, someone said to Mark Messier.

title: The Neediest Cases; Donations Continue to Rise as Another Record Falls
description: After a dramatic upswing in donations, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund set a record on Tuesday, surpassing the $8.03 million collected in last year's campaign, also a record. By Wednesday, contributions reached an even higher record -- $8,309,809.99.

title: If Elected, Stoiber Plans A New German Economy
description: FRANKFURT  - As first order of business if he defeats Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder in September, Edmund Stoiber vows to dismantle much of Mr. Schroeder's economic record.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRAGNER, BERTRAM I.
description: FRAGNER-Bertram I. Dearest Poppa Bert, Thirteen years without your stories. How we miss them and you. With love forever, Your Family

title: White House Casts Doubt On Money for Health Plan
description: The Bush administration has blown a major hole in a multibillion-dollar health care plan proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki that includes salary increases for members of a politically influential union in New York. Mr. Pataki's two Democratic rivals in the campaign for governor immediately attacked his plan, and one of them called on him to withdraw it.

title: Embracing His Senegal, His Continent, His World
description: For a three-night stand at Joe's Pub, the Senegalese singer Baaba Maal traded his usual full-size funk band for a string band: three acoustic guitars, electric bass and two West African stringed instruments, a kora (a harp) and a hoddu (a small, skin-faced lute that sounds like both the oud and the banjo). The music they made on Monday night was magnificent: hypnotic and galvanizing, uplifting and visceral.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Despite Bumps, Citigroup 4th Quarter Was Up
description: Citigroup's exposure to Enron and Argentina did not interfere with a successful fourth quarter for the company, which posted a 36 percent increase in profit, thanks in part to the continuing strength of its consumer business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTO, JOHN M.
description: KANTO-John M. Died on January 7, 2002 at age 57 after a long and courageous struggle with emphysema. Son of Florene and the late John U. Kanto, John was born in Carlsbad, NM in 1944. In 1967, after attending Texas Western University in El Paso, John came to New York and joined Citibank as a Teller. He rose steadily through the ranks at Citibank until his retirement in 1992 when he was a Vice President and Chief of Staff to the Chief Auditor of Citicorp worldwide. John was a volunteer in numerous organizations, including the Community Health Project and the AIDS Memorial at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. He was preceded in death by his good friend Jim Zitlow and his companion Jonathan Sand. He leaves his mother and many friends with memories of his generous spirit and quick wit. Contributions in John's name may be made to the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, the ACLU Lesbian and Gay Rights Project or St Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. A Memorial Service to celebrate John's life will be held in St. Luke's Chapel in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Ave at W. 110 St., on Saturday, February 16, at 1 PM.

title: Deals That Helped Doom Enron Began to Form in the Early 90's
description: The financial dealings that played a central role in Enron's collapse were begun a decade ago, court records show, by a newly hired financial whiz kid in part to keep debt off the company's books so it could grow unimpeded.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: More Corporate Restructuring
description: In a sign that the restructuring of corporate Germany is gathering speed, Munich Re disclosed that it had doubled its stake in Commerzbank and said it was looking to find the bank a new partner. Munich Re increased its stake in Commerzbank from 5 to 10 percent, and it said it wanted to secure its interest in the consolidation of Germany's banking industry. Commerzbank has been struggling with low profits and has been under pressure from investors to merge with a larger institution. Its shares surged 11 percent at one point because of expectations that Munich Re wanted to marry off Commerzbank. Munich Re, the world's biggest reinsurer, owns 25 percent of Germany's second-largest bank, Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank. Under a law that took effect Jan. 1, companies can sell their stakes in other enterprises without having to pay capital-gains taxes. Munich Re is one of several large German financial institutions that are eager to sell holdings that they acquired decades ago and are now worth billions of dollars. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: A.I.G. Quits Talks on Buying Korean Firms
description: The American International Group confirmed yesterday that it had ended talks to be among the investors in three financial firms owned by the Hyundai Group of South Korea after failing to reach an accord with the Korean government.

title: The Chip On China's Shoulder
description: As soon as the two planes hit the World Trade Center, Chinese Internet users logged into online chat rooms to discuss the terror attacks.

title: Hopping Rides With a Range of Extremists
description: THEM

title: Plan to Split Up Antitrust Oversight Stalls
description: A plan by the Bush administration to overhaul antitrust reviews and give the Justice Department responsibility for oversight of all mergers involving communications, entertainment and software companies was at least temporarily scuttled today after protests from Capitol Hill.

title: Defamation Suit Filed
description: The attorney for Rusty Smith, a short-track speed skater on the United States Olympic team, filed a defamation lawsuit against Tommy O'Hare in Colorado Springs yesterday, in response to O'Hare's claim that Smith and Apolo Ohno conspired to fix the results of a race at the trials on Dec. 22.

title: A Chilling Effect on the Great Global Melt
description: One of the biggest predicted impacts of global warming is a rise in sea level as ice on land melts. And nowhere is there more terrestrial ice than in Antarctica. If the vast West Antarctic Ice Sheet were to slide into the sea, it would raise oceans more than 13 feet.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett May Sell French Factory
description: Hewlett-Packard said yesterday that it was close to completing a deal to sell a computer-making factory in France to the contract manufacturing company Sanmina-SCI. Financial terms were not disclosed. As part of the proposal, Sanmina would make computers for Hewlett-Packard at the factory in l'Isle d'Abeau, which produces two-thirds of Hewlett's personal computers, notebooks and low-end data-serving computers for European corporate customers. Hewlett has increased outsourcing to cut costs. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Progress In Colombia: New Talks About Talks
description: After they resolved a crisis that brought Colombia to the brink of war, it might seem that the government and a powerful rebel group ended up exactly where they started: talking about how to start real talks.

title: Best Restraints Are Those That Move in a Crash
description: THE most sophisticated head restraints are called ''active'' because they move up and close to the back of the head after a rear impact.

title: Contractors at Ground Zero Denied Insurance for Cleanup
description: By everyone's account, the contracting companies excavating the tons of broken steel and smoking debris at ground zero have worked with energy and devotion. But there is one thing they have worked without -- insurance.

title: Philippines Said to Have Refused Bush Offer of G.I.'s in November
description: As American military advisers traveled to meet Philippine Army units that are battling Muslim guerrillas on a southern island, a senior Philippines official said here today that President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo rejected an offer from President Bush in November to send American combat troops to join directly in the fighting.

title: Commissioner Says Officers Appear Justified in Fatal Shooting
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that a preliminary investigation indicated that an officer and a sergeant were justified when they fatally shot an apparently deranged man who confronted them and refused to drop a carving knife and a stick.

title: National Briefing | Labor: Roll Of Union Workers Is Steady
description: The number of American workers belonging to unions remained unchanged last year, at 16.3 million, as did the unionized share of the work force, at 13.5 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said. The agency said 37 percent of government employees were union members, compared with 9 percent of workers in the private sector.

title: Out of the Vociferous Planet and in the Orbit of Funk and Hip-Hop
description: When the interplay between rap music, hip-hop culture and contemporary art gets the exhibition it deserves, it will probably be a show that picks up where the Bronx Museum of the Arts' ''One Planet Under a Groove: Hip-Hop and Contemporary Art'' leaves off.

description: NEW YORK

description: Jack Shainman

title: A Bird That's on a Lot of Hit Lists
description: Rob Burger wants to stomp the eggs under his feet. Brian Harrison would like to round up 300 hunters and pump shotgun shells into the nests. Mark Clymer is ready to bypass the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and call in the Department of Defense.

title: Coal Town's Hopes Clouded by Killings Of 3 at Law School
description: Townspeople looked on in shock and grief this morning as the failed law student known on campus as Peter O. was led into the Buchanan County courtroom, shuffling in chains and hiding his face from television cameras, to face murder charges in the bloodiest shooting this remote Appalachian coal town has ever suffered.

title: At Ralph Lauren, Scruffy Isn't Cool : Old England Class, But American Ease
description: MILAN  After a decade of dressing down, casual Fridays, sloppy sportswear and designer stubble, men's fashion has returned to an old ideal: aspirational attire. Looking scruffy in no longer an essential element of cool.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: A Bid For An Auction House
description: BarclaysPrivate Equity offered to acquire the venerable French auction house Drouot and its weekly magazine, La Gazette. It was seeking to thwart an offer made earlier this month by Pierre Berg, at left, the business partner and companion of Yves Saint Laurent, himself an avid collector. Drouot became a hot property under a French monopoly that formerly required all French auctioneers to sell through its 110 shareholders, who are also its auctioneers. They hold about 2,000 auctions a year out of a busy building on the Rue Drouot. But removal of the monopoly last year opened the French market to major international competitors, notably Christie's and Sotheby's, prompting Mr. Berg to offer 122 million euros, or $108 million, to buy out the Drouot shareholders. Barclays says it seeks to be a passive but long-term investor and wants to forge a partnership with Drouot's shareholder-auctioneers. It says many of them want to continue in the business and are eager to preserve their independence. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Red Cross Team Will Examine Prisoners From Afghanistan
description: Four representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross arrived here today to determine whether the United States is mistreating prisoners from Afghanistan as international human rights groups have contended.

title: Police Identify Student Wanted in School Shooting
description: Investigators yesterday identified the teenager who they believe wounded two students at Martin Luther King Jr. High School on Tuesday as Vincent Rodriguez, a fellow student. It is believed he shot them because the victims had harassed his girlfriend, officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Economic Growth Slows
description: German economic growth last year was the slowest since the recession of 1993, and economists predict that this year will be no better. According to the German Federal Statistics Office, the gross domestic product grew by 0.6 percent in 2001, which is probably the lowest rate in the European Union and increases the chances that Germany's budget deficit will exceed the limits set for countries in the euro zone. Economists also expect the unemployment rate to rise above four million. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: In Shattered Kabul, Powell Vows Long-Term Support for Afghans
description: In a whirlwind visit to this war-ravaged capital, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell announced today that the United States had restored its crumbling, long-shuttered embassy to full diplomatic status, and he assured Afghanistan's interim leader, ''We will be with you in this current crisis and for the future.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kohl Talks Of Wife's Suicide
description: Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl, 71, said in a television interview that he had discussed the question of suicide with his wife, Hannelore, before she took her life last year. They were married 41 years. Mrs. Kohl had a rare illness caused by an allergic reaction to penicillin in 1993. After that, she had been increasingly sensitive to light. ''Her quality of life was steadily deteriorating,'' Mr. Kohl said. ''You can't picture this unless you've lived through it, what life is like for someone who can no longer see daylight or the sun.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip-Plant Deal Near
description: Negotiators from Micron Technology are on track in talks with Hynix Semiconductor for Micron to take over all or some of its memory-chip factories, according to Lee Duk Hoon, president of the government-controlled Hanvit Bank, one of the Korean company's leading creditors. He said he expected Micron and Hynix to sign a memorandum of understanding in the near future as a prelude to a final agreement. Micron is reported to be willing to pay only $2 billion, however, for the seven Hynix plants that produce memory chips. Hynix, burdened with liabilities of approximately $8 billion, had hoped to get considerably more from Micron, which surpassed it last year as the world's second-largest manufacturer of memory chips after Samsung Electronics. Micron's estimate of the value of the Hynix plants was in line with the $300 million that it agreed to pay for a Toshiba semiconductor plant in Virginia. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Dance; Worlds of Ballet, Seen From the Inside
description: Certainly one of the films to single out this weekend in the annual Dance on Camera Festival at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center is ''Dancer,'' a rambunctious and dramatically insightful portrait of Nikolaj Hbbe, the Danish dancer who has been a principal with the New York City Ballet since 1992.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the restoration of the Winter Garden, the World Financial Center atrium damaged in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, misstated the name of the Arizona desert that was the source of 16 Washingtonia robusta palm trees there. It is the Sonoran Desert, not Sonoma.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Pastrana Urges Steps To Peace
description: President Andrs Pastrana warned Colombian rebels to ''make progress'' in setting up a timetable for talks about a cease-fire. ''Negotiating in the middle of the conflict has finished,'' he said, ''and we need progress quickly.'' Mr. Pastrana has until Sunday to decide whether to renew the rebel hold on a huge demilitarized zone ceded to them by the government three years ago. Mr. Pastrana's words came three days after he and the rebels agreed to talk about a cease-fire, a deal that came after five days of tense negotiations aimed at patching up stalled efforts toward peace. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Wireless Components Merger
description: Two makers of wireless networking products, Proxim Inc. and the Western Multiplex Corporation, said yesterday that they would combine in a merger of equals. The deal would create a company with about $222 million in annual sales. Under the deal, each of Proxim's 27.6 million shares outstanding would be converted to 1.89 shares of Western Multiplex common stock, valuing Proxim at $7.94 a share based on the close Wednesday, before the agreement was announced. That was less than Proxim's close of $8.72 on Wednesday, and its shares tumbled $1.97 yesterday, to $6.75. Shares of Western Multiplex slid $1.13 yesterday, to $3.07. At yesterday's price, the deal was valued at about $160 million. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Families of Victims Rally for Higher Federal Awards
description: In the first major rally held to protest the proposed rules for compensating relatives of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, more than 500 relatives crowded into the Park Avenue Armory last night to show their support for more generous compensation.

title: Yankees Sign Enrique Wilson
description: The Yankees signed the infielder Enrique Wilson to a one-year contract yesterday, avoiding a salary arbitration hearing. Wilson played third base, shortstop and second base for the Yankees last season, hitting .242 in 48 games after being acquired from Pittsburgh.

title: A Solo Influence in Group Works
description: There were times when watching Molissa Fenley and Dancers on Wednesday night was like watching passing clouds. Dancers often crossed the stage of the Joyce Theater while their arms and upper bodies twisted into choreographic shapes that kept melting away, just as clouds melt in the air.

title: For Auction Online: Enron's Memos
description: A former Enron employee was selling a 64-page cache of internal Enron Corporation memorandums on eBay today.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Some Headway on Head Restraints
description: WHIPLASH may still be a punchline in comedy routines, portrayed as an insignificant injury and a means of perpetrating insurance fraud, but automakers are finally taking it seriously. After decades of turning out head restraints that experts criticized as ineffective, manufacturers are designing a new wave of restraints that should help to prevent painful neck injuries.

title: Judge's English-Only Directive Rescinded by Paterson Mayor
description: The judge laid it out in plain English: Courthouse workers could not speak any other language but English while at their desks. But the edict lasted only two days.

We celebrate Anne's many achievements as an artist and will treasure the memory of her friendship and support. Ann L. Gund, Chair Judson P. Reis, President Skowhegan School of Painting & Sculpture

title: A Repertory of Pratfalls And Animals That Wink
description: In ''Snowdogs,'' Disney's latest update of the lame live-action B comedies that have been among the studio's more dubious contributions to American pop culture, the irrepressible Cuba Gooding Jr. plays Theodore Brooks, a Miami dentist who travels to a remote town in Alaska. Once there, he slips on the ice, falls in the snow, slips on the ice a few more times, is pursued by a bear, falls in the snow and is dragged behind a dog sled. Then, if I recall correctly, he slips on the ice.

title: CABLE AND WIRELESS WINS COURT APPROVAL TO BUY EXODUS
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. won a judge's approval yesterday to pay $560 million and assume $116 million in debt for the assets of Exodus Communications, a Web site services provider. Cable and Wireless, a provider of phone and Internet services, was the only bidder at a Jan. 11 auction for Exodus, which filed for bankruptcy last year. The purchase will make Cable and Wireless and its Digital Island unit the largest manager of Web sites for businesses in the United States. Cable and Wireless is based in London; Exodus is based in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Baby-Rape Charges Dropped
description: Prosecutors withdrew charges against six men accused of raping a baby girl, saying they had insufficient evidence against the men. The police had said earlier that they believed only one of the men was responsible for the attack on the infant. Investigators, who feared outraged citizens might try to beat or kill the men, promised to continue searching for the baby's attackers. The baby was less than a year old when she was raped.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Wildwood: Fire At Amusement Ride
description: Two teenage boys have been arrested in connection with a fire on the boardwalk that burned a haunted house and boat ride on Wednesday, officials said. No injuries were reported in the fire, which razed the four-story Castle Dracula, a 20-year-old building on Nickels Midway Pier and one of the largest attractions on the boardwalk. Detective Sgt. Kevin McLaughlan of Wildwood said officers arrived on the scene and arrested the boys, ages 15 and 16, both of Wildwood Crest, who were seen fleeing the building. The boys, whose names were not released, are being held on arson, burglary and criminal mischief charges.

title: In Experiment, Mammal Cells Produce Silk Like a Spider's
description: In an experiment that could lead to mass production of strong, lightweight silk, scientists at a Canadian biotechnology company and a United States Army research center have spliced spider genes into cells from cows and hamsters and induced the cells to churn out silk. The silk, grown in tissue cultures, has been spun into threads that are comparable to those produced by spiders.

description: Gov. George E. Pataki won an important victory today in his constitutional battle with the Legislature when a State Supreme Court justice ruled that he, not lawmakers, had the authority to alter the language in spending bills.

title: Editorial Observer; Yonkers Shows How Not to Desegregate a School District
description: Brown v. Board of Education was eight years old when I entered fifth grade in September 1962, at an all-black elementary school in Chester, Pa., a deeply segregated city just south of Philadelphia. I was summoned to the principal's office on the first day of school, given my records wrapped in rubber bands and told that I was being transferred to another school whose name I had never heard.

description: The aviation security bill passed by Congress in response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks set today as an interim deadline for all checked luggage to be scrutinized, by one method or another. This week Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta pronounced the government and the airlines ready to do so. That will make flying safer, but not safe enough.

title: Thousands Flee From Volcano Erupting in Congo
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 18  Tens of thousands of refugees poured across Congo's eastern border into Rwanda today, fleeing a vicious volcano outside Goma that spewed torrents of burning lava through the town.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Top Official Stepping Down
description: The state treasurer, Richard N. Dixon, announced that he would resign on Feb. 1 because diabetes had caused him deteriorating health, including blindness in one eye. Mr. Dixon, a 63-year-old Democrat, is the most powerful black official in Maryland, a result of his membership on the Board of Public Works, which approves major state purchases, projects, contracts and financing of local schools. He has often cast the board's deciding vote, because of feuding by its two other members, Gov. Parris N. Glendening and Comptroller William Donald Schaefer. The legislature will pick Mr. Dixon's successor. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: When Personal Conflicts Mix With Regional Ones
description: One of the catalytic forces in ''Time of Favor,'' Joseph Cedar's tricky thriller about political tensions in contemporary Israel, is Rabbi Meltzer (Assi Dayan), a charismatic teacher who quotes Maimonides on the subject of martyrdom for one's beliefs: a dead lion, he preaches, can be more alive than a living dog. Those are fighting words that can easily be taken the wrong way. ''Time of Favor'' is about the near-catastrophe that ensues when Pini (Edan Alterman), a young soldier who is the star pupil in the rabbi's yeshiva, takes his teacher's words too literally and plans a terrorist attack to blow up the Dome of the Rock, the ancient Islamic monument, in the heart of Jerusalem.

title: Astacio's Health Is a Key To the Mets
description: Bobby Valentine reached to his side and squeezed the right arm of the man sitting next to him. Pedro Astacio smiled and the two shared a laugh. Astacio was being introduced at Shea Stadium as the Mets' newest starting pitcher, and while Valentine's gesture was playful, it hinted at a worrisome issue for the Mets.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Unisys Loss Meets Expectations
description: Unisys, a provider of business computers and related services, reported a fourth-quarter loss yesterday, citing a drop in sales and expenses related to job cuts. Unisys said that its quarterly loss was $169.4 million, or 53 cents a share, compared with net income of $39.1 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier. The results met analysts' estimates. Lawrence A. Weinbach, above, the chief executive of Unisys, predicted a gradual turnaround this year. ''We have seen encouraging signs of stabilization in our U.S business,'' he told analysts during a conference call. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: I.B.M. reported yesterday that its sales and profits declined in the fourth quarter of last year, but the financial results once again reflected the comparative resilience of I.B.M. at a time of economic weakness and a severe slump in technology markets.

title: New Evidence Paved Way For Arrests in a '75 Killing
description: It was a brazen, tightly organized attack. A gang of men and women wearing ski masks burst into a bank in Carmichael, Calif., on an April afternoon in 1975, killed a female customer and escaped in a series of getaway cars with $15,390. But the police found virtually no evidence and had no idea that it was the work of the radical Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: A Kafkaesque Bureaucracy (Literally)
description: Those who feel that this winter has not been sufficiently winterlike might benefit from a trip to the Manhattan Ensemble Theater, where ''The Castle,'' Franz Kafka's odd story of befuddling bureaucracy, is being staged with icy precision. Just looking at Anna Louizos's vivid set, a clear cube on a frigid landscape, chills the bones.

description: Responding to growing criticism of accounting practices stemming from the collapse of the Enron Corporation, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today that the accounting industry should be policed by a group dominated by outside experts instead of policing itself.

She was a fun-loving person and her laughter will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 19, at the Church of Sweden, 5 E. 48 St., 4PM. We miss you, Lillebi.

title: Camilo Jos Cela, Spanish Writer and Nobelist, Dies at 85
description: Camilo Jos Cela, winner of the 1989 Nobel Prize in Literature who was as well known in his native Spain for his sardonic humor and irascible personality as he was for his writing, died today at a Madrid hospital. He was 85.

title: Hedge Funds Sue Auditor and Underwriters Over Bond Losses
description: Four hedge funds that lost more than $120 million on Enron bonds sued Arthur Andersen, the company's auditor, and several underwriters, asserting that they ignored evidence of Enron's crumbling finances.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Second Runway For Narita Airport
description: The Transport Ministry approved the use of a second runway at the international airport at Narita outside Tokyo, ending a three-decade fight to expand the facility. The airport, which handles more than half of the international flights in and out of Japan, has just one runway, 13,000 feet long, and it can accommodate 370 flights a day. Local residents prevented the government from adding other runways and helped make Narita the world's most expensive airport. The second, shorter runway will handle 176 additional flights and open on April 18, in time for the World Cup games to be held here in May and June. Patrick J. Lyons (NYT)

title: XEROX RAISES $746 MILLION IN PRIVATE DEBT OFFERING
description: The Xerox Corporation raised $746 million, more than it expected, in a private debt offering after a pending investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission barred a public debt issue. The bond sale, issued in dollars and euros, raises the company's cash position to about $4.6 billion from $3.9 billion in December, Xerox said. The 9.75 percent coupon notes, a record yield for the company, are due in 2009 and will be used to repay debt. Xerox expected to raise about $500 million. Xerox, which has lost money in four of the last five quarters, has about $2 billion of its public debt coming due this year and is in the midst of raising cash and cutting costs. Xerox shares were unchanged at $9.80.

title: In Polish Trip, Putin Talks Of More Trade And New Ties
description: Russia and Poland vowed today to let renewed trade and pragmatism warm the frost off their troubled past as President Vladimir V. Putin ended a two-day trip here -- the first by a Russian leader since 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNN, MARVIN S.
description: LYNN-Marvin S. Age 73, of Great Neck, NY died peacefully in his home on Wednesday, January 16, 2002. After 50 years of marriage, he remains adored by his wife Nancy; beloved father of Amy Freed & Richard Lynn; treasured grandfather of Janelle & Hope Lynn and Julia & Gregory Lynn; dear brother of Renee Secof. He will always be remembered for his devotion to his family. Services will be held at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck on Friday, January 18th at 11:00 AM.

title: Verizon in Vermont Bid
description: Verizon Communications asked federal regulators today to let it sell long-distance service in Vermont, a market valued at $200 million annually. Verizon, based in New York, said it had opened its local telephone network to rivals in the state as required by law. The Federal Communications Commission has 90 days to decide whether Verizon has met the conditions in Vermont.

title: The Big City; Blame Game Has Two Sets Of Standards
description: WHEN bad things happen to bad companies, Washington likes to believe that it's hearing a cry for help from Wall Street. Now that Enron has collapsed, politicians are frantically investigating and vowing to protect us against greedy corporate executives.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: White Librarians Win Verdict
description: A jury in a federal court awarded $25 million to eight white Fulton County librarians who contended that they were victims of racial discrimination. The librarians, transferred to outlying branches from desirable assignments at the central library in downtown Atlanta, said the reason was that county officials wanted more black librarians downtown. The library argued that the moves had been part of a wide-ranging reorganization that had nothing to do with race, but the jury, whose six members included no blacks, found that race had been the deciding factor. County officials said they would appeal.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PC Sales Fell In 2001
description: In spite of unexpectedly strong personal computers purchases during the holidays, the worldwide and American PC markets declined in 2001 for only the second time, according to two market researchers. Gartner Dataquest said computer vendors sold 128 million PC's worldwide last year, a 4.6 percent decline from 2000, and 44 million units in the United States, an 11.1 percent drop, because of the poor economy and a saturated market. In the fourth quarter, PC shipments fell 6.7 percent from the period in 2000, but rose 16.9 percent from the dreary third quarter, according to the International Data Corporation. Businesses continued to delay computer upgrades, but improving confidence in the economy and price cuts prompted consumers to buy more PC's than anticipated last quarter. Unit sales declined by double digits last year for every PC vendor expect Dell Computer, whose sales rose 18.3 percent, enabling it to take over the worldwide lead from Compaq Computer early in 2001. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 3,113 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as the result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: The Fate Of Qaeda Prisoners
description: Even as representatives of the International Red Cross go to work in Guantnamo Bay, interviewing Taliban and Qaeda prisoners and inspecting their cage-like cells, many Americans seem to find this concern for the prisoners hard to understand. After all, some of these men may well be responsible, directly or not, for the horror of Sept. 11 and for terrible crimes during Taliban rule. So what if they are subjected to some discomfort, particularly in light of the observation by Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, that some of them ''would gnaw hydraulic lines in the back of a C-17 to bring it down''? Why should anyone care?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Stocks Surge
description: A surge in orders by foreign investors helped send the Philippines' benchmark stock index up 3.6 percent to its highest level since Sept. 11. News that the central bank had cut interest rates to their lowest level in six years, together with hopes that United States military assistance would help end the country's long-running Muslim rebellion, helped buoy sentiment. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Isles Get an A for Effort But an L in the Standings

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Bid To End Hunger Strike
description: In an effort to end a hunger strike that has claimed 46 lives, the justice minister said inmates in new high-security prisons would be permitted to socialize in small groups for five hours a week if they took part in organized recreational activities. Hundreds of prisoners and supporters have been starving themselves to protest new prisons in which small cells for one to three inmates replaced large ward-style accommodations; they say prisoners in smaller cells are more vulnerable to abuse by guards. Human rights advocates said the proposal by Justice Minister Hikmet Sami Turk was unlikely to affect the strike because inmates had already refused to join recreational activities.

title: HEWLETT SAYS DIRECTOR IS MISLEADING ON DEAL
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company accused a director, Walter Hewlett, of misleading investors on the purchase of the Compaq Computer Corporation, saying that he is a ''musician and academic'' who never worked at the company and that the other board members support the proposed deal. ''We strongly object to his flawed presentation of the merger, which misleads rather than informs shareowners,'' Hewlett-Packard's eight other directors said in a letter to shareholders. They said the purchase offered the best way to increase share value. Walter Hewlett, son of the co-founder William Hewlett, urged shareholders to reject the proposed $24.5 billion purchase in a letter this week. Mr. Hewlett, who is leading a proxy fight against the transaction, called it a ''backward-looking strategy'' with ''substantial'' risk for the company, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif. Analysts and other investors have criticized the deal, so Walter Hewlett is not alone in his opposition, a spokeswoman for him, Joele Frank, said. His arguments are ''resonating with shareholders, forcing the company to resort to personal attacks,'' she said.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Child Abuse Charges For Church Members

Last year, the state took 49 children of church members into protective custody, and has since returned all but 8, who may be put up for adoption. Mr. Allen has said that parents have the right to discipline their children. He and the others face up to 20 years in prison.

The purchase will require permission from the bankruptcy court handling Big V's Chapter 11 bankruptcy case and from antitrust regulators, an Ahold spokesman, Hans Gobes, said. title: REGULATORY AGENCY PROPOSES $6 MILLION FINE FOR SBC
description: The Federal Communications Commission proposed fining SBC Communications Inc. $6 million yesterday, accusing it of failing to offer rivals fair terms for access to part of its network in five states. The fine is the largest ever proposed by the agency. In approving SBC's 1999 purchase of the Ameritech Corporation, the F.C.C. required the telephone carrier to offer competitors terms similar to those offered in Texas when transporting certain local toll traffic to SBC central offices. The commission found that SBC appeared to have violated that condition in each of the five former Ameritech states: Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, the F.C.C. said. SBC denied wrongdoing.

''It was so silly. Why didn't he just say Ken Lay was a strong supporter and gave him a half-million dollars and is a good friend, and he's really sorry Ken's in these terrible circumstances?''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Pope To Visit Mexico
description: A Vatican spokesman said Pope John Paul II would visit Mexico this summer to canonize Juan Diego, an Aztec Indian who reported seeing the Virgin Mary in Guadalupe, near Mexico City, in 1531. The pope will travel to Mexico after celebrating Mass at World Youth Day in Toronto in July. But the spokesman said there had been no discussion of a papal stopover in New York to visit ground zero, where the World Trade Center stood, as has been widely reported in the Italian press. The pope, who will be 82 in May and suffers from Parkinson's disease, also plans to visit Bulgaria in late May. Melinda Henneberger (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Desegregation Settlement
description: State lawmakers overwhelmingly ratified a $503 million settlement of the state's 27-year-old college desegregation lawsuit, clearing the way for final approval by the courts. Judge Neal B. Biggers Jr. of Federal District Court, who expressed concern that the settlement would do little to actually desegregate the state's three historically black universities, said he would approve it only if the Legislature endorsed it. The state's political and university leadership argue that the 17-year plan will upgrade long-neglected campuses.

title: SCIENCE ACADEMY SUPPORTS CLONING TO TREAT DISEASE
description: The creation of human clones, babies that are genetic replicas of adults, is unsafe and should be outlawed, a panel of scientific experts said today. But citing the promise of research, it said that scientists should be permitted to clone embryos to treat disease.

title: Another Top 100 List: This Time, Intellectuals
description: Things are not looking good for Isaac Rosenfeld. As a piece of intellectual property, Rosenfeld, one of the smaller lights of modern Jewish literature and cultural criticism, has always tended to fluctuate in value from footnote to fat paragraph. But investors holding large quantities of Rosenfeld stock may want to unload. As table 5.1 in Richard A. Posner's ''Public Intellectuals: A Study of Decline'' (Harvard University Press, 2001) shows, Rosenfeld's name turns up only 89 times when entered on Google, a popular Internet search engine. A search of the Lexis-Nexis database, which covers journals and newspapers, elicits a mere eight mentions.

title: Corrections

title: Moseley and Weinbrecht Try to Recapture Freestyle Glory
description: Jonny Moseley and Donna Weinbrecht are America's king and queen of mogul skiing, the only mogul skiers from the United States to have won Olympic gold medals. Weinbrecht's reign, however figurative it may be 10 years after her groundbreaking Olympic victory, could be down to its final days. A run or two down the mountain Saturday will either be the end of a precedent-setting career or the beginning of a miraculous comeback.

title: The Donor's Right to Take a Risk
description: Mike Hurewitz, a 57-year-old journalist, died at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan on Sunday after an operation to remove part of his liver for transplant. The recipient, his younger brother, is apparently doing well. The procedure of liver-lobe transplantation, hardly more than a decade old, can save lives, but it can also lead to disaster. The case of the Hurewitz brothers illustrates both. The risk of death for a donor may be as high as 1 in 100. Yet even when the magic works, when donor and recipient survive, the procedure raises troubling questions. The death of Mike Hurewitz gives those questions a sharper edge.

title: 'John Maynard Keynes'
description: Dominating the upper part of the vale of the Clwyd, in north-eastern Wales, is the ruin of Ruthin Castle. It stands on a rock 270 feet above sea level. Nestling under its walls on their northern slope is the ancient town of Ruthin. Rhudd-ddin means Red Fortress in Welsh, and it was so called because it was built from the red sandstone on which it stood. The original castle was founded by Edward I in 1281 as a royal base, part of a chain of forts built to garrison the country he had just conquered in a brutal war. The outer walls, fortified by seven great towers, enclosed an area of about a hundred acres, including the castle proper, a chapel and a well a hundred feet deep. It was at Ruthin that the Welsh patriot Owen Glendower raised the standard of revolt against Henry IV in 1400, plundering the English who had come [to the fair] with their goods, slaying many of them, sacking the town and concluding his day's work by firing it. In the Civil War the Castle was held for the King by Colonel Marcus Trevor, who surrendered it to Parliament after a two months siege on 12 April 1646. General Thomas Mytton wrote to Parliament: The reducing of the Castle of Ruthin has cost me more time and ammunition than I expected .... It was then demolished. From the Myddletons who owned it, the property came, by marriage, into the hands of the West family, which, in the mid-nineteenth century, built a strange three-storeyed, red-sandstone, castellated edifice on the edge of the old ruins. Colonel William Cornwallis West entertained the Prince of Wales there in 1899; a year later his son George (aged twenty-six) married another of his house guests on that occasion, the widowed Lady Randolph Churchill, Winston Churchill's mother (aged forty-six). The Colonel started selling off the Ruthin Castle estate in 1919. Today it is a luxury hotel.

The owners, Oliver Pihlar and Peter Kane, kept the pink awning that reads ''Yie He Health Club,'' and patrons can watch an original surveillance video of the private rooms downstairs that was edited and looped by Noah Klersfeld, an artist. The bar's designers, Girth, of Brooklyn, styled the main lounge, above, after 1950's Las Vegas, with red velvet banquettes and walnut paneling. Downstairs, they converted the sauna rooms into hangout nooks illuminated with red lights. The hot tub area now houses group seating and a D.J. booth. But the waist-high shower decorated with the image of a rapturous woman riding a swan is still there. Anthony Bernard, a 24-year-old model, who was lounging in one of the ex-saunas with two women said, ''It's very 2002 to be able to go out and feel illicit thrills without actually engaging in any.'' title: 'The Caprices'

The packed dirt could cover any country road, and the dust that rises in billowing sheets, lifted by the lazy hands of the dry season, could menace any provincial town. It is three o'clock in the afternoon, but no children wander back from school. The Chinese shopkeeper's door has been shut for nearly a year, but no matter, since the children will not bother him for moon cakes, sweet wafers, and candied tamarind. A kalesa driver sits idly by his cart; his horse, unperturbed by the state of affairs, dozes behind blinkers, flicking rhythmically with his tail, one rear hoof casually cocked to bear no weight. In response to a fly, the horse shakes his head, jangling gear and whipping his mane from side to side. The fly rises up, buzzing at a higher pitch.

title: From a Fiery Conga Player, Jazz's Latin Tinge
description: IT is a truism that the African elements in jazz's rhythmic language are often delivered with a Hispanic accent. In New Orleans, regarded by many as the northernmost outpost of the Caribbean, as well as in Cuba, slaves and former slaves from West Africa maintained their percussion traditions, mixing ritual drumming with other elements from Spanish music. What Jelly Roll Morton called the ''Spanish tinge'' -- a rumba-flavored pattern of rhythmic accenting -- has been an important part of jazz since long before his own 1923 piano recordings of ''The Crave'' and ''New Orleans Joys.'' And, for decades following, recordings like Louis Armstrong's ''Peanut Vendor'' and Duke Ellington's Latin specialties like ''The Flaming Sword'' and ''Conga Brava'' have restated the centrality of those elements.

title: Sending the Bags Packing
description: Travelers eager to avoid -- long waits at airports caused by heightened security are lightening their load and sending their luggage ahead. Tino Merli, the chief concierge at the Plaza Hotel in New York, says the number of hotel guests sending and receiving luggage by Federal Express, U.P.S. and similar services has skyrocketed. ''Just the other day, two women traveling back to Mexico shipped a tower of suitcases home,'' he said. He said that not long ago it was only the rich who shipped their luggage. But now shipping luggage is becoming more commonplace. ''We think this trend is only going to increase,'' he said. That seems a safe bet, now that under a law that went into effect Friday, the nation's airlines will have to do some form of screening for all checked baggage. Jennifer McGowan, a spokeswoman for Federal Express, said the cost of shipping bags can be easily calculated at its Web site, www.fedex.com: just plug in weight, dimensions and ZIP code. For instance: If you are leaving New York City and heading to Aspen, Colo., and you want to ship a 30-pound suitcase along with your skis, it will cost about $100 for overnight service, or just $50 for the five-day option. Not bad if it means cutting the line at the airport.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; In Destiny's Choir
description: Alexander Chee's haunting first novel, EDINBURGH (Welcome Rain, $25), introduces us to Fee, a 12-year-old Korean-American boy who discovers his homosexuality not long before the director of the professional boys' choir he belongs to begins molesting him and several other boys. Although the director is imprisoned, his victims are never the same: Peter, whom Fee loves, dies after setting himself on fire; Fee's friend Zach shoots himself; Fee himself attempts suicide, does too many drugs and has random, dispiriting sex. Chee's tone never slips into bathos -- not even when, years later, Fee moves back near his hometown with his lover to teach. Among his students is the choir director's son, Warden, who doesn't know his father's history and bears a startling resemblance to Peter. The complex plot strands come together when Warden develops a crush on Fee -- and ultimately discovers Fee's connection to his father -- forcing both of them to face an ugly past. Chee skillfully interweaves his story with scientific imagery, Korean mythology and spirituality, and Western literary allusions. If his metaphors occasionally seem more sophisticated than his teenage narrators, it's forgivable because they're generally so evocative: ''Sometimes the scattered thoughts of their deaths run like a jagged red seam of fire inside me,'' explains Fee of Peter and Zach, ''and I burn from the inside out, like a lightning-struck tree: the outside whole, the inside, that carried the lightning's charge, a coal.'' Chee frequently says volumes with just a few incendiary words. Ann Abel

title: A Venerable Berlin Museum Reopens

Inaugurated in 1876 by Kaiser Wilhelm I, the towering neo-Classical building, on Museum Island in the Spree River in the former East German sector, was damaged during World War II and suffered from subsequent years of neglect. Plans call for the other four museums on the island to be renovated over the next decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE SAINT PHALLE, PIERRE
description: de SAINT PHALLE-Pierre, 84. A retired textile executive and highly decorated veteran of World War II, died Monday at his home in Wyndmoor, PA. Mr. de Saint Phalle, a captain in the Army Signal Corps, was awarded the Bronze Star for heroic or meritorious achievement. He earned the medal by hiding in a water tower for days intercepting German radio transmissions during the seige of Anzio. Mr. de Saint Phalle proudly told the story of his responsibility to deliver a decoded message he received from then President Franklin Roosevelt to alert General Eisenhower of his promotion to Allied Commander. General Eisenhower exclaimed to Mr. de Saint Phalle ''Well it's about time!''. Mr. de Saint Phalle grew up in Philadelphia and graduated from the William Penn Charter School in 1936. He earned a Bachelor's Degree from Yale University in 1940. For more than 50 years, he worked as a Textile Industry Executive in Philadelphia and New York. He enjoyed golf, bridge and watching football. He often reminisced of fond childhood memories spent in France. Mr. de Saint Phalle is survived by his wife of 56 years, Virginia, children Francois of New York City, Phillipe of Boston, MA, Jacques of Rye, NY, Sat Siri Khalsa of Sante Fe, NM and Alexandra of Springfield, IL, three sisters; and 11 grandchildren. Private services will be held Monday at St. Martin in the Fields Episcopal Church in Philadelphia.

title: On Writers And Writing; Harry Potter for Grown-Ups
description: BY the third Harry Potter book, I was in just the state two young readers had predicted. Until then I'd been having such a good time with cosmic crises, games, all those vehement school friendships and rivalries, and the efficient way children move between compliance and well-planned anarchy. The magic is literal in these books, like those old tales where children stowed away on ships or ran off to the circus; it's also as quick and exact as a video game. The values -- courage, independence, camaraderie -- are honorable. J. K. Rowling can plot as well as any thriller or television drama writer. And she knows how to use social realism too; think of Hermione trying to unionize the house elves, or being an overachiever partly because her undistinguished background (nonwizard parents) makes her the equivalent of a lowly scholarship student.

title: Lower Manhattan Journal; A Downtown Cobbler Gets Back on His Insoles

Well, O.K., there really is no such saying, but it is a truism that has served Salvatore Iacono well during the 35 years he has mended, stitched and shined the shoes of Lower Manhattan's shuffling masses. The son of a Sicilian shoemaker, Mr. Iacono, 67, has done well on Barclay Street, where he tends tattered soles with the zeal of a charismatic preacher. ''If it looks, smells or feels like leather, I can fix it,'' said Mr. Iacono, cradling a broken heel as if it were a wounded sparrow.

title: Communing in Darkness With an Ancient Forerunner

''The Shadow of Night'' -- which the Cleveland Orchestra and Christoph von Dohnanyi commissioned, played for the first time last weekend and will bring to Carnegie Hall on Friday -- is like all its predecessors: something strikingly new but heavy with echoes from the past and, indeed, the future. This is music made to speak now, authoritatively, and (like little else in our time) made to last.
