title: N.J. VINES/Ringoes; A Riesling With a Smidgen of Sweetness
description: The Windfall Riesling from Unionville Vineyards never disappoints. The 2000 edition, like such predecessors as the 1994 and 1998, resembles a German riesling from the Mosel: light, piquant, charming. Drunk ice cold, as too many whites are, this riesling shows little. Drunk cool, the peaches-and-apricots bouquet gives way to a creamy texture and to a complex fruit salad flavor with orange zest notes. A smidgen of sugar was left in the wine during fermentation, keeping it off-dry. On Tuesdays, it may come across as an aperitif; on Fridays, it will want to wash down fish and chicken. The wine's name derives not from a stock market boon but from the Windfall Vineyard in East Amwell Township, Hunterdon County, which Unionville once leased. Like Mosel rieslings, Unionville's ($13 at the winery) has less than the 12 percent alcohol usually found in most whites: in this case, 11.5 percent, which can translate into an extra half-glass without noticeably diminishing one's alertness. Unionville also turns out a pleasing Chambourcin ($14), a red wine from a hybrid grape with a long history of success in the Northeast. Having undergone a two-week fermentation on the grape skins and then spent a year maturing in barrel, the 2000 Chambourcin begins with a sweet aroma, which gives way to a darkish, meaty, brooding wine with something of a raspberry and plum character. I'd drink it with beef stew or lamb dishes. Howard G. Goldberg

During the night, Khushal had learned that Majeed's father, the Afghan war hero Abdul Haq, had been executed by the Taliban. For a moment, Khushal debated telling Majeed the horrible news. But with reports last week from two bellwether companies -- I.B.M. and Microsoft -- a pattern may be emerging for the way the world will work going forward.

title: Children's Books; A Surplus of Elsies
description: Natalie Babbitt's 13th book for children, ELSIE TIMES EIGHT (Michael di Capua/Hyperion, $15.95; ages 4 to 8), is a comedy of errors based on the notion that even fairy godmothers aren't perfect. Elsie's fairy godmother is hard of hearing, and interprets the word ''before'' to mean there should be four of Elsie. After the wand is waved and the deed done, Elsie's father cries, ''No! WAIT!'' prompting the fairy godmother to scratch her head, snap her fingers and make that eight Elsies.

title: A Menu of Trendy Choices at a Hotel Spot
description: WHEN I heard about Morgans in the Four Points Sheraton Hotel in Norwalk I was intrigued by the name. Could it be kin to a lively, original establishment that used to exist in the Glenville section of Greenwich?

title: COMING UP
description: President Bush meets with House and Senate leaders and makes remarks on the war effort on Wednesday. On Thursday, he meets with mayors and county officials about homeland security. Congress returns to work on Tuesday, with the Senate focusing on the budget and the economic outlook, including testimony from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and the judiciary committee considering nominations. The House will focus on aviation security.

description: SELIGMANN-William Benbow. On January 16, 2002, of injuries due to a fall fixing yet another leak on the roof, is survived by his wife of forty-six years, Ligoa Duncan; his daughter, Doree; his stepsons, Michel and Jean-Pierre Merle; his sister, Joan and George Hagner, and a medley of nieces, nephews, grandchildren, acquired extended family, friends and pets dispersed across the world. Not one for solemnity or dreary thoughts, we encourage happy reminiscing. Send us materials, stories and photos for a commemoration.

description: Millions of Americans regularly work from home. So who are these people?

title: Mystery of the Midnight Locksmith Stickers
description: A detective story that has neither failed love nor untimely death can still be a good one with the proper share of intrigue, and, of course, a detective. That is the case in a whodunit now gripping the Upper East Side.

title: Two Barges Added To European Fleet
description: Go Barging has announced plans for a new ship, new seven-day itineraries and the addition of a converted freight barge for a total of 13 vessels serving England, Ireland, France and Germany.

description: When do you become a true New Yorker? It is, of course, not just a matter of birthright, but one of attitude.

title: The Nets Start Slowly But Pull Out a Victory
description: These Nets were starting to look a little like the old Nets, struggling against a weak opponent in front of a sparse crowd that came on a blustery winter night. There was not much energy in the building, on the court or in the stands, and the Nets were in danger of losing after the Houston Rockets took a 52-47 lead at halftime.

title: The Thin Red Lines
description: Zalewski's article about how contemporary heist films lack the ''innovation and intellectual gamesmanship'' common to earlier ones in the genre made me recall the 1979 movie ''The Great Train Robbery,'' starring Sean Connery and Donald Sutherland. It recounts the 1855 plot to steal 25,000 in gold bullion, ferried by rail to pay British troops in the Crimean War. The criminals in this fast-moving Victorian caper rely not on technological wizardry or cinematic coincidences but on pure evil genius.

title: Personal Business; Credit Counselors Have Problems, Too
description: LAST year was particularly busy for the multibillion-dollar credit counseling industry. With the economy in a recession and consumer debt and unemployment rising, millions of people turned to the industry's roughly 800 nonprofit agencies or for-profit companies for help in managing their bills.

title: Crane Is Secured and Jersey City Evacuees Return
description: Despite a driving snowstorm and high winds, workers tonight secured a damaged crane that since early Wednesday had teetered over this waterfront neighborhood.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Martin Luther King's Birthday

title: Ice Sturm
description: If you tuned into Court TV recently, or even if you just glanced at the paper, it was hard to miss the Massachusetts case in which Thomas Junta, a 44-year-old truck driver, was convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of his son's hockey coach, Michael Costin. Even in the already dismal annals of American sports excess, this was a gruesome incident: while several children -- including their sons -- watched, Junta, who outweighed Costin by more than 100 pounds, pounded the other man senseless on the ice-rink floor. Yet those of us who spend much time in rinks have had to acknowledge that the Junta case shouldn't have come as a huge surprise. It was entirely foreseeable that when one enraged sports parent finally succeeded in killing another, it would be a hockey dad who was responsible.

title: Racially Motivated Attack Was by Outsiders
description: Warren Strugatch's column on Ned Dougherty [''Putting His Nightclub Experience to Good Use,'' Dec. 23] describes the ''racially motivated'' attack on Shane Daniels outside the club Marakesh in 1996. It omits mentioning that Mr. Daniels's attackers were led not by East Enders but by members of the New York Police Department. Other members of the police department led a courthouse demonstration at the attackers' trial and loudly insulted the injured Mr. Daniels.

title: Ideas & Trends; Casting Civic Pride In a Utopian Mold
description: IN the stakes to erect the first major monument to the rescuers and victims of Sept. 11, a developer proposed a large bronze statue, based on a photograph of three white firemen raising the American flag over the smoldering ruins. But the sculptor wanted to make one change: the three would become a multiethnic group -- one white, one Hispanic and one black.

title: Police Demand A Right to Sue If Broken Rules Cause Injuries
description: New legislation pending in Albany has rekindled an old and bitter debate between New York City and its police unions over the extent to which an injured officer should be able to sue a fellow officer or the city for negligence.

title: For Refugees, a Longer Wait at America's Door
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service, in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, has increased its scrutiny of refugees seeking to enter the United States and the relatives who sponsor their entry.

title: In His Return, Jordan Is Not as Bad as the Bulls
description: Michael Jordan's long-awaited return to the N.B.A. playground of his past almost featured the 29th triple-double of his nearly flawless career.

title: Keeping Cool on the Ice
description: BEN'S skate blade rests on my thigh. It is five minutes before practice starts, and I am lacing quickly. In the corner of my eye I spot a woman watching me and smiling at Ben.

description: Nancy Campagna and Charles B. Moss Jr. are to be married today by Judge Leslie Crocker Snyder of the New York State Supreme Court at the University Club in Manhattan.

description: PEOPLE in Bay Shore are remarkably frank in talking about how far their large expansively named hamlet on the South Shore of Long Island slid before some folks dug in their heels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, DAVID HALLAM
description: TUCK-David Hallam. 70, died Palm Beach, January 15, after a brief illness. Survived by a brother, James M., of Guadalajara, two sisters, Clare Fahnestock Moorhead and Lee Fahnestock Leggett, both of NYC. Graduated from St. Paul's School, Hanover, NH. Attended University of Virginia and George Washington University. Served in US Army, 1954-1957, stationed in Germany. As stockbroker he worked at Auchincloss Parker & Redpath in Washington, DC, at Dominick & Dominick in Montreal and NYC. Recently lived in Christiansted, St. Croix. His sense of humor never failed him, nor his interests in good reading, professional football and the stock market. Funeral at Woolworth Chapel, Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, January 23, 2 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

title: Anime, Japanese Cinema's Second Golden Age
description: IT is easy to get the impression that the Japanese cinema disappeared from the world stage with the passing of its three greatest filmmakers, Kenji Mizoguchi, Yasujiro Ozu and Akira Kurosawa. Since Kurosawa's death in 1998, a number of gifted directors have emerged in Japan, including Takeshi Kitano (''Hana Bi'') and Shinji Aoyama (''Eureka''). But none of them have been able to fill American and European art houses as their elders did in the 1950's and 60's, when Japanese film was in its golden age.

title: Loans That Turn a Home Into a Cash Flow
description: A DOZEN years after their introduction, reverse mortgages remain little known, and perhaps less understood. Only an estimated 60,000 to 75,000 of the loans, available to people 62 years of age or older who own and live in their own house, town house or condominium, have been made. But a number of financial institutions, seeing a marketing opportunity based on the sharply increasing number of Americans who are living longer, are vigorously expanding their reverse-mortgage programs.

Sam Matarazzo performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GISH, MARGUERITE DROUIN (NEE MARGUERITE EILA NEVILE DROUIN A PARIS LE 20 AOUT, 1930)
description: GISH-Marguerite Drouin (nee Marguerite Eila Nevile Drouin a Paris le 20 Aout, 1930). Died January 15 at her home in Greenwich. The only child of Pierre Marcel Joseph Drouin and Betty Nevile Drouin, Margot spent her childhood in Morocco and France. She lived in St. Jean de Luz during the German occupation. After the war she studied at Oxford and the University of Geneva, where she earned a degree in translation. Margot moved to the U.S. in 1954 but maintained her French citizenship while living here most of her life. She came to the U.S. to work with the World Bank and eventually became an assistant to the designer Raymond Loewe in New York City. In 1956 she married Peter Michael Gish, an artist from Westport with whom she had three children; Charlotte, Peter and Carl (K). Margot travelled extensively and was a travel consultant in Greenwich for 25 years. She was very involved in the community and was a vice president and secretary for the Alliance Francaise and a 50-year volunteer with the Red Cross. Margot is survived by her husband, three children and grandchildren. An intelligent, beautiful woman of uncommon grace, she will be dearly missed by her family, many, many friends and acquaintances. A funeral mass will be held at St. Roch's Church in Greenwich on Monday, January 21st, at 11 AM.

title: Looking for Caves, But Digging Up Trouble
description: FOUR amateur cave explorers were busy passing buckets of dirt out of a 20-foot-deep shaft, when they looked up to find a state park ranger standing there. It was June 9, near sundown, and they were not supposed to be looking for underground passages on federal land near the Appalachian Trail.

title: Montreal
description: Montreal is a place of sophisticated contrasts. Centuries-old buildings -- the city was founded in 1642 -- and historic streets give it a vintage European atmosphere. Step inside, however, and the people and fashions radiate a hip, modern sensibility. In the largest French-speaking city in the world after Paris, concierges or cashiers who greet you in French switch to fluent English when they hear your accent. A ''typical'' meal might be a $4 smoked-meat sandwich or a $100 six-course dinner, each essential to the Montreal experience.

title: The Widows' Battalion
description: Cut Intan is 23 years old, five-feet-nothing tall and -- like the 24 young women under her command -- trained to kill. She belongs to the elusive ''widows' battalion'' of the Free Aceh Movement (GAM), a 15,000-strong rebel army fighting for independence in Aceh, a rugged, jungly province on the northernmost tip of Indonesia's vast archipelago. ''We all feel a duty to fight for our land and for our ancestors,'' says Cut Intan.

title: Corrections
description: The first paragraph of the article on Page 24 of The Times Magazine today, about the troubled history of the Milosevic family, omits a word and refers erroneously to a pistol used by Marija, daughter of Slobodan, on the night he was arrested. The pistol was not her father's. The affected passage should read, ''The daughter, Marija, went on trial for firing a pistol during a drug-and-alcohol-induced frenzy 10 months ago, on the night her father was arrested in the presidential mansion.''

title: What Workers Will Suffolk Wage Law Affect?
description: WHEN the Suffolk County Legislature voted last July to approve what its proponents called a ''living wage'' law, Suffolk joined a growing list of state and local governments requiring certain employers to pay more than the hourly rate set by federal minimum wage law, and to provide health-care benefits to boot. Under the new law, beginning July 1, at least 5,000 Long Islanders -- among them, home health-care attendants, school-bus matrons, and child-care assistants -- who work for agencies under contract to the county must be paid $9 an hour if benefits are included, or $10.25 an hour if they are not.

title: Vengeful Is the Night
description: I can hear my son in the next room cry out in his half-sleep, and in my half-sleep I am out of bed, pulling my way through the tug of recent dreams. As I enter his room, the animal-warm smell of fresh urine rushes at me, and even as I take the wet bundle of my son into my arms, I am remembering.

description: Anne Poor, an American artist who painted combat scenes in World War II and later concentrated on dreamlike landscapes, died in Nyack, N.Y., on Jan. 12. She was 84 and lived in Haverstraw, N.Y.

title: Personal Business; Consumer Tools for Holding Bill Collectors at Bay
description: WHEN Stacey Edwards, an employee of the Florida juvenile justice system, moved out of her apartment complex in Tallahassee last July, she didn't think there would be any problems. After all, she said, she had given what she believed to be proper notice and left the apartment in good condition. But last month, without hearing a word from the apartment managers, she said she began receiving telephone calls from a debt collection agency demanding $815 for unpaid rent and cleaning fees.

title: When Bark Shows Its Splashes of Color
description: THE transition from fall to winter brings many trees and shrubs from their most ostentatious to their most subtle beauty. Like a developing photographic image, the textures and colors of various kinds of bark come slowly into view against the increasingly stark winter landscape. If you were to choose one plant for its bark, what would it be? The chalky, peeling bark of the paper birch (Betula papyrifera) usually comes to mind, of course. But there are other trees and shrubs with notable bark, some as striking as birch, others with a subtle loveliness best appreciated during a winter stroll or viewed through a window from a comfortable chair.

title: Keeping Their Faiths Under Taliban Rule Drew Sikhs and Hindus Together
description: The men emerge from the rubble like an apparition, 10 of them, most bearded and turbaned. They move toward a bruised, shuttered building whose roof has been caved in by a rocket, and unlock the door. They pass through an interior courtyard, remove their shoes and enter a vast room empty except for a barren altar and perfumed smoke. They move down a path formed by incense holders and fan out around the altar into a semicircle. Their voices echoing off the emptiness, they pray.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, LEAH
description: SCHNEIDER-Leah. The Board of Directors and staff of the Manhattan Valley Development Corporation and Manhattan Valley Management Company Inc. mourn the recent passing of Ms. Schneider, long our Executive Director, inspirational leader and board Member. Over the past thirty years, Leah's deeds have been manifested by the revitalization of the Manhattan Valley section of the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Her vision and determination transformed a deteriorating predominately low-income neighborhood into a paragon of affordable Housing development and community preservation, which attracted visitors and researchers from across the seas and our country. The community she rebuilt will sorely miss her leadership, kindness and wisdom. Mildred Dweck, President of MVDC Board Donna-Marie Gibbons, Executive Director, MVDC Jose Valerio, Executive Director, MVMC

title: Another Baggage First At the Denver Airport?

title: The Body As Machine, Taken To Its Extreme
description: IN 1909, Filippo Tommaso Marinetti, the poet and author of the ''Futurist Manifesto,'' proclaimed, ''A racing car whose hood is adorned by great pipes . . . is more beautiful than the Victory of Samothrace.'' Within the next five years, artists as diverse as Fernand Lger, Kasimir Malevich, Francis Picabia and Marcel Duchamp all used mechanistic imagery in their paintings to allude to the body -- the central icon of Western art -- in motion or in repose. A more literal use of machine iconography followed, in, for example, the work of Jean Tinguely, who produced sculptures that could move, make noise, draw or self-destruct, like us.

title: Bloomberg and the Man on the Street; Reaching Out to the Homeless, Mayor Finds No Easy Answers

We speak for her colleagues, former residents, close friends, and grateful patients in expressing our sincere appreciation for her many contributions to the New York medical community and in extending our heartfelt condolences to her family. Those who dread dark days ahead on the American cultural front owe themselves a visit home.

title: Lingering Legacy Of War in the 80's
description: Countless Afghans lost limbs by stepping on land mines dating from the Soviet Union's war in Afghanistan, from 1979 to 1989. Some were combatants, many others were children. At the Guardians Institute for Orthopedics in Kandahar, officials say, 70 percent of the patients were injured by Soviet land mines. By now, many of the original prostheses have been damaged and need to be replaced, or at least repaired. No one knows how many mines remain in Afghanistan; estimates range upward into the millions. To this day, mines kill or maim three Afghans a day. One patient recalled: ''I was injured 17 years ago. A big bullet took my leg off. It took three operations to repair what was left of it.''

description: A judge ruled last week that North Brunswick can condemn a farm to prevent a developer from putting houses on it. In the first ruling in the state that empowers a town to condemn property for open-space use, state Superior Court Judge James Hurley ruled that the town could condemn a 104-acre farm to stop the U.S. Home Corporation, based in Texas, from building 400 single-family homes there. The ruling, though welcomed by environmental groups, may not be put into practice. Most members of North Brunswick's new Town Council say they do not want to condemn the farm but wish instead to buy a third of the land for open space and sell the rest for development. Jo Piazza

title: Design Line Online
description: Fashion lovers who prefer to buy -- their Pucci and Calvin Klein on the auction block have a new place in which to browse. EBay has introduced a new online column, Phillip's Fashion Finds, by Phillip Bloch, the Hollywood stylist. ''Just think of me as a cruise director of sorts,'' Mr. Bloch said. ''I'll be offering shopping tips, highlighting hot items and pointing out trends I've noticed.'' This week, he discusses bustiers and recommends eBay shops like Guccigranny's Closet. And there is a new list of designers, organized alphabetically, whose designs are on the auction site -- under D, for instance, a Dolce & Gabbana purple sequined bustier for $36 and a Dries van Noten embroidered coat, straight off the runway, for $375. Mr. Bloch said eBay was a great way to assess value. Since Yves Saint Laurent announced his retirement on Jan. 7, for example, a flood of his designs has come up for sale, ''although buyers and sellers are being cautious,'' he said. For a peek, log on to www.eBay.com, click on clothing and accessories and then on designer boutique.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EASLICK, SUSAN BOLLES
description: EASLICK-Susan Bolles, 61. Of Washington, DC, Grosse Pointe Farms, MI, and Ridgewood, NJ. Died of cancer on January 16, 2002. Susan was the Administrative Director of Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity and the Development Director of its educational foundation, the Rampant Lion Foundation, which she and her husband David, attorney and DKE Executive Director, helped found in the 1980's. Unique in her twentyyear leadership role in a men's fraternal organization, she was the spark that continually advanced the spirit and the services of the fraternity. The 35,000 alumni and 2,500 undergraduate members of DKE will greatly miss her. Her unique package of skills included an eye for decorating, and she was President of Park Avenue Designs, her own interior design firm. An early and strong admirer of President Bush, in the 2000 elections Susan single handedly organized ''Grosse Pointers for George W. Bush,'' hosting a breakfast during the primaries and serving as the official greeter for an early Economic Club of Detroit campaign visit. She and David continued as proud members of the Republican National Finance Committee until her death. They relocated to Washington, DC from their Grosse Pointe Farms, MI. home, where they had resided for 15 years, in February 2001. She was a graduate of Dwight School for Girls in Englewood, NJ, Bennett College, and attended Finch College. An avid sailor, she directed junior sailing programs at the Shelter Island Yacht Club and Grosse Pointe Club. Susan was a sustaining member of the Junior League of Washington, DC and a member of the Grosse Pointe Junior League Gardeners. She also held memberships in the Yale Club of New York, the University Club of Washington DC, the Grosse Pointe Club, and the Detroit Club. A member of St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington, she had previously served on the vestry of St. Elizabeth's Church in Ridgewood, NJ, and directed its children's choir. Survived by husband David Kenneth Easlick, Jr., daughter Susan Ackerson Holmes and fiance Sean Thomas Cosgrove, daughter Elisabeth Holmes McKean and son-in-law George Edwin McKean III, stepdaughter Sarah Jane Easlick, stepson David Kenneth Easlick III, grandchildren George Edwin McKean IV, Michael Edmunds McKean, her West Highland White Terrier ''Poppy,'' and the many good friends around the world, with whom she stayed in constant contact. A memorial service will be held at St. Alban's Episcopal Church, Washington DC on January 21, 2002 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rampant Lion Foundation, the Educational Foundation of Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity, 2238 47th Street NW, Washington, DC, 20007.

The Cystic Fibrosis Association of Greater New York marks with profound sadness the passing of Paul Perces, our beloved friend and esteemed member of the CFA Board of Directors. Paul, together with Marjorie, was a pioneering advocate for cystic fibrosis children & served for better than 35 years in dedicated effort to advance the life horizons for Becky and all cystic fibrosis young. His humanism, dynamic personality and creativity meaningfully furthered the research, care and scholarship programs helping to bring today's CF average age of survival to 31 years. His vision and warmth of caring will be greatly missed. Our love and heartfelt condolences to his wife Marjorie and the family. Phyllis L. Kossoff, Chairman Norton Hight, President

title: New Life for the Ancestral Home
description: FIFTEEN years ago, when my wife and I took our two older children to Tuscany, we visited the house where my father was brought up. It's a big old stone building at the top of a hill so steep you need four-wheel drive to get there. Hills and valleys, dotted with tiny villages, farmhouses and churches stretch below in all directions. You might think you were in heaven.

title: George Divoky's Planet
description: Divoky has observed 27 years of global warming on his Arctic island, but that does not prove it is caused by ''our endless consumption of fossil fuels.'' It now appears that Mars -- without S.U.V.'s or oil drilling -- is also in a period of global warming.

title: Do You Look Best Wearing Envious Green?
description: WHY is Julia Roberts living my life? That question has gnawed at me for years, and I still haven't come up with the answer. Yes, I'm aware that comparing myself to America's Sweetheart is perhaps not the sanest idea, and I admit that I'm not entirely serious. But every so often I wonder why someone of my age and with my eye color, who is also smart and funny, is earning $20 million a film to emote into a camera, while I would consider it a good day if I found $20 in my jeans pocket.

title: About Face
description: One Sunday evening early in the fall, Glenn C. Loury arrived at the Charles Hotel in Cambridge, Mass., where a group of distinguished black intellectuals, including Cornel West, Lani Guinier and Henry Louis Gates Jr., was gathering to discuss the Sept. 11 attacks. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the keynote speaker, had flown in to talk about possible shuttle diplomacy with the Taliban. Loury, an economist at Boston University who first achieved prominence as one of the nation's leading black conservatives in the Reagan years, was there on a diplomatic mission of his own: to mend the rift that has long separated him from liberal blacks like Jackson. He knew he might elicit more than a few hostile glances. ''I've been trying to figure out who you were for the longest time,'' one woman said coldly when they were introduced, according to Loury. But he decided to brave it.

Mr. Watson said the most seriously affected customers -- numbering fewer than 100 -- lost service for several days.

title: The Power to Help
description: GIVEN our tight economy, heightened national security concerns and renewed anxiety about our supply of oil, it's time that we in the Northeast became serious about conserving electricity. Conservation is a meaningful act, just when many of us are looking for something of lasting good to do for our country. Investment in more efficient electrical equipment in our homes, offices and factories benefits us, individually and collectively, for the long term.

title: FRONT LINES
description: AL QAEDA -- A search of an Al Qaeda training camp once occupied by Muhammad Atef, Osama bin Laden's lieutenant, yielded five hourlong videotapes. The Justice Department described the tapes as showing five men making ''martyrdom messages,'' though it stripped the sound from the clips it showed reporters and offered no transcript. The department announced a global manhunt for the five, saying they could be preparing suicide attacks. The only one already known to investigators was Ramzi Muhammad Abdullah bin al-Shibh, a Yemeni, who has been linked to Zacarias Moussaoui, the first and only person charged in the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: The Nation; Give Me a Home Where the Buffalo Roam Less
description: HERE'S one early lesson from America's two-front war against terrorism: it can be less confounding for the United States to fight a battle-hardened enemy thousands of miles away than to figure out how to secure its own shores.

title: ENRON SCANDAL DEEPENS
description: It didn't seem like the scandal surrounding the collapse of the Enron Corporation could get any worse. Then it did. In a flood of revelations, documents were released from a Congressional committee showing that the company's chairman had received an anonymous letter from an employee in August, giving him a heads-up on the problems at Enron months before the company unraveled. The chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, ordered a legal review, while still chatting up the prospects for the company's stock. Then, the company's auditors, Arthur Andersen & Company, fired the partner who handled the Enron account, saying that he had led an effort to destroy documents in the days after the Securities and Exchange Commission requested documents from the company. And there doesn't seem to be an end in sight. Kurt Eichenwald

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Jussara Lee; She's Downsized, but Up
description: ONE highlight of Jussara Lee's new boutique, a glass-and-concrete candy box in the aggressively stylish meatpacking district, is her office. On Thursday, the night of her opening party, that space, which might have been smuggled in from the set of ''Being John Malkovich,'' was crowded with schoolgirls. In their midst sat Malka Katzav, fixing intruders with a frosty stare. ''I'm the boss's daughter,'' she declared. While her mother, Ms. Lee, 34, whooshed guests around the store, Malka, 8, held court for friends. She paused to field questions: ''Do I want to be a fashion designer? Kind of and kind of not. It's not exactly a fun job.''

title: Streetscapes/50 East 42nd Street; Ballet Dancer of a Building, Its Tower Lithe and Trim
description: NOW that the building across the street has been demolished to make way for a new tower, passers-by can better appreciate the graceful lines of the former Heckscher Building, which was put up in 1916 at the southeast corner of 42nd Street and Madison Avenue. Compared with the clunky office buildings that surround it, 50 East 42nd Street, as the Heckscher Building has long been known, is a ballet dancer of a structure, its setback tower lithe and trim.

title: 'Home Lands'
description: The South is no one place, and there are many ways to be a Jew. The Jewish experience in the South evokes such terms as ambivalence, Paradox, and contradiction . "Who is a southerner?" and "who is a Jew?" are sufficiently complex questions without the added complication of asking "who is a southern Jew?" Southerners and Jews are Americans, too, although both peoples have often found themselves outside the national mainstream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREVOR, IRWIN
description: PREVOR-Irwin. Age 70, of Atlanta, GA, formerly of NYC, died unexpectedly December 14, 2001. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, in 1931. Before leaving to join the staff at the American Cancer Society, he worked for Forbes Magazine. Irwin came to Georgia in 1988 to continue his career as Vice President for Benefits and Insurance Planning when the American Cancer Society relocated there. Throughout his career, Irwin never stopped devising new and better employee benefit plans, including cancer screening tests, long term disability, tax deferred annuity and HMO medical plans to the society's total benefits package. By providing post retirement medical, dental and life insurance coverage, he ensured a good retirement package for every retiree. He earned a reputation among his non-profit peers as a leader in the employee benefits field. Irwin is survived by his wife, Marilyn. A memorial service is pending.

title: Indifference Toward Vaccinating the Poor
description: In the early 1990's more than 70 percent of children in developing nations were vaccinated against basic childhood diseases, the fruit of a campaign begun in 1985 by Unicef and the World Health Organization. But today poor countries report that only 56 percent of their children get the basic vaccines against diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, tuberculosis and measles, and the real number is likely much lower. The cause is a falloff in financial support and mounting indifference in wealthy nations toward poor ones.

title: Nuclear Reactors as Terrorist Targets

A group of environmentalists and public officials has petitioned the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to close down Indian Point until it can be made safe from terrorist attack. That seems an overreaction. A shutdown would deprive New Yorkers of a valuable source of electricity even as energy companies are scrambling to build more power plants to meet projected demand. Whatever threat is posed by terrorists can more sensibly be addressed by enhancing the plant's security measures.

title: The War in Colombia
description: Yesterday's agreement between the Colombian government and rebel forces to hold cease-fire talks was an encouraging sign. It was a rare moment of hope in a country long battered by civil war. The near collapse of talks earlier this month contained an important lesson for the Bush administration and Congress. When President Andrs Pastrana threatened to forcibly take back the chunk of southern Colombia he had ceded to the leftist guerrillas three years ago, civilians living in the area became terrified. For as bad as life has been under the guerrillas -- and it has been awful -- the prospect of a Colombian military takeover meant the certain arrival of the murderous paramilitary forces. If Washington continues or expands aid to the Colombian military, it must do so on the condition that the military cut its ties to the paramilitaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, DAVID H.
description: GOLDSMITH - David H. The Grand Street Boys' Association and The Grand Street Boys' Foundation express their deep sorrow at the passing of David H. Goldsmith, Chairman of the Board and past President of the The GBSA and distinguished Board Member of the GSBF. His total involvement in the charitable affairs of our organization and foundation were only exceeded by his devotion to his family, his wife Karen, their sons Jeffrey and David, their spouses and grandchildren. Notwithstanding his responsibilities as an active practicing attorney and partner in a law firm, he unselfishly gave of himself for the benefit of his fellow man. With Karen's constant support at his side, until her death last year, he provided inspirational leadership to GSBA over many decades, enabling it to carry on its' well known hobbies program as well as many other charitable endeavors. Under his guidance and wise counsel, the Foundation has provided financial support to 501(C)3 organizations far and wide. His Herculean efforts on behalf of Grand Street were equally matched by his Masonic works. We will miss his enthusiasm, his courage, his gentlemanlyness, his kindness and total concern for the welfare of others. Our heartfelt sympathy to his loving family.

title: A New Rallying Cry for Reform
description: Congress returns from its winter break tomorrow to take up the defense of democracy against terrorism. Lawmakers would do well to note that American democracy is also being attacked from within by a poisonous system of unregulated campaign donations. There is no better illustration of the system's destructiveness than the fact that the attorney general has had to recuse himself from his department's investigation of Enron because Enron gave his campaigns a lot of money. Members of Congress find themselves in the same fix, and some are returning their Enron donations. Enron's vast contributions have already corrupted decision-making on tax cuts, energy policy and financial regulations. Now they threaten to hamper the investigation into one of the biggest business scandals in American history.

title: The Prisoners at Guantnamo
description: The handling and prosecution of Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners at the American naval base in Guantnamo, Cuba, cannot be left to the whim of the Pentagon. There have been disturbing reports about the conditions under which some of these detainees are being held. And a federal court will hear legal challenges to their treatment today. It is in America's interest to afford all the prisoners humane conditions of detention and basic standards of due process. The United States should stand for the rule of law, even when it comes to prosecuting violent enemies committed to carrying out terrorist attacks.

title: Restoring Yosemite
description: One way the administration can improve on its mediocre record on the national parks is to proceed with a Clinton-era plan to ease the disgraceful overcrowding of Yosemite National Park. Key elements of that plan are under fire from George Radanovich, a California Republican who is the new chairman of the House National Parks Subcommittee. He thinks the plan, by limiting automobile access and campsites, shortchanges tourists. The tourists will be fine. It is nature that will suffer unless the National Park Service sticks to its guns.

title: The Hard Road Back For Paula Poundstone; Comic Tries to Save Her Career After Arrest

One of the few women to break out of the nightly grind of playing small clubs and theaters during the stand-up comedy boom of the 1980's, she had earned as much as $1.2 million annually in recent years.

title: Thinkers in Need of Publishers
description: Every semester brings a new symposium, every season a new book, every Sunday a new furrowed-brow disquisition. The topic is ''public intellectuals'' -- writers and thinkers who address a general audience on matters of broad public concern -- and the theme is decline. Russell Jacoby, who coined the phrase, delivered the consensus judgment in the title of his 1987 book, ''The Last Intellectuals: American Culture in the Age of Academe'': There are none to speak of. And as Mr. Jacoby noted in the splashy 2000 edition, ''Happenings since its publication do not cause me to revise its main points.''

Attempting to investigate the microscopic properties of black holes, the gravitational traps from which not even light can escape, Dr. Hawking discovered to his disbelief that they could leak energy and particles into space, and even explode in a fountain of high-energy sparks.

Listening to the Emerson String Quartet play six Haydn works at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon led one, oddly, to thoughts of Shostakovich. Haydn might have admired the originality of his modern counterpart, but he would have found the cries of spiritual agony vulgar.

description: Willamette Industries said late yesterday that it had agreed in principle to accept a sweetened $6.1 billion cash offer from the Weyerhaeuser Company.

title: Review/Fashion; Seeing a New Man Calling the Tune, Fashion Gets in Step
description: If the social commentators are to be believed, the post-Sept. 11 world has caused a certain kind of woman to re-evaluate what she is looking for in a man. Theoretically, this woman -- clever, controlled, prone to overthink -- no longer feels an inexorable pull toward the guy who shows up in a skinny vintage suit and a pair of Converse All Stars, a copy of something by Gaston Bachelard peeking out of his pocket. She has seen the valiant efforts of rescue workers and remarked to herself that men like Donald Rumsfeld make big, impactive decisions in the time it would take any of her exes to order lunch. Suddenly she finds herself tired of the dawdlers, melancholics and other variants of genius who would not know what to do with a baseball mitt or a drill press.

title: Review Delays Work on Center for 911 Calls
description: Work to build a backup dispatching center for the 911 emergency telephone system has been put off while the Bloomberg administration reviews whether it can afford to go forward with the project at this time, according to officials.

description: To the Editor:

title: Part Parade, Part Strut, Part Funk
description: Afrobeat, the simmering, politicized Nigerian funk invented by Fela Anikulapo Kuti, has outlived its creator and leaped across borders. At the Knitting Factory last Tuesday night a double bill of Afrobeat packed both the house and the club's small stage when the New York band Antibalas opened for Psyco on da Bus, led by Fela's drummer, Tony Allen. Antibalas held on to vintage Afrobeat; Psyco on da Bus extrapolated from it.

title: 2 Early Enron Lenders Didn't See the End Coming
description: Enron's modern era dates back to the mid-1980's, and throughout that period Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase have been there to lend with both hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ILENE
description: SUSSMAN-Ilene. Along with the VIs parents at City and Country School, we are deeply saddened by the passing of our cherished friend Ilene. The times we shared as mothers and friends will always remind us of what a wonderful, inspiring woman she was. Her graciousness and spirit are enduring. Our thoughts are with Brian and Rhy, and the Sussman and Kelly families. ''How could we not.'' Simone Weissman, Peter Levitt Beth and Alf Blitzer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERINS, SR. JOSEPH MERCEDES
description: KERINS-Sr. Joseph Mercedes. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent Mary the Queen, died Saturday, January 19, 2002. Dear sister of Marianne Dempsey and sister-in-law of Dorothy Kerins. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Convent Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, NY, on Tuesday, 1-8 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM, at the convent. Interment to follow at St. Joseph's CemeteryYonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, New York 10471.

title: KMART IS ON VERGE OF FILING A CLAIM FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Kmart Corporation, the nation's third-largest discount retailer, is expected to seek bankruptcy protection as early as this morning in Michigan, where it has its headquarters, advisers to the company say.

title: An I.B.M.-VeriSign Venture for E-Commerce
description: I.B.M. and VeriSign, an Internet security and domain-name manager, are to announce a three-year services and marketing agreement today that is intended to accelerate companies' adoption of technology to make electronic commerce more secure.

title: Dozens Die in Congo as Lava Sets Off Blast at Gas Station
description: As Goma continued to struggle with the aftermath of the huge flow of lava that leveled great swaths of the town, a gas station exploded in its center this morning, and dozens of people who had been looting gasoline were believed to have died.

title: Russian Court Orders Closing Of Nonstate TV
description: A Moscow court abruptly ordered Russia's Press Ministry on Monday night to shut down the nation's last independent television network, TV-6, which has battled for months against what its managers called a Kremlin-inspired vendetta.

title: Body's Defender Goes on the Attack
description: At the slightest provocation -- a mosquito bite, a mild sunburn, a tiny splinter -- the body mounts a hair-trigger defense, sending cells and natural chemicals to destroy dirt or germs and repair the damage. As a result, the site of injury becomes red, swollen, warm and painful -- inflamed.

title: Jospin Faces an Epidemic of Unrest by Health-Care Workers
description: PARIS  With hospital workers, nurses and general practitioners either walking off their jobs Monday or announcing strikes, this was not a good week to fall ill or have an accident in France, and the unrest also bode ill for the Socialist government as it prepares to fight a presidential election less than 100 days from now.

title: Giving Voice to Lesser-Known Songs
description: The first thing to be said about Deborah Voigt -- that is, apart from the obvious, which is that she has an enormous, powerful soprano that is fully in her control -- is that she knows how to put together a compelling recital program. It wasn't that the program she sang on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall was full of favorites. Most of the selections were comparatively obscure songs by well-known composers. Nor were they all unjustly neglected gems that one hopes to hear on every third soprano recital, although a few (a set of Griffes songs for example) could be.

title: A Fiscal Fantasy
description: I want to share a fantasy with you. Trust me: it will explain everything you need to know about the budget debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, EDWARD
description: FINCH-Edward. We lost a guiding light. A friend, partner, and beacon of support and strength. We will miss you. Our deepest sympathies to the entire Finch family. Bob Bell, COO. Centra Marketing & Comm.

title: Israeli Army Seizes One West Bank City and Enters Another
description: The Israeli Army seized control of the Palestinian city of Tulkarm on Monday, , and this morning began moving into another West Bank city, Nablus.

title: Walker to Be Moved From Ship to Airport Camp
description: John Walker, the 20-year-old Californian captured with Taliban soldiers in northern Afghanistan, will be moved from a Navy ship in the Arabian Sea as early as Tuesday on the first leg of his journey back to the United States, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Iranian Influence Felt In Afghanistan's West
description: Iran is working to consolidate its influence in the western part of Afghanistan through a firm alliance with the local ruler and the steady shipment of aid and supplies that may include weapons, residents and officials say.

title: Fire Escape
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: In Shift, Bush Assails Enron Over Handling of Collapse
description: Abruptly changing his tone about a company that contributed heavily to his political campaigns, President Bush said today that he was ''outraged'' that the Enron Corporation misled its employees and investors, including his mother-in-law, who he said lost more than $8,000 when its stock collapsed.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Program For Housing Down Payments
description: The Bush administration announced that its budget for next year would include a $200 million program to help lower-income families with down payments and closing costs on their first houses. Mel Martinez, secretary of housing and urban development, said the program was part of a response to a growing housing crisis for working families. The U.S. Conference of Mayors reported last week that cities had estimated that they will need an additional $1.12 billion each year to meet the demand for affordable housing. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONASON, ELLIE
description: CONASON-Ellie. On January 5, 2002. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, January 27, 3 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Amid Tears, 40 Saint Laurent Years Pass in Review
description: When Laure de Gramont, a French literary agent, woke up in her apartment in Paris today, her thoughts were of Yves Saint Laurent, the French fashion designer who ended a 40-year career with a grand retrospective show at the Pompidou Center this evening.

title: Heroes of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Flat Panel Profits
description: Reflecting the grow ing preference for flat-panel displays over traditional tubes for televisions and computer monitors, Samsung SDI, the Samsung Group company that makes both types but emphasizes flat screens, posted a 29 percent increase in profit for the fourth quarter. Samsung SDI said it had earned 141 billion won ($105 million) as it made 24 percent of all flat screens sold worldwide last year for computers, televisions and mobile phones. It said it hoped to expand its share to 30 percent in 2002. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Doorway to Tuscany, by Way of the Circus
description: IT'S hard to think of a restaurant that works harder at fun than Osteria del Circo. It opened, nearly six years ago, with a trumpet blast and a big shower of confetti, and if the owners, Mario, Marco and Mauro Maccioni, did not actually send out clowns on tiny tricycles, it's only because they could not quite figure out how.

title: Dublin Court Convicts Man in Ulster Blast That Killed 29
description: An antiterrorism court here today convicted the only person to be tried so far with the bombing of Omagh, Northern Ireland, in 1998, despite allegations of police impropriety and a bungled investigation.

title: Satellite Start-Up for Apple Co-Founder
description: Emerging from an early retirement he began more than a decade ago, Stephen Wozniak, one of Silicon Valley's legendary computer designers, has caught start-up fever and is forming a company to develop consumer products based on wireless and global positioning satellite technologies.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Water Bill Slogan Resumes
description: The Stagecoach General Improvement District will resume stamping ''God Bless America'' on all but one of its 450 monthly water bills. Starting in November, a district manager at Stagecoach in Lyon County in western Nevada put the phrase on all bills. A customer complained, saying it violated his civil rights and used tax dollars to support religion. But after a majority of customers demanded that the slogan be continued, the district's board decided to continue using the stamp. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Lawyers for Arts Club
description: To the Editor:

title: Daschle Hopes to Lead Senate Toward an Economic Recovery Package
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic majority leader, said today that he intended to begin the new legislative year with an effort to pass the elements of an economic recovery package that both parties support.

title: Let Education Guide Welfare
description: WE urge young people to get more education, arguing for example that women with college degrees earn 48 percent more than similar women with only high school diplomas.

title: Walker to Arrive in U.S. Today To Await His Conspiracy Trial
description: John Walker, the 20-year-old Californian accused of fighting in Afghanistan against his own countrymen, is expected to arrive on American soil on Wednesday to await trial, officials said today.

title: Owner Gets Week to Plan Tigers' Removal
description: The owner of 24 tigers that the state wants sent to a Texas sanctuary has received a one-week extension of a deadline of Thursday for her to develop an alternative plan, her lawyer said today.

title: 9/11 Inspires Call to Review Response Plan For Crises
description: At the time the World Trade Center towers collapsed, the New York Fire Department had little idea how many firefighters were inside and could not communicate with a Police Department helicopter flying overhead, a fire official said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Concern Over Danes' Proposal On Foreigners
description: The United Nations refugee agency says it will examine proposed Danish legislation that would limit the number of foreigners in the country to see if it hurts asylum seekers. The office of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees said it was especially concerned over possible restrictions because Denmark is to take over the rotating presidency of the European Union for the second half of 2002 and would be in a position to influence Europe-wide asylum policies. The proposed restrictions are to be debated this spring in the Danish Parliament. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Mets' Balanced Lineup Has Piazza Revved Up
description: Anyone who watched the Mets last season can recite the scenario they encountered dozens and dozens of times. Mike Piazza is slowly walking to the plate and there is excitement at Shea Stadium because it is Piazza, but there is also some frustration because the bases are empty again.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A.F.L.-C.I.O Backs Republican
description: John Ravitz, the Republican running in a special election for a State Senate seat for the East Side of Manhattan, received a major labor endorsement yesterday. The New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., which represents more than two million union members, endorsed Mr. Ravitz, even though it usually supports Democrats. Mario Cilento, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. spokesman, said it endorsed Mr. Ravitz, who is a member of the State Assembly, because his voting record in recent years was 100 percent pro-labor. Mr. Ravitz has already been endorsed by two powerful unions, the United Federation of Teachers and 1199, the health care workers' union. Liz Krueger is the Democratic candidate for the seat, which Roy M. Goodman held for 33 years. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, GUSTAVA
description: WEISS-Gustava, 91. On December 24, 2001. Widow of Edward Weiss, pianist, and mother of Angela Migliorini, Gustava Weiss (nee Kirchberg) had been a highly-acclaimed coloratura soprano. More recently she taught singing and was a judge for The International Vocal Competitions of The National Arts Club, The Liederkranz Foundation, and The National Federation of Music Clubs. A Memorial Service will be held 6 P.M., Thursday, January 24th at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, 65th Street and Central Park West in Manhattan.

title: Kmart Files Bankruptcy, Largest Ever For a Retailer
description: The Kmart Corporation filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, the largest such filing ever made by a retailer.

description: Is the venerable Century Association destined to become a bedroom community?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Trust Unit Acquired
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and other investors agreed to buy the trust management unit of Kookmin Bank for 44.4 billion won ($33 million), as the bank reorganizes after a merger. Morgan Stanley signed a nonbinding agreement to buy the bank's 87 percent stake in the Kookmin Investment Trust Management Company for 8,500 won a share, an acquisition that is expected to be completed by the end of February, Kookmin said. The sale is aimed at ''reducing overlapping businesses'' after Kookmin combined with a smaller rival, H&CB, in November, Kookmin said.

title: Getting To Know Bach Better
description: Reinhard Goebel is a musical spark plug, sure to energize any program or performance he touches as violinist or conductor. So it came as no surprise that the New York Collegium, led by Mr. Goebel, played on its mettle in a scintillating evening of German Baroque concertos on Friday at the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

title: First Appointment at Columbia
description: LEE C. BOLLINGER will not become president at Columbia University until this summer, but the Columbia trustees approved his first appointment this week. He named SUSAN K. FEAGIN as Columbia's next vice president for development and alumni relations. A Columbia graduate, she is vice president for development at the University of Michigan, where he was president until December.

title: Seeking Top Berth In Pursuit Of Enron
description: The lawyer William Lerach was all over the television news today as he lugged a large carton of shredded Enron documents to the courthouse in Houston. Amid a sea of microphones, Mr. Lerach gave the impression he was leading the charge for angry shareholders in their legal battle against Enron.

description: NEW YORK

title: Kidd Upgrades His Game As Nets Surge Past the Spurs
description: Suddenly and defiantly, Jason Kidd regained his shooting touch tonight with the flinch of muscle memory. Kidd has reshaped the Nets in his image halfway into a season that has been anything but regular for them.

title: Jack Shea, 91; Won 2 Olympic Golds in '32
description: Jack Shea, who won two gold medals in speedskating at the 1932 Lake Placid Olympics and was the United States' oldest Winter Games gold medalist, died yesterday in Saranac Lake, N.Y., of injuries incurred Monday in an auto accident. He was 91.

title: Survey Calls Loss of Jobs Big Problem For Retailers
description: The disappearance of 100,000 jobs from Lower Manhattan as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center is the key reason that most stores and restaurants in the area are struggling to survive, according to a survey conducted earlier this month by a downtown business group.

title: New Role at Sarah Lawrence
description: SUZANNE M. MURPHY was named vice president for college resources at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. Ms. Murphy, 37, will lead a campaign to raise $75 million for the college through 2004, for plans like a new visual arts center. Allison Fass

title: Surf to Turf: A Flaky Boon From Wales
description: The newest designer sea salt comes from Wales: Halen Mon is an excellent, snowy white salt that's more flaky than crystalline, which makes it better for cooking. A miniature canister fits purse and pocket -- for all those annoying restaurants that don't put salt on the table. The regular size, 8.8 ounces, is $7.95; the mini, $1.50, both at Chelsea Market Baskets in the Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street).

title: The Promise of State Aid Inspires Both Relief and Uncertainty
description: If New York City officials were looking to the state for significant aid to help them close a multibillion-dollar shortfall in the city budget in the coming year, the budget that Gov. George E. Pataki proposed here today makes it clear that they will have to keep looking to the federal government.

title: Council-Districts Referendum Wins Narrowly in Brookhaven
description: A referendum that would create six districts to elect the Town Council won narrowly last night in the sprawling Long Island Town of Brookhaven, according to unofficial results.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Focus Of Extradition Fight Dies
description: Robert Lee Burns of Eugene, the focus of a lengthy extradition battle with California, has died of prostate cancer at 71. Convicted in a robbery in 1963 that resulted in the death of an officer of the California Highway Patrol, Mr. Burns was transferred to Oregon after five years to finish serving a previous sentence. He was paroled in 1975 after numerous citations for good behavior. Gov. Robert W. Straub subsequently rejected calls to extradite Mr. Burns again.

title: United Way Board Members Question Officials' Spending
description: Present and former board members of the United Way of the National Capital Area, in Washington, have questioned the propriety of some of the local United Way's spending and its administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PULITZER, MARGOT
description: PULITZER-Margot. The Yeshiva University Family mourns the passing of the beloved and cherished daughter of Ann and Marcus Rosenberg, YU Guardians, who established the Marcus and Ann Rosenberg Scholarship at YU; beloved wife of Randy; mother of Jessica, Samuel, Miles, and Mina; and sister to Helen (and Willy) Waks, Steven (and Ruthy) Rosenberg, Lizzy (and Dr. Jules) Greis, and Sheri Rosenberg. We extend heartfelt condolences to their families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees

title: Yak, Yak, Yak, All the Way to Westchester
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Air Force Boss Steps Down
description: Anatoly Kornukov retired as commander of the air force, ending a long career curiously marked by two incidents in which military forces shot down passenger jetliners. General Kornukov was attending a Ukrainian military exercise last October when Ukraine's air defenses shot down a Russian jet, killing 78; he joined Ukraine in adamantly denying that the military had downed the jet until evidence proved otherwise. In 1983, he commanded the Soviet air division that shot down a Korean Air Lines jumbo jet after it veered over sensitive military sites. He will be replaced by his deputy, Vladimir Mikhailov. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Executives are being named to new posts as Carat Interactive, Boston, part of the Carat Group unit of the Aegis Group, acquired two agencies: Lot21, San Francisco, which specializes in interactive and mobile marketing, for $2 million, and Vizium, Framingham, Mass., which specializes in e-mail marketing, for $700,000. Lot21 and Vizium are being merged into Carat Interactive, which will now have 100 employees and billings estimated at $200 million from clients like AT&T Broadband, Adidas, Bank of America and Pfizer. Kate Everett-Thorp, chief executive at Lot21, becomes chairwoman at Carat Interactive. Eric Wheeler, president and chief operating officer at Lot21, becomes chief operating officer at Carat Interactive. Also, Alan Osetek, president at Vizium, becomes senior vice president for electronic customer relationship marketing at Carat Interactive. Sarah Fay continues as president at Carat Interactive.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 3,113 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 7 about Yahoo's new corporate strategy referred incorrectly to comments from people involved in the company's efforts to buy Headhunter.net, an online job-listing site. They said that although Yahoo had not made a formal offer, it had been prepared to pay more than the $200 million offered by CareerBuilder, which eventually bought the site. They did not say that CareerBuilder's bid was less than Yahoo's final offer.

title: Student Project: Redesign Church Hit Sept. 11
description: As a professor of architectural technology, Tim Maldonado tries to find real-world projects for his students at New York City Technical College in Brooklyn. They have worked on a hospital floor for AIDS patients in Queens, a playground for children with Down syndrome on Long Island and buildings for the Con Edison site in Manhattan.

title: Rowland Hints At Layoffs And Tax Rise On Cigarettes
description: Thanks to a slowing economy further weakened by last fall's terror attacks, even wealthy Connecticut will soon see its 10-year string of budget surpluses come to an end. And with that reality sinking in, Gov. John G. Rowland has begun preparing lawmakers and taxpayers for a return to 1980's-style spending cuts.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Unrest In Southern City
description: Riot police officers in the southern city of Maan used tear gas to disperse demonstrators who set fire to the main police station and post office, ransacked other government buildings and looted a bank. The protests started over the death on Saturday of a 15-year-old boy held by the police on robbery charges. Relatives said he had been tortured to death; the police said he had died of kidney failure. In the past, unrest in Maan has spread throughout Jordan. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Qaeda Moving Into Indonesia, Officials  Fear
description: For the last two years, Osama bin Laden has been working to establish a beachhead here in the world's most-populous Muslim nation, say American and Asian officials. Members of his organization Al Qaeda have slipped in and out of the archipelago, bringing millions of dollars in cash for radical Islamic organizations, recruiting members, and providing military training, those officials say.

title: Stanley Marcus, the Retailer From Dallas, Is Dead at 96
description: Stanley Marcus, whose verve and flair in running the Neiman Marcus stores made him one of the world's best-known retailers, died yesterday at Zale Lipshy University Hospital in Dallas. He was 96.

title: U.S. Labels an Arab Captive A Planner of Qaeda Attacks
description: A terrorism suspect handed over to Americans last week by Bosnia and Herzegovina has been identified as a European lieutenant in Al Qaeda who was ordered to carry out attacks on American targets in the Balkans after Sept. 11, law enforcement and military officials said today.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Federal authorities announced today that the reward for helping to catch the anthrax mailer has been doubled, to $2.5 million, and that central New Jersey and part of Pennsylvania are being blanketed with fliers showing the four letters found so far.

title: Qaeda Role Suspected
description: A suspect handed over to Americans last week by Bosnia and Herzegovina has been identified as a lieutenant in Al Qaeda who was ordered to attack American targets in the Balkans after Sept. 11, law enforcement and military officials said.

title: Peggy Lee, Singer Whose Understated Style Kept Sizzling for Six Decades, Dies at 81
description: Peggy Lee, whose sultry singing style set standards for pop jazz sophistication for more than half a century, died on Monday night at her home in Los Angeles. She was 81.

title: The Mezzogiorno Comes Alive at Your Table
description: Baby wild artichokes and piquant caper flowers, wood-grilled onions and plump sun-dried tomatoes  those are earthy foods that seem far removed from the hypersleek Manhattan restaurant scene. But that's exactly where you'll find them, now that Tom Colicchio, the chef and owner of Craft, is importing an excellent new line of foods from southern Italy. The peppery marinated artichokes suggest a hint of anise, the lush eggplant in oil has a lovely sweetness and the slightly smoky tomato- eggplant preserves are more irresistible than peanut butter spooned right from the jar. The line, called CraftKitchen, is sold only at the restaurant, 43 East 19th Street, and next door at CraftBar, where they are used in some dishes. A 9-ounce jar of the condiments costs $8 to $12; the olive oils are $16 and $24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELFENBEIN, ELEANOR
description: ELFENBEIN-Eleanor. Born NYC September 23, 1920 died January 21st, 2002. Preceded in death by husband Mel. Funeral January 24, 2002 at 11 AM Higgins Memorial Home, 20 Center St, Freehold, NJ. Burial Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: Court Says Twins Stay; Baseball Is Defiant
description: It seems that everyone outside of Major League Baseball's central office is proceeding under the assumption that there will be 30 teams in 2002. Baseball fans are buying tickets to see 30 different teams, schedules that include 30 teams are being distributed, 30 teams with 30 managers are preparing for spring training.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMSTEIN, KYVER
description: BLUMSTEIN-Kyver. Age 95, in Palm Beach. Beloved husband of Esther Lurie for 66 years. Devoted father of Joseph Blumstein and Timmie Rome. Loving grandfather of Narric, Mallory, Greg and Jeffrey. President of L.M. Blumstein Department Store, founded 1886. Life long member of the New York Society for Ethical Culture. Visiting hours 7-9 PM Wednesday, 1/23 at Frank E. Campbell. Funeral Service Thursday, 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Society for Ethical Culture or a charity of your choice.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Energy Crisis
description: The government said an acute power shortage had affected nearly every aspect of the economy and everyday life from factories to agriculture to drinking water to public lighting. The report by the Korea Central News Agency blamed years of natural disasters for the problem and held the United States responsible for delays in construction of two nuclear reactors intended to provide electricity under a 1994 accord in which North Korea agreed to freeze its nuclear weapons program. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Transit Plan Would Connect Dots Downtown
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has put the finishing touches on an ambitious blueprint for rebuilding the crumbled transit network beneath Lower Manhattan, proposing to unite a tangle of unlinked train lines with a huge underground pedestrian concourse and moving sidewalks.

title: A Marathon Displays the Many Ways to Trick a Guitar
description: Strings, neck and resonator. Those are the basic elements of a guitar and the sole unifying factor for the 17 soloists and ensembles that performed at the Guitar Marathon on Sunday at the 92nd Street Y, the closing event in the six-day New York Guitar Festival.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 6 about the School Arts Rescue Program, a project assisted by The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund, misspelled the surname of the consultant who organized the program. She is Carol Fineberg, not Feinberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIER, MILTON
description: FEIER-Milton, 84. Of Tenafly, NJ. Passed away January 21st, 2002. Beloved husband of May Feier. Loving father of Ellen Stern, Olivia Lazarus & Jane Doft. Grandfather of Lauren and Daniel Doft and Avi Stern. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, January 23, 10:30 AM, at Gutterman-Musicant (Wien & Wien), 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, 201-569-2404.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, EDWARD ''TEDDY'' III
description: WHITE-Edward ''Teddy'' III, age 30, tragically but heroically on September 11, 2001 in the line of duty at The World Trade Center as a firefighter for The Fire Department of New York, Engine Co. 230. Loving husband of Jennifer. Devoted father to his daughter, Taylor. Beloved son of Regina and Edward Jr. Loyal brother of Jimmy, Chris, Suzanne and Billy. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. In celebration of his life, a memorial mass will be held at 11 AM on Friday, January 25, 2002 at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, 43-19 30th Ave., Astoria, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in his memory to The Burn Center Foundation, 21 ASCH Loop, Bronx, New York 10475.

title: Boy, 11, Arrested in Brooklyn And Charged With Sex Abuse
description: An 11-year-old middle school student who investigators suspect had sexually molested five female classmates over the past two months was arrested yesterday morning at his Brooklyn school, officials said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIVINE INC., Chicago, an Internet software maker and consultant, said it had acquired closely held Northern Light Technology, Cambridge, Mass., an Internet search engine, in an all-stock transaction.

title: An Espresso Runs Through It
description: IT'S quite possibly the simplest dessert imaginable: vanilla ice cream doused with coffee. To make it right, though, you must begin with rich ice cream -- preferably gelato -- and a shot of espresso, straight from the machine.

title: McGreevey Plans to Eliminate Some State Jobs
description: In his most dramatic step yet to address New Jersey's looming budget problems, Gov. James E. McGreevey said today that he planned to send layoff notices to more than 600 state workers beginning Wednesday.

title: Rights Groups Press for Names of Muslims Held in New Jersey
description: With about half the Muslim men detained on immigration charges after the Sept. 11 attacks now in county jails in New Jersey, advocacy groups are increasing their efforts to find out who, where and how many detainees are in custody there -- and to ensure their access to lawyers.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Insulation Against Airport Noise
description: Anchorage International Airport is starting a $15 million project to insulate nearby houses against noise. About 650 houses will be outfitted with noise-muffling materials at a cost of $35,000 to $50,000 each over 10 years. The modifications are part of a Federal Aviation Administration model that will include a system to match noise complaints to specific flights to see which planes stray from their flight plans. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

description: The Islanders are much more productive this season, but they can apparently generate only so much voltage. They open games with magnificent bursts, but then they seem to run low on fuel and watch hard-earned leads vanish like steam through a grate.

title: Department Plays Down Transfers Of Firefighters
description: When Edward McMellon, a former police officer involved in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, became a probationary firefighter at Engine Company 332 in Brooklyn in November, there were at least two black firefighters working in the East New York firehouse.

title: Bush Proposes to Add $48 Billion to Pentagon's Budget Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  President Bush said today he would ask Congress for $48 billion more in military spending next year  the biggest increase in two decades, since Ronald Reagan was in the White House and the Soviet Union and the cold war were American preoccupations.

title: Teachers Seeking Better Pay Stage Rare Protest in Tehran
description: For the second time in a week, thousands of teachers demonstrated here today to demand pay raises and better working conditions.

title: TITAN BUYS A MAKER OF RADAR SYSTEMS FOR THE MILITARY
description: The Titan Corporation, whose irradiation equipment is being used by the Postal Service to kill anthrax, agreed to buy the closely held Jaycor Inc. for $95 million in stock to attract military-electronics contracts. Jaycor makes radar and communications systems. Jaycor will add $45 million in sales this year and is expected to increase profit, the company said. Both companies are based in San Diego. Titan had sales of about $1 billion in 2001.
