title: Two Airlines to Ease Frequent Flier Rules
description: Northwest Airlines announced yesterday that it would be the first domestic airline to eliminate blackout dates from its frequent flier program, enabling its customers to redeem miles for travel on any day of the year.

title: Accounts
description: * Celebrity Cruises, Miami, part of Royal Caribbean Cruises, to Digitas, Boston and Miami, to handle its account, which had been handled by offices of West Wayne. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $30 million.

title: The Mdoc's Public Secret, Hidden by St.-Julien's Walls
description: WHEN I drive north from Bordeaux to the Mdoc, I usually take the back way through Macau, linking up with the main road through the vineyards just below Cantenac, which is part of the big Margaux appellation. I drive through the villages of Margaux, Soussans, Lamarque and Cussac-Fort-Mdoc. Then, up ahead on the right, I spot the imposing, elegant Chteau Beychevelle, with its formal French gardens, and I know I'm at the southern edge of St.-Julien.

title: EATON WILL CUT 1,100 JOBS AND FORECASTS SLUMP IN PROFIT
description: The Eaton Corporation, a leading maker of hydraulic equipment, will eliminate 1,100 jobs and said its 2002 earnings would be well below estimates because of slumping demand for industrial and aerospace products. Eaton now expects sales to decline 8 percent this year from 2001, the chief executive, Alexander Cutler, said, citing declining sales of truck parts and electrical controls. The job cuts represent about 2.2 percent of the work force of about 49,000 and follow the elimination of about 1,550 jobs last year. Sales should rise in 2003 by 8 percent to 10 percent, Mr. Cutler said. The company also reported that fourth-quarter income fell 48 percent, to $30 million, or 42 cents a share, as sales fell 13 percent, to $1.7 billion.

title: Connie Chung Gets CNN Prime-Time Spot
description: Connie Chung, who has been among TV's best-known news personalities for two decades, is moving from ABC News to CNN in what is the cable news network's latest effort to increase its roster of stars.

title: Treatment of Taliban Raises Concerns, Europeans Say
description: BERLIN, Jan. 23  The fury in Europe over the treatment of the Taliban prisoners in Cuba, European analysts and diplomats said today, stems from what appears to be another example of the United States bending international law to suit its own purposes.

title: Volcano-Scorched Congo City, Ground Shaking, Returns to a Nervous Kind of Normal
description: One of the first babies born since the eruption of Mount Nyiragongo last week was named Volcano by a woman who was still in search of two of her other boys. Men with sledgehammers helped build a road across the mound of lava dividing the town. In these and other ways, life began returning to normal in Goma today as residents lined up by the thousands for the first food and water that many had received in days.

title: Chatty Waiters? Innocent Diners? Just Half the Story; Give Waiters Some Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Lucent Says Sales Dropped But Shortfall Is Narrowing
description: Lucent Technologies reported its third consecutive quarter of lower sales yesterday but said sales might climb in the current quarter, holding out hope that the worst could be over. The company has nearly halved its work force and posted more than $16 billion of losses in the last year.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Schools Chief Faces Ethics Charges
description: A state ethics commission has found that the state schools superintendent, Stan Bunn, violated rules that bar the private use of his state cellphone, state car and frequent-flier miles earned on state trips. The director of the Government Standard and Practices Commission, Patrick Hearn, said a suit would be filed in Marion County Superior Court against Mr. Bunn, who has said he did not violate the law. With a fine of $1,000 for each of the 1,400 reported individual violations, Mr. Bunn faces the largest such penalty in state history, Mr. Hearn said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: White House Memo; 'West Wing' Rides Coattails of the Real Thing
description: As far as the White House is concerned, there is at least one significant difference between the real West Wing and the NBC television show of the same name.

title: A Dutch Touch in Flying (Right Down to the Flies)
description: VICTOR VAN DER CHIJS began his first board meeting at the new International Arrivals Building at Kennedy Airport promptly at 9 a.m. on Sept. 11. The meeting ended at 9:10.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Euro Zone: Inflation Steady
description: Annual inflation in the 12-member euro zone remained at 2.1 percent in December, the statistical office of the European Union, Eurostat, said. Inflation in the 15 countries of the European Union rose to 2.0 percent in December from 1.8 percent in the previous month. The highest rate, 5.1 percent, was in the Netherlands, and the lowest, 0.9 percent, was in Luxembourg. Initial estimates indicate that the euro zone had a trade surplus in November of 5.5 billion euros ($4.86 billion), down from 9.6 billion euros the previous month, the European Commission said. Paul Meller (NYT)

description: The National Basketball Association is suffering from declining ratings and the advertising marketplace is in a tailspin, yet those obstacles did not prevent AOL Time Warner and the Walt Disney Company from agreeing to new television deals worth $4.6 billion to the league over the next six seasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALETAN, HAROLD HENRY
description: SALETAN-Harold Henry. At age 91. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Florence (Bobbie Green) and Shirley (Goodman). Loving father of Jane Friedberg and Richard and Suzanne Saletan. Adored Poppy of Michael and Rhonda Friedberg, Marc & Holly Friedberg, Steven and Michelle Saletan, Karen and Mark Pacicca, and Elizabeth & Richard Berkman. Special great-grandfather of Benjamin Scott and Zachary Lee Friedberg, Stuart, Henry and Noah Ian Saletan & Emily Rose Pacicca. A graduate of New York University's School of Finance, Harold was a decorated W.W. II Army Veteran serving in General Patton's Third Army, Fifth Armored Division. As a Vice-President of the Empire Liquor Corporation he was known and admired throughout the liquor industry. His loving, gentle presence will be greatly missed by his family and all who knew and loved him. Donations in his name can be made to the International Myeloma Foundation, 12650 Riverside Drive, Suite 206, North Hollywood, CA. 91607, or to The United Mitochondrial Disease Foundation, 8085 Saltsburg Road, Suite 201, Pittsburgh, PA. 15239.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, CHARLES
description: GINSBURG-Charles. The Brotherhood Synagogue expresses its condolences to our Chairman of the Board, Carol Ginsburg, and her husband, Steven Ginsburg, on the passing of their son, Chuck. Our heartfelt prayers are also with his wife, Erica Okone, his sister, Marjory (Phil) Paone, and his grandmother, Sylvia Krentzman. A memorial service will be held at The Brotherhood Synagogue, 28 Gramercy Park South, on Sunday, January 27, at 2 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALI, ASAD, MD.
description: ALI-Asad, MD. The Medical Staff Society of New York Hospital Queens mourns the loss of its distinguished colleague and extends its heartfelt sympathies to his family. Marvin Leder, M.D., President Talat Addasi, M.D., Vice President Gabriel DeAngelis, M.D. Secretary/Treasurer

title: The Mezzogiorno Comes Alive At Your Table
description: Baby wild artichokes and piquant caper flowers, wood-grilled onions and plump sun-dried tomatoes -- those are earthy foods that seem far removed from the hypersleek Manhattan restaurant scene. But that's exactly where you'll find them, now that Tom Colicchio, the chef and owner of Craft, is importing an excellent new line of foods from southern Italy. The peppery marinated artichokes suggest a hint of anise, the lush eggplant in oil has a lovely sweetness and the slightly smoky tomato-eggplant preserves are more irresistible than peanut butter spooned right from the jar. The line, called CraftKitchen, is sold only at the restaurant, 43 East 19th Street, and next door at CraftBar, where they are used in some dishes. A 9-ounce jar of the condiments costs $8 to $12; the olive oils are $16 and $24.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Estonia: New Prime Minister
description: Parliament approved Siim Kallas as prime minister to replace Mart Laar, who resigned this month. Mr. Kallas, the former head of the central bank, has allied his pro-business Reform Party with the social democratic Center Party, which has sometimes called for a harder line in negotiations with the European Union on Estonia's joining the bloc. Difficult talks are expected on energy; Estonia wants to limit liberalization, and duty-free trade. The former Soviet republic, with a population of 1.4 million, has fallen behind its Baltic neighbors, Latvia and Lithuania, in talks on joining the union. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Press Law Delayed Again
description: Parliament again delayed discussion of a bill that would tighten government control of the press, prompting speculation that the governing party is divided on the wisdom of the measure. The bill, which would require that journalists be licensed and be citizens of Zimbabwe, has drawn widespread international criticism as the country gears up for a presidential election in early March. Earlier this month, Parliament passed new security and election legislation, and the press bill was expected to follow last week, but with each delay, its fate becomes increasingly clouded. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Steel Users Campaigning Against Curbs on Imports
description: A coalition of manufacturing companies that rely on steel imports has begun lobbying the White House and Congress to reject proposed restrictions on foreign-made steel, arguing that protecting ailing steel makers will cost consumers far more than it helps producers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREVAT, PETER D., M.D.
description: KREVAT-Peter D., M.D., 33. Died after a brief illness on January 20. Loving son and grandson to Ruth and Betty Love Zatrapeznoff of White Plains, cherished brother to Liz Krevat of West Islip. Also survived by his stepmother Vickie Hochman and two brothers, Rob and Scott. His father Jon Krevat and paternal grandparents Larry and Leona Krevat also survive him. Graveside service will be held today at 1:30PM at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions to your favorite charity would be greatly appreciated.

title: From the Beat of the Tom-Tom to Clapping and Finger Snapping
description: Kroumata, a Swedish percussion sextet, caught the attention of American listeners in the early 1980's, when a spectacular recording on the Bis label became a favorite test of the then-new compact disc system. The group was founded in 1978, and although it performed in New York with the Swedish baritone Hakan Hagegard in 1999, its concert on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall was its first full program on its own in New York.

title: Historian Says Publisher Quickly Settled Copying Dispute
description: The historian Doris Kearns Goodwin has acknowledged that her 1987 book, ''The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys,'' closely echoed sentences from the works of three other authors. She said that soon after the book's release her publisher, Simon & Schuster, reached a confidential agreement to settle accusations from one author, Lynne McTaggart.

title: Lamoriello's Frustration With Devils Leads to Moves
description: Saying he wants more of a commitment to winning from his players, Devils General Manager Lou Lamoriello took the first hard steps today in his effort to return the team to championship caliber, demoting two players and labeling the team's current level of play unacceptable.

title: Run, Osama, Run
description: On the way back from Kabul, I passed through Pakistan, the Persian Gulf, London and Belgium, where I had a variety of talks with Arab and Muslim journalists and business people and Muslim community leaders in Europe. All of them were educated, intelligent and thoughtful -- and virtually none of them believed that Osama bin Laden was guilty.

title: Parental Division as Downtown School Reopens
description: They were four blocks from ground zero, but the students returning to Intermediate School 89 yesterday were exuberant, hugging one another and clamoring to talk to reporters at the school gate.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Republican Gauges His Prospects
description: The former chairman of the Republican National Committee, Haley Barbour, now a lobbyist in Washington, told a coalition of conservative state legislators that he would not announce until the fall whether he would seek the Republican gubernatorial nomination next year. But in the clearest sign that he is serious, he said he would spend several months traveling to meet supporters and civic groups. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove, a Democrat who was elected in 1999, is widely expected to seek re-election.

title: Cavorting in a Three-Ring Cosmos Where Newton's Laws Share Top Billing
description: The universe is a circus. That appeared to be the message of ''Within Outer Spaces,'' the ingenious show that Capacitor presented on Sunday night at Here.

title: On Day After, the Knicks Have Much to Talk About
description: Allan Houston does not want to compare Don Chaney with Jeff Van Gundy. But the difference between the Knicks under the two coaches is so pronounced that comparison is inevitable. So when pressed today to say whether he could envision the Knicks' losing eight straight games, including Monday's 43-point debacle at Madison Square Garden, on Van Gundy's watch, Houston answered honestly, if reluctantly.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Syria's new cabinet misstated the given name of the industry minister. He is Issam Zaim, not Hisham.

description: With the size of two state Congressional delegations in the balance, the Supreme Court agreed today to hear Utah's challenge to a statistical method used by the 2000 census that cost the state a new House seat.

title: Audience Connection Gets Lost In Translation
description: Over the last 20 years, the use of projected English supertitles has ''given a shot in the arm to opera, for sure,'' the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne said to an audience that filled the Juilliard Theater on Friday night for the ninth annual Marilyn Horne Foundation recital. Since promoting the song recital is the purpose of her foundation, Ms. Horne continued, she decided to try an experiment in the first half of the evening's program and use supertitles to provide simultaneous English translation of the German texts to 18 songs by Mozart, Korngold, Brahms and Strauss.

title: Accounting Board Resigns Over New Plan
description: A five-member board that oversees ethics and disciplinary issues for the accounting profession announced today that it had resigned as a group after the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission proposed creating another body that could render the board irrelevant.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Final Spending Plans
description: In his eighth and final State of the State address, Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano expressed optimism at Hawaii's economic progress since Sept. 11 and emphasized a need for greater spending on education. Mr. Cayetano asked the Legislature to appropriate $255 million for public school repairs and to release $142 million to build a permanent branch of the University of Hawaii on the western side of Oahu. He said he would balance the budget by using the Hawaii hurricane fund and raising the liquor tax. Officials expect a $100 million tax shortfall because the Sept. 11 attacks hurt the state's top industry, tourism. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: Summerall-Madden Era Almost Over
description: Pat Summerall announced yesterday that his 21-year partnership with John Madden would end after the Super Bowl on Feb. 3. He insisted that he was not retiring, and that he might continue to work for Fox Sports.

title: Something New, Something Blue
description: Blue velvet cake looks disconcerting, like something in a David Lynch movie. But those neon layers iced with creamy chocolate are only the first thing to catch your eye at Angelina's, on the Lower East Side at 188 Orchard Street (Houston Street). The shop offers a good selection of breads and other baked goods, olive oil, pasta and sandwiches, in a neighborhood where you're more likely to find Chinese duck than imported tuna. That cake is a riff on the classic red velvet cake, said Angela Trento (near right with her partner, Megan Cariola). This variation, based on a recipe from Ms. Trento's grandmother, Angelina, is blue. A nine-inch cake -- sold on weekends and Wednesdays -- is $20, or $2.50 a slice.

title: Chief's Words Paint Hands-Off Image, but Actions Offer Different View
description: Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman of the Enron Corporation, more than once made a point last year of telling people how little he understood about the finances of the company he has run since 1986.

title: Court Sets Limit on Detaining Sex Offenders After Prison
description: The Supreme Court set a constitutional limit today on the growing state practice of keeping convicted sexual predators in extended civil confinement after their criminal sentences expire.

description: GREENBERG-Cassrell ''Casey.'' We all mourn this extraordinary man. He lived a full life touching many with his kindness, love and sense of humor. He will live in our hearts always. Survived by his devoted and loving wife Florence. Dear children Carl, Ellen, Ted and Tammy. Cherished grandchildren Seth, Lauren, Rachel and David. Dear brother of Frederique Gurtman. Services January 23, 1:30PM, Temple Israel, 112 E. 75 St., NYC.

title: Suicidal Nuclear Threat Is Seen at Weapons Plants
description: Since the suicidal terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, some experts on nuclear security are increasingly concerned that intruders could break into American weapons plants, assemble a nuclear bomb from materials there and explode it on the spot.

title: A Second Helping Of the Belle poque
description: The French culinary revolution -- the glorious period for breakthroughs like the birth of the modern restaurant and the fashion for toast at breakfast -- is being celebrated at an exhibition in Paris at the Muse d'Orsay on the Left Bank. The show, ''At the Table in the 19th Century,'' includes images of elaborate banquet dishes like a salmon decorated with crayfish, below, as well as posters, dinnerware, jewelry, paintings by Manet -- even a preserved asparagus from 1889. Part of the Caf Riche, a fashionable restaurant that opened in 1894, was reconstructed for the exhibition, which runs through March 3. Also, at the Arsenal library, near the Marais district on the Right Bank, cookbooks from the 14th to the 18th centuries are on display.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Officer Pleads Guilty
description: A former Nassau County police officer charged with coercing sex from a woman during a traffic stop more than a year ago pleaded guilty yesterday to third-degree attempted receipt of a bribe, the authorities said. The woman was a passenger in a car he pulled over for a traffic violation in October 2000. The officer, Jay Seifert, was initially charged with rape, but a grand jury found insufficient evidence for that charge. Mr. Seifert was indicted instead on lesser charges of coercion, receiving a bribe and official misconduct. He is to be sentenced March 12 and faces up to four years in prison, officials said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINER, SAMUEL
description: RABINER-Samuel. At age 90. Loving husband of Fay Soloway Rabiner. Devoted father of Barbara Bergstein with her companion Orin Finkle, and Bruce and Mary Rabiner. Adored grandfather of Elizabeth and Rob Heller, Jordan and Paula Bergstein, Shauna and Zasha Crupnick, and Danielle and Yariv Kafri. Great-grandfather of Jenna, Jason, Max and Ari. Dear brother-in-law of Kitty Sobin and Lee and Harry Protass. You will always be in our hearts. Services Wednesday, January 23, 11:15 AM, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: A Woman In Search Of Mother
description: Lauren Weedman's one-woman show ''Homecoming'' was first presented at the Westside Theater last fall. Following are excerpts from Anita Gates's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 21. ''Homecoming'' reopened on Monday at the Arclight Theater on the Upper West Side.

title: Museum's Stolen Chagall, or a Good Fake, Turns Up in Topeka Mail
description: In the shadowy world of art theft, it was a case to boggle the imagination. In June, a small painting by Marc Chagall was stolen from the Jewish Museum in Manhattan. A confounding ransom note later said the painting would not be returned unless there was peace in the Middle East.

title: Kind Words for Andersen
description: Last week, the Enron Corporation fired its longtime auditor, Arthur Andersen, during the company's accounting scandal. But not so long ago, Enron's chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, had only nice things to say about his auditors.

title: Sharpton Loses the Ring, But Never the Spotlight
description: IF it had come from almost anyone else, the gesture might have been an engaging exercise in humility. From the Rev. Al Sharpton, it came across as just another self-aggrandizing moment.

title: A FRAUD SUIT BROUGHT BY RAYTHEON IS DISMISSED
description: A judge dismissed the Raytheon Company's lawsuit claiming Towers Perrin caused the military contractor to overpay in its $9.5 billion purchase of a Hughes Electronics Corporation unit. Judge Manuel Real of the United States District Court in Los Angeles issued his ruling from the bench without hearing oral arguments from either side. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., claimed it overpaid based on Towers Perrin's mistaken statement that Hughes's pension plan had a surplus of at least $1 billion at the end of 1996. A Raytheon spokesman, David Polk, said the company would appeal. Towers Perrin is based in New York.

title: Topics of The Times; Camouflage on Clean Air
description: Victories for the environment, even small ones, come rarely in the Bush administration. So last week there was reason to cheer when John Ashcroft, the attorney general, said that as a matter of law the Clinton administration and a group of Northeastern states were justified in launching lawsuits against operators of 51 power plants that had failed to install pollution controls as required by the Clean Air Act. Yet the victory is almost certain to be temporary. Powerful forces inside the administration are determined to eliminate or weaken the provision of the Clean Air Act on which these suits were based. If that happens, the legal process involving the 51 plants will come to a halt and the nation will be robbed of a useful weapon against dirty air.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Reporter Found In Contempt
description: A judge found a journalist in contempt of court yesterday for violating a court order not to speak to jurors in the trial of a rabbi accused of arranging his wife's murder. The journalist, Carol Saline, a senior writer at Philadelphia magazine, faces up to six months in prison and a $1,000 fine. Ms. Saline's lawyer said she approached a juror Nov. 9 and asked him if he would speak with her after the conclusion of the case of Rabbi Fred J. Neulander, above. The lawyer told Judge Theodore Z. Davis of Superior Court that his client knew that what she did was wrong but meant no harm. The jury in the rabbi's trial deadlocked, and Judge Linda G. Baxter of Superior Court, who ordered the ban against interviewing jurors, declared a mistrial Nov. 13. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the On Stage and Off column of Weekend on Friday misidentified the sponsor of Hot Ink, a festival of play readings at New York University. It is the undergraduate drama department of the Tisch School of the Arts, not the university's Experimental Theater Wing.

description: Adapted from Korova

title: Russians Find Suspicions Fly As Network Goes Off Air
description: Russians who turned their television remotes early today to the TV-6 network expecting the movie ''Night of a Nightingale'' found instead a blank screen -- and later a tennis match from the sports network NTV-Plus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSOY, NATALIE ROGOFF
description: RAMSOY-Natalie Rogoff. On January 18, 2002. Born in Brooklyn, New York on August 25th, 1924. Beloved sister of Mortimer Rogoff and sister-in-law of Sheila Rogoff; loving aunt of Louisa Thompson, Alice Rubenstein, & Julia Rogoff, and great aunt of Alexa, Ellie & Andrew Rubenstein, and of Lisa Thompson. She was a graduate of Barnard College and the University of Chicago. In the United States she worked at both Columbia and Harvard Universities. Natalie emigrated to Norway in 1960 to become a Professor at the University of Oslo, and wife of Dr. Odd Ramsoy. She remained in Norway until 1994, having become the Director of the Norwegian Institute of Sociological Research. We remember her fondly, and with respect for her great achievements and leadership in the world of sociology.

title: Espresso in China Cups, Even in Martini Glasses
description: Coffee lovers who insist on sipping espresso from a china cup should elbow up to the bar at Crestanello Gran Caff Italiano, which just opened at 475 Fifth Avenue (41st Street). This sleek coffee shop and wine bar is the new American outpost for Antonio Crestanello, who opened his first cafe, in Vicenza, near Venice, nearly two years ago. Pastry includes big, lush bomboloni and other desserts ($1.95 and to $3.75 a portion; $23 to $28 for a whole cake) made just for the shop by Goupil & DeCarlo, a fine East Village bakery. There are also panini, salads, cold plates, crepes and pastas ($5 to $13). Coffee drinks include a shakerati, an espresso shaken with ice and served in a martini glass. Tables are on two levels, with waiter service on the balcony. Hours: 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. weekdays, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. weekends. The menu is available to go: the only time paper cups are used.

title: Public Affairs Post at Hunter
description: JENNIFER J. RAAB, the president of Hunter College, reached back to the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, where she was previously chairwoman, for a new director of external affairs for Hunter: TERRI ROSEN DEUTSCH, who served as chief of staff at the commission. Ms. Rosen Deutsch will be responsible for building Hunter's relationships with city and state agencies and with elected officials and for developing partnerships with museums, hospitals and other institutions.

title: Stigma of AIDS Strong in Ukraine
description: No one outside a small sympathetic circle knows that Iren is infected with H.I.V., not even her mother. Telling, she said, would only ''make trouble.'' It would also invite unkind assumptions, given the way AIDS has cut through Ukraine, the nation with the worst problem in a region where the disease is spreading with alarming speed.

title: Salads That Bloom in Winter
description: I CAN'T imagine a meal without salad.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bond Default
description: The Fujian International Trust and Investment Corporation, which was closed by China's central bank last month, said it would default on 14 billion yen ($104 million) of bonds. Liquidators ordered a halt to bond payments while they wind up business at the corporation, which was the investment vehicle for Fujian Province, according to a statement on Dec. 29 in The Fujian Daily. China is closing almost 200 trusts after the 1998 failure of Guangdong Trust, under about $3 billion of debt. Fujian Trust is one of several companies that have struggled to pay debts after lenders cut off credit.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Flat Profits At Lever
description: India's largest company, Hindustan Lever, said a general economic slowdown kept its profits nearly flat in the fourth quarter, despite a 4.3 percent rise in sales to 27.6 billion rupees ($571 million). The company said it planned to grow by developing new consumer-product brands to take advantage of its distribution network in the rural villages, where most of India's one billion people live. Many of Hindustan Lever's best-selling brands, like Surf detergent and Lifebuoy soap, originate overseas. Saritha Rai (NYT)

description: LICHT-Esther. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of one of our founding members, wife of the late Meyer, and extends to Arnold and Louise our heartfelt condolences.

title: Mayor Tells New Firefighters He Won't Skimp on Training
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that although the city's budget would not be able to cover all the needs of the Fire Department, New York would still go ahead with plans for a new $50 million training center for probationary firefighters, as well as a new command center for the city's Office of Emergency Management. The old command center, known informally as the bunker, was destroyed in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Man Is Shot To Death
description: A co-owner of a bodega was shot to death yesterday shortly before 8 p.m. in an apparent robbery, the police said. A co-worker in the back room of the store, the Azzel Deli, was not injured. The police said they did not know how many people shot the co-owner, 40. He was pronounced dead at the store, at 1804 Richmond Avenue. The police did not release his name, pending notification of family. No one has been arrested, said Detective Cheryl Cox. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Exemption Won In '97 Set Stage For Enron Woes
description: As it expanded aggressively overseas in the 1990's, the Enron Corporation won an exemption from a Depression-era law that would have prevented its foreign operations from shifting debt off their books and that barred executives from investing in partnerships affiliated with the company.

title: Where All Paris Can Be Found, Indulging in the Afternoon
description: IT is freezing here, often gray, and the air is damp enough to make halos around the lampposts along the Pont Neuf. But Paris in winter is still a magical place, and to savor one of its most delicious pleasures, you have only to walk into a cafe late in the afternoon when the windows fog over from the warmth of so many people sitting knee to knee.

title: Senate Offices Reopen
A Name in a Cold Continent
description: Some people have buildings named after them. Others have plants named after them. Now there is a prominent rock ridge in Antarctica bearing the name of ROBERT L. DE ZAFRA, professor emeritus in the physics and astronomy department at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. The United States Board on Geographic Names named de Zafra Ridge, which is on Longhurst Plateau in the Cook Mountains of Antarctica. Professor de Zafra and his colleagues showed that chlorine from chlorofluorocarbons was responsible for a seasonal ozone hole over Antarctica. They used techniques they developed for making remote measurements of stratospheric trace gases. Last year, a long-neck sauropod dinosaur was named for another Stony Brook professor, the paleontologist DAVID W. KRAUSE. Karen W. Arenson

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: F.D.N.Y. Logo Unchanged
description: Like many official logos of city departments, the emblem of the Fire Department of New York includes an image of the World Trade Center. Although many organizations like movie studios and television production companies have deleted the towers from films and other images as a too-raw reminder of the Sept. 11 attack, the Fire Department has decided to keep the towers. ''There are absolutely no plans to change the emblem of the Fire Department,'' Nicholas Scoppetta, the new fire commissioner, said yesterday.

title: In Phoenix, a Drug Theft May Have Led to Murder
description: He was on the phone with a detective on Dec. 14, providing more information about how his accomplices had stolen a large shipment of human growth hormone. Suddenly, the detective heard a loud scream. Then the phone went silent.

title: Sports of The Times; Ordinary Punctuality Could Help Knicks in Extraordinary Times
description: IT was 12:20, just past noon, and Latrell Sprewell came into the Knicks' locker room in Madison Square Garden Monday in time for the 1 p.m. tipoff against the Charlotte Hornets. The other 11 players on the team were in their uniforms -- the league rule is that players should be in the locker room an hour and a half before game time -- and they were ready to play, or thought they were, anyway. Sprewell, 50 minutes late, then donned his basketball garments and was ready to play, too, or thought he was.

title: Espionage? By the U.S.? China Prefers To Stay Quiet
description: A Chinese government spokesman offered a muted reaction today to disclosures that a presidential jet outfitted in the United States had been crammed with listening devices, and his comments suggest that China would not let the incident upset plans for the first state visit by President Bush next month.

title: A Neighborhood Wine Bar With a Provenal Accent
description: THE full-scale arrival of Italian wine-and-panini shops in the last few years has been a great thing, especially for the neighborhoods lucky enough to get a good one. The combination of salads and sandwiches made with simple, fresh ingredients, along with wines available by the glass, make these the perfect informal hangouts, whether by day when the rest of the world is either at work or at Starbucks or for the after-hours crowd.

title: Corrections

title: An AOL Unit Sues Microsoft, Saying Tactics Were Illegal
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation, the commercial pioneer in Web browsing software, whose fortunes faded after a withering assault from Microsoft, filed a broad antitrust suit yesterday against the company. Netscape charged that its decline was a result of Microsoft's illegal tactics, echoing many of the findings in the government's case against the company.

title: As Streaks Collide, Only Seles's Survives
description: Venus Williams did what she could. She called for the trainer when her body started to hurt in yet another place. She kept serving for the lines. She read through her notebook of tennis reminders on changeovers: ''Head down. Stay down. Racket speed.''

The program is intended for students who wish to work in areas of the law like intellectual property, health, drugs and telecommunications, said PATRICK HOBBS, dean of the law school. Peter Valdina

description: Two years ago the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council accepted Sonya Sklaroff, a painter known for evocative cityscapes, into a program that gave artists studio space in the World Trade Center. During her six months there she produced a series of vertical pictures in black and white that depicted views from her 91st-story window in Tower 1.

title: U.S. Picks Its Freestyle Skiers
description: The United States Ski Team yesterday announced the 14-member freestyle team expected to compete at the Salt Lake City Olympic Games next month, a group with five former Olympians, including the defending gold medalists Jonny Moseley in the moguls and Eric Bergoust in aerials.

title: People
description: * Marty Donohue, a senior vice president and group creative director at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was promoted to executive vice president and executive creative director. Mr. Donohue, who becomes the top creative executive for the Hill, Holliday Boston office, takes on creative duties that had been handled by Mike Sheehan, who was promoted last month from president at the Boston office to the new post of president for the United States operations of Hill, Holliday, which also has offices in New York and San Francisco.

title: Some Memorable Lunacy On Layers of Refinement
description: Marc Ribot's musicianship is broad, with plenty of room for character, both his own and that of others; the wonder is that the character doesn't swallow up the musicianship. His early set at Makor on Thursday night, part of the 92nd Street Y's New York Guitar Festival, was split between solo guitar performances and duets with James Chance, and if the solo portion presented further refinement of Mr. Ribot's art, the duets were memorable lunacy.

title: Residents of 'Free Kashmir' Vow to Keep Fighting
description: Signs of a crackdown on Islamic militants can be seen here in what Pakistanis call ''Free Kashmir,'' where the police have closed the offices of several groups and splashed fresh paint over graffiti supporting the fighters who slip across the border to wage an insurgency against Indian forces on the other side.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Starting Fee-Based Search Service
description: The search engine and Web portal company Yahoo plans to introduce a fee-based search service today. The company said that the service, Premium Document Search, would let users search for articles and other documents from more than 7,100 newspapers, trade journals and other sources. Users may view each document for a $2.95 fee, or they can pay $4.95 a month to view up to 50 documents. Yahoo said that it would continue to offer its free service.

title: Patricia Hearst Says Good May Come From Murder Trial
description: Patricia Hearst Shaw, the heiress to a newspaper fortune and former kidnapping victim of the Symbionese Liberation Army, said tonight that she remained horrified by the group's acts of violence and that a coming murder trial might resolve the case for relatives of a woman killed in a 1975 bank robbery in which Ms. Shaw admits playing a role.

title: Twice-Cooked, Full of Flavor
description: FILIPINO cuisine, unlike so many other Asian cuisines, has never really taken off in America. And so when I serve chicken adobo, I almost always get the same amazed response, something along the lines of ''This is the best chicken dish I ever tasted.'' Just last week, my not-easy-to-please 16-year-old daughter was marveling over it.

But although tobacco companies have complained before about the commercials made by the American Legacy Foundation, one company is now formally threatening legal action against the organization, apparently for the first time.

title: Unaccountable in Washington
description: The first of at least 11 Congressional hearings into the largest corporate bankruptcy in United States history begins tomorrow. Although Enron's executives and accountants have much to answer for, they can be forgiven for cracking a wry smile when members of Congress begin lecturing them on their dereliction of duty: Congress itself, as much as Enron and Arthur Andersen, bears some responsibility for the current state of affairs.

title: Swiss Knife Sales Slide at Airports
description: For years, tourists stopped in at the Coutellerie du Mont-Blanc shop in the Geneva airport and scooped up as many as a dozen Swiss army knives, the mainstay of the tiny business, to take back home as souvenirs for family and friends.

title: Topics of The Times; The Gloom at the Garden
description: Basketball fans booed themselves hoarse as the New York Knicks bumbled through one of the most embarrassing losses in franchise history at Madison Square Garden on Monday night. The players and coaches are to blame for that 111-68 drubbing at the hands of the Charlotte Hornets and for the longest Knick losing streak in nearly 15 years. It's hard to believe a group of highly paid professional athletes could play with so little motivation or pride. But the ultimate responsibility for the team's decline lies with the front-office managers who have wasted draft choices and initiated a series of unimaginative trades.

title: A Bridge to Sicily /World's Longest Span Proposed : Italy Envisions an Engineering Masterpiece
description: EVER since Odysseus skirted between the six-headed monster called Scylla and the whirlpool of Charybdis, seamen have feared the rocks and fast-running currents of the Strait of Messina separating Sicily from the Italian mainland.

title: Patriots Shop at Filene's Basement
description: They are locker mates, the National Football League reject and the N.F.L. retread. Jermaine Wiggins is a too small, too slow, often-cut but loquacious tight end from East Boston, Mass. David Patten is a soft-spoken wide receiver from South Carolina who is humbled to have found a home with the New England Patriots.

title: FOX WILL LEASE ITS SATURDAY MORNING SLOT TO 4KIDS
description: Fox Broadcasting will lease its Saturday morning programming slot to 4Kids Entertainment Inc. for $101.2 million over four years, making Fox the second network to leave the children's time period. 4Kids will pay Fox about $25.3 million a year, the company said in a federal filing. The deal comes amid a slowdown in advertising sales on television, including the periods when children's shows run. 4Kids, based in New York, provides children's programs like Pokmon.

title: Pashtuns, Once Favored by Taliban, Now Face Retribution in Afghanistan's North

He says he was attacked by ethnic Uzbek fighters, and he is just one of hundreds of Pashtun villagers who say that Uzbek troops are looting, raping and kidnapping under the guise of disarming Pashtuns in northern Afghanistan.

title: A Half Moon That Brightens Kitchen Labors
description: THE mezzaluna, with its half-moon-shaped blade and knobby handles at each end, possesses the simplicity of a tool like the hammer. Its design recalls an earlier time, before the food processor, and before home cooks had knife skills worthy of a restaurant kitchen. Instead, it seems like something you would expect to see in a Chardin painting next to an austere bunch of leeks.

title: Judge Accused Of Taking $18,000 Bribe
description: A State Supreme Court justice was arrested yesterday on charges that he solicited and took an $18,000 bribe from a lawyer in a civil case in Brooklyn, the first time in 15 years that a justice of the Supreme Court has been charged with bribery, officials said.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Approval For Redistricting
description: Gov. Gary Locke signed a law validating the Redistricting Commission's plan for new legislative and Congressional boundaries. The panel completed redrawing 49 legislative districts and 9 Congressional ones on Jan. 1, just before a constitutional deadline. The commission had five members, two Democrats, two Republicans and a nonvoting mediator. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Final Appeal For Berenson
description: A lawyer for Lori Berenson, the New Yorker serving a 20-year prison term in Peru for collaborating with leftist rebels in a plot to attack Peru's Congress, asked the country's top court to overturn her sentence. A five-judge panel of the Supreme Court has up to 15 working days to decide whether Ms. Berenson's conviction last June after a three-month trial was justified. The appeal is the final avenue in Peru's legal system open to Ms. Berenson, who argues that her rights were violated in a sham trial that relied on shoddy evidence. Her conviction last year, in a civilian court, followed a conviction in 1996 by a military tribunal, which sentenced her to life in prison. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Hamburg Journal; 'Judge Merciless' Thinks All Germany Needs Him
description: Ronald Schill, known in the press as ''Judge Merciless,'' came into office in this elegant and seamy city state on a tide of disgust with crime and immigration, shaking political assumptions. Now he is thinking about going national.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: A Tool To Pursue War Criminals
description: Parliament ratified a new extradition treaty with the United States, giving both nations a potentially powerful new tool to bring remaining World War II criminals to trial. The treaty replaces one signed in 1923, which falls short of international legal standards and is limited to extraditing foreigners. The new treaty permits extradition of any accused felon and also allows Lithuania to refuse extradition of accused people who might face the death penalty in the United States. The Simon Wiesenthal Center last year issued a list of 97 Lithuanians suspected of genocide, 37 of whom were said to live in the United States. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: ALLERGAN TO SPIN OFF EYE-CARE UNIT AND FOCUS ON DRUGS
description: Allergan Inc. plans to spin off a business that makes contact lenses and eye-surgery devices to concentrate on medicines that treat ailments including skin disease and muscular pain. The company intends to give shares in the new publicly traded entity, Advanced Medical Optics Inc., to Allergan investors by midyear. The eye-care unit had sales of $551 million last year, about a third of Allergan's total $1.69 billion. Allergan, based in Irvine, Calif., said the split would help increase per-share earnings growth at the drug unit by as much as 25 percent and revenue by more than 15 percent. The operations are moving in different directions, with medicine sales climbing 15 percent last year, while eye-care revenue fell 4.8 percent.

title: N.F.L. Expansion Draft: Big Names on the List

In fact, the draft is like an opulent yard sale where teams make available some of the highest-paid players in the organization, hoping to unload a once-prized commodity on a new buyer.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nomura Earnings Slip
description: Net income at Japan's largest brokerage, Nomura Holdings Inc., fell 81.5 percent in the nine months ended in December, as the stock market slid to near 18-year lows and demand for new share listings declined. Nomura earned 28.6 billion yen ($215 million) because of a 30 percent decline in brokerage commissions, which make up about one-third of the company's revenue. A decline in initial stock offerings led to a 25 percent decrease in underwriting commissions. Nomura Holdings listed its shares in New York last December. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Dr. Herchel Smith, a chemist who developed a process to synthesize hormones for birth control pills and then gave millions of dollars he earned from the patents to support academic research, died on Dec. 20 at his home in West Chester, Pa. He was 76.

description: The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, said today that he would consider firing members of a commission charged with reviewing requests for tax reductions in the wake of reports that politically connected residents received significant tax breaks.

description: ASCH-Stuart S., M.D. The Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine, the faculty, staff and candidates of the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague, Stuart Asch. Dr. Asch, a supervising and training analyst at the Center, was an active and valuable member of the psychoanalytic community. We remember him as a man of great sensitivity and humor and an inspiring teacher to several generations of psychiatrists and psychoanalysts. We extend our sympathy to his wife Mary Trudel, his children, stepchildren, and grandchildren. Robert A. Glick, M.D. Director, Psychoanalytic Center Vivian Pender, M.D. President, APM

description: In life, Mayor T. R. Gallo of Kingston, N.Y., had decided to put his office in the grand old City Hall, a renovated Victorian building that came to symbolize his tireless efforts to rebuild the fortunes of this struggling Hudson Valley city. The building had been abandoned in the 1970's and largely forgotten until the mayor campaigned for its restoration.

title: GENCORP DELAYS ITS RESULTS TO REVIEW ACCOUNTING ITEMS
description: GenCorp Inc., which makes aerospace supplies and chemicals, delayed the release of its fourth-quarter and full-year financial results for a review of accounting items and costs at two auto parts plants. The plants are part of GenCorp's GDX Automotive unit, which reported a $2 million profit for the first nine months of fiscal 2001. The company said it might have to revise quarterly results from last year. It closed two GDX plants and laid off 760 workers last March.

title: The Governor's 'Monsoon' Budget
description: Gov. George Pataki unveiled an $88 billion financial plan for next year that would close a huge gap with a breathtaking array of fiscal gimmicks. It relies on more than $3 billion siphoned away from reserve funds, some of them nearly unknown to people outside the tiny circle of state budget experts. Mr. Pataki is running for re-election this year, and if he is hoping that voters will not understand what he's doing to make the numbers add up, he is probably right. Even in New York, a state famous for the incomprehensibility of its fiscal planning, this budget would have to win a special award for opaqueness.

title: Jitters in Japan for Savers and Banks
description: As Japan's debt-sodden banks stagger to the end of the fiscal year in March, the impending end of the government's blanket guarantee on bank deposits is causing skittish savers to pull their money out of the country's smallest lenders, sinking some and potentially generating a wider economic crisis, with larger banks also at risk.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Loss Meets Expectations
description: Motorola reported yesterday that it had lost $1.24 billion, or 55 cents a share, on sales of $7.32 billion in the last quarter of 2001. Excluding results from discontinued operations and $1.1 billion in after-tax charges for plant closings and other actions that Motorola termed unusual events, the company lost 4 cents a share in the quarter. That figure was in line with what the company had warned analysts to expect last month. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

description: Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts criticized President Bush's energy plan today as ''old thinking'' that would not end the nation's dependence on foreign oil, becoming the latest prominent Democrat to stake out his differences with the president.

title: Calculating the Square Root of Sadness
description: In the final scene of Sarah Schulman's ''Carson McCullers (Historically Inaccurate),'' a young female student visits the dying McCullers in her hospital room and professes the devotion of a reader who has found her own life story in the work of a writer. Partly in the language of a senior thesis in semiotics, partly in the plaintive bleat of a besotted paramour, the student provides the love that McCullers feared she'd never experience. The student, whose name is Madeline, then reads to the immobile McCullers from the 23rd Psalm, and the lights come down.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Escaped Prisoner Is Caught
description: A prisoner who escaped from a Department of Correction van this month has been recaptured, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Omari Scott, 21, was arrested on Monday in an apartment, though prosecutors would not say where or whose. Mr. Scott now faces an escape charge, in addition to the assault, witness-intimidation and criminal-contempt charges for which he was awaiting trial, said Orlando Rivera, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney's office. On Jan. 9, he freed himself from restraints and bolted from a van taking prisoners to central booking in downtown Brooklyn. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank's Profit Declines
description: Fourth-quarter profit at Santander Central Hispano, Spain's largest banking group, fell 20 percent, the first decline in at least five years, as the bank set aside more money to cover costs in Argentina. Net income fell to 493 million euros ($436 million), or 11 cents a share, from 616 million euros, or 14 cents, a year earlier. Santander set aside 537 million euros in the fourth quarter to cover investments in Argentina, bringing the total to 1.29 billion euros. Santander said it would stop investing and leave the country only if the financial system collapses. ''Our presence in Argentina depends on the banking system remaining viable,'' the chairman, Emilio Botin, said.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Grant For Police DNA Testing
description: The Abell Foundation, a Baltimore charity, is giving the city's Police Department a $350,000 grant for DNA testing of evidence from unsolved violent crimes. The DNA will come from evidence stored in a police crime laboratory freezer. Investigators will then search for matches in state DNA databases. Gary Gately (NYT)

Offered in some trades and rumored in more, Payton probably has the best chance to be the Mets' opening day center fielder.

title: Mocking Social Custom Since the 17th Century
description: Doa Angela, a beautiful young widow, thinks chastity does not become her, especially when it is enforced by her two brothers, and the scheme she devises to escape her affliction provides the comic plot for one of the world's most enduring comedies, ''The Phantom Lady'' (''La Dama Duende''), by Pedro Calderon de la Barca. The play's free-thinking, skeptical mockery of social customs and its celebration of women who ignore them are so modern that it is difficult to believe it was written by a Spanish courtier before 1630.

title: PROFIT FALLS 49% IN THE FOURTH QUARTER AT EXXON MOBIL
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation said profit fell 49 percent in the fourth quarter as lower energy prices reduced revenue from oil and natural gas production. Net income declined to $2.68 billion, or 39 cents a share, from $5.22 billion, or 75 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue fell 26 percent, to $47.3 billion from $64.1 billion, as the company's oil output fell. Exxon's chief executive, Lee Raymond, said that profit margins on refining remained weak and that jet fuel sales had fallen. Earnings from oil and gas production fell 55 percent, to $1.67 billion, compared with the period a year earlier. Refining and fuel marketing profit fell 12 percent, to $1.02 billion.

The oil patch surrounding Odessa is depressed by the drop in gasoline prices, and the Permian High School's once-celebrated Panthers have not won a state championship in a decade.

title: At Barneys, Designer Space Goes Midcentury Modern
description: The Madison Avenue branch of Barneys New York invited Evan Lobel (inset) to invade its sales floor. It saw a potential collaboration between its store and his, Lobel Modern, which has an unusual mix of midcentury modern originals. ''There's a lot of overlap between our clientele,'' Mr. Lobel said. His dining area vignette on the fourth floor in the women's designer area, above, has a Tommi Parzinger 1940's dining table ($15,000), a 50's candelabrum (also by Parzinger, $1,500), a 50's sideboard by Edward Wormley ($7,500) and porcelain and brass Stiffel 50's lamps ($3,000 the pair). The displays will change themes every few weeks. All items are available from Lobel Modern, 207 West 18th Street (212-242-9075). Barneys is at 660 Madison Avenue (61st Street).

title: Judge Grants A Suspension Of Lawsuit On Napster
description: A federal judge has granted a request by four of the five major record companies to suspend their three-year-old lawsuit against Napster, the Internet music service that exploded in popularity by allowing users to freely exchange songs and was deemed by the record companies a threat to their existence.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Firefighter Imposter Pleads Guilty
description: A man who posed as a firefighter after the Sept. 11 terror attack pleaded guilty yesterday in state Supreme Court in Queens to attempted criminal possession of stolen property and scheming to defraud. Prosecutors said that the man, Jerome Brandl, 34, claimed he was a Wisconsin volunteer firefighter, and as such, stayed at Engine Company 39 for a week, receiving catered meals and free tickets to a Mets game, and stole a Fire Department pass that he used for free tolls and parking. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said he expected Mr. Brandl to receive a sentence of one to three years in prison. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Directions From a Device That Knows Which Way Is Up
description: The compass, it seems, is old hat. Its replacement: the Global Positioning System, satellites broadcasting to a thick black antenna strapped to a wayward car, backpack or, in this case, electronic organizer.

title: Incongruously, Moldova Samples the Club Scene

In an economy that has shrunk by 60 percent since the breakup of the Soviet Union a decade ago, the average Moldovan salary is between $25 and $45 a month, life expectancy has dropped by five years, and living conditions are abysmal.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens Posts Profit
description: Siemens, the German electronics and engineering company, posted its first profit in three quarters and said it might cut more jobs in addition to the 20,000 already announced, as demand for phone networks falls. Siemens, based in Munich, earned 538 million euros ($477 million) in the three months ended in December, compared with a 1 billion euro profit in the quarter a year earlier, the chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, said in a conference call. Siemens may step up job cuts at the networks business after orders fell 22 percent, Mr. von Pierer said. The unit had a quarterly loss of 124 million euros.

title: Audit Changes Are Facing Major Hurdles
description: Congress appears reluctant to impose stricter standards on the accounting profession, an industry that is among its largest political patrons, despite public and presidential expressions of outrage over the failure of auditors to warn investors of the perilous condition of Enron before they lost tens of billions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, GEOFFREY D.
description: HOLLAND-Geoffrey D. ICM Artists mourns the loss of a respected colleague and extends its sincere condolences to the Holland family. We will deeply miss Geoff's dedication and kindheartedness. David V. Foster, President and CEO Lee Lamont, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHT, ESTHER
description: LICHT-Esther. The entire Long Island College Hospital (LICH) family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Esther Licht, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague, Arnold Licht, M.D., Chairman, Department of Psychiatry. To Arnold, his family and loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. John Wren, Chairman Board of Regents, LICH Vice Chairman, Board of Trustees Continuum Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Board of Trustees, Continuum Peter A. Kelly, President and CEO Continuum Mark McDougle, Executive VP and COO, LICH Jagdish Gupta, M.D., President Medical Board, LICH

title: Bloomberg Names Special Mayoral Adviser
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday named Kevin Sheekey special adviser to the mayor, one of the last high-profile jobs to be filled in his administration.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Lagging Law Enforcement Interviews
description: One month after the federal deadline passed, officials in Eastern Michigan have interviewed fewer than half the Middle Eastern or Muslim men in their area wanted for questioning after the Sept. 11 attacks. Of the 521 men sought near Detroit, 44 have left the country, 36 have moved out of state and 8 have declined the voluntary interviews. Law enforcement officials have been unable to find 56 of the men, and they are still waiting for reports on 119 others. The interviews are part of a nationwide canvass of 5,000 Middle Eastern or Muslim men ages 18 to 33 in the United States on temporary visas. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Heaven Is a Corner Of Upstate New York
description: The athletes marched briskly through the hallways of the graceful Mirror Lake Inn in this Olympic town last week, their competition credentials swinging from their necks as they rushed from one post-event confab to another. They were downhill skiers, speed skaters, ski jumpers, bobsledders and members of Nordic combined teams.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column last Thursday about the $62,000 settlement of a lawsuit against the Village of Ossining by the family of Christopher Malone, a man shot by the police, referred to him incorrectly. Mr. Malone had a gun, though it was not resolved whether he had turned it on the officers; he was not unarmed.

title: Dim Those Fluorescents
description: To the Editor:

title: CORNING LOST $655 MILLION IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: Corning Inc. said its fourth-quarter loss widened sharply on expenses for job cuts and inventory write-downs and a 53 percent decline in sales. It lost $655 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with $58 million, or 6 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales fell to $974 million from $2.08 billion. Corning has eliminated 12,000 jobs, or 28 percent of its work force, and closed plants amid a slowdown in demand for its products. Corning recorded $308 million in pretax expenses for cutting jobs and terminating leases; $306 million to account for a drop in value of plants idled last year; $90 million associated with a change in an employee stock plan, and $60 million to write off obsolete inventory. Excluding costs for the job cuts, plant write-downs and $35 million in pretax acquisition costs, Corning said it would have had a loss of $261 million, or 28 cents a share.

title: In Personal Anecdote, Some See New Distance Where Others See New Strategy
description: To listen to President Bush, it was almost as if an epiphany involving his mother-in-law drove him to turn on the Enron Corporation, his most generous political benefactor. In assailing Enron on a trip Tuesday to Belle, W.Va., Mr. Bush said, ''My own mother-in-law'' lost all of her investment when the company's stock collapsed.

title: Labor Dept. Reviews Ban On Stock Sale
description: The Labor Department is reviewing whether the Enron Corporation acted properly when it told its employees they could not sell Enron shares in their retirement accounts at a time when the shares' value was evaporating, agency officials said today.

title: Drawn to the Hearth's Electronic Glow
description: WHEN Rick Rombach was looking for a house 18 months ago, he had one particular requirement. It needed a room he could dedicate to his home theater.

title: Philips Asks, Is HDTV In the Eye of the Beholder?
description: Philips Consumer Electronics will market new 30- and 34-inch televisions this spring that will be able to convert standard-definition video signals transmitted by broadcasters, cable and satellite networks into pictures of a quality closer to that produced by high-definition TV's.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Stricter Rules On Reporting Abuse
description: The State Senate voted to require that clergy members report past evidence of sexual abuse to state authorities, not just evidence of current sexual abuse. The bill, which now goes to the House, goes beyond a new Boston archdiocese rule that does not require reporting past abuse. The Legislature's actions come as the Roman Catholic Church is embroiled in the case of John J. Geoghan, a former priest who is accused of abusing 130 children. On Friday, Mr. Geoghan was convicted of indecent assault on a 10-year-old boy, and yesterday he was ordered to undergo 30 days of psychiatric evaluation before his sentencing. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: The Conditions at Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: American Intellectuals: Unsung, Uncited
description: To the Editor:

title: Expert Panel Cites Doubts On Mammogram's Worth
description: An independent panel of experts said today that there was insufficient evidence to show that mammograms prevented breast cancer deaths.

title: Creating Space, and Privacy, Where There Wasn't Any
description: Guests are coming, the bed isn't made, and who has time to pick up all those magazines? Quick, set up the telescoping Penelope curtain rod ($125) from Industrielle of France, which allows you to create a temporary scrim without any additional hardware or tools. Designed by Jrme Lart, the mobile Penelope curtain rod is made of flexible carbon tubes that can be extended from around 6 feet to more than 11 feet, and will support a load of 2.2 pounds.

title: An American With Opinions Steps Down Vocally at War Crimes Court
description: In the circumspect world of the judges at the United Nations war crimes tribunal, Patricia M. Wald has stood out and knocked down quite a few taboos. To begin with, there was her American-style informality in a place of stiff etiquette.

title: Some Witchcraft From Cy Coleman and Friends
description: Cy Coleman, the Broadway composer and pianist best known as the musical hand behind brash, strutting star turns like ''Hey, Look Me Over!,'' has always been something of a musical chameleon. And on Friday at Carnegie Hall, where the New York Pops Orchestra under Skitch Henderson devoted a full evening to celebrating his contribution, Mr. Coleman revealed another side of his musical personality.

title: Morale and Occupancy Are Low At the Headquarters in Houston
description: Inside the glass-sheathed 50-story Enron headquarters here, the televisions that once carried news and financial channels in the elevators have been turned off. ''ETV is under construction,'' the monitors now read.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Tellabs Loss Is 20 Cents a Share
description: Tellabs Inc., the biggest maker of equipment that manages traffic on phone networks, said yesterday that its quarterly sales and earnings had dropped, but that its business was stabilizing and that it had maintained positive operating cash flow throughout 2001. The company's loss was $80 million, or 20 cents a share, in contrast to income of $294.9 million, or 71 cents, a year earlier. ''We are encouraged to see signs of stability in the United States, driven by customer demand,'' Richard C. Notebaert, chief of Tellabs, said in a statement.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Magistrate Urges Use Of Confession
description: Robert Larsen, a federal magistrate, recommended that the confession of a pharmacist who told the F.B.I. that he had diluted chemotherapy drugs be allowed at his trial. Lawyers for the pharmacist, Robert R. Courtney, argued that the confession was inadmissible because Mr. Courtney thought he was negotiating a plea agreement. The magistrate said the request to suppress the confession should be denied because Mr. Courtney's lawyers were told that the government did not want to negotiate a plea and that no specific plea offer was made. A federal judge will make the final decision. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Big Dreams Of Broadway Fulfilled; Youthful Group Who Bet On 'Urinetown'
description: When the musical ''Urinetown'' opened at Henry Miller's Theater on Sept. 20, the crowd included many of Broadway's opening-night regulars, a group in which gray hair and recollections of the Kennedy assassination are plentiful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIER, MILTON
description: FEIER-Milton. Lincoln Square Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of Mr. Milton Feier, beloved father of our esteemed member, Ellen Stern. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Ken Cappell, President

title: The Essentials: Stoves and Rocks
description: IT'S best to buy a wood stove and other sauna paraphernalia near home. Stoves are heavy, and if you order from Finland you will pay as much for shipping as heating.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Expedia Buys a Tour Company
description: Expedia said it had agreed to buy a Classic Vacation Group Inc. unit for $82 million in cash, stock and assumed liabilities to add sales from traditional travel agencies. Buying the unit, Classic Custom Vacations, will expand Expedia's wholesale business and deepen its offerings in locations like Hawaii and Mexico, executives said.

title: Study Finds a Growing Gap Between Managerial Salaries for Men and Women
description: The difference in managerial salaries for men and women in American industry grew from 1995 to 2000, a Congressional study has found.

title: Pataki Proposal Raises Hopes For a New Teachers' Contract
description: A proposal by Gov. George E. Pataki to give New York City schools $204 million has raised hopes among education officials that a new contract for the city's 80,000 teachers may be reached in the next few weeks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday summarizing the previous week's developments in the collapse of the Enron Corporation misstated the timing of an online chat session in which the company's chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, answered employees' questions. It was conducted on Sept. 26, not in October.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Telecommunications Loss
description: BCE, which controls Canada's biggest phone company and a diverse stable of media properties, posted a net loss from continuing operations of 326 million Canadian dollars ($202.7 million), or 40 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 2001, in contrast to earnings of 4 million Canadian dollars, or a penny a share, a year earlier. The latest figure includes BCE's share, totaling 347 million Canadian dollars after tax, of restructuring and other charges at Bell Canada, the phone unit in which it owns 80 percent. The results were in line with analysts' expectations. Revenue climbed 8.5 percent, to 5.7 billion Canadian dollars. The company, which is transforming itself into a multimedia conglomerate, said it had had strong growth in subscribers to its wireless, high-speed Internet and satellite television services. Jean Monty, BCE's chairman and chief executive, said he expected the restructuring to be completed in late 2003 or early 2004.

title: More Grants to Help Downtown Art Groups
description: In yet another attempt to help arts organizations hurt by the events of Sept. 11, the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts today announced $600,000 in emergency grants for New York City arts groups below 14th Street.

title: Court Asked to Revive Case Against 2 in Salt Lake City Bid Scandal
description: With the sting of the bidding scandal long passed, the Justice Department today asked a federal appeals court to reinstate charges against two men who were accused of bribing Olympic officials to secure the 2002 Winter Games for Salt Lake City.

title: CALENDAR
description: Looking In

title: Police Say Sergeant Kills Man Who Refuses to Put Down Gun
description: A police sergeant shot and killed a man in Washington Heights last night after the man ignored orders to put down a shotgun he was holding and ran off instead, law enforcement officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHLESINGER, MARY EDDY
description: SCHLESINGER-Mary Eddy. A service to celebrate her life will be held at 1 PM, January 26, 2002, at The Congregational Church, Main Street/Route 44, Salisbury, CT. During the service, family and friends will be invited to share their memories. Please join the Schlesinger family after the service in the parish hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, HOWARD H.
description: SHAPIRO-Howard H. Loving father of Michael (Marcy) and David (Susan). Dear brother of Bernice Schiff. Cherished grandfather of Rebecca & Ben. Dear companion of Sheila Andrews. Services on Friday 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Rita & Howard Shapiro Memorial Scholarship Fund at Sophie Davis School or Biomedical Education at CCNY, 138th Street & Convent Avenue, Room J909, NY, NY 10031, would be appreciated.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Software Sales Gain Expected
description: A leading maker of business management software, SAP, forecast that sales would increase about 15 percent in 2002, as software spending revives in the second half of the year. The German company, which has 15,000 customers, said it had been winning market share from competitors even as fourth-quarter profit fell 13 percent on losses at a partner, Commerce One. SAP's sales increased 7 percent in the fourth quarter, which compared with 30 percent a year earlier. Net income fell to 319 million euros ($283 million) from 367 million.

title: No Appeal on TV At Moussaoui Trial
description: A cable television network announced today that it would not appeal a judge's ruling that barred cameras from the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, who the authorities say was meant to be the 20th hijacker on Sept. 11 and is the only person charged in the attacks.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Molecule-Sized Machines Advance
description: Hewlett-Packard and the University of California at Los Angeles said that they had received a United States patent on technology that may prove useful in wiring together the molecule-sized switches that a growing number of scientists and engineers say may one day lead to a new kind of ultra-tiny electronics. A number of start-up and large companies are now pursuing the idea of molecular electronics, which might come into play at the end of this decade, when traditional silicon-based microelectronics are expected to reach fundamental limits. The patent, issued to Philip J. Kuekes and R. Stanley Williams of Hewlett-Packard Laboratories and James R. Heath of U.C.L.A., is titled Molecular-Wire Crossbar Interconnect for Signal Routing and Communications. No one has yet proved that molecular-scale computing is possible, but some researchers are increasingly confident that they will be able to make machines of Lilliputian size, several orders of magnitude smaller than the tiniest transistors now forecast. John Markoff (NYT)

title: A Long, Bitter Feud Is Tipping Sharon's Way
description: Ariel Sharon had just become Israel's foreign minister when he arrived in Maryland in October 1998 for talks to salvage the Middle East peace process.

title: City Reviewing Investment Strategy for Its Pensions
description: The pension funds for New York City's firefighters, teachers, police officers and other workers lost $109 million in Enron investments and $25 million in Kmart investments, leading the city comptroller to say yesterday that he was considering a change in how the funds invest.

title: Fleury Fined $1,000 for Flashing Ire at Fans
description: A contrite Theo Fleury arrived at Madison Square Garden yesterday $1,000 poorer after he was fined by the National Hockey League for making obscene gestures as he left the ice following the Rangers' come-from-behind 5-4 victory over the Islanders Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum.

title: At Long Last, Paychecks for Afghan Civil Servants
description: It is payday at long last in Afghanistan, and after months of penury the lucky few are taking home their first wages since last July dreaming of simple things.

description: Congress's failure to renew an unusual antinarcotics program that used flowers to fight drugs means that tariffs are now being collected on roses, carnations and certain other products imported from four South American nations for the first time in a decade.

title: Corrections
description: Charts on Jan. 18 through 21 showing holiday travel schedules for Martin Luther King's Birthday (on the 21st) included an erroneous summary of New York City parking rules supplied by the Department of Transportation. Alternate-side regulations were suspended; other normal regulations -- not Sunday rules -- were in effect. The Times regrets the error.

title: Robert Nozick, Harvard Political Philosopher, Dies at 63
description: Robert Nozick, the intellectually nimble Harvard philosopher whose critique of America's social welfare system 25 years ago continues to define the debate between conservatives and liberals, died yesterday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 63.

title: Sales Drop Reported For Licensed Goods
description: Retail sales of licensed merchandise in North America declined last year, according to the 25th annual licensing industry survey by The Licensing Letter, a newsletter published by EPM Communications in New York.

title: Hingis, True To Form, Is Finalist In Australia
description: Martina Hingis shrieked with delight and surprise. Her last shot of the match had landed dangerously short in the court, and Monica Seles moved forward with an excellent chance of keeping their Australian Open semifinal going.

title: City Escapes
description: The 92-room Fitzpatrick Manhattan and 155-room Fitzpatrick Grand Central in New York and the 120-room Fitzpatrick Chicago have a variety of Valentine's Day deals for Feb. 14. The two New York hotels offer Bound for Romance on Broadway, with two tickets to "Mamma Mia!," a one-bedroom suite and a Continental breakfast for $450. The two hotels also have Roses and Romance, with a deluxe room, a dozen roses and in-room Continental breakfast for $199. In Chicago, the package includes a suite, a bottle of Champagne and a full breakfast, for $159. Tax and service are extra. Offers subject to availability; (800) 367-7701, on the Web at www.fitzpatrickhotels.com .

title: Democrats Review Changes in Bankruptcy
description: In the wake of the bankruptcy filing by the Enron Corporation, some Democrats in the Senate are weighing whether provisions of a bill to overhaul the bankruptcy code should be reconsidered. They are also looking at changes that would make the bill friendlier to consumers.

description: To the Editor:

title: A woman known for TV shows aimed at women is now chief programmer at male-tilted UPN.
description: WITH the UPN network recently placed under his control, Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS Television, wasted little time in inserting his own chief programmer.
