description: To the Editor:

title: What's Black and White and Rhythmic All Over? Ask Peter Martins
description: ''Hallelujah Junction,'' Peter Martins's eighth and latest ballet to music by John Adams, is a spare and elegant work, the black-and-white equivalent of the propulsive Technicolor fantasias Mr. Martins has choreographed to other Adams scores.

title: The Limits of Servers
description: To the Editor:

title: An Unlikely Coach
description: The first thing you notice about Tyrone Willingham is how small he is. He's 5-8 and very slight, almost delicate-looking. He dresses neatly, even fastidiously. He has a mustache that is carefully trimmed and his hair is cut very short. You might guess he was a high school teacher.

title: Brooklyn Casino Boat Set to Sail Once More
description: The slot machines wait glistening, the boat lies at anchor, and shipboard gambling is poised to make its triumphant return to the slate-green waters off Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, tomorrow night after a two-year absence.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online On the Rails
description: Amtrak, with help from Yahoo and Compaq Computer, began offering free wireless Internet service on some of its trains. The service is available on Amtrak's Acela Regional, between Washington and Boston; the Capitols, between Sacramento, Oakland and San Jose; and the Hiawatha, between Chicago and Milwaukee. Amtrak mounted Compaq iPAQ Pocket personal computers on the trains, with Yahoo providing wireless connections. While electrical outlets for laptops are scattered throughout the trains, the interactive service is available only on the Compaq machines, which are in one car of each train, an Amtrak spokeswoman said.

title: The Euro Catches On, Despite Some Confusion in Italy
description: The SuperBowl bowling alley here warns customers before they even get their shoes: it will accept payment only in euros, not in German marks.

title: Putting a Value on Lives
description: There has been mounting criticism from the families of the victims of Sept. 11 that the compensation fund established last year by Congress is unfair. Indeed, Kenneth Feinberg must occasionally wonder why he ever took the job of administering the multibillion-dollar fund. The preliminary rules he devised to govern its payouts have been relentlessly attacked as too stingy, not only by victims at the bottom of the income scale but also, increasingly, by those at the top.

title: The Conditions at Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Case On Far-Right Party Postponed
description: The country's highest court postponed hearings planned for next month on a government proposal to ban the far-right National Democratic Party after learning from the interior ministry that a leading party member due to testify in the case had been an informer for the domestic intelligence service. Anti-Semitic statements by Wolfgang Frenz were to be used as evidence against the party. Interior Minister Otto Schily said that the government had stopped using him as an informer in 1995 and that the evidence related to statements made earlier. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Picking Up Static While Fine-Tuning a Play
description: The perennial lament about the dearth of new plays makes this a difficult argument to uphold, but here it is anyway: It isn't always a good thing when young writers are encouraged to continue developing promising early works.

title: Economic Scene; Optimism needs a warning label when it comes to forecasting productivity.
description: ONE tantalizing question in economics these days is whether productivity will rise as rapidly after this recession as it did in the late 1990's. If productivity -- the output of the economy per hour of work -- grows robustly, so will the economy. But if it does not, wages will not rise rapidly, profits will be weaker, and federal revenue will be much lower than expected. America may again find itself in a state of political confusion and disarray, just as it did in the slow-growing era from 1973 to 1995.

title: Enron Chief Quits Under Pressure And Calls Inquiries a Distraction
description: Kenneth L. Lay resigned this evening as chairman and chief executive of the Enron Corporation under pressure from outside creditors, nearly two months after his company filed for one of the largest bankruptcies in the history of American business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, DON
description: GREENE-Don. Role model, big brother & good friend. The world is a better place because of Don. Bud and Marilyn

title: Fair Local Phone Rates
description: The New York Public Service Commission helped jump-start competition for local phone service yesterday when it ordered Verizon to further discount the wholesale rate at which it leases its lines to competing companies trying to enter the New York market. The move is not only beneficial to state consumers; it could be of vital importance to the nation's overall economy.

title: Beethoven for a Contemporary Generation
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra was at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, reminding us of a distinctive character and stubborn personality that no recent music director has been able to quell or significantly add to. The lower strings rumble with a kind of seismic elegance; the violins glow with a breadth that never thickens or congeals. The orchestra's departing music director, Wolfgang Sawallisch, conducted, but Murray Perahia playing Beethoven's First and Third Piano Concertos was the center of attention.

title: Europeans Win in Tourney But 2 Americans Can Smirk
description: One of the world's great tournaments, founded in 1987 under the name Staten Bank, apparently came to the end of the road in The Hague on Sunday. The Ernst & Young Cap Gemini event, which assembles 16 of the world's best partnerships each January, will not be played next year unless another sponsor is found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUGH, CAROLYNE (NEE) FOWLER
description: PUGH-Carolyne (nee) Fowler. On January 22, 2002 of Rutherford, NJ. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Devoted mother of Roberta Fontenla. Funeral from Macagna Diffily Funeral Home, 41 Ames Avenue, Rutherford, NJ on Thursday at 1 PM. Interment at George Washington Memorial Park Cemetery. Born in Hartford, CT. Died Hackensack Med. Ctr.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Not Guilty Pleas In Killing
description: Four teenage boys pleaded not guilty in the killing of a 10-year-old boy who was fatally stabbed in November 2000 as he returned home to a rough housing project in southeast London from an after-school computer class. The slain boy, Damilola Taylor, a Nigerian immigrant who had been in London for just four months, bled to death after being stabbed in the leg in a deserted stairwell five minutes from his home. The trial of the three 16-year-olds and one 14-year-old is expected to last up to three months. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Car Bomb Kills Former Chief of Christian Militia in Lebanon
description: CAIRO, Jan. 24  Lebanon relived a moment drawn from its brutal civil war today when a powerful car bomb detonated in a Beirut suburb, assassinating Elie Hobeika, a former Christian militia chieftain turned politician.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Labor Official Reappointed
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has reappointed James F. Hanley, left, as commissioner of labor relations. Mr. Hanley, 53, has held the position since his appointment by Mayor David N. Dinkins in 1991. The commissioner represents the mayor's office in all labor relations. Mr. Hanley first went to work in the labor relations office about 30 years ago. He served as first deputy commissioner in the labor office under Mayor Edward I. Koch. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: A Lull in Europe on Hewlett-Compaq Deal
description: Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer have not offered to sell any operations in Europe to secure a quick approval of their $23.6 billion merger by European regulators, people with knowledge of the investigation said today.

title: Gigante Is Sane And Runs Mob, U.S. Charges
description: Vincent Gigante, the convicted Mafia chief who was sometimes called the Oddfather because he wandered around the streets in a bathrobe, infuriated prosecutors for years by fending off charges with claims that he was too mentally ill to be a boss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, STANCIE W.
description: ROBINSON-Stancie W. Age 81, in NY. Widow of the late William E. Robinson. Dear friend to many. Active supporter of many charities. She will be sorely missed. No memorial service. Memorial contributions may be sent to the William E. Robinson Foundation, 255 W. 88th Street, 13A, NY, NY 10024. M. David Sherrill

title: Head of Health Workers' Union Leaves the Democratic Committee
description: The president of New York City's largest union of health care workers, Dennis Rivera, resigned from the Democratic National Committee yesterday. Mr. Rivera, who has signaled that he might support the re-election bid of Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, said he was resigning because he was overextended, not because of any differences with the party.

title: International Objet Lesson From Paris
description: GLOBAL fusion. That was the message from the Maison et Objet show last week near Paris. This international fair of housewares and furniture included the striped bedding designed by the Belgian Valrie Berkowski and made in Morocco; brilliantly colored Italian furniture; and tin plates from Senegal, paired with fine German porcelain. Gone were the chopsticks and rice bowls from Vietnam; the new Vietnamese lacquerware is in classical European forms of vases and lamps. Even outside the convention hall, home wares from Morocco, Japan, India and France were displayed together. On the Left Bank, the Galerie Downtown paired works by Jean Prouv, a French designer of midcentury modern furniture, and contemporary pieces by Choi Byung Hoon, a Korean designer. This season there is truly a United Nations of style.

title: Merrill Lynch Posts $1.3 Billion Loss
description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that it had lost a record $1.3 billion in the fourth quarter, after it took a charge to pay for cutting jobs and closing offices.

title: For a Downtown Parent, Shock Waves Won't Quit
description: THE telephone is ringing incessantly in Sharon Sprague's SoHo loft on a recent afternoon, and she tries to ignore it. She looks beat, saying she has been waking up at 4 a.m., her mind spinning with worries about Public School 89, four dusty blocks from ground zero.

title: Many Ride Out the Recession In a Graduate School Harbor
description: The sagging economy has created a bonanza of applicants for the nation's schools of business, law, journalism, education and many other graduate programs as laid-off workers and college seniors are deciding to wait out the recession by honing their skills.

title: Protests by Refugees Spread, Putting Pressure on Australia to Act
description: Pressure is mounting on the Australian government to resolve a hunger strike by hundreds of asylum seekers whose condition is deteriorating as they resort to increasingly desperate measures to protest their detention at a remote facility in the outback.

title: Sharpton, in Houston, Calls Attention to the Workers
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton pulled up to RJ's Rib Joint this afternoon to meet with local ministers, a state representative, an N.A.A.C.P. official and a victim of the Enron collapse.

title: Metro Matters; Pataki Takes Roosevelts To Heart
description: DISCUSSING his new budget on Tuesday, Gov. George E. Pataki stood before a portrait of his favorite predecessor, Teddy Roosevelt, inviting inevitable comparisons.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Air Accord With Iraq
description: The deputy transport minister, Behzad Mazaheri, announced that Iran would soon start using Iraqi airspace for direct flights to Syria and would resume flights to Iraq, its former bitter enemy, ''once suitable grounds are prepared.'' The decision was made after the Iraqi transport minister visited Iran last week. Many Iranian pilgrims visit Shiite sites in Syria and Iraq. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Trade Center Tenants Find Deposits Tough to Recover
description: Hope remains that many millions of dollars in government aid will come, that insurance payments and charitable grants will help cover what was lost. But for some tenants in the World Trade Center, the first cash to help them start over is coming indirectly from their own pockets -- in the form of returned security deposits.

title: Mayors Seek Payback of Spending on Security
description: The nation's mayors came to Washington today asking to be repaid for the billions they say they have spent defending their cities from terrorist attacks, and Tom Ridge, director of homeland security, said the administration would offer them ''unprecedented support.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the relationship of Martha Stewart to the Kmart Corporation misstated her role. While Ms. Stewart's company has a contract giving Kmart exclusive rights to an array of product designs, she is not a member of its board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENG, YANG, CHAI
description: FENG-YANG-Chai. Former Director of the Security Council and Political Committees of the United Nations, died at age 94 on January 18, 2002. Born in China, he attended Tsinghua University, graduated from Stanford University in 1931, and did graduate work at the University of Illinois and the London School of Economics before embarking on a diplomatic career spanning four decades. He served as First Secretary of the Nationalist Chinese London Embassy during World War II and participated in the UN's work from its inception at both the Dumbarton Oaks and San Francisco Conferences. He joined the newly formed Secretariat in 1946 as an international civil servant, ultimately becoming Director in the Department of Political and Security Council Affairs. During his tenure at the UN, he was also appointed Secretary of numerous committees, including the Committee of Experts of the Security Council, the Committee on Admission of New Members, the Palestine Conciliation Commission, the Committee for Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, the ad hoc Committee on the Seabed, and the Special Political Committee. Ever devoted to world peace, he was central and influential in the Security Council's response to international crises until his retirement in 1970. Later he became a lecturer, research fellow, UN consultant, and US citizen, spending his leisure years in California and Hawaii. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Chi-Hui, and loving children and grandchildren.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Cuts Shares
description: The British retailer Marks & Spencer said it would return $2.9 billion to shareholders and reduce the number of shares held by stockholders. The chairman, Luc Vandevelde, has been winning the battle to turn around the troubled retailer recently by cutting costs, improving merchandise and selling assets, including the Brooks Brothers chain in the United States. For every 21 shares they own, investors will get 17 new ordinary shares and 21 Class B shares, which are redeemable for 70 pence (about $1) each in cash. Investors can also retain the Class B shares and get a dividend instead. The program is expected to reduce the number of shares outstanding to 2.3 billion from 2.8 billion. The government's tertiary industry index, which tracks spending on everything from banking to theme parks, jumped 1.7 percent in November from October, as demand for cellphones and recreation rose. title: NEWPORT, AN EQUIPMENT MAKER, BUYS MICRO ROBOTICS
description: The Newport Corporation, which is based in Irvine, Calif., and makes equipment used to produce semiconductors and fiber optic parts, plans to acquire Micro Robotics Systems for $55 million to $65 million in cash and stock. Micro Robotics, a closely held company, makes assembly and dispensing systems for fiber optic communications. Micro Robotics could add $15 million to $18 million to Newport's sales in 2002, the chief financial officer, Chuck Cargile, said. Micro Robotics, based in Billerica, Mass., had sales of $25 million in 2001.

description: In one of the most spectacular and swift reversals of fortune in the entertainment industry, EMI Records said yesterday that it had ended its agreement with Mariah Carey, who has had more No. 1 songs than any musical artist except Elvis Presley and the Beatles.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: New Headache For President
description: Prosecutors said they would question a nephew of President Kim Dae Jung's wife about his role in a salvage project that has led to the jailing of a businessman on charges of embezzlement and stock manipulation. The investigation is the latest in a string of inquiries and scandals that have dogged the president. Prosecutors want to ask Lee Hyung Tack about his role in a company whose stock price rose on reports of hidden treasure on a sunken ship off the southern coast. The price plunged when the treasure hunt failed. The president's spokesman denied charges by the opposition Grand National Party that Mr. Lee, former executive director of the government's Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation, had run a slush fund for Mr. Kim. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: Dispute Won't Block Czechs
description: A senior European Union official said a dispute between Austria and the Czech Republic over a Czech nuclear reactor would not affect the Czechs' application to join the union. The far-right Freedom Party, a member of Austria's governing coalition, wants the government to veto the Czech Republic's entry if it does not shut the Temelin reactor, 35 miles from the Austrian border. But Eneko Landaburu, the union's director general for enlargement, said the issue of the plant, which has been plagued by technical problems, is ''outside the enlargement process.'' Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Yale and Unions Extend Deadline
description: Yale University and its two major labor unions agreed yesterday to extend their contract deadline to March 1. The possibility of a strike arose after the current contracts expired on Jan. 20. Last week, the unions, which have engaged in seven strikes against Yale since 1968, and the university vowed to adopt a new, more cooperative approach. The unions, part of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union, represent 3,900 clerical, technical, service and maintenance workers. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: 2 Named To Labor Panel
description: President Bush made two recess appointments to the National Labor Relations Board, naming two management-side labor lawyers. The two appointees are Michael J. Bartlett, director of labor law policy for the United States Chamber of Commerce, and William B. Cowen. John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, criticized the appointments, calling them ''a troubling sign.'' The Constitution allows presidents to bypass Senate confirmation of nominees by making temporary appointments when the Senate is in recess . Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Budget Includes Tax Increases
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber announced a proposal that includes tax increases to balance Oregon's budget and ease a $830 million deficit. The governor said he would call the Legislature into a special session to consider the plan on Feb. 8. In addition to $414 million in cuts, Mr. Kitzhaber, a Democrat, proposed three new revenue sources: a repeal of a measure that lowered taxes paid to the state, an increase in beer and wine taxes and an increase in the cigarette tax by 30 cents a pack. The proposal is likely to face opposition from the Legislature, which has suggested $525 million in cuts. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: U.S. Says Officials In Puerto Rico Stole For Party and Profit
description: A wave of corruption scandals that has already led to dozens of arrests of officials and police officers crested today with the federal indictment of 17 people, including a former education secretary charged with stealing money for himself and for his political party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCH, STUART S., M.D.
description: ASCH-Stuart S., M.D. A devoted uncle. Physicianly to the end. Described as a ''dazzling'' teacher, he inspired the younger generation of his family along with his many students. We will miss him. Jane Asch, M.D.

title: Scientists Unlock Major Clue About How Anthrax Kills
description: Scientists have worked out the exact three-dimensional structure of edema factor, the last of three components in the deadly toxin produced by the anthrax bacterium. The knowledge should help both in understanding how edema factor works and in devising drugs to block it.

title: A Crime Boss Clouds Inquiry On Shooting In Calcutta
description: The telephone jangled in the offices of The Telegraph on Tuesday, just hours after gunmen on motorcycles strafed police officers guarding the American Center here with automatic gunfire, killing 4 and wounding 17.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton Township: 2 Arrested In Deer Protest
description: Two people were arrested on Monday during a demonstration against the township's annual deer hunt. Michael B. Hamilton, the mayor of Roosevelt, N.J., and Carol A. Knott, a resident of Hillsboro, N.J., were part of a group of about 18 people protesting the thinning of the deer population. Mr. Hamilton and Ms. Knott were charged with trespassing and were released on their own recognizance. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Discouraging 'Social Promotion'
description: Baltimore's public school system decided to require elementary and middle school students to receive passing scores on standardized national tests to be promoted to the next grade. The policy, intended to reduce ''social promotion'' of failing students, will be based on results of the Comprehensive Test of Basic Skills. Had the policy been in effect last school year, about 25 percent of students in Grades through 5 would have scored too low to be promoted, the school system said. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Pakistan Will Hold Elections in October, Military Chief Says
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 24  Pakistan's military leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, confirmed today a plan to allow free elections for the national and provincial assemblies in October. But he also made it clear that he will remain in power as president and watch for signs of the corruption and chaos that led to military takeovers.

description: The GO RVing Coalition in Reston, Va., a group of companies involved in the recreational vehicle industry, has narrowed a review for its account to four agencies from seven. Billings were estimated at $40 million over three years.

title: Pope Leads Prayer for Peace
description: ASSISI, Italy, Jan. 24  Pope John Paul II convened an unusual one-day gathering today of leaders of a dozen religions  including Muslims, Jews and Christians  to affirm the principle that "whoever uses religion to foment violence contradicts religion's deepest and truest inspiration."

title: Corrections
description: Charts on Jan. 18 through 21 showing holiday travel schedules for Martin Luther King's Birthday (on the 21st) included an erroneous summary of New York City parking rules supplied by the Department of Transportation. Alternate-side regulations were suspended; other normal regulations -- not Sunday rules -- were in effect. The Times regrets the error.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Increase In Park Fees
description: The Natural Resources Commission raised state parks fees for the second time in less than a year. The new fees, which range from a $1 increase for park admission fees to a $4 increase for annual park passes, take effect on Feb. 1. The commission increased similar fees last year. The higher fees are expected to add $2 million to the state parks budget over the next 18 months. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Amgen Profit Falls 23%
description: The big biotechnology company Amgen Inc. said that fourth-quarter net income fell 23 percent because of costs related to ending collaboration agreements. Net income fell to $163 million, or 15 cents a share, from $210.8 million, or 19 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 18 percent, to $1.12 billion from $951.4 million. Excluding expenses of $243 million, or 15 cents a share, mainly from Amgen's termination of collaborations with Praecis Pharmaceuticals Inc. and Guilford Pharmaceuticals Inc., profit would have been 30 cents a share, the company said. The company's shares rose $2.40, or 4.2 percent, to $58.46.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SETON, STANLEY, DDS
description: SETON-Stanley, DDS. On January 22nd. Adored husband of Adele, cherished uncle of Tony, Jennie, Nora, Maggie, Julie, Wendy, Richard, Simone, Joel, Beverly, Charles and Lois. Loved by a multitude of friends. Served in the U.S. Army in WW II and as a Captain in the Air Force in the Korean War. Was a clinical instructor in oral surgery at Polyclinic Hospital. His work was his life. He was considered the best by the best. title: Who Helped Cheney?
description: Last February, President Bush announced the formation of a task force, led by Vice President Dick Cheney, to develop energy legislation. While task forces are not new -- Hillary Clinton headed one to develop health-care legislation -- they are uncommon, and they raise questions when they work in secret. In the case of Mr. Cheney's energy task force, these concerns are heightened because of both his and the president's strong ties to the energy industry, as former oil executives and as recipients of large campaign support from the industry.

title: Editorial Observer; Finding Out How the Neighbors Are Faring
description: According to the venerable Adam Smith, ''the great commerce of every civilized society is that carried on between the inhabitants of the town and those of the country,'' who are, he writes, ''mutually the servants of one another.'' In some deep-down sense that must still be true, though everything has changed since those words were published. Food still comes from farms, and farmers still buy products made in cities. Farmers, of course, never forget that reciprocity. But to city dwellers, who now make up nearly the entire population of America, agriculture tends to look, unfortunately, like an afterthought, a remnant industry fighting in Congress for a disproportionate share of the national wealth.

title: Below Stairs: Evenings in a Brooklyn 'Steam Bath'
description: Some people believe a steam bath is a great place to recover from a night on the town. Barbelow in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, offers the look and feel of a steam bath in the bar itself. Stephen Ng, a co-owner of the bar, did the designs himself; his partner, Raymond Tung, did the work, building the shapes and meticulously tiling the seamless, curved bar and seating area, above. A small depression at one end of the bar has a blue glass ''crystal'' that emits a puff of smoke, a reference to the heated stones in a sauna. (The rock has already been stolen once; its replacement is now secured.) The back lounge, to the left, opened this month; the bare bulbs on the wall are hidden behind a scrim of taut white tulle. The scattered floor cushions and small translucent tables, lighted from within by candles, are all from Ikea. There is even a small patch of real grass under a Lucite panel.

title: The Neediest Cases; Furniture, A Steady Job And a Vision For Herself
description: Cassandra Matthews liked working at Charlie Brown's Steakhouse in Mount Holly, N.J. Her co-workers were friendly, her hours were manageable, and tips were good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZ, LOLA
description: GEWIRTZ-Lola. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Lola Gewirtz, beloved mother of Dorothy Berman and mother-in-law of Julius Berman, extraordinary supporters and cherished friends who are devoted to maintaining a strong and vital Jewish community. Dorothy is a member of UJA-Federation's Commission on Jewish Identity and Renewal and Julius is a member of UJA-Federation's Board of Directors. May the legacy of their mitzvot bring them comfort in this time of mourning. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Putin's Message to the Media
description: The recent decision of Russia's Higher Arbitration Court to dissolve TV-6, a national television network, has been described as marking the end of large-scale independent broadcast journalism in Russia. The truth is both less and, potentially, more dramatic. Russian television has a vibrant, extensive web of local and regional TV stations; not all free speech has come from Moscow. However, the attack on the national stations may well have serious effects on regional journalism, including a return to the self-censorship that was such a noticeable feature of the Soviet decades.

title: The PC as D.J., Talking to the Hi-Fi
description: ASIDE from the talking garden gnome and the combined baseball hat and glove, few devices have ever been asked to do more than the personal computer. Lately it is being called upon to function as a stereo. But most people already own one of those, and usually it is in a room better suited to listening to music. Is there a way, then, to use your PC for what it's good at -- storing and organizing music into customized playlists -- while leaving playback duties to the real thing, your home stereo?

title: Mariah Gets Scratched, but With a Glittering Buyout From EMI
description: Mariah Carey, the U.S. pop diva whose recent career has failed to match her soaring voice, was singing the corporation blues Wednesday after Virgin Records paid her $28 million to walk away from the biggest recording contract in history.

title: House Democrats Propose Making the '96 Welfare Law an Antipoverty Weapon
description: A yearlong struggle over welfare policy will begin on Thursday when House Democrats offer a proposal to convert the 1996 welfare law into a tool for reducing poverty, while extending its major provisions for five years.

title: John Arthur Love, 85, Governor Of Colorado and an Energy Czar
description: John Arthur Love, a former Republican governor of Colorado and energy czar in the Nixon administration, died on Monday. He was 85 and lived in Denver.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLER REPORTS LOSS FOR QUARTER
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises, the largest bottler of Coca-Cola beverages, reported a fourth-quarter loss yesterday, saying it was a result of a change in how it accounts for payments from Coke and higher revamping costs. The change, which reduced 2001 earnings by $302 million, or 70 cents a share, will not affect profit this year, the chief executive, Lowry Kline, said. Coca-Cola owns about 40 percent of Coca-Cola Enterprises. The bottler said it had a loss of $36 million, or 8 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $16 million, or 4 cents. Sales rose 11 percent, to $3.97 billion.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Challenge To Abortion Law
description: Planned Parenthood has filed a federal lawsuit challenging a state law that abortions after 12 weeks of pregnancy must be performed in hospitals. Planned Parenthood, which operates clinics in Sioux Falls and Rapid City, said the 1973 law relied on old standards regarding what medical resources should be required at what point in pregnancy. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Dungy Can See Colts Returning to the Playoffs
description: When an N.F.L. team hires a new coach, it is usually to rebuild. Tony Dungy does not see it that way.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Old Lyme: Nature Preserve Urged
description: The Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy has formed a public/ private coalition to try to buy and preserve more than 60 acres on which the late naturalist Roger Tory Peterson, left, and his wife, Virginia, lived and worked. Mrs. Peterson's family said it planned to donate a substantial portion of the wooded land, and on Monday the town of Old Lyme will vote on a proposal to dedicate $140,000 toward the total cost of $840,000 for the land purchase. Mr. Peterson, who died in 1996, wrote 15 bird-watching field guides. Mrs. Peterson, a coauthor of some of the guides, died last year. Hope Reeves (NYT)

A memorial service will be held at 1:00 PM on Sunday January 27, 2002, at the chapel at Salisbury School in Salisbury, CT. The director, Tony Pemberton, wanted to create a contemporary, poetic slice of life whose lineage includes the sober, sometimes meandering work of the British director Ken Loach.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Fewer Runway Accidents
description: The rate of runway incidents in which a plane or a vehicle blunders into a place where it could cause a collision dropped last year to 0.59 per 100,000 takeoffs and landings, down from 0.64 the year before, the Federal Aviation Administration said. Officials could not say whether some of the improvement was caused by decreased congestion after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, but they said they thought most of it was because of efforts to educate pilots. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Greenspan Says He Sees Signs That Recession May Be Abating
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 - Sounding optimistic though hardly ebullient, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, told lawmakers today that he thought the United States' first recession in a decade may soon abate.

description: PATT-Brucha. Died January 23. Born Sheva Brucha Zalcman in Warsaw in 1915, she was a member of a generation of idealistic Jewish activists who believed that justice and peace are possible in a pluralistic society. She arrived in America in 1940 with her husband, Dr. Emanuel Patt, doctor, writer, and leader in Yiddish and Jewish labor organizations. title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Ban On Rebels May Be Lifted
description: The new prime minister, Ranil Wickremesinghe, told Parliament that he is considering lifting the ban on the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the separatist group that has been fighting for a Tamil homeland since 1983. The Tigers have said such a step is a condition for peace talks. Their chief negotiator, Anton Balasingham, praised Mr. Wickremesinghe as ''a realist and a man of vision.'' The government hopes Norway can broker a formal cease-fire soon. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Albert Oehlen -- 'Self-Portraits'
description: Skarstedt Fine Art

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Sisterhood Is Powerful

title: Edith Bouvier Beale, 84, 'Little Edie,' Dies
description: Edith Bouvier Beale, once a successful model and aspiring actress who later lived a gothic life in Grey Gardens, a dilapidated 28-room house in East Hampton, N.Y., with her mother and dozens of cats, raccoons and opossums, was found dead in her small apartment in Bal Harbour, Fla., on Jan. 14. She was 84.

title: Arabs, Americans and bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, EDWARD E.
description: FINCH-Edward E. Age 77, resident of Rockville Centre, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. died on January 18, 2002. Survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Mildred. Devoted father of Raymond, Jack, Dan, Julie, Florence, Ed and Liz. Cherished ''Pop'' of thirteen grandchildren. Ed was born and raised in New York City. He served in World War II as a navigator on C47's and retired as a Lieutenant Colonel in the United States Airforce, Irongate Squardron. Graduated from New York University with a Bachelor of Science degree. Considered the ''original prize guy'', Ed started and help build an industry that specializes in promotional advertising on television. We love him and will miss his strength and support. A memorial Mass will be held at 10 AM at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre on January 26th.

title: Leader Plans Open Election For Pakistan In October
description: Pakistan's military leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, announced today a plan to allow free elections for the national and provincial assemblies in October. But the general also said he expected to remain in power for as long as five years after the assembly was seated, to watch for signs of the corruption and chaos that led to military takeovers in the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSIMIS, JOHN N.
description: TSIMIS-John N. On January 22, 2002. Beloved husband of Maroula. Loving father of Nickolas, George and his wife Evelyn. Cherished grandfather of John. Fond brother of Joan Halkias, her son Stelio and his wife Eleni. Brother-in-law of Michael, his wife Jacqueline and Constantine. Son-in-law of Anna. Funeral Mass Friday, 12 noon at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 343 East 74 Street, NY. Interment to follow at Kenisco Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers family request donations to be made to the American Heart Association, 122 East 42 St., NY, NY 10168. For further information please call Frank E. Campbell ''The Funeral Chapel''.

title: Mayor Is Wary on Teacher Pay
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg expressed reservations yesterday about a controversial plan in Gov. George E. Pataki's state budget proposal to help the city school system raise $204 million, which some officials hope could be used to pay higher teachers' salaries.

title: American Home Changing Name
description: The American Home Products Corporation, posting a fourth-quarter profit of $823 million today, said it would change its name to Wyeth, the name of its drug unit.

title: Referees Turn To Video Aid More Often
description: He watches television in front of millions of people each week. He is an audience of one, and his privileged screening is a powerful exercise in interactivity: when he is done, he has the power to reverse a ruling based on the replays he just saw. He is a National Football League referee, a modern Captain Video.

title: Arabs, Americans and bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani's Papers Go to Private Group, Not City
description: For most former mayors of New York City, the trip into the dusty files of history began with hundreds of boxes of mayoral papers and artifacts being carted from City Hall across Chambers Street to the Municipal Archives in the old Surrogate's Court. There, city archivists undertake a long, slow process of sorting and indexing.

title: A Governor in the Middle of a Race He Won't Run
description: Gov. George Ryan decided not to seek re-election this year. But while he is not a candidate, he is nevertheless in the race. In a way, he is the race.

title: Old Laws Hard to Apply to Modern Terrorism : For Afghans in Cuba, Untested Legal Limbo
description: PARIS  The prisoners from Afghanistan being held at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba are in an uncharted legal limbo, some of whose parameters and requirements are clear and some of which are not, international legal analysts, scholars and human rights activists agree.

title: Needlework Dazzling In Its Detail
description: In Tony Kushner's new play, ''Homebody/Kabul,'' a middle-aged British housewife reads an old guidebook about Afghanistan that sets her dreaming about an ancient shah. She rhapsodizes about his green tunic ''over which are worked flowers of gold and a breast plate of diamonds, shaped like flattened fleurs-de-lis, ornaments of the same kind on each thigh, emeralds above the elbows, diamonds on each wrist, strings of pearls like cross belts.'' She tapers off in reverie.

title: Afghan Leader Hints at Need for More Peacekeeping Troops
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 25  The interim leader of Afghanistan, Hamid Karzai, edged closer to calling for the deployment of peacekeeping troops throughout his country today, as he welcomed the United Nation's secretary general, Kofi Annan, to the Afghan capital.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Camp Gives Children Fun and Parents Respite
description: Except for a crow's call, all was quiet outside today as a steady snowfall began to show signs of accumulation. Inside a toasty cabin at Wagon Road Camp, though, the voices of a score of youngsters, some physically handicapped, others mentally retarded, filled a large community room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, FANNIE
description: BARON-Fannie. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Board and staff of Peninsula Hospital Center are saddened by the passing of Fannie Baron, longtime Benefactor and mother of Selma Kaplan, Secretary and Officer of the Board of Directors. Sincere condolences are extended to the entire Kaplan and Baron families. Joel A. Miele Sr., P.E., Chairman, Board of Directors Robert V. Levine President & Chief Exec Officer Narendra K. Hadpawat, M.D., President, Medical Board

title: Dean of Journalism School Is Stepping Down at Columbia
description: Tom Goldstein will step down as dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University in June after five years in the post.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Visit to the Probation Officer

title: Utah Colleges Fight To Keep Weapons Out
description: To Bernard Machen, the president of the University of Utah, a classroom with students who may be carrying guns is an intimidating place to learn. For that reason, he has insisted on maintaining the university's longtime ban on weapons, concealed or otherwise, on campus.

title: Fathoming Meaning From a Talking Fish
description: ''Maelstrom'' is probably the first romantic drama ever narrated by a smelly dead fish. What might a dead fish have to do with love? It has something to do with the ocean whence life springs. And as it turns out, fish figure prominently in the symbolic structure of this fine French Canadian film, written and directed by Denis Villeneuve. Its protagonist, Bibi Champagne (Marie-Jose Croze), is a beautiful and successful 25-year-old businesswoman. Virtually overnight, Bibi's sleek yuppie existence unravels, and she faces an acute spiritual crisis when she has a series of personal disasters.

title: A determined effort to recruit mentors to work with youths.
description: AN ambitious campaign meant to change behavior, not sell products, is under way, the first of its scope since Sept. 11 that is unrelated to the terrorist attacks.

title: Understanding Enron
description: CONTRACT FOR REED -- Karl Rove, President Bush's top political adviser, recommended the Republican strategist Ralph Reed to Enron for a lucrative consulting contract as Mr. Bush was considering whether to run for president, close associates of Mr. Rove say.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Rise In The Homeless
description: The number of homeless people in the state rose 42 percent over the last three years, according to a study by the Missouri Association for Social Welfare. The study found that St. Louis and its neighboring counties led the state, with a 69 percent increase from 1998 to 2001. The association asked shelters across the state to record the number of people they served on two specific days last year. According to the survey, a daily average of 16,425 people used the shelters. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Hoping for Calm, Preparing For Strife at Economic Talks
description: Even many of the veterans of wild protest melees at Seattle and Genoa say there would be something unseemly about violent protests in New York, still healing from the wounds of Sept. 11, when the World Economic Forum starts meeting next week.

title: LONE STAR FUNDS BUYS SHONEY'S RESTAURANT CHAIN
description: Shoney's Inc., which operates and franchises Shoney's restaurants and Captain D's Seafood restaurants, said it agreed to be acquired by Lone Star Funds for about $20 million in cash and the assumption of about $255 million in debt. Lone Star Funds, a closely held group of real estate-related investment funds, will pay 36 cents a share for all outstanding shares of Shoney's and has assumed about $135 million in debt, a Shoney's spokesman, Hank Dye, said. Lone Star will assume about $120 million in additional debt upon closing the transaction, Owen Blicksilver, a spokesman for Lone Star, said. He said Lone Star did not plan any immediate changes in operations or management. Shoney's is based in Nashville; Lone Star, in Dallas.

title: Layoffs Start In New Jersey As Towns Brace for Cuts
description: Even during his campaign for governor, James E. McGreevey warned New Jerseyans that a yawning budget deficit would cause pain. Now, as governor, he has begun to inflict it.

title: Mining Giant Set to Depart From Zambia
description: Anglo American P.L.C., the global mining giant, announced today that it was pulling out of Zambia, where the company has been struggling to turn around the crumbling mines it acquired from the state 22 months ago.

title: Mysteries Multiply In Spooky Adventures
description: A few years ago on ''Saturday Night Live,'' David Duchovny tossed off a Richard Gere impression that was all gesture but pluperfect in delivery. He screwed his face into a camera-aware pout and stared into the lens as if it were a mirror, the better to catch his Olympian self-regard. And now, with the all-style-and-no-substance thriller ''The Mothman Prophecies,'' Mr. Gere is turning the tables on Mr. Duchovny, delving into the spookily unreal of ''The X-Files.''

title: EMC's Loss in 4th Quarter Was Not as Deep as Feared
description: To the delight of Wall Street, EMC, the data storage company that became a widely held technology bellwether during the 1990's, yesterday reported a narrower loss than expected in the last quarter of 2001 and projected a return to profitability as early as this spring.

title: HOULIHAN'S RESTAURANTS SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Houlihan's Restaurants, the operator of casual restaurants in 17 states in the Midwest and Southeast, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Kansas City, Mo., where it is based. The company said that it would continue to operate its 52 Houlihan's and Darryl's restaurants, but restructure its debt, change its menu and focus on profitable restaurants. Houlihan's has closed 28 poorly performing restaurants since October, but a spokeswoman, Anita-Maria Hill, said it did not plan to close more. Houlihan's officials listed more than $100 million in assets and in debts in the Chapter 11 petition.

title: Clara Williams
description: Nicole Klagsbrun

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIRING, WILLIAM, MD, FACP,
description: FEIRING-William, MD, FACP, age 95. Died January 23, 2002 at his home in Waterside Retirement Estates, Sarasota, FL. He was born in New York City on June 25, 1906 and came to Sarasota in April 1972. He was a graduate of CCNY and NYU and practiced medicine as an internist. He was married to the late Ruth Rosenthal in 1941 and served as a medical officer in the Air Force from 1942 to 1946. He was a member of Temple Beth Sholom. He is survived by his family, Hilda Feiring and Ruth, Stephen and Eugene Rosenthal. A memorial service will be held at Waterside Retirement Estates at a later date.

title: Homeless in California
description: To the Editor:

title: Investors Lured To Enron Deals By Inside Data
description: Enron executives enticed wealthy individuals and institutions to invest in one of the partnerships that helped wreck the company by dangling the prospect that inside knowledge could potentially help them double their money in a matter of months, according to partnership records and prospective investors.

title: Police in Chechnya Accuse Russia's Troops of Murder
description: Nearly two years after major hostilities ended here in Chechnya, the devastated republic in the Caucasus, Russian troops are killing civilians in a campaign of executions and looting that takes place alongside military operations aimed at destroying rebel forces, according to Chechen police officials.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Comdisco Cleared To Sell 2 Units
description: Comdisco Inc., a technology and financing company in the midst of bankruptcy reorganization, won a judge's approval yesterday to sell two leasing businesses to General Electric for about $665 million in cash and assumed debt. Comdisco first announced the deal two weeks ago, but it was subject to approval by United States Bankruptcy Judge Ronald Barliant in Chicago. In the deal, GE Capital, the finance arm of General Electric, will acquire the electronics and laboratory and scientific leasing units of Comdisco. GE Capital will also make payments to Comdisco if the transferred leases exceed specified performance goals. Comdisco shares, which traded over $16 in the last year, ended the day at 73 cents, up 1.3 percent. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Judge Allows a Jury Trial In a Case of Jewish Divorce
description: A judge has allowed bribery and defamation accusations against several Orthodox rabbis to go to trial in what advocates for the rights of Orthodox wives call a battle against the abuse of power and subjugation of women by religious authorities.

title: Task for a Solomon
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Chairman Says Tax Cuts Should Follow Debt Reduction
description: A year after giving his blessing to President Bush's tax cut, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, urged Congress today to link any further tax reductions or spending increases to progress in paying down the national debt.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Labs To Cut 200 Jobs
description: AT&T Laboratories, the telecommunications company's elite research arm, is cutting about 200 jobs as it shifts its focus to Internet-based network technologies. AT&T is also seeking to sell its research and development laboratory in Cambridge, England, an operation it acquired three years ago from Olivetti of Italy, Hossein Eslambolchi, president of AT&T Labs, said. About 3 percent of the 6,000 employees at AT&T Labs will lose their jobs, Mr. Eslambolchi said. The moves are part of a larger plan announced earlier this month to cut 5,000 jobs and take a $1 billion restructuring charge. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOSEN, LEILA
description: ROOSEN-Leila. Of Westport, CT. Wife of Dr. Willem Roosen. Mother of Richard Roosen, Julie Litoff and Catherine Shepard. Sister of Mickey Scheinman and Bernard Fink. Retired teacher for the NYC Public School System. Services and interment were private.

title: Igor Kipnis, a Harpsichord Master Who Championed His Instrument, Is Dead at 71
description: Igor Kipnis, the virtuoso harpsichordist whose busy concert recording career made him the instrument's most ardent cheerleader, died on Wednesday at his Connecticut home. He was 71.

title: Nokia's Earnings Surpass Expectations
description: Nokia, the world's biggest maker of mobile phones, reported earnings today that exceeded its own projections and those of analysts.

title: 11th Grader Finds That His Swing Takes a Recess
description: Ty Tryon would have fared better in his 11th grade English class today than he did on the golf course.

title: Indonesian in Terror Inquiry Lauds bin Laden
description: An Islamic cleric who was questioned here today by the police after Singapore and Malaysia demanded his arrest lauded Osama bin Laden as ''a true Islamic warrior'' who had shown the courage and skill to fight the United States.

title: Complaint Withdrawn; Skaters Are Cleared
description: Apolo Anton Ohno's quest to win four medals at the Winter Games is no longer in jeopardy after an arbitrator said today that there was no evidence to support the claim that he and Rusty Smith conspired against Tommy O'Hare at the United States Olympic short-track speedskating trials.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Explosives Maker Renationalized
description: The Czech government said it would take back control of Explosia, the company that makes the plastic explosive Semtex, less than two months after its parent, the chemical conglomerate Unipetrol, was privatized. The finance minister, Jiri Rusnok, said another state-run company would pay a nominal amount, 1 million koruny ($270,000), and assume 700 million koruny ($19 million) in debt to take over Explosia. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: American Charged as a Terrorist Makes First Appearance in Court
description: Shorn of his bushy beard and long dark hair, John Walker Lindh looked thin, pale and a bit bewildered today as he stepped into a courtroom here to begin his defense against charges that he aided terrorist organizations and conspired to kill his countrymen.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Australia: Policy Change On Afghan Migrants
description: The government will resume processing visas for Afghan asylum seekers today, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said after a meeting with the government's advisory group on alien detention centers. The government stopped processing applications from illegal Afghan immigrants after the Taliban government fell. Hundreds of asylum-seekers are staging a hunger strike inside the largest center, protesting the policy of holding illegal immigrants behind barbed-wire fences during the wait for their cases to be resolved, which can last months or years. On Wednesday, three Afghan immigrants, including a 16-year-old boy, tried to hang themselves, the government said.

title: Many H.M.O.'s For the Elderly Cut or Abolish Drug Coverage
description: The nation's largest health insurers, which recruited elderly people to Medicare H.M.O.'s by dangling offers of free prescriptions, are eliminating drug coverage or demanding sharply higher payments for drugs and treatments from some of their sickest members.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRAGER, INGEBORG, ''INCA''
description: SCHRAGER-Ingeborg, ''Inca'', age 80. Beloved wife of Leon. Devoted mother of Linda (Spencer) Cohen and Gene (Elizabeth). Cherished grandmother of Erin and Trevor. Her gusto and flair will be missed. Services today, 10 AM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Columbia Recruits Former Senator
description: Columbia University has recruited former Senator George J. Mitchell, who helped broker peace talks in Northern Ireland, as a senior fellow at its School of International and Public Affairs. Mr. Mitchell will lecture and conduct faculty briefings for the school's Center for Conflict Resolution. Although he will not officially join the university until July, he spoke about international conflict resolution at the school yesterday. Mr. Mitchell, a former Senate majority leader, was chairman of the Northern Ireland peace negotiations from 1996 to 1998 and helped bring about the Good Friday agreement of 1998, which linked political progress to phased disarmament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLINGER, VIOLA P.
description: WILLINGER-Viola P. Age 95. Of New Rochelle, New York. Loving wife of the late Dr. Louis. Devoted mother of Blossom Miller, Lorraine Kolb, Larry, Warren and Lowell Willinger. Adored grandmother of 15 and great grandmother of 12. Past President, four terms, of the United Order of True Sisters. Warm and giving, her family was her life. Services Friday, January 25th, 12 Noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon. Interment Mount Pleasant Memorial Park, Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENSCHEL, LEONARD
description: HENSCHEL-Leonard. The National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the passing of Leonard Henschel, devoted husband of Judith and beloved father of our benefactor Laurel, a steadfast supporter of NJOP's efforts to assure a bright Jewish future for American Jewry. Condolences to the entire family. Yehi zichro baruch. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: 'Wannabes'
description: Directed by Charles A. Addessi and William A. DeMeo

title: Giants' Fassel Hires Special Teams Coach
description: After twice experimenting with special teams coaches who lacked experience, Giants Coach Jim Fassel hired a coach with a more traditional pedigree yesterday.

title: Dark Doings Proliferate In a World of Vivid Colors
description: ''Metropolis,'' a hallucinatory tour de force of color, perspective and scale, virtually encapsulates the history of Japanese animation. Based on a postwar manga by the legendary comic-book artist Osamu Tezuka and directed by Rintaro from a screenplay by Katsuhiro Otomo (whose ''Akira'' is a landmark of feature-length anime), the film combines the latest digital technology with traditional painted-cel techniques.

title: Mariah's Song
description: To the Editor:

title: Organizers Criticized in Tyson-Lewis Melee
description: The chairman of the Nevada State Athletic Commission yesterday sharply criticized the organizers of the news conference Tuesday in Manhattan at which the heavyweight fighters Mike Tyson and Lennox Lewis traded blows. He also said the commission had the option of giving Tyson a boxing license that could be revoked under certain circumstances -- for example, if Tyson were charged with rape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMOWITZ, MURIEL
description: DOMOWITZ-Muriel. Formerly of Jackson Heights and Staten Island, died on Jan. 12, 2002, in Suffern, NY. She is survived by her sons Evan Domowitz & Ted Domowitz and her brother Dr. Barry Karp. Mrs. Domowitz was born in 1929 in Brooklyn, the daughter of Sadie and Samuel Karp. She attended Newtown High School. In 1957 Muriel married Irving Domowitz. Funeral services were held at Hellman Memorial Chapels, Spring Valley, NY, on January 14. Interment United Hebrew Cemetery, S.I., N.Y. Donations to The American Cancer Society.

title: Warner Held Out of Practice
description: Quarterback Kurt Warner sat out the St. Louis Rams' practice today because of spasms in the bruised part of his rib cage. Coach Mike Martz said he expected Warner to practice Friday and play against Philadelphia on Sunday, but the injury raises questions about how vulnerable Warner will be against the Eagles, a team expected to blitz him relentlessly.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC SETS ASIDE MONEY FOR ASBESTOS CLAIMS
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation is putting aside about $221 million for its share of less than $1 billion in payments over 10 years to settle asbestos-related complaints. The company, the lumber, paper and tissue maker, plans to record that amount as a fourth-quarter expense, without which the period would have had profit of $34 million, the company said. Insurance will cover the rest of the payments. Georgia-Pacific used asbestos, which can cause lung disease, from 1965 to 1977 to make a compound used to hang wallboard. The company, which is based in Atlanta, had 62,000 asbestos claims pending as of Dec. 31. Its stock has lost 35 percent since Dec. 1, partly out of concern about the impact of the asbestos claims.

title: Pope, at Ecumenical Meeting, Denounces Violence in Religion's Name
description: Pope John Paul II today convened an unusual one-day gathering of leaders of a dozen religions, including Muslims, Jews and Christians, to affirm his belief that ''whoever uses religion to foment violence contradicts religion's deepest and truest inspiration.''

title: 'A Walk to Remember'
description: Directed by Adam Shankman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALI, ASAD, MD.
description: ALI-Asad, MD. January 17, 2002. The Neurology Staff at The New York Hospital-Queens, is deeply saddened by the death of our longtime friend and colleague, Asad Ali, MD. Among his many legacies is a lifelong devotion to the care of the needy and the infirm, and a determined commitment to the health and well-being of his patients, family and friends. He will be greatly missed. Drs. J. Applebaum, A. Farkash, G. Ney, E. Oribe, N. Schaul, G. Waldman

title: Before Poetry Was Superseded
description: In a blah month for new releases along come the French. ''A studio film as fine art,'' says the director Terry Gilliam in his introduction to Marcel Carn's ''Children of Paradise,'' which opened in Paris in 1945 and is now available in a fine two-disc set of DVD's from the Criterion Collection, distributed by Home Vision. Some call it the French ''Gone With the Wind.'' On another level, many consider it the best French film ever made, the product of an era when ''poetry and big budgets went hand in hand,'' Mr. Gilliam says. Imagine that.

title: Playing Into Sharon's Hands
description: To hear the Israeli government tell it, the reason behind the enduring conflict between Israel and the Palestinian people is one man -- Yasir Arafat. Hence, Israel's approach to the problem is confining the Palestinian leader to his Ramallah headquarters, destroying the symbols of the Palestinian Authority he leads and gradually reoccupying its territory.

title: Appeals Court Denies Convict DNA Test in a '90 Rape Case
description: Overturning a lower court ruling that drew national attention, a federal appeals court in Virginia has refused to allow a man who was convicted 12 years ago of sex crimes to have DNA tests he contends would exonerate him.

title: A NEWS CORPORATION OPERATING OFFICER RESIGNS
description: The News Corporation's co-chief operating officer, Chase Carey, resigned after the company canceled plans to spin off as a separate, publicly traded company the Sky Global Networks satellite-television unit that Mr. Carey led. Mr. Carey will remain a director and a consultant at the company, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, through 2002, the News Corporation said. A spokesman, Andrew Butcher, said Mr. Carey would not be replaced.

title: Datek Pays $6.3 Million To Settle Securities Charges
description: Datek Online Holdings, a big online brokerage firm, has agreed to pay $6.3 million to settle federal charges that its former day trading unit engaged in securities fraud in the 1990's.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Too many elements of the system are not trustworthy today. They have failed us because of self-dealing and self-interest.''

title: Arabs, Americans and bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Wedding in Puerto Vallarta
description: Viva Vallarta, a 355-room resort in Puetro Vallarta on Mexico's Pacific coast, has cut the price of its wedding packages to $390, from $690. For that price, which is added on to the regular all-inclusive rates of $115 a person from Feb. 1 to March 31 and $88 a person April through June, the couple receive the help of wedding counselor, a judge and all legal costs, the bridal bouquet, decorations, a wedding cake, an open bar for 10 people for one hour, 10 color photos and music. Couples are required to provide passports, birth cirtificates, arrifavits that both are single (or divorce decrees or death certificates), blood tests with the results in Spanish, tourist cards and four witnesses. Information (800) 898-9968 or www.vivaresorts.com

title: Teach the Children Well, First Lady Urges Senators
description: Following the examples of Hillary Rodham Clinton, Rosalynn Carter and Eleanor Roosevelt, Laura Bush testified on Capitol Hill today about correcting a social ill in America. Her topic was the importance of early childhood education, and she included the lessons that she and her husband had learned from reading ''Hop on Pop'' to their twin daughters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ARMS, JOHN H.
description: D'ARMS-John H. It is with deep sorrow that the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the loss of John D'Arms, distinguished scholar, President of the American Council of Learned Societies, and Fellow of the Academy for the past ten years. His wide scholarly interests and administrative skills made him one of this nation's leading advocates for humanistic study. He will be remembered for his efforts to create an extensive program of fellowships to support new research in the humanities. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Teresa, to his family, and to all those who benefited from his wisdom and generous spirit. President Patricia Meyer Spacks, Vice-President Louis Cabot, Secretary Emilio Bizzi, Treasurer Peter Lynch, Executive Executive Officer Leslie Berlowitz.

title: A Park for All (Not Just Homo Sapiens)
description: To the Editor:

title: Contraction Fuels Debate
description: With the possibility of contraction continuing to hang over Major League Baseball, the union's grievance aimed at blocking it for this season continued to plod along yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Invited To NATO Summit
description: President Vladimir V. Putin has been invited by the Czech Republic's president, Vaclav Havel, to attend NATO summit talks scheduled for Prague in November, the Czech foreign minister said during a visit to Moscow. Nine east European countries once under Soviet control will attend the meeting, which will center on their applications to join the 19-nation alliance. Russia opposes NATO expansion but has softened its stance since NATO voted last month to give Moscow a voice in setting policy on some issues like fighting terrorism.

title: 2 Japanese Insurance Giants Will Merge
description: Two big Japanese insurers, Meiji Life and Yasuda Mutual Life, said today that they would merge, creating Japan's third-largest life insurer, in a move to cut costs and bolster returns at a time when the Japanese economy is sour and interest rates are near zero.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Congressional Hearings Focus on Andersen's Role

title: Television's Interest in Hearing of Taliban Fighter Eclipsed Enron
description: Hearings into the collapse of the Enron Corporation opened on Capitol Hill yesterday, but the all-news cable television channels showed little interest, providing only intermittent coverage.

title: 'Torture' on TV: It's Not Funny
description: To the Editor:

title: Rams' Revamped Defense A Pretty Great Show, Too
description: It was one of the Rams' last practices of the preseason and they all took it very seriously, players and coaches shouting, flush with adrenaline. The St. Louis offense -- Kurt Warner and Marshall Faulk and the other stars of ''The Greatest Show on Earth'' -- went into a two-minute drill against the Rams' reconstructed defense.

title: Making Artful Images Out of Science, With the Sure Touch of Experience
description: Photographers have long mined the art in science. Berenice Abbott saw abstract beauty in a magnified penicillin mold. Catherine Wagner discovered algae mating in petri dishes transformed into calligraphic semaphores and unsterilized dispensing tubes resembling a work by Frank Stella. Gary Schneider explored the universe in the irises of his eyes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, HERBERT S.
description: DAVIDSON-Herbert S. Passed away on January 24 at age 79. Beloved husband of Jan and the late Grace, devoted father to Ken and Willa and Andrew Epstein, adored and loving grandfather of Michael, dearest brother of Robert and Esther Davidoff, and much loved brother-in-law to Richard and Lynn Hyman, Diane and the late Martin Hyman, caring son-in-law of Billie Hyman. A leading innovator in the electronic distribution industry and the founder and CEO of Milgray Electronics, Inc. title: TROUBLES IN ARGENTINA TO REDUCE EARNINGS AT DIAL

Dial said it might have to write off the value of at least some of its $44.7 million in good will, the premium paid above assets, for acquisitions made in Argentina. The company plans to cut marketing, manufacturing and administrative expenses sharply in Argentina, where it gets about 7 percent of its sales. Dial, the maker of soap, Armour Star canned meat and Renuzit air fresheners, put itself up for sale in August. Shares of Dial, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., fell 74 cents, or 4 percent, to $15.76.

According to Enron, the partnership was independent of the company, but the top executives of LJM2 were also top executives at Enron -- a connection highlighted in the partnership offering papers as one reason LJM2 would be a desirable investment. Here is one way that the partnership became a problem. Dylan Loeb McClain

description: Strobe Talbott, the deputy secretary of state in the Clinton administration, has been named the next president of the Brookings Institution, one of Washington's oldest research centers, and will join Brookings in September. For 21 years, Mr. Talbott, 55, worked as a journalist for Time magazine and specialized in foreign affairs; in 1993, he moved to the State Department. Now director of the Yale Center for the Study of Globalization, Mr. Talbott will succeed Michael H. Armacost, a former ambassador to Japan and the Philippines. Christopher Marquis (NYT)

As a result, many individual investors -- through these funds -- unwittingly owned a piece of an entity that was used to finance some of the partnerships that contributed to Enron's failure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAI, FENG, YANG
description: CHAI-Feng-Yang. Former Director of the Security Council and Political Committees of the United Nations, died at age 94 on January 18, 2002. Born in China, he attended Tsinghua University, graduated from Stanford University in 1931, and did graduate work at the University of Illinois and the London School of Economics before embarking on a diplomatic career spanning four decades. He served as First Secretary of the Nationalist Chinese London Embassy during World War II and participated in the UN's work from its inception at both the Dumbarton Oaks and San Francisco Conferences. He joined the newly formed Secretariat in 1946 as an international civil servant, ultimately becoming Director in the Department of Political and Security Council Affairs. During his tenure at the UN, he was also appointed Secretary of numerous committees, including the Committee of Experts of the Security Council, the Committee on Admission of New Members, the Palestine Conciliation Commission, the Committee for Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, the ad hoc Committee on the Seabed, and the Special Political Committee. Ever devoted to world peace, he was central and influential in the Security Council's response to international crises until his retirement in 1970. Later he became a lecturer, research fellow, UN consultant, and US citizen, spending his leisure years in California and Hawaii. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Chi-Hui, and loving children and grandchildren.

description: The town of Haddam has agreed to accept about $13 million over the next 10 years in exchange for allowing a nuclear power plant to store spent fuel in a location about three-quarters of a mile away from its plant. The town's selectmen voted 2 to 1 on Wednesday to allow the decommissioned plant of the Connecticut Yankee Atomic Power Company to store its waste on a 15-acre site. The agreement stipulates that the plant will use security personnel to prevent and intrusion and that it will also install devices to check water safety. Hope Reeves (NYT)

It also absolved servicemen of having to hide their uniforms under Western-styled shirts while driving off-base, a practice adopted more recently for security reasons.

title: When Strindberg Found His Truth Machine
description: August Strindberg is famous for being a playwright, madman and misogynist. He is not so well known as a photographer. In fact it seems downright weird to think of him with a camera. Such a cool, scientific medium seems the wrong outlet for such a hothead. But a few dozen photographs of and by Strindberg, on view at Scandinavia House, belie this hunch. Strindberg was fascinated with photography.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sanmina-SCI Buys Alcatel Plants
description: The Sanmina-SCI Corporation, an electronic contract manufacturer with more than 100 factories, said it had bought Alcatel's manufacturing plants in Cherbourg, France; Gunzenhausen, Germany; and Toledo, Spain. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, though the companies said it included a supply contract. The acquisition will help Sanmina-SCI, which is based in San Jose, Calif., expand its sales in the communications, industrial and medical instrumentation and computer technology sectors. Alcatel, based in Paris, said outsourcing its manufacturing would allow it to focus better on product development and integration. The factory in Cherbourg produces microwave systems, the one in the Gunzenhausen makes high-end voice switching and data transmission systems and the one in Toledo manufactures network access products. The three factories employ 1,500 people. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Executive Change

The loss increased to $143.9 million, or $2.26 a share, from $14.0 million, or 40 cents, in the year-earlier quarter, the company said. XM had $532,000 in sales in the fourth quarter; it first reported sales in the third quarter. Costs rose as XM spent more than some analysts expected to advertise its $9.99 a month service with 100 channels of programs, fewer commercials and better sound quality than conventional radio.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Pipeline Approval Expected

Petronas was scheduled to begin taking delivery of gas along the $500 million pipeline by the middle of this year, but construction has been held up for more than a year amid protests by environmentalists and villagers along the pipeline's proposed route. description: Facing a shortage of $1.1 billion in the state's two-year budget of $48.8 billion, Gov. Scott McCallum has proposed cutting aid to local governments, laying off state workers and trimming financing for higher education. An analysis suggests that 500 cities and towns and half the state's counties would receive no state aid under the governor's plan, and local officials say they would have to cut budgets for libraries, snow plowing and even tax collection. Governor McCallum, a Republican, has suggested borrowing the $794 million the state received from the tobacco litigation settlement to help bridge the gap for local governments, and reducing state operations expenses by 11.5 percent. The lawsuit, filed Jan. 10, charges that the assailants intentionally harmed the boy, Stephen Bender Jr., then 15, and that their parents and the board of education knew of the children's behavior problems. The boy was beaten and a nail file was plunged into his neck. The five students pleaded guilty to the assault. Four were given suspended sentences and one is currently in a youth detention center serving a two-year sentence that includes charges unrelated to the attack. A spokeswoman for the school district said she could not comment on the pending litigation. Hope Reeves (NYT)

It was the first time since the Republicans took over the House in 1995 that a majority of members had affixed their names to a drive to circumvent the speaker and bring to the floor a measure he had bottled up in committee. title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Population Continues To Shrink
description: Continuing a decade-long trend, Russia's population fell by 781,500 people from January through November of last year to a total of 144 million, the government said. Demographers say that the nation could lose another 10 million people in the next 15 years and that the population could fall to 125 million or less by mid-century. A very low birthrate and low male life expectancy are major factors in the decline, which has been partly offset by immigration. Russia's population has dropped by 4.7 million people since it peaked in 1992.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brookhaven: Opponent Won't Fight Ward Vote
description: The leading foe of Tuesday's town referendum, Supervisor John J. LaValle, said he accepted the voters' decision to create districts for the Town Council's six members, replacing current townwide elections. The referendum's proponents say that sprawling Brookhaven, with an area rivaling some counties and more people than many large cities, needs more localized representation. ''Certainly I am disappointed, but I am committed to creating a smooth transition,'' said Mr. LaValle, a Republican, whose post is unaffected. Although Republican officials fought the change for years, he said he would not seek a new referendum to overturn this one.
