The launch of the Agni missile, which has not yet been inducted for use into the army, is likely to profoundly alarm India's rival, Pakistan, and a world that is worried these two hostile neighbors may go to war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, MARY EUNICE (HOWLEY)
description: RYAN-Mary Eunice (Howley), 87. Died on January 21, 2002 in West Palm Beach, Florida. Lived in New York City, Yonkers and South Salem, NY and Fort Lauderdale, FL. Beloved mother of Lani Owen of Bethesda, MD, John J. Phelan III, of New York and James W. Ryan, Jr. of Barrington, R.I. Widow of James W. Ryan, MD & Lt. Col. John J. Phelan, Jr. Grandmother to Tara Owen, Steve Owen, Meredith Owen, Jonathan Owen, John Phelan, Dana Phelan, Mark Phelan, Christopher Ryan, Timothy Ryan and Kevin Ryan. Great-grandmother of five. Sister of Bernadette Kosco of Harrisburg, PA. Graduate of Manhattanville College. A Memorial Mass will be said at St. Sebastian Church, 2000 S.E. 25th Avenue, Ft. Lauderdale, FL. on January 25, 2002 at 10 AM. Donations in lieu of flowers to the Lourdes-Noreen McKeen Residence, West Palm Beach, FL., would be appreciated.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,100 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Announces Cutbacks
description: Gateway, the No. 4 personal computer maker in the United States, said it would eliminate 16 percent of its work force and close 19 Gateway Country stores after sales slumped in the fourth quarter. The company, based in San Diego, reported a fourth-quarter profit of $9.4 million, or 3 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $128.2 million, or 40 cents, in the year-earlier period. Unlike several competitors who reported an increase in PC sales during the holidays, Gateway said it had sold 681,000 computers, a 17 percent decline from the third quarter, which is usually weaker. As part of a turnaround effort by Ted Waitt, the company's founder and chief executive, Gateway said it would cut 2,250 of its 14,000 jobs and close 19 of its 296 stores, including 10 in California and one on Staten Island. Mr. Waitt said Gateway had sacrificed sales growth for profits. The company predicted losses over the next several quarters as it lowers prices and spends more on marketing. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONAS, DORIS F. (NEE WARSHAW)
description: JONAS-Doris F. (nee Warshaw). On Sunday, January 20, 2002 in Chevy Chase, MD. Formerly of London, England and New York City. Beloved mother of Francis C. Klein and Jill Elise Grant; motherin-law of Diane F. Klein and Stephen M. Grant; grandmother of Lauren and Amy Klein, Matthew and Peter Grant; aunt of Oliver Warshaw, Jeremy Warshaw and Jane Trueman. Fellow with the Royal Anthropology Institute, author and world traveler. A memorial service will be held at the Riverside, 180 W. 76 St, NYC 10003 at 1 PM on Sunday, January 27, 2002. Interment is private.

title: Heineken and Revlon Dismiss Agencies
description: Two major advertisers are dismissing agencies.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Maker Posts Profit
description: Pohang Iron and Steel, also known as Posco, said it had a net profit of $615 million last year, despite the worldwide downturn that resulted in losses for most of its rivals. That figure was half the profit recorded in 2000, but the company reported a $200 million fourth-quarter profit last year after having lost slightly more than $1 million in the period the year before. The company passed Nippon Steel as the world's largest steel manufacturer last year, producing 27.8 million tons. Yoo Sang Goo, the chairman, said the company would reduce exports in deference to criticism from abroad, notably the United States. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Enron or Andersen Made Donations to Almost All Their Congressional Investigators
description: Of the 248 senators and House members serving on the 11 Congressional committees that are investigating the Enron collapse, 212 have received campaign contributions from Enron or its accounting firm, Arthur Andersen, according to an analysis of campaign contributions.

title: Excerpts From a House Hearing on Destruction of Enron Documents
description: Following are excerpts from remarks at a hearing yesterday before the House Energy and Commerce Committee on the destruction of documents related to the Enron Corporation, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service. The speakers included Representatives James C. Greenwood, Peter Deutsch, Billy Tauzin and Diana DeGette; the Arthur Andersen officials C. E. Andrews, Dorsey L. Baskin and Nancy Temple; and David B. Duncan, a former partner at Arthur Andersen.

description: WHAT WENT WRONG?

description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 25  It was an Australian Open men's semifinal with two faces, and one only had to look at the face of Tommy Haas's coach, David Ayme, to understand why.

description: Puck Building

title: U.S. Will Give States $1 Billion To Improve Bioterrorism Defense
description: Federal health officials said today that they were planning to distribute more than $1 billion to help states improve their defenses against a biological attack but that the bulk of the money would be withheld until the states submitted detailed preparedness plans.

title: Certified Public Scapegoat
description: Accountants are trained to make complicated corporate situations neat and easily comprehensible, and that is just what representatives of Arthur Andersen tried to do at yesterday's Congressional hearings into the destruction of Enron documents. A panel of employees of the accounting giant testified that the fault for what now appears to be a truly huge document-shredding project, spread out over months and perhaps involving scores of workers, lay entirely with a single man, David Duncan, who has been fired as an Andersen auditor.

title: In Remembrance of Sorrow From Other Times
description: YOU will never forget Sept. 11. But there are already more than 40,000 New Yorkers who will never remember. And their numbers grow every hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, LORNA MCCLENAHAN
description: ANDERSON-Lorna McClenahan. Family and friends mourn the passing of Lorna Anderson, beloved daughter of Rachel Breck, sister of Leith Speiden and Doug McClenahan, aunt of five devoted nieces and nephews. She died on January 20, 2002 in her Connecticut home. At the time of her death, she was the president of L.M. Anderson Securities. Memorial service Wednesday, January 30 at 1:15 PM in the chapel of St. Bartholemew's Church at Park Ave. and 51st St. Reception at the Cosmopolitan Club. Contributions may be made to the Northeast Salem Animal Shelter, 204 Highland Avenue, Salem, MA. 01970.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Reassessing Indians' Radiation Exposure
description: Indians living near the Columbia River were exposed to higher levels of radiation from the Hanford Nuclear Reservation than previously thought, a new federal report has found. Stuart Harris, a risk assessor at the Umatilla Reservation near the Oregon-Washington border, said the report confirmed that the federal standard for fish consumption used in previous studies had been much too low. Tribes that fished heavily in the river, where Hanford released radioactive materials, from 1944 to 1992 were exposed to a disproportionate amount of radionuclides through consumption and preparation of fish from the river, Mr. Harris said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Move Against Term Limits
description: The House has voted 50 to 20 to repeal the Idaho law on term limits. The bill is scheduled to be debated and voted on by a Senate committee next week. If it clears the committee, the full Senate will then vote. Voters approved Idaho's term-limit law in 1994, and it is to go into effect in this year's elections, but only for local offices. State offices would not be affected until 2004. Gov. Dirk Kempthorne, a Republican, has said he will veto any bill that repeals term limits. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Islanders Get a Point, But No Satisfaction
description: The Islanders scored goals on their first two shots tonight. The foghorn sounded and the red lights flashed, but that should have been a warning. The Islanders had wandered again into the perilous territory of being asked to hold a lead.

title: Roosevelt Sues To Stop Cuts Made by State
description: The Roosevelt school board has sued state education officials to block $2.8 million in state-imposed budget cuts that would lay off 29 employees and eliminate several programs starting Friday, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: GOLDSTEIN-Sylvia. A Board member of the American Music Center and a former corporate vice president of Boosey & Hawkes, died at her home on January 21, 2002. She was 82. Goldstein's career included the support and nurturing of generations of composers from Copland to Reich, and the mentoring of many executives in the field. Composer/ author Ned Rorem devoted a chapter of his 1996 book ''Other Entertainment'' to her. Born in New York City on February 21, 1919 she received an undergraduate degree in economics from Long Island University in 1941. She began working for Ralph Hawkes of Boosey & Hawkes shortly after graduating. Encouraged by Hawkes, she graduated from Brooklyn Law School in 1944. After her retirement from Boosey & Hawkes in 1993 she held the title of corporate vice president for several years. She also maintained an active role on the Board of Directors of the American Music Center. In January 2002, AMC bestowed Sylvia Goldstein with its Letter of Distinction. The award was presented to her ''in recognition of her 50-plus years of remarkable service in support of composers and the field of new music''.

title: Top U.S. Aerialist To Miss Olympics
description: Emily Cook, the United States' top female freestyle aerialist, will not compete in next month's Salt Lake City Olympic Games because of an injury sustained in training last week.

title: Statements by Senator and Ex-S.E.C. Head at Senate Hearing on Enron
description: Following are statements at the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee hearing yesterday in Washington on Enron by Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, and Arthur Levitt, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Durbin's statement was provided by his office. Mr. Levitt's is from the committee's Web site.

title: Only Shot Bettis Wants Is Against the Patriots
description: The warm-up had gone well. Pittsburgh running back Jerome Bettis had left the locker room at Heinz Field about 90 minutes before the 12:30 p.m. kickoff, accompanied by his teammate Chris Fuamatu-Ma'afala. They ran laps up and down the field and Bettis did some high-stepping, too, testing the injury between his groin and abdomen that had caused him to miss the final five games of the regular season.

title: Inside View of Tourette's as a Lifelong Companion
description: When people with disabilities turn up in plays and films, the story is often only partly about them; the real drama involves the struggles of the disabled person's teacher or lawyer or loved ones. ''Syndrome,'' a one-man play at the Greenwich Street Theater through Feb. 9, aggressively avoids that model. Not only does the lone character in the play have Tourette's syndrome, but so does the actor playing him.

title: A Ballet Evolves Through Several Lives
description: Two early works by Peter Martins, ''Jeu de Cartes'' and ''Valse Triste,'' are enjoying successful revivals this season with New York City Ballet.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about criticism of Justice Priscilla Owen of the Texas Supreme Court, a nominee for a federal judgeship who accepted campaign donations from Enron, misstated the amount of money saved by the company because of a decision she wrote, dealing with taxes owed to a local school district. It was $224,988.65, not $15 million. The larger sum, cited in her opinion as the district's revenue loss, was the amount by which the value of a piece of the company's land was lowered.

title: Mariah's Song
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about television programs that feature fighting robots, and a list of related Web sites, misidentified the cable network that carries ''Robot Wars.'' It is TNN, not CNN.

title: Preparing for the Fray, Gloves On; As McCall Defines Himself, Some Question Instincts
description: H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, was discussing his campaign for governor at a seminar in Lower Manhattan the other morning when a member of his invited audience of young Democrats offered up a sweeping, if not surprising, question: What were the principles and vision of his candidacy?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIS DAVID
description: COHEN-Harris David. January 25, 1967-August 13, 1985. What a year-we welcomed Jake Harris on September 22. We all miss you so much. Our memories are beautiful; our hearts are broken. Much love, Mom, Dad, Jonathan and Lisa

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend last Friday about the 25th anniversary of the mini-series ''Roots'' referred incorrectly, in a comparison, to a sequence in the animated film ''The Lion King.'' The cub Simba is lifted to the sky toward the end of the song ''The Circle of Life''; that does not occur at the start of the song.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Dust Stirs Worry in Tour of a Shuttered School
description: When a group of teachers from the High School of Economics and Finance went back to tour their shuttered school next to the World Trade Center site, city officials assured them that it had been thoroughly cleaned. The building, which is closer than any other school to ground zero, has been closed since the terrorist attacks and is scheduled to reopen Jan. 30.

title: When You're in the Right, Obstinacy Can Be a Virtue
description: The hero of ''Beijing Bicycle'' is Guei (Cui Lin), a young man from the countryside who finds a job in the Chinese capital working as a bike messenger. On one especially stressful day, he arrives at a high-class spa in search of a customer named Mr. Zhang, whom Guei interrupts in the midst of a massage. It turns out that this is the wrong Mr. Zhang, and the mix-up culminates in a comical standoff with the management, the summoning of uniformed security guards and a sarcastic piece of advice from a receptionist: ''Try Zhang Yimou.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JULIUS, JACOB
description: JULIUS-Jacob. Dear ''Yonny''. Our loss is inestimable but you filled our lives immeasurably with love, humor, learning & adventure and for that we will be eternally grateful. Bob and Janet Winston Children Micah, Resha, Jared

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Meadowlands Plan Urged
description: The Meadowlands Commission has voted to withdraw from a plan for nearly 8,000 acres of wetlands. Known as the Special Area Management Plan, it was created 13 years ago to protect wetlands and balance them with development. ''That plan never worked, and now it's time to get one that does,'' said Susan Bass Levin, commissioner-designate of the State Department of Community Affairs. Developers want to build a 2.1-million-square-foot shopping center, 1,000 hotel rooms and 2.2 million square feet of office space called Meadowlands Mills. Conservationists want to see the area cleaned and preserved.

title: U.N. Aide Asks More Security Troops for Afghanistan
description: A senior United Nations official who has spent weeks monitoring tensions between warlords who control much of post-Taliban Afghanistan but is quitting his post said today that he believed the international security force deployed here should be expanded across the country and increased to perhaps as many as 35,000 soldiers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sulzer's Orders Fall
description: The Swiss machinery maker Sulzer said its orders fell in the fourth quarter, leaving it unable to meet its earnings and sales targets for 2003. The company, which is based in Winterthur, made its forecasts while fending off a takeover bid last year from InCentive Capital, which holds a stake of almost 10 percent. It was Sulzer's first sales decline in more than two years, although orders for oil pumps climbed 13 percent, and its sales of turbo-machinery services rose 57 percent. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Hingis and Capriati Ready For Rematch in Australia
description: There was more relief than delight on the faces of Jennifer Capriati and Martina Hingis after they advanced to the Australian Open final. Both women have been here before, and both knew that their return trips were in genuine jeopardy of being canceled on Thursday.

title: Trying to Salvage What Can Be Salvaged While the Creditors Line Up
description: When he resigned as chairman and chief executive of Enron on Wednesday under pressure from outside creditors, Kenneth L. Lay said he was stepping aside to ensure the survival of the company. But as Enron tries to sort through creditors' claims and to tally the billions of dollars in debt parked off its balance sheet, its chances of surviving, even in a greatly diminished form, remain far from certain.

title: Jobless Claims Are Now Near A 6-Month Low
description: The number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits fell last week to the lowest level in almost six months, the Labor Department reported today, a sign that companies are slowing the pace of dismissals.

title: Paterson's Mayor Indicted On Charges of Trading City Contracts for Gifts
description: The mayor of Paterson was indicted today on federal charges of taking cash, gifts, 14 vacation trips, home improvements and payments for ''female companionship'' from city vendors in return for contracts.

title: BIOGEN WILL PAY UP TO $250 MILLION TO SCHERING
description: The biotechnology company Biogen will pay the drug maker Schering of Germany as much as $250 million to settle a patent dispute over medicines used to treat multiple sclerosis. Biogen will initially pay the Berlex unit of Schering $20 million. If an appeals court rules that Biogen infringed on Berlex's patents, the company will pay as much as $230 million more to Berlex and its partners as a licensing fee, a Schering spokesman, Oliver Renner, said. The agreement allows Biogen to cap its liability. If the appeals court rules that Biogen did not infringe on Berlex's patent, then there will be no second payment, Mr. Renner said. The dispute involves the rights to a technology used to produce medicines using Chinese hamster ovary cells.

title: Bush Requests $2.1 Billion More for Homeland Security
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  President Bush reiterated today his commitment to keeping the nation's borders safe, saying that he would ask Congress to spend an additional $2.1 billion next year for that purpose.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Yom Kippur Holiday Proposal
description: Trenton's superintendent of schools has recommended that the city's public schools remain open on Yom Kippur. The superintendent, James Lytle, who is Jewish, said that classes were too often interrupted during the fall months and that only a small number of students actually observed the holiday. Under his proposal, Jewish students would still be excused from their classes during the holiday. Mr. Lytle said he would withdraw his proposal if the teachers' and principals' unions did not approve it.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Concern Over Antiloitering Proposal
description: Civil rights groups are voicing concerns about the Portland city attorney's work to revise the city's ordinance against loitering. One revision would give the police the authority to remove people from public benches; another would prevent people from resting on a sidewalk if it interfered with pedestrian traffic. To become law, the revisions would have to be approved by the City Council.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 13 about Carmen Rivera and her daughter, Tenia, who have muscular dystrophy and were helped by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service -- a charity assisted by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund -- referred incorrectly in some copies to the size of the room where they live. It is 15 feet square (225 square feet), as the article said, not 15 square feet.

title: Embracing the Ambiguity Inescapable in a Story
description: ''Storytelling'' was shown as part of the 39th New York Film Festival in 2001. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 29; the full text is available at nytimes .com. The film opens today at the Angelika Film Center in Greenwich Village.

description: GREENE-Don. Role model, big brother & good friend. The world is a better place because of Don. Bud and Marilyn

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Near Ground Zero To Reopen
description: Transit officials said yesterday that the World Trade Center station on the E subway line would reopen Monday morning. The reopening would go far in restoring the subway map ever closer to its old appearance and easing subway congestion on the A, C and E lines. The E train station, almost untouched by the Sept. 11 terror attack, is beneath the northeast corner of ground zero and has remained closed mainly because the recovery work above it meant that passengers leaving the station would have nowhere to go. The station is the nearest to the trade center except the Cortlandt Street 1 and 9 station, which was heavily damaged and will be demolished. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: Bus Driver Takes Children on Detour of 150 Miles
description: A school bus driver who the F.B.I. said was armed with a loaded rifle took 13 children on an unexplained six-hour, 150-mile ride south today, from this small farm community to suburban Maryland.

title: Ex-Workers Say Unit's Earnings Were 'Illusory'
description: A major division of the Enron Corporation overstated its profits by hundreds of millions of dollars over the last three years, and senior Enron executives were warned almost a year ago that the division's profits were illusory, according to several former employees.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Energy Acquisition Considered
description: Woodside Petroleum of Australia wants to buy the oil and gas exploration and production assets of the German energy company Veba Oil and Gas, the company told the Australian Stock Exchange. Woodside would not disclose details, but media reports in Australia suggest the assets could be worth $2 billion. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Safin Outlasts Haas in Men's Semifinal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 25  It was an Australian Open men's semifinal with two faces, and one only had to look at the face of Tommy Haas's coach, David Ayme, to understand why.

description: IS there a Lycian syndrome developing in Lower Manhattan?

title: Political Reform Has to Start on Television
description: The Enron story has brought into sharp focus the links between politics, business and campaign money. What they have in common is television.

title: Bipartisanship and Beautiful People at Hearings
description: The first day of public hearings in a Congressional investigation is like opening day of the baseball season. The seats are filled, the anticipation is boundless and the players -- in this case, the lawmakers -- are dreaming of glory.

title: Developing an Ear for Nature's Untuned Orchestra
description: It's name-that-creature time. We're sitting in the living room, just like a family from the time before television, listening. We're playing tracks from a new CD of animal sounds, and trying to guess the source of each noise. Some of the sounds are not too hard. Whale recordings have become familiar enough to be recognizable. The wolf howl is easy. And my son guesses that the trumpeting of an elk, a whinny that sounds like a scream, is a horse. Pretty close.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: For Musicals, Big and Brassy Gives Way To Small And Affordable
description: IN November an unheralded and underfinanced new musical, ''Little Ham,'' began a showcase production at the Hudson Guild Theater in Chelsea. After four weeks, to attract publicity and potential investors, the show converted to a union contract and had an official Off Broadway opening. Without expectations I went to see it, mainly because the week before Christmas there wasn't much else on my theatergoing schedule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, IRENE
description: STERN-Irene. SAR Academy mourns the loss of the beloved wife of Boris Stern, loving mother of our longtime benefactor, Joel Stern, and former parent Roberta Horowitz. May the entire family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President Ludwig Bravmann, Vice-Chairman, Board of Trustees

description: NEW YORK

title: Fed Chairman Hints at End Of Rate Cuts
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, signaled today that the Fed was ready to declare its campaign of interest rate cuts over, telling a Congressional committee that the economy appears to be on the brink of recovery.

title: Bill Would Require Laboratories to Adopt Strict Security
description: In the months since the anthrax scare, Congress has hammered out legislation with universities and researchers to reduce the risk that viruses, bacteria and toxins might turn up in biological weapons.

title: Nets' Victory Earns Scott a Trip to All-Star Game
description: Byron Scott glanced at the floor with about four minutes left against the Houston Rockets tonight and realized he would be booking a trip to Philadelphia for the All-Star Game on Feb. 10.

title: No Headline
description: Enron's collapse brought to light business practices now under investigation by Congress. The article at the right and the one below describe two of them: how former employees say Enron overstated profits by hundreds of millions of dollars, and how it provided selected backers with information not available to company shareholders.

title: Bush Says Arafat Is Not Doing Enough to Fight Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  President Bush expressed deep disappointment with Yasir Arafat today, accusing him of doing too little to stop terrorism in the Middle East and, indeed, allowing it to flourish.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Spy Chief to Run Police Intelligence
description: A former spy master with the Central Intelligence Agency joined the New York Police Department yesterday to serve as its deputy commissioner for intelligence, a new position that was created to help steer the department through the post-Sept. 11 world.

title: Calligraphy, Cavorting Pigs and Other Body-Mind Happenings
description: Performance art and body art were far-out stuff in the United States and Europe starting in the 1960's. But a version of them had already existed for centuries in East Asia. It was called calligraphy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KELLY, MARTIN J.
description: KELLY-Martin J. On your 75th birthday. With loving thoughts and memories. Ed

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about reports of listening devices in an aircraft outfitted in the United States for China's used an erroneous given name in some editions for the United States ambassador, who was cited as an advocate of improving relations. He is Clark T. Randt, not Alexander.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz; Two Commissioned Works That Range Far and Wide
description: Jazz has been a natural area for speculation about the musical connections between Africa and the New World, given its unchartable stylistic range, its high level of musicianship and its natural emphasis on study. Two new works commissioned by Jazz at Lincoln Center will be presented tonight and tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall: Randy Weston's ''Ancient Future'' and Danilo Perez's ''Freedom of Colors.'' They look at the Old World-New World nexus in slightly different ways.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The big fish in the middle of Times Square is Blue Fin, in the new W Hotel. It's the second local production from Stephen Hanson, who opened a Times Square branch of Ruby Foo's Dim Sum and Sushi Palace two years ago, and like that restaurant, Blue Fin aims to please the eye. Large mustard-colored booths downstairs look out over a shiny sushi bar, a floating staircase and a school of polypropylene fish suspended from the ceiling.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: American and British Air Reject Government Terms for Alliance
description: American Airlines and British Airways ( news/quote ) rejected conditions proposed by Washington today that would have given the two carriers the right to merge their operations across the Atlantic.

title: Official Says Bush Renewed Pledge of $20 Billion in Aid
description: John C. Whitehead, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said yesterday that President Bush had renewed his pledge to send the city $20 billion in federal aid to help it rebuild after the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: G.I. Raid on Taliban
description: In the most intense fighting of recent weeks, Army Special Forces killed as many as 15 Taliban fighters and captured 27 in a raid 60 miles north of Kandahar, officials said. One American was wounded.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about plans to rebuild the transportation network at the World Trade Center site gave an outdated name for the organization overseeing development in Lower Manhattan. It is the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. It recently changed its name from the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation.

title: Trade Center Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCH, STUART S., M.D.
description: ASCH-Stuart S., M.D. Professor Emeritus of Clinical Psychiatry, Weill Medical College of Cornell University, and Honorary Attending Psychiatrist, New York-Presbyterian Hospital. An unusually gifted teacher, clinician and administrator, Dr. Stuart Asch was a beloved member of our department since 1976. He combined warm compassion with intense intellectual curiosity, and taught his students and colleagues as he cured his patients. His verbal fluency and quick sense of humor insured that the process was always fun. Heartfelt condolences to his devoted wife, Mary, and to his children and grandchildren, of whom he was always proud. Jack D. Barchas, M.D. Chairman, Dept of Psychiatry Philip J. Wilner, M.D. Medical Director Lisa S. Sombrotto, M.D. Clinical Director New York Weill Cornell Medical Center

title: Domestic Security Spending To Double Under Bush Plan
description: President Bush said today that he would propose doubling the amount the government spends on domestic security next year to nearly $38 billion, saying the United States was ''still under attack'' and would remain on a war footing for a long time to come.

title: Wall Street Journal Reporter Missing in Karachi for 2 Days
description: Daniel Pearl, a Wall Street Journal reporter who was in Karachi, Pakistan, reporting on Al Qaeda, has been reported missing. He left the home where he was staying on Tuesday to meet two people who had presented themselves as sources with contacts in the terrorist network, according to a spokesman for Dow Jones & Company, which owns The Journal.

title: And Swashes Buckled All Around
description: The arrival in theaters of the latest film adaptation of Alexandre Dumas pre's durable tale of treachery and vengeance is a puzzling, somewhat anachronistic event.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell to an 18-year low in 2001 as the recession in the United States hurt exports of electronics and other high-technology equipment. Japan's surplus stood at 6.6 trillion yen ($50 billion) last year, 38 percent lower than in 2000. The surplus has declined over the last decade as manufacturers have moved some production overseas, where costs are lower. Total export volume, which removes changes in exchange rates, fell 15 percent, the 12th straight decline. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Orders Planes
description: The Irish airline Ryanair has ordered 100 Boeing 737 jets and taken options on another 50 as it tries to overtake national carriers like British Airways and Lufthansa. The catalog price of the deal would be $9.1 billion, Boeing said, but the airline probably received a discount of up to 30 percent to win the order. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: AMERICAN AND AMERICA WEST AIRLINES RECALL WORKERS
description: The AMR Corporation's American Airlines and a rival, America West Airlines, are calling back employees laid off after the Sept. 11 attacks as the carriers add flights before the summer travel season. American is bringing back at least 400 flight attendants, beginning April 1, an AMR spokesman, Todd Burke, said. America West Airlines will recall 75 pilots from mid-February through early March, the unit of the America West Holdings Corporation said. Airlines cut more than 90,000 jobs as the Sept. 11 attacks worsened a travel slump.

title: At 30, Shane Mosley Seeks Stardom Beyond the Ring
description: Shane Mosley stared at the wall of Gleason's Gym in Brooklyn. Dozens of photographs were taped up there. They were of fighters big and small in weight, fierce and friendly in disposition. But all were champions at one point or another.

title: Indictment of a Brooklyn Judge Provides Details of Seemingly Routine Corruption
description: Two men were strolling near the courthouse in Downtown Brooklyn at lunchtime on June 11.

title: China Invites Backers of a Free Taiwan to Visit
description: China extended an invitation today to members of Taiwan's officially pro-independence governing party to visit the mainland, apparently signaling a more conciliatory approach toward the disputed island.

title: Marmite on Your Bagel
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Say Former Enron Executive Committed Suicide
description: Aformer senior executive of the Enron Corporation ( news/quote ) who challenged the company's troubled financial practices was found shot to death in a car in his suburban Houston neighborhood today. The police said he died from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot to the head.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Drought Warning Area Expanded
description: The Department of Environmental Protection has expanded a regional drought warning to include seven more counties: Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Monmouth, Morris, Ocean and Passaic. The warning urges voluntary conservation by county residents, but allows the state authority to reduce flow rates and enact other temporary changes if necessary. Drought warnings were declared in 13 other counties on Nov. 21.

title: So-So Game From Duke Is Too Much for Eagles
description: Duke's nonconference road games at this time of year take on the appearance of a traveling road show, with opposing fans turning out as much for the slim chance of an upset as for a peak at the best team in the country. Boston College sold out Conte Forum tonight and its students, clad in mustard yellow T-shirts, tried their best to rattle Duke's best player, Jason Williams.

title: A Baseball Great
On the Street: So Much for Baseball Season
On the Street: So Much for Baseball Season
In My Honest Opinion
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Critic Who Quit Top Enron Post Is Found Dead
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 25  The body of a former Enron Corporation ( news/quote ) vice chairman who resigned last May after voicing concerns about the company's financial practices was discovered early this morning inside his Mercedes-Benz after he apparently killed himself.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 18 about the White House's refusal to turn over documents related to its energy task force misstated the budget for another program on which the president acted during the day -- Safe and Stable Families, which helps children whose fathers are in prison. The current budget is $375 million; $130 million is the amount by which President Bush is proposing to increase it for the 2003 fiscal year.

title: Yankees Add Coomer To Bolster Infield
description: The Yankees signed the veteran infielder Ron Coomer to a minor league contract yesterday with the hope that he can give them a strong backup at first base and third base.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 17 comparing modern antiterrorism efforts with the capture of four Nazi saboteurs in 1942 misstated the location of the Palisades Amusement Park, which the saboteurs had intended to visit. It was in Cliffside Park and Fort Lee, N.J., not nearby Palisades Park, N.J.

title: The Jupiter Orchestra Is a Lively Survivor
description: No one really expected the scrappy Jupiter Symphony to survive the passing of its founder and conductor Jens Nygaard, who died of cancer at 69 in September. Not even Mr. Nygaard.

title: Globalization Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, RICARDO J.
description: QUINN-Ricardo J. FDNY Paramedic. Tragically in the line of duty on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Virginia (nee Lomangino). Loving father of Kevin, Adam and Nicholas Monaco. Cherished son of Bernard and Annamaria Quinn. Dearest brother of Gregory, Bernie and the late David. Memorial service Sunday, January 27, 2002, 2-5 PM at Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193rd Street.

title: Corrections
description: Transcription excerpts yesterday from remarks at a House committee hearing about the Enron Corporation's collapse used a mispelled given name in some copies for an executive who had questioned the company's accounting practices. She is Sherron Watkins, not Sharon.

title: Corrections
description: In his column yesterday, Paul Krugman misattributed the source of the phrase ''Clinton-Levitt recession,'' describing the current economic situation. Its author was Don Devine of the American Conservative Union, not Lawrence Kudlow. Mr. Krugman apologizes.

title: A Wrenching Family Dilemma Inflicted by Mental Illness
description: For a film about a weighty subject, ''My Sister's Keeper,'' tomorrow night's offering on CBS, feels feather light.

title: Western Brands Eye Lucrative China Market : The Lure of the East
description: BEIJING  On a bitterly cold evening in central Beijing last month, Chinese and Italian menswear executives toasted each other at a reception at the city's plush China World Hotel.

title: Bertalan de Nemethy, 90, Equestrian Coach
description: Bertalan de Nemethy, an elegant, one-time Hungarian cavalry captain who coached the United States Equestrian Team to Olympic and other international success for a quarter century, died Jan. 16 at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 90 and had contracted pneumonia after being hospitalized the week before with an arm injury.

title: NUCOR TO BUY IDLED STEEL MILL FROM TRICO
description: The Nucor Corporation, a steel maker, received approval to buy the Trico Steel Company's idled steel mill in Decatur, Ala., for $120 million. A Delaware bankruptcy court approved the purchase of the mill, which makes steel sheet, often used in appliances, Nucor said. Trico, a joint venture between the LTV Corporation, Sumitomo Metal Industries and the Corus Group, filed for bankruptcy protection in March. Nucor, based in Charlotte, N.C., expects the transaction to be completed in the third quarter. The mill can make 1.9 million tons of steel a year, Nucor said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vodafone Sells Unit
description: The Vodafone Group said it agreed to sell Arcor DB-Telematik G.m.b.H. and its railway telecommunications network to Deutsche Bahn for 1.15 billion euros ($1 billion) to focus on its traditional phone business in Germany. Deutsche Bahn, which will get 49.9 percent now, will assume full control as early as July. The network controls signals and switching on the railway's tracks.

title: An Extraordinary Act of Giving
description: This year The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has broken last year's record figure with more than $8 million in contributions. That says something extraordinary about New Yorkers. It would not have been surprising if the fund had come up short after the outpouring of aid, much of it from New Yorkers, for the victims of Sept. 11. Such a stark emergency seemed as though it might engulf our awareness of the chronic need that many people in this city feel even on the best of days. But that didn't happen. What happened is that New York's sense of need -- and our response to it -- has been enlarged.

title: KORDELL STEWART -- Bruised/Sports of The Times; For Stewart, a Cut That Wounds Deeply
description: KORDELL STEWART faced the news media yesterday afternoon, 48 hours before the most important game of his career. He was engaging, introspective and diplomatic, even though the last three years have been the most harrowing of his career.

title: Part of Plane Wing Falls Through Roof
description: A drainage pipe from an airplane wing fell through the roof of a warehouse in Oceanside, Long Island, just before noon yesterday, the Nassau County police said. No one was injured.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Ads Suggest the Pitfalls Of Losing Art Education
description: At the beginning of a television commercial that will first be broadcast tomorrow, a boy, about 10 years old, walks past a street musician playing a violin, looks toward him and blurts, ''Get a job!''

title: Shelters Safer Than Streets, Report Suggests
description: Despite their unsavory reputation, the largest city-run homeless shelters for single adults may be safer these days than the streets in most city neighborhoods, according to crime statistics compiled by the Department of Homeless Services for the first time last year.

title: Opponents Hope to Raise Doubts on Campaign Overhaul
description: With the House set to consider an overhaul of the campaign finance law, Republican opponents of the effort suggested today that they would seek to stoke doubts among lawmakers about fundamentally changing the system under which they were elected.

title: U.S. TO RECONSIDER AGENCY CONTRACTS IN ENRON SCANDAL
description: The Bush administration ordered federal agencies today to review contracts worth more than $60 million a year with Arthur Andersen and the Enron Corporation, saying the accusations swirling around both companies raised doubts about whether they should continue to receive taxpayer money.

title: 2 Canadian Energy Concerns in Merger Talks
description: TORONTO, Jan. 25  The Alberta Energy ( news/quote ) Company and PanCanadian Energy ( news/quote ) said today that they were in discussions about merging. The combination would be Canada's biggest producer of oil and natural gas, with a market value of about $12.5 billion, and would rank among the biggest gas suppliers in North America.

title: In Performance: Classical Music; An Improvisatory Bach Makes the Harpsichord Sing
description: Bradley Brookshire

title: Beliefs; A revival of religious traditions sweeps Vietnam. A rejection of modernization? Seemingly not.
description: Dong Ho is a Vietnamese village near Hanoi where for centuries families have created bold, colorful woodblock prints portraying village scenes, folk tales and national legends. This ancient art form is now supported there by Unesco.

title: The Neediest Cases; Eyeglasses Help a Boy, 5, Improve in His Preschool
description: The section of Madison Avenue where Frankie Arce goes to preschool does not contain any advertising agencies -- only the somber red-brick buildings of the Taft Houses, between 112th and 115th Streets in East Harlem.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Tourism Fell In 2001
description: Tourism declined about 9 percent last year, mainly because of the worldwide drop in travel after Sept. 11, the state said. Roughly 6.3 million visitors came to Hawaii in 2001, according to preliminary figures. The largest decline was in foreign visitors, who declined 16 percent from the year before. Mainland tourism was down 5 percent. Immediately after Sept. 11, the Legislature allocated $36 million to improve transportation security and $10 million to promote tourism, the state's biggest industry. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: AMR Rejects Pilot Request on Regional Jets
description: The AMR Corporation rejected a proposal today from its American Airlines pilots to shift the flying of regional jets from its commuter unit, American Eagle, to American Airlines. AMR said the plan was not financially sound.

title: Something Different for Jones
description: Roy Jones Jr. will try something different as a prelude to his fight against the Australian light heavyweight champion Glen Kelly next Saturday night in Miami. On Monday, Jones will appear as a rap singer at Club Level on South Beach.

title: The Tax-Cut Wars Continue
description: The Democrats' recurring nightmare about President Bush's State of the Union Message next Tuesday is that he will take time out from basking in all the applause to blame Democrats for obstructing legislation to cut taxes and revive the economy. Partly to neutralize this threat, partly to offer a valid alternative, Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, tried this week to win approval for a Democratic bill consisting of carefully targeted tax cuts and unemployment benefits that contrast sharply with the huge giveaways in the Republican bill.

title: Hopkins Grateful for His Success
description: Bernard Hopkins has celebrated his 37th birthday since he beat Flix Trinidad. But regret that glory came so late in his career never came as well.

title: Corrections
description: A list of recipients on Thursday with an article about grants to downtown arts groups from the Andy Warhol Foundation included a misspelling from the foundation for the name of one group. It is Rhizome.org, not Rhizone.

title: In Performance
description: Classical Music

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,096 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as the result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: In Fragile Times, Ruggedness Returns
description: NEW YORK  In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on Sept.11, the date by which it seems all things are now defined, the description of the iconic male shifted dramatically. This new man walks with the sturdy earnestness of someone who might be good in a crisis; he exudes stability. The size of his heart and, perhaps, his biceps are far more important than the measure of his stock portfolio.

title: The Enron Inquiry: Lessons From a Collapse
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Gun Thefts At County Building
description: Investigators for St. Clair County, southeast of St. Louis, said 151 handguns had been stolen from a county evidence room in multiple thefts. Seven firearms have been recovered, and investigators are looking for the others. The guns had been seized by county law enforcement agencies. The thefts were discovered this month after a police department asked that its seized guns be returned. Joseph Williams, a building custodian, was charged with burglary this month after officials said he left the evidence room with some of the guns. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a visit to Houston by the Rev. Al Sharpton to draw attention to Enron employees who have lost their jobs misstated the surname of the local representative for the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who also planned a visit. The aide is William-Paul Thomas, not Michael.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, FANNIE
description: BARON-Fannie. For close to 80 years you were the matriarch of the NYC taxi business. You and your beloved husband Sol and your beloved son Milton worked side by side to build the company. Your strength, wisdom, tenacity, leadership and, of course, brilliant mind will be missed by all of us. Your were a beautiful lady in a tough man's business. We admired you, respected you, and loved you. You will always be remembered by us. Team Systems-Cab Operating Co.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, MONROE JAY
description: MAYER-Monroe Jay. Of Greenville, SC, formerly of NYC, died January 24, 2002. Surviving are three sons, Donald, John and Tom Mayer, all of New York; one daughter, Jane Poisson of Indianapolis, IN; fourteen grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. Services will be held in Greenville, SC with burial in Mount Carmel Cemetery, Queens, NY. The Mackey Mortuary, Century Drive.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day last Saturday about a $6 million fine proposed by the Federal Communications Commission against the SBC Corporation, over rivals' access to part of its network in five states, carried an erroneous credit. It was by Reuters, not Bloomberg News.

title: Forrest Prefers His Cheers in the Ring
description: The screaming began when Shane Mosley stepped on the scale at Madison Square Garden yesterday evening. It had been like that all week, at least in the eyes of Vernon Forrest. Shane this, Shane that. Now Mosley was basking in the adulation of his fans at the weigh-in before tonight's bout with Forrest at the Garden's Theater.

title: Capriati Rallies to Retain Her Title
description: It was a final between two champions; a final played against the elements. Jennifer Capriati won both tussles today, requiring only one match point to finish off what Martina Hingis failed to do with four of her own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, STUART
description: SCHIFF-Stuart. Amy and I will miss you terribly. We worked closely together for 14 years and we enjoyed a lasting friendship for an additional 12 years. We grieve for Barbara and for Stephen and we will always fondly reflect smilingly on the hundreds of times we spent laughing together over those 26 years. Doodles, it's hard to believe that you are really gone; and I hope that if you happen to run into Eddie, that you will remind him that he still owes us money. With all of our love, Amy and Ronnie Goldberger

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Panel To Fight Corruption
description: Faced with a growing number of political scandals, President Kim Dae Jung appointed members of an anticorruption commission. Kim Chul Kyu, the chairman, said the panel would dedicate itself to ''eradicating corruption involving officials in leadership posts.'' The appointment of the commission was delayed after the man first selected as chairman was linked to one of the main targets of prosecutors. The government has offered rewards of as much as $150,000 for evidence of corruption by government officials. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: IVAX CLEARED TO KEEP SELLING GENERIC CANCER DRUG
description: The Ivax Corporation said yesterday that regulators would allow it to keep selling a generic version of the cancer drug Taxol, after Ivax signed a licensing agreement with the medicine's original marketer, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, settling patent suits between the drug makers. Earlier this week, Bristol-Myers asked the Food and Drug Administration to remove a disputed Taxol patent from the agency's registry, effectively ending yearslong patent litigation between the companies. The withdrawn patent is held by a third drug maker, American Bioscience which, along with Bristol-Myers, sought to stop Ivax from selling the drug. Ivax is based in Miami.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Raises Outlook
description: All Nippon Airways, Japan's No. 2 airline after JAL, said it would beat its full-year sales target by up to 30 billion yen ($223 million) as increased demand for domestic flights offset a downturn in overseas travel. In November, the company lowered its sales forecast to 1.2 trillion yen ($8.9 billion) in the aftermath of Sept. 11. But sales recovered in December, when ANA carried 3.3 million passengers, a 67 percent increase from the previous month. The company now estimates that it will lose about 40 billion yen in the fiscal year that ends March 31. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, LARRY
description: LEVENSON-Larry. Larry Levenson's family, with great pain, must tell you of his tragic death on January 24, 2002. Larry was one of the best, nicest people who ever lived. His career in advertising was brilliant, his many other writings were sharp, insightful, full of love and humor. But the magic was in his love of family, of friends, of community, of his joy of simply being with others. He shared his wit and wisdom and compassion wherever he was welcome, and he was welcomed everywhere. He leaves behind his wonderfully strong and devoted wife Davida, his children Alan and Hilary, Laura and Jay, Lee and Kate, Mark and Holly, his grandchildren Indy, Billy, Ben, Emmy, Annie, Tyler, Brian and Austin, a long string of cousins, his brother Bob and sister-in-law Kathe. In a prescient moment, Larry wrote, ''I'll miss me when I'm gone.'' You said it, brother. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, January 27th, 1:30PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Topics of The Times; Foot-dragging on Fat
description: Three years ago the Food and Drug Administration announced a plan to require food manufacturers to disclose the amount of trans fatty acids in a product. That made good health sense; the artery-clogging ''trans fats'' may pose an even greater risk of heart disease than the saturated fats already listed on package labels. Trans fats are formed when vegetable oils are hardened into margarine and into the shortening used in baked goods or other processed foods.

title: Corrections
description: A Books of The Times review of ''The Caprices'' by Sabrina Murray on Jan. 9 quoted the novelist L. P. Hartley incorrectly in an allusion to the theme of change reflected in Ms. Murray's collection of short stories. He wrote that the past is a foreign country, not that childhood is another country.

title: Drug Makers Willing to Pay F.D.A. Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (Bloomberg News)  Drug makers signaled a willingness today to help pay for the Food and Drug Administration to expand policing of the industry, an industry official said.

title: Masters Record Set For 3,200 Relay
description: A Central Park Track Club 3,200-meter relay team set a world masters record for ages 60 to 69 when it won the event in 10 minutes 15.2 seconds Thursday night at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. The meet was sponsored by the New York Road Runners.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am disappointed in Yasir Arafat.''

title: France Fines General, 83, for Memoir Justifying Algerian War
description: An 83-year-old former French general who wrote a book admitting that he had tortured and summarily executed dozens of Algerians during France's brutal colonial war was convicted today ''of trying to justify war'' and fined $6,500.

title: Ericsson's 2001 Loss Is First in 50 Years
description: LONDON, Jan. 25  Ericsson ( news/quote ), the Swedish maker of telephone equipment, reported its first unprofitable year in half a century today and warned that losses in the first quarter of 2002 would be even greater than analysts had expected.

title: In the Middle East, All Violence Is Not Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Shortchanging the City's Schools
description: Governor George Pataki said, in this year's State of the State address, that we need to ''throw out the existing school aid formula and to achieve equity.'' Last year he delivered a similar message, calling the current system for financing our public schools a ''dinosaur'' that should be ''on the ash heap of history.'' At about the same time, State Supreme Court Justice Leland DeGrasse issued a landmark ruling in Campaign for Fiscal Equity v. State of New York, declaring the state's school funding system inequitable and unconstitutional.

title: Many Voices, but Little Dialogue On Memorial for Trade Center Site
description: One group talks of a quiet, peaceful place to sit and remember loved ones, away from tourists and commercial activity; the other, of master plans and infrastructure and a memorial that will accommodate millions of visitors each year.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Senate Limits Business Tax Break
description: The Senate continued to work on a proposed economic recovery package, rejecting a Republican amendment that would have expanded a tax break for businesses. The amendment, sponsored by Senator Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, would have allowed companies to write off 30 percent of the value of any investments they make in new factories and equipment for the next three years. As proposed by Democrats, the plan would limit the write-off to this year. The vote came as members of both parties questioned whether the stimulus package would be needed if the economy continued to improve. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Demand For Nuclear Inspections
description: Senior diplomats from the United States, Japan and South Korea demanded that North Korea agree to inspections of its nuclear sites by the International Atomic Energy Agency as a condition of the agreement under which they are supporting construction of two nuclear reactors to fill the North's energy needs. President Bush is to visit South Korea next month, and the Foreign Ministry said four former American ambassadors to South Korea would travel to North Korea during the visit to promote dialogue. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKEL, JACK S.
description: SOKEL-Jack S. Devoted husband of Molly. Adored father of Drs. Andrew and Nancy. Dear brother of Saul. Cherished grandfather of Jason, Julia and Jacqueline. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Phone Executive To Leave
description: Tormod Hermansen, the chief executive of Telenor, Norway's biggest phone company, will leave by the end of June after 11 years at the helm. Mr. Hermansen, 61, oversaw the former state monopoly's $1.7 billion public offering 13 months ago. He also headed the company during a failed merger with a Swedish rival, Telia, in 1999. The Telia-Telenor merger was scrapped after two years of talks as the Norwegian and Swedish governments bickered over which country should control the combined company, where assets should be located and which executives should be in charge.

title: CAPITAL AUTOMOTIVE BUYS 14 AUTO DEALERSHIPS
description: Capital Automotive REIT, the largest owner of auto dealership properties in the nation, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 14 locations from Sonic Automotive Inc. for $80 million. The properties, in seven states, include Cadillac, Honda, Oldsmobile and Volvo dealerships, Capital Automotive said. The company said it expected to complete the purchase in the second quarter. Capital Automotive, based in McLean, Va., is the first real estate investment trust to focus on auto dealerships. The company has about 260 properties in 27 states. It rents the real estate to dealership operators.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: No Death Penalty For 2 In Killing
description: District Attorney J. Tom Morgan of DeKalb County will not to seek the death penalty against two of the three men charged in the Dec. 15, 2000, killing of Derwin Brown, the sheriff-elect. Mr. Morgan, who has said he, too, was a target of a death plot by the same men, said he would defer a decision on whether to seek the death penalty against former Sheriff Sidney Dorsey, who is accused of ordering the killing. The trial of the other two men, David Ramsey and Melvin Walker, is set for March 11. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Afghans Choose Panel for Organizing Crucial Grand Council
description: Afghanistan marked a political milestone today, with the announcement of a 21-member commission that will organize a grand council, known as a loya jirga, to choose the country's next government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOULOS, JOHN
description: BOULOS-John. We thank God for the life of a great husband, father, brother, and salute a great American soccer star and soccer's premier Hall of Famer. Mary and Alfred J. Boulos

title: A Profitable Amazon Looks to Do an Encore
description: So Amazon.com Inc. actually turned a profit. Skeptics thought it never would and even fans assumed that the company would take another couple of years before its ink ran black.

title: Here Comes the Judge, Making His Game Again
description: Since judgment is a major element in success at the bridge table, one might expect that a judge would be a successful player. One thinks immediately of Walter Avarelli, who won 12 world titles as a member of Italy's Blue Team, and Amalya Kearse, who won the 1986 World Women's Pair title and sits on the federal bench in Manhattan. Count Egmont von Dewitz, a German judge, was a regular member of his national team in the postwar years.

title: British Airways And American Cancel Alliance
description: American Airlines and British Airways abandoned their effort to merge their operations across the Atlantic yesterday, rejecting a demand by Washington that they transfer some of their landing and takeoff rights at Heathrow Airport to competitors.

title: The Evolving Definition Of Underground Hip-Hop
description: Some rappers come alive when they rap. With Beans, it's almost the opposite: he looks as if he's gone into a trance, as if the words he's saying are emanating from somewhere else.

title: West Village Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Blast in South Jersey Factory Kills Worker, Hurts 4 Others
description: A vat of acid being used to clean metal exploded this morning in this South Jersey town, killing one worker and injuring four others, one of them seriously.

title: Most of Assessment Review Panel Is Removed in Nassau County
description: The Nassau County executive is removing all but one member of a board that has been accused of political and personal favoritism in reducing property tax assessments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: GOLDSTEIN-Sylvia. The Aaron Copland Fund for Music expresses its regret at the death of a great friend of contemporary American music, Sylvia Goldstein.

title: Ericsson's 2001 Loss Is First in 50 Years
description: LONDON, Jan. 25  Ericsson ( news/quote ), the Swedish maker of telephone equipment, reported its first unprofitable year in half a century today and warned that losses in the first quarter of 2002 would be even greater than analysts had expected.

title: The Road Back to Formal:Vuitton's New Voyage
description: PARIS  In a smart start to the French menswear season, Louis Vuitton's show on Friday pointed the way ahead, as hunky, manly models showed off a collection that melded skillfully sporty and tailored clothes. Think multipocketed leather vest worn under a traditional Shetland jacket that sparkled with a reflective weave.

title: Accommodations, Next Door to Devastation
description: When guests of the Marriott Financial Center hotel ask the front desk for a map of Lower Manhattan, they cannot help but notice the advertisements for places that have been obliterated: the Windows on the World restaurant, for example, and the mall that once thrived beneath the World Trade Center (''We've got great shopping in the bag!'').

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILS PALESTINIAN CHIEF ON ARMS SHIPMENT
description: In his harshest comments yet on Yasir Arafat, President Bush suggested today that the Palestinian leader was ''enhancing terror'' with a boatload of smuggled arms intended for use against Israel, as the president and top advisers met to consider ways to isolate and punish Mr. Arafat.

title: 'Sleeper Cells' in Singapore Show Al Qaeda's Long Reach
description: Shortly after the United States began bombing Afghanistan on Oct. 7, a 30-year-old Indonesian traveling on a false Filipino passport slipped into this tightly controlled city-state carrying a plan to strike back at America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, HERBERT S.
description: DAVIDSON-Herbert S. Passed away on January 24 at age 79. Beloved husband of Jan and the late Grace, devoted father to Ken and Willa and Andrew Epstein, adored and loving grandfather of Michael, dearest brother of Robert and Esther Davidoff, and much loved brother-in-law to Richard and Lynn Hyman, Diane and the late Martin Hyman, caring son-in-law of Billie Hyman. A leading innovator in the electronic distribution industry and the founder and CEO of Milgray Electronics, Inc. Passionately devoted to his family and friends, a generous and caring man with a wonderful sense of humor. He will be so greatly missed by all those whose lives he touched. Services on Sunday, January 27, at 1 PM. Gutterman's Parkside, Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, 718-284-1500.

title: U.S. Identifies a Canadian As Taker of Martyrdom Pledge
description: The Justice Department today identified a Canadian citizen of Tunisian descent as the fifth suspected Al Qaeda follower who the authorities said had pledged himself to martyrdom on a videotape found in Afghanistan, indicating he might be preparing for a suicide attack.

title: Nets' Martin Has Outside Shot at All-Star Team
description: After a relaxed 45-minute practice this morning, Nets Coach Byron Scott basked in his new role as coach of the Eastern Conference All-Stars by playing golf with two people who helped him get there: Rod Thorn, the team president, who hired him, and the star point guard Jason Kidd.

title: Brooklyn Bishop Silent on Handling of Sex Scandal
description: The Roman Catholic bishop of Brooklyn was basking yesterday in what is a joyous rite of passage for a priest, a Mass celebrating the 50th anniversary of his ordination. But he found himself confronted by suggestions that 20 years ago he helped to hide a scandal involving a Boston priest who molested boys.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: KURT WARNER -- Battered; Warner's Game Face Shows Strain
description: Kurt Warner will play Sunday, and his bruised ribs will give him pain. He is certain of this, just as he can be sure that the blitz-crazed Philadelphia Eagles will attempt to pepper him with crushing body shots and worsen his pain.

title: Christopher J. Blackwell: Seemingly Fearless
description: Christopher J. Blackwell liked life on the edge.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: A Gesture Of Peace
description: As part of reconciliation efforts on the divided island of Cyprus, the Greek Cypriots have asked the United Nations to help dispose of an weapons cache collected in the early 1970's in anticipation of war against the Turkish Cypriots. The request followed the first week of formal reunification talks between President Glafcos Clerides and Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader. The Greek Cypriots have also asked the United Nations to begin clearing the estimated 17,000 mines along the line that has separated the two groups since 1974. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: St. John's Keita out Tonight vs. Providence
description: St. John's center Abe Keita will miss tonight's game against Providence at Madison Square Garden because of a stress fracture in his foot.

title: 94-Year-Old Becomes Case Study in British Health Care Woes

title: No Qaeda or Taliban at U.S. Target This Week, Afghan Says

title: Castro's Road, a Historical Pageant
description: Cuba is back in the news with the arrival of prisoners from Afghanistan at the Guantnamo Bay naval base. But that hasn't aroused in the American public any renewed interest in Cuba's maximum leader, Fidel Castro. This apathy isn't likely to be disturbed by ''Fidel,'' the lumbering two-part biography on Showtime tomorrow and Monday nights.

title: Iona Manages to Keep Manhattan at a Distance
description: Iona emphatically turned Manhattan's early-season basketball success into a memory tonight. The Gaels handed Manhattan its third defeat in the last five games with a 75-70 Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference victory, generating cheers of ''over-rated'' from some of the 2,800 fans at Iona's Mulcahy Center.

title: Embassy Bombings Case Goes to New Judge
description: The federal judge who presided in the trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the terrorist convicted in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center, has been assigned the future trials in the 1998 embassy bombings conspiracy that prosecutors say was led by Osama bin Laden.

title: TYSON FOODS WILL CLOSE 3 PLANTS AND LAY OFF 1,100
description: Tyson Foods Inc. will close three plants and lay off at least 1,100 workers as the company consolidates operations after its purchase of IBP Inc., the company said. Tyson will close IBP meat plants in Detroit and Grand Rapids, Mich., on March 15, the company said. On April 1, it will close an administrative office in Farmington Hills, Mich. The three locations employ about 1,100. The company will also close its DFG Foods plant and office in Chicago, which employs about 200. Production at DFG Foods, which was IBP's appetizer unit, will be shifted to Tyson's Chicago culinary foods plant, where DFG workers will be offered positions, the company said.

title: Durst Waives Extradition To Texas Trial In Murder
description: Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate heir, will soon leave his gritty cell in a 19th-century prison here for Texas, where he will spend months in a county jail awaiting trial on a murder charge.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: TOM BRADY -- Buoyant; Patriots' Brady May Be Young, But He's the Boss
description: When he was an anonymous backup quarterback with a modest $298,000 salary and only three pass attempts in the National Football League, Tom Brady offered David Patten, a veteran wide receiver for the New England Patriots, advice last summer about how to run a crisper route. Patten was, needless to say, surprised.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIEN, AUGUSTA
description: LEVIEN-Augusta. Born September 15, 1905, died January 25, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Eddie, loving mother of Joy and Jimmy and his wife, Arlene, proud grandmother of Jason and Stacey and her husband, Chris Ciauri, and great-grandmother of Sabrina, dear sister of Edward Ritz and his wife, Kitty, and Evelyn Wolf, and devoted aunt to many nieces and nephews. ''Augie'' was an extraordinary and beautiful woman, inside and out, who saw only the good in all people and never turned anyone away who needed a home or help. She will be greatly missed by all those whose lives she touched with her unbounded generosity, amazing vibrancy and exceptional kindness. Service Monday, January 28th, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Ron Taylor, 49, Voice of Blues and a Plant, Dies

title: 2 Canadian Energy Concerns in Merger Talks
description: The Alberta Energy Company and PanCanadian Energy said today that they were in discussions about merging. The combination would be Canada's biggest producer of oil and natural gas, with a market value of about $12.5 billion, and would rank among the biggest gas suppliers in North America.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Disputed Dam Project Begins
description: Construction has begun on a $550 million dam project on the Nile that will greatly increase electricity in Uganda, where less than 5 percent of the population of 22 million has it. Under consideration since 1994, the plan came under criticism from environmental groups and local residents because it will disturb burial sites and wipe out some white-water rapids. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: New Inquiry On Missing Journalist
description: The deputy prosecutor general, Oleksandr Baganets, said forensic experts would make a new examination of the headless body found in November 2000 that is believed to be the remains of the missing journalist Georgy Gongadze. The decision indicated a fresh initiative in response to Western pressure to solve the case. Mr. Gongadze's disappearance ignited widespread protests and months of political crisis after secret recordings made in the office of President Leonid D. Kuchma were played in Parliament. They ostensibly revealed that Mr. Kuchma, who said the tapes were doctored, had placed the journalist under surveillance and ordered a top police official to orchestrate his kidnapping, or worse. Mr. Baganets said new DNA tests would seek to remove the conflict between previous DNA tests. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Waldorf Moves Up; Tryon Set to Move On
description: Duffy Waldorf did enough to take the lead. Ty Tryon did enough to make himself proud.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consumer Prices Sag
description: Consumer prices fell 0.7 percent in 2001, the largest decline in three decades. Prices have been falling along with the economy, which is now mired in its third -- and deepest -- recession in the last decade. Retailers and others are cutting prices to compete with cheap imports that are flooding the country from nearby China. The price declines come even as the yen lost 16 percent of its value in the last four months of last year. The Bank of Japan expects prices to decline this year, too. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: The Women Behind The Masks Of Hate
description: FOR a year, Kathleen Blee, a small woman with a rather tentative voice, traveled America, seeking the ugly and the dangerous. She was interviewing neo-Nazis and members of the Ku Klux Klan and Christian Identity organizations for a book on women in hate groups. She sat over coffee with women who had spiked hair and swastika tattoos, and respectable-looking homemakers who smiled as they delivered racist utterances about blacks and Jews. At first, Ms. Blee, a sociology professor at the University of Pittsburgh, was horrified. Then scared. And then she got bored, pretending in desperation that she was just a tape recorder taking it all in. Finally, she grew numb.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Senate To Review Red Cross Safety
description: The recall of thousands of pints of blood by the American Red Cross has prompted a Senate investigation into the safety of the nation's blood supply. The call by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, chairman of the Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, came in response to court documents cited by Public Citizen, a liberal advocacy group. Senator Kennedy said the documents ''raise serious questions about the ability of the American Red Cross to assure the safety of its blood supply.''

title: KODAK STOCKHOLDERS APPROVE EMPLOYEE SHARE PLAN
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said shareholders approved a plan to exchange employee options now almost worthless after a 25 percent drop in the share price last year. Investors holding stock representing 90 percent of the votes cast approved the proposal, Kodak said. Employees with options to buy the stock at $37 a share can get new options at a 1-for-1 ratio, the company had said in a regulatory filing. They can exchange two grants for one if their options are priced at $58 to $69.99. Options priced at $79 and higher can be exchanged at a ratio of 3 to 1. About 61,000 employees hold options granted in 1998 and 2000 that are eligible to be exchanged. The new options are expected to be granted in August.

The Washington Group filed for Chapter 11 protection in May, attributing its financial problems to its July 2000 purchase of the engineers and constructors unit of the Raytheon Company. After the purchase closed, Washington Group sued Raytheon, saying the company had hidden the unit's cost overruns and other liabilities. The two companies announced a settlement of the legal disputes in November.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance on Jan. 14 (and in late editions on Jan. 13) misstated the rarity of resignations from that post over matters of principle. Historians generally agree that there were three, not two. Besides Mr. Vance, who objected in 1980 to the attempt at a military rescue of American hostages in Iran, and William Jennings Bryan (1915), over policies he felt might lead the country to war, Lewis Cass resigned in 1860 because he considered President James Buchanan weak on secessionists.

title: Kipling Knew What the U.S. May Now Learn
description: ''Take up the White Man's burden,'' was Rudyard Kipling's notorious prescription for the United States as it began to rule the Philippine Islands. That refrain, from an 1899 poem, eventually became a key exhibit in the case against the racism and exploitation of 19th-century imperialism. Kipling's attitudes toward ''new-caught, sullen peoples,/Half devil and half child'' permanently sullied his reputation.

Clifford Baxter, the former vice chairman of the Enron Corporation who had criticized the company's convoluted finances before resigning last May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLIN, HILDA
description: BERLIN-Hilda. Born in Leeds, England in 1913, this vibrant woman came to America in the 1930's and spread her abundant cheer until her death on January 23, 2002. Our plucky Hillie showered us with her compassion, loyalty and love, and cooked her way into our hearts. She had a long and loving marriage with the late Milton Berlin, and will be fondly remembered by her son, Ronald Berlin and daughter, Vickie Klinger; her daughterin-law Stephanie Magdziak and son-in-law, Phil Klinger; her dear brother, Gilbert Pelham; her greatly beloved granddaughters, Michele Klinger and Sofia Berlin; her devoted nieces and nephews, and a great many faithful friends. A memorial service will be held at Parkside Memorial Chapels on Sunday, January 27 at 3 PM. The family would welcome contributions in her memory to the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens.

With $21 million here, $28 million there, pretty soon the bottom line starts to suffer.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance on Jan. 14 (and in late editions on Jan. 13) misstated the rarity of resignations from that post over matters of principle. Historians generally agree that there were three, not two. Besides Mr. Vance, who objected in 1980 to the attempt at a military rescue of American hostages in Iran, and William Jennings Bryan (1915), over policies he felt might lead the country to war, Lewis Cass resigned in 1860 because he considered President James Buchanan weak on secessionists.
