title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Sentence In Omagh Bombing
description: The only person to be charged with a crime related to the 1998 car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, which killed 29 people and wounded hundreds, was sentenced to 14 years in prison for lending two cell phones to the Real I.R.A., the dissident republican paramilitary group that carried out the attack. Colm Murphy, a 49-year-old building contractor, was convicted on Tuesday by a special no-jury court that is used to try terrorist offenses. The bombing was the worst single act of violence in Northern Ireland's 30-year conflict. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: City Papers Belong to the Public
description: A week before he left office, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani quietly worked out a deal with New York City's records commissioner to move his papers to a private storage facility in Queens, where they now reside. This unprecedented and self-serving contract gives him the right to choose an archivist to catalog a roomful of city documents and to initially determine what is public and what is not. Mr. Giuliani's people have described this as an effort to help the city by financing and thus speeding up the archiving process. Not coincidentally, it will help Mr. Giuliani maintain control of his image and get quick access to material he needs to fulfill a $3 million book contract to write about his days as the city's mayor.

title: Mormons Project Image As Diverse as Olympics
description: The first time two Mormon missionaries knocked on the door of her family's house in Taiwan, Ming Chun Chen, a teenager, took one look at the young men in black suits struggling to introduce themselves in broken Mandarin and shut the door.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony's Profit Falls
description: Helped by its popular PlayStation 2 game console, Sony posted record quarterly sales while net income fell a lower-than-expected 14 percent compared with the year before. Sony said game sales jumped 63 percent in the period, which ended Dec. 31 and was the third quarter of its fiscal year, offsetting a 2.8 percent decline in its core electronics business, which has been plagued by weak demand for semiconductors. Sony also revised its annual sales forecast upward by 0.6 percent, to 7.55 trillion yen ($56 billion).

title: The Benefit of Manners
description: IT was mid-January, high social season in Palm Beach, and my mother and I were looking at pictures of puffy-haired socialites and their stoic husbands in the newspaper. ''I've always wanted to go to one of those black-tie parties,'' she said. It took me aback because Mom, a retired librarian, is no glamour puss. But when I saw an ad for a low-cost benefit, I suggested we attend.

title: Vail
description: Vail, Colo., one of the nation's largest ski resorts, turns a fit 40 this year. Celebrations of the onset of its middle age won't be held until the end of 2002, however, and with no new basins, bowls, lifts or lodges opening, this season is free of hoopla. Considering the noisy distraction of the Olympic Winter Games in Salt Lake City, the promise of sensible skiing and snowboarding in the Rockies is a mellow come-on to the visitors Vail draws, themselves mostly middle-aged and sensible.

title: Suicide Bomber Strikes Scarred Shopping District in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 27  A Palestinian suicide bomber killed one other person and injured dozens with a tremendous blast today in the scarred central shopping district here, just steps from where a Palestinian gunman raked the same area with semiautomatic fire on Tuesday.

title: 'The Englishman's Daughter'
description: On a balmy evening at the end of August in the year 1914, four young soldiers of the British army—two Englishmen and a pair of Irishmen—crouched in terror under a hedgerow near the Somme River in northern France, painfully adjusting to the realisation that they were profoundly and hopelessly lost, adrift in a briefly tranquil no-man's-land somewhere between their retreating comrades and the rapidly advancing German army, the largest concentration of armed men the world had ever seen.

title: In a Greenhouse, the Thriving of Perennials
description: IT was freezing outside. The perennial garden was neatly clipped and raked, a few rose canes dangling from the top reaches of a rustic tripod made of cedar branches. But inside the greenhouse at Wave Hill, that intimate public garden in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, a South American vine, Pyrostegia venusta, or orange trumpet vine, was covering an entire wall with its clusters of bright tubular flowers.

title: Streetscapes/Early-19th-Century New York; The Streets Are Familiar, but the Way of Life Is Gone
description: LIKE a few other New Yorkers, George A. Thompson methodically reads multiple daily New York newspapers -- but they don't arrive on his doorstep. Over the last decade, Mr. Thompson has been gradually reading dozens of different New York newspapers from the early days of the republic to World War I; last summer he happened upon the earliest recorded use of the term baseball, in 1823.

title: RACIAL PROFILING REPORT
description: A report released last week by court-appointed federal monitors monitoring racial profiling by New Jersey state troopers said drivers were no longer being pulled over because of their race. Federal monitors visited 10 State Police barracks between April and August 2001 and reviewed records of 175 vehicle stops and numerous videotaped stops and found little evidence of racial profiling. The monitors also found a 69 percent drop in searches but a rise in drug finds in vehicles that were searched, which the monitors say shows improved training. The state agreed in 1999 to federal monitoring after admitting that troopers were engaging in racial profiling. John Holl

title: Corrections

Half-cooked bacon is stacked near the grill, and cut potatoes course through the deep fryer. But the sizzling will probably stop soon, and the diner has become a potent emotional symbol in a larger debate about historic districting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINS, MAY LIPTON
description: CUMMINS-May Lipton. Of Rockville, Maryland, formerly of New York City, on Saturday, January 5, 2002, at home. She is survived by her sisters Helen Gutterman, of Rockville and Evelyn Berger of Dallas and brother, Gerald Lipton of Spokane, Washington. She was predeceased by sister Estelle Goldberg. She is also survived by niece Lyn Tanenholtz and cousin Aileen Bloom as well as many other family members and friends. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWENSTEIN, LOUIS K.
description: LOEWENSTEIN-Louis K. Urbanologist and civic activist, died in San Francisco, CA Jan. 22, 2002 at the age of 74, of cancer. Raised in NYC, he was educated at the Univ. of VA, Columbia and the Univ. of PA. He moved to San Francisco, where he divided his time between an international consulting practice and an academic career, teaching planning at Stanford and San Francisco State. He wrote ''Streets of San Francisco: The Origins of Street and Place Names'' and four other books on urban topics. He served on numerous boards devoted to civic causes, including San Francisco Planning and Urban Renewal (SPUR) and Lambda Alpha International. Dr. Loewenstein is survived by his wife Neyde Trindade, his son Lexy, his daughter Lael and her husband Adam Wasson.

At Comme des Garons, Rei Kawakubo uses large black-and-white Pop Art numbers printed on voluminous skirts ($290 for the short skirt, $395 for the long, at Saks Fifth Avenue). Jet puts a 66 inside a heart on T-shirts ($38) and Troo turns that number upside down on its ribbon-tie 99 sweat pants ($118, both at Henri Bendel). At eluxury.com, Dior has a Logo Racerback dress with number 2 at the hip (left; $300). Noir's stretch lace polo features ribbon garters on the sleeves and appliqud satin numbers (above, center; $120 at Shop Noir), while M.A.D. Women's cotton cashmere crew neck has 02 in huge numerals on the back ($154 at Bendel's). Delia's rugby top has a star-edged 57 (above; $24 at www.ae.com), and Old Navy puts ZIP codes -- with a spray-painted look -- on black mesh long-sleeve baby T's ($12.50). title: 'Martin Luther King, Jr.'
description: Almost a geological age ago, it seems now—that great moral saga of belief and violence that unfolded in the musky deeps of the South during the civil rights movement of the fifties and sixties. It's hard to remember at this remove of years how profoundly the South then was like another country within the United States. Locked into its own massive apartheid system, implacably enforced by legal and political authorities across the whole spectrum of its social life, it really had more in common with the South Africa of that day than the rest of the nation. At the same time, the South seemed a region that belonged to some older, more primal and guttural script about the human situation, tribal, stark, fatal, that was wholly outside the general American sensibility of rationality and optimism. Even so, it had fallen the lot of the South, formed by slavery and its camouflaged sequel of segregation, to serve as the crucible for the whole nation's periodic struggles of conscience over its own endemic and pervasive racial malaise. As early as Jefferson, the recognition was already gathering that the only fundamental and intractable crisis this Republic finally faced was that of racial schism—that the American political adventure, conceived in such brave hope and largeness of idea, may have also held from its very inception, when the first black man in chains set his foot on the continent's shores, the seeds of its undoing. Indeed, that aboriginal crime has been with us, one way or another, ever since. And it was the South, living more directly and intimately in that crime than anywhere else, that seemed appointed the violent ceremonial ground for America's intermittent travails to purge itself of that primeval shame and guilt.

title: The Twang Thang

Although the idea of a slide guitar wasn't new, this metal-cone-amplification idea was, and the instrument quickly grabbed hold of the ears of folk music, country and blues audiences. Nowadays you cannot imagine certain kinds of music without its unique plangencies. They are what Ravi Shankar's ragas and ''Norwegian Wood'' and a bluegrass standard like ''Randy Lynn Rag'' have in common: twang.

These trips fueled conversations with family and friends for years to come. For 25 years Myra managed Bolton's, a women's designer clothing store on 86th Street and Madison Avenue. She retired to West Palm Beach, FL., and spent her final years in Taos, NM, near her daughter Gayle and son-in-law Ted McNeil. Myra is survived by Gayle McNeil of Taos, NM; her stepson Stuart Robinson of San Diego, CA; her grandchildren Allyson Beardslee, Peter Crump and Matthew Crump; as well as her four great-grandchildren and large extended family. description: Areview on Jan. 6 about ''Anthony Blunt: His Lives,'' by Miranda Carter, misstated the position of Michael Straight, an American who knew the British art historian and Soviet spy Anthony Blunt at Cambridge University before World War II. From 1969 to 1977 Straight was deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts; he was never its chairman. The review also referred incorrectly to the sides in the Spanish Civil War; the rebels represented the political right, not the left, and received help from fascist nations, not from the Soviet Union.

This was in 1968, the year of the ''White Album,'' and I was still trying to figure out how to play ''Rocky Raccoon'' on my brand-new guitar, but I was also chewing my way through the selected works of Dave Brubeck, Duke Ellington, Stan Kenton, Frank Sinatra and Peggy Lee, whose recording of ''Fever'' was -- shall we say -- instructive.

title: Death by Stoning
description: Sufiyatu Huseini sits on the earth floor of a tiny mud hut breast-feeding her 10-month-old daughter, Adama, and occasionally waving away flies that swarm around the child's eyes and mouth. She says she is 35, but her wizened face and broken brown teeth make her look considerably older. This ordinary woman, as poor as any in this impoverished region of northern Nigeria, recently became horribly extraordinary: last June, an Islamic court in Sokoto, the regional capital, sentenced her to death by stoning for committing adultery. The evidence is the child she now feeds. The judge mandated that the sentence be carried out as soon as Adama is weaned.

title: 'TIGER LADY'
description: Joan Byron-Marasek, known as the Tiger Lady because of the tiger compound she maintains on her property in Jackson Township, has been given until Tuesday to come up with an alternative to moving her 24 Bengal tigers to a new location outside New Jersey or the state will take steps to move them to a wildlife refuge in San Antonio, Tex. Ms. Byron-Marasek has asked for time to sell her property and find land in another state where she can continue to care for the tigers. If a judge rules in favor of the state Division of Fish and Wildlife, the animals will be transported in a specially equipped trailer. The move would cost about $150,000, of which the refuge has agreed to pay $60,000.

title: 'The Truth Will Set You Free'
description: Ioften see elderly persons in the pharmacy collecting the pills and potions prescribed to them by their family doctors. Sometimes I ask them whether their doctors ever talk to them about their lives or only about their illnesses. "What do you think?" they usually reply. "There's no time for that kind of thing—there are dozens of people in the waiting room. And what good would it do, anyway? The main thing is he knows what's wrong with me and what to do about it." Sometimes I persist and ask whether there is anyone at all they can talk to about their lives. "What are you driving at?" they ask. "When I was younger I went out to work and had no time for talking. Now that I do have the time, who'd be interested in hearing the story of my life? When it comes down to it, you're on your own."

title: Accounting for Lobbyists: Lobbyists for Accounting
description: Lobbyists for Enron ( news/quote ) who once roamed aggressively through Washington are few and far between, now that its lobbying office has been cut from six people to two. But the lobbying industry has found momentum from Enron's collapse: accountants are beefing up their lobbying ranks on the Hill. The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has hired former aides to Newt Gingrich and Bob Kerrey, along with the veteran lobbyists and former congressmen Vin Weber, Republican from Minnesota, and Vic Fazio, a Democrat from California. Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm dismissed by Enron earlier this month, has supplemented its in-house lobbying staff of two dozen by hiring a top Washington firm, the Duberstein Group, run by a former Reagan White House chief of staff, Kenneth M. Duberstein, as well as former Senator John Danforth, a Missouri Republican.

title: Looking Natural Takes Work

Charlie Green, a makeup artist who has worked on Penlope Cruz and Julia Stiles (above), among others, says the subtler style is a logical progression from Jennifer Lopez's frosted Valley Girl look. ''It's sexy without being intimidating or obvious,'' Ms. Green said. ''It's a totally natural look -- although you really have to work to get it.'' Ms. Green uses Sephora Collection No. 609M ($10), a baby pink lipstick, as a base coat with a top coat of No. 01 Chantilly gloss ($12, at Sephora). Other pale pink ''twin sets'' include Stila's Kelly lipstick ($16, at Saks Fifth Avenue) and Apricot lip glaze ($24, at Saks), and Delux Beauty's Clive sheer lipstick ($18) with sparkly Denton gloss ($15, at Henri Bendel). For a more neutral alternative, Clinique has Creamy Nude Soft Shine lipstick and a top of Honey Bee Glosswear for lips ($12.50 each at www.clinique.com). Origins carries Nearly Naked Lip Color ($12) and Caramel Candy liquid gloss ($11, at www.origins.com). Those who would rather forgo any color can go straight to the veneer with Make Up For Ever's super lip gloss, which is $16 at (877) 757-5175 and is a clear, ultrahigh-sheen varnish that makes polyurethane look like kid stuff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDIN, AKE
description: BRANDIN-Ake. Of Ossining, New York died in the early hours, Monday, January 21, succumbing to congestive heart failure after a long and difficult illness. He was 77 years old. Husband, father and grandfather, he is held in loving memory by wife Greta, sons Jan and Per and his grandchildren Nina and Anna who are all immeasurably grateful to have shared his life. Born in Malmo, Sweden, Mr. Brandin rose above difficult childhood circumstances to enjoy a long, successful career in international reinsurance. He had a remarkable facility with mathematics and briefly considered becoming a teacher before beginning his reinsurance career in 1950 at AEquitas in Malmo, Sweden where he worked until 1954. He moved to Atlas Reinsurance Company in Stockholm where he stayed until 1959. Mr. Brandin was recruited by Casten von Otter to immigrate to Toronto, Canada as Assistant Manager of Gerling Global Reinsurance Company, and then became Manager in 1962, and Assistant General Manager in 1963. In 1964, Mr. Brandin was offered the opportunity to represent Gerling Global Reinsurance Company of Cologne for the American market and became President of the New York office in 1967. In 1969, he additionally took over as President of Gerling Global in Toronto and also became President of Gerling Global General Insurance Company in Toronto in 1970. Mr. Brandin's dynamic innovative management style was responsible for turning the companies into profitable enterprises. In the 1970s, he expanded the operation and became President of Gerling Mexico while also establishing branch offices of the New York office in San Francisco, Los Angeles and Boston. New Canadian offices were opened in Calgary and Vancouver. Mr. Brandin considered this period to be among the most gratifying and exciting times of his career. In 1980, Mr. Brandin took on a new challenge and started his own company, StellaRe Management Corporation, to manage two newly created reinsurance companies, Hansa Re of America and Zurich Re of New York. He had a true passion for his work and enjoyed many close business relationships. His longest working associations were with Gunter Dahling of Sleepy Hollow, New York and Ulla Sjoo of New York City. He retired in 1991. He will be remembered for his generosity of spirit, his keen intellect, and charm. His ability to contribute to the success of colleagues and family gave him the greatest happiness. A Memorial Service was held in Tarrytown, N.Y. on January 25, 2002. Funeral services will be held in Malmo, Sweden in mid-February. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the American Heart Association, Donation Processing Center, P.O. Box 3049, Syracuse, NY 13220-3049.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, HERMAN
description: MELTZER-Herman. The family of Herman Meltzer sadly notes his passing on January 26, 2002, in Glen Cove, NY. Mr. Meltzer was 94 years old. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Selma and his sister Sylvia. He is survived by his sisters Phoebe Levine and Blanche Multer of Deerfield Beach, FL, his nephews, Eric and Larry Greenbush of New York City and Jim Slavin of East Windsor, NJ. Mr. Meltzer, a respected and renowned condemnation attorney, was a long time partner in Cullen & Dykman of Brooklyn and Garden City, NY. Herman was a man possessed of incredible intelligence, impeccable integrity, boundless kindness and profound wisdom. He will be sorely missed by those whose lives he touched. Graveside services will be held at New Montifiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, L.I., at 2 P.M. on Monday.

title: 'Down the Great Unknown'
description: The few inhabitants of Green River Station, Wyoming Territory, gather at the river front to cheer off a rowdy bunch of adventurers. Ten hardy men in four wooden boats had spent the morning checking their gear and their provisions one last time — bacon, flour, coffee, spare oars, sextants and barometers (their leader, the skinny, one-armed man in the Emma Dean, fancied himself ascientist). Their plan could hardly be simpler. They will follow the Green River downstream until it merges with the Grand to become the Colorado, and then they will stay with the Colorado wherever it takes them. They intend in particular to run the river through the fabled chasm variously called Big Canyon or Great Canyon or Grand Canyon, a region scarcely better known than Atlantis. No one has ever done it.

title: MAMMOGRAPHY REVIEW
description: An expert group reviewing mammography studies decided that it could no longer say that the test prevents breast cancer deaths. The group, the P.D.Q. editorial board, said that mammography's benefit, if any, is so small, the risks that it will lead to unnecessary treatment so real, and the uncertainty over whether there is a benefit so large, that it would be just as rational for a woman not to have a mammogram as to have one. title: Return of the Native
description: The seabeach amaranth, a plant that had not been seen in New Jersey since 1913, has reappeared in large numbers all along the coast, and scientists are not sure why. The habitat for the low-growing plant, which can help stabilize beaches and build dunes, had shrunk to a few places in South Carolina because of beach development and erosion, and it is on the federal list of endangered species. One hypothesis is that in 1989 Hurricane Hugo might have carried seeds from South Carolina to Long Island, where it first reappeared, and then other storms carried seeds to New Jersey, where the plant reappeared in 2000, said Annette Scherer, a biologist with the federal Fish and Wildlife Service in Pleasantville. Another is that seeds were lying dormant in sand pumped from the sea bottom in beach replenishment projects and that they sprouted when exposed to sunlight, she said.

title: Dissension Within Taliban Made Daring Escape From Prison Possible
description: It was a spectacular feat when Ismail Khan, the former governor of Herat and the Taliban's highest ranking political prisoner, broke out of his shackles in the dead of night and raced to the Iranian border and freedom two years ago.

description: If absence makes the heart grow fonder, then I am besotted with the bonefish of the Florida Keys. Of all the gamefish that one can fish for, these Floridians are the wariest. Still, you fish where you can when you can, so when the guide Allan Finkelman and the trout guru Al Caucci invited me down for a few days, I went.

title: CONVICTION IN IRISH BOMBING
description: More than three years after the worst act of violence in Northern Ireland's 30-year sectarian conflict, a car bomb attack that killed 29, an antiterrorist court in Dublin convicted the first person to be tried for the crime. Despite evidence that the police fabricated interrogation notes, Colm Murphy, a 49-year-old building contractor, was sentenced to 14 years for lending two mobile phones to paramilitaries in the breakaway republican group the Real I.R.A., which used the phones to arrange transportation of the 500-pound explosive. Brian Lavery

title: On the Docket Next Season, Transitions
description: RECENTLY, within a week of each other, the New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall announced their programs for the 2002-3 season. But those looking for indicators of the artistic visions of the new leaders at each institution will have to wait a year or so. Though the conductor Lorin Maazel officially takes charge of the Philharmonic with the opening concerts in September, a large segment of next season's programs, including four of the five commissioned works that will be given premieres, were already planned by the departing Kurt Masur and his artistic team. Similarly, though Robert Harth has been the executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall since last September, most of next season's offerings were arranged by his two predecessors: not just the embattled Franz Xaver Ohnesorg but also the well-regarded Judith Arron, who died in 1998.

title: Stalking the Ocean's Most Elusive Creatures
description: Watching ''The Blue Planet: Seas of Life,'' Discovery Channel's lavishly produced four-part series about the world's oceans, a viewer's reaction is likely to alternate between awe at nature's remarkable diversity and curiosity about how the documentary team managed to film it. A pack of killer whales methodically separates a gray whale calf from its mother before brutally killing it. A school of marlin corrals hundreds of thousands of tiny sardines into a tight, swarming ''bait ball'' before going into a feeding frenzy that soon attracts hungry tuna and a giant, never-before-filmed sei whale.

description: This was a hit felt as much by everyone else as it was by Jerome Bettis. After all, the 255-pound Bus is rarely sent reeling backward by anyone, let alone a rookie linebacker in the early days of training camp.

title: Indian Patriotism Gets a Bollywood Makeover
description: In the action movie ''Indian,'' the hero is a policeman battling an Osamaesque mastermind of terror. In ''Maa Tujhhe Salaam,'' the star is a Kashmiri hunk who takes up arms to defend Mother India.

title: Sheila Gray and Jason Bagdade
description: SHEILA GRAY, 40, shops the Chelsea flea market in New York weekly. She considers it a trove of all sorts of marvelous treasures, like porcelain and antique dresses. But the last thing she expected to find on one of her jaunts was a husband.

title: Executive Life; Hard Times Prompt an Entrepreneurial Itch
description: LAST August, Scott Allison checked to make sure that his phone was still working. It was, but there were no calls, no new clients. With pink-slip contagion sweeping the Bay Area, it looked as if his days as the No. 2 executive at a long-successful public relations agency might be coming to an untimely end.

title: Uncertainty Over Mammograms
description: The questions surrounding the value of mammograms in fighting breast cancer have just gotten a lot more perplexing. It was disturbing enough when two European researchers argued late last year that there were so many flaws in the studies that purport to show a benefit from mammography that the results were virtually meaningless. But last week, a panel of the nation's top experts in cancer screening agreed that the evidence justifying mammography was shaky. It was the first judgment by authoritative independent reviewers that there may be little hard evidence to support the large breast cancer screening industry that has become a well-entrenched feature of the American medical system.

title: This Doesn't Add Up
description: In ''The Apartment,'' Billy Wilder's 1960 tribute to character, the accountant C.C. Baxter overcomes temptation and does what he knows is right. ''Loyal, resourceful, cooperative C.C. Baxter,'' one of his bosses says with a twist to his voice at once soothing and menacing, ''you don't want to louse yourself up.'' The boss wants to borrow the apartment for an affair. But in the end, Baxter says no. He gives up a lot -- money, power, the key to the executive washroom -- but he saves his soul. He keeps his self-respect.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: BEST SELLERS: January 27, 2002
description: Weeks

title: Political Briefing; Woes Keep Piling Up For Condit Campaign
description: With less than six weeks to go until California's March 5 primary, the news just keeps getting worse for Representative Gary A. Condit.

title: Waiting to Exhale
description: LAST winter I moved into a new apartment on the sixth floor of an elevator building in Brooklyn Heights. Everything was perfect except for one problem. The first time I stepped inside the small, musty, wood-paneled elevator, I instantly felt like a character from a Edgar Allan Poe story, buried alive. My fingers grew clammy, my chest began to tighten, and I started to flush. Suddenly even my clothes felt constrictive, and with shaky hands, I ripped off my sweater. As the door started to slide shut, I lunged out of the elevator, to the hallway and to freedom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUER, JEAN, ''PANCHO''
description: AUER-Jean, ''Pancho'', (nee Patchett) of La Quinta, CA and Westhampton Beach, NY passed away on January 22, 2002 after a long battle with emphysema. Born in Preston, MD, Pancho became a nationally known photographic model in the 40's, 50's, and 60's gracing covers of more than 40 magazines including Vogue, Harper's Bazaar, Glamour and Life. She is survived by her husband of fifty years Louis', her daughter Amy of Westhampton Beach, her sister Mrs. J. Fred King and her brother Frank Patchet, Jr. Funeral services private. The family requests contributions in her memory be made to the American Lung Association, 1740 B'way, NY NY 10019 or the charity of your choice.

title: For New Novel, DeMille Visits His Past
description: ALTHOUGH he is a novelist, Nelson DeMille prides himself on getting the facts straight in each of his contemporary thrillers. But for ''Up Country,'' his new novel coming out on Tuesday, he relied more on his own memory and less on researching his subject matter.

title: CONTEMPT IN RABBI TRIAL
description: A magazine writer was found in contempt of court last week for her contact with a juror during the murder trial of Rabbi Fred J. Neulander. Carol Saline, a writer for Philadelphia Magazine, was accused of violating an order by the trial judge, Linda G. Baxter, forbidding reporters to contact jury members. Ms. Saline acknowledged she talked with a juror as he walked outside the Camden Hall of Justice on Nov. 9 during a break in the trial, where Rabbi Neulander was charged with setting up the murder of his wife in 1994. The trial ended in a hung jury. The maximum penalty for the conviction is six months in jail and a $1,000 fine. A sentencing date has not yet been set.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: OFFBEAT and quirky are two adjectives that wrap themselves snugly around the Scottish director Bill Forsyth's comedy LOCAL HERO, which was named to The Times's 10-best list for 1983 and won Mr. Forsyth the New York Film Critics Circle accolade for the year's best screenplay. Magical is another way of describing this story of a hard-driving young American oil company executive (Peter Reigert) sent to Scotland by the company's volatile chairman (Burt Lancaster) to buy up a picturesque little town called Ferness and replace it with a refinery. En route to - and in - Gerness, strange things pop up: the rabbit, the speeding motorcyclist, the inhabitants and a remarkable young woman - Friday at 11:45 a.m. on TMC.

title: China Changes Its Approach in the Latest Espionage Incident
description: Last April when an American spy plane collided with a Chinese jet over international waters near China's coast, China's state press was filled with angry rhetoric and its people with indignation. ''World Cop Stop the Arrogance,'' screamed the China Defense News, ''Americans, You Are Too Hegemonic,'' blazed the Global Times -- headlines typical of that time.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 6 about the British television music program ''Top of the Pops'' misstated the occupation of Sven-Goran Eriksson, the subject of the song ''Sven Sven Sven.'' He is the coach of the English national soccer team, not a player.

title: Where All the Restaurant Is a Stage
description: EVEN those who might not appreciate dinner-theater will likely find the theatricals at Il Castello engaging. The ''stage'' at the end of the dining room holds the diner's attention with a diorama of Capri, seen from Positano, with greenery framing the view. The painted galleon looks as if it might bob and lurch across the bay at any moment.

title: The World; Colombian Riddle: What Drew Rebels to the Table?
description: MANY Colombians were relieved when the country's largest rebel group -- which is also the largest and richest guerrilla army in Latin American history -- unexpectedly conceded to government demands and agreed to start cease-fire talks.

title: COMING UP
description: President Bush meets with Hamid Karzai, the Afghan leader, on Monday, and delivers the State of the Union address on Tuesday. The World Economic Forum begins meeting in New York on Thursday. The January employment report will be released on Friday.

title: Quiet, Please. This Is a Library After All.
description: WHEN Lincoln Center opened 40 years ago, it was notoriously bedeviled by acoustical problems. The interior of Avery Fisher Hall (originally Philharmonic Hall) has repeatedly been redesigned, and a further attempt is reportedly on the way; the New York State Theater has never adequately served the New York City Opera. Now a third Lincoln Center acoustical crisis has materialized in an unlikely place: the library.

title: Court Demands a State Plan For Integrating a High School
description: New Jersey's highest court has ruled that the state has the primary responsibility to create a plan for integrating Dwight Morrow High School here.

title: Quertaro, Witness To History
description: TRAVELERS have marveled at Quertaro ever since the 17th century, when it was the third most important city under Spanish rule. Built from the fortunes made in the silver mines to the north, Quertaro's graceful plazas and baroque chapels, preserved in much of their original splendor, were settings for the rise and fall of colonial power in Mexico.

title: Channel-Surfing Past Cluttered Screens
description: To the Editor:

title: Boeing Plans a Major Property Sale
description: SEATTLE

title: Homeless but Not Helpless by the Harlem River
description: CLYDE TENSLEY is not, technically, a homeless man. He lives in a corrugated steel shack along the Harlem River, and has kept the same address for eight years.

title: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS
description: IMPACT IN FLORIDA -- The Enron scandal is starting to resonate in Florida, where it is touching another Bush: Gov. Jeb Bush. The state pension fund lost $335 million from its Enron holdings. Seeking deregulation, Enron spread its campaign contributions widely. PAGE 32

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 27, 2002
description: Weeks

title: On a Quest, Youth Finds Aid and Friends
description: BOARDING a plane in Macedonia for the United States last month, Bertan Selim, who was born with cataracts, knew that in a matter of days an ophthalmologist at Johns Hopkins would evaluate his vision, and with corrective eye surgery, possibly change his life.

title: How to Read a How-to-Read Book
description: WRITERS being a self-conscious bunch, they often feel the need to run themselves down a little before offering the public instruction on how to read, which is, after all, a presumptuous thing to do. Such modesty may be false. Writers in this situation aren't required to be sincere; they're required to assuage the reader's pride with a show of humility.

title: Where to Eat?
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Gastronome, Know Thyself,'' by David Kirby (Jan. 6) about finding a restaurant in a new city by asking someone who reminds you of yourself: Talking to a fellow traveler on a flight to Tokyo we had the same experience.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Helping Hand After a Mother's Death
description: In a ground-floor apartment in the Red Hook Houses in Brooklyn, a single candle burned in a bare corner of the living room, smoke drifting past photographs of Luisa Lopez with her gray hair pulled back into a ponytail.

title: 'Beyond the Last Village'
description: As soon as I entered the hut, the man sitting by the fire turned away from me. He had known I was coming. Two Taron women, his older and younger sisters, stood beside him. As Khaing worked with the translator to ask the women questions, I sat down beside the man, sipping tea and looking into the fire. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw him cast furtive glances toward me. I waited.

title: Eisenberg Miffs the Right, But His Money's Still Good
description: While conservatives might be upset with the appointment of Lewis Eisenberg, a moderate, to head the fund-raising activities for the Republican State Committee, others -- namely, those seeking to run for the United States Senate -- are happy with the pick.

title: Devils' Sykora Will Sit for Transgressions
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 26 — Petr Sykora is the first player to feel the wrath of Devils Coach Larry Robinson's new no-tolerance edict regarding variances from team play, and he is feeling repentant.

title: Private Sector; Accounting for Lobbyists: Lobbyists for Accounting
description: Lobbyists for Enron who once roamed aggressively through Washington are few and far between, now that its lobbying office has been cut from six people to two. But the lobbying industry has found momentum from Enron's collapse: accountants are beefing up their lobbying ranks on the Hill. The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has hired former aides to Newt Gingrich and Bob Kerrey, along with the veteran lobbyists and former congressmen Vin Weber, Republican from Minnesota, and Vic Fazio, a Democrat from California. Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm dismissed by Enron earlier this month, has supplemented its in-house lobbying staff of two dozen by hiring a top Washington firm, the Duberstein Group, run by a former Reagan White House chief of staff, Kenneth M. Duberstein, as well as former Senator John Danforth, a Missouri Republican. Leslie Wayne

title: Riverhead in Violation Of Environmental Law
description: Riverhead officials violated state environmental law by approving a golf course and residential resort in Baiting Hollow, the Appellate Division of state Supreme Court has ruled.

title: Another Style for the Soul
description: The fashion industry, a pushover for spiritual fads like feng shui and cabala, has now embraced karma. In the last month, galleys of ''The Power of Karma,'' a book by Mary T. Browne, a psychic, have been circulating in the style world, serving as a sort of practical handbook for the karmically deprived. ''Karma isn't just an esoteric New Age philosophy -- it's the action that creates the road map for your life,'' Ms. Browne said in a telephone interview. The book (published by William Morrow; $24.95), which links karma to every aspect of life, including money, sex, love and carbohydrates, will arrive in bookstores on Feb. 4. In the meantime, karmaphiles can soothe their souls with Tarte Karma lip gloss, Trish Becker's karma earrings and sterling silver karma wish boxes at Language on Mulberry Street in Lower Manhattan. Apparently the road to self-discovery is paved with merchandise. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: January 20-26; FRONT LINES
description: MIDEAST -- It was a bloody week, with Israel's army taking over the city of Tulkarm in the West Bank and conducting a raid on what it called a bomb-making laboratory in nearby Nablus, killing four members of Hamas. Then, in the first attack on Jerusalem since Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, called for a cease-fire last month, a Palestinian opened fire with an M-16, killing 2 and wounding 20. A Palestinian, described by Israelis as a Hamas leader and by Palestinians as a relative of a Hamas leader, was killed in an Israeli helicopter strike in Gaza. And then a suicide bomber attacked in Tel Aviv, injuring more than two dozen people -- and setting off Israeli airstrikes in the West Bank and Gaza. Incrementalism in Israel, Page 1.

title: Where Families (and Adults) Can Go Out to Play
description: ONE Wednesday evening last month at Sports Plus in Lake Grove, the crowd was thick with a thousand people who worked for the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York, in Hauppauge, and their families.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a new chapel at the Marian Woods retirement center for nuns in Hartsdale misstated the location of Fort Tryon Park, where a stained glass worker sought inspiration for the windows. It is in Manhattan, not the Bronx.

title: The World; Prisoners, Surely. But P.O.W.s?
description: OVER the past week, images of prisoners taken in Afghanistan, shackled, bound and hooded on their arrival at the United States naval base in Cuba, drew angry criticism from Europeans and humanitarian organizations. The Bush administration replied that the prisoners are being treated as humanely as possible, given that many are terrorists.

title: The Guantnamo Food Pyramid
description: Their cells may be small and their jumpsuits an unpleasant shade of orange, but the Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners in Cuba are getting some good eats. Their meals, which the military has ensured are halal, or in keeping with Islamic law, are nearly identical to the MRE's (Meals Ready to Eat) given to American soldiers. A typical day's cuisine, as it might fit into the Department of Agriculture's food pyramid:

title: Witches Who Push Brooms
description: WITCHES are alive and well and living in New Jersey. Perhaps that comes as no surprise. But doing pro bono work?

title: A Knicks Question
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: INVESTING WITH/Timothy P. Beyer And Paul H. Lundmark; USAA Balanced Strategy Fund
description: THE stock market's rally late last year, combined with declining earnings for many companies, has made stocks less attractive, say Timothy P. Beyer and Paul H. Lundmark, co-managers of the $240 million USAA Balanced Strategy fund in San Antonio.

title: THE OPPOSITE OF ENCORE
description: In one of the most spectacular reversals of fortune in the entertainment industry, EMI Records ended a $80 million contract for five albums from Mariah Carey, who has had more No. 1 songs than anyone except Elvis Presley and the Beatles. After disappointing sales of Ms. Carey's ''Glitter'' album, for which it paid $21 million, EMI's Virgin Records division decided to pay her $28 million to free itself from the high costs of producing and promoting any more albums. Alex Kuczynski

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Amid Recession, Hopeful Signs for Industrial Space
description: GROWN big and burly over the years, New Jersey's industrial real estate market shows signs that it might barrel through the current recession in reasonably good health.

title: America at War in Five Letters
description: The letters shown here, sent to and from the front lines, offer an intimate record of our country at war. It used to be that war letters themselves -- like the bloodstained missives of Union and Confederate soldiers -- revealed something of the fury of battle, but as e-mail replaces the handwritten word, our correspondence has become less formal and more detached. This selection of letters from the 19th century to the present is a vivid reminder of the anxieties of those who serve and the sacrifices that war demands.

title: Key West Is Tiring Of Chickens in Road
description: This is a tolerant place, usually. Greasy bikers in black leather and mirrored shades cruise their rumbling Harley-Davidsons down streets filled with college boys on pastel scooters. Tanned women in bikini tops and silver toe rings share sidewalks with sun-blasted old men in ragged T-shirts who walk their battered bicycles like wounded horses.

title: Champion Overeaters, and Proud of It
description: TUCKED into a booth at Ben's Kosher Delicatessen in Baldwin, Don Lerman of Levittown gripped a knife in his right hand, quickly slicing baseball-size matzo balls into quarters like apples and shoveling one after the other into his mouth with his left. His fingers quivered. Crumbs dribbled down his chin and stuck in his beard. He didn't pause until he had devoured 12 of the half-pound dumplings in two minutes and 50 seconds, just beating out Eric Booker of Copiague, who gulped only 11 3/4.

title: A Return To Yonkers, And a Fall Cushioned
description: THE story that has unfolded here in recent weeks regarding Jay B. Hashmall is more than just one of political intrigue, or of the decline and fall of a powerful politician.

title: Refugee Issue Clouds Visit By Australian To the U.S.
description: Prime Minister John Howard has an embarrassing problem at home over Australia's treatment of illegal immigrants, one he hopes to avoid when he visits the United States next weekend.

title: How the Eagles and Patriots Can Win
description: It was the opening game this season, and St. Louis quarterback Kurt Warner, normally about as unflappable as a veteran Broadway show actor, had a perplexed, almost confused look on his face. It is a look many quarterbacks would later share after going against the blitz-happy defense of the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Rainforest Cafe Closes In Palisades Center
description: The bustling Palisades Center in West Nyack has lost its first eating spot. The Rainforest Cafe, one of 12 restaurants in the mall, has closed. According to the Palisades general manager, John Mott, the restaurant had more than six years remaining on its lease.

title: Belichick's Experience Is Needed for Upset
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26  The New England Patriots do not like what they are hearing. They do not like words like underdog and destiny applied to their team.

title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; A Light, Sweet Treat for the Morning Rush
description: The coffee-colored awning at Bonjour Montclair is an elegant addition to the cluster of shops around the Watchung Plaza train station in Montclair. It's also an invitation to a tiny, friendly cafe and creperie with flavors of France and the Middle East. Stopping there while waiting for a commuter bus on a recent morning, I tried a lemon crepe ($3.50) so light and intensely lemony, the memory lingered for days and drew me back again and again. The other crepe offerings, like cinnamon apple ($4.50) or ham, cheese and mushrooms ($6.50) have their appeal and tabouleh salad ($5.50) or a prosciutto and mozzarella sandwich are better suited for lunch, but that simple lemon crepe is my new breakfast ideal. And for commuters heading for a bus or train, it's more portable than a crepe loaded down with chunks of strawberry or apple. Mike and DiDi Tuma opened the cafe in early December, encouraged by the raves their crepes drew at a festival in Montclair last year. Every Sunday from last April through September, they sold crepes at festivals, working 18- to 20-hour days. With a young daughter, they wanted a routine. Raised in Nazareth, Israel, Mr. Tuma has worked at a string of restaurants. His mother used to make crepes for him, he said, but he recognized their commercial potential on trips to Paris. ''They have crepes on the street, and people carry them along,'' he said. He spreads batter into a thin circle on a special round griddle, adds the filling and folds it into a rectangle. The sweet crepes get a dusting of powdered sugar and perhaps a drizzle of sauce. That seductive lemon flavor is nothing more than fresh lemon, squeezed over the crepe's warm, eggy surface. Roberta Zeff

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ARNOLD
description: COHEN-Arnold. January 24, 2002. Devoted husband, brother, brother-in-law, uncle, great uncle, sonin-law, friend and dedicated educator. We shall miss you.

title: The Nation: Whistle While You Work; In Washington, the Dreaded 'P' Word Rears Its Head
description: PRODUCTIVITY is an economic concept that makes people's eyes glaze over. But rub them and stay awake. Productivity is about to join taxes, budget deficits and the recession as a grass-roots political issue.

title: Raise Hand, Place in Vise; Budget Pinch Greets New Governor in Trenton
description: The New Jersey State House has become such a font of bad news about budget deficits and layoffs in recent weeks that it seems almost quaint to look back to last summer, when many elected officials conducted themselves as though the state's economy was somehow recession proof.

title: The 2 Domes Of Belgium
description: For all that has been written about Sept. 11, there is still one big hole in our knowledge: We know who Osama bin Laden is. He is a unique cult figure -- a Muslim Charles Manson with the organizational skills of Jack Welch. We also know who bin Laden's passive supporters are -- all those Muslims who sympathize with him out of anger with their own leaders, America or Israel. But who were the guys in the middle -- the killer pilots who went beyond passive support to become suicidal mass murderers?

title: Toward Total Road Safety
description: IN the year just ended a number of new laws and legal rulings have begun to alter the rules of the road significantly. The United States Supreme Court upheld the right of the police to handcuff and jail a driver for speeding; New Jersey now permits the police to confiscate a car on the suspicion that the driver is under the influence; and New York State made it illegal to use a hand-held cell phone while driving.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Monument to the Slum

title: Manhattanville Ends Middlebury's Streak
description: Manhattanville College, which started its program three years ago, ended Middlebury's 136-game Division III unbeaten streak yesterday with a 4-1 victory in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Woes Keep Piling Up for Condit Campaign
description: With less than six weeks to go until California's March 5 primary, the news just keeps getting worse for Representative Gary A. Condit.

title: Marlin Potash, Thomas Ivanyi
description: Dr. Marlin Sue Potash, a psychologist, and Thomas Peter Ivanyi, a financial executive, are to be married today at the Central Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein will perform the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: The Soapbox column last Sunday, about snow in New York, misidentified the historical figure whose statue in Union Square Park is holding a sword that would be softened by a blanket of snow. It is the Marquis de Lafayette, not Ulysses S. Grant.

title: A Free County Newspaper Folds But Offers a Substitute
description: Without even a mention in its own pages, the Westchester County Weekly ceased publishing with its Dec. 27 issue. The demise of the eight-year old free alternative newspaper represents ''a business plan that was not successful -- that was the concept of being able to publish two newspapers out of one infrastructure,'' said Andrew B. Sutcliffe, interim group publisher for New Mass Media, a division of the Tribune Corporation.

title: An Orange Grove Illustrates Japan's Economic Woe
description: Using the innards of mountains cored for highway tunnels, bulldozers here are filling a valley with layer upon layer of dirt and rock, creating what may be the world's most expensive orange grove.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Stop on a Dime and Leave 2 Nickels
description: IT'S as if the St. Louis Rams' wide receivers were Olympic sprinters in the 100-meter dash. All you hear is how fast they are. And they are.

description: JANE ADDAMS AND THE DREAM OF AMERICAN DEMOCRACY

title: King for Beginners
description: MARTIN LUTHER

title: A Financial Whodunit, Awaiting Answers
description: LONG before there was Enron, there was Martin R. Frankel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 30 about anxiety in children misstated the title of a book by Dr. Tamar Chansky. It is ''Freeing Your Child From Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: A Powerful, Practical Program for Parents of Children and Adolescents,'' not ''The Anxious Child.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAPKIN, ARNOLD
description: DRAPKIN-Arnold, January 24, 2002. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Brock, Meredith, Betsy and step-father of Lisa. Loving brother of Jocelyn Ruthberg. Cherished grandfather of Ryan and Gemma. He was a distinguished physician and member of the faculty at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends, colleagues and patients. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, January 27th, 2-5PM. Interment private. A fund in his memory will be announced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, GERDA
description: LEWIN-Gerda. Age 91, died peacefully on January 23, 2002. Wife of Gerhard, mother of Gabriela and Vivian, grandmother of Nicole, Alyssa and Meredith ''Puppell''. Contributions in her memory may be made to Department of Radiation Oncology, c/o Dr. Andrew Zablow, St. Barnabas Medical Center, 94 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, NJ 07039. For more information contact O'Boyle Funeral Home, 309 Broad St, Bloomfield, NJ 07003.

title: Money Funds Cut Fees As Their Yields Fall
description: With money market yields dropping to record lows, several money market funds have cut their fees to ensure that investors do not lose money.

title: More Than a Witty Novelist, She Wrote Plays, Too
description: UNTIL recent years, the proper response on hearing the name Dawn Powell was -- in the words of the playwright John Guare (a Powell fan since 1987) -- ''Who?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSERSCHMITT, JOHN C., JR.
description: MESSERSCHMITT-John C., Jr. January 23, 2002. Beloved husband of Darlene. Devoted son of John Messerschmitt and the late Evangeline. Loving brother of Pamela Bennett. Loving uncle of Jessica and Jeffrey Bennett. Cherished nephew of Carlette and Richard Allen. Dear friend of Betsy Messerschmitt a beloved member of the Jamerson family of Asheville, NC. Memorial service Saturday February 2, 2002, 11AM at Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 East 92nd Street and Park Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the North Asheville Baptist Church in Asheville, NC.

title: Serving Brookhaven, Regardless of Party
description: In the face of the Brookhaven Town Republicans' failed effort to dissuade voters from creating councilmanic districts and in light of the history of the Hempstead G.O.P. and Nassau G.O.P. fighting the creation of councilmanic and legislative districts, I find the press conference held by the North Hempstead G.O.P. supporting the creation of said districts on Jan. 15 both ironic and pathetic.

title: ENRON WATCH
description: It is perhaps a sign of the intensity of the scandal at the Enron Corporation that the resignation of the man most identified with the company -- its chairman, Kenneth L. Lay -- seemed like just a rivulet in a flood of developments. The week began with word that Enron employees had shredded records as recently as this month -- long after subpoenas were served. With the possibility that search warrants were hours away, the company invited federal agents into the building to secure the documents. New Congressional hearings opened into shredding by Enron's accountants, Arthur Andersen & Company, but the chief accountant involved invoked his Fifth Amendment right not to testify. At week's end, another stunning piece of news: the company's former vice-chairman, who retired in May, apparently killed himself. Kurt Eichenwald

title: Whose Sarasota?
description: To the Editor: What does Robert Plunket really think? His opening thesis in ''Beyond the Beach in Sarasota'' (Jan. 13) is that ''Sarasota has become younger, richer and infinitely more stylish. Hip people can successfully vacation here.'' Then he contradicts himself in his closing paragraph:

title: Supermarket Development Gets A Mixed Reception in Red Hook
description: Dozens of community advocates crammed into a City Council hearing room last week to protest a project that would bring a Fairway supermarket to a spit of land in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: Whose Sarasota?
description: To the Editor: Robert Plunket first informs us that his friends disdain the city ''as some sort of retirement center for Republicans.'' While it still ''has that side,'' he tells us, Sarasota is of late ''infinitely more stylish'' and it is now possible for ''hip people'' like him to ''successfully vacation'' there. Thank God -- the town is safe for people like Mr. Plunket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, GEORGE H.
description: EISENBERG-George H., 92. On January 13th, 2002 in Rancho Bernardo, CA. Predeceased by adored wife, Dorothy, of 41 years. Beloved husband of Maidie for 31 years. Loving father of M. Michael. Devoted grandfather of Elyse, Ellen & Andrea. Cherished great-grandfather of Gabby and Tom. A gifted athlete all his life. A life characterized by honesty, integrity, generosity, loyalty, and an incredible work ethic.

title: Another Bruce
description: Bruce Willis, left, is trying a new venture. He has started a recording label, Uptop Entertainment. And tonight at 8, his Club Bruno Tour will appear at the Xanadu Theater at the Trump Taj Mahal. The show features Bruce Willis and the Accelerators, performing with Ivan Neville, son of the blues singer Aaron Neville.

title: Sales Survey Predicts More Hiring Than Firing
description: The job prospects for many professionals are bleak these days, but a hiring survey released last week suggests that the outlook is not so bad for those in sales and marketing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: Three Reconfigured Lines Produce for Rangers
description: When Rangers Coach Ron Low dismantled Eric Lindros's line last week, he did so out of desperation. In their wildest dreams, neither Low nor the Rangers could have predicted the results.

title: Who Is She?
description: The Miss America Pageant began 81 years ago as a public relations promotion to extend the summer season in Atlantic City. But it has evolved into a lightning rod for views about pop culture. Is it merely kitsch Americana? Or does it say something about feminism? Or by now has it become a pass event that attracts only a shrinking core of well-wishers on a lonely Saturday night each September?

title: I'm on the Olympic Team? Bummer!

At Trax, a dance club on a Bend, Ore., highway, a couple hundred snowboarders are unwinding while a band called Red i Rider pumps out its own twisted brand of rockabilly, a twangy cover of Ice-T's ''Cop Killer,'' the drummer pounding out the beat wearing a sequined face mask that's two parts Hannibal Lecter, one part Liberace. title: In Memoriam
description: Adorned with votive candles, flowers and handwritten prayers, many of New York City's firehouses seem like red brick chapels since Sept. 11. BROTHERHOOD (American Express/Sterling, $29.95) memorializes these improvisational offerings and gives a glimpse into the firefighters' lives after the tragedy. With more than 300 images by over 60 photographers, the collection includes a prologue by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and a foreword by his fire commissioner, Thomas Von Essen. A lively introduction by Frank McCourt reflects on the civic connection we feel with firefighters, whether we see them shopping at the local deli or racing past on a fire truck. The book is organized into several thematic sections, like ''The Fallen,'' which shows snapshot displays of lost firefighters pasted up in firehouses, and ''Grief,'' a showcase of the shrines that sprouted on the city's sidewalks in their memory. In ''The Living,'' two adjacent black-and-white portraits of older firefighters, their faces stoic beneath leather helmets, convey a sense of quiet perseverance. The personalized spaces within the firehouses -- an old poster of Babe Ruth, a musty library of fire records more than a century old -- resonate as powerfully as the portraits of the firefighters themselves. But it's the book's least prominent feature that is also its most stirring: from cover to cover, in tiny, fine silver lettering, the names of the fallen form an unbroken chain across the bottom of each page. Ihsan Taylor

If none of the resulting works have so far appeared on record, that must be partly because they are so thoroughly unusual and alive. Made for instruments and groups sounding from different parts of the auditorium, they change the single perspective of the concert hall and challenge the possibilities of sound reproduction. DVD audio may have arrived at just the right time to deal with music that opens up space, at once heartily and deftly.

Illuminated manuscripts and carvings indicate that they flourished in England as early as the 12th century, and by the time Henry VIII came along, the royal inventory listed 40 recorders of sundry sizes, among them a ''Greate Base Recorder of Woode.''

description: IN the 1950's and 60's, Norman Rockwell was commissioned by the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company to illustrate an advertising campaign that would appear in national magazines, including The Saturday Evening Post. Guggenheim Museum in New York City, where ''Norman Rockwell: Pictures for the American People'' is ending its national tour.

description: Oh, the pull of Planet Enron.

title: ALL STATE TV, ALL THE TIME
description: Last summer, the independent television network NTV was wrested from a Russian tycoon and political opponent of the Kremlin, Vladimir Gusinsky, with the help of an obscure law permitting the breakup of failing companies. Now an independent television network staffed mostly by refugees from NTV, TV-6, has been wrested from a Russian tycoon and political opponent of the Kremlin, Boris A. Berezovsky, with the help of the same obscure law. Both tycoons insist that the Kremlin engineered their demise, and most outsiders agree. Now, of Russia's four national television networks, three are under state guidance, and the fourth, TV-6, is awaiting the the government's choice of a new owner. Michael Wines

description: AFTER years of overbuilding that left many movie theater companies reeling, some analysts and money managers say it may again be time to invest in the industry.

title: Friday Night Fights Return to the Island
description: WEARING the look of an expectant father, Joe Winters worked the hallway of the Huntington Hilton, shaking hands and welcoming fight fans as if they were relatives headed for the maternity ward.

title: George Divoky's Planet
description: Hats (and gloves) off to Darcy Frey (Jan. 6) for his outstanding report on George Divoky and his work on Cooper Island. I don't think any article has touched me in the way this one has. As long as we have even one man with the devotion, love of nature and spirit of survival that George Divoky has, our planet may just survive.

title: Center or Side?
description: In my car, the back seats by the doors have lap belts and shoulder harnesses, but the middle seat has only a lap belt. My two children, ages 3 and 7, ride in the car, and occasionally we pick up another child for a play date. Ethically, who should sit in the middle, less safe seat -- one of my children or the friend? Cheryl Mccaffrey, Newtown, Conn.

title: In the Region/Long Island; For Single-Screen Theaters, the Next Act
description: WITH multiscreen movie theaters now an integral part of today's entertainment, most of Long Island's original single-screen theaters, once owned by the giants in the movie industry, have lost their audience. Unprofitable in their original function, most old theaters have been bought by developers or local entrepreneurs who have proposed various uses for what was once a strong economic anchor for downtown businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, NORMA
description: LEVINE-Norma. Of Forest Hills, Queens, suddenly on January 14, 2002. Beloved sister of Allen Levine and aunt of Dan Levine and Debbie Fixsen. Graduate of Queens College and longtime English teacher at Russell Sage Junior High School.

description: IN the opening scene of the first episode of the new WB series ''Smallville,'' a young woman and her husband walk into a flower shop, where they meet a little girl dressed in a white gown, wearing homemade wings and a tiara and carrying a magic wand.

description: AS we sat in a booth in the dining room of Bear & Grill in Fairfield, marveling at the handsome rendering of the Adirondacks, my companion said, ''All that's missing are the black flies, thank goodness.''

title: Write-In Mayor Asks Who Cast His 2 Votes
description: The voice of the people has struck like a Halloween prankster in this minuscule bastion of democracy.

title: This Kiss Is Slightly Sweet
description: Willie Gluckstern, who imports offbeat German wines, calls his 1999 Weingut Blankenhorn sptburgunder (pinot noir) a curio. It's aptly named Der Kuss (The Kiss). Expect souffl weight and a stream of delicious near-sweet cherrylike flavor. Grilled salmon is this delicious Baden red's ideal companion; ham and turkey come next. Is-Wine, 225 East Fifth Street (Second Avenue), asks $15. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Mexico Court Exonerates Californian Held 6 Years
description: David Cathcart woke up today $250,000 in debt, in an apartment someone else had rented for him, eager to resume a life interrupted seven years ago.

title: Private Sector; Moving Up, Way Up, in the Art World
description: Vladimir O. Potanin, whose estimated $1.8 billion makes him one of the wealthiest of Russia's powerful oligarchs, has been working to repair an image hurt by the economic free-for-all that followed the collapse of Soviet Communism a decade ago. In that maelstrom, he and a handful of other well-connected Russian businessmen quickly became rich. He has established a philanthropic foundation and donated money to some of the world's premier art institutions.

title: Habitats/Grand Street on Lower East Side; Suburban Couples Find Roomier Pieds--Terre
description: JUDEE REIFMAN MARCUS and her sister, Corinne Reifman Barsky, are very close, and their husbands, Larry Marcus and Marvin Barsky, get along well, too. Both couples lived in Princeton, N.J., for decades, and often went into Manhattan together for plays and concerts.

title: Keeping Him Under Control
description: Gooey, lovey-dovey types will be buying flowers and chocolates in the next few weeks. More pragmatic partners have other options. The Boyfriend Training Kit (Bloomsbury Publishing) was created by Tanya Sassoon, 25, as a graphic design project at the University of Brighton in England. The kit includes a guidebook for boyfriends with rules in six categories, including Restraint (''Do not come home drunk and find it amusing'') and Fidelity (''Take your girlfriend's side against others''). It also comes with a score book complete with gold star and yellow warning stickers; it is $7.95 at Urban Outfitters and Barnes & Noble.

title: Eileen Ergas, Liad Meidar
description: Eileen Rebecca Ergas, a daughter of Joscelyn Ergas and Dr. Enrique Ergas of New York, was married here last evening to Liad Meidar, the son of Margalit and Moshe Meidar, also of New York. Rabbi Chaim Levine officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street.

That was the party line when he left Enron last May as vice chairman, and if former colleagues now say it was never that simple, they nonetheless expected him to be living the good life.

description: CRUZ-Urias M. My father, born January 8, 1917, died December 31, 2001, A.D. He went to bed. He went to sleep. He left it all behind. Alone as he chose. Louis A. Cruz

description: KANE-Michael. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael Kane, associated with The Times from 1976 until retiring in 1993.

title: At Airports, New Watchdog Is Taking Over
description: SHARP-EYED travelers will begin noticing in the next few weeks that at security checkpoints at scattered airports around the country, the emblems on security screeners' uniforms will change -- from Argenbright, Worldwide and Globe to the Transportation Security Administration. That is the Transportation Department division that Congress created in November to take over the security functions now mostly handled by private contractors working for airlines.

title: Capriati Beats Australian Heat and Hingis
description: MELBOURNE, Sunday, Jan. 27  It was at some stage early in the final set, after having saved four match points and had ice packs applied to her entire body, that Jennifer Capriati got her second wind. Or was it only her second?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZ, LOLA
description: GEWIRTZ-Lola. Yeshiva University Women's Organization (YUWO) expresses sorrow upon the passing of Lola Gewirtz, founding president of the Fairfield-Bridgeport, Connecticut chapter and former member of the YUWO National Board. Heartfelt condolences to her daughter Dorothy Berman, member of the YUWO National Board and to all members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. description: On Sept. 11, the luxury Ritz-Carlton chain was less than a month from opening a hotel in Battery Park City, five blocks south of the World Trade Center. title: Concert Features Clarinet Soloist
description: PHILHARMONIA VIRTUOSI regularly attracts world-class soloists. Joining the orchestra at next Sunday's 3 p.m. concert at Purchase College is Richard Stoltzman, whom the music director, Richard Kapp, calls ''perhaps the pre-eminent clarinet soloist in the world today.'' In addition to playing the much-loved Mozart Concerto, Mr. Stolzman will be featured in a work he recently recorded, ''Dance Preludes,'' for clarinet, harp, piano, percussion and strings, by the Polish composer Witold Lutoslawski. Mr. Kapp has also paired 18th- and 20th-century pieces to complete the program: Haydn's Symphony No. 95 and ''La Mtamorphose d've,'' written in 1925 by the Parisian-born Dsir Inghelbrecht. Tickets and information: (914) 693-5595.

description: HONOLULU, Jan. 26  Bumper stickers here shout the slogan "Slow down! This ain't the Mainland!" But drivers are now in open revolt over a program forcing them to drive more slowly.

description: Monet had water lilies. Degas had dancers. Naima Rauam has cod.

title: Organizing the World to Fight Terror
description: The year 2001 was a turning point for Russia, the United States and the world. Not long ago everybody wondered what was in store for mankind in the 21st century. Many expressed doubts that Russian-American relations would retain their key role in world politics. On Sept. 11, all these issues appeared in a completely different light. The barbaric acts of terrorists in New York and Washington were indeed a tragedy of worldwide scale. It is no coincidence that President Vladimir Putin compared them with the Nazi crimes of World War II.

Across the room Koma called out to her softly: ''Walk as if each step was on a carpet of tiny, tiny flowers and you are not wanting to crush them. Feel the nice smell of the flowers in the upper body. And below, under your feet, destruction!''

title: Ideas & Trends; Seeking Perspective on the Movie Front Lines
description: THERE is a scene in Oliver Stone's ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' where Sgt. Ron Kovic, played by Tom Cruise, goes to talk to his commanding officer. Kovic is conscience-stricken because he thinks he killed a fellow soldier in the chaos of an engagement. The officer, though, can't be bothered. He tells Kovic to shrug it off, makes a few perfunctory comments about how confusing war can be and then tries to shoo Kovic out. When Kovic presses, the officer finally snaps and warns him to forget it. Such was military command in Vietnam War movies -- remote and uncaring. It is a far cry from generals blinking back tears as they sent their men into battle in World War II pictures.

title: Thanks to Hedwig, They're Overnight Hits
description: OF all the instant stars that Hollywood created with this year's holiday blockbusters, owls are surely among the most unlikely.

title: BUDGET PREVIEW
description: President Bush said he would seek $48 billion in new spending on the military, the biggest increase since Ronald Reagan's Pentagon buildup two decades ago and the centerpiece of the $2 trillion budget Mr. Bush sends to Congress early next month. It will also seek a doubling of funding for domestic security and money for an economic recovery package, including tax cuts. It will also call for cuts and freezes in social, health and environmental programs -- and will project budget deficits for the next several years. Richard W. Stevenson

title: Glossary Of Trends
description: Djellaba? Talitha Getty? Koos van den who? Yes, it's another season, with another list of buzzwords to bone up on. To keep you fluent in 2002 spring fashion speak, we've provided a cheat sheet. Quiz to follow.

title: At a Loss
description: THREE weeks after my husband died after a battle with a brain tumor, I joined a bereavement group. I hadn't gone to the group to make friends, just to find comfort. But I did begin to make friends with some of the other widows. We looked forward to Joan's appearances in the group. She had a different slant to grief. Joan was one of those liberals who wants to save humanity but doesn't much care for any of its individual members. And she was given to saying outrageous things about who should and who shouldn't have died. But she made us all laugh. Each week she would regale us with her daily problems in living.

title: Female Bomber Strikes Scarred Shopping District in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 27  A Palestinian bomber triggered an explosion that resounded throughout Jerusalem today, killing herself and an 81-year-old man and injuring 113, most of them lightly.

title: Needing To
description: 'You need to shut up and follow when an order is lawful,'' said Lt. Col. Martha McSally as she sued the Defense Department for requiring a female fighter pilot to wear a head-to-toe gown off-base in Saudi Arabia. ''You need to step out when it's unlawful.''

title: Daly Gives the People What They Want to See
description: As John Daly played today's third round of the Phoenix Open, he was hardly alone. A massive crowd watched him play the final few holes, part of the more than 200,000 fans who have attended the tournament this week, upholding its reputation as one of the most popular and rowdy events on the PGA Tour.

title: Brimming With Color and Light
description: THE long-term mission of the Jersey City Museum is to show contemporary art that is outside the mainstream, usually by artists who have not had much exposure. That mandate is reflected in the Winter 2002 Fine Arts Annual, the second show in the museum's new building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, LEWIS M.
description: GREENE-Lewis M., 102 years, loving and proud father of Barry H. (and Betty), adoring grandfather and friend of Lisa (and Jonathan Polish) and Jacqueline (and Joshua Orenstein). He began each day reading the New York Times obits. Private funeral service.

description: MY dad left me a voice mail message a few years ago that's typical of my upbringing and motivation: ''Your mother and I just got our Black Enterprise magazine and you are listed in the top African-Americans in corporate America. Congratulations, but I just wanted to let you know you have more work to do.''

description: WHEN Homestore.com, the nation's largest online real estate company, reported an unexpected third-quarter loss on Nov. 1, executives there blamed Sept. 11.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column last Sunday, about hotel bargains in the Caribbean, misstated terms of a deal for repeat guests at Cap Juluca, a luxury resort on Anguilla. Through April 5, they are offered either 15 percent off the usual room rate or a seventh night free -- not both.

title: On the Fringes of Florence, Memorable Eating
description: WHAT I love most about Florence is the way its compact center is packed almost equally with great art, great shopping and quaint trattorias. But it can become what I like least about the city too. In Tuscany, I want to get out of the city and see rolling green hills.

title: A Fight to Restore Cleanup Money
description: TWICE a year, Fair Lawn holds a litter cleanup day. A posse of about 15 volunteers boards the township minivan. They pluck a surprising number of beer cans from the edges of a highway off-ramp and by evening fill a two-ton dump truck with detritus of the disposable economy. All it costs the township is some cotton gardening gloves, garbage bags, a driver and the lunch tab at the Heights Deli.

title: Corrections

Her current film, ''Italian for Beginners,'' is not the first by a woman in Dogma. Maya Berthoud was a co-director of an earlier Dogma film, ''Chetzemoka's Curse,'' which has not been released theatrically.
