title: Crisis Incites More Protests And Discord In Argentina
description: Since taking office at the start of the month, President Eduardo Duhalde has taken the position that national unity is the only way out of the worst economic crisis in Argentina's history. But the country and his own Peronist party remain divided, with the fiercest criticisms of his government coming from the party's titular chief, former President Carlos Sal Menem.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Pages 5 and 23 of Arts & Leisure today about the graying of Broadway stars and audiences include outdated references to the play ''Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks,'' starring Uta Hagen, 82. After the section had gone to press, the producers postponed the opening from this April until the 2002-03 season. They said that Ms. Hagen, who has been ill, wanted to recover fully.

title: His Rallying Cry at First Boston: Smaller, Cleaner, Fairer
description: WHEN John J. Mack was hired as chief executive of Credit Suisse First Boston in July, his reputation as a driven, demanding titan of Wall Street preceded him. So did the story about the delivery guy.

title: LEBANESE WARLORD KILLED
description: Lebanon relived a moment of its brutal civil war when a Beirut car bomb killed Elie Hobeika, 45, the one-time Christian militia chieftain whose gunmen carried out the 1982 massacre of hundreds of Palestinian refugees in the Sabra and Shatila camps. There was no shortage of possible culprits: over the years, the warlord-turned-politician created enemies among virtually every faction involved in Lebanon. And Mr. Hobeika had just agreed to testify in a Belgian court in a case accusing Ariel Sharon of the 1982 massacres. Neil MacFarquhar

title: An Artist Beyond Isms
description: You can't miss the painter Gerhard Richter's studio in a suburb outside Cologne. It is a large white brick-and-concrete shoe box he designed several years ago, an industrial-looking building with a blank wall facing the street. This is a distinguished neighborhood of split-level houses occupied by prosperous families. Richter moved here from a former factory building in Cologne, where many artists live, partly because he wanted to get away from other artists. Just recently, he bought some trees and had them planted in a row to screen the front of the building after he discovered that a few of the neighbors were complaining about its severity. Having built a private Berlin Wall with his studio, he has now decorated it with wild apple trees.

title: Thorn's Risky Plan Comes Up a Winner
description: When he left his secure job at league headquarters for the Nets two years ago, Rod Thorn was told he was taking a major gamble. Being a seven-card-stud-playing West Virginian, Thorn was undeterred.

title: At the Nexus Of Tragic And Absurd
description: WHEN any world-class director dies, the loss is a tragedy, but especially when the filmmaker is still in his prime: how much talent was still untapped?

title: The Trouble With Bubbles
description: As Walter Bagehot, the great 19th-century editor of The Economist, put it: ''The rocks only show once the tide has gone out.'' In recent months, we have seen the tide of sentiment and wishful thinking, which buoyed Enron in its rise to glory, subside. The rocks, upon which the company was scuppered, emerge in ever sharper form. However, the Enron affair is not an isolated case. On the contrary, it can be seen as representative of the greatest speculative mania in the history of the world.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Jan. 6 about ''Anthony Blunt: His Lives,'' by Miranda Carter, misstated the position of Michael Straight, an American who knew the British art historian and Soviet spy Anthony Blunt at Cambridge University before World War II. From 1969 to 1977 Straight was deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts; he was never its chairman. The review also referred incorrectly to the sides in the Spanish Civil War; the rebels represented the political right, not the left, and received help from fascist nations, not from the Soviet Union.

title: Expense-Wise, Maybe, but Morale-Foolish
description: Hard times have brought hard measures. Rare is the company that isn't looking on every line of every budget to nip one expense here or another there. No outlay seems too small to overlook, no perk too sacred to be spared.

title: Which Way Did He Run?
description: As the neurosurgeon who operated on Kevin Shea when he was injured in the terrorist attack, I read Grann's article with great interest. On Sept. 11, I watched in shock and disbelief from my office window in Newark as the towers burned. Every hospital in the area, including ours (University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey-University Hospital), was put on full alert, but the patients never came -- with a few exceptions.

title: A PLANE WITH EVERYTHING
description: President Jiang Zemin's luxurious official aircraft turned out to have some unadvertised features, according to reports that filtered through the Chinese military. The plush upholstery of the Boeing 767, built and outfitted in the United States under the eyes of Chinese guards, hid 20 sophisticated satellite-operated bugging devices. Exactly who planted the devices is not clear, but China, preparing for President Bush's first state visit, kept its fingerpointing at the U.S. to a minimum.

title: 'Jane Addams and the Dream of American Democracy'
description: Jane Addams lived a quintessentially public life; there are no mysterious lost periods in her story. Records are sparse from the six months she spent bedridden following back surgery performed by her brother-in-law Harry Haldeman—probably due to her relative inactivity during this period and to her state of mind (she had reportedly suffered a nervous breakdown). But apart from this six-month period, her whereabouts and her actions are well documented. Born September 6, 1860, she was christened Laura Jane Addams; but throughout her childhood and youth, she was called Jennie by her close family members and friends. She was the eighth of nine children of John Huy and Sarah Weber Addams, and one of only four (three girls and one boy) to reach adulthood. Her mother died when she was two years old. She was cared for by her older sisters until 1868, when her father married Anna Haldeman, a widow with two children. Jane Addams entered the Rockford Female Seminary in 1877, and graduated in 1881. She was retroactively awarded a bachelor's degree in 1882, when Rockford Seminary became Rockford College and gained the right to confer that degree on students who had completed qualifying work in science.

title: Corrections
description: APolitical Memo article last Sunday about the end of winter meetings of the Republican and Democratic Parties misstated the number of Democrats in the House of Representatives. It is 211, not 221.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about economies at Newsday referred incorrectly to reductions in the newspaper's stock tables. The decision was announced by the paper in December; it has not yet been carried out.

title: KMART IN BANKRUPTCY
description: On Monday, the Newspaper Association of America declared the Kmart Corporation, the nation's third-largest discount store operator, the best overall retailer of the year. A day later, the company filed for bankruptcy, a victim of a flawed pricing strategy, suspicious suppliers and, most remarkably, the scandals surrounding the collapse of Enron. Kmart's workers compensation plan was backed by surety bonds -- handing responsibility for the plan to an insurance company in the case of corporate failure -- whose price has risen by up to 1,000 percent since Enron went belly up. Stephanie Strom

title: POSTINGS: The Future of 2 Columbus Circle; Will the Site Go to Trump?
description: The Giuliani administration, known for keeping projects under wraps, seemed to have an especially heavy blanket reserved for the city-owned site at 2 Columbus Circle, the former Gallery of Modern Art.

title: SUIT ON DETAINEES
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey filed a lawsuit against Hudson and Passaic Counties last week requesting the names of all Immigration and Naturalization detainees held in both counties' jails after the Sept. 11 attacks. The suit was prompted by the jails' refusal to disclose the names after several A.C.L.U. requests. Deborah Jacobs, executive director of the state A.C.L.U., said her organization's offer to legally represent detainees was being thwarted by the refusal. About half the Muslim men held since the Sept. 11 attacks are believed to be in county jails in New Jersey. Jo Piazza

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Bob Gallenbach, Edgar Pea, Juan Pea, Tatyana Pea, Apna Ghar Agency, Chicago, Nov. 24, 2001

title: IT LIVES
description: The effort to overhaul the campaign finance law came back to life with a boost from the scrutiny of Enron. As politicians scrambled to return its campaign contributions, advocates of limiting money in politics won enough support to force their issue to the House floor. In a defeat for the Republican leadership, debate was assured when 218 members of the House -- or a majority -- signed a petition demanding the vote. Alison Mitchell

title: All-Wheel Drive in Many Flavors
description: BY now, most drivers know the crucial distinctions between rear drive and front drive. But even experts' heads may spin when they try to account for the many variations of all-wheel-drive (and four-wheel-drive) systems.

title: AFTER THE VOLCANO
description: Residents of Goma, Congo, began rebuilding their lives in a city topped with lava. They pounded away at the mounds of molten rock with sledgehammers and cooked on the still-sizzling lava. With their agricultural fields covered by the innards of Mount Nyiragongo, the victims lined up by the tens of thousands for food and water provided by the relief agencies. Mother Nature was not done, though. Heavy rains fell, tremors shook the ground and volcanologists worried that one of the two volcanos in the area might strike again. Marc Lacey

title: Cornell Raises Tuition to $27,270 a Year
description: Cornell University trustees voted on Friday to raise tuition by 5 percent, to $27,270 for many of its students in the 2002-2003 school year.

title: Political Briefing; From Counting Ballots To Counting Dollars
description: In five Congressional campaigns in Florida's 13th District, just south of St. Petersburg, Representative Dan Miller never spent more than $380,000 to win, and usually considerably less. He did not have to spend more. He is a Republican and the district is heavily Republican.

title: In Riverdale, Tropical Vines Fly in Winter's Face
description: It was freezing outside. The perennial garden was neatly clipped and raked, a few rose canes dangling from the top reaches of a rustic tripod made of cedar branches. But inside the greenhouse at Wave Hill, that intimate public garden in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, a South American vine, Pyrostegia venusta, or orange trumpet vine, was covering an entire wall with its clusters of bright tubular flowers.

title: Down to a Reviving Seaport for Tickets

At the street's other end, crowds were swarming the new viewing platforms at the World Trade Center ruins. Then Paul Goldstein, the district manager of Community Board 1, had a brainstorm: Why not redirect the crowds to the seaport and solve two problems at once? Soon, the city began issuing free tickets for the platforms at the South Street Seaport Museum.

He was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center and was listed in serious condition yesterday. Investigators had not determined a motive for the attack. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNAPP, MARTHA GRATWICK
description: KNAPP-Martha Gratwick. A longtime resident of Darien, died Friday, January 25, in her home at Edgehill in Stamford, Connecticut. She was 88. She graduated from the Ethel Walker School, and, in 1937, from Smith College after a junior year at the Sorbonne. During WWII when her late husband, George Owen Knapp II, was overseas, she was a Red Cross nurse in Buffalo hospitals and a civil defense worker. In Darien, she volunteered at the First Aid Society, the annual Smith College Book Sale, and Reading for the Blind. Born on December 11, 1913, in Buffalo, she was the daughter of the late Frederick C. and Dotha Dart Gratwick. Mobbie loved to laugh, often at herself. Her sense of fun, her warmth and gentle manner belied an inner core of strength. She had a passion for sports. She actively competed during the 1930's and 1940's in New York State alpine ski racing with her mother and her identical twin sister, the late Lisa Gratwick Nagel, often the three of them placing first, second, and third. She was also a tennis player, a golfer, and an avid ice dancer. In addition to her parents, husband and twin sister, Mrs. Knapp was predeceased by her brother Stephen Gratwick. She is survived by her brothers Frederick C. Gratwick Jr. and Davies Gratwick of Buffalo; four children, George O. Knapp III of Plantation, Florida, Lisa Gratwick Knapp of Redding, Connecticut, Louise Knapp Page of Newton, Massachusetts, and Susan KnappCook of Norwalk, Connecticut; three grandchildren, Jared, Tom and Sara, three great-grandchildren, Taylor, Dylan and Hadley; and many devoted nieces, nephews, and other relatives. A memorial service for Mrs. Knapp will be held on Thursday, January 31st, at 2 PM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1848 Post Road, Darien, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Roswell Park Cancer Institute, Elm and Carlton Streets, Buffalo, NY 14263 or Visiting Nurse and Hospice Care of Southwestern CT, Inc., 1029 East Main Street, Stamford, CT 06902-4108.

His line was, ''I try to tell the truth whenever I can.'' It was his comic effort at the whole truth; but of course he was deceiving himself. He had below-zero interest in the truth.

title: A Long Weekend in Cannes
description: Last month, the Residence All Suites Hotel opened in Cannes, two blocks from the Croisette Beach. Its 110 rooms range from studios to five-bedroom units and have kitchens. There are two heated pools, a sauna, whirlpool, billiards and room service. A three-night package from New York on Air France that includes air fare and transfers in Cannes costs $469 a person, based on double occupancy (regularly $579), and must be bought by Feb. 28; travel must begin by March 31. Other United States gateways are available; (888) 733-3876.

At this point, no one knows for sure whether the actions that led to the collapse of the company constituted financial crimes, and, if they did, which should be the focus of the investigation.

title: Michel Poniatowski, 79, A Backroom French Rightist
description: Michel Poniatowski, a former French interior minister who helped Valry Giscard d'Estaing become president in 1974 but whose career was plunged into controversy by a murder scandal and increasingly reactionary views, died on Jan. 15 in his home in Opio, Alpes-Maritimes, in southeastern France. He was 79.

title: Recapturing A Spirit Of Daring
description: With a performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony on Saturday night that proved music making can be both intellectual and thrilling, the 72-year-old conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi concluded the last of three milestone concerts with the Cleveland Orchestra on successive nights at Carnegie Hall. These were Mr. Dohnanyi's final appearances in New York as the orchestra's music director. He leaves the post at the end of this season after a nearly 20-year tenure of staggering accomplishment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, HERMAN

He is survived by his sisters Phoebe Levine and Blanche Multer of Deerfield Beach, FL, his nephews, Eric and Larry Greenbush of New York City and Jim Slavin of East Windsor, NJ. Mr. Meltzer, a respected and renowned condemnation attorney, was a long time partner in Cullen & Dykman of Brooklyn and Garden City, NY. Herman was a man possessed of incredible intelligence, impeccable integrity, boundless kindness and profound wisdom. He will be sorely missed by those whose lives he touched. Graveside services will be held at New Montifiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, L.I., at 2 P.M. on Monday.

There were 20,000 new patients last year, including 500 children. Most were from Texas, but others came from across the nation and the world, hoping for a cure.

title: Letting 'Figaro' Be Itself, So Subtlety Can Shine
description: One of the more refreshing aspects of Jonathan Miller's 1998 staging of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday, is the degree to which it sets aside directorial conceits and lets the opera speak for itself. That isn't to say that this is a work that directors should keep their hands off, or that Mr. Miller's production is a blank slate; far from it. But ''Figaro,'' with the undercurrent of social commentary that survived the translation from the original Beaumarchais play to Lorenzo Da Ponte's libretto, seems to invite updating and magnification of all kinds.

title: Liz Krueger for State Senate
description: After 33 years as a Republican state senator from New York City, Roy Goodman stepped down recently, making way for a new voice to represent Manhattan's East Side in Albany. The choices to succeed him in a midterm election on Feb. 12 are Liz Krueger, the Democrat who nearly defeated Mr. Goodman in the last election, and State Assemblyman John Ravitz, a Republican who has represented a portion of the district since 1990.

title: Extra Fortification for Baby Formulas
description: For years, much of the baby formula sold around the world has contained two fatty acids that are naturally present in breast milk and are believed to help babies' neurological and visual development. But it was only last year that this country approved use of the ingredients.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 29  President Kim Dae Jung today dismissed the minister in charge of pursuing peace with North Korea as part of a cabinet shake-up aimed at revamping a government buffeted by political scandals.

title: Warm and Dry
description: There must have been a time, years ago, when nobody worried about why a detachment of mid-spring days, like the ones just past in New York City, would pop up at the tail end of January. Last weekend was Georgia weather in Central Park, a hint of the Carolinas on the Grand Concourse, temperatures 20 degrees and more above normal. Enjoyable as they were, those temperatures were also inherently worrisome. People who wanted only to sit in the sun had to do so next to people who wanted to sit in the sun but couldn't help asking, ''What does it mean?'' before being overcome by the joy of basking like a lizard on a hot rock.

description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 56 percent as fewer people traveled by air after the terrorist attacks in September.

Celia's late husband, Solomon Heiferman, was a respected Trustee who served as Chairman of the Board from 1978 to 1981. Celia continued to support the mission of Parker as a member of the Founders Society and by establishing a fund for educational programs to improve the quality of later life. Our condolences and deepest sympathy to her daughter, Ruth Heiferman Prenner, and other members of the family. Barbara N. Kurshan, Chair of the Board Barry T. Zeman, President

title: Corrections
description: A dance listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday misidentified the company that is to appear at 8 p.m. on Saturday at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. It is the National Song and Dance Company of Mozambique, not the National Song and Dance Theater Company of Jamaica.

title: Seeking Safety, Downtown Firms Are Scattering
description: Morgan Stanley, the largest securities company in Manhattan, announced an agreement yesterday to buy the former Texaco headquarters in Westchester County as part of an effort to decentralize its operations.

title: Jenny Craig Founders Are Selling Chain in $115 Million Deal
description: Sid and Jenny Craig have found a buyer for their weight-loss chain after a nine-month search, during which the company's shares slipped off the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Vodafone In Deal With Start-Up
description: Bytemobile, a wireless data start-up based in Mountain View,Calif., said yesterday that it reached a deal with Vodafone, Britain's largest mobile phone operator, to provide technology that improves the performance of networks that allow mobile users to send e-mail messages and surf the Internet. Bytemobile also announced details of its venture financing yesterday. It received $29 million in second-round financing from a group of investors led by Ericsson Venture Partners. In October 2000, the company received initial financing of $15 million. Created in July 2000, the company makes hardware and software products that streamline wireless data transfer by compressing data packets. The company says that depending on the type of file sent, a mobile user can transfer data up to seven times the speed currently possible. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: China Sentences Man on Reduced Charge for Importing Bibles
description: A Hong Kong citizen accused of bringing tens of thousands of annotated Bibles into China for use by a banned evangelical Christian group was given a two-year prison sentence today by a court in Fujian Province. It was a far lighter sentence than his supporters had feared.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: More Hutu-Tutsi Violence
description: After a crackdown on the Hutu rebel stronghold by the army, which is dominated by members of the Tutsi minority, the rebels are stepping up road ambushes, prompting many bus drivers to refuse to drive outside the capital. In an attack on Sunday, rebels opened fire on a minibus about 12 miles south of Bujumbura, killing three civilians.

title: In Wartime, the People Want the Facts
description: Four months into the war, a review of news coverage reveals that over time Americans are getting fewer facts and more opinion -- a narrow range of opinion, at that -- from newspapers, magazines and television. At the same time, polls show the press losing a measure of the respect it had gained in September, when the public overwhelmingly applauded the timely, comprehensive and informative news coverage it was getting.

title: When H.I.V. Made Its Jump to People
description: For several years now, Dr. Beatrice H. Hahn and Dr. George M. Shaw, AIDS researchers at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, have been well aware that the scientific evidence for the origins of AIDS had a few crucial gaps. And they intended to fill them.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Two Theories On Chechnya Crash
description: An examination of the wreckage of a military helicopter that crashed in Chechnya on Sunday and of the bodies of the 14 men who died led to conflicting assertions about the cause of the midair explosion that brought it down. Some officials said a technical malfunction was the most likely cause but prosecutors in Chechnya opened a criminal investigation. Chechen rebels said they brought the helicopter down with a shoulder-fired missile. Among the dead were the deputy interior minister, Gen. Mikhail Rudchenko, and his aide Gen. Nikolai Goridov.

title: John Paul Says Catholic Bar Must Refuse Divorce Cases
description: Pope John Paul II said today that civil lawyers who are Roman Catholic must refuse to take divorce cases, and should instead try to help separated couples reconcile.

title: Jerusalem's Battered Road Tries to Get Back to Work
description: In the battered center of Jerusalem, beefed-up police squads guarded sidewalks and street corners today as weary shopkeepers opened for business and workers repaired the stores damaged by a bomb set off Sunday by a Palestinian woman.

title: A Departure at Cond Nast Prompts a Reshuffling Among Its Publishers
description: In the first top-level shake-up of the year at a major magazine company, the most senior marketing executive at Cond Nast Publications in New York is leaving, leading to new roles for two well-known publishers -- and perhaps leaving the door open for the return of another familiar face.

title: John Jackson, 77, Guitarist And Singer in Piedmont Style
description: John Jackson, a master of the Piedmont tradition of blues, country and ragtime, died on Jan. 20 at his home in Fairfax, Va. He was 77.

title: Sports of The Times; Super Scientists At Work
description: THE streetcar named Desire is now a bus. And has been since before Super Bowl IV, the first of what will be Bourbon Street's ninth Super Bowl, the most of any site. But there is still a trolley on St. Charles Street and they're constructing a trolley line on Canal Street that leads to where the Mississippi and the bourbon flow.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Compaq Introduces New Server
description: Compaq Computer introduced its smallest server computer yesterday to compete for sales of low-end systems. Compaq's ProLiant BI e-Class, or blade server, piles all of the chips and a hard drive onto one board the size of a long book, rather than current pizza-box-size models. That lets users put several servers into a smaller space. The blade servers will compete against servers from I.B.M. and Sun Microsystems Inc.

title: Party On: When Bacchanals Collide
description: Never mind that the National Security Special Event this Sunday (known to civilians as the Super Bowl) will be the most secure, patted-down, X-rayed and no-fly-zoned event in sports history, at least until the Olympics begin the next weekend. Forget the loss of primacy of the New Orleans Police Department to the Secret Service, resulting in a heartbreaking loss of downtown parking spaces and exit ramps.

Whites such as semillon and verdelho are garnering attention for their sassy succulence, while powerful reds from old-vine grenache, mourvedre and cabernet sauvignon are poised for stardom of their own.

title: Edwards Convinced Patriots Can Win
description: The Jets played the St. Louis Rams and the New England Patriots this season, and lost to both, so Jets Coach Herman Edwards has respect for each team in Super Bowl XXXVI. And while the Patriots are significant underdogs, Edwards said yesterday that he had a lot of confidence New England could pull off an upset.

title: U.S. IS REQUESTING TIGHTER SECURITY AT UTAH OLYMPICS
description: The Justice Department has requested major last-minute changes in security arrangements at the Olympic Games in Salt Lake City out of concern that some sites had not been adequately protected from a terrorist attack, law enforcement officials said.

title: 130 FASHION BUGS SCHEDULED FOR CLOSING
description: Charming Shoppes, which operates Fashion Bug and Lane Bryant clothing stores, is closing 130 Fashion Bug stores as well as its Added Dimensions/Answer chain and its 77 stores. The closings will cost $23 million, or 21 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, which ends Thursday, Charming Shoppes said. It said the moves would help it save $12 million a year before taxes. Charming Shoppes, which is based in Bensalem, Pa., will also convert 44 Fashion Bug stores into Lane Bryant stores. The retailer expects to lose 2 cents to 4 cents a share in the quarter, including the costs.

title: Accident-Prone Sub Bumps U.S. Warship
description: The submarine Greeneville, widely known for its deadly collision with a Japanese trawler last year, bumped into an American warship in the Arabian Sea on Sunday, causing no injuries but leaving a gash in one of the ship's fuel tanks, the Pentagon said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Power Plant Planned
description: RWE, a leading European power company, and Volkswagen plan to jointly build a power plant in Puebla, Mexico. Volkswagen builds 400,000 cars a year in Puebla, a city 120 kilometers (75 miles) south of Mexico City, and 80 percent of those cars are sold outside Mexico. The joint venture will help Volkswagen and its suppliers become independent of the public energy supply and will cut costs, RWE said.

Keith Olbermann, on his ABC Radio program, said Parcells had discreetly asked the Buccaneers if their previous offer was still on the table.

Rooms, with fireplace, afternoon tea, wine and hors d'oeuvres and full breakfast for two, are $135 to $170 a night Sunday to Thursday; Friday is $40 more; (800) 698-2910.

title: U.S. Rejects Bid to Double Foreign Aid To Poor Lands
description: The Bush administration has rejected an international proposal to double foreign aid in the wake of the war in Afghanistan, contending that poor countries should make better use of the assistance they now receive, diplomats said today.

title: Monarchos Retired; Won Derby, Little Else
description: For Monarchos, the 2001 Kentucky Derby winner, there were two minutes of fame and nine months of unfulfilled potential. Without a victory since scoring a mild upset in the second-fastest running of the Derby, the gray colt was retired yesterday, the latest in a long string of prominent horses to end their careers prematurely.

Favorite mother-inlaw of Nick Catinella. Wonderful grandmother to Matthew, Francesca, Nicole and Jeffrey. Her strength and devotion to her family was an inspiration to us all. Crime has become a major issue in the April 21 presidential election, with some polls showing that it has replaced the economy as the top concern among voters. While all categories of crime are on the rise, the largest increase was in violent crime, which jumped 9.86 percent.

title: BUSH RECONSIDERS STAND ON TREATING CAPTIVES OF WAR
description: After a lengthy meeting with his national security team today, President Bush said he was reconsidering whether Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters held at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, should be protected under the Third Geneva Convention. But he quickly added that they were ''killers'' who would not be granted the status of prisoners of war.

title: Mayor Pleads Not Guilty In Bribe Case From Paterson
description: The mayor of Paterson, Martin G. Barnes, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he defrauded the federal government and accepted cash, vacations, designer suits and arrangements for female companionship from contractors doing business with the city.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Pornography Case
description: The state's highest court overturned the pornography conviction of a man who took photographs of a 15-year-old girl posing topless with her boyfriend. The Supreme Judicial Court ruled that John C. Bean, 40, an aspiring photographer who was taking classes at the Worcester Art Museum, acted without ''lascivious intent.'' Had the conviction stood, Mr. Bean would have had to register as a sex offender. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Reduces Prices
description: Gateway Inc. reduced the price of its personal computers yesterday and added more free items, in an effort to win back market share lost during the last year. Gateway, the No. 4 personal computer vendor in the United States, cut the price of most notebooks, as well as several desktop and data-serving computers, by $100 or more, and added features like DVD drives and flat-panel screens. The company also said it would start its largest-ever advertising campaign, including in-store marketing and television advertisements during the Winter Olympics. The company had foreshadowed the move last week, when it reported a narrow fourth-quarter profit but said it expected to lose money in the coming quarters as it tried harder to sell more computers. Chris Gaither (NYT)

description: It was not your everyday flamenco dance festival in New York. There was a deliberate mix of the experimental and the traditional.

title: Musicians of Operatic Turf Add a Bit of Singing Art to Mahler
description: Carnegie Hall seemed like home away from home for this critic last week. From Thursday through Saturday nights there were three remarkable concerts by the Cleveland Orchestra to take in, the last New York appearances by the retiring Christoph von Dohnanyi as music director of this world-renowned orchestra. Then on Sunday afternoon it was the Met Orchestra's turn on the same stage, with James Levine, in a program of Berg's Seven Early Songs with Rene Fleming as soloist and Mahler's formidable Sixth Symphony.

title: HOSPITAL-EQUIPMENT MAKER CUT 189 JOBS
description: Graham-Field Health Products Inc., a maker of hospital beds and wheelchairs, cut 189 jobs as part of closing its Bay Shore, N.Y., factory. Wheelchairs, bathroom safety and other medical seating products manufactured at the plant will be made by other suppliers to save money, Graham-Field said. Those products will be sold under the company's Lumex brand. Graham-Field, which is based in Atlanta, sought bankruptcy protection in December 1999 after five consecutive quarters of losses.

title: Pounds of Prevention in Drops of Baby Blood
description: In 1963, Dr. Robert Guthrie of the University of Buffalo gave birth to an early detection technique that has since saved the health and lives of countless babies. With a few drops of blood drawn from a newborn baby's heel, he showed that a retardation-causing genetic disorder called PKU (for phenylketonuria) could be detected -- and ultimately treated -- before an affected baby's brain was irreversibly damaged.

title: Accounts
description: Re:PLAY, Providence, R.I., a toy maker, to Rotter-Kantor, New York, to handle its integrated marketing account, with spending estimated at $6 million. The account had been handled on a project basis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MARION
description: KAHN-Marion. On January 26, 2002, at age 97. Devoted mother of Lois Wallace. Beloved grandmother of George and his wife Caroline. Lifelong resident of New York, New York. Graduate of Barnard, Class of 1925. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Monday, January 28th, 5-8 PM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Offer for Ikos Is Extended
description: The Mentor Graphics Corporation, which designs software for computer chip makers, today extended its $99 million offer to buy Ikos Systems Inc. to midnight Friday, the second time the offer has been extended. The cash offer of $11 a share was previously scheduled to expire on Jan. 8 and was extended last month to midnight last Friday. Ikos Systems, which makes hardware to check the design of electronic systems, told shareholders in December to reject Mentor's takeover offer even though the bid was superior to one from Synopsys Inc. Synopsys has offered $6 to $20 a share, depending on sales and profit goals.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Suit On M.I.T. Suicide
description: The family of a Massachusetts Institute of Technology student who set herself on fire in her dormitory room has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against M.I.T. Elizabeth Shin, 19, a biology major from Livingston, N.J., died in April 2000, and received treatment through M.I.T. for more than a year before her death. M.I.T denies it was negligent. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RILEY, ELIZABETH M.
description: RILEY-Elizabeth M. The Trustees and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Library mourn the death of Elizabeth M. Riley, who died in New York on January 27, 2002. She was ninety-four years old. Liz, who had a distinguished career in publishing children's books, became a Fellow of the Library in 1955 and served as a conscientious, devoted, and valuable member of the Board for twenty-four years. She believed passionately in the importance of books and great institutions, making her a vigorous force in guiding the Morgan Library. We will greatly miss her and extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. Charles E. Pierce, Jr., Director S. Parker Gilbert, President, Board of Trustees

title: Top Argentine Clubs Face Budget Troubles
description: Perhaps the only thing worse than the condition of the Argentine economy is the financial state of Argentina's soccer clubs. The country's top 20 clubs are estimated to be more than $200 million in debt, with most of the money being owed to players.

title: India Police Kill 2 Tied to Calcutta Attack
description: The police in eastern India said today that they had shot a Pakistani man in a gun battle early this morning and that he had confessed before he died that he had fired an AK-47 at officers guarding an American cultural center in Calcutta on Tuesday. The attack there killed four officers.

title: First Things First
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MARTIN
description: KLEIN-Martin. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of their devoted member. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THIER, IRA L.
description: THIER-Ira L. On January 27, 2002. Beloved husband of Joanne. Loving father of Amy. Cherished grandfather of Alex Martin. Dear brother, cousin, uncle and friend. A gentle, caring, courageous man. Contributions in his memory may be made for music scholarships to The Juilliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023, Attn: Office of Development and Public Affairs. Funeral services private.

title: The Great Divide
description: It was a shocking event. With incredible speed, our perception of the world and of ourselves changed. It seemed that before we had lived in a kind of blind innocence, with no sense of the real dangers that lurked. Now we had experienced a rude awakening, which changed everything.

title: Still Family After All These Years; New York Companies 100 Years Old and Going Strong
description: Enrons they are not.

title: Front Row; In the Public Eye
description: Heather Mills has lived a life so ruled by hardship and coincidence that it might have come straight out of Dickens. When she was 9, her mother abandoned her. Soon afterward, her father was imprisoned for defaulting on a debt. At 13, she ran away from her London home, haunting Waterloo Station and stealing food and clothing to survive.

title: Metropolitan Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWELL, SHIRLEY
description: SCHWELL-Shirley. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our member, Steven Schwell. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: Rams Waste No Time Debating Their Tactics
description: St. Louis Rams Coach Mike Martz ended speculation that he lives his life in jogging suits, making his first Super Bowl week appearance today, addressing the news media in a dark pinstriped suit, his hair trimmed and slicked. But Martz still spent most of his day meeting with assistant coaches, preparing a game plan to wield against the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XXXVI on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIZERIK, JOEL
description: MIZERIK-Joel, tragically on January 22, 2002. Joel was a self-employed decorator who lived in Manhattan and later in Yonkers. Survivors include his father, Frank; his sister and her husband, Gwen and Leo Penzine; his brother, Frank Jr.; nieces and nephews, Christina and Maurizio Nicolelli, Lea Penzine, Frank and Ocean Mizerik III, Lori and Joe McHale; great-niece and nephew, Alexis and Matthew Nicolelli. Memorial Mass Saturday, February 2, 2002, 10 AM, Church of the Sacred Heart, Broadway and Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to a charity of your choice.

title: Jesse Jackson Declines To Judge an Enron Leader
description: Descending from the fog-shrouded 50th-floor office of Kenneth L. Lay, the patriarch of the Enron Corporation, Jesse Jackson strode into the gray morning today and approached the television cameras. The moment seemed ripe for a familiar flourish of indignation and versification.

title: Charleston Journal; Where the Bench Orders Some Southern Comfort
description: Philip C. Inwood showed up for Livability Court this morning looking more than a little bleary.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Jabil And Tellium Begin Venture
description: Jabil Circuit Inc. will assemble circuit boards and subassemblies for the Aurora line of core optical switches from Tellium Inc. Financial terms were not disclosed. In a statement released yesterday, Tellium said Jabil would provide Tellium with full turnkey manufacturing services for the assembly and testing of circuit boards and subassemblies used in Tellium's optical switching systems. Jabil, an electronic manufacturing services provider, will also support Tellium with procurement and test process development.

title: Setting Molire in the 1930's: Not Anti-Religious, Just Anti-Fanatic
description: It's hard to know for sure from Jeff Cohen's adaptation of ''Tartuffe'' whether he meant it as a commentary on the fanatics who brought down the World Trade Center towers, but there are a few hints that he did. For one, the TriBeCa Playhouse, where this Worth Street Theater Company production of Molire's most oft-performed work opened this week, is the closest theater to ground zero, and in a director's note Mr. Cohen talks about wanting to present a play to celebrate New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, SR. JEAN GAILHAC, RSHM
description: WALKER-Sr. Jean Gailhac, RSHM, 81, January 27, Tarrytown, NY. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary 54 years. Educator Marymount School, Los Angeles, CA, and Marymount Colleges: Los Angeles, CA, Palos Verdes, CA, Arlington, VA. School Social Worker Shelton, CT. Parish Minister Portland, CT. Survived by cousins, Margaret Leininger of Pittsburgh, PA, and Joan Baldinger of Spring Hill, FL. Visiting Tuesday, 3:00-7:30 PM, Mass Wednesday 10:30AM, both at Marymount Convent, Tarrytown, NY.

title: The War on Painkillers
description: To the Editor:

title: Patrolling His Green Oasis With a Red Bolt Cutter
description: ADRIAN BENEPE, the city's new parks commissioner, is behind the wheel of his green Parks Department S.U.V., pulling away from his office on West 61st Street. He is wearing a blue suit and tie; a beeper and cellphone are latched to his belt. Classical music plays on the radio. On the back seat is a red long-handled bolt cutter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSTER, GEORGINA M.
description: FORSTER-Georgina M. Born February 21, 1915. Died January 27, 2002. Beloved mother of Frances M. Forster. Also survived by a sister Anna R. Schwartz and a brother Frederick W. Schwartz. Reposing Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th St, NY, NY Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church Thursday 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, WERNER
description: WOLFF-Werner. Born June 11, 1911. Husband for 60 years of Alice E. Wolff, father of Steven and Mark H. Wolff, grandfather of Dr. Elizabeth R. Wolff and Avery M. Wolff. Werner Wolff was a prominent photojournalist who worked with Alfred Eisenstaedt and later went on to photograph such notables as Albert Einstein, Eleanor Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy, among many others. He died at home after a long illness with his family at hand.

title: Assessing Terror Attack in a New Light
description: Wendy Osserman and her dancers began to see what they were creating in a different light after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. Then the short pieces started to flow into a whole, called ''In the Light of Loss,'' which the Wendy Osserman Dance Company performed on Friday night at the Kitchen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ISRAEL S. ''SOL''
description: FRIEDMAN-Israel S. ''Sol'' died peacefully at home January 25, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Blanche Friedman for 62 years. A WWII veteran and retired dentist, he worked 30 years for the Veteran's Administration. He is survived by his daughter Lois, son Matthew and his wife Mary and beloved grandchildren Jessica, Carly and Daniel. A wonderful husband, father and grandfather, he will be terribly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIFT, RICHARD N.
description: SWIFT-Richard N. His College High School classmates of 1940 mourn the loss of our Valedictorian, WWII artillary officer, Harvard Ph.D., Professor Emeritus at NYU, and, most importantly, a dear friend.

title: BERMUDA INSURER EXPECTS TO LOSE $60 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: XL Capital Ltd., Bermuda's biggest insurer, said it expected to lose $60 million in the fourth quarter because of the collapse of the Enron Corporation and an increase in other claims. XL Capital said it paid claims for the November crash of American Airlines Flight 587 in Queens, and for property losses in Europe. The insurer said last month that it expected the bankruptcy of Enron to cost it about $75 million. The company is also setting aside funds to cover losses at its NAC Re Corporation unit after claims rose on policies written before XL Capital bought the company for $1.1 billion in 1999. XL Capital, which is based in Hamilton, Bermuda, provides reinsurance coverage to other insurers.

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column on Sunday about people who are losing their jobs at B/E Aerospace in Litchfield, Conn., gave a misspelled surname in some references for a former plant employee who plans to open a woodworking shop. He is Andy Sewell, not Newell.

title: Fox TV Pulls 'The Chamber,' A Reality Show
description: The Fox network has pulled its new reality show ''The Chamber'' off the air after just one week in its regular Friday time period.

title: A Law Firm's 2 Roles Risk Suit by Enron, Experts Say
description: The dual role of the Houston law firm Vinson & Elkins in providing legal opinions for several Enron entities and later in reviewing the propriety of those transactions has tarnished the firm and may expose it to a malpractice suit, several law professors and lawyers say.

title: Planet or No, It's On to Pluto
description: In 1991, the United States Postal Service issued a series of stamps commemorating American space exploration. The stamp for Pluto consisted of a painting of a grayish disk with an apology of sorts underneath: ''Not Yet Explored.''

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Palestinian Authority: Ship Suspect Jailed
description: A Palestinian official said that an official accused of involvement in an arms shipment seized by Israel last month had been moved from house arrest to prison in the compound of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. Jibril Rajoub, the Palestinian security chief in the West Bank, said that Fuad Shobaki, who had been in charge of finances for the Palestinian security services, would be prosecuted if evidence linked him to the shipment.

title: Justice at Guantnamo
description: Encouragingly, President Bush now seems to be reconsidering the administration's hasty and ill-advised decision that Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters being held at the Guantnamo Bay naval base are not entitled to the procedural protections of the Geneva Convention on prisoners of war. That arbitrary action rightly offended most of America's allies. By undermining the clear language of the convention, it also potentially endangered future American troops who may fall into enemy hands. The concerns expressed by America's top military commanders on this score may be leading Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld to reconsider his initial enthusiasm for this bad idea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLINESMITH, JEANNETTE
description: CLINESMITH-Jeannette. Our beloved mother passed into eternity on January 24, 2002. An artist and musician, she was a being of tremendous courage, conviction and resilience. As a single parent who endured the loss of her first born child, Gillian, she is survived by two sons, Khahim and Malik, a daughter, Raven, as well as two beautiful grandchildren, Ayanna and Walker. She will be greatly missed, though her fiery spirit will continue to radiate in the lives of those who love her.

title: More trouble arrives for Bates Worldwide as Hyundai Motor puts a job up for review.
description: THE Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea has dropped the other shoe, squarely on the head of its struggling longtime agency, Bates Worldwide.

title: Squabbles at the Start for World Trade Talks
description: The big formal announcement of a new global round of trade talks came last month at the World Trade Organization conference in Doha, Qatar, and in the future the talks will be called the Doha Round. But they did not actually begin until today in the group's headquarters.

title: Chip Makers In Japan See Only Trouble
description: Chip makers in other countries, like South Korea, Germany and even the United States, have been saying the skies for their gloomy industry are brightening. But the Japanese see only a false dawn.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Richard D. Gottlieb retired as chairman at Lee Enterprises, Davenport, Iowa, after 37 years with the company. Mary Junck, president and chief executive, adds the title of chairwoman; she assumed the chief executive's post from Mr. Gottlieb, 59, last year.

title: Post-Punk Pioneers, No Illusions
description: Most musicians chase the illusion of alchemy, the idea that the music they make can be more than the sum of its parts. Girls Against Boys, who played the Bowery Ballroom on Saturday night, seem too jaded to be taken in by this myth of transcendence. They make music that sounds exactly like the sum of its parts, adhering to a formula they helped invent more than a decade ago.

title: Dust Cloud Causes Helicopter To Crash, Injuring 14 Soldiers
description: An Army cargo helicopter carrying troops from the 101st Airborne Division crashed today while trying to land at a remote base in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, injuring 14 soldiers, the Pentagon said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Economic Confidence Climbs
description: A closely watched barometer of German business confidence rose in January, suggesting that the German and European economies may have hit bottom and may be closer to a recovery. That barometer, the Ifo economic research institute's monthly survey of businesses, showed that confidence has climbed for at least the last two months, though it remains weak. The unexpectedly positive report did little to help the euro, which is slumping against the dollar again. The survey reinforced expectations that Germany, Europe's biggest economy, will probably have little or no growth for several more months but may start picking up again by late spring. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fatal Fire Called Arson
description: A man who died Sunday night in an East Village apartment fire deliberately set the fire with a flammable liquid, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Cieran O'Connor, 29, who died of extensive burns, ignited the fire in the fourth-floor apartment of a former girlfriend at 242 East 10th Street, according to Fire Chief Brian Dixon. Investigators said that the woman was out of town, but that Mr. O'Connor had a key. They said that his motives were unclear, but that he had been drinking heavily. Three firefighters sustained minor injuries, but no one else in the six-story building was injured. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Argentines Check Their Baggage
description: Argentines are the object of much mock derision from other Latin Americans, who laugh at their air of superiority, their pretension, their arrogance. Jokes abound: Why do Argentines run outdoors when there's lightning? Because they think that God is taking their picture. Nothing could be more humiliating to an Argentine than having to emigrate to, of all places, Spain.

title: In Clubs, a Potent Drug Stirs Fear of an Epidemic
description: Some know it as crystal. Others refer to it as Tina, a campy abbreviation of its other name, Christina. But among the habitus of New York's frenetic gay club scene, the extraordinarily powerful stimulant commonly known as crystal meth is earning a new nickname: the Evil One.

title: Bills to Widen Health Care For Women Pass Assembly
description: Trying to pressure the State Senate in the midst of a hard-fought Senate campaign in Manhattan, the Assembly passed three bills today that are liberal favorites, mandating access to female contraceptives and barring discrimination against gays.

title: Smokers' Ethnicity May Make Difference
description: When it comes to the health effects of smoking, the ethnicity of smokers may be as important as the kind of cigarettes they smoke.

title: Fuel Efficiency's Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Bargain Acquisitions Evaporate in Korea
description: The Korean fire sale appears to be ending.

title: Those Schools. That Dreadful Uncle. Those Hats.
description: It's getting to the point where it's almost impossible to make a bad television adaptation of a Dickens novel. Or to make one that looks substantially different from all the others. The two-part ''Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' that turns up tonight and tomorrow night demonstrates these dueling truisms perfectly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALTMAN, SANDRA
description: KALTMAN-Sandra. On January 28, 2002. Beloved mother of Lucy Dasbach and the late Sarah Cantor. Mother-in-law of Kurt Dasbach and Kevin Cantor. Dear brother of Jake Stern. Loving grandmother of Shane, Kai and Sam. Memorial service Friday, 2:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Earnings Fall 15% at an Arizona Utility
description: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, the owner of Arizona's biggest electric utility, said fourth-quarter net income fell 15 percent because of expenses from the collapse of the Enron Corporation.

title: Now, Fear of Flying Is More Than a Phobia
description: Christy Nolan has never been a fearful flyer.

title: Texas Instruments Reports 4th-Quarter Loss
description: Texas Instruments, which makes chips that run two-thirds of all cellphones, reported a fourth-quarter loss today on slack demand for consumer-electronics devices. Still, sales beat analysts' forecasts, and the shares rose as much as 7.5 percent.

title: WAL-MART SAYS SALES RUNNING AT FORECAST
description: The retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that its January sales at stores open at least a year are running at the upper end of its plan for a 4 percent to 6 percent increase from a year earlier. Sales at its Wal-Mart division and its Sam's Wholesale Clubs were above plan in the third week of January, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECTER, EVELYN
description: SCHECTER-Evelyn. Died at Hospice of Palm Beach on January 27, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Harry, loving mother of Carol Schwartz and the late Edward Schwartz, Rabbi Edward and Laurette Schecter. Adored grandmother of Sid, and Kiki, Lori, Sara, Adina, Elie and Ariel, great-grandmother of Emily, sister of Lou Kasdan and the late Phyllis Morris. Private burial and shiva.

title: An Evening Relying on Instant Replay, and Not a Football in Sight
description: ''I think we need to hear that again,'' Pierre Boulez said to a New York Philharmonic audience some 20 years ago, then plunged into a piece by Webern for a second time.

title: Illuminating the Cheney Task Force
description: Sunshine, the Watergate-era rallying cry proclaimed, is the best disinfectant. It is a credo that, 30 years later, is more relevant than ever as the White House and Congress battle over whether records from Vice President Dick Cheney's energy task force should be made public.

title: Front Row; Beyond the Shoe
description: ''This is the 17th iteration'' of the shoe, Theresa Tran, a Nike spokeswoman, said yesterday of the new Air Jordan, the first Michael Jordan footwear introduction since the 38-year-old legend, and comeback compulsive, returned to the N.B.A.

title: Ford Mustang Said to Have Failed Company Crash Tests
description: The Ford Mustang repeatedly failed the Ford Motor Company's internal crash tests for fuel tank integrity while it was being redesigned in the early 1990's, but it met broader company guidelines and the production version later passed government tests, according to a lawyer who obtained numerous internal Ford documents as part of a civil suit.

title: Putting 'Lost Everything' In Perspective
description: Even as Linda Lay, the wife of the former Enron chairman Kenneth L. Lay, told a television audience yesterday that her family had ''lost everything,'' the Lays' personal finances remain a mystery.

title: Andersen Says It Is Losing Clients
description: Clients and potential clients of Arthur Andersen are asking ''hard questions'' about the firm's role in the collapse of the Enron Corporation and it is losing business as a result, the firm's chairman and chief executive, Joseph F. Berardino, said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Windsor: Pileup On Turnpike
description: A four-vehicle pileup involving three tractor-trailers closed a southbound section of the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday for more than four hours, the police said. The accident, which occurred at Milepost 67 in East Windsor at 8:10 a.m., happened when a car rear-ended a tractor-trailer, said Al Della Fave, a state police spokesman. The car spun out of control, causing a second tractor-trailer, which was carrying potatoes, to overturn and spill its load on the highway. A third tractor-trailer lost control after swerving to avoid the second one. Two of the drivers suffered minor injuries, Sergeant Della Fave said. The highway reopened at 12:15 p.m. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Letters: Society and Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERACE, ANNE R.
description: GERACE-Anne R. on January 27, 2002. Former executive secretary to the late Edwin Foster Blair, Esq.; thereafter member of the Dean's Office of NYU Medical School as Assistant Registrar and Coordinator of Alumni Affairs. Beloved sister of Jean G. Vale and Henry Gerace; loving aunt. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday and Wednesday, 4pm-9pm. Funeral Mass at St. Monica's Church, 413 E. 79th St, Thursday 10:30am. Interment private.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the health care union leader Moe Foner on Jan. 11 misstated the name of the New York State Legislature committee that investigated him and his brother in 1942 during a drive against Communists in government. It was the Rapp-Coudert Committee, not Rabb-Coudert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPSLEY, JOHN WILLARD
description: LAPSLEY-John Willard. Died January 26, 2002, following a prolonged illness. He is survived by his wife, Hope Whitney Lapsley; a daughter, Adelaide Mulry of Glen Cove, NY; two sons, Howard of Needham, MA, and Robert of Seattle, WA, and three sisters, Marion Schwarz of New York, NY, Nina Alexander of Bozeman, MT, and Katherine Beug of Kinsale, Ireland. He also leaves three grandsons and four granddaughters. Jack was born in New York City in 1935, the son of Howard Lapsley and Eleanor Hallowell Lapsley. A graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and Harvard College, where he was a member of the Porcellian Club and captain of the Varsity Heavyweight Crew for two years. An avid sailor and lover of the waters of the Maine coast, he also had a fondness for bird shooting in Great Britain. In addition, he gave many friends great pleasure with his extraordinary talent for story telling. Most of his professional career was with J.P. Morgan & Co., where he retired as senior officer in 1996. A memorial service will be held Thursday, January 31, at 11AM, at The Church of The Advent in Westbury, L.I. Contributions may be made in lieu of flowers to: Plastic Surgery Development Fund at the New York Presbyterian Hospital, c/o Dr. Lloyd Hoffman, 525 East 68th St., Box 115, New York, NY 10021.

title: Expedia Posts First Profit
description: Expedia Inc. reported its first profit and surpassed its rival, Travelocity.com, to become the largest Internet travel seller as it increased the number of more-profitable hotel bookings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, JOSEPH P.
description: DEAN-Joseph P. On January 27, 2002. Retired employee of the New York Daily News and the New York Times. Beloved husband of Margaret M. (nee Tucker). Loving father of Paul, Michael and Thomas. Dear brother of Dorothy Saldana and Audrey Schossow. Cherished grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of two. Funeral Wednesday, 8:30 AM, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9:30 AM at Good Shepherd R.C. Church. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Metropolitan Hospice of Greater New York, c/o MJG Nursing Home, 4915 10th Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11219.

title: Let Them Be P.O.W.'s
description: In 1993, an American helicopter pilot named Michael Durant was shot down in the ''Black Hawk Down'' incident in Somalia and seized by gunmen. The Somalis accused him of terrorism and initially threatened to put him on trial.

title: 2 Presidential Hopefuls Keep France Waiting as Vote Nears
description: If this were America, the candidates would have already crisscrossed the country and spent tens of millions of dollars on their campaigns.

title: Motorcycles Find Market In Brazil's Countryside
description: If you buy a motorcycle from Onelio Pimentel, you will be guest of honor at his monthly party in the town square. He will send you a card every year on your birthday. And he will always be waiting with a smile to show you the next new model.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Beyond Oom-Pah-Pah: Music as Teacher
description: To the Editor:

title: Guarding Basketball Players' Teeth
description: High school and college football and hockey players have long accepted the requirement that they wear mouth guards to protect their teeth. But would basketball players be ready to do the same?

title: Lawyer Says Client's Trial Can't Be Fair In New York
description: A lawyer for a man suspected of being a top aide to Osama bin Laden told a federal district judge in Manhattan yesterday that he wanted his client's trial moved from New York City because jurors may be prejudiced by the Sept. 11 terror attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Society and Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing American Journalist Wasn't Spy, Friends Say
description: Danny Pearl never seemed stressed. From the mid-1980's, when he was a laid-back radio host on the overnight shift at Stanford University's campus station, to the mid-1990's, when he was writing lighthearted articles for The Wall Street Journal about federal agencies that had no reason for being, Daniel Pearl, the Journal reporter apparently kidnapped in Pakistan last week, has seemed impervious to pressure.

title: Q & A
description: Yerba Mat

title: Governor of Utah, in Reversal, Seeks Scenic Area Designation
description: After years of complaining about President Bill Clinton's use of a law to set aside scenic areas in the West as national monuments, Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah said last night that he would ask President Bush to use the same law to create a protected area among the red rock canyons and bluffs of the San Rafael Swell in the central part of his state.

title: School Worker Is Not Guilty In Release of Pedophile's Files
description: A former state mental health worker who warned a suburban neighborhood that a mildly retarded man classified as a pedophile was moving in was acquitted today of charges that he illegally removed the man's confidential medical records.

title: Shrinking Our Presence in Saudi Arabia
description: In the debate about the United States-Saudi relationship, there are growing indications in Congress and reportedly among Saudi officials that a reduction of American military forces in Saudi Arabia is politically inevitable. A drastic change like a complete withdrawal of forces is unlikely. But a force reduction is prudent as both nations assess their relations.

title: Jewish Museum Show Looks Nazis in the Face and Creates a Fuss
description: Two months before it will open, a contemporary art exhibition that uses Nazi imagery and was organized by the Jewish Museum is making some tempers boil. Holocaust survivors and their families have pronounced the show vulgar and repugnant, while Abraham H. Foxman, the national director of the Anti-Defamation League, recently told a reporter that such an exhibition was at least premature while survivors were still alive who might be offended.

title: Cotton Jobs Gone, Black Migrants' Town Limps On
description: The old folks say this used to be quite a place, with small businesses, a post office, a little night life and enough cotton in the fields to give people economic stability and hope for the future.

title: Tax Shortfall Grows Worse In New Jersey
description: In another sign that New Jersey's fiscal situation continues to deteriorate, the state treasurer announced today that tax revenues in January were at least $470 million less than the state had projected when it adopted its budget last summer.

title: Bloomberg Is Increasing City Lobbying In Washington
description: Tonight is not the most convenient of evenings for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to go to Washington, given that tomorrow he is to deliver the first of his annual addresses to the City Council -- arguably his most important speech since taking office. But Mr. Bloomberg's presence at the State of the Union address is just the most visible among many recent moves he has made to establish aggressive lobbying on Capitol Hill to put New York City's needs front and center with the nation's lawmakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, WILLIAM
description: GRAHAM-William. Of Stamford, CT and St. Simons Island, GA, died January 27, 2002 at age 86. Beloved husband for 62 years of Louise Stern Graham. Loving father of Patricia G. Stotler, Margot G. Kaczynski and William L. Graham. Fond father-in-law of John L. Stotler, Stanley J. Kaczynski and Susan H. Graham. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth A. Stotler, Karen J. Kaczynski, Brian J. Kaczynski (Sarah) and Ryan W. Graham. During his lifetime Mr. Graham was one of the founders of Temple Sinai in Stamford, CT and was active in the Literacy Volunteer Program and at the Rehabilitation Center. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice Residence, 1029 E. Main St., Stamford, CT 06902 or to a cancer society of your choice. Service private.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Price War Continues
description: The price war between Intel and Advanced Micro Devices, the two largest makers of chips for personal computers, escalated yesterday as both companies cut prices on some chips. Intel reduced prices as much as 18 percent for some of its desktop Pentium 4 chips. The 1.6 gigahertz Pentium 4 was cut to $133 from $163 for orders of at least 1,000 units. Advanced Micro Devices, which also introduced a 1.3 gigahertz microprocessor for mobile computers yesterday, cut prices on several products. The price of the Athlon XP 1900 dropped to $231 from $269, a decrease of 14 percent; and the Athlon XP 1600, is now priced at $130, which is 19 percent below its previous price. Last year, Advanced Micro hoped that price cuts would help it take 50 percent of the United States retail laptop market, but fell short of that goal. Intel responded to Advanced Micro's aggressive price cutting with deep discounts of its own. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SPENCER MERRIAM
description: BERGER-Spencer Merriam. Age 84, died on January 12, 2002. Business executive, film historian and artist. President and chairman of the board of the former Berger Brothers Company of New Haven, CT. A leading authority on the Barrymores. Important artist of watercolors and pen-and-inks, mental landscape themes, dealing primarily with aspects of Hollywood as well as of the human condition. His collection of films, mainly silent and early sound pictures, is now part of the Spencer M. Berger Collection at the Film Study Center and the Beinecke Library at Yale University and the Cinema Archives at Wesleyan University. Avid fan of Ted Lewis and Leopold Stokowski, amassed large collections of recordings and works, later donated to Yale University. Born May 6, 1917, to Darwin Spencer Berger and Emma Hoyt Merriam Berger in New Haven, CT. Member of the Yale University Class of 1940. He was the brother of the late Elizabeth Berger Stevens and the husband of the late Jane Hoadley Berger. He is survived by two sons, George Spencer Berger of Jamestown, Rhode Island, and Dr. Eric Hoadley Berger of New Haven, CT; and two grandchildren, Timothy Antonio Aiken Berger and Laura Cristina Livingston Berger, both of New Haven. Donations in his memory may be made to the Yale Film Study Center, c/o Michael Kerbel, Yale Film Study Center, 53 Wall St., New Haven, CT 06511, and to Wesleyan University's Cinema Archives, Wesleyan University, 301 Washington Terrace, Middletown, CT 06457.

title: Hotel Discounter's Stock Soars
description: Hotel Reservations Network, which sells discount-price hotel rooms over the Internet, said here today that fourth-quarter profit fell as expenses rose faster than sales.

title: Nascar Products Prove Profitable
description: The Action Performance Companies, which markets motor-sports merchandise for Nascar racers like Dale Earnhardt Jr. and Jeff Gordon, had a quarterly profit as sales of clothes and die-cast products rose 65 percent.

title: Health Risk Stems Players' Use of Painkillers
description: When an N.B.A. trainer recently doled out a weeklong dose of an anti-inflammatory medicine called Vioxx to an ailing player, the player shot him an incredulous glance. ''I'm not taking these anymore, especially after what happened to 'Zo,'' said the player, according to the trainer. ''Give me something else.''

title: Belichick Dodges, Parries and Wins
description: A perfect snapshot of Bill Belichick's personality was revealed today after his team arrived for Super Bowl XXXVI. title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about ''Just Like Beauty'' by Lisa Lerner, misstated the name of the protagonist at one point and of her friend at another. The protagonist is Edie, not Lisa; her friend is Lana, not Lara. The review summarized the plot incompletely; although Edie and Lana drive off into the sunset, they change their minds and return home.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Endorsement For Hewlett Deal
description: The International Data Corporation, a leading technology research group, gave a carefully qualified endorsement yesterday to the contested Hewlett-Packard plan to buy Compaq Computer. In a detailed 41-page assessment sent to its corporate clients, the research firm acknowledged the risks of the deal, but stated, ''I.D.C. believes that H.-P. and Compaq may very well be better off together than apart.'' The strategic rationale for the merger, the report noted, is to move quickly to become a full-service supplier of hardware, software and services to corporate customers, who are steadily moving to Internet-based computing. ''H.P. and Compaq are making their strategic move for the next wave -- and they are making their move right now,'' the report concluded. The merger plan is being challenged by the heirs of the Hewlett-Packard founders, led by Walter B. Hewlett, a Hewlett board member, who asserts that the deal is too risky and costly. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Rights Inspector To Go To Iraq
description: Iraq said it would allow a United Nations human rights investigator to visit for the first time in a decade, according to the United Nations. The organization's human rights commission, which said last year that Iraq repressed and terrorized its citizens, appointed a special investigator in 1991 but Iraq has allowed only one visit, in 1992.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 12 Held In Gun Smuggling
description: The leader of what the authorities described as a Brooklyn gang responsible for smuggling AK-47's and other high-powered weapons has been arrested, Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, left, said yesterday. In arresting Ricardo Johnson, whom the authorities described as the founder and leader of the United Kings, the police seized 23 firearms, including several sawed-off shotguns and 9-millimeter handguns. Eleven others, identified as members of the United Kings and other gangs, were also arrested. All were charged with possession and sale of firearms. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: Students Face School Move In Midst of Crucial Test Week
description: The Board of Education has decided to move hundreds of children at two Lower Manhattan schools in the middle of a critically important fourth-grade test week. But it agreed to delay the move at another school after parents challenged it in court.

title: Linking Anxiety, Depression and Strokes
description: Middle-aged men who suffer from psychological problems like depression and anxiety are much more likely to die of strokes than men who do not, a study reports. But they are no more likely to suffer nonfatal strokes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retail Sales Fall
description: Retail sales in December fell 5.7 percent from December 2000, the ninth consecutive monthly decline and the largest in three years. For all of 2001, retail sales slipped 2.2 percent, the fifth straight annual decline. Rising unemployment and falling wages are hurting consumer spending, which makes up more than half of Japan's $3.8 trillion economy. Separately, the government said that consumer confidence stood at a three-year low in December. Declining retail sales, combined with cuts in corporate capital spending and weak exports, have pushed Japan into its third recession in the last 10 years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Hometown of British Prisoners Known for Tranquil Diversity
description: Two Britons designated by the Foreign Office as detainees of the United States at Guantnamo Bay have been identified as friends from the same English town, one known for its harmonious diversity.

title: Astrid Lindgren, Author of Children's Books, Dies at 94
description: Astrid Lindgren, the Swedish writer whose rollicking, anarchic books about Pippi Longstocking rattled some tradition-bound Swedes when they first appeared almost 60 years ago but came to captivate millions of children around the world, died yesterday at her home in Stockholm. She was 94.

description: President Bush today proposed spending $190 billion over the next decade to overhaul Medicare and provide prescription-drug benefits to the elderly, starting with low-income people. Members of Congress from both parties said that amount was insufficient.

title: Bush, Focusing on Terrorism, Says Secure U.S. Is Top Priority
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  President Bush tonight told Americans that "our war against terror is only beginning," and sent new warnings to terrorists around the world and to three nations  Iran, Iraq and North Korea. Using unusually strong language, he charged that the three "constitute an axis of evil," evoking a word once used to describe the alliance of Germany, Italy and Japan during World War II.

title: Knicks' All-Stars? Not This Season
description: Last season, Latrell Sprewell and Allan Houston were All-Stars. But neither harbors much hope of being anywhere but home for the All-Star Game in Philadelphia on Feb. 10.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Baltimore Renewal
description: Baltimore hopes to take control of up to 5,000 abandoned houses through foreclosure or condemnation to fight urban blight. Sites could be cleared and offered to private companies or nonprofit groups for redevelopment or designated as open space, Mayor Martin O'Malley said. He also called on law firms, banks and other companies to help by providing their services. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: DNA Samples for 9/11 Inquiry
description: Families of victims of the attack on the World Trade Center who submitted toothbrushes, razors, hairbrushes or other items containing DNA material for genetic matching are being asked to call the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner to make sure that enough material was collected for the testing to be completed. Of the 2,870 victims in the Sept. 11 attack, 692 have been identified, 117 of them solely through matching the genetic material in the remains with the items families submitted, said Ellen Borakove, spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office. In some cases, the items did not contain enough genetic material for testing to be completed. All family members who have not submitted material for DNA testing are urged to do so as soon as possible. They are asked to call (212) 447-7884, between 9 a.m. and 9 p.m., seven days a week.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 2 Companies Sue Turkish Concern
description: Motorola Inc. and the Nokia Corporation said yesterday that they had filed a federal lawsuit in an effort to reclaim about $3 billion owed to the companies by the Uzan family, owners of Telsim Mobil, a Turkish telecommunications company. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, states that the Uzan family defrauded the companies in violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. The statute, known as RICO, was intended to pursue organized crime and racketeering in legitimate businesses, including cases involving interstate or foreign commerce. Motorola is seeking more than $2 billion in compensatory damages; Nokia seeks more than $700 million in compensatory damages. The two companies are also seeking to collect punitive damages. Motorola and Nokia lent Telsim money to buy base stations, switching equipment, telephones and other equipment used to develop a wireless network in Turkey and to acquire a license from the Turkish government to create such a network, company officials said.

title: The Old Man Who Loved The Sea, And Papa
