title: Transcript of Will Foster's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, Jan. 15, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Will Foster. Mr. Foster was accused of being a drug dealer and sentenced to 93 years in prison. He is now out on parole, and is a marijuana legalization activist. This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: Toys 'R' Us Plans To Lay Off 1,900 And Close 64 Stores
description: Trying to compete more forcefully against Wal-Mart without battling it on price, Toys ''R'' Us announced yesterday that it would lay off 1,900 people, close 64 stores and move its administrative offices into a single location in New Jersey. The company said it would take a $126 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the costs of severance and other expenses.

title: Experts Dissect Last Layer of Anthrax Toxin
description: Scientists have worked out the exact three-dimensional structure of the edema factor, the last of three components in the deadly toxin produced by the anthrax bacterium. The knowledge should help in understanding how the edema factor works and in devising drugs to block it.

title: An Innovative Way to Borrow Started at Enron
description: What do AT&T and British Airways have in common with Enron? All three companies have borrowed money in the financial markets using credit-sensitive notes. The notes are intended to send a signal that a company is more creditworthy than it appears, yet they could end up actually affecting its credit rating, or, in dire circumstances, even accelerating its demise.

title: NETS SIGN JOHNSON AND MARSHALL
description: For depth and security against injury, the Nets signed the point guard Anthony Johnson and the small forward Donny Marshall to contracts for the rest of the season yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: General Denies War Crimes
description: In a test of the country's ability to try its own war crimes suspects, proceedings resumed against a general accused of killing Serbian civilians in 1991 in the central town of Gospic. The general, Mirko Norac, 34, considered a war hero by many Croats, pleaded not guilty, as did three other defendants. Another said he did not understand the indictment. The United Nations war crimes tribunal at The Hague has considered trying Mr. Norac itself, and has voiced irritation at months of delays in his case. He is charged with ordering the roundup of Serbs in which at least 42 were later killed, including a woman prosecutors say he personally executed. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Finance Unit Acquired
description: The GE Capital Corporation, the finance arm of General Electric, has agreed to buy Kingfisher's financial services unit for 149 million ($210 million) to increase its business in Europe. Proceeds from the sale of the unit, Time Retail Finance, will be used to reduce Kingfisher's 900 million ($1.27 billion) of debt, the company said. The purchase will be made by GE Capital Bank, a unit of GE Capital, which plans to provide financial services to Kingfisher's British retail businesses, B& Q and Comet, GE Capital said. Kingfisher is based in London.

title: Review/Fashion; The Liberated Woman, Through the Prism of Couture

Following entries for fashion designer, art patron, costumer, bon vivant and demigod of Gaulist culture, some mention might be made of his role as a pioneer of feminism's second wave. In the weeks since Jan. 7, when Mr. Saint Laurent announced that his spring 2002 haute couture collection would be his last, he has been depicted as a kind of Ti-Grace Atkinson -- someone who, during the 1960's, heaved a big pitchfork into patriarchy's tummy.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Whistle-Blower Blocked From Running
description: Election officials blocked the candidacy for Parliament of a former presidential bodyguard, Mykola Melnichenko, who has implicated President Leonid D. Kuchma in the disappearance and possible murder of a journalist, Georgy Gongadze. The Socialist Party nominated Mr. Melnichenko for the March 31 election but a Central Election Committee official said that bacause Mr. Melnichenko, who fled Ukraine citing concerns for his safety, has been living outside the country since November 2000 he did not qualify under a statute requiring candidates to have lived in Ukraine ''for at least five years.'' title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: G.E. Considers Acquisition
description: General Electric, which is pursuing acquisitions to revive sales, may bid for Legrand, a French maker of electrical products. Antitrust regulators ordered Schneider Electric to sell Legrand. ''It's a business we know very well and it's a situation that's in flux,'' G.E.'s chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, said in an interview. ''And it's one I would say we are studying.'' Buying Legrand would help Mr. Immelt with his goal of expanding in Europe after the European Union blocked General Electric's $47 billion purchase of Honeywell International in July.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Greenwich: Double-Decker Trains
description: Metro-North Railroad is considering the acquisition of double-decker cars that can each carry 146 people instead of the 110 that the current train cars carry. But first the railroad must figure out how to fit the 16-foot-tall double-deckers into the tunnels and sheds from 97th Street to Grand Central Terminal. Those tunnels and sheds are at least eight inches too low for the double-deckers. The ''bilevel clearance study'' will examine whether pipes, electrical boxes and other obstacles can be relocated to accommodate the double-deckers. Metro-North trains are running close to capacity, and the double-deckers would ease congestion. The study is scheduled to be completed in July. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: How Dolphins Keep Their Cool in the Zone That Counts
description: Scientists have long known that sperm production requires coolness. The mammalian scrotum has two testes that hang below the warm body cavity, lowering temperatures to the point that sperm production is possible, at least for animals like cats and dogs, cows and horses, rats and bats -- and humans. If a man wears overly tight pants or spends too much time in a hot tub, the testes warm up and he may become a candidate for the fertility doctor.

title: Catalyst Appoints A New Chief
description: Gil Bashe has been named president and chief executive at Catalyst Communications in South Plainfield, N.J. As president, Mr. Bashe, 47, succeeds Rod Mehling, 53, who becomes chairman and chief operating officer; the post of chief executive is new.

description: In an effort to silence Saudi and American critics of his kingdom, Crown Prince Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz al-Saud embraced the United States today as a close friend and branded the Sept. 11 attacks a ''deviant'' attempt to destroy the bonds.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Europe: Mobile Phone Users Increase
description: The Vodafone Group and Orange each reported subscriber growth that met analysts' expectations, yet shares in both companies fell. Vodafone said it added 4.2 million customers in the fiscal third quarter, bringing its total subscriber base to 99.9 million and cementing its position as the world's largest wireless operator. In the year to Dec. 31, Orange said it added 8.8 million customers for a total of 39.3 million. Strong growth at Orange contributed to an 18 percent rise in fourth-quarter sales at the parent company, France Tlcom. With the number of people using mobile phones reaching saturation in many European countries, wireless operators are coming under pressure to generate more revenue from existing customers, rather than simply signing up new ones. Orange said the rate of decrease in the average revenue per customer slowed ''significantly'' in 2001. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; On Wall Street, Bonuses Fall, but Giving Increases
description: Every year, investment banks on Wall Street hire from a pool of young graduates from the top business schools in the country. Those hired into the firms' two-year training programs can count on spending long hours in the office, leaving little time for outside activities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERACE, ANNE R.
description: GERACE-Anne R. on January 27, 2002. Former executive secretary to the late Edwin Foster Blair, Esq.; thereafter member of the Dean's Office of NYU Medical School as Assistant Registrar and Coordinator of Alumni Affairs. Beloved sister of Jean G. Vale and Henry Gerace; loving aunt. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday and Wednesday, 4pm-9pm. title: Durable Goods Orders Up 2%; Hint of Revival
description: Orders for durable goods rose in December, the Commerce Department reported today, the second increase in the last three months and a sign that factories are starting to recover from a year-and-a-half-long slump.

title: Near Ground Zero, a Vote to Return to School
description: Parents and teachers at Public School 89, which was evacuated after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, have voted by a wide margin to return to their school on Feb. 28, after five months in temporary quarters.

title: New Council Members Submit an Assortment of New Measures
description: As the City Council finally begins to get down to business this year, a deluge of proposed measures has flooded the agenda for today's meeting of the full body. Dozens of bills and resolutions are up for consideration, many of them submitted by new members who have only recently learned where their offices are.

title: Geographic Gaffe Misguides Anthrax Inquiry
description: The postmarks on the deadly letters laced with anthrax made clear from the start that they came from Trenton. But tracing the origin of the strain of anthrax that killed five people last fall has been a far murkier venture. And it now turns out that scientists and investigators have been on the wrong trail all along.

title: Can You Become Daniel Boulud Just by Boiling Water?
description: IT may be a fantasy to invite a top chef like Thomas Keller or Charlie Trotter to a dinner party at your home, but what about serving their food instead?

title: A Morsel That Makes the Soup
description: HOW many times have you grated a piece of Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese down to the rind, then tossed that hard little piece in the garbage? Too many.

title: The Fox News Channel tops CNN's audience, and casts its eyes toward its advertising rates.
description: FOR the first time in its five-year history, the Fox News Channel has drawn a larger audience than CNN for a full month, and it has also topped it in the major demographic categories.

title: Eugene M. Ezersky; Environmental Educator, 75
description: Eugene M. Ezersky, an expert on outdoor and environmental education who was involved in programs to foster gardening and greenery in New York City, died on Jan. 18 at a hospital in Westchester County. He was 75 and lived in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Honors Program to Be Expanded
description: The new Honors College at the City University of New York is being flooded with applicants. More than 2,400 students have applied for next year, up from about 1,400 last year, CUNY's chancellor, MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN, saidon Monday. The program's students receive free tuition, free laptop computers and free access to cultural events. The program, currently on five campuses -- Baruch, Brooklyn, City, Hunter and Queens Colleges -- will expand to Lehman College and the College of Staten Island in the fall. Karen W. Arenson

description: Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton sat out the State of the Union speech in an undisclosed place, officials said tonight.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's performance as mayor is likely to be measured in large part by his success at leading New York City to a consensus on what should happen with the World Trade Center site, and the pace and quality of the subsequent rebuilding.

title: Rams' Offensive Line Snaps to It at Snap of the Ball
description: Kurt Warner boarded the Rams' charter flight Monday and informed the offensive linemen that he intended to join them for dinner here. Pick a restaurant, he said, get anything you want. The All-Pro quarterback intended to pick up the tab.

title: The Festival At Lincoln Center Goes Global
description: The character of this year's Lincoln Center Festival, whose program was announced yesterday, will be set by diverse performing groups from around the world, with companies from Iran, China, Russia, Egypt, Japan and elsewhere.

description: New York University and the United Auto Workers announced yesterday that they had reached the first union agreement between a private university and its graduate teaching and research assistants.

description: The young Khoikhoi woman who boarded a ship for England from South Africa in 1810 apparently was convinced that she would make a fortune there.

description: Israeli troops backed by tanks raided this Palestinian-controlled village near Bethlehem early today and arrested a suspected militant, leaving four people wounded in exchanges of gunfire and a trail of crushed and overturned cars.

title: Evoking a Festival's Past With a View From the Kitchen
description: Liz Lerman's ''Hallelujah: In Praise of Fertile Fields,'' performed on Saturday night at the Danspace Project, is now the plain-spoken poetic evocation of the history and culture of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival that it was intended to be two years ago at its premiere.

title: Travels With Avocados
description: IT helps to be a history buff as well as a lover of food to appreciate ''The Origins of Fruit and Vegetables'' by Jonathan Roberts (Universe, $22.50). While any reader could enjoy the book's gorgeous color illustrations from paintings, botanical prints, photographs and ancient mosaics, Mr. Roberts's talent in explaining foods' beginnings make this elegant 228-page volume a real page turner.

title: Down the Hatch
description: AT the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo last Thursday, a Belgian artist named Wim Delvoye walked up five steps to reach a steel platform. As television cameras rolled and reporters scribbled notes, he leaned over and picked up a cloth napkin enclosing a knife and fork. Then he lifted a plate of seared monkfish with fines herbes, and, very deliberately, began cutting the food into little bites and feeding it to a room-size machine named Cloaca, from the Latin word for sewer. From time to time he would reach down for a bowl of Belgian frites, dip a stick of crisp brown fried potato in mayonnaise, and throw it into the clear glass bowl that serves as Cloaca's mouth. Cloaca washed down its dinner with a big glass of Duvel, a Belgian beer. In a matter of five minutes, the meal was over and Cloaca settled down to do what it does best: digest.

title: Merck Intends to Spin Off Unit That Manages Drug Plans
description: Merck & Company, faced with a slumping stock price and stalled earnings growth, said yesterday that it would shed a business that generates more than half its sales but just a fraction of its profits.

description: Enron today named Stephen F. Cooper, a specialist in revamping troubled companies, to lead it through the largest bankruptcy in the nation's history.

description: Patriots quarterback Tom Brady said today that even though his sprained left ankle is still swollen and sore, he is preparing this week as if he will start in the Super Bowl.

title: Andrew W. Cooper, 74, Pioneering Journalist
description: Andrew W. Cooper, a civil rights advocate and publisher of The City Sun newspaper, a defunct weekly once on the must-read list of many black New Yorkers, died in Brooklyn on Monday. He was 74 years old.

title: Corrections

Carl McCall's criticism of the state's use of managed care plans that do not offer family planning misstated the affiliation of one plan, Community Premier Plus. It is sponsored by three nonsectarian institutions -- New York-Presbyterian Hospital, North General Hospital and the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. It is not affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Closed-Door Legislating
description: House Republicans and Democrats are planning a private joint caucus to deal with the state budget, the first such meeting in memory to include the whole house. Caucuses, even joint ones, are not subject to the state's open-meetings act. Legislators will discuss proposals by Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat, to shore up a $1 billion revenue shortfall projected over the next three years, including an unpopular income tax. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNER, DOROTHY BOOTH
description: BENNER-Dorothy Booth. Left this world on January 26, 2002 from complications following hip surgery at the age of 84. She was the beloved wife, for 60 years, to G. Willard Benner who survives her. She also leaves her nephew Robert W. Booth, Jr. and grand niece and nephew, Kimberly Booth and Robert W. Booth, III, to whom she was a treasured and much loved surrogate grandmother. Dorothy attended Ohio State University, received a B.A. from Barnard College and earned a Master's degree at New York University. She went on to distinguished herself in her career as the Advertising Director of DePinna Department Store. After living abroad and traveling extensively, she and her husband came back to their first love, Manhattan. Her intelligence, generosity, loving personality, impeccable fashion sense and superior hors d'oeuvres for which she was well known, will be forever missed. We love you Aunt Dot; you are the ''cat's meow''.

title: Brief Health-Care Remarks Draw Praise and Skepticism
description: Mr. Bush sought to ease growing concerns about the cost and availability of health care, particularly prescription drugs.

title: In Brooklyn, an Island for French-Caribbean Cuisine
description: YOU have to admire the vision of the owners of La Brunette in Williamsburg. They opened this small, ambitious French-Caribbean restaurant a few months ago on a corner practically underneath the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. A dim light from the restaurant's storefront is the sole sign of life, while outside a back door on Metropolitan Avenue, a menu displayed under lighted glass glows like an altar to high hopes. Nobody is out there to be lured in.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Plant Passes Emissions Test
description: A cement-additive plant that local groups say pollutes their neighborhood passed its first annual emissions test since opening in June, the state said yesterday. The plant passed what is known as a stack test, which was administered in October and certified last week, said Amy Collings, a spokeswoman for the Department of Environmental Protection. The department was the defendant in a lawsuit filed by black and Hispanic groups charging the department with ''environmental racism'' for allowing operation of the plant, owned by St. Lawrence Cement Group. A federal appeals panel dismissed the suit on Jan. 16. The groups have not yet decided whether to appeal. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Corrections

It was La Repubblica, not Corriere della Sera.

It also has a network of American offices to help resettle refugees here. Dr. Rupp, 59, will succeed REYNOLD LEVY. Karen W. Arenson

description: CHRISTMAS-Walter. Died January 26, 2002, at age 83. Beloved husband of June. Devoted father of Vincent, Rachel, and Gordon. Caring father-in-law of Karlton and Lisa. Adored grandfather of Shamsa, Romare, Miles, and Khari. After many years in corporate and nonprofit public relations, he retired to become a travel writer and public and independent school volunteer. His family, who will always cherish him, will hold a memorial service. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Jackie Robinson Foundation, for the Spike Lee Youth Motivation Award, 3 West 35th Street, New York, NY 10001.

title: Constantine Learns on the Fly As the Devils Halt the Islanders
description: A sellout crowd at Nassau Coliseum began to boo the Islanders early, and the underachieving Oleg Kvasha in particular, because they had to find something to do. The Devils were wringing the entertainment value out of tonight's game.

title: Devils Try to Regroup
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Jan. 29  Kevin Constantine says he likes to thinks of himself as a hockey teacher. First the Devils' new coach must become a student and cram for a final exam.

title: Jets' Ramos to Retire
description: Frank Ramos, the Jets' long-time head of public relations and the last link to their Super Bowl III championship team, announced yesterday that he would take early retirement, effective March 1. Ramos spent 39 years with the Jets.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Tribal School Closing
description: The Native American Preparatory School will close for at least one academic year. The school, which enrolls 60 students from more than 30 tribes, has been struggling financially and is selling its main campus, 1,600 acres in Rowe. The school, which is seven years old, will close for the 2002-2003 academic year, but school officials said they hoped to reopen elsewhere. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Resignation In Food Scandal
description: The president of the Snow Brand Food Company, Shozo Yoshida, resigned after it was reported that his company had repackaged almost 30 tons of American and Australian beef as Japanese beef to claim government compensation under a state-run beef buyback program. After two cases of mad cow disease were identified in Japan last fall, beef sales slumped and the government bought domestic beef stocks. Mr. Yoshida said that Snow Brand would stop selling beef, a major blow to a company that barely recovered from a tainted-milk problem that sickened 13,000 people in 2000. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Battering Begins. The Police Come. It All Starts Again.
description: The word that comes to mind most often while you're watching Frederick Wiseman's unambiguous new documentary, ''Domestic Violence,'' is weariness. The fatigue starts with the police officers, who come off best with their measured responses in the tense aftermath of household warfare. You can only imagine how many of these incidents they've rolled into, and their ability to move through them and ask the relevant questions without being sickened by another depressing tableau is testament to their patience in their work.

title: Tyson Denied License in Nevada
description: Mike Tyson, boxing's most fearsome and dangerous attraction, was denied a license today to fight Lennox Lewis for his heavyweight titles at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas on April 6.

title: A Vision of an America Devoted to Volunteer Duties
description: With words that recalled a famous passage in John F. Kennedy's Inaugural Address, the president called on Americans to commit thousands of hours over their lifetimes to the service of the country.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 2 Tyco Officials Sold Stock By Returning It To Company
description: Two senior executives of Tyco International Ltd. quietly disposed of more than $100 million in Tyco stock during the company's last fiscal year, despite public comments that they rarely if ever sold Tyco shares.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Vote Observers Allowed
description: Government officials said they would allow election observers and journalists from foreign countries -- excluding Britain, Zimbabwe's former colonial ruler -- to observe the presidential election scheduled for March. The European Union has threatened to impose sanctions if the government does not keep its promise. Under pressure from South Africa and Western countries to abandon efforts to silence critics and intimidate the opposition, Zimbabwe has delayed passage of a bill that would require journalists to be officially licensed. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Before the Towers Fell, Fire Dept. Fought Chaos
description: In scores of emotionally searing interviews conducted by the Fire Department for an internal inquiry, the agency's most senior commanders have provided new and, in some cases, alarming revelations about the events of Sept. 11.

title: International Ideas for Domestic Wizardry
description: At Maison et Objet, the home design show held on the outskirts of Paris this month, quirky new gadgets for kitchen and tabletop ranged from the truly practical to the whimsical. The huge international fair showcases the ideas of both hopeful young designers and established manufacturers. Not all the products have made it across the ocean yet, but many are on their way. Others can be ordered directly and shipped.

title: Itinerant Wizard of Sonoma Pinot Noir
description: OVER the years, I've derived a lot of pleasure from wines made by Merry Edwards. I've written about a couple of those wines. I've even quoted her occasionally on now-forgotten wine-country crises. But other than on the phone, I'd never met her. Until now.

title: A Professor Who Never Fought That Old Ennui
description: When the trustees of the City University of New York added MARSHALL BERMAN, a professor of political science at City College, to its pantheon of distinguished professors on Monday, he offered them an observation about his more than 30 years at the university. ''Some of my friends who came out of grad school 30 years ago with me, who taught, got jobs and entrenched themselves in much classier universities than ours, came to feel that they were very bored and empty and couldn't think what they were doing there,'' Dr. Berman said. ''And that's one thing that I have never felt. I have often felt tired at City University, but I have never felt bored.'' Karen W. Arenson

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Loss For Chemical Maker
description: Shares of Rhodia, France's largest specialty chemical maker, fell 2.7 percent after the company announced a fourth-quarter loss and said that it would not meet its 2003 profit targets. The company posted a net loss of 213 million euros ($184 million) for 2001, in contrast to a net profit of 216 million euros a year earlier. Rhodia attributed the decline in profit to the rising cost of raw materials, which exceeded expectations by 1 billion euros. The chief executive, Jean-Pierre Tirouflet, said in a news conference that Rhodia would continue cost-cutting measures like reducing the staff by 6 percent and closing 19 sites, Bloomberg News reported. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: President's Day in Santa Fe
description: For Presidents' Day weekend Feb. 14 to 17, the Inn on the Alameda in Santa Fe will take 15 percent off room prices for any guest with the same last name as a United States president or an address (street or community) with such a name. Jefferson Davis does not count, but if your last name is Grant or Roosevelt or the like, you're in. Guests must show a valid driver's license at check-in as proof. Residents of Lincoln, Neb., and similarly lucky people will pay as little as $159 with the discount. The inn's 69 rooms are done in classic Southwestern style, and daily breakfast is included. Information: (800) 289-2122.

title: G.O.P. Senators Divide Over Disclosing Information on Enron-White House Contacts
description: With the White House preparing for a showdown over its refusal to tell Congress about contacts between Enron and the administration's energy task force, House Republican leaders backed the White House today. Several Republican senators, however, varied from the party line.

It also has a network of American offices to help resettle refugees here. Dr. Rupp, 59, will succeed REYNOLD LEVY.

title: A Plan Unfolds for a $75 Million Morgan Makeover

The project is so ambitious it would require the Morgan to close for two years.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Financier Insolvent
description: Medison, once a highly profitable venture capital firm specializing in ultrasonic equipment, became insolvent under South Korean law after defaulting on a $3.4 million loan payment. A spokesman for Chohung Bank said the company had failed for two days to come up with the funds, meaning that it will have to apply for court receivership. The company piled up debt of more than $200 million before South Korean venture firms began to suffer in the economic downturn last year. The debts were attributed to hasty expansion into noncore fields, beginning in 1998. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Commercial Real Estate; Airport Hotels Multiply. Yes, Airport.
description: Opening a new hotel after the terrorist attacks sent occupancies and room rates plunging would seem to be a case of bad timing. That timing seems especially bad in the case of a new airport hotel, when airlines are still struggling to fill empty seats and many Americans remain reluctant to fly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NERKEN, JEAN
description: NERKEN-Jean. The Board, Faculty and Staff of The Cooper Union and the Albert Nerken School of Engineering note with sorrow the passing of Jean Nerken. With her late husband Albert, a trustee and major benefactor, Jean Nerken was a great friend of the college and a generous and loyal supporter. We are grateful for their friendship and we extend our condolences to her daughters Ruth and Sara and her entire family. Robert A. Bernhard, Chairman Dr. George Campbell Jr., Pres. Dr. Eleanor Baum, Dean The Albert Nerken School of Engineering

title: Fuzzy Rules Of Accounting And Enron

title: Andeans Find Wreck of Jet; All 92 On Board Are Dead
description: Soldiers and villagers climbing a fog-covered volcano in southern Colombia today found the wreckage of an Ecuadorean airliner that crashed on Monday with 92 people aboard, all of whom were killed, Colombian military officials and the airline said.

title: Elizabeth M. Riley, 94, Editor of Children's Books
description: Elizabeth Mildred Riley, a prominent children's book editor, died Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: MERGER PLAN OF CRUISE LINES IS REFERRED TO REGULATORS
description: P&O Princess Cruises P.L.C.'s planned $7.4 billion merger with Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., which would create the world's biggest cruise operator, was referred to British regulators by a government administrator. The trade and industry secretary, Patricia Hewitt, sent the proposal to the Competition Commission on the advice of the director general of fair trading, the Trade and Industry Department said. The Competition Commission is due to give its report on the combination by May 20. P&O Princess has rejected a $6.4 billion takeover bid by the world's biggest cruise line, the Carnival Corporation, citing concern about regulatory approval.
