Great-grandfather of Rachel and Samantha. Services on Thursday, 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Gerstner To Step Down As I.B.M. Chief In March
description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., an outsider who guided a remarkable turnaround at I.B.M. and transformed its once-hidebound culture, announced today that he would step down as the chief executive on March 1.

title: Giants Hire McCarver
description: Tim McCarver, who was not hired by the YES Network to continue broadcasting Yankee games, has agreed to call 25 San Francisco Giants games for the Fox television affiliate. He will work with the former pitcher Mike Krukow.

title: Smith Makes Most of Second Chance
description: As her grandson Antowain stroked her hand in her last days of kidney failure, Clara Smith told him to go to college, to get out of Millbrook, Ala., and try for something more. Nobody could have imagined then that Antowain Smith, who had played only one year of high school football, and who had taken time off from school after graduation to care for his grandparents, would turn his bedside promise into a circuitous trip to the Super Bowl as a 1,000-yard rusher for the New England Patriots.

title: Viacom's Board Tells Redstone And Karmazin to End Feud
description: Directors of Viacom Inc. ( news/quote ) told Sumner M. Redstone, the company's chairman and chief executive, and Mel Karmazin, the company's president and chief operating officer, to end a feud that has emerged into public view, people associated with the company's board said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, MARIA JANICE (NEE TOIA)
description: JOHNSON-Maria Janice (nee Toia). Of New York City, on Monday, January 28, 2002. Born February 1, 1922. Beloved wife of the late Allan R. Johnson. Loving sister of the late Joseph Toia. Cherished aunt of Mark, Joseph and Steven Toia, and Laura Toia-Guardino. Adoring great aunt of Joseph, Nicholas and Lindsay Toia. Maria studied fashion illustration and design in school. Her inspiration to the world of talent came during those years when, in her spare time, she sang with her father's dance band. She later attended Marymount College. She began her distinguished career in 1948 at Young & Rubicam Advertising Agency in the Public Relations department, and worked there for ten years, becoming Assistant Casting Director. From there, she headed up Casting at the Harry Conover Model Agency before joining Cunningham & Walsh, Inc. as Casting Director and Fashion Coordinator. Her life also included a successful career as a professional entertainer, performing as a featured singer on radio, TV, benefits, distinguished hotels, supper clubs and on cruise ships in the U.S., Europe, Canada and the Caribbean. Her time as an Elite Tour Director thorughout Europe, and later as Marketing Manager for Hotel Okura contributed to her numerous visits and familiarity with over thirty countries. After retiring, she continued singing for many years at ''Jazz at Noon'' performances in Manhattan, for fun. She was a long-time member of the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. Family will receive friends Thursday, 3-5 and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral Mass Friday, 11AM at Saint John Evangelist, 348 East 55th St, N.Y. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINGER, LEAH
description: LEVINGER-Leah. All of us at Bank Street College of Education and its community mourn the passing of Leah Levinger, longtime friend and colleague, who died on January 22nd. Leah touched so many lives in so many important ways. In 1997, Bank Street College awarded Leah an honorary doctorate. Throughout her long career, as a college proffessor and a clinical child psychologist, Leah exemplified a moral and intellectual commitment to improve the lives of children. Her contributions to Bank Street and society at large will be felt by all of us for many years to come. A memorial service is being planned. Dr. Augusta Souza Kappner, President, Bank Street College of Education Elizabeth S. Pforzheimer, Chair, Board of Trustees, Bank Street College

title: Potluck Tips: A Note to the Host
description: HERE are some ways to make sure a potluck lives up to its promise: a relaxed evening with good friends and good food.

title: Mink? In a Shirtsleeves Winter?; Just as Fur Was Getting Hot, Busy Season Turned Balmy
description: In a little more than a year, Bobbi Rudd, the owner of a real estate company in Manhattan, has bought herself four fur coats.

title: Bronx Democratic Chief Quits, But Still Plans Political Role
description: Roberto Ramirez, who has been chairman of the Bronx Democratic Party for the last seven years, announced yesterday that he would step down from that position effective Sunday. Mr. Ramirez, who is 51, said that he planned to start a political consulting firm, practice law and look for opportunities to teach at the college level.

title: Japan in the Village, Ready to Surprise
description: FOR generations, Greenwich Village produced a reliable supply of two kinds of restaurant, each of them cheap. Diners who went to mingle with the bohemians could count on dimly lighted family-run Italian restaurants for spaghetti and red sauce, and on crazy places like the Pirate's Den, a mainstay of the 1920's and 1930's, where the waiters wore eye patches and the basement contained fake buried treasure.

title: Musicians, Like Actors, Can Master the Method
description: In 20th-century music there's a topic of which general audiences dare not speak the name, less for reasons of prudery than fear on the one hand and nomenclature on the other. It can be called 12-note composition, or subsumed under the larger heading of Serialism, or designated, as this year's Focus Festival at Juilliard does, the 12-Tone Method (a term subsequently shortened to a Strasbergian ''method'' in Joel Sachs's program introduction).

title: A Jumpy, Anti-Immigrant Europe Is Creeping Rightward
description: From Spain to Scandinavia, European politics is drifting to the right. As the economy slows, political parties stressing law and order and stricter controls on immigration are gaining ground and mainstream conservative politicians are becoming more popular.

title: Potluck Follies: 12 Cooks, One Iron Will
description: AFTER decades of practice I have finally come to terms with potluck dinners. The path has been strewn with anxious moments and hilarious encounters. (Well, maybe not so hilarious when they were happening: What do you do when the person you asked to bring the bread shows up with a loaf called Wonder and a pound of margarine? Or when the main course ends up decorating the back seat of the car?)

title: No Respite in the Enron Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: Solo on the Mekong, Mile by Mile, Source to Delta
description: THE RIVER'S TALE

title: Number of Aspiring Teachers Rises
description: Applications for the New York City Teaching Fellows program are up sharply compared with last winter, a change due partly to the economic downturn, Board of Education officials say. The program, which recruits professionals with no teaching experience to work in low-performing schools, has received 4,411 applications for September, more than four times the number at this time last year. Some applicants have lost jobs in the corporate world; others say they were inspired to find more meaningful work after Sept. 11. The application deadline is March 1. Abby Goodnough

title: Corvis to Acquire Dorsal
description: The Corvis Corporation, a maker of fiber optic equipment, has agreed to buy Dorsal Networks for $90.4 million in stock to expand in the market for equipment used in underwater cables.

title: More Layoffs At Fallon Worldwide
description: Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, said yesterday that it had laid off 20 workers, or 30 percent, of the employees in its New York office, including all but one creative staff member.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ELCOR CORP., Dallas, a maker of roofing shingles and coatings for locomotive engine parts, said it would lay off about 80 employees when its Cybershield unit shuts a Georgia plant and moves production to its facility in Lufkin, Texas. Some workers will be allowed to move to the plant in Texas.

title: Surer Voice, Bigger Vision
description: The changes in George W. Bush as a leader over the last four months have been noticed across the nation and around the world, but tonight's State of the Union address showed how significantly his own conception of the presidency has evolved.

title: Worries of More Enrons to Come Give Stock Prices a Pounding
description: Concerns about the troubling practices that led to the failure of Enron slammed into the stock market yesterday.

title: A Gerstner Loyalist Cut From Quite Different Style
description: The resignation of Louis V. Gerstner Jr., a man with a large presence, as chief executive of I.B.M. paves the way for the ascension of Samuel J. Palmisano, one of Mr. Gerstner's most loyal executives yet someone expected to display a markedly different leadership style.

title: Undrafted Players Took Different Paths
description: Many players were ushered to Super Bowl XXXVI by headlines or highlights. Others got here by different routes. For the Rams' kickoff returner, Yo Murphy, a long and winding road took him to Canada to Scotland to Tampa Bay to Minnesota and to Las Vegas before he got to St. Louis. For the New England Patriots' long snapper, Lonie Paxton, the road was shorter, but the view was upside down.

title: In a Surprise, Report Says U.S. Economy Grew in Fourth Quarter
description: Fueled by government spending and a rise in automobile sales, the nation's economy experienced some surprising though modest growth in the fourth quarter of 2001, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Ritual Moment of Glory as Battle-Tested Bush Returns to a Once-Chilling Setting
description: In a booming moment of shouted welcome and applause, months of pent-up national anguish seemed to find a release point tonight as the House doorkeeper formally told Congress that the leader of a severely tested nation had arrived to be heard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDES, ROBERT N.
description: LANDES-Robert N. January 25, 2002. Of New York City and Naples, FL. Beloved husband of Phyllis Markman Landes. Loving father of Jeffrey Mark Landes, Kathy Braddock and Lucy Harrop. Dear father-in-law of Mark D. Harrop and Andrea C. Landes. Cherished grandfather of Philip Wildman Braddock. Charles Gibson Braddock and Sophie Eva Landes. Devoted brother of William Landes. Services at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. at 65th St., Wednesday, January 30th, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56th St., New York, NY 10019.

title: Mayor Says: Come on Down
description: Saying that New Orleans would be the safest place in America this weekend, Mayor Marc Morial urged visitors to come to the city for the Super Bowl and not worry about security. At a news conference yesterday attended by law enforcement officials representing the city, the state of Louisiana, the National Guard, the Secret Service and the F.B.I., Mayor Morial called the security effort ''unprecedented,'' for a Super Bowl.

title: At Cocktail Time, Snacks in Stacks
description: TINY knee-high lounge tables have enough space for drinks and maybe a dish of mixed nuts. But these days, when as much eating as drinking goes on before dinner, or even instead of it, there has to be room for food. The answer is multitiered stands, once typically used for afternoon tea and laden with crustless sandwiches and pastries, but now just as likely to hold spring rolls, fried calamari, chicken wings and even soup.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Expects Loss
description: One of Japan's leading chip makers, Fujitsu, lowered its earnings forecasts for the full year as the slump in global demand for semiconductors and telecommunications equipment chews into profits. Fujitsu now expects to lose a net 380 billion yen ($2.8 billion) in the fiscal year ending March 31, 23 percent more than it planned last October. The company, which will also lose money on an operating basis for the first time ever, is considering whether to eliminate 1,000 jobs on top of the 21,000 layoffs already planned, and will spend 400 billion yen ($3 billion) to cover restructuring costs. A rival chip maker, Toshiba, also lowered its fiscal year earnings outlook. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: The Drive to Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Awards for Helping Improve Education
description: The recipients of the 2001 Harold W. McGraw Jr. Prize in Education were honored last night at the New York City Public Library. The prize, established in 1988 to mark the 100th anniversary of McGraw-Hill and named for its chairman emeritus, honors commitment to the improvement of education. The recipients were DR. CARL A. COHN, the superintendent of the Long Beach Unified School District; DR. FREEMAN A. HRABOWSKI III, the president of the University of Maryland Baltimore County; and MARY CATHERINE SWANSON, the founder and executive director of AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination). Peter Valdina

title: No Respite in the Enron Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: Did NBC Let Lay's Wife Get Around Hard Issues?
description: Lisa Myers, the NBC Capitol Hill correspondent long known as tough-minded, left much of her aggressive edge at the door on Saturday when she did an exclusive interview with the wife of Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executive of Enron.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPSLEY, JOHN WILLARD
description: LAPSLEY-John Willard. Died January 26, 2002, following a prolonged illness. He is survived by his wife, Hope Whitney Lapsley; a daughter, Adelaide Mulry of Glen Cove, NY; two sons, Howard of Needham, MA, and Robert of Seattle, WA, and three sisters, Marion Schwarz of New York, NY, Nina Alexander of Bozeman, MT, and Katherine Beug of Kinsale, Ireland. He also leaves three grandsons and four granddaughters. Jack was born in New York City in 1935, the son of Howard Lapsley and Eleanor Hallowell Lapsley. A graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and Harvard College, where he was a member of the Porcellian Club and captain of the Varsity Heavyweight Crew for two years. An avid sailor and lover of the waters of the Maine coast, he also had a fondness for bird shooting in Great Britain. In addition, he gave many friends great pleasure with his extraordinary talent for story telling. Most of his professional career was with J.P. Morgan & Co., where he retired as senior officer in 1996. A memorial service will be held Thursday, January 31, at 11AM, at The Church of The Advent in Westbury, L.I. Contributions may be made in lieu of flowers to: Plastic Surgery Development Fund at the New York Presbyterian Hospital, c/o Dr. Lloyd Hoffman, 525 East 68th St., Box 115, New York, NY 10021.

title: Lindros to Miss Isles and All-Stars
description: As forward Eric Lindros remained in his Manhattan apartment today to rest the sprained medial collateral ligament in his right knee, the Rangers said he would miss Wednesday night's game against the Islanders at Madison Square Garden and Saturday's N.H.L. All-Star Game in Los Angeles.

title: Warner Keeps Faith From Dividing Rams
description: Kurt Warner was asked a simple, but potentially touchy, question yesterday. Why does it seem that the subject of religion has left the St. Louis Rams relatively unscathed, even though it has often divided countries, families and many an N.F.L. locker room?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Suit Challenges Gambling Expansion
description: A lawsuit was filed yesterday against Gov. George E. Pataki and other state officials, claiming that recent legislation allowing for a major expansion of gambling in the state was unconstitutional. The suit, filed on behalf of a state senator, an assemblyman and several community organizations, charges that the gambling law illegally favors private parties. In October, the governor and the Legislature acted to create the biggest expansion of legalized gambling in the state's history by, among other things, allowing the construction of six new casinos. A spokesman for the governor said Mr. Pataki was confident the legislation would overcome ''every legal challenge.'' Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Once Again That Hulking Creature Remains Nameless
description: Frankenstein is one of the loonier treasures of our pop culture mythology. The serious intent of Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley's Gothic original has after all been lovingly twisted and stretched for the purposes of movies, cartoons, television sitcoms (remember Herman Munster?) and Halloween costumes. For one thing it always seems to bear repeating that Frankenstein was the family name of the scientist (his first name was Victor) who built the monster out of parts from a variety of corpses; the monster himself never had a name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIZERIK, JOEL
description: MIZERIK-Joel, tragically on January 22, 2002. Joel was a self-employed decorator who lived in Manhattan and later in Yonkers. Survivors include his father, Frank; his sister and her husband, Gwen and Leo Penzine; his brother, Frank Jr.; nieces and nephews, Christina and Maurizio Nicolelli, Lea Penzine, Frank and Ocean Mizerik III, Lori and Joe McHale; great-niece and nephew, Alexis and Matthew Nicolelli. Memorial Mass Saturday, February 2, 2002, 10 AM, Church of the Sacred Heart, Broadway and Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to a charity of your choice.

title: 4 Movie Studios to Issue Films in a High-End Video Format
description: Four movie companies are to announce today that they plan to release films like ''Die Hard,'' ''Independence Day'' and ''Terminator'' on high-definition videocassette to be used with a player from JVC, the Japanese electronics manufacturer. The new JVC format, called D-Theater, is designed exclusively for use with high-definition television sets.

title: Neighbors of Economic Forum Prepare for the Worst
description: The Gap is dusting off its policy manual for store managers, with guidance for handling mayhem at the door. Starbucks is working with the police so cappuccinos can be dispensed and consumed in safety. Citicorp has called in Labrador retrievers.

title: McGraw-Hill Reports Loss for 4th Quarter
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies, the publisher of Business Week magazine and the owner of the Standard & Poor's financial rating service, said yesterday that it had a fourth-quarter loss because of expenses for cutting jobs and revamping some units.

title: Michael P. Hammond Is Dead; New Arts Chairman Was 69
description: Michael P. Hammond, a composer and music expert who was confirmed as the new chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts last month, died yesterday at his temporary residence in Washington. He was 69.

title: Uneasy Mix Of Contrasts At Airports Of Moscow
description: Even for the frequent visitor to Russia, a common reaction upon arriving in Russia's main international airport, Sheremetyevo, is an overwhelming desire to get right back on the plane.

title: IDT Says It May Want to Buy Some Assets of Global Crossing
description: The IDT Corporation, the long-distance and prepaid-calling-card company, said yesterday that it was interested in buying assets from Global Crossing, the fiber optic company that filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, ARNOLD Z., MD.
description: PFEFFER-Arnold Z., MD. On Jan. 27, 2002, at age 86. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Loving father of Margaret and Zachary. Cherished brother-in-law, uncle and great uncle. Services today 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Neuro-Psychoanalysis Foundation, 39 East 74th Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: Metro Briefing | Brooklyn: Guard Charged With Assault
description: Federal prosecutors charged a prison guard yesterday with forcing a 23-year-old female inmate to have sexual relations at the federal Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn. The guard, Randy Denjen, 38, faces charges that could bring life imprisonment, if he is convicted. He is a 300-pound, 6-foot-tall lieutenant who, according to prosecutors, entered the inmate's cell after midnight on Nov. 25, 2001. The prosecutors said he left and returned several times, making increasing demands on the woman. Another guard witnessed Mr. Denjen in the cell, prosecutors said, and there was DNA evidence implicating Mr. Denjen. His lawyer, Joseph Gentile, said the lieutenant denied the charges. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: A Blue Burka for Justice
description: I had to call Attorney General John Ashcroft recently to ask if he had instructed his advance team to remove naked lady statues and calico cats from his vicinity because they were wicked.

title: No Respite in the Enron Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeb Bush's Daughter Is Arrested On Charge of Faking Prescription
description: Gov. Jeb Bush's daughter was arrested early this morning and charged with prescription fraud after she illegally tried to obtain the antianxiety drug Xanax from a Walgreens pharmacy in Tallahassee, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the appointment of Richard H. Hersh as president of Trinity College in Hartford listed a university erroneously among his past employers. He has not worked at Clark University.

title: Security Buildup and Tax Cuts Win Protection From the Deficit
description: Nearly a year after traveling to Capitol Hill with a plan to carve up a huge budget surplus, President Bush made clear to Congress and the nation tonight that the abrupt return of deficits would not constrain his efforts to revive the economy through tax cuts while also bolstering national security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RILEY, ELIZABETH MILDRED
description: RILEY-Elizabeth Mildred. Died January 27, 2002, at her home in New York City at the age of 94. She is survived by her nephew Frederick G. Riley and great niece Michele Riley Allen. A service will be held Wednesday, February 6, 10AM at the Church of Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th St, NYC 10016, the Textile Conservation Department of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Ave and 82nd St, NYC 10018, or the Church of Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street, NYC 10128.

title: Recipe: Macaroni and Cheese
description: Time: 45 minutes 2 cups diced onion

title: Songwriter, Citing First Amendment, Sues F.C.C. Over Radio Sanctions
description: In an unusual counteroffensive, a New York poet and performance artist filed suit yesterday against the Federal Communications Commission, charging that it violated her First Amendment rights when it fined a radio station for playing a spoken-word song by her with vivid sexual imagery.

title: Democrats' Response: Trying to Put Aside Partisanship
description: Following is the Democratic response, given by Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, to President Bush's State of the Union address, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Willingboro: Damaged Plant Reopening
description: A plant where one worker died and four others were injured in an explosion on Friday is reopening for business, company officials said yesterday. The company, Hi-Temp Specialty Metals Inc., a recycler of specialty metals, has also been directed by the town to tear down part of its damaged plant. Emergency response officials have said it may take months to determine the cause of the incident, in which a vat of acid being used to clean metal exploded. Two workers are still hospitalized. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOY, THOMAS G.
description: JOY-Thomas G. A Miami and New York resident died January 27, 2002. He retired from International Flavors and Fragrance as Senior Vice-President. Past member of the Regional Whist Club of NY. Thomas was on the Board of Adopt-a-Pet. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10:30 AM Thursday at St. Hugh Catholic Church (3460 Royal Road, Coconut Grove, FL). Friends may call from 6-8 PM Wednesday at Stanfill Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donation in Thomas's memory to Adopt-a-Pet (11900 SW 232 Street, Miami, FL. 33170). For more information contact Stanfill Funeral Home, 10545 South Dixie Highway, Miami, FL. 305-667-2518.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Government Planes To Get Internet Service
description: The Boeing Company won a contract valued at as much as $112 million to equip aircraft for the vice president and other officials with two-way Internet, e-mail service and television service. Under the contract with the United States Air Force, Boeing will outfit as many as four C-32A planes with the satellite-based service, known as Connexion by Boeing, the company said. The C-32A is a modified version of the 757-200 passenger airliner. Boeing has said it has mainly been trying to sell Connexion to governments and corporations since the Sept. 11 attacks, which forced airlines to slow spending. In November the three largest United States air carriers, the AMR Corporation's American, the UAL Corporation's United, and Delta Air Lines Inc., pulled out of a venture to install the service in their airliners.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: The Truth Is Bittersweet
description: LET me confess right away: I've never been a big dolcetto fan. In its home base in the Piedmont region of northwest Italy, dolcetto is the third-string red grape, behind nebbiolo and barbera. Nebbiolo makes exalted Barolos and Barbarescos, long-aged, expensive wines for special occasions. Barbera is great for everyday wine, juicy and refreshing, though it makes some serious wines, too. To my mind, they ought to get the most playing time, which leaves precious little room for dolcetto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, ARTHUR DOWNS
description: WARD-Arthur Downs. Of Forest Hills, NY. A retired Navy Captain with a lifetime of service in naval aviation. Active leader with the Naval Aviation Commandery, the Navy League and the Association of Naval Aviation. A long career in the popular music field as manager of singing groups ''The Honey Dreamers'' and ''The Arbors''. President of A&R Recording Inc, NY, NY. Husband of the late Sally Fisher. Loving father of Candy Ward-Ruchala, Karen Ward-Rode, Arthur, Jr. and Russell Fisher Ward. Grandfather of Douglas Paul Bauer, Tracy Marie Rode, Molly Ann Rode, Nicole Ward and Noelle Ward. Reposing Fox Funeral Home Inc., 9807 Ascan Ave, Forest Hills, NY 11375 Wednesday 7-9 and Thursday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Service Fox Funeral Home Inc., Friday, February 1, at 10am. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Naval Aviation Museum Foundation, 1750 Radford Blvd, NAS, Pensacola, FL. 32508

title: Baseball Names A New Agency
description: Major League Baseball in New York named the New York office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group, to handle combined consumer marketing tasks including advertising, research and strategy. The decision on the assignments, with billings estimated at more than $30 million, came without a review.

title: Coke Earnings Soar, Yet Its Stock Price Falls
description: Free from the burden of paying the largest racial discrimination settlement ever and the cost of revamping, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings nearly quadrupled.

title: No Respite in the Enron Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety at Shelters
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Foreign Minister Is Fired After Months of Feuding
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi fired his foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, on Tuesday, ending a tumultuous nine-month alliance in which two of Japan's most popular politicians tried to balance their reformist tactics in the same government.

title: Patriots Trying to Find a Way to Deflate the Rams' Air Attack
description: What strikes fear in most cornerbacks facing the St. Louis Rams receivers is their insistence on the long ball. From nearly any place on the field, quarterback Kurt Warner can unleash a bomb, his receivers gain separation from defenders and smoothly run underneath it and catch it. And keep running.

title: Afghan Leader Honors Terror Victims
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 30  With an outbreak of heavy fighting in Afghanistan adding urgency to his words, Hamid Karzai, the interim leader of Afghanistan, today appealed to the United Nations Security Council to "extend and expand" the international force now limited to policing Kabul.

title: Metro Briefing | Albany: Dairy Is Fined For Overcharging
description: A large dairy has admitted to overcharging New York schools for milk and agreed to pay a $500,000 fine, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer announced yesterday. The dairy, Crowley Foods of Binghamton, one of the state's largest, serves more than 135 school districts. It agreed to pay a fine of 150 percent of overcharges, plus the cost of an audit recently and over the next five years. The average overbilling was more than 6 percent, with the highest above 14 percent. A spokeswoman for Crowley said yesterday that schools had been undercharged as well as overcharged because of bookkeeping errors. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,094 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as the result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Puerto Rico Journal; It's Good Talk, but Bad Language
description: Juan Manuel Garca-Passalacqua is a political analyst, a newspaper columnist and a professor. He graduated from Harvard Law School, has written more than a dozen books on politics and was an adviser on Latin America and the Caribbean in the Carter White House.

title: Special Delivery
description: During his 56 year career as a messenger, Kenneth Marks has delivered a baby elephant to the old Madison Square Garden, a Cartier watch to President Harry S. Truman, Liza Minnelli's (first) wedding dress, a script to Errol Flynn and a jacket straight from Armani to Sylvester Stallone.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Terminating Limits
description: Legislators are expected to repeal the term-limits law by a comfortable margin today, but the votes required to override a promised veto from Gov. Dirk Kempthorne, a Republican, are less certain. Robert L. Geddes, president pro tem of the Republican-dominated Senate, said the number of senators set to vote against term limits was ''somewhere in the 20's.'' Twenty-four votes are needed for an override. If approved, the repeal of term limits, passed by voter initiative in 1994, will be the first enacted by a state legislature. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Gephardt Puts Emphasis on Common Ground on War
description: Faced with a popular president rallying the nation for a long struggle against terrorism, Democrats sought tonight to stand united with President Bush in the war effort and to showcase their own competing domestic agendas without appearing partisan or confrontational.

title: Greeting for a Great Day: 'Great Hat!'
description: To the Editor:

title: FLEETBOSTON REPORTS LOSS AFTER WRITE-OFFS
description: FleetBoston Financial posted a fourth-quarter loss of $507 million yesterday as it wrote off loans in Argentina and investments in technology companies. The loss of 49 cents a share is in contrast to profit of 81 cents a share in the period a year earlier. Argentina's debt default and currency devaluation forced the company to lower earnings by $628 million, the most of any American bank. FleetBoston has not ruled out exiting Argentina, where it has done business since 1917. The bank had about $6.5 billion in consumer and corporate loans in the country at the end of the year. The write-off wipes out six years of FleetBoston's earnings in Argentina, where the currency plunged after the government broke its link to the dollar this month.

title: Diverse Group Opposes EchoStar-DirecTV Deal
description: Satellite TV makes strange lobbying fellows. As Charles W. Ergen, the chief executive of EchoStar Communications tries to win regulatory approval for his company's takeover of DirecTV, the formidable forces arrayed against him include Rupert Murdoch, the Rev. Al Sharpton, powerful members of Congress from both major parties and a Missouri soybean farmer named Charles Kruse.

title: The Power of Divine Right Set to Music for a Devout Tudor Queen
description: Much of the music the Miller Theater presents is new, or at least post-Romantic. But George Steel, the theater's director, also has an antiquarian streak, and although his theater at Columbia University isn't particularly suited to early music, St. Paul's Chapel, only a few steps west on the campus, is perfect for it.

title: Terrorism Jitters Not Enough To Keep Some Students Home
description: For months now, some residents have worried that terrorists were winning a war of nerves here on the North Shore of Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the Pentagon's suspension of the transfer of Taliban and Al Qaeda captives from Afghanistan to its naval base in Guantnamo Bay misidentified the newspaper that carried a commentary by an Italian journalist, Vittorio Zucconi, on their treatment. It was La Repubblica, not Corriere della Sera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, EVE
description: FRANKEL-Eve. On January 28, 2002 of Plainview, Long Island. Beloved wife of Herbert. Devoted mother of Alan Zollner (Rachel). Dear sister of Israel Rubin. Adored grandmother of Rebecca Zollner. Services are today 12:00 noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged as Economy Hints at Recovery
description: Pointing to evidence that the economy's decline may be ending, the Federal Reserve suspended today its yearlong campaign to revive growth by cutting interest rates, leaving its main short-term lending rate unchanged.

title: Harvard Adds Black-Politics Scholar to Faculty
description: Harvard University, which lost a top black scholar last week to Princeton and is facing the possibility of losing other celebrated members of the Afro-American studies department, has hired a pre-eminent scholar of black politics from the University of Chicago.

title: French Government and the Louvre in a War of Words
description: In the complex and secretive world in which politicians and bureaucrats maneuver for power in France, Henri Loyrette, the new director of the Louvre, is discovering the perils of candor. Ten days ago, seemingly unaware that he was entering a danger zone, he echoed his predecessor's lament that budget restrictions required the museum to close one-quarter of its galleries every day because of a shortage of security guards.

title: Pakistani Group Threatens to Kill U.S. Reporter
description: The Wall Street Journal said today that it has received a new message that it believes to be from the militant Islamic group suspected of seizing Daniel Pearl, a correspondent for the newspaper who has been missing in Pakistan since last week.

title: An Intricate Web Lured U.S. Reporter to Meet a Cleric Who Then Vanished
description: Daniel Pearl, the American reporter for The Wall Street Journal who was kidnapped here last Wednesday, was drawn into a well-laid trap by abductors who had been in contact with him for more than two weeks, promising to arrange a secret meeting with a Muslim cleric, police officials said today.

title: Print the Recipes
description: Braising the Legs

title: Knicks Send Iverson to Background
description: They turned out at Madison Square Garden last night expecting to see a small guy making breathtaking plays, weaving his way through defenses and baffling opponents with craftiness and speed. One of the Garden's few legitimate sellout crowds this season saw just that.

title: Broadening Of 'Doctrine'
description: In reviewing the dangers that confront the United States, President Bush tonight laid the basis for an ambitious campaign of diplomatic pressure and potential military action against Iraq and other hostile nations that are seeking to develop weapons of mass destruction.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Wireless Reports Strong Sales
description: AT&T Wireless Services Inc. reported a fourth-quarter loss yesterday, but said that fourth-quarter revenue rose 18.7 percent from a year earlier to $3.528 billion and that it had added more customers than analysts expected. The company said its previously announced exit from the fixed wireless business greatly contributed to a charge in the quarter of $1.3 billion. On Jan. 15, the Netro Corporation, a provider of broadband network equipment, said it would acquire some of those fixed wireless assets. AT&T Wireless said it expected to add two million new subscribers in 2002, which would put its growth rate in the low teens on a percentage basis. In 2001, it had a 19 percent growth rate. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's State of the City Address
description: Following is the text of Mayor Michael Bloomberg's State of the City Address Wednesday as recorded by The New York Times:

title: A New Wrinkle For a Winter Classic
description: THE standard coq au vin, even when it is made with shortcuts, is a hearty dish, what with its bacon, garlic, deep red wine and enrichment of butter. But the one I like best is made with prunes: it's darker, richer, fuller, the kind of recipe one adores and makes repeatedly.

title: Braising the Legs
description: Duck legs have a dark, intensely flavored flesh that holds up well to long, slow cooking methods. Confit (cooking the legs and then preserving them in their own fat) is a very popular option at restaurants, but you can get the same effect (tender meat that falls off the bone) at home with this slow braise technique. (Braising simply means browning meat in a pan, then simmering it in a liquid, and finishing it off in the oven if necessary.)

title: St. John's Forces Overtime, But It Only Delays Defeat
description: A blowout was averted, but when St. John's rallied from a 16-point deficit to send its game with Seton Hall to overtime tonight, the Red Storm only provided itself with an opportunity for greater disappointment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAPKIN, ARNOLD, M.D.
description: DRAPKIN - Arnold, M.D. We mourn the untimely death of a man whose golden hands found breast cancer before the mammogram (the sonogram he ordered confirmed his skills) and whose wonderful capacity to listen and care was unique. He said that when you enter your seventies, you enter a minefield. He was killed off too early. Irreplaceable. Dolores and Bruce Rogers

title: Corrections
description: A report by The Associated Press in the Metro Briefing column on Thursday listed two restaurants erroneously among a group suing Columbia University over a professor's letters falsely claiming that their food had caused illness. The Gotham Bar and Grill and Le Bernardin were among those that received the letters -- written as part of a business-school research experiment -- but they did not join the suit.

title: George W. Bush's Moment
description: President Bush delivered a message last night that told more about the robust state of his presidency than the uncertain State of the Union. Contrary to most predictions of a year or even six months ago, Mr. Bush has soared to heights of popularity enjoyed by few modern presidents. His prosecution of the war against terror has given Americans a new appreciation for his character and confidence in his leadership. That feeling was palpable on Capitol Hill, where the president seemed to get an even warmer welcome than usual. Right now Mr. Bush has an extraordinary amount of political capital, enough to press forward with a far more difficult and dramatic domestic agenda than the one he suggested last night.

title: Frontline Views
description: Interviews with hundreds of firefighters are helping the New York City Fire Department review its procedures and equipment. Excerpts from some of those interviews capture many of the triumphs and problems associated with the rescue operation after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

title: President Bush's State of the Union Address to Congress and the Nation
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's State of the Union address, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHING, BRYANT
description: CUSHING-Bryant. Died suddenly in New York on January 26, 2002, and will be deeply missed by family and friends. He established a successful consulting practice, Cushing & Cushing of CA. with clients such as Boeing, Maersk, and The Commone Commission, which addressed racial unrest in Los Angeles. He was a member of the Univerity Club of N.Y. contributions may be sent to Class of '44 Scholarship Fund, Northfield-Mt. Hermon School, Gift Recording Office, Northfield, MA. 01360.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, ANDREW Y.
description: ROGERS-Andrew Y. Age 90, died on Sunday, January 27, 2002, in Scarborough, ME. He was born in Madison, NJ on January 28, 1911. Educated at Phillips Academy, Yale, and the Yale Law/Harvard Business School program, he was a partner for more than 60 years at the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell. During World War II, he served as a navy intelligence officer in the Aleutian Islands. He served on the Ethics Committee of the Bar Overseers of the City of NY, as chairman of the NYC Parks Association/Council, as an elder of the Brick Presbyterian Church of NYC, as a corporator of the Maine Medical Center, and on the boards of the International Grenfell Association; American Hospital, Istanbul; Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts; the DryDock Savings Bank; and the Wm. Matheus Sullivan Musical Foundation. He was a member of the Prouts Neck Association and the Prouts Neck Country Club, where he served as president. He was also a member of the Union Club in NYC, the Yale Club of NY, the Downtown Association, and the Meadow Brook Club. Active in alumni affairs at both Yale University and its law school, he served as chairman of both the Yale Alumni and the Yale Law School Funds, and was awarded the Yale Medal in 1977. He was married to Polly Porteous from 1937 until her death in 1982, and to Barbara Sizer from 1985 until her death in 1995. He is survived by his identical twin Arthur M. Rogers, M.D., of Charlotte, NC; four children, Polly Larned, of Scarborough, ME; Andrew Y. Rogers, Jr. of Maplewood, NJ; Malcolm P. Rogers, M.D. of Cambridge, MA; and Frances P. Zilkha, of Portland, ME; thirteen grandchildren; and twelve great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at State Street Church, 159 State Street, Portland, ME, Saturday, February 23rd, 11:00 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Boys and Girls Clubs of Greater Portland, 277 Cumberland Avenue, P.O. Box 7830, Portland, ME, 04112.

title: Phone Company Starts Strong In Key Public Offering in India
description: Bharti Tele-Ventures, a leading company in India's booming telecommunications market, has begun the country's first significant initial public offering in two years, and got it off to a good start on Monday by collecting bids for about 60 percent of the shares to be offered.

title: Sports of The Times; After All the Kicking and Screaming, Knight Still Wins
description: WHILE Mike Tyson was lobbying unsuccessfully for his livelihood yesterday in Las Vegas, another of our adult bad boys of sport was living large again, getting the votes from the news media posse that helped de-legitimize and then depose him from his former heavyweight post in Bloomington, Ind.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Drops Plan To Use Customer Data
description: Qwest Communications, the big telecommunications company, said it would shelve a plan to share customer information among its divisions. At the beginning of the year, the company sent its customers a pamphlet describing new ways that it planned to make commercial use of its customers' records and data. Privacy advocates strongly objected, saying they did not want more promotional mail from Qwest affiliates. ''When many of our customers tell us that they're concerned or don't understand what we're doing, it's time to stop the process,'' Joseph P. Nacchio, chief executive of the company, above, said in a statement. Yesterday, Qwest reported a fourth-quarter loss, attributing it to the weak economy, and warned that its 2002 revenue would be at the low end of the range it had previously projected. Shares of Qwest fell 59 cents, to close at $11.76. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRACCHIA, ALFRED ANDREW, M.D.
description: FRACCHIA-Alfred Andrew, M.D. On January 27, 2002, after a long illness. A nationally recognized surgical oncologist with an expertise in breast cancer, he practiced at Memorial Hospital Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for approximately 50 years. A native New Yorker, he completed his undergraduate education at Villanova University in 1937 and received his Doctor of Medicine degree from Georgetown University in 1941. After his internship in Washington D.C., he spent five years with the United States Naval operation in the Pacific theater during WWII. He served his nation as Lieutenant Commander onboard the USS Hornet Aircraft Carrier and Admiral King's flagship, the USS Dauntless. He is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, ''Timmie,'' seven children: John, Paul, Robert, Alfred, Diane, Claudia and Michael; his sister, Vivian Bottari, two nephews, three nieces and nineteen grandchildren. Services on January 30, 3-5 & 7-9 PM at Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Boulevard in Manhasset, New York. Mass of Christian Burial is at St. Mary's R.C. Church at 10 AM on Thursday, January 31, 2002 with interment immediately following at Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury, New York.

title: People
description: * Kevin Labick was named chief executive at KPE, New York, succeeding Kaleil Isaza Tuzman, who continues as chairman. Mr. Labick had been principal at Mobilocity, New York.

title: First for the Fire Department: A Black Female Lieutenant
description: In a department composed overwhelmingly of white men, few things are as rare as a black female New York firefighter. There are six of them, or about 0.06 percent of the force.

title: The Yankees Sign Thurman
description: The Yankees signed right-hander Mike Thurman to a minor league contract yesterday and will give him an opportunity to make the team as a long reliever.

title: Hometown Remembers Man Who Wore Success Quietly
description: When J. Clifford Baxter returned to this quiet village in September for his 25th high school reunion, his success was no secret. He arrived with a chauffeur, and afterward, he treated a group of 20 or so classmates to drinks at Giacomo Jack's, a nearby restaurant.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Curb On Ultrasound Devices
description: To reduce the use of ultrasound machines to detect the sex of a fetus -- a practice that has led to widespread abortion of female fetuses -- the Supreme Court ordered states to confiscate ultrasound machines that had not been licensed. The court had earlier ordered manufacturers of the machines to provide names and addresses of purchasing clinics and individuals. Those lists have since been provided to the states for follow-up. In some of India's richest states, where the preference for boys is strongest -- including Punjab, Haryana and Gujarat -- the spread of ultrasound sex determination tests has led to a marked decline in the ratio of girls to boys being born. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Greta Van Susteren, the anchor who moved to the Fox News Channel from CNN, misstated the position of Teya Ryan, whom the network cited as an example of women in executive posts. She is general manager and executive vice president of CNN Headline News; those titles at CNNfn are held by Ken Jautz.

title: Chargers Hire Schottenheimer
description: San Diego hired Marty Schottenheimer yesterday as coach, hoping he could end their six-year playoff drought. Schottenheimer becomes the fourth head coach in six seasons for the Chargers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the relevance of Rudyard Kipling today referred incorrectly to the mother of the title character in the novel ''Kim.'' He was the son of an English nursemaid and an Irish soldier, reared by an Indian woman who said she was Kim's aunt; he was not the son of a low-caste Indian woman.

title: Corrections
description: A graph in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day yesterday with a report about Vodafone of Britain, which reached a deal with Bytemobile, a wireless data start-up, tracked an incorrect stock. The prices shown were for the company's German subsidiary, not the parent. Shares of Vodafone fell 6.25 pence yesterday, to 154.25, after falling 2.25 pence on Monday.

title: Athletes Guess on Supplements
description: Pavle Jovanovic was not unlike many Olympic athletes who begin and end their training sessions by taking nutritional supplements in an effort to maximize their body's potential.

title: Illicit Antiquities And a Test Case Fit for Solomon; The Trial of a Dealer Divides the Art World
description: It is a long way from the ancient tombs of Egypt to a federal courtroom in Lower Manhattan. But jurors in the criminal trial of a prominent New York City antiquities dealer are making that leap this week in a case that has injected anxiety into the rarefied and secretive world of antiquities traders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUDSON, JEANNETTE A.
description: JUDSON-Jeannette A. The Officers, Board of Directors and Staff of The Jewish Guild for the Blind are deeply saddened by the death of Jeannette A. Judson, beloved mother of Pauline Raiff, our Chairman-Elect, longtime member of the Board of Directors, Past President of our Women's Division and leader of numerous Guild events. Mrs. Judson had been an active and generous supporter of The Guild for many years. We extend our deepest sympathies to all of the Judson family. Joseph S. Mishkin, Chairman Alan R. Morse, President and CEO

title: Sauteing the Breasts
description: Duck breasts are not as flavorful as the legs and are much fattier. By preparing them correctly, however, you can get a mild, tender product that acts as a nice counterpart to the richer legs. The key is to score the skin so the fatty layer of the breast can render, allowing for both less fat and a crispier skin.

title: Mayor to Speak of Education and Development
description: In his first address to the City Council today, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to call for dissolving local school boards in favor of mayoral control of the Board of Education, and will propose several economic development projects for the city, many of them outside Lower Manhattan, his aides say.

title: For City, Good Buzz May Be Best Payoff Of Economic Forum
description: Money pumped into New York's economy by bigwigs on a spree at the schmoozefest called the World Economic Forum: $13 million or $19.4 million, depending on how you figure it.

title: The Cost of Politics: How TV Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Bouley's Back

title: Ginger and Cassis Sauce
description: Despite the name, this flavorful, but not overpowering sauce actually uses black currant jelly (the jelly provides some extra body to the sauce).

title: Before the Towers Fell, Fire Dept. Fought Chaos
description: In scores of emotionally searing interviews conducted by the Fire Department for an internal inquiry, the agency's most senior commanders have provided new and, in some cases, alarming revelations about the events of Sept. 11.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Londonderry Journal; 'Bloody Sunday' of '72: Digging Anew for the Truth
description: On Jan. 30, 1972, the day known since as Bloody Sunday, British paratroopers fatally shot 14 unarmed Roman Catholic civil rights marchers in the streets of this city. Now, 30 years later and just blocks from the scene, the event is being painstakingly recreated in the longest legal inquiry in British history.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Psychiatrists Agree Doctor Was Insane as Parents Were Killed
description: The accomplished New Jersey doctor charged with smothering her aging parents in their bedroom a year and a half ago is scheduled to go on trial tomorrow, with both defense and state psychiatrists in agreement that she was insane at the time of the killings.

title: Honey, I Shrunk The Treacle
description: I'VE never been a fan of honey. But a single taste of a new one blended with hazelnuts has made me a convert. Adding toasted hazelnut paste to orange honey has transformed what to me has always been a treacly sweet into something worth mixing with yogurt, sour cream, crme frache, fromage blanc -- you get the idea. The other night I tried it on bread and I can imagine it happily as a topping for vanilla, chocolate or coffee ice cream or frozen yogurt -- even as a light glaze on a pork roast just before removing from the oven.

title: Our Towns; On Slopes, Ticket Sellers and Lift Operators Almost Outnumber Skiers
description: THE Weather Channel was on, as usual, and as usual it was predicting more of the same: highs in the 50's, partly cloudy, rain or ice later in the week. About as bad as it gets in the ski industry in what is supposed to be the dead of winter. And don't even mention the drought.

title: Davos on the Hudson
description: Many corporate gatherings have themes, but the World Economic Forum may be the only one that has a human ideal. The Davos Man, named for the Swiss town where the conference has been held for the past 32 years, is a model of globe-trotting, high-tech, New Economy savvy. And for the next five days some 3,000 Davos Men, and a sprinkling of Davos Women, will descend on the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City from around the world, Blackberry personal messaging devices in hand and silk ties flapping in the wind.

title: Mixed Praise For Efforts To Stanch Terror Funds
description: Lawmakers praised the Bush administration today for its quick use of the new money-laundering provisions of last fall's antiterrorism law but pushed it to do more and questioned some newly imposed regulations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIELMAN, WILLIAM
description: SPIELMAN-William. Beloved son of Rose, adored husband of BetteAnn, cherished father of Jayne and Stephen Baumgarten, Rachel and Eric Ceder, Dodi & Jonathan Spielman, grandfather of Hannah, Sarah, Sam, Talia, Ethan, Micah, Jonah, and Ava, loving brother of Stanley. Vice President of Independent Chemical Corp, Bill's creative energy and passion for community, characterized his ardent involvement in many organizations. Bill served as Past President of The Solomon Schechter Day School of Nassau County where he dedicated himself to the growth and enhancement of The School, including the founding of Solomon Schechter High School of Long Island. Bill was an Associate Trustee of North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, NY, Fellow For Life of The Metropolitan Museum of Art, NY, NY, member of The Commission of The Holocaust Memorial and Educational Center of Nassau County, member of The Chancellor's Council of The Jewish Theological Seminary, NYC, Past President of Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn, NY, Chair of The Chemical Division of UJA-Federation, Member of The Board and Trustee of The Davidson School of Education and member of The Board of The Sid Jacobson Jewish Community Center in East Hills, NY (where he was an avid swimmer). For his dedicated and active involvment over the years, Bill was honored by many organizations including Israel Bonds, The Jewish Theological Seminary, Temple Beth Sholom, and The Solomon Schechter High School of Long Island. He is remembered by his family and many friends for his passion, charismatic warmth, love of children, sense of humor, leadership, enthusiasm and integrity. Always in motion, alway creating, Bill was an inspiration and a source of strength for all who knew him. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Solomon Schechter Day School of Nassau County, Barbara Lane, Jericho, NY 11753; 516-935-1441. Funeral services will be held at 11 A.M. Wednesday, January 30, 2002 at Temple Beth Sholom, 401 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, New York 11577; 516-621-2288.

title: Call to Step Up Antiterror War Identifies 3 Nations as Threats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  As he sought to balance strengthening national security and reviving the economy, President Bush asked America tonight to support a continuing war on terrorism that may expand from shadowy Al Qaeda to at least three nations that he said sought weapons of mass destruction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ROSS, DOROTHY
description: STERN-ROSS-Dorothy. Our lives have been enriched through our friendship with Dorothy. She met every challenge with determination and the energy to achieve. Her love and compassion for others was constantly demonstrated by her willingness to share her blessings. We loved her and will always cherish the memories of our 55 year relationship. Gloria and Mel Haupt

title: CONSECO TO SELL ASSETS TO HELP MEET ITS DEBT PAYMENTS
description: Conseco Inc. will sell assets and take other steps to raise as much as $800 million and meet payments on $1.25 billion of debt maturing this year. The chairman, Gary Wendt, said in a memo to shareholders the finance and insurance company will sell its variable annuities unit as well as some of its loan holdings and other assets to help raise cash, and will seek a joint-venture partner for its business of financing mobile-home dealers. Conseco, based in Carmel, Ind., will also buy back existing bonds at a discount, tap a credit line at its finance unit and free up capital that can be used for debt payments by reinsuring parts of its supplemental health and life insurance lines.

title: Lingering on Delicious Byways
description: ''Words make you think a thought, and music makes you feel a feeling, but a song makes you feel a thought,'' observed Harold Arlen. That quotation, cited by the composer and music historian Rob Kapilow on Sunday evening at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse, where he appeared with the singer Ann Hampton Callaway, distills the spirit of Lincoln Center's three-year-old American Songbook series devoted to celebrating our popular song heritage.

title: Sports of The Times; Tyson Has Only Himself to Blame for Turndown
description: INSTEAD of his usual hip-hop clothes, Mike Tyson was wearing his most sincere suit -- gray with a white shirt and a gray tie.

title: Painless Cost-Cutting
description: When New York City has a budget crunch, everyone hopes that the administration will find ways to provide the same services for less money. Those easy solutions are unfortunately rare. But Mayor Michael Bloomberg does have a chance to cut the cost of providing attorneys for indigent defendants without shortchanging justice.

title: Diplomacy Star Is Born
description: If Central Casting (or Central Intelligence) had searched for an unknown player to explain the challenges of a reborn Afghanistan to the United States and the world, it could hardly have done better than Hamid Karzai, the country's interim leader. Underlining a successful three-day visit, he emerged at the State of the Union as Washington's latest star, with a modest smile and a series of small, sharp bows.

title: Jets' Ramos to Retire
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29  Frank Ramos, the Jets' long-time head of public relations and the last link to their Super Bowl III championship team, announced yesterday that he would take early retirement, effective March 1. Ramos spent 39 years with the Jets.

title: Hurdle Leapt, U.S. Will Help Philippines Battle Rebels
description: American and Filipino military officials appear to have worked out last-minute differences that threatened to delay the start of joint operations to battle armed Muslims in the southern Philippines who are suspected of having ties to Al Qaeda, officials said today.

title: All-Star Snubs Include Nets' Martin and All the Knicks
description: When the word reached Kenyon Martin today that only Jason Kidd would represent the Nets on the N.B.A.'s Eastern Conference All-Star team, he shrugged his broad shoulders. But Martin countered every effort he made to insist he did not care with a forced smile as he detailed the reasons he should have made the team.

title: Recipe: Key Lime Chiffon Pie
description: Time: 45 minutes

title: Seeking Solace In Words Of President
description: Here in steel country, where the hum of mills has waned and where some unemployed workers worry more than they sleep these days, there was hope tonight that the president's State of the Union address would offer a salve, if not a solution, for these troubled economic times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOLLUM, H.W.
description: McCOLLUM-H.W. The Board of Directors and Officers of Amerada Hess Corporation express their deep sorrow and sense of loss on the death of their esteemed colleague and close friend, H.W. McCollum. Mr. McCollum's leadership as Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors of Amerada Hess and his advice and guidance as a Director of Amerada Hess from 1969 to 1998 were instrumental in the growth of the Corporation. His contributions and wise counsel have been of great value and will be missed. We express our deepest sympathy to his children and grandchildren.

title: South Korean Cabinet Shuffle Augurs New Overture to North
description: President Kim Dae Jung today dismissed the minister in charge of pursuing peace with North Korea as part of a cabinet shake-up aimed at revamping a government buffeted by political scandals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRATTO, RUSSEL A.
description: FRATTO-Russel A. Died on January 25, 2002. A memorial will be held on Saturday, February 2, 2002 at 1:00PM at the Norwalk Inn, East Avenue, Norwalk, CT.

title: Capturing for History Many of a Tragic Day's Triumphs and Problems
description: The New York Fire Department has conducted roughly 500 interviews with its personnel about the events of Sept. 11, gathering recollections, exploring decisions and capturing for history many of the day's triumphs and problems. Following are excerpts from interviews with a handful of the department's members, including some of its highest-ranking officers.

title: Life as a Bearer of Tidings and More Exotic Things
description: HE has delivered a baby elephant to the old Madison Square Garden, a snake to a television station, a Cartier watch to President Harry S. Truman at the Hotel Carlyle (he tipped a dollar, which was worth more then), Liza Minnelli's (first) wedding dress, a jacket straight from Armani to Sylvester Stallone on Park Avenue, a script to Errol Flynn, and Heaven only knows how many pieces of paper that keep the city's commerce flowing. But this week, at 76, Ken Marks is ending a 56-year career in the messenger business.

title: As Games Near, 2 Names Lose Tarnish
description: They were indicted on bribery charges and scorned for embarrassing the city. They lost their jobs, their savings, their friends and reputations. Then, after a federal judge last year dismissed the charges, the Justice Department went back to court last week to have them reinstated.

title: Business Travel; The Concorde can still turn heads after 25 years in the air.
description: HERE is a typical workweek as once described to Mike Bannister, the chief Concorde pilot for British Airways, by a British executive for an American bank.

title: The Cloning Conundrum
description: Human cloning and hate crimes would seem to have little in common. But in a series of shortsighted decisions on the constitutional limits of Congressional power, the United States Supreme Court has managed to create legal precedents that may make it difficult for the federal government to ban cloning as well as hate crimes. This will no doubt come as a surprise to opponents of abortion, who oppose cloning on a moral basis and have been eager to outlaw it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Enron Says That Shredding Was Stopped Only Recently

title: A Focus on Communication Failures
description: Several issues surfaced repeatedly over the last four months as fire investigators interviewed hundreds of firefighters and other emergency workers about what they remembered from the day the World Trade Center was attacked.

title: Dead Man Walking
description: Yasir Arafat is a dead man walking. Few American, Israeli or Arab leaders, not to mention Palestinians, really believe anymore that he will ever lead his people into a peace deal with Israel. The only thing keeping Mr. Arafat afloat today is that no one wants to own his demise -- neither Israel nor America nor the Arabs nor his own aides wants responsibility for finishing him off. That's why this conflict has left the realm of diplomacy and entered the realm of biology -- everyone is just waiting for Mr. Arafat to pass away. Too bad he eats yogurt and takes regular naps.

title: Even Grief Can't Stop This Protest
description: THE words have formed a national mantra since the planes hit the twin towers: or else the terrorists will have won. Take a trip somewhere, or else the terrorists will have won. Go to a ballgame, or else the terrorists will have won. Give Jean-Georges Vongerichten all your money for a meal, or else the terrorists will have won.

title: Suicide Threat By 9 Refugees Held in Camp By Australia
description: Nine teenage Afghans seeking asylum are threatening to kill themselves unless they are freed from a camp where hundreds of illegal immigrants have been on a hunger strike for two weeks to protest their detention.

title: BUSH, FOCUSING ON TERRORISM, SAYS SECURE U.S. IS TOP PRIORITY
description: President Bush told Americans tonight that ''our war against terror is only beginning'' and sent new warnings to terrorists around the world and to three nations -- Iran, Iraq and North Korea.

title: Japanese Trading Company Plans Sharp Cutbacks
description: By turning to drastic measures to salvage some sort of future for itself, the Nissho Iwai Corporation may have marked a crucial watershed today in the evolution of corporate Japan.

title: 17 Are Charged in Theft of Sept. 11 Funds
description: Twelve employees of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and five others were charged yesterday with filing false claims and stealing money intended for victims of the Sept. 11 attack from a government agency and charities, the authorities said.

description: THE AMERICAS

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: N.Y. Law

title: F.B.I. Agent Ousted Over Her Handling Of a Spying Inquiry
description: The director of the F.B.I., Robert S. Mueller III, has removed a senior counterintelligence official from her job over her handling of an investigation into suspicions of Chinese espionage, bureau officials say.

title: If Tried, Real Integration Easily Proves Its Worth
description: THE Supreme Court found school segregation unconstitutional in 1954, discarding its 1896 ruling that had provided the legal rationale for ''separate but equal'' education.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNSHINE, NORMA (NEE DEUTSCH)
description: SUNSHINE-Norma (nee Deutsch). Of Fort Lee, N.J. Wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Linda Sunshine and Susan Sunshine Dorenter. Mother-in-law of Dr. Peter Dorenter. Dear sister of Bernie Deutsch. Loving grandmother of Adam and Alexis and loving aunt of Barry Katz, Stephanie Sunshine and Danny Kopelson. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, N.J., Wednesday, 1:30 PM. (1-800522-0588). Mom, we are proud of you. You did it your way.

title: Introduction
description: astes like chicken." That phrase has been used to describe everything from quail to frog, with varying degrees of accuracy. But not duck. Duck is, in fact, valued for its rich, dark flesh; when prepared well, it's more flavorful than chicken, with a skin that crisps in a way that chicken skin often doesn't. Sadly, home cooks shy away from duck, often because of its fatty reputation (it is, of course, a water fowl, so it needs the protection of the fat). We'll solve that problem, and show how easy it can be to quarter a whole duckling. We'll prepare duck legs by braising them (always a great technique for dark meat) and the breasts with a simple sear. We'll also make a sauce of ginger and cassis that is a perfect, tempered accompaniment.

title: No Respite in the Enron Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Thomas W. Barritt, senior vice president at Ketchum, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, was named as the global director a new issues and crisis management network. He will continue in his role as director for the Ketchum New York issues and crisis team.

title: Evening of Varied Works, All of Them From Britain
description: All the works that the New York New Music Ensemble brought to Merkin Hall last Wednesday night were British, though resemblances ended there, except that all the pieces were of keen interest and expertly presented.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Poor Economic Signals
description: Japan's jobless rate hit a record high for the fourth straight month, rising to 5.6 percent in December, as electronics companies, steel makers and others retrenched to ride out the current downturn. At the same time, household spending fell 4.4 percent in December from the month a year ago, the third consecutive slide. For all of 2001, household spending slipped 0.8 percent, the fourth annual decline in a row. Weaker spending bodes ill for the economy since personal consumption accounts for nearly 60 percent of Japan's gross domestic product. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Identity Services Challenged
description: A privacy group urged state law enforcement officials to investigate Microsoft's online identity services, saying they expose consumers to fraud, an increase in unsolicited commercial e-mail messages and the ''release, sale and theft of their personal information.'' Microsoft created the services, like Passport, Wallet, Kids Passport and .Net Services, to simplify Internet transactions by permitting consumers to store passwords, credit card numbers and other personal data together. ''Immediate state action is necessary to protect consumers and ensure Microsoft does not continue to improperly collect personal information,'' the Electronic Privacy Information Center said in a letter it sent to all 50 state attorneys general. The group, which also sent the letter to some members of Congress and to the Federal Trade Commission, said the company's failure to make people aware of security risks associated with the services was a violation of state laws prohibiting unfair and deceptive trade practices. A spokesman for Microsoft, Rick Miller, said, ''The claims are totally unfounded.''

title: Longtime Family Friends and New National Heroes Dot Attendees List
description: The list of special guests invited to watch President Bush's State of the Union address with the first lady, Laura Bush, included old friends and new heroes, home-grown Americans and people from half a world away.

title: Earnings Data For Quarter Is Delayed By Williams
description: The Williams Companies said yesterday that it was delaying the release of its fourth-quarter results to complete an assessment of the financial health of the Williams Communications Group, the telecommunications company Williams spun off as an independent business in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLER, CARL, M.D.
description: SCHILLER-Carl, M.D. The medical staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with deep sorrow the death of Dr. Carl Schiller. Dr. Schiller was affiliated with Maimonides Medical Center for over 50 years in the Department of Surgery. In 1952, he set up the service of Plastic Surgery and served as the Chief of Plastic Surgery for 40 years. His smile will be missed by all his friends, colleagues and patients. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. Steven Farber, M.D., President Herbert Lehman, M.D., President Elect Ira Mayer, M.D., Secretary Amin Hakim, M.D., Treasurer

title: Finishing and Plating the Dish
description: Separate the drumstick from the thigh with a knife. If you like, "french" the drumstick by scraping away the skin, tendons and cartilage from the bottom of the bone. Lay the drumsticks and thighs over rice (a mixture of white and wild rice is a pleasant accompaniment) and fan out the breast slices. Spoon the sauce lightly over everything and serve with sauteed greens or vegetables.

title: Three Plead Guilty to Aiding in Huge Stock Fraud Case
description: A former F.B.I. operations manager and two former New York securities executives pleaded guilty today to illegally helping two Frenchmen who carried out huge stock frauds in the United States and Europe.

title: Restless Night, Hard School Day: A Bedtime Story
description: To Donna Swift, it's obvious that some of her third graders are not getting enough sleep.

title: Foreign Stock Markets Beckon, but a Strong Dollar Discourages
description: Oh, the poor diversifying investor.

title: Capturing for History Many of a Tragic Day's Triumphs and Problems
description: The New York Fire Department has conducted roughly 500 interviews with its personnel about the events of Sept. 11, gathering recollections, exploring decisions and capturing for history many of the day's triumphs and problems. Following are excerpts from interviews with a handful of the department's members, including some of its highest-ranking officers.

title: Japan Premier Faces Major Crisis Over Firing of Foreign Minister
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30 -- Japan's reformist prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, whose power derives primarily from high approval ratings in opinion polls, faced a major crisis today as voters frowned on his firing of the popular foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka.

title: In Flash of an Afghan Cape, a World Star Is Born
description: His smile was modest, and so was his series of small, sharp bows from the first lady's box. But the reception was emphatic and Hamid Karzai, Afghanistan's interim leader, emerged at the State of the Union tonight as Washington's latest star.

title: Voting Rights in Peril
description: At the heart of the debate over reforming the nation's electoral system lies the question of whether standards for voting should be set by the federal government or left up to state and local election officials. It is hardly a surprise that the Election Reform Information Project found, in a survey released last week, that state and local officials would prefer to continue exercising exclusive authority over federal elections. But it is disappointing nonetheless. The national voting rights standards that I have pushed for in the House and that Senator Christopher Dodd has pressed in the Senate provide fundamental safeguards that should have been guaranteed long ago.

title: Scholarships as Tribute to Rescue Workers
description: ROBERT FRIEDMAN, a limited partner at Goldman Sachs and a partner in Sage Capital Management, is creating 25 $2,000 scholarships for students bound for the City University of New York. They will be known as the ''Myself Third: Spirit of New York Scholarships,'' a reference to a lesson he learned in the sixth grade: to put oneself third after responsibilities to God and to country. The scholarships -- a tribute to the Sept. 11 rescue workers -- will be available to students who participate in College Now, a CUNY program that helps prepare high school students for college. Applicants will be required to submit an essay describing a personal experience that demonstrates appreciation of civic responsibility. Karen W. Arenson

title: More Layoffs at Fallon Worldwide
description: Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe ( news/quote ), said yesterday that it had laid off 20 workers, or 30 percent, of the employees in its New York office, including all but one creative staff member.

title: True Pearls Of the Caribbean
description: FROM here to Miami and well beyond, in greasy spoons and roadhouses and proper restaurants, conch (rhymes with honk) is the mollusk of choice. Deep-fried conch fritters are on offer, and conch chowder, cracked conch (a kind of steak), conch salad, conch ceviche -- even, in a few places with no shame at all, conchburgers.

title: Kurt Gutenbrunner
description: PEOPLE think of pastry when they think of Austria. But for me, the most wonderful Austrian dessert is the big, puffy mountain of a souffl called Salzburger nockerl.

title: IN CHAPTER 11, WARNACO SELLS ITS FRAGRANCE DIVISION
description: The Warnaco Group, the maker of Calvin Klein jeans and Speedo swimsuits reorganizing under Chapter 11 protection, won a judge's permission to sell its fragrance unit for $11 million to Royal Holdings. Judge Richard L. Bohanon of federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan approved the sale of the unit, Penhaligon's, yesterday, said the company's bankruptcy attorney. Most of the unit's assets are located in Britain. Additionally, Warnaco got court permission to hire John Kourakos as president of its sportswear group, which includes the company's Calvin Klein Jeans and Calvin Klein Underwear.

title: Glenn Sues the League And Cites Depression
description: New England Patriots receiver Terry Glenn sued the National Football League today in federal District Court in New York, claiming that the league undertook discriminatory actions against him and failed to provide for a reasonable accommodation for his chronic depression.

title: Raji Jallepalli-Reiss, Chef, 52; Merged French and Indian Cuisines
description: Raji Jallepalli-Reiss, a chef credited with originating the fusion of classic French and Indian cuisines, died on Jan. 27 at her home in Memphis. She was 52.

description: Even the most ardent followers of the federal government, the kind who spend hours watching C-Span, might have trouble remembering the names of any of the six previous holders of the office of comptroller general.
