description: Despite intensive security procedures, a passenger at San Francisco International Airport whose shoes tripped an alert for possible explosives walked past security agents this morning and into the crowd.

title: Cork Coverings Are Back (Marcel Proust, Take Note)
description: Cork has been applied to walls before. But hand-printed cork wallpaper is new. Tomorrow F. Schumacher is introducing Damask Arabesque cork wallpaper, far right, and La Cit cork wallpaper, inset. The printed wallpapers have what the company calls ''dimensionality.'' ''It's a modern medium with traditional imagery,'' said Janice Langrall, the marketing director of Schumacher fabrics and wallcoverings. The wallpaper is backed with paper and no thicker than normal.

title: A Video Study Of Enron Offers A Picture of Life Before the Fall
description: In April 2000, Enron was still flying high, at least publicly. Jeffrey K. Skilling, the president and chief operating officer at the time, faced a video camera and spoke enthusiastically about the corporate culture that would, he insisted, enable Enron to go from the world's largest energy-trading company to the world's leading company, period.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Trade Center Tenants To Meet
description: The World Trade Center Tenants Association will hold a meeting, open to anyone who leased space in the complex. It is scheduled for noon in the office of the Manhattan borough president, Municipal Building, 19th Floor, Manhattan. Information: Meyer Feig at mfeig@theinteracorp.com.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Suit Opposes Rise In Cougar Hunting
description: An animal rights group has filed a lawsuit to block increased cougar hunting. The group, Animal Protection of New Mexico, contends that the state game commission abandoned its legal responsibility when it voted to increase the number of cougars that can be killed annually to 227 from 176. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Board Dashes Cold Water On Public Feud at Viacom Between Top Executives
description: Members of the Viacom board yesterday told Sumner M. Redstone, the company's chairman and chief executive, and Mel Karmazin, the president and chief operating officer, to end the personal conflict between them that has emerged into public view in the last several months, people associated with the board said.

title: Suspect Calls Malaysia a Staging Area for Terror Attacks
description: An operative of Al Qaeda arrested in Malaysia has begun cooperating with investigators and provided new evidence to show that the Southeast Asian nation was a major staging area for the Sept. 11 terror attacks in the United States, Bush administration officials said today.

title: University of California Panel Suggests Abandoning SAT
description: A University of California advisory panel recommended today that the university scrap the SAT in favor of new admissions tests with more emphasis on academic achievement.

title: In Rebirth of 'Silk City,' a Snag; Mayor's Indictment Tries the Patience of Paterson
description: This much can be said of this bleak but battling community, hard by the Passaic River, that was forged by the Industrial Age, ruined by its demise and is still reeling from a century of labor strife, racial tensions, high crime rates and joblessness: at least there was no plague of locusts.

title: THE FIGHT AGAINST TERROR / Persuing bin Laden: Driving Al Qaeda:Religious Decrees
description: PARIS  Before and after Sept. 11, prominent religious figures in Saudi Arabia and the Gulf issued numerous decrees denouncing the United States, justifying suicide bombings and, in some cases, offering overt support for Osama bin Laden, according to a collection of Islamic decrees and correspondence assembled by a French terrorism expert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, RUTH
description: LLOYD-Ruth. Of Devonwood Drive, Farmington, CT, died on Monday, January 28, 2002 at John Dempsey Hospital in Farmington. She was born on August 27, 1910 in Buffalo, New York. Mrs. Lloyd was the widow of Norman Lloyd, former Director of the Arts of the Rockefeller Foundation and Dean of the Juilliard School of Music, with whom she played professional four-hand piano, and co-authored books ranging from Piano Improvisation to Tap Dancing. She also collaborated with Mr. Lloyd on his acclaimed encyclopedia of Music, published by Simon & Schuster. A graduate of NYU, Mrs. Lloyd taught at Lakemont School in New York; and taught and provided piano accompaniment at Bennington College and Connecticut College as part of the American Festival of the Dance, where she was a friend and professional colleague of Martha Graham, Jose Limon, Martha Davies, Bessie Schoenberg and other giants in the field of dance. In the 1940s, Mrs. Lloyd joined the faculty of Sarah Lawrence College where she taught for more than twenty years. She concluded her teaching career at SUNY in Purchase, New York. Mrs. Lloyd is survived by her two sons, David Lloyd of Washington, DC, and Alex Lloyd of Farmington, CT, together with six grandchildren and one great grandchild. There are no calling hours. Memorial service will be at the convenience of the family. For info the Vincent Funeral Home, Canton, CT. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in Mrs. Lloyd's memory may be made to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605.

title: KOHL'S TO HIRE 1,700 WORKERS FOR NEW STORES
description: The Kohl's Corporation plans to hire more than 1,700 workers as it prepares to open its first stores in Massachusetts and New Hampshire in April. Each store will hire about 135 workers, the company said. The managers have been hired. Kohl's, based in Menomonee Falls, Wis., said the new locations include Andover, Burlington and Walpole in eastern Massachusetts, and Nashua, N.H. Kohl's, which has 382 stores in 29 states, has been expanding in the Northeast and Midwest and plans to enter the Southwest next year, a spokeswoman, Susan Henderson, said.

title: Sea to Shining Slope On New Wallyskis
description: For Luca Bassani, a wealthy Italian yachtsman, winter takes him away from sailing and into skiing. His favorite hideaway is the snow-covered Alpine village of St. Moritz, Switzerland, an idyllic place where he has been able through the years to refresh himself from the business demands of his high-tech boat building company. But now skiing has infiltrated Bassani's workaday world, and he concedes he has only himself to blame.

title: 'Wanna play?' That's what Club Med asks in its new campaign.
description: CLUB MED is worried that vacationers do not fully understand what its resorts are all about, so it has introduced an advertising campaign to try to make that clearer.

title: Album Delayed But Not Denied
description: In 1996 Josh Clayton-Felt, a songwriter and multi-instrumentalist who used to play in the rock group School of Fish, began to record his second solo album for A&M Records.

title: Arrest of Convicted Killer Raises Concerns About Missed Warnings
description: After admitting in 1988 that he had murdered a former girlfriend and stabbed another woman, Edwin Snelgrove wrote to a New Jersey judge about violent sexual fantasies that started when he was a second grader. He described images of strangling or hitting a woman on the head, carrying her limp body to a bed and ''arranging her arms and legs in some kind of seductive pose.''

title: Rumsfeld Urges U.S. to Be Ready For New and Deadlier Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the United States must be ready for terrorist attacks far worse than those of Sept. 11 and refashion its military forces accordingly.

title: New Gene Test May Provide Early Signs of Colon Cancer
description: A new screening test for colon cancer, based on detecting a gene that is disrupted very early in the course of the disease, could prevent many thousands of deaths each year, researchers are reporting today.

title: Mutual Fund Growth Was Slack Last Year
description: Investors added less money to stock mutual funds in 2001 than in any year since 1990 as the average stock fund lost money for a second year, an industry group reported today.

title: Sony Appoints Universal McCann
description: The Sony Corporation of America, part of Sony of Japan, said yesterday that it had selected Universal McCann in New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group, to handle its consolidated media planning and buying account.

title: Times Co. Reports 46% Drop In Fourth-Quarter Net Income
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income fell 46 percent as a weak advertising market more than offset cost cuts and gains in circulation income.

title: Carnival Cuts Some Strings From Its Bid For Princess
description: The Carnival Corporation dropped almost all the strings attached to its offer for P&O Princess Cruises today, in hopes of garnering shareholder support before a scheduled vote on a rival plan to merge P&O Princess with Royal Caribbean Cruises.

title: Metro Briefing | Calender: Tomorrow: Hearing On Dental Clinics
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on the rehabilitation of four city dental clinics intended for low-income residents, including East Harlem Health Center. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (212) 788-7100.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Schools and Founding Fathers
description: The new state education commissioner said yesterday that he would revise a draft of the state's basic education curriculum to include the names of the founding fathers, including George Washington. State Senator Gerald Cardinale, a Bergen County Republican, threatened legislative action if the founders were not named. Standards for the state's core curriculum, first adopted in 1996, must be updated every five years. A draft proposal, developed over several months by a panel of experts and submitted to the State Department of Education last month, omitted the founders in social studies lessons. The education commissioner, William L. Librera, said a new draft would name the founders. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Unexpected Eulogy For Night Train Lane
description: AMID a crush of reporters yesterday, someone sidled up to Aeneas Williams, the St. Louis Rams' 11th-year cornerback, and broke a bit of bad news: Night Train Lane had died Tuesday night.

title: Reno Faints in Speech
description: Janet Reno, the attorney general under President Clinton, collapsed last night while giving a speech at the University of Rochester.

title: Prominent Legislator in Zimbabwe Faults Plan to Limit Media
description: Adding his voice to a rising chorus of criticism of Zimbabwe's government, a prominent member of President Robert Mugabe's own political party has publicly denounced as unconstitutional a proposed law that would sharply restrict freedom of speech.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pension Fund Loses Money On Stock
description: New York State's pension fund has lost $63 million on the stock of Global Crossing, the telecommunications company that filed for bankruptcy protection this week, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall's office said yesterday. Last year, the fund lost $58 million in the collapse of Enron. The losses represent a small fraction of the $112 billion fund, which is widely diversified. But the campaign of Andrew M. Cuomo, Mr. McCall's rival for the Democratic nomination, has raised questions about Mr. McCall's management of the fund, pointing to recent losses. The fund has lost $15 billion over the last two years, a period in which most investors suffered in a weak market. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Bush Aides Say Tough Tone Put Foes on Notice
description: President Bush decided to lump Iran and North Korea with Iraq as members of an ''axis of evil'' whose support for terrorism seeks to acquire and spread weapons of mass destruction, officials said today, despite the fact that the two nations have sporadically sought improved relations with the United States.

title: High Drama, Slow Traffic
description: The World Economic Forum, which opens today on the Upper East Side, may provide some of the best street theater around. But parking won't be pleasant. Page A17.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, DORIS L.
description: ROSENBERG-Doris L., 83. Died on January 29, 2002 at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. Daughter of the late Paul F. Lowinger of Vienna, Austria & Claire Lowinger of Jacksonville, Florida. Wife of the late Irwin H. Rosenberg, of New York. A passionate advocate of the rights of children and the elderly, a great friend to scores of men and women, a devoted New Yorker, and a polymath of enormous range and depth, Doris Rosenberg left an indelible mark on the life of this City. She is survived by her son and daughter-inlaw, Gerald & Rosalind Rosenberg of Manhattan, two grandsons, Clifford and Nicholas, a granddaughter-in-law, Kim, and one greatgrandson, Henry. Services will be at Frank E. Campbell (Madison Avenue & 81st Street) on Sunday, February 3 at 2:30. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Barnard College (the Doris Lowinger Rosenberg Fund Class of 1939), 3009 Broadway, New York, NY 10027, or the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, 120 West 57th Street, New York, New York 10019.

title: Plaintiffs Sought Timeout After Turn in Napster Case
description: The major record companies, which two weeks ago surprised analysts by seeking a temporary suspension in their copyright lawsuit against Napster, were about to face potentially damaging inquiries into their own behavior on maintaining copyrights.

title: Fiscal News For Nassau: From Bad To Worse
description: Just how bad is Nassau County's budget crisis? Take the previous deficit calculation and double it, the county executive said today. Fixing the problem will require steps he called ''drastic'' and ''painful.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIELMAN, WILLIAM
description: SPIELMAN-William. Bill's life recalls the Rabbinic story of a king who had a beautiful diamond. But it had a scratch, which no one could eradicate, until a craftsman converted the scratch into the stem of a rose. Bill's life also was like a rose, becoming more beautiful as he enriched all our lives. Nancy and Irving Silverman

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Denver Suspends Photo Radar Program
description: Denver has temporarily suspended a photo radar speeding enforcement program because a county judge ruled that four tickets were not legal because they were issued by a private company and not the Denver Police, as required by a city ordinance. The photo radar program was started in Denver in 1998 and each ticket carries a $40 fine, which is doubled in school zones.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Man Arrested At Casino
description: A man has been arrested and charged with offering loans with exorbitant interest to high-stakes gamblers at the Mohegan Sun Casino. The state police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that they were investigating the man, Mu Can Lin, 42, for possible connections to organized crime. Mr. Lin was arrested Tuesday at the casino and charged that day with extortionate extension of credit, court officers said. He has not offered a plea and is being held on $25,000 cash bail.

title: Bush Asks Volunteers To Join Fight On Terrorism
description: President Bush said today that he would create a national volunteer agency called Citizen Corps to engage Americans in protecting the United States from terrorist attacks and helping out in future catastrophes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARECKY, LILLIAN
description: JARECKY-Lillian. On January 29, 2002, in her 100th year. Devoted wife to the late Julian Jarecky. Loving mother to Maida and husband Abraham Piaker, and the late Jesse Jarecky. Beloved grandmother to Daniel Jarecky, Steven Piaker and David Piaker. Cherished great-grandmother to Rachel, Lindsay, Zachary and Joseph. Adored aunt, great-aunt and friend. Lifelong resident of New York City. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial Chapel Friday at 12:45PM. Contributions may be made to Temple Israel, Deerfield Place, Vestal, NY 13850.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: S.E.C. Sites Warn Against Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had created a series of Web sites to warn people about rushing into investments on the Internet without fully investigating the offers. Borrowing tactics often used by those who promise quick and easy riches from the stock market, officials said, the sites appear to offer legitimate investment opportunities. But potential investors are linked to a page that says, ''If you responded to an investment idea like this, you could get scammed!'' The page provides tips for researching investments, and information on groups that help consumers who have fallen prey to online investment schemes. The S.E.C. said it had introduced the first of the sites earlier this month and had already received thousands of visitors. Other government agencies and law enforcement organizations will assist the S.E.C. with similar sites.

description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,094 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as the result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

description: The Devils have a two-game winning streak.

description: BORN: Oct. 2, 1951, in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Inge Morath, Photographer With a Poetic Touch, Dies at 78
description: Inge Morath, a photographer who brought a whimsical, lyrical touch to her images from travelogues to reportage to portraits, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. She was 78 and lived in Roxbury, Conn.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DAKOTA, MINNESOTA & EASTERN RAILROAD CORP., a four-state railway, won federal approval for a $1.5 billion plan to build about 260 miles of track to serve coal fields in the Powder River Basin of Wyoming.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sales Of High-End Machines Lag
description: Sales of high-end computer systems suffered along with the moribund PC market last year because of cutbacks in corporate spending, according to the market research group Dataquest. Dataquest, a division of Gartner, said worldwide unit sales of the data-serving computers that run corporate networks and data centers increased 1.8 percent from 2000, the lowest growth rate in five years. Compaq Computer held the top spot, with 23.3 percent of the systems sold, but Dell Computer, the only vendor to gain market share, leap-frogged I.B.M. into second place. In a separate report, Gartner said sales of workstations, powerful desktop computers used for graphics, declined for the first time ever, by 11.2 percent. Dell added nine points of market share in the year, holding the top spot with 32.4 percent, ahead of Sun Microsystems and Compaq.

title: The Pebble Beach Forecast Is the Wild Card in the Field
description: Instead of practicing this morning, Tiger Woods was battling the flu.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Messaging Company Names A Chief
description: Odigo, a New York-based provider of instant-messaging services, said it had named Howard Woolf as its new president and chief executive. Mr. Woolf was formerly president for the Americas at Intel Dialogic, a software and telecommunications services company. ''Howard is exactly the right leader for Odigo,'' Lewis Pell, Odigo's chairman, said in a statement. Founded in 1998, Odigo has licensed its software to customers like NEC, British Telecommunications and Prodigy/SBC. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Fighting Erupts in Afghan City As Warlords Compete for Power
description: After two months of rising tensions between rival warlords across much of Afghanistan, this strategic city 80 miles south of Kabul erupted today in heavy fighting that continued into the night with bursts of mortar, rocket and rifle fire, flashes and smoke from exploding ammunition. There were unconfirmed reports of civilian as well as military casualties.

title: Germany and Portugal Face Warnings to Rein In Deficits
description: The European Commission recommended today that Germany and Portugal be sent early warnings over the size of their national budget deficits.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Effort To Revive Bank Reforms
description: The three-party governing coalition will try to avert a new financial crisis by returning a vetoed bank reform law to Parliament for a second vote. The law, which would inject up to $5 billion into the ailing banking industry, is a crucial element of reforms demanded by the International Monetary Fund in exchange for a new $10 billion bailout. President Ahmet Necdet Sezer vetoed three articles of the legislation over the weekend, but must ratify it if Parliament passes it a second time.

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYLER, WILFRED
description: WYLER-Wilfred. Died January 29, 2002 at age 93, after a long illness. Survived by his wife of 63 years, Marjorie, his daughters, Ruth W. Messinger and Dr. Barbara W. Gold, five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Founder in 1937 and senior partner of Wilfred Wyler and Company, CPAs. His community commitment and loyalty are reflected by his half century as a Trustee and Treasurer of the Jewish Home and Hospital, and as Chairman, Treasurer and Officer of the Joint Retirement Board, and member, Board of Overseers for the Jewish Theological Seminary. He was a graduate of Harvard College, B.S. 1928 and NYU Graduate School of Business, M.B.A. 1934 and attended Columbia Business School 1935 to 1938. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM Friday, February 1, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Shiva will be Sunday and Monday, 4 to 7 PM, at 333 Central Park West, Apt #

description: Firing its old auditor was easy. Now, with Arthur Andersen out of the way, the Enron Corporation faces a much more difficult task: finding another accounting firm willing to take its place.

description: While baseball's labor negotiators plodded along in their discussions for a new collective bargaining agreement, the $158 million sale of the Florida Marlins to the owner of the Montreal Expos inched closer yesterday toward completion.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sotheby's And Ebay Plan Venture
description: EBay and Sotheby's said they would join forces to create a new auction Web site that allows for live online auctions of items sold in Sotheby's showrooms. The site will be a newly designed version of Sothebys.com, into which will be folded eBay's Premier site, a section that focuses on expensive collectibles and requires users to put credit card numbers on file. EBay will build the new site and the company's auction technology will be used to manage the bidding and selling process, whether for live auctions or auctions that take place over a set number of days. By the summer, officials said, online users will be able to participate in some of Sotheby's auctions at the same time as those who are sitting in the auction halls. ''People will be able to see on their monitors, in real time, the action in the showroom,'' said David Redden, vice chairman of Sotheby's and chairman of Sotheby's.com. Officials would not disclose the financial terms of the deal.

title: Fish, Wine, Music, For Every Wall
description: ECONOMIC uncertainty usually results in few new products. But a surprising variety of fresh designs was shown at the New York International Gift Fair, the semiannual wholesale marketplace that took place last week at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. The booths in the ''accent on design'' area, showing contemporary furnishings and housewares, were filled with innovative products, which used plastics and paper in unexpected ways. While last year's show emphasized flourishes and patterns, like toile de jouey, this year simple lines and clean surfaces prevailed.

title: Who Said What When?

title: A Designer D.J. Turntable Gives New Meaning to Mixing
description: ''Everyone wants to be a D.J.,'' said the designer Karim Rashid (above). And now everyone can be. The new DJ Kreemy table (top) has space for two turntables and a mixing board (sorry, turntable and mixing board are not included), built-in power outlets and a dual lighting system. Made of molded fiberglass with a steel base, it comes in yellow, pink, orange and white. Mr. Rashid was a D.J. in the 1970's and early 80's and says he may consider doing ''a monthly venue somewhere.'' At home, he will use DJ Kreemy as a bar. ''It is time to celebrate living,'' he said. The table is available from Pure Design, a Canadian manufacturer, for $2,900; on the Web at www.puredesignonline.com. (Shipping will run about $750.) STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Brilliance May Be Possible In Theory, but in Practice . . .

description: The Energy Department plans to ask permission to dispose of nuclear waste at Yucca Mountain before it has finished designing the repository, and it hopes to begin burying the waste long before it knows how to seal the tunnels, department officials said in testimony here before an independent science advisory panel.

description: They are the flotsam and jetsam of the digital life: personal identification numbers, passwords, user names, and credit card and bank account numbers. It can be difficult to keep track of all those codes and numbers in your head, and keeping a list on paper is a security risk.

title: Painkillers a Quiet Fact of Life in the N.F.L.
description: Kurt Warner's ribs remain the talk of the town. Warner, the St. Louis Rams' quarterback, says that the ribs he bruised in the playoffs against Green Bay are feeling better. But they are still quite sore, and there remains a possibility he will take a painkilling injection before playing against the New England Patriots Sunday in Super Bowl XXXVI.

description: You could get insight into your sullen teenager's view of life by rereading ''The Catcher in the Rye.'' Or you could pop her head inside an M.R.I. machine. Either way, what you learn won't stop her mood swings, but it might make you feel better about them -- or not.

Mourned by brother Arthur, children George and Linda, Charlotte and Norman Gilden, grandchildren Jennifer, Linda, Miles and great grandchild Wendy. We were blessed to have her in our lives.

description: The Swiss-Swedish industrial group ABB rattled investors today by saying it expected to post a loss for 2001 because of increased provisions for asbestos lawsuits in the United States.

title: Now You See It. Now You Still See It.
description: As might be expected, the Dutch designer Richard Hutten, who has worked with Droog Design, has different notions from the usual about what makes a chair. With Droog, he made the Constructionless chair (a seamless blob of plastic) and the Cross couch (a Miesian minimalist double bench, which is used in the lobby of the Mondrian Hotel in Los Angeles). The beechwood Thing 7 bench (above) is the newest in a series he began in 1995. As with all Things (Felissimo carries a range of them), it employs an atypical arrangement of elements. ''It is an image you know and at the same time never saw before,'' Mr. Hutten said. He likens it to a family -- with the parents sitting forward on one end, a child askew at the other. It's like the childlike impulse to ''do something more fun.'' Thing 7 is $1,380 by order from Felissimo Design House, 10 West 56th Street (212) 247-5656. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

Gallagher, President

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Job Cuts At Hitachi
description: The electronics company Hitachi joined two rivals, Toshiba and Fujitsu, in announcing additional job cuts to cope with the downturn in semiconductor prices and falling sales. Hitachi will eliminate 4,000 jobs before June 30 through early retirement buyouts for workers more than 40 years old. Along with the 16,350 job cuts announced last September, Japan's largest employer will trim 6 percent of its work force. Hitachi expects to lose 230 billion yen ($1.7 billion) in the fiscal year ending March 31.

title: Old Masters Generate Mixed Results At Auctions
description: Prices paid for artists like van Dyck and Romney broke records, but some paintings that had been on the auction market a little too recently were bargains. Then there was a rare, early Turner that did not get a single bid. Such were the vagaries of the January sales of old master paintings in New York.

title: Dear Sir or Madam, Please Fax Me a New Home Office
description: Topdeq, a catalog of European office design, offers a free over-the-phone design service for home offices. Fax a floor plan and one of Topdeq's designers faxes back a scheme with everything including desks and coffeepot. One unusual piece from Topdeq is Fat Boy (above), a new take on the beanbag chair. Fat Boy (in silver or red, $145) starts as a 54 1/2-by-72-inch floor cushion. It can be rearranged as shown into a kind of club chair. Everything is in stock. Delivery from the warehouse in Cranbury, N.J., is within days. Remaindered and returned furniture is up to 50 percent off. The catalog is free, from www.topdeq.com, or (866) 876-3300. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

description: Results of the largest organizing vote at any company in more than three decades will be learned tomorrow when federal officials are scheduled to announce whether a majority of 19,000 flight attendants at Delta Air Lines voted to join the Association of Flight Attendants.

description: The camps of Mike Tyson and Lennox Lewis said yesterday that they were looking to hold a heavyweight championship bout outside Nevada, even as the Las Vegas police were investigating a second rape complaint that was filed against Tyson this month.

title: Russia Calls for Binding Pact To Reduce Nuclear Arsenals
description: Russia told the United States in arms talks here this week that it wanted a binding agreement that both sides would make real and irreversible cuts in their nuclear arsenals, and that Washington would not simply store excess warheads, as it proposed, but destroy them.

title: Pace Expected to Miss Practice
description: Orlando Pace, the Rams' All-Pro left tackle, was expected to miss practice Wednesday and Thursday because of his sprained right knee. St. Louis Coach Mike Martz said Pace would probably join his teammates in Friday's workout and would be available to play in Sunday's game.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Air Force Cadet Charged With Stealing
description: A United States Air Force Academy class president has been charged with stealing more than $9,000 from the Class of 2003 cadet fund. The cadet, Chad Tucker, a junior, is also accused of misusing a government travel card and having an ''unprofessional relationship with an enlisted member.'' The cadet faces a maximum of 89 years in prison if he is found guilty of all of the charges. Officials said an investigation was under way at the academy, in Colorado Springs. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Great Performers Series Presses Its Minifestivals
description: Lincoln Center's 2002-3 Great Performers season, announced at a news conference last week, continues the expansionist approach to programming that has been this series's hallmark in recent years, and the lineup shows that whatever problems Lincoln Center's renovation plans are causing, its programming continues to evolve interestingly.

title: Put the Plan Before the Plants, and Add Water
description: HERE'S the way most people landscape: They plant a locust tree in the front yard when they move in, they put in a bed of roses at some point, and if they are really ambitious, they add a vegetable garden, foundation plantings or a grape arbor. Over the years they may waste money on cute shrubs that grow into giants that block the window, or on planting a privet hedge where the driveway should be.

description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to leave interest rates unchanged:

title: Travel Companions on Life's Inevitable Journey
description: It is not the what but the how that matters in the mesmerizing slow pieces of the experimental dancers and choreographers Eiko and Koma. Their latest piece, ''Be With,'' is a collaboration with Anna Halprin, a rebel who became den mother to much of the dance avant-garde in the 1960's and at 81 is still a major innovator.

title: Witness in Antiquities Case Tells of a Smuggling Plot
description: Every profession has its secrets and in a federal courtroom in Manhattan yesterday, a convicted antiquities smuggler revealed his, including details of how he once sneaked the sculptured head of a 14th-century B.C. pharaoh out of Egypt by disguising it as a cheap tourist gewgaw.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUINNESS, MURTOGH D.
description: GUINNESS-Murtogh D. Died January 30th, 2002 in his home in New York City at age 88. He is survived by his sister Grania, Dowager Marchioness of Normandy, and sixteen nieces and nephews. A collector and longtime benefactor of the arts, he was a former President of the Music Box Society. Funeral services will be held at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, on Monday, February 4th, at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMARTIN, JOHN P. ''JACK''
description: GILMARTIN-John P. ''Jack'', 70. Died at home in Belmar, NJ,. Jan. 29, 2002. He was a member of the NY Stock Exchange and a Sr. Floor Broker, retired from Morgan Keegan in 1999. He worked for 51 years on the floor of the Exchange. Born in Brooklyn and was a member of the JINX Club. Beloved father of Stephen P., John P., Mark D., Janine T. and Rachael E. Gilmartin. Dear brother of Maureen Ferguson. Loving grandfather of Kyrsten, Ryan and Shaye. Funeral Mass Saturday, February 2 at 11 AM, at St. Rose Church, Belmar, NJ. McDonough Funeral Home, 304 Eighth Ave., For information call Belmar ''732-681-1113''.

title: American Express Gets Mayoral Seal of Approval
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggested yesterday that he never leaves home without it, and engaged in a little product plugging as he addressed a packed chamber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORATH, INGE
description: MORATH-Inge. The adventure of Magnum for all of us, photographers, staff, and friends is immeasurably less sparkling today. For fifty years Inge Morath has enlivened our company with her bravery, charm, wit and wisdom. For a generation of us the magic of Paris started at Inge's Place at 8 Rue de la Chaise. She was a person of ineffable elegance-personal, intellectual and artistic. Hopefully it was contagious. There are no pieties that can possibly describe our sadness. When we meet in Paris next June there will be more than a chair that is empty. We all loved Inge and we are all richer for it.

title: Appearing in the Role of Evil: The Other Side
description: The first act of a major theatrical production opens today in the streets of New York, as thousands gather inside the Waldorf-Astoria for an exclusive event called the World Economic Forum, and thousands more muster outside for protest. Advanced billing for the spectacle, which has a limited engagement of five days, promises stimulating and perhaps even violent confrontation between good and evil.

title: UNILEVER TO SELL RETAIL DRY CLEANING BUSINESS TO ZOOTS
description: Unilever said yesterday that it would sell its retail dry cleaning business to Zoots, a laundry chain based in New England. Under the deal, Unilever will get a minority stake in Zoots and its chief financial officer and chief operating officer will sit on the dry cleaner's board. For Unilever, maker of detergents like Wisk and All, the agreement is a compromise between two competing priorities. The company has been cutting back on all but its biggest brands. But as consumers spend more on laundry services outside the home, it also wants to maintain a foothold in the dry cleaning business. Zoots has $40 million in annual sales. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEVILLY, WILLIAM
description: McEVILLY-William. Of New Rochelle, NY died on January 29, 2002 at home. He worked as a producer for WOR-Radio ''Rambling with Gambling'' in NYC for 43 years before retiring in 1992. He was a member of Wykagyl C.C. in New Rochelle and served in the Army from 1945-47. He is survived by his sister, Jane Marie Mahoney of Utica, NY. He was predeceased by his wife, Joan, and his brother, John. Friends may send memorial donations in his memory to the Perry Fund C/O Highwatch Farm, P.O. Box 607, Kent, CT. 06757.

title: 9/11 in Firefighters' Words: Surreal Chaos and Hazy Heroics
description: The New York City firefighters who escaped when two of the world's largest buildings collapsed around them on Sept. 11 soon found themselves facing both a surreal landscape and an unimaginable task.

title: Economic Scene; Globalism and the liberal model: Playing the invisible hand that's dealt us.
description: AS business and political celebrities gather this week for the World Economic Forum, their mood is somber compared with the triumphalism of the 1990's. Not only have the organizers moved the meetings from Davos, Switzerland, to post-Sept. 11 Manhattan, but these international movers and shakers can expect to be confronted by protesters determined to stop global economic integration. The confidence of ''Davos man'' in the irresistible march of globalization -- and his belief in his own righteousness and cultural cool -- has been shaken.

title: Lindros Plans on Olympics
description: Eric Lindros was able to walk without a limp but sat out the game with a sprained right knee as the Rangers played the Islanders at Madison Square Garden last night. Although Lindros, a center, is also out of the National Hockey League All-Star Game on Saturday in Los Angeles, he said he would play in the Winter Games in Salt Lake City.

title: Around the World, Many Views Of the Enron Scandal's Meaning
description: The world is watching the unfolding of the Enron ( news/quote ) bankruptcy and its aftershocks through local lenses of sometimes surprising hues.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Damages 2 Buildings
description: A four-alarm fire caused by a fallen candle displaced several families and damaged two Upper Manhattan apartment buildings early yesterday morning, a Fire Department official said. Four firefighters suffered minor injuries, and a resident with chest pains was taken to the hospital. Heat from the fire, which started about 3 a.m., roused Efrain Pizarro, 35, an off-duty firefighter who lives on the second floor of one of the buildings, at 117 East 101st Street. Mr. Pizarro ''went around the building and got everyone out,'' said Firefighter Louis Giaconelli, a department spokesman. The fire took about an hour to control and was ruled accidental. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: * VF Corp., Greensboro, N.C., to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network, to handle its account for lingerie brands, including Bestform, Lily of France, Vanity Fair and Vassarette. The assignment, with billings estimated at $5 million, had been handled by agencies including D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, part of the Bcom3 Group; there will be advertising, promotions and other marketing efforts.

title: Blazing a Trail Before a Single Tree Falls
description: IN the early days of alpine skiing, trail design consisted of an expert skier's hiking to the top of a mountain, then tramping through the woods flagging trees to be chopped down by hand. The end result was haphazard at best and often had more to do with expediency than aesthetics.

title: Corrections

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: New Airline Foresees Cost Savings
description: Japan Airlines and Japan Air System will save 53 billion yen ($400 million) after their full merger in the fiscal year that begins in April 2005. The companies will eliminate 3,000 jobs, or about 6 percent of their combined work force. The two carriers also plan to save money by combining operations and computer systems and more effectively using aircraft. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's annual address yesterday on the state of the city, as recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript is available on the Web: nytimes.com/nyregion.

title: COMPUTER PART MAKER TO CUT 1,250 JOBS AFTER LOSS
description: The Read-Rite Corporation, a maker of computer disk-drive parts, said yesterday that it would lay off 1,250 workers in the United States and Thailand, an 11 percent reduction, after a posting a quarterly loss. The company will have about 10,000 workers after the reduction, a spokesman said. Read-Rite said it had a loss of $4.49 million, or 4 cents a share, in the period ended Dec. 31, the first quarter of its fiscal year. That was in contrast to profit of $12.5 million, or 11 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales fell 28 percent, to $136.9 million from $190 million. The company expects fiscal second-quarter sales of $65 million to $85 million and a loss of 25 cents to 35 cents a share.

title: As Bush's Stature Rises . . .
description: It will take a lot more than Dick Gephardt's tepid address on Tuesday night to interfere with the bond that is developing between President Bush and the American people.

title: Epson Printer Needs No Wires To Listen to the Laptop
description: The freedom that laptop users enjoy when their computers are connected to wireless networks can end when it is time to print. Unless a second computer is on the network acting as print server, they are forced to plug in.

title: Philip Morris Names Next Chief
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it had named its chief financial officer, Louis C. Camilleri, to succeed Geoffrey C. Bible as chief executive. The company also reported that its fourth-quarter profit rose 7.6 percent.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: A Health Campaign -- And More?
description: President Vladimir V. Putin ordered a national campaign to promote sports and healthy life styles, saying the state of Russian health damages the economy. The government estimates that only 1 in 10 Russians plays a sport and says the number of sports institutions has fallen by a fifth since 1991. Skeptics suggested that Mr. Putin's new campaign was actually a plan to assume state control of TV-6, an independent network liquidated by court order earlier this month, because Russia's deputy prime minister for social affairs immediately said the government should establish a national sports channel on the old TV-6 frequency. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Complex Deal Is First Step To Create New National Park
description: The Nature Conservancy announced the signing today of a $31 million purchase agreement for a 151-square-mile ranch in Colorado, a complex deal that is the first step toward creating a new national park with the adjacent Great Sand Dunes National Monument and Preserve, in the San Luis Valley.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: 18 Intel Science Finalists
description: Eighteen high school students from the region, including 15 from New York State, were among the 40 finalists named yesterday in the Intel Science Talent Search. Begun in 1941 and formerly known as the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the contest is the nation's most prestigious high-school science contest and is closely followed by students interested in applying to elite universities. In New York City, Bronx High School of Science produced two finalists, Suhan Li and Raminder Kaur Parihar, above, as did Stuyvesant High School, while Manhasset High School on Long Island also had two finalists. New Jersey had two finalists and Connecticut one. Each finalist will receive a computer and at least $5,000 in scholarship money; the winner gets $100,000. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: Reporting Live, From Almost Anywhere
description: AFTER watching young boys on military maneuvers at a training camp in northern Afghanistan, said Elizabeth Palmer, a CBS News correspondent, she was inspired to use the scene as a backdrop for a live report. Her goal was to show not only how the anti-Taliban forces of the Northern Alliance were gearing up for an assault but also how most boys' lives there were forged for war.

title: Case Closed: A Sound Card Plugs In From the Outside
description: For many PC users, there are two kinds of add-on devices: those that they plug into the back of the computer, which is easy to do, and those that require opening up the case, which for many people is never going to happen.

title: Integrity and the State of the Union
description: The United States is in the middle of two undeclared wars. George W. Bush addressed one of them with considerable eloquence on Tuesday night. His pride in his new role was clear. So were several important omissions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAPKIN, ARNOLD, M.D.
description: DRAPKIN-Arnold, M.D. To the most caring doctor, we miss you so much. My son grew up with you from teenage problems to young adulthood. You are like the great uncle we never had. Natasha and Alexis Hubshman

description: Larry A. Silverstein's Fifth Avenue boardroom is awash in the developer's hopes, dreams and architectural drawings for rebuilding the World Trade Center.

title: U2 on a Mission
description: The rock group U2 will perform at halftime of the Super Bowl, and at a news conference today, the band jumped right into the biggest football topic of the week.

title: Cleaning Up Massachusetts Politics
description: Massachusetts is the cradle of American democracy, but it has been years since most races for state elected office there involved more than one candidate. Hefty campaign war chests keep the Statehouse a secure preserve of unopposed Democrats. Little wonder that the Legislature has repeatedly thwarted a voter initiative for public financing of state races. Fortunately, the state's highest court has stepped in, and a welcome change in state politics -- that could help spur reform nationwide -- may be near.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Construction Merger
description: Mitsui Construction and Sumitomo Construction said they had agreed to merge in one to two years in a push to cut costs and cope with shrinking demand. The companies will cut a combined 500 jobs, or 9.7 percent of their work forces, before joining operations, they said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, GERALD
description: WEINBERG-Gerald. Born February 16, 1930. Died January 29, 2002. A graduate of Brooklyn College and the New York University School of Law, Class of 1954. For over 45 years a practicing attorney in New York City and Albany. Mr. Weinberg made his permanent home in East Chatham, New York in 1966. Shortly thereafter, he founded Gerald Weinberg, P.C. & Canaan Corporate Records, a widely known Albany firm specializing in corporate services for attorneys. During the 1970's and 80's, Mr. Weinberg was actively involved in harness horse racing and breeding. He owned the Canaan Horse Farm in Guilderland, New York. He is survived by his wife, Anne, and by his beloved pug, Mavis. Services 2PM Thursday, January 31 at Congregation Beth Emeth, Albany, New York. For information call the Levine Memorial Chapel, Albany, NY at 800-427-0280.

title: For Mail, a Palm That Gets It

Ever since the inventors of the Pilot, PalmPilot, Palm V and Palm VII departed to found Handspring in 1998, Palm has done little more than tweak its existing designs, adding a little more memory here, a card slot there. When it comes to innovation, Palm has done more poking at the envelope than pushing it.

title: More Funds For Arts Groups
description: The Andrew Mellon Foundation announced yesterday a second round of grants to arts institutions in New York affected by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. Twenty-nine museums and related organizations will receive awards totaling $6.6 million. The groups range from small to midsize and include the American Craft Museum, the Fraunces Tavern Museum, the Drawing Center and El Museo del Barrio.

title: YANKEES HOPE TO COMPLETE POSADA AGREEMENT
description: The Yankees are hopeful of reaching at least a one-year agreement with catcher Jorge Posada soon, which would enable them to postpone a salary arbitration hearing scheduled for next Wednesday. Posada has asked for $7.75 million and the Yankees offered $6.7 million in arbitration. If the sides split the difference and agree on a one-year contract for $7.225 million, they will continue trying to complete a multiyear deal worth about $10 million a year. The Yankees are willing to give Posada, 30, $51 million for five years; he is seeking $55 million. Jack Curry

title: Donnelley Reports a Loss
description: The R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, a leading printing company, said today that it had a fourth-quarter loss as its financial publishing and advertising inserts businesses declined in the recession. The loss was $37.7 million, or 33 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $71.6 million, or 58 cents, a year earlier, the company said.

description: The Calcutta police arrested a man and accused him of providing logistical support to the men who sprayed bullets at police guards outside the American Center on Jan. 22, killing 4 officers and wounding 19 people. Jamaluddin Nasir admitted having picked up two of the attackers at a railway station and arranging for their stay at a local house, said the city police commissioner, Sujoy Chakraborty. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOHALEM, LILLIAN
description: YOHALEM-Lillian. Age 89. Died on Wednesday, January 30, 2002 at home in Chappaqua, NY. She was the beloved wife of Aaron; adored mother of Deborah and Frank Wadsworth, Nan and Allen Banks, Jane and Daniel Yohalem; grandmother of fourteen and great grandmother of eight. Born in Mt. Vernon, NY to Sarah and Samuel Cohn, she was a graduate of the public schools and of New York University. Over her lifetime, she had a passionate love affair with Havassah, UJA/Federation and the New York Association for New Americans. She worked tirelessly for these organizations serving as the Chair of UJA's Leadership Council, member of the New York Cabinet and as a founder and leader of the Women's Campaign of Westchester County. She also served on the Board of Directors of NYANA and filled numerous leadership roles in her nineteen years with the organization. In recognition of her years of devoted efforts, UJA/Federation presented her with an award for helping to advance the quality of life for Jews in Israel, around the world and in New York. She was much loved by her family, and inspiration and source of strength to all who knew her. In lieu of flowers contributions should be made to UJA. Funeral services will be held Friday, February 1, at 11:15AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Board of Education is intrinsically incapable of meeting the educational needs of our children. It must go.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Cuts Some Chip Sales
description: Hynix Semiconductor said it had stopped selling its memory chips on the spot market because it expected faster price increases if fewer chips were sold. For at least the first quarter of this year, the company said it had decided ''to apportion memory products to its strategic and contractual customers.'' Don Kirk (NYT)

title: The Limits of Power
description: The application of power and intimidation has returned to the forefront of American foreign policy. That was the unmistakable message delivered by President Bush in his State of the Union address when he labeled Iran, Iraq and North Korea an ''axis of evil'' that he would not permit to threaten the United States with chemical, biological and nuclear weapons. Not since America's humiliating withdrawal from Vietnam more than a quarter-century ago has our foreign policy relied so heavily on non-nuclear military force, or the threat of it, to defend American interests around the world.

title: When Acting Speaks Volumes
description: A spoken book. There can be tremendous pleasure in hearing a book, if the voice of the narrator is right. Those authors who don't narrate their own books have in a sense ceded to an actor the direct connection to the listener-reader that is part of the power of authorship, in much the same way a playwright does. But if the whisper or the rumble resonating from an audiobook has the right complexity of tones, it can be as satisfying as theater.

title: Mixing Romance With Responsibility
description: It's not the most sophisticated piece of theater around, but ''What's on the Hearts of Men,'' a traveling show making a brief stop at the Beacon Theater through Sunday, covers a lot of sins with some great humor and powerful singing voices.

title: 'To Fight Freedom's Fight'
description: When a dramatist places a gun on the table in the first act, the astute playgoer knows that the weapon will be used before the drama ends.

title: Floating in France
description: Six barge trips through Provence or Burgundy next month are being sold by eWaterways in a package that includes round-trip air fare to Paris from many United States cities and two nights in a three-star hotel in Paris. Departures on March 22 or 29 feature the 50-passenger Chardonnay, which will make a seven-day trip on the Rhone to Avignon, Arles and the medieval walled city of Aigues-Morte. The price is $2,199 a person, double occupancy. Trips departing on March 8, 15, 22 and 29 use the 22-passenger eWaterways, which follows canals in Burgundy, with stops in Dijon, the Clos de Vougeot vineyards and Chateauneuf. The price is $1,999 a person, double occupancy. Both itineraries include transfers to the barges. Information: (800) 676-6613 or at www.ewaterways.com .

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: I.N.S. To Allow Legal Aid
description: Reversing itself, the Immigration and Naturalization Service will permit civil-liberties lawyers to advise hundreds of foreign nationals held since the Sept. 11 attacks. The decision, issued Jan. 11 but not received by the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey until Jan. 24, followed two lawsuits accusing the government of illegally withholding the names of detainees and the charges against them. The decision will allow members of the A.C.L.U. to determine whether detainees require legal assistance. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: MANPOWER SAYS IT WILL MISS FIRST-QUARTER ESTIMATES
description: Manpower, a provider of temporary labor, will miss analysts' forecasts for its first-quarter earnings as the weakened economy has slowed demand. Profit will be 6 cents to 10 cents a share on revenue that will lag year-earlier levels, the chief executive, Jeffrey A. Joerres, said during a conference call. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected the company to earn 15 cents a share. The company, based in Milwaukee, made the forecast while reporting fourth-quarter results. Manpower earned $26 million, or 34 cents a share, down from $53.5 million, or 70 cents, a year earlier. Sales declined 9.5 percent to $2.82 billion from $3.12 billion.

title: Rich and Powerful Gathering At Elite Forum on Economy
description: In keeping with the times, the way to the site of the grand annual retreat of the world's movers and shakers was a maze of police barriers, concrete barricades, flashing lights and blue uniforms yesterday. But once inside the Waldorf-Astoria, it was more like the start of summer camp.

description: A CELLPHONE is more than a few chips and a battery. Those things do lurk under the keypad, but most of a phone's insides are taken up by filters, duplexers and resonators -- passive components that sort radio frequencies so that you get your calls and not someone else's.

description: Enrique Perusquia, a former broker at Lehman Brothers Holdings and PaineWebber, was charged today with defrauding a Mexican client of $68 million by investing his money in gold mining companies from which he was receiving kickbacks.

description: Using cells from cloned cow embryos, scientists at a biotechnology company embroiled in the stem cell debate say they have grown small kidney-like organs that perform some of the functions of real kidneys.

title: Bobsledder's Father Faces Sex Charge
description: The father of Jean Racine, the top American women's bobsled driver, has been charged with second-degree criminal sexual conduct and child abusive commercial activity. The Oakland Press reported yesterday that the charges filed against David William Racine, 51, stem from an alleged incident in August involving a 13-year-old girl who was visiting his youngest daughter at their home in Waterford Township, Mich.

Bloomberg, terms inhumane and wants her to humanely eliminate, pronto.

description: THOSE unfamiliar with Harlem and its architecture may think of its streets as a maze of magnificent brownstones, interspersed with boarded-up storefronts, tenements and down-home restaurants.

description: What's a man of means to do when he no longer trusts the air around him? He buys a thousand-plus-dollar coat, of course, enhanced with a detachable microcomputer that tells him just how contaminated his surroundings may be.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Sentences In Dormitory Fire
description: A court sentenced the principal of a boarding school and his deputy to eight months in prison for failing to prevent a dormitory fire last March that killed 67 students. One of the two doors to the dormitory at Kyanguili Secondary School, 30 miles east of Nairobi, was locked. Two teenagers accused of setting the blaze are facing a separate trial on murder charges. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Contract For Touch-Screen Voting
description: Miami-Dade County commissioners approved a $24.5 million contract to replace a punch-card voting system with touch-screen voting equipment. All 7,200 of the new laptop-size machines are expected to be in place before the county's Sept. 10 elections. They will make it impossible to mark ballots for more than one candidate in each race and will alert voters if they fail to pick a candidate in a race. Florida law requires counties to use either touch-screen or optical scanning machines in future statewide elections because of difficulties with punch-card ballots in the 2000 presidential election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCELWAIN, JACK WHITE, M.D.
description: McELWAIN-Jack White, M.D. Of Huntington, formerly of Muttontown, N.Y., on January 30, 2002 in his 80th year. Beloved husband of Ruth (Kelly). Dearly loved father of Valerie Flynn and Donna McElwain Helder. Cherished grandfather of Jay Flynn. Devoted brother of Dorothy Will and loving uncle of Richard and Eric Will of Syracuse, N.Y. Jack will be forever fondly remembered in the hearts of his family and the countless friends who knew him. A graduate of Syracuse Medical School, a respected and dedicated physician, Jack was an Associate Clinical Professor at SUNY, Stony Brook Medical School. As Head of the Department of Colon and Rectal Surgery at Nassau County Medical Center for 35 years, he founded a training program for general surgeons in colon and rectal surgery. Jack's professional affiliations included past Vice President of the American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons, President of the Nassau County Medical Society, the Nassau County Surgical Society, the New York Society of Colon & Rectal Surgeons, the Pennsylvania Society of Colon & Rectal Surgeons, and founder and first president of the Northeast Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons. He was active in the Nassau County Cerebral Palsy Association for 40 years. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc. of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Road. Visiting on Friday 2-5 and 7-10PM. Private cremation with interment to follow at a later date in Syracuse, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Society for Colon & Rectal Surgeons Research Society, 85 W. Algonquin Ave., Suite 550, Arlington Heights, IL 60005 Att: Stella Seclalis.

title: I.M.F. Backs Official Shift To U.S. Dollar By Afghans
description: With its economy and monetary system in tatters, Afghanistan is weighing a plan to adopt the United States dollar as legal tender until it introduces a new currency.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Oil Profit Falls
description: Squeezed by falling crude oil prices, the European oil company TotalFinaElf said that fourth-quarter operating income dropped 28 percent, to 1.37 billion euros ($1.18 billion), on a 24 percent decline in revenue, to 23.6 billion euros. Net income fell 41 percent to 630 million euros. For all of last year, Total said operating income fell 6 percent, to 7.57 billion euros, on an 8 percent revenue increase, to 105.2 billion euros. But Total's net income for the year rose 11 percent, to 7.6 billion euros, thanks largely to the sale of assets worth 6.2 billion euros, including shares in the Sanofi-Synthelabo drug company and the French utility Cogema. Total predicted that 2002 would be a better year, but that the company would continue to shed noncore assets to maintain investment levels and growth.

title: Conducting Diplomacy With Flair And a Cape
description: When Tom Ford, the creative director of Gucci, recently called Hamid Karzai ''the chic-est man on the planet today,'' he was merely making note publicly of something many people were thinking, that something fascinating was going on with Mr. Karzai's clothes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, ANDREW Y.
description: ROGERS-Andrew Y. Age 90, died on Sunday, January 27, 2002, in Scarborough, ME. He was born in Madison, NJ on January 28, 1911. Educated at Phillips Academy, Yale, and the Yale Law/Harvard Business School program, he was a partner for more than 60 years at the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell. During World War II, he served as a navy intelligence officer in the Aleutian Islands. He served on the Ethics Committee of the Bar Overseers of the City of NY, as chairman of the NYC Parks Association/Council, as an elder of the Brick Presbyterian Church of NYC, as a corporator of the Maine Medical Center, and on the boards of the International Grenfell Association; American Hospital, Istanbul; Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts; the DryDock Savings Bank; and the Wm. Matheus Sullivan Musical Foundation. He was a member of the Prouts Neck Association and the Prouts Neck Country Club, where he served as president. He was also a member of the Union Club in NYC, the Yale Club of NY, the Downtown Association, and the Meadow Brook Club. Active in alumni affairs at both Yale University and its law school, he served as chairman of both the Yale Alumni and the Yale Law School Funds, and was awarded the Yale Medal in 1977. He was married to Polly Porteous from 1937 until her death in 1982, and to Barbara Sizer from 1985 until her death in 1995. He is survived by his identical twin Arthur M. Rogers, M.D., of Charlotte, NC; four children, Polly Larned, of Scarborough, ME; Andrew Y. Rogers, Jr. of Maplewood, NJ; Malcolm P. Rogers, M.D. of Cambridge, MA; and Frances P. Zilkha, of Portland, ME; thirteen grandchildren; and twelve great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at State Street Church, 159 State Street, Portland, ME, Saturday, February 23rd, 11:00 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Boys and Girls Clubs of Greater Portland, 277 Cumberland Avenue, P.O. Box 7830, Portland, ME, 04112.

description: Last week the National Gallery of Ireland unveiled the first collection of French Impressionist works ever seen in this country. The landmark exhibition, on loan from the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, proved wildly popular even before it arrived: tickets for the first two weekends sold out shortly after they went on sale in November.

title: Knicks Winning at Full Strength
description: The Knicks' president, Scott Layden, has been roundly criticized for piecing together a roster that currently sits in 11th place in the so-so Eastern Conference. While much of the disparagement is deserved, in fairness to Layden, it must be stated that the Knicks have had their top nine players for only the past six games. And during that stretch -- aside from the 43-point farce against Charlotte -- the Knicks have played as well as anyone in the East.

title: Connecticut's Trip to Rutgers Turns Out to Be a Lost Cause
description: Jerome Coleman of Rutgers said he was ball-hungry. In a 1-minute-58-second sequence against 17th-ranked Connecticut tonight, he was ravenous. Coleman, a junior guard, scored 7 of his 26 points in that span late in the second half, willing Rutgers to a 61-53 upset of the Huskies in a Big East game at the Louis Brown Athletic Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ROBERT P.
description: FISHER-Robert P. Of Scarsdale, NY and New Suffolk, NY died peacefully on January 22 at the age of 78 due to leukemia. He was for many years the President of George F. Fisher Inc, a silk yarn company, and was the President of two leading silk trade groups the American Silk Council and the International Silk Association (US). Born in Brooklyn, NY, he was educated at Dartmouth College, MIT and the Amos Tuck Business School. Active in alumni affairs at Dartmouth and its business school, he served as Chairman of the Tuck Annual Giving Campaign. During World War II he served as a First Lieutenant in the Army Air Corps in the Atlantic and Pacific theatres. In Scarsdale he was a member of the Town and Village Civic Club, the Rotary Club, the Scarsdale Historical Society and was a deacon and elder of the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church. In New Suffolk, he was a member of the New Suffolk Civic Association, the Cutchogue-New Suffolk and Southold Historical Societies, the North Fork Country Club and served as the West Creek Baykeeper. A dedicated lifelong sailor, he served on the Race Committees at the Larchmont Yacht Club, the Old Cove Yacht Club, the Storm Trysail Club and was a member of the New York Yacht Club. As a teenager, he and his brother unsuccessfully tried to teach Albert Einstein how to sail. He is survived by his wife of 48 years Greta, children Rip of Scarsdale, NY, Melinda Fisher Callaway of La Jolla, CA, James of Brookfield, CT and Susan Fisher Nannig of Kingstown, RI, seven grandchildren and his brother John of New Suffolk, NY. Donations may be made to the Memorial Fund-Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, 6 Greenacres Ave., Scarsdale, NY 10583 or the charity of donor's choice.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Glum Electronics Forecast
description: Japan's electronics manufacturers expect only a mild recovery in domestic production this year after a record decline of 15.3 percent in 2001. The Japan Electronics and Information Technology Industries Association expects output of consumer and industrial electronics to grow just 0.7 percent this year, with a recovery not taking hold until the second half of 2002. While demand for personal computers, televisions and audio equipment is expected to remain weak, output of digital cameras and car navigation systems is expected to grow. The group also expects strong demand for digital satellite broadcasting equipment during the World Cup soccer games in June.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Lawyers And Undercover Work
description: The State Supreme Court ratified an amendment of the state bar's ethics code that says lawyers can supervise, but not participate in, undercover investigations that would force them to lie. The decision puts to rest a legal debate that began with another ruling last year in the case of Daniel Gatti, a lawyer who impersonated a doctor as part of an investigation. In that ruling, justices wrote that lawyers should not lie or encourage others to lie; prosecutors interpreted the opinion as preventing them from supervising any undercover work and sought the amendment. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Candidate Drops Out Of Race
description: Secretary of State William F. Galvin, left, said he would drop his campaign for governor and run for re-election this year. Mr. Galvin said the crowded field hurt his chances. Five Democrats remain in the race to challenge Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift, a Republican. They are Thomas Birmingham, the Senate president; Steve Grossman, the former head of the National Democratic Committee; State Treasurer Shannon O'Brien; former Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich; and former State Senator Warren Tolman.

title: How to Flee The Forum And Really See the City
description: So here you are, a delegate to the World Economic Forum. You're rich. Or famous. Or serious. Or all of the above. And of course you're really here because of your abiding commitment to participating in a dialogue about new priorities in economic policy (and because you long to see your old pal Bill Gates again).

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Report: Technology Mergers Don't Work
description: Walter B. Hewlett took another step yesterday in his assault on Hewlett-Packard's planned purchase of Compaq Computer with a report intended to prove that big mergers in the computer business are destined to fail. The 25-page report, prepared by Mr. Hewlett's investment adviser, Friedman, Fleisher & Lowe, and filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, reviews mergers in the computer industry over the last two decades. A leading example is Compaq's purchase of the Digital Equipment Corporation in 1998, in which management's optimistic predictions were followed by falling profit and share value for the next three years. Compaq executives have said recently that the company would have been even worse off without the Digital merger. Mr. Hewlett, a Hewlett-Packard director, said the report ''clearly illustrates the extreme risk involved in the proposed H.P.-Compaq merger.'' Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: West Wayne Promotes President
description: West Wayne in Atlanta said yesterday that it had named Jeffrey L. Johnson, president for the last two years, to the added post of chief executive. He succeeds Ben West, 50, who continues as chairman.

title: Chief Executive Mayor
description: In this season of earnings reports on Wall Street, the businessman-turned-mayor Michael Bloomberg delivered a cautiously bullish annual report on New York City's current health and future prospects.

description: IN the halls of academia, researchers are tinkering away on tools they think may one day be useful to television reporters filing from the middle of nowhere.

title: Asylum Seekers Detained in Australia Suspend Hunger Strike
description: Hundreds of asylum seekers at Woomera, Australia's largest immigration detention center, said late Wednesday that they would suspend a 15-day hunger strike while negotiations continued with the government over their detention.

title: Germans Tell Liberty Media Its Cable Deal Is in Jeopardy
description: Competition regulators in Germany will formally warn the Liberty Media Corporation today that they will block its $5 billion deal to buy Deutsche Telekom's cable television systems if Liberty does not significantly change its business plan, according to executives who have seen the written warning already sent to the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIB, ROBERT
description: LEIB-Robert. Beloved father of Jeffrey and Patricia Leib, Gregory and Diane Leib, and Andrea and Kenneth Gold. Loving grandfather of Michael, Sharon, Ginger, Steven, Larry and Jessica. Services Friday, February 1, 2002, 12:45PM at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; AT&T and AOL are very different and yet very much alike.
description: FROM the personality of their executives to the source of their power, AT&T and AOL Time Warner are very different sorts of companies. Yet as both titans reported quarterly financial results yesterday, it became clear that there were important similarities in the challenges they face and even in their responses to the obstacles.

title: Maze of Barricades, Police, Detours and Irate Shoppers
description: Whether or not typical New Yorkers care about the debates at the World Economic Forum, the five-day conference at the Waldorf-Astoria, it is likely to shake up their daily routines.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Another Missile Test
description: The Defense Ministry said it had successfully test-fired a naval version of its Trishul missile, which has a range of up to 7.5 miles and carries a small warhead. Unlike the Agni missile, which flew about 435 miles in an Indian test last week, the Trishul is not able to carry a nuclear weapon. It is based on a ship, and its purpose is to shoot down missiles fired from enemy ships or submarines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALEM, STEVEN
description: SALEM-Steven. Of New Rochelle, NY, beloved husband of Rose, cherished father of Radiance, David James, & Norel Linda. Devoted son of David and Linda Salem. Brother of Howard & Allan Salem. Partner of Salem & Salem Consulting Inc., Salem & Eng., (Motor Jam Records). Owner of Salem Entertainment, & Ray & D.J. Publishing. Funeral Services Thursday (today) at 11:00 AM, Plaza Jewish Community, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NY, NY. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY

title: Inmate's Transplant Prompts Questions of Costs and Ethics
description: In a sign of the kind of expenses many states may soon face, a California state prison inmate has received a heart transplant that is likely to cost taxpayers here close to $1 million.

title: Cram Sessions: The Evolution of an Ever Deeper Disc
description: LIKE almost everything in the electronics industry, compact disc technology started to show its age pretty quickly. A decade after the first CD's appeared in the early 1980's, their 640 megabytes of storage capacity had begun to look paltry, particularly when it came to the holy grail of in-home entertainment: accommodating a high-quality feature-length film on one disc.

title: METLIFE TO BUY $125 MILLION OF REINSURANCE SHARES
description: MetLife said yesterday that it planned to buy a $125 million stake, or 11 percent, of the Reinsurance Group of America's common stock. The planned purchases will permit MetLife to maintain its 58 percent ownership of Reinsurance Group of America if certain trust products offered by the reinsurer are converted into shares, a spokeswoman said. Reinsurance Group posted a fourth-quarter net loss of $28.1 million, or 57 cents a share. Stewart Nagler, the MetLife chief financial officer, was recently named chairman of the Reinsurance Group of America, and will continue his duties at MetLife.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEGAN, FRANCES C.
description: KEEGAN-Frances C. On January 30, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Joseph T. Keegan. Devoted mother of Michael (Joan), Joseph (Eileen), and Gerard (Mary Jane). Cherished grandmother of Kathleen, Tricia, Gerard Jr, Christine, Bridget, Karen, Elizabeth and great-grandmother of Wil, Tim and Abby. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, on Friday 10 AM.

title: Valentin in Utility Role (for Now)
description: The Mets made an intriguing addition yesterday as they signed the free-agent infielder John Valentin to a minor league contract and invited him to compete for a roster position this spring. Valentin is a former third baseman for the Boston Red Sox, but he has also played shortstop and second base. All three positions are filled by capable players, so how Valentin fits with the Mets could prove to be interesting.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Walt Clarke, management supervisor at the health care division at Rockett Burkhead & Winslow, Raleigh, N.C., was promoted to vice president and director for the division.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Bank Names Executives
description: Deutsche Bank named a former Merrill Lynch executive, Michael Philipp, and Jrgen Fitschen, who has been with the bank for 15 years, to help oversee the company as Josef Ackermann, left, takes control. Mr. Philipp, a 48-year-old American who joined Deutsche Bank in 1995, will be part of a group that runs the consumer banking and fund management unit, the bank said. Mr. Fitschen, 53, will be involved in overseeing the investment bank. Mr. Ackermann, 53, is scheduled to replace Rolf Breuer, who is retiring, as chief executive in May.

title: World Briefing | World: Wet Forecast For Northern Europe
description: A new analysis of warming global temperatures and the relationship to rainfall foresees a fivefold rise in the risk of destructive winter rains in parts of Europe in this century and of summer floods in southern Asia. Combining the output of 19 different computer models, British and Swedish scientists showed that Britain and a swath of northern Europe from Germany through Finland and Russia were most likely to see extremely wet winters. The watersheds feeding the Brahmaputra and other nearby rivers that contribute to floods in Bangladesh were the likeliest to see extreme summer rains, according to the study, which was published in the journal Nature.

title: Budget Cuts by Bush Include Job Training
description: Even though unemployment has increased sharply in recent months, President Bush's budget will seek cuts in several job-training programs for laid-off workers and young adults most affected by the rise in unemployment, according to budget documents and federal officials.

title: Black Musician, Beaten by Spanish Police, to Miss Concert
description: In a case that has raised concerns over racial profiling in Spain, the principal trumpet player for the Barcelona Symphony Orchestra was beaten so badly by police in Barcelona two weeks ago that he will be unable to appear with the ensemble in its performance at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night.

title: Many in Europe Voice Worry U.S. Will Not Consult Them
description: The three countries pinpointed by President Bush as an ''axis of evil'' -- Iran, Iraq and North Korea -- reacted angrily today while commentators in many other nations, including European allies, bristled at what they saw as the combative, go-it-alone tone of the State of the Union address.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Monroe: 3 Students Sickened
description: Three teenage boys were hospitalized yesterday morning after officials said they drank a clear liquid, drove to school, vomited and then lost consciousness in class. Notices were immediately sent to the district's 5,100 students to quell a rumor that an environmental hazard had hospitalized scores of students. The teenagers, students at Williamstown High School in Monroe Township, were taken to nearby hospitals. They are 18, 17 and 15, and their names were not released. John Hagerty, a State Police spokesman, said it would take about a week to analyze the liquid. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
