title: Sports of The Times; Regional Rivalry Gets Ugly at Garden
description: FOUR quick Islander goals last night touched off a display of Islander orange in the stands -- and some red blood on the ice. The Rangers retaliated in the old goonish hockey tradition, with cynical and predictable fights.

title: Brady Will Start for Patriots
description: New England Coach Bill Belichick made the same decision tonight that he made in November. After watching practice and reviewing the film, Belichick again chose Tom Brady over Drew Bledsoe.

title: Green Berets Take Humbling Victory Lap in New York
description: Somewhere between sitting near Laura Bush for the State of the Union address, doing a live interview the next morning with CBS and ringing the closing bell of the New York Stock Exchange, Capt. Jason Amerine of the Army's Fifth Special Forces Group apologized if anyone had the impression that he was not 100 percent. He had had only an hour of sleep.

title: Why Are Globalizers So Provincial?
description: As the world's corporate and political leaders gather in the 32nd World Economic Forum, globalization has never been greater. Business between countries was briefly paralyzed right after Sept. 11, but today's volume of international trade and investment is huge by historical standards.

title: Lusaka Journal; Look at Him Now: Kisses, Cheers and a Serenade
description: The dragonflies were darting, the roosters were crowing, the wrinkled trousers were wilting on the clothesline.

title: Japan Premier Taking Heat Over Firing Of Minister
description: Japan's reformist prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, whose power derives primarily from high approval ratings in opinion polls, faced a potential crisis today as criticism piled up over his firing of his popular foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka.

title: Bishop John McGann, 77, Dies on Long Island
description: Bishop John R. McGann, who led the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, N.Y., for more than 20 years, died yesterday in Rockville Centre. He was 77.

title: Where to Put A TV So Big That It's On When It's Off
description: THESE days a television can never be too big or too thin. But buying one of those skinny flat-screen sets is the easy part; finding a place for it is another.

title: South Korea and Japan Begin to Sweat After Bush Turns Up the Heat on North Korea
description: In Japan and South Korea, two countries within missile range of North Korea, people reacted nervously today after President Bush singled out North Korea as a new focus for America's war on terror.

title: Rams' Defense Learns the 2 R's: Rest and Rotate
description: In football culture, asking out of a game is akin to surrendering. If you are exhausted, you are supposed to gut it out, an instinct honed through the years by the shouted demands and angry stares of coaches. Dig deeper. Fight through the weariness.

title: Head of F.B.I. Office in New York Says He Will Retire March 1
description: Barry W. Mawn, the assistant director in charge of the F.B.I.'s New York office, yesterday told the 1,100 agents who work for him that he would retire March 1, after 30 years in the bureau, officials said.

description: Horse Sense

title: Joshua L. Miner, 81, Founder Of American Outward Bound
description: Joshua L. Miner, a former boarding school dean who introduced the rugged learning experiences of Outward Bound to the United States, died Tuesday at his home in Andover, Mass. He was 81.

title: Dust-Up In the Desert
description: At the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture, learning by doing is taken to extremes. After drafting until the wee hours, students are expected for breakfast at 6:30 -- except those doing the cooking for an extended family of 40, including faculty members and guests, who might just as well stay up all night. Eric Lloyd Wright, the master's grandson, who studied at the school 50 years ago but is not above channeling his grandfather when asked, said Wright believed that ''to learn how to design a kitchen, you have to work in a kitchen.''

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Corruption Seen As Threat To Nation
description: Senior officials in the governing party have assailed corruption as ''a threat to the country's survival.'' A prominent journalist and a senior banking official who were investigating corruption in recently privatized banks were assassinated by people who were hoping to stop their investigations, officials say. The party, known by its acronym, Frelimo, called on its members to fight corruption ''with energy and determination.''

title: Council Leader Says Euro Is Just a Start
description: European Union countries must seize the ''great opportunities'' for economic growth and put structural changes in place if they want to compete with the United States, said Rodrigo Rato, Spain's economics minister and the new chairman of the European Union's council of finance ministers.

title: When $450,000 Will Buy Just a Starter Home
description: The little house stood behind another, one with a rusty pickup truck in the driveway and a weedy side lot. It had a deck with a view of the garage, two bedrooms counting the attic, wall-to-wall carpet tiles and an iron spiral staircase that only the very young or limber could master.

title: FED HOLDS STEADY ON INTEREST RATES AS ECONOMY FIRMS
description: Against the backdrop of an economy that is displaying remarkable resilience, the Federal Reserve brought its yearlong campaign of interest rate cuts to an apparent end today, voting to hold rates steady and citing signs of an incipient recovery.

title: New British Hospital Scandal: Dead Baby Put in Hamper
description: Britain's accident-prone National Health Service suffered a fresh public humiliation today when a hospital in Kent admitted that the body of a premature baby boy had been dumped into a laundry basket and then sent through the wash at an industrial cleaning company.

title: Brown Brothers Harriman Names Managing Director
description: Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, the nation's oldest and largest private bank, has named Michael W. McConnell managing partner, a position akin to chief executive.

title: Sony Appoints Universal McCann
description: The Sony Corporation of America, part of Sony of Japan, said yesterday that it had selected Universal McCann in New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group, to handle its consolidated media planning and buying account.

title: In London, Microflat Is Packing Them In
description: ARCHITECTS at the London firm of Piercy Conner say they have a solution to the shortage of affordable housing for people here who want to buy their first apartments. Borrowing from boating design, where every inch of space counts, the architects have produced the Microflat, a 344-square-foot pod, which despite its name, is large enough for a king-size bed, a sofa, a desk and a table that seats six. Depending on its location in central London, a Microflat is expected to cost from $84,775 to $127,164.

title: Mostly Quiet on Protest Front as Economic Forum Convenes
description: Under cloudy skies and light rainfall, the World Economic Forum began today in New York City, and through the late afternoon the gathering was noticeably absent of violent activity from protesters who had previously sought to disrupt similar events elsewhere.

title: Sept. 11 and the State of the Union
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: 'Dirty War' Extradition Rejected
description: The new government rejected Sweden's request for the extradition of Alfredo Astiz, a death squad leader accused of killing a Swedish teenager at the height of the ''dirty war'' against leftists in the late 1970's. The former Navy officer was arrested in December, when a different government was in power, but was freed after the foreign ministry re-affirmed a ban on handing over Argentines for trial in foreign countries.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Holds Rates Steady; Economy Defies Attacks

title: Chrysler to Increase Vehicle Incentive Offers
description: The Chrysler Group reversed course today and said that it would increase incentive offers to its customers because of a slump in January sales.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Studio Backs Linux
description: DreamWorks SKG announced a three-year partnership with Hewlett-Packard yesterday to buy powerful workstations and server computers for DreamWorks' growing computer animation unit. The companies did not disclose terms of the agreement, other than calling it a ''multimillion-dollar alliance.'' The computers will run GNU Linux, a variant of the Unix operating system that is distributed free and under licensing terms that allow programmers to improve and fine-tune the software. Linux has made steady advances in computer-animation studios. DreamWorks used Linux in making ''Shrek,'' an animated hit last year. Pixar Animation Studios is also converting to workstations that run Linux. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: New Message Threatens Execution of U.S. Reporter and Others Who Stay in Pakistan
description: A new, more menacing e-mail message apparently from the group claiming to have kidnapped a Wall Street Journal reporter in Pakistan was sent to news organizations yesterday threatening to execute the reporter, Daniel Pearl, within 24 hours and to target all American journalists who do not leave Pakistan in the next three days.
